reviews.review: Old versus New. This district in Istanbul really combines old and new. In between the modern buildings one can still find the older apartments and shops and this combination is what makes Sultanahmet so unique and an almost natural way of living.

Beautiful place <3. You will find here everything touristic attractions, museums, parks, shops, restaurants and cafes. If you would like to stay close to heart of Old Istanbul you can find for yourself boutique hotel or hotel, for those who prefer to live in more quite place you easily can reach Sultanahmet by tram. This area needs at least 2 days to explore. I will suggest you to get a museum card as it will save for you time and money (85TL for 5 days), also if you are planning to stay more in Istanbul or you are often guest, please get a transportation card - Istanbulkart (). Warning! Be aware of pick pocketers on tram-, bus- and metro stations! Keep your documents and money close
nice location. its a unique place which u can see even from distance and on a ship.this is the main tourist attraction of the city.try to walk around if its safe in the morning and have drinks near

Touristic yet abit expensive. It contains the most important places to see as a tourist, it is abit amazing to see during the day and night since the lightening of these places is also magnificent...the restaurants there are touristic and some of them take advantage and have higher prices than usual...some restaurants are amazing and are found in gulhane area which is minutes walk from topkapi...beware of some scams that u might face from shops as they know u dont speak nor read their lamguage...the park between aya sofia and blue mosque is very nice to enjoy with charcoal grilled chestnuts and corn on a cob...alot of amazing pictures can also be taken at night...
Crowdy but a good area. Very good area to visit because it has a good market of nice clothing and jwellery products and also we eat nice street foods there.

Majestic place. There are so many things to see and do in this historical area that you may need a good guide to see them all. The most famous monuments to visit are the Topkapi Palace with its Harem and the gardens with the Aya İrini church/museum, the Sultanahmet or Blue Mosque with its fabulous blue tiles from Niceia, magnificent Aya Sofia facing the Blue mosque, the incredible Basilica Cistern and the Milion stone right next to it, the Obelisk, İbrahim Pasha Palace/museum, the German Fountain given to the sultan by the German emperor as a present. Between the Blue mosque and AYa Sofia is a historical Hamam originally built by Sinan, the great architect. The Hippodrome behind the Blue Mosque doesn't exist any more but you can easily see traces of it. There are so many things to see and do, including restaurants with fantastic views like the Seven Hills just across the Four Seasons Hotel which also has a nice and expensive restaurant. There are also street cafes. There are many shops too and also the Arasta, with a collection of good shops and also the Mosaic Museum. The Arasta is behind the Blue Mosque also. If you can find the right guide, you will find another layer of Istanbul under the present city. This is the Byzantine Istanbul which you may find in underground cisterns and also tunnels, rooms which can be reached from some carpet shops.

Fantastic Area. I couldnt imagine Sultanahmet would be such a nice. After visited many place my mind automaticly changed about here. I will right back to see what I miss it. The food is delicious. Atmosphere of the location almost nearby everywhere. Its so easy to get decision where to go.

Bustling and interesting. A lovely district to walk around and explore. It's a thriving, bustling area, with lovely shops to look through and dozens of fresh baklava and Turkish delight stores to taste and buy goods. So much history here, much better than the Taksim area, which is far too modern for an authentic experience. However, beware the charlatans -everywhere - you're less likely to be charged an extortionate amount for your meal in Taksim than in Sultanahmet, which is probably it's only bad point.

Great touristic area. Sultanahmet is brilliant in terms of offering the tourist things to do and see. Great attractions such as the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophia, Topkapki Castle, the Cisterns, the Great Bazar, Mosques, etc. The district is full of quaint little streets with incredible shopping as well as restaurant choices. Transportation is quite easy as two tram lines crosses the main street which connects to metro to Airport or other parts of town.

Really interesting monuments. Definitely worth a visit on a trip to Istanbul as all the chief monuments are here. Just need to steal yourself against all the restaurant 'whippers in', although we were told it is particularly bad this year because of the drop in tourist numbers. Such a shame as it is a beautiful city.
Beautiful city. A beautiful city where you can find the old and the new together and be in love with this place forever
not a must-see at all. Many museums but very touristic. There are other districts in istanbul, with are more authentic. i recommend so plan 1/2 day to walk through.
must visit. the district is loads of fun. the food and dessert options are extraordinary. the vibe is energising and the diverse cultures and tourists make the place fun

Hub of Istanbul. Loved this area
Shopping is great here and much cheaper than Grand Bazaar
So many street cafes coffee shops
The Istanbul. Definitely a place to visit. DO get a museum card; it's really worth the money. You can skip the lines and you get your money back with your third or fourth entrance.
Beautiful area. Our hotel was in this area. Very old cobbled streets with tourist shops and restaurants. Nice for a stroll.

Balik Ekmek - Wow!. First time to Istanbul. Such an amazing city but not possible to see everything in a long weekend. Headed for the floating fish boats serving balik ekmek. Amazing place with a hive of activity. The hustle and bustle of the place is fun to experience. Would certainly love to go back there again.

The place to be if you want to experience the old Istanbul. Definitely bring your camera and a good pair of walking shoes. There is so much to see and experience in a relatively small area, but you will need at least 2-4 days to see most of the sights. Be mindful of major Islamic holidays because it changes some of the experiences. Our last visit was during Eid Al Adha and the last 2 days of this holiday was so crowded that you could easily feel claustrophobic! The spice market was impossible! You didn't dare to stop to look or buy anything! Overall, this area is a wonderful experience with lots to see, many shops and restaurants, sweet shops and street vendors. Public transport is very reliable and cheap. I've been back several times and will still go back in a heartbeat.
Losts of historical buildings. If you love historical places this is the place to take a stroll. Lots of ancient beautiful places and things to see.
History & beauty!. We stayed in this historical district which has a rich history and a colourful present day cultural experience! Many must see sights are within walking distance of each other.

good experience. you can go by tramway to sultanahmet station , you can see blue mosque . hagia sophia church , topkapi museum , gulhane park , basilica cistern in here.
ticket of topkapi museum 40 tl
ticket of hagia sophia 40tl
blue mosque is free
gulhane park is free

Great history!. This is a historical area with rich Turkish history as well as many museums around.
We visited the blue mosque and the underground museum medusa. Cannot imagine how people built the architecture back in thousands years ago! Hopefully it gets protected.
You should visit this place if come to Istanbul!

tourist spot. good area to do sightseeing.lots of mosques and old monuments..
perhaps the only area in istanbul to see for myself.

Gorgeous. I think no one will miss this location especially history lovers, you can spend your day at this place in Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and The Islamic Museum, also the Souvenir shops

Beautiful Mosque!!. The detail in this mosque are breath taking. Its so peaceful even though there is hundreds of people visiting. I would definitely visit this place again. Best traveling experience so far.

Center of the east europe and ottoman empirement.. The person can see many things on same penisula such as Topkapı Palace, St sophia Museum, Blue Mosque, Basilical Cistern and Grand Bazaar. All these options in same part but it is not posibble to see all this location in same day. There also options for shopping, walking and to take pictures on history.

*****. The Hippodrome of Constantinople was a circus that was the sporting and social centre of Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire. Today it is a square named in turkish Sultanahmet Meydanı (Sultan Ahmet Square) in the Turkish city of Istanbul.You can see the DIKILITAŞ (Obeliks from hippodrome of Constantinople.....Like walking sistance from Hagia SOFIA and Topkapi Palace.....In 1 day time you can see lots of historical places in one shot.....

A delight to walk around. Walking around the cobbled streets of Sultanahmet is one of the highlights of one's visit to Istanbul. The area is packed with Ottoman-era mosques, architecture, parks, tombs and palaces. Possibly the most touristy area in Istanbul, it still retains remnants of its old character in its back alleys but you'll have to search for these. You might be hassled (in a friendly manner) by carpet salesmen or waiters trying to convince you they sell the best Iskender kebab in Istanbul, but its all part of the fun. Walking around the area in the late evenings as the shops close down is especially atmospheric. The abandoned dark alleyways and dim streetlights provide a glimpse into what old Istanbul might have felt like.

A Turkish Delight. Walking around the Sultanahmet Area,every corner and every junction holds something exciting and awe-inspiring....Try as you may, you will never get tired of these fascinating surroundings and there is a good chance that you will find some new jewel hidden away down a side road or backalley. From the marketplaces to the mosques this is truly a wondrous place.

One can never have enough of this place. One can never have enough of this place, be it strolling, watching the architecture, or soaking in the the greenery and the spik n span surroundings.The mosques, streets, quint small eateries or full out restaurants (Misale cafe).Blue mosque, Hagia Sofia, Hippodrome or Sultanahmet tomb are all at a walking distance.

So much to see. We stayed in an hotel in the Sultanahmet district for three days before starting a tour with Fez Travel. All places of interest were within walking distance as the area itself is not that big. Loved the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Archaelogical Museum, Basicilla Cistern and Grand Bazaar - especially as there weren't that many tourists around, unfortunately for Turkey but good for us.

Sultanahmet is Istanbul. The strength of Istanbul is that most of its historical attractions are located in one area hence tourists can spend their time enjoying the attractions rather than wasting time on travelling from one place to another.Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern are within one place. The Grand Bazaar and the Trajan Column a short walk away or 2 tram stops away. Little Hagia Sophia is slightly out of the way but still within walking distance from the main area. Restaurants, hotels, art galleries, shops selling souvenirs and other commercial establishments catering to the tourism industry are plenty here.Should you want to explore the 'other' side of Istanbul in Galata, Taksim Square, Dolmabahce Palace and the likes the tram takes you the other side efficiently and at TL4 costs one way almost nothing.Sultanahmet district is Istanbul if I could say without exaggeration.
Great. Amazing area… lots to see and do… though everything here is uphill. Went to the Hurram Sultan ha am and got a world class massage… it's a must go!
A great place to visit. We stayed in the neighborhood and this has great places like blue mosque, hagia sophia around. There are nice cafes and restaurants as well to make your stay great.

A great district to base your exploration of Istanbul. We stayed in this district for 6 days while we explored the area and further afield in Istanbul. It's great if you are happy to walk or use public transport. There are plenty of restaurants but try and get off the main streets they are expensive and the food not terribly authentic or great quality.

Such a safe, fun area to visit.. This neighborhood, although very touristy (sadly, except for us, there were no Americans here), is very fun. Lots of fun people watching and places to see, the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the public areas around here, and lots of very attractive "polis". the trams are very clean and safe. I never felt afraid in this area.

Historical Place. Sultan Ahmet area is the center of Istanbul where Sultan Ahmet Mosque is located there.Resturants and cafees are located in the main street.I recommend all visitors to Istanbul to visit Sultan Ahmet area.

very central. I stayed in a lovely hotel in this district and could not have chosen better, a short stroll got me to the Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia and Topkapi and it was only a little further to catch a tram in the main street and handy for lots of shops and restaurants. Charming old part of the city,

A great place to wander about. It is a nice area to walk around and soak in the turkish culture. There is hustle bustle and is a lively area. The place is easily accessible by metro. It is recommended you buy a travel card that you can tap on the machine for travel else you will need to buy a travel coin from the machine just before you get on the metro. The Sultanahmet/Blue mosque and Hagia Sofia are just 2 mins from the metro stop. There are cool cafes and restaurants, souvenir shops and a park to sit by and people watch. Turkish people are nice and friendly and is ok to strike a conversation but, it is recommended you do not accept any offers for joining for a drink or someone offering to show you carpets, or a freelance guide that you randomly meet. Try and pre-arrange a guide, or just let yourself be and explore by yourself. Never buy the line "want to join for drink", "this musueum is closed, tourist doors that side", "want to see carpets".........
Very cosmopolitan metropolis. Very easily accessible. The tram runs nearby. Get the Istanbul card from the hotel and add on the money just like Oyster. Plenty food stall everywhere with fixed prices.
Beautiful - friendly - Wow. Beautiful - walking distance to almost everything. cant wait to go back. would stay in this district again

Mrs. Nice area to walk with beautiful shops. No cars there only the train. There is a beautiful park and great restaurants. Shops are little bit expensive and don't make special prices but have nice stuff
Nice peaceful atmosphere. It's nice just to walk around the square, eat roasted chestnuts and boiled or bbq corn on the cob! We felt completely safe in Istanbul.
Nice For a Walk!. Sultanahmet district is a good area to walk and discover the surrounding area. There is the Grand Bazar, Sultanahmet mosque and Haiga Sophia.
This is the place to live . If you are going to Istanbul for the first time this is the place to stay all main tourist attraction are on a walking distance

Old historical area of Istanbul. Stayed at hotel right on the Gulhane tram station. Within walking distance of many sites including Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome etc. Grand Bazaar two stations away on tram. Many excellent restaurants within walking distance. Tourism is really down in Turkey due to recent coup attempt as well as several terrorist attacks however, I felt very safe and the people are in general very friendly

Best base for sightseeing Istanbul. Sultanahmet is your best base for sightseeing in Istanbul. First thing to see is Sultanahmet Square which hosts the most important historical buildings of İstanbul and throughout history it has always been a significant center. Another one is Blue Mosque - one of the most important structures of the city and its outstanding characteristic is that it is decorated with more than 20 thousand blue, green and white tiles. Next one, Topkapi Palace which was used as the administrative headquarters and magnificent Aya Sofya, meaning holy wisdom, considered one of the three properties of God in the Orthodox communion. Sultanahmed District has also number of restaurants and dozens of good stores in all price ranges.

A MUST in ISTANBUL. This place will transport you to a different time - this is the place to stay in Istanbul. I think a week wouldn't be enough in this place. There is so much to see and explore. Everything is within walking distance. The local businesses are well-run, the restaurants are quite good, and the attractions are full of history. I had a chance to also walk to the Grand Bazaar and do some shopping. I would recommend staying in a hotel in Sultanahmet to fully enjoy what the area has to offer. My husband and I strolled around at midnight one night, when everything was quiet- it was an experience.I felt very safe here- there were police officers walking about, and there was ample security in the mosques. I'll be back for sure!

Sultanahmet Mosque is very big mosque having from inside a lot of old drawing the garden in the back side is also very. once you go to Istanbul you must visit Sultanahmet Mosque it will be one of your remember places which you will till your friends about it.
The place to stay. This compact area provides days of interest for the tourist. Monumemts, public spaces, shops, hotels, a complete experience in itself.

A place of beauty. Thus area is a place of many stories to tell. Everyone is very welcoming and willing to help. Take time to sit down with some çay and drink tea with a local to hear of the many stories they have to tell. This area is very diverse with many people from around the world.

Must do eating, shopping and history.. You can't go wrong here. Lots of shopping, street food, restaurants, historical sites and walking. Great place for walking around and experiencing Istanbul. A must do. Enjoy!!

Place to visit. It's recommended to visit this area as you will enjoy it.
A lots of restaurants, many landmarks to visit

One of my favorite places on earth. Culture. History. Cuisine. Spice. Shopping. Religion. You name it, it's here. Whether you are a planner or you like to walk around to see what you are going to find, you will enjoy Sultanahmet. There are hotels of all classes and prices, too. Be sure to walk through the Grand Bazaar. If you are from the West, practice not smiling and sticking your chin in the air in defiance - this means "No!" when you are asked to come see a carpet or buy some goods. Do go in and have some tea and a chat with some of the vendors, though - it is an experience and you are guaranteed to be educated on something during the respite.

If you're going to istanbul, you can't miss this. . In this district stands more than a millennium of history. From the topkapi palace to the hagia sophia, every stone speaks of the conquered and the Kings that touched it. An able guide and time on your hands should allow for a truly educational experience.

Museums and mosques and markets! . You have everything here. To the shopping part:If you see something you wanna buy, walk around and compare prices. Sometimes a piece of smth costs f.e. 7-10 ytl somewhere, around the corner there is a store with the same items for 2,5 - 4 ytl! Don't believe the sellers that only his are high quality they are all the same (probably low quality, but cheap), and don't listen to their stories (their kids have to go to school or the rent is too high or whatever).To the museums:If you want to visit hagia sophia and the Palace with the harem close by, buy the museum pass! It costs 85 ytl and you get your moneys worth pretty fast. You get into the hagia sophia, into the palace with harem (which costs extra), and into quite some museums for free! You can also ask restaurants or museum shop if they take the card for discounts! Enjoy your stay and don't let the city overwhelm you ;)
Historical District. Historical District.Hagia Sophia , Blue Mosque , Topkapi Palace , Basilica Cistern , Gulhan Park etc.

Great place for history . Major historical attractions close to one another such as the Blue mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia etc. Well connected by trams. Must visit if in Istanbul. All this by the sea side.
short visit for some shopping. great markets, loads of art and crafts , many traditional shops and cafes.easy accessible from the new city .
A must!. You really get the essence of this amazing city right here. The buzz is eclectic. I must warn you to be careful though. Beware of pickpockets and bag dippers. Be vigilant and cautious

A visit to Istanbul must include a visit to the Sultanahmet District. Even a very short trip to Istanbul must include a visit to this area. You will be spoiled for choice as to what to see first. The Hagia Sofia should top your list, then wander down to the Basilica cisterns. The hippodrome and the blue Mosque are also in close proximity and the Grand Bazaar is one stop away on the tram. To recover from the hustle of the bazaar visit the Topkapi Palace and savour the view from the shady gardens. If one really wants a 'spoil' make an appointment at the Ayasofya Hamam which is connected to the Hagia Sofia building. Very professional, unintimidating Hamam experience especially for first time visitors. You will need to book ahead and it's quite pricy but well worth it.

A lot to see. This immediate area is abundant with people, smells and sites to visit a photograph. There are restaurants galore, street food carts and ice cream galore. The immediate attraction is the Blue Mosque. Not to be missed.

What a magnificent place.... I love this place and its mixture of cultures and modernism. Obviously, its a not to be missed place when in this magnificent city. One of my favorites cities, I must say.
Wow!. This district of Istanbul must be seen. It is very authentic and during the pray call you could hear it all over this district.
the big sultan. we went to sultan ahmet palace two or three times,it was excellent and beautiful but they earn so much money for each part and if you want to visit whole palace its kind of expensive

If you have one day, this is where you should be.. The Sultanahmet District is where all of the best highlights of the city are. On our cruise, (which was delayed on arrival), we only had a limited time (only hours!) in the city and this hits most of the top 10 list (Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, etc). If you do hire a tour guide, just skip the rugs all together - that wasted our precious time in the city and we regretted sitting in for the demonstration (aka. sales pitch)

Magnificent place. It was great.i am not interested in historical places.but it was a great experience... tour leader was good explained history of palace with alot of details...Many of turkey leaders have lived in these palaces and u can see their works and interest in there... without any doubt if u visit istanbul u have to visit this place too...worth 40 turkish lira that u pay for each person

Sultanahmet District. A bustling city is Istanbul, and Sultanahmet District is no exception. At night, the sea front is quite amazing. Traders selling their wares, busy restaurants and cafe's. Yes, have enjoyed many occasions here over the years.

Bring your best Turkish and your hiking boots. It is cleaner as far as streets and facilities than where I came from, Oregon USA which itself is cleaner than California, USA. It is hilly, there are 2 min prayer broadcasts every day and EID started a few days ago when I came and ends soon but most banks, post office and serious trading shops are closed now. The endless twisted cobblestone streets (get a map or a camera and use google and mapquest or you WILL get lost) are lined with kalim rug shops, art dealers, coffee shops, kebob shops and the occasional mosque and ice cream or juice stand. Everything edible is delicious and relatively cheap. If you are vegetarian I recommend lentil soup, Esav would eat his heart out for it.This area includes the Four Seasons Hotel and the Rug Museum, flying carpets and levitation, anyone? A carpet that flies would be preferable to a blue bus (crazy driver does not begin to describe bus drivers in Istanbul) but if you take a taxi in Istanbul you need the address you are going to written out for the driver and they charge flat rates depending on the traffic not by a meter. They also all seem to smoke American cigarettes. Get some French ones and hand them out. Smile a lot. Say Tesheh Kur Adeera when you smile. Learn Turkish.
Best for shopping. Great historic building , restaurant , interesting shopping pick your activities Hagia Sophia is close Area is best for foodlover

One of the good place to walk. If you are looking for a place to walk and coffee shop this place is to be. Lots of coffee shops are open at night and you can order just Chai (Turkish tea) and enjoy the view.

Lively but manageable . great area but even though it's one of the main tourist areas it's still manageable not heaving or full of pushy salesman. overall great central location full of lots of amazing sights and places to visit

centrally located. The sultanahmet district is a perfect combination of Europaian and Turkish cultures. Beautiful buildings, mosques, can buy fresh pomegranate juice on every corner. Sultanahmet is a must.

The True Istanbul . I have visited this lovely location many times and it is always great experience. We feel you are walking in history while visiting the area since there are many traditional shops and historic places to visit and enjoy.
There are many wonderful restaurants in the area for all kinds of foods that suits everyone.
The truely Istanbul

Buzzing. Worth one day of Istanbul visit to see aya Sophia (if necessary), topkapi, the grand bazar, the spice bazar and eminonu shore where a fish sandwich grilled on the ships on the shore is worth the try.
Spice bazar seem vibrant than grand bazar.

Little time? No worries.... My wife and I had a 48-hr layover in Istanbul. It was planned that way because we wanted to hit two birds with one stone and see what we could of this amazing city. If you're on a brief visit, Sultanahmet is where you want to stay. This is is the district where the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Basilica Cisterns are all located within walking distance from each other. ANY hotel in that district is in a prime location but prices may vary wildly. We found ours on Expedia as an exclusive offer and saved 75% off refuser price. The T1 tram line dissects the district and is a good point to anywhere else in the city. As far as getting to Sultanahmet from Ataturk Airport, taxis are cheap but be aware of Fridays and holidays when traffic can turn a 25 min commute into a two or three hour nightmare. We took the Metro and it's a piece of cake. Get a Istanbulkart which is a reloadable pass that's valid for subway, tram and ferry. From airport-- take M1 metro line to Zetinburnu Station. Cross the tracks to the T1 tram line toward Kabasi. You'll be on the tram for approx 14 stops, get off at Sultanahmet. To take ferry from Sultanahmet to cross Bosphorus, take same T1 line, exit at Eminonu and the ferries will be visible. To visit the museums, but yourself an $85 (Turkish Lira, approx 50 US $) Museum Pass which allows you to see any museum within 5 days. Otherwise it will be $20-30TL per museum. Enjoy!!!

A must see if you are in Istanbul. The district contains many historical buildings and you can experience Turkish authentic food and see many old shops. Walking old streets was no nice and enriching. Be prepared to walk a lot

Stay right in the heart of it all. The Sultanahmet district is just divine!! You have it all at your fingertips or should I say toe tips! Staying in this area with all of its history takes you back in time but at the same time shows you modern Turkey. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace - just a few of the must see sights all within walking distance not to mention Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Galata Tower - oh I could go on and on. The streets are cobblestone and bluestone and there is marble and spiral staircases wherever you go. What a romantic city it is and especially so in this district. Turkish people are very friendly and so helpful. I was travelling solo and stayed in Sultanahmet and found it very easy to get around - everything was just a walk away and I left tis place having made so many friends. It is a very special place indeed.
Famous place in Istanbul.. It's one of the famous places mush visit in Istanbul, it has the sense of the traditional Turkish style.
Must visit. If you are in Istanbul you have to visit this area to enjoy every thing there like the blue mosque and ayaa sophia
Fine place. Recommended on a day light. With gathering because if you're alone in these kind of places you will miss the vibes of family

something special in Istanbul. Istanbul is so vast you cannot possibly expect to get a full understanding of the city in one trip - its takes probably 10 or more to really understand the whole thing and you shouldn't try to get it all in on one or two visits, but this is certainly the place to start and certainly the place to stay to get to know this part of the city, its easy to walk around with most of the major attractions on the doorstep you can also walk a little further to places like the spice bazaar. part of the drawback and an equal part of the pleasure is the constant haggling with the shop owners whether its a carpet, ceramics or tourist trash its a constant battle - but if taken with the right attitude and a pinch of salt its an experience (good or bad you'll need to make up your own mind) , its a great area to walk around day or evening - not all the restaurants are that fantastic but that can be said of any city the world over.
Safe as it can be.. This area is now for pedestrians only so it is easy to get around. Everything is within walking distance . There is a great deal to see so don't rush your visit.

The heart of Istanbul. I am a lover of History and Culture. So it was the best part for me. You can enjoy best food and great tourist attractions in this area. This area is the real gem in the crown of Istanbul.
Nice area but expensive services. It is nice area but not expensive as other Istanbul areas especially Nargilas restaurant..please ask the waiters about that before you sit and order

Great place to visit. I have visited this lovely place with wife and I found the place very interesting. We have visited the different locations inside with the tour guide. It is a great experience to visit such a historic place.

Long awaited trip. We have been planning to visit Istanbul's Sultanhamet area for a lomg time and our expectations did not let us down. Amazing place, beautiful scenery and wonderful people. Made us feel at home the moment we arrived. Spent 7 amazing days there we pretty much walked or jumped on the trams to everywhere we went. So much history to this amazing civilisation. I always thought the world was too big to visit the same place twice. Not this place. Simply Amazing

Definitely stay here if visiting Istanbul. We stayed in the Seven hills hole in the Sultanahmet area and would highly recommend, this is by far the best are we found. You have all the major historical,attractions nearby. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. Also you are near the Bosphorus for river tours. Other areas such as Taksim are very commercial, we would definitely come back here to Sultanahmet.

A beautiful location! Rich with culture . One of the worlds most distinguished locations and a must visit for anyone. History and culture, a beauty beyond imagination. Can't say enough. Just visit and enjoy
Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia. Visiting the blue mosque and aya sophia especially at night is breathtaking, you have to eat at sultanahmet koftachi and for sweets the next door shop Hafez Mostafa

Must see. I think SultanAhmet district has the most of Istanbul attractions in it. You shouldn't miss visiting The Topkapi palace, Blue Mosque, & AyaSufiya. I think it takes you 2 days to visit the attractions in SultanAhmet district.

Great area to walk around . Many places to visit in this area
Lots of walking
Eating places and coffee places vary in price many are cheep

Amazing. Best time to be there in the sunset try it
Sit between aya sofya and sultan ahmet camii and enjoy the historical scene
And forget to visit the mosque

Must visit area. The district comprises of everything historical you would want to see in Istanbul.
All the famous places, monuments are here. Lots of places to have lunch. Allocate atleast a day to this place.
Start with the blue mosque early morning, then have lunch and then visit other places.
Tram will be the most convenient mode of transport.

A week in Sultanahmet. Look we did go further than our title suggests, but simply there is more than enough to hold your attention in this district, from historic buildings, to the Grand bazaar, the many cafes and restaurants with a Grand Palace and street vendors selling corn and chestnuts. There is an aroma of foods from sweet desserts to grilled meats and fish, it is lively with the trams, the people from all over the world with many cultures, what a city. Markets crammed with spices, cheeses, saffron from Iran so much to enjoy, fresh fish served straight from the boats just like Rick Stein told us on his journey on TV.

History, heritage, food amazing. This is one of the best area to visit in Istanbul as you have plenty of history to explore and there are plenty of shops for traditional food nd drinks. You can walk around nd also.enjoy the famous hamam. Highly recommended

Picturesque town. Lovely beautiful place. Downside is it gets a bit quiet later on at night although you will find open places. Positives are that you are in the middle of a lot if the touristic sites and it is cleaner and more picturesque than places like taksim for example.

History, Culture and Food. This should be every ones number one visit in Istanbul. You will find so many things to see and do. Do see the Blue Mosque, the city wall, watch the whirling Dervish show, visit Basilica Cistern and walk around the market at night - try the Turkish delights!

Allocate a day - take your time to enjoy the sites and atmosphere. Staying in the Sultanahmet district will make exploring this major historical area easier. However, if you’re not staying in this district, consider using the train-tram network; the tram runs frequently and has a stop in the centre of the Sultanahmet district. The centre of the district is marked by the two Obelisks in the Hippodrome open area. Do the two major attractions first thing in the morning - Blue Mosque (free entrance /plan 1.5 hours / closes for midday prayers ) and then Hagia Sophia. There are plenty of restaurants around for lunch. After lunch visit Topkapi Palace. If you’re wanting some respite from the noise, then adjacent to the Palace is Gulihane Park which is large, shaded with hundreds of tall trees and peaceful. You need to have your passport to purchase one of the multi day museum passes.

Lovely area. Lively and lovely atmosphere with echoes of the Islamic call to prayer. Found this very memorable at sunrise and sunset. Lots to see and do eg Blue mosque, museum, Turkish baths, swirling dervishes.Lots of local restaurants but stay away from street vendors - had fish and was out of commission for 3 days!!

Old Istanbul. Plan to spend at least a full day here, unless you are staying in one of the hotels in Sultanahmet district. If you are staying in a different part of Istanbul, then you are come to Sultanahmet using Tram. Start of with Blue Mosque (free entrance) and obelisks. Spend about half an hour here. Blue Mosque closes for mid-day prayers so best time will be early morning. Next, Head to Hagia Sophia. You can buy your museum pass at one of the counters (you must bring a copy of your passport or any other form of ID). You can get free pass for children under 12 years age here as well. Spend about 2 hours in Hagia Sophia. By then it will be Lunch time, so head to one of the restaurants between Hagia Sphia and Blue Mosque, or alternatively opposite to Sultanahmet tram station. After lunch spend the rest of the afternoon at Topkapi Palace.

FABULOUS. Sultanahmet is very peaceful area . It is very good taking walk in the center also back side of main area. Also consist many historical monument from both ottoman and byzantine empriement. It is also very easy to reach Sultanahmet from every part of city. As railway system connected eachother. I definitely recommend people to visit Sultanahmet at least once in their life.
Good location. It was a nice experience to visit the mosque of Sultanahmet, to know about his many wives. The location over there and city view is marvellous.
Beautiful area. We had a great time exploring this area. There is so much there. We bought lots of lamps and one MUST haggle. There were times when we got an item half price......

Turkish History in a Nutshell. Visiting the Sultanahmet district is to visit much of the history of the Ottoman empire. There are wonderful attractions to visit, beautiful architecture to admire and much to learn about the region that is now part of modern Turkey. Topkapi Palace, the Sultanahmet (Blue) Mosque, Hagia Sophia museum, Basilica Cistern (amazing), Hippodrome and Grand Bazaar, to name just some of the highlights. A visit to Istanbul is not complete without a visit to this district.

Something to see around every corner. Beautiful area packed full of amazing historical sights, restaurants, cafes, street stalls, inventive icecream makers and more. It is packed full of tourists and more expensive but a definate must
Scam scam scam. Scammers everywhere. Police are not functioning at all. Will not come back. Definitely. I will only come back after the scam syndicate has been handled by authorities thoroughly.
Sooo Romantic. It is Paris is city of love. Truely, sultanehmed district is the city of love. So calm and cool with nicely serving restaurants and hotels. Ideal for lovers.
A true wonder. Beautiful district with major historical sites to visit, the district was clean and I felt very safe

we need to back again inshaallah. we need to back again inshaallah itwas very nice and historical but really expensive in this area then some restaurant staff is not good because they says first we will help you but then they cant.

The first place in Istanbul. This is the first place in Istanbul ever. You should go there when ever and every time you went to Istanbul. This area has everything you could need when you travel to buy gifts, remarks, gold, silver, statues etc..

Very nice historical area. The old city or what is know as "Sultan Ahmet" district, is a very nice area.
With all the history of the Osman's period.
I enjoyed every moment there.
Visited: Blue Mosque,Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazar and more.
You must go there, discover this part of the city and enjoy the moment.

The game start here. sultanahmet place located in where important and ancient place of istanbul where you'll find Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Saray), Binbirdirek Cistern, the Istanbul Archeological Museums, Great Palace Mosaic Museum, and several lesser sights .also this area has very delicious donner.It's your best base for sightseeing in Istanbul. For a rundown on things to see, go to Istanbul Sights.

Best location to stay in Istanbul . Far from the noise of taksim, sultan ahmad area is without any doubt the best location in istanbul to stay at. Coffee shops and restaurants are near, best historic locations and a calm yet touristic area.
Sultanamet district. This is another amazing monument. All these monuments are near to each other on walking distance . It depends on invidual how much time one wants to spend and enjoy .

Old Istanbul . This district is not commercialised like the new area of Istanbul. There remains huge tradition and history. Although there will be many many tourists this is the core of Istanbul from the ottoman empire with lots to see. From sultanhamet masjid to hagi Sofia to topkapi palace to the Islamic museum to the cistern to the grand bazaar lots to see and soak in.

Enthralling. I cannot say enough about this area of Istanbul. It just overwhelms with the sense of old world meeting new. There seem to be 1000 attractions but just walking around is enough to have all the senses engaged. There's the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Archeological Museums, the square and fountains, loads and loads of restaurants. I wandered around for several days and could not get enough! Beyond the tourist attractions, there is the energy of the area which is alive with centuries and centuries of history. Take your time and wander around! It's well worth it!

Should get the detailed map. It is the unique place that surrounded lots of wonders. You should dedicate at lest 2 days to see all. When you get tired get rest in Yesil Ev, Arslan restaurant these 2 are my certain favorites.
Nice relaxed area of Istanbul. Really nice and relaxed area of Istanbul - great cafes and shopping. Some of the nicest restaurants are in the back streets.

The place to stay in Istanbul. This was our second visit to Istanbul and while we previously stayed in the exquisite Kapinski Palace Hotel, we had to catch a cab and cross the bridge to get to most of the main sites.On this visit we decided to stay in the Sultanahment district. While we couldn't find a hotel to match the first one we stayed at, it was a definite bonus to be able to walk to most of the attractions in the area without the cost of a taxi several times a day. It was easier to make several trips to the Grand Bazaar and come back to the hotel to unload the shopping. It also meant you could pop out of the hotel to take some special shots at sunset or take some snaps while walking to dinner.

Reliving Constantinople. Sultanahmet is a very historic and tourist area. It is a unique and very interesting neighborhood with its own characteristics. It is famous for not only stay but also eating, shopping and strolling. In this area, there are many monuments, hotels, various mosques, many resturants, many cafes and local shops.The most important monuments in the area are: the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Underground Cistern. Walk around Sultanahmet would be great to get to know the history and culture of Istanbul. For historical, religious sites and outdoor places in a single day, visit this disitrio is the best choice possible. To find the essence of Istanbul city and fall in love at first sight, the Sultanahmet district is highly recommended. This neighborhood makes you travel back in time feel the old contsntinopla. Full of the Turkish spices smells, imposing monuments a place to visit whenever the Instabul.

Tourists sites abound. One of the most well known areas of the city.Tourist spots include the blue mosque and the topkapi palace as well as great shopping and a host of restaurants and bars to try out.A must see!!!

History around every corner on every step.. There is so much to see and do in this area, with all the major historical attractions. Although filled with very touristy shops as one expects, this place is thriving with life. I loved staying in this part of town as I felt safe and it was easy to remember and learn your way around.

Historical centre of istanbul. This area is the historical centre where you will feel the ultimate history of Ottoman Empire.. İstanbul doesnt only represent Ottoman or Islam. This city was the capital of Byzantine Empire once.. So imo this is the most beautiful city for culture turism due to its mixed identities. Still very different people from different background and ideologies live together in peace in this awesome city where asia and europe is connected with two bridges. Also 3rd is opening in a month..  So istanbul is a must and in Istanbul sultanahmet district is a must too. As an Istanbuler i have couple of recommendations. First find the original sultanahmet meatball restaurant. There are two big restaurant in the centre but the original and better one is the one where they dont accept credit cards. Also just a metro stop away there is a corlulu ali pasa medresesi where you can drink one of the most delicious and authentic turkish coffee and there are aromatic teas. Also a waterpipe (hokkah) of course!! I didnt need to mention blue mosque or hagia sofia btw.  All the cafes in sultanahmet area are authentic whereever you go you will just love the athmosphere. If i am to recommend a luxury 5* hotel that would be four seasons sultanahmet which was a prison once. They keep the feeling and touched it a little bit to give the luxury look. You can have a drink at the roof watching blue mosque. It is picturesque but stop taking photos and feel the rhtym:) if you prefer to stay in a boutique hotel just pick one. All have similar concept. But about the view its not guaranteed coz this is historical area so buildings are old and short.. Topkapı palace is in the area too. So one world just go...
Nice History Places. I liked this area very much, many sightseeing places, very nice location, many local and small shops, too crowded with people

Quiet February Day in Sultanahmet District. Despite it being cool, we found the restaurant staffs more than willing to find us tables out of the wind and provide heaters and blankets. The view was spectacular with the Blue Mosque in one direction and the Hagia Sophia in the other. With fewer people around, there was no waiting, no line-ups, smaller crowds and very attentive staff.
Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet area is very crowded but still a must-see & you have to visit it more than once.very good for shopping too.

Charming area, historical and beautiful!. Recently spent a few days in Istanbul in the Sultanahmet district. It is beautiful and charming. Great places to eat good food on a budget and also to shop. It also houses some major historical sites like Topkapi Palace and The Blue Mosque.

The Fun area. Sultan Ahmet is a very Famous Area where The Ottoman Leader use to live and pray. It is surrounded with Avenues and roads built with stones no asphalt local markets and restaurants all over the Area
Inspiring. Would come back over and over. Love this place filled with shops, colors and flavors.Photographer's paradise for great shots.

History lies on my dreams. Standing in between centuries ! This place is exceptional. Besides ancient ruins, middle age buildings are standing as if new. And how magnificient is the blue mosque making the peak of all things around.
so sad. Istanbul is such an amazing place--crossroads of world history and religions. It breaks my heart to read what is happening. Can't honestly recommend that anyone travel there now.

Very nice place. its full of history. friendly people, and plenty of free places to visit. you can enter any mosque for free.
Yoy can use the train or taxis but beware if taxi drivers and try to negotiate the price before riding.

Beautiful insight of the old part of Istanbul. Beautiful to walk around in the old part of th city! Feeling of being a part of the local community. We were ther in the beginsignaal of march so it was not very crowded!

Lovely area to visit and stay . There is so much history within this area of Istanbul. If you want to visit the main sites, then Sultanahmet is the place to stay. With thousands of places of eat, lots of places to visit...you will never be bored. Whether its museums, palaces or even just a national park. This has it all!

feel this city is alive. you can feel your self in local, the sights of Istanbul are wonderful, you can find good food and traditional hand made souvenirs visit this place it's really good experience.
Culture abound!!!. Fantastic cultural area to visit . Can get a bit busy so try to start early in the day to capture all the sites. Visit to Topkapi palace a must.

Watch out for the salesmen.... The sights of Istanbul are wonderful but, because of the reduced tourism (due to the country's current political unrest) the salesmen are very aggressive. We attempted to be polite our first day and got sucked into two different carpet stores - a waste of their time and ours since we were not going to buy anything. The store owners are extremely congenial and non-threatening - but your time could be better spent amongst the antiquities. From day 2 on, sadly, we were forced to be somewhat rude and simply ignore anyone who spoke to us in English so that we could get to our museum destinations.

Local feel. If you want to have a local feel of Istanbul, this is the best place to find a hotel. You will love its feel, its architecture, its people, the food. Every single thing about it was awesome. So when in Istanbul, stay at Sultan Ahmet. To plus the point, all the main attractions are at the walking distance, and also close to the tram station, which will take you anywhere in the city.

A charming area of a taste of it's own.. We stayed in this area for about 10 days,it was supposed to be only 5 days,but the area was very active and live the grand bazaar was just a 7-10 minutes walk,the transportations near to it,the restaurants are plenty with various kind of meals to choose from, 3 play grounds at walking distance my kids used to play in when we feel lazy or fatigued to go out to distant place,at night we feel very safe to go out to have a walk or late dinner,locals treating us very nice especially the kids, they loved my little daughter, they gave her kandies and gifts some times,the tourism places are near to our hotel luckily.I would advise families to stay in this hood although old area but has it's own taste.
Close to all the main attractions. Close to all the main tourists site in the Sultan Ahmet district, spoilt for choices when it comes to eating out.

Sultanahmet District means the center of Constantinopolis. Most important places to see in this ares is Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and Hippodrome. Ofcourse more to see but these are the highlights. Dont see Hagia Sophia before Blue Mosque and Hippodrome, you need to see hippodrome first because history of Hagia Sophia has Nika Revolt which started at the Hippoddrome. And if you will see Hagia Sophia before the Blue Mosque you will be dissapointed when you go to Blue Mosque :)By the way make sure to have a tour guide for Hagia Sophia, if you wont join a day tour or have a tour guide for a day, at least get one of the guides infront of Hagia Sophia, some of them are really good on history and almost you can find in any language.
Must visit place. A trip to Istanbul is not complete without trip to Sultanahmet. There are so many places to see around here that you need one full day to experience all that is stored over there.

Lived like the Locals. We visited Istanbul on a cruise and stayed a few more days in the Sultanahment District. We chose this area as it is near local tourist attractions but also close to wear many locals live. We stayed in a small apartment for 5 days and walked around this area a lot. It is very safe and the people are friendly. A number of supermarkets and places to dine to enjoy the Turkish atmosphere.

Main Center. This is a wonderful area of Istanbul, that has many historical and beautiful sites. In close proximity you can see the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, the Basalica Cistern, as well as find many shopping and dining establishments. One of my favorite things to do is find a bench and take in the amazing sites. It's a tourist hub but it's a great introduction to a great city.

The whole district is fabulous . Myself & family enjoyed in the area. You need to visit early of the day to avoid crowd. Bring also your phone charger to avoid running out of charge as this place require lots of photographs. Beverages a bit expensive and you need to bring empty bags for trashing.
A great Area. This is a great area to walk through and enjoy the rich and long history of the place. There are a lot of shops in the streets around.

I love this place. So many amazing places to see in a relatively small area. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Basalica Cistern, Hippodrome. The area is very walkable and you see so much more on foot. Istanbul was the first Islamic city I visited, and the people and the beauty of the place forever changed my perspective of the world,

We enjoyed the area. The area was very suitable for old people and children ... We enjoyed the area with all the shops and restaurants. If the security situation improves in Turkey I will immediately visit the area with my family.

Ottaman Culture. ok this place is very nice to visit and walk around after noon time, its touristic area full of many attractions, such as blue mosque and Ayia Sofia famous church, as well souvenirs shops and food places etc..
Place to stay. We stayed in this area and spent most of the time here. It has such rich history and fun places to shop and eat. It is touristy but everyone needs that now and then.
Amazing District. Filled with lot of antique flavors and beautiful domes, it is a living historical district. I recommended for a first visit to Istanbul to in touch with this magical city.

Great atmosphere. We were lucky that we picked a local nearby hotel so were only few minutes walk away from everything. Lots to choose from for eating, cafes, kebab shops, gift shops.....all historical buildings located opposite each other so you do not waste any time as they are all within a minutes walk away from each other especially blue mosque, Hagia sophia and Topkapi palace. The tram is also accessible, and we used it few times to get to different parts of the city, again locals helped us how to buy tokens and where to stop.

Area filled with historic buildings and great shops and dining establishment's. We stayed three days in this area of Istanbul. It is a great area to locate in due to all the historic sites as well aas great shops and dining establishments. Everywhere you look there are things to see and do. It is a very lively area of the city. I would recommend that this is the area you would want to stay in during a visit to Istanbul.

Magical CIty. Very nice, magical city. Full of history and character. Excellent tram links saves money and arrives you at all the destinations quickly. Run every 1-2mins and very cheap 2l or less per way. Weather and tourist sites well kept and looked after. Bustling shopping area in fatih near Sircesi Station with all the shops, dessert parlours you need.

Nice & cool. We started our day from Hagia sofia, then walk thru sultanahmet square upto hippodrome & then visited basilica cistern. Our next destination was topkapi palace museum including its harem section. We then went to Antalya, & on back to Istanbul stay for 2 more days in this area (Staying at Sultan corner). We walk thru the streets several time, sitting on benches & enjoying the time there. We left the area, after the Jumma prayers in Blue masjid.

Fabulous place to spend a few days. I stayed in a hotel in th old district so was able to walk to the Blue Mosque in under 5 minutes. Outside the mosque there is a square which is the remains of the ancient hippodrome used for chariot races. In the square is an obelisk taken from Karnak, Egypt about 400AD. The Hagia Sofia is right there as well and the Basilica Cistern which is a huge ancient underground water "tank". Make sure you leave plenty of time to visit Topkapi Palace - give that at least half a day especially if you see the Harem section. A short walk,in the other direction is the Grand Bazaar where the mechanics are waiting patiently to take your money - lots to see there. The Spice Market is a couple of stops away on the tram.
😭. God it's a place where you can forget everything and just live the moment don't miss the view at night you can sit by the fountain and have something

Well worth seeing. The Sultanahmet district is a must see. The blue mosque and the Hagia Sophia are historical gems. The jewel in the crown is the Topkapi palace and it is really interesting and a lovely palace. The harem is interesting as well because few people realise that they were actually prisons and seeing the palace and the harem quarters together, the contrast is marked. The mosaics museum is also worth a visit. It is possible to buy a ticket which enables access to most historical monuments.
old city. old city is here, history of istanbul is here, topkapi museum, blue mosque, hagia sofia, grand bazaar, egyptian bazaar ...
I would like to go back. When I visit Istanbul and visit the old city I don't want to leave. I am even thinking to have a flat in this city for my retirement

Old and new Istanbul meets at Sultanahmet.... The best time for Istanbul is April-july and september-November period. We visited the square with my 5year old son and my 65 year old mother. He could freely ride a scooter there. We parked and walked through the ruins to the square. Visited Sultanahmet mosque. My son was amazed with the size of the Mosque. Unfortunately the Toilets were no good. After spending time here and there at the square, we moved towards the street to have a great meal at historical Sultanahmet köftecisi. Then we walked through the small streets around and even took the tram to the Grand Bazaar. He had great time just like we did.

Beautifully desgined, prominent in the skyline and a fantastic view. High up, above the bazaar is this huge mosque, which could easily rival the blue mosque. Its much quieter, less crowded than the blue mosque. Plus there's plenty to see around the mosque complex.
Magical place. Sultanameth is full of everything you want to see when you visit Istanbul. Good and diverse food and restaurants, Souveniers, shopping, buildings
just amazing. worth a visit for sure...at least once in a lifetime...the hustle bustle of tourist activity and the historical places...make a fantastic day trip

City and area that never sleeps. So much to see and do and so much history and loads to do from sitting by the colourful fountain and opposite the blue mosque to having ice cream and walking by the sea to eating great food...
This area is the pulse of Istanbul. Historical buildings, Rich in Culture, Friendly People and Delicious food guaranteed in Sultan Ahmet
Sultanahmet. Nice area, full of restaurants and stores. Safe place hang around. Client oriented service will make your trip a great one!

Nice old town. This is old town full of major attraction in walking distance. Right across the bridge is new town ( Taskim Square ) which is Europe side full of night life. However staying in Sultanahmet is cheaper and more comfortable for day out. Easy cab ride to Taskim square.

An excellent location for first time travelers. This is perhaps the best place to stay if you are a first-time traveler in this city. Sultanahmet has all the glory of the old Turkey and everything is just within walking distance - for example, the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. The hotels around were competitively priced and generally clean. You will not run out of dining and shopping options as well. It can get really busy. However, it never affected my holiday experience.

Glad I went in April. I was determined to see the ancient sites - as well as the city of Istanbul - between bombings, before the coup. So glad I did. It was peaceful, heavily policed, and the fears that kept other tourists away made for a relaxed trip. The Blue Mosque was "meh" to me, (and my guide at Ephesus confided that "it's only impressive to tourists") but the Hagia Sophia and Tokapi Palace met my expectations. Details such as the Viking guard chief's graffiti, "Halfdan carved these runes" into a railing on a marble parapet resonated for me, as did the mosaic of the fair haired, Irene (born "Piroska") of Hungary. I'd no idea that there had been centuries of intermarriage, mercenary activity and trading between Byzantium and Eastern & Northern Europe. Three-four days was just the right amount of time for me to absorb history, and some excellent Turkish cuisine.
The blue mosque is amazing. Blue Mosque is also known as Sultanahmet Mosque. The mosque’s interior has 20,000 blue tiles that line its high ceiling.
Great!. A very inspiring place, a must visit on your list of things to do / go when in istanbul! A must visit

Great place to visit. Very beautiful and big place with lots of places to just relax on the grass or benches for couples or families. Many street corn salesmen etc around to buy snacks. Great views over both the blue mosque and Hagia Sophia as well as many beautiful fountains from the park like area! Highly recommended!

Awe inpsiring. A safe and enjoyable place to visit. The Blue Mosque is so beautiful as were the other mosques in the area. They even supply the head scarfs for woman at no charge so femailes can enter the mosques. Be prepared to take off your shoes!! No shorts for males or females. Inside is breath taking.

The Sultanahmet by metro - place to relax. Walking around this area was peaceful and tranquil. The Green Mosque its a walking distance to the Grand Bazaar for shopping. I have enjoyed using metro train to reach most of the areas.

It is absolutely beautiful and cannot be missed.. Every moment spent there was wonderful. The sights are amazing, the city is clean. The public transport systems work perfectly and the food is so good. It was fantastic.
History -- your in the centre . The difference between Greece and Turkey is that you can touch and sit on history in Turkey where as Greece always lets you look .A great area to sleep eat shop party

One of my favorite spots in istanbul. Amazing place very clean has many imoortant touristic places and mosques..beautiful scenery with ppl selling smit and corn everywhere around u. Wish to go there again

Awesome area that is good for exploring. . The entire area is worth exploring and there is much to see that is within walking distance. The Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, water front, Gohane Park, and so much more is closeby. Lots of restaurants to try out local dishes that you can pick from visually.
Great location. Has everything, restaurants, shops, a variety of hotels and a few minutes walk from some of the main attractions.

A nice change from the grand bazaar. A fascinating open air walk that leads you to the spice bazaar. I found this bazaar far more entertaining than the grand bazaar. The sales persons seemed more friendly, far less pushy, and it was a more manageable experience. The array of spices and teas were a site to behold. A great experience that let to me bringing home many gifts for this upcoming holiday season.
Istanbul . Whole area is fantastic you can touch the history every where Ottoman Khilafa was so powerful and creative

a must in istanbul. everybody needs to walk the streets around and inside the bazaar. there's so much to see. your senses go into overdrive. not only inside the bazaar, that seems to be mainly for tourists nowadays (one vendor actually was straight forward and just told us to give him our money.....but it's always with a smile and a joke) we loved the alleys around the bazaar where you can buy anything from birthday party essentials to fur hats (my daughter described it: like the oriental trading catalog exploded onto the streets!!) also you find many nice restaurants, many with outdoor seating in this area, don't forget to look up, lots of the buildings have fabulous roof top restaurants with great food and views to die for!!!!

Stay in a hotel in this area. We stayed right in the heart of the Sultanahmet area and can really recommend it. You can walk the entire area or get onto the tram (very efficient!) when you need to get further. The Blue Mosque is worth the visit, especially early in the morning when we found it very quiet, adding to the whole experience.

Exotic & Enriching. This is the finest location in Istanbul for historic, exotic sites, architecture and enriching culture. So lively, and so much to see! You will definitely require a minimum of 3 days to tour and absorb, if possible.

A walk in the past. Everything you experience in Sultan Ahmed area is special and only can be experienced in Istanbul. Wow historic scenery. Old shops. The access the the bazaar. Ottoman history. I recommend that you stop at Sultan Ahmed station either via taxi or tram and have a journey through the old alleyways descending to Gulhane park. It can take a couple of hours while visiting all the shops and attractions through the journey.

Feast for your eyes and tummy. Wonderful pretty area. Pleasure to walk in. Quite and friendly. Hundreds of eating options. Our favorite area in Istanbul. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Hamam are all walking distance. Baby car comes in very handy.

The best place to take a walk in Istanbul. I have walked around the Sultan Ahmet area many times. There is the Blue Mosque and the Sophia Hagia and the cistern and Topkopi Palace to see all within a few minutes walk. The archaeological museum is well worth it. We walked around t the Arista Bazaar and went in many interesting shops.W signed up for a Bosporus cruise in one and then ate dinner at the restaurant. While we were there they had a whirling dervish on the stage which saved us the cost of a show. They also had Trukish music group as we dined. If you want to use a hookah, they are available.

Get a hotel in this area. If you are a tourist, this is the place to stay and visit. Most hot spot places are in this neighborhood, but actually there are also quite a lot outside to be fair.Walkable, reasonably safe and full of history.Really consider to choose your hotel in this District.

Steeped in history. Travel thru the ages as you walk through this area. See amazing structures and enjoy the noise and taste some of the wonderful street food on offer

Hard to beat for sightseeing. Some of the best sightseeing spots are in Sultan Ahmet, and most of the "major" ones. Very walkable, nice parks, public transport, etc. But it is very, very touristy. You are (politely) harassed by vendors and restauranteurs at every turn. It may have been particularly bad when we were there since we felt like the only tourists in Istanbul due to some tough times. But we always felt very safe, and people were really friendly!

Historic and Beautiful . Sultanahmet Dist is one place where you'll find history in every corner. You need at least few days to see every part of it. You have so many restaurants to eat food. Best is to eat the local food. Turkey has the best food. Travelling is no problem. Tram and taxis are every where. There is lots of shopping both traditional and modern. Grand Bazar is one option.

Wouldn't stay anywhere else. The old quarter around Sultanahmet was just perfect for wandering and gaining an immediate sense of belonging. Everything, pretty much, was within walking distance and the cafes and restaurants were around every cobble-stoned corner.

Sultan Ahmet Mosque. Turkey's Historic Centre. A popular tourist site, Sultan Ahmed Mosque continues as a mosque today with men kneeling in prayer on the mosque's lush red carpet after the call to prayer. Construction of the Blue Mosque, as it is popularly known, was built between 1609 and 1616 during the rule of Ahmed I. Its Külliye contains Ahmed's tomb, a madrasah and a hospice. Magnificent hand-painted blue tiles adorn the mosque’s interior walls and at night the mosque is bathed in blue as lights frame the mosque’s five main domes, six minarets and eight secondary domes. After the Peace of Zsitvatorok and the crushing loss in the 1603-1618 war with Persia, Sultan Ahmet I, decided to build a large mosque in Istanbul to reassert Ottoman power. It would be the first imperial mosque for more than forty years. While his predecessors had paid for their mosques with their spoil of war, Ahmet the First had to remove the funds of the Treasury, because he had not gained remarkable victories.It caused the anger of the ulema, the Muslim jurists. The mosque was built on the site of the palace of the Byzantine emperors, in front of the basilica Ayasofya (at that time, the primary imperial mosque in Istanbul) and the hippodrome, a site of significant symbolic meaning as it dominated the city skyline from the south. Big parts of the south shore of the mosque rest on the foundations, the vaults of the old Grand Palace.

See more with a private guide! -- Berrin Yavuz of Parasol Tours. We had only one day to explore Istanbul on a recent trip to Turkey, but I feel like we were able to really experience a lot, and I credit that to the tour company that we booked under, Parasol Tours, and the absolutely wonderful guide they provided for us, Berrin Yavuz. Berrin took my husband and I on a private, walking tour to Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Hippodrome, the Blue Mosque, and the Spice Bazaar (at our request as we were less interested in the Grand Covered Bazaar). She was SO knowledgeable about each location and very passionate about sharing that knowledge with us. She had a great sense of humor and never made us feel like we were in a rush or that it was a bother if we needed to stop for a bit. In addition to the main locations mentioned above, she took us to a tile shop where we were able to see a ceramics demonstration using a manual pottery wheel and to a Turkish rug weaving shop where we visited an underground cistern to see a simulation of the Hippodrome in its glory days, watched a weaving demonstration, and had all sorts of beautiful rugs laid out to hear about the different materials and styles. Berrin even recommended local places for lunch and dinner for us, even though those were separate from the tour and dinner fell after the tour had already ended (she made sure we knew how to find the location before dropping us back off at our hotel). Both meals were absolutely delicious, and it was especially appreciated after being suckered into eating at a tourist restaurant the night before with much heftier prices and lower quality food. We were fortunate enough to travel all around Turkey through this company, and I cannot recommend them enough. The drivers and guides are ALWAYS on time, if not early, and they will make the places you visit really come alive for you.
Love the Blue mosque. Love the view and love the architecture of the mosque from inside do not forget to have a coffee in the cafes on the other side of the street next to the tram you will love it

A vast area of History. As our tour guide would say -- The Sultanahmet district is the heart of historic Old Istanbul.In this district you'll find Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Saray), Binbirdirek Cistern, the Istanbul Archeological Museums, Great Palace Mosaic Museum --- all of which are walking distances to each other. Historical wonders!. Here you can stand where people have gathered for thousands of years before you. There is the ruin where the Romans raced chariots and killed Christians. Vibrant Meeting of Many Cultures, Lots of Restoration. Visited Istanbul twice in 3 years, both times during Ramadan. My original first impressions of Istanbul is that it is incredibly packed with people, with narrow haphazard streets, and people walk everywhere disregarding traffic. It's like one big free for all. Everything has a bit of a crumbling, dilapidated look to it. This is not the clean, well-maintained old Paris. You get a sense of the extreme age of things from how it is all wearing away but slightly sad about the condition. When I returned this year, the same hustle and bustle was present but the city seemed to be more vibrant, less dilapidated, less crumbling. It seems like there are (much-needed) restoration and new development projects all over. Stopping at the many wonderful sites around the Sultanahmet was like visiting old friends. This is one of the most beautiful collections of buildings and public spaces I have ever visited. I love the wide open Hippodrome with its looted ancient artifacts, the stunning and massive Blue Mosque, and the charmingly crumbling and historic Aya Sofia. During Ramadan all of the plazas and streets around Aya Sofia and Blue Mosque are packed to overflowing. At dusk, the call to prayer plays over the loudspeakers and everyone starts to eat making it eerily quiet and beautiful. We sat on the edge of an old stone wall and ate our street vendor sandwiches, just taking in the sheer mass of people around us. It is an incredible sight. While other areas of Istanbul might be more modern, visiting the ancient Sultanahmet with its unparalleled mixing of all cultures is a must in everyone's lifetime.

Jewels in a tiara. Many of the monumental treasures of the old Byzantium, Constantinople and Istanbul are resting and breathing here, side-by-side. Take some time-out to sit on one of the benches under a shady tree close to the Hippodrome and contemplate the pictures and people this area has seen coming and going.
Old and beautiful Buildings. This is a must see in Istanbul. The Suleymanii Mosque, the Hagia Sophia and all the small streets to walk through
