Easy to walk around and everything is there. Everything is around here and easy to walk about. You will be greeted by many shop keepers touting to make you buy their stuffs. For those who are suckers for everything American; McD, Starbucks, Burger King, you will find it further up the street. Try having something from the pudding shops and if possible to stay away from the kebab shops as it is very overrated and not too nice. Explore the alleys as you find many interesting things. When you see the prices of the food dont be shocked especially for the kebab as it comes in a full package with bread, cous cous, salad and its worth your money instead of the regular dry street kebab. We usually share most our foods. Try the mezes and the savory baklava. Some many food to try.

Great Old City. A great area to stay in while visiting Turkey. Walking distance to all major tourist attractions such as Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern and the harbour. Large variety of eating places with various cuisines.

The centre of historic Istanbul. To me this is the main a hugely atmospheric place and it is easy to understand why: Many of the great attractions of Istanbul are concentrated in Sultanahmet: Topkapi Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, and other interesting sights. I recommend staying in Sultanahmet - there are a range of hotels and guest houses to suit most budgets. The Sultanahmet Square is the hub around which these sights are found and it is full of life at all times of the day - its cooling fountains and line of sight the great Blue Mosque, and Hagia Sofia while also being a main transport hub bring many travellers and locals alike.The food scene here is also exceptional - wander around the back streets and find cafes and restaurants serving delicious authentic Turkish fare at very reasonable prices. You will live amidst the history and feel it like a living thing.

So much to see, do and eat in one central location. In our first visit to Istanbul, we ended up coming back to this district over 2 days as there was so much to see and do, not to mention the abundance of restaurants and cafes that offered traditional turkish cuisine and desserts. We really enjoyed the Spice Bazaar which offered an extensive array of shops and food stalls. We bought some homemade honey and goats cheese that were simply delicious and we didn't feel the need to haggle as the prices were pretty competitive. Dotted around the area are magnificent mosques of various sizes to marvel at.
Great place to stay. With scores of shops, restaurants and cafe's, and with all the historic sights the Sultanahmet area it a great area to stay in Istanbul.

A walk through history. In addition to the essential historical sites—Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Sulemaniye Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, and the Basilica Cistern, among others—the streets of the area hold untold visual and historical treasures of a more prosaic nature.
Must Visit. This area has so many attractions and all of them within walking distance of each other. Great option for a day out and for some excellent pit stops to eat.
Imposant. one of the bigest and most important mosque in the word. Make time for exploration ancient and modern islam religion

Incredible!. Take your time to walk around, it is huge! Unexpensive entrance and easy to find, don't pay a tour to go there!! Cover yourself ahead of time...also, bring appropriate clothes, you don't want to be that shorts and sandals tourist in this country!

Beautiful Architecture - Beautiful People. A visit to Turkey is like a visit back in time (well when you do get away from the touristy places) Museums are excellent - especially Islamic History and Artifacts.
Enjoyed the visit.

Top Location for Historical Sites. Topkapi Palace, Sophia Haggia and the Blue Mosque are located in this area plus many other attractions. Was pretty safe in May 2016. High police presence but typical big city street smarts are required.
Facinating place. Plenty of history at every turn. Well and truly worth a visit. It is a safe area. Plenty of places to eat.

Authentic Turkish area to stay in. Beautiful to stay in this old part of Instanbul amongst the local residents are the numerous hotels - just choose your hotel wisely. Easy walking area with local eating spots, beautiful old buildings and lovely sea views. Close to Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Sophia Hagia and most attractions. Walking best way to find hidden gems.

good to spend your day or night. that day was a bit cold and gloomy but everything are nice. birds here and there. Turks are nice and they are pretty and handsome people. so television-ish. sultanahmet is good for free time

Clean, historic and impressive . A very manageable walking tour gets you to several impressive attractions. Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Basilica Cisterns are all in a very small cluster. A little more walking gets you to Topkapi Palace, The Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market. Constantinople was the center of Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman empires for a good reason. Great hotels, food choices and shopping make this a great place for a three day stay. Except for the aggressive but polite rug salesman that are out in the streets trying to get you in their store, we loved the Turkish people. Very friendly.

This place remember 1001 nigths tale!. I and my daugther enjoy too much too spent on afternoon or one day just aroud this place, many trhings to see arts in all parts and places. Like you back to the past.After we go to Bosforo channel and aprecieta the sunset. It is the best.

The Historic Area of Sultanahmet ! Beautiful !. This main area of Istanbul owns its name to Sultan Ahmet the First who ordered the building of the world famous Blue Mosque, a superb example of early Byzantine Architecture. The Blue Mosque lies opposite Aya Sophia,a former Byzantine Church turned into a mosque;A picturesque square is in the nearby as well as many other interesting places and sights ! Beautiful and historic !

Unbelievable Architectural Design. Entering the mosque of Sultanahmet iand its surrounding make you feel proud of those Engineers to designed this magnificent building, with natural sound system to announce the prayers two centuries back without loudspeakers with neutral ECHO generated by the spacious building structure and its dooms Amazing calligraphy the size of writings can be observed in equal for those who is written 38 meters in height and the one above your head with few meters The local Bazar and traditional market gives you the sound of Alladin with his magical lamp specially at night

A memorable Experience. The Monuments are well kept and Clean. A lot to offer through their history, displays and the Contents. Since Admissions are through Tickets which are priced between 20 Turkish Lira to 40 Turkish Lira. Traveler's must opt for the Single Ticket Option which is Currently 85 Turkish Lira with a validity of 5 days. This allows entry to most of the Museums .
Gorgeous!. Visited Turkey and this was definitely one of the places I would highly recommend. The ambience and people are so nice there. Would highly recommend for everyone to visit this place

Sultanahmet District Experience. Sultanahmet District is also known as the "Old City" and offers many historical sights that are all within walking distance from one another. These include Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet a.k.a Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, The Grand Bazaar and my personal favorite the Spice Market, just to name a few.

vibrant wonderland. This area never fails to hold my interest and fascination.This time the Ramzan markets added to the interest. I love the seagulls overhead reminding you that you are near the water wherever you wander. So many places to see and restaurants galore that make it hard to choose from.

All major sights in one place. If you are in istanbul for limited days. You can spend one day in this district and cover major sights.Blue mosque, haga sofia, topkapi palace, bascilla cistern all are walking distance.You can easily get to sultan ahmet via tram Make sure you have your walking shoes onFood around the area can be expensive yet not tasty but you can break at mado cafe for some kunafe or waffles with icecreamThere is a walking street also so you can buy souvenirs.There is an arasta bazaar also which you go from haga sofia

Beautiful and historic. The historic area of Sultanahmet is known for its architecture, Islamic culture, and busy marketplaces. This is where you want to go to see Turkey in its most traditional sense.

Everything within walking distance!. This is an area full of history. Most of the major historical attractions of the city are within a 10 - 15 minute walking distance. Recommend using a guide - they are very well trained, speak great English and make the 4,500 year history come alive during the tours.
History alive. History is alive around you here. It was so inspiring. I loved that it was walkable and there was no harrassment at all.
So much to see in such a small area!. I love how easy it is to visit so many amazing sites all together. The corn vendors helped us keep the energy going without stopping for a meal :)
stunning views for miles. stunning is an understatement,try to take it all in and enjoy all scenery and the boat rides, also visit all museums if possible
Impressive views. Very interesting, we did a walking tour, there is a lot to see in this area from the Blue Mosque to Hagia Sophia and the sultan Palace
Historic Centre. The historic centre which dates back to the Ottoman Era. Centrally located in close proximity to all the major tourist attractions.

The heart of historical Istanbul. This busy area is full of interesting mosques and historic buildings and the great Bazaar, including such icons as Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and many more. Lots of restaurants and bars - the heart of Istanbul.

Oh how I love this place. The fountains in front of Hagia Sophia, the gardens of the Blue Mosque, the Arasta Bazaar, great winding little streets and all the attractions of the Spice and Grand Bazaar... all the reasons I love this place.

Safe. After recent terrorist attack at Sultanhamet security is very tight, police are always present. We felt very safe walking around the area, the local people are very friendly and welcoming, plenty of restaurants and cafes in the area. We were staying in the area at the time of Ramadan where at sundown Sultanhamet square came alive with thousands of people having picnics with there families, it was such a beatiful sight.
Exciting. You can go no further than the Sultanahmet district to get a real feel for the old Istanbul. The atmosphere is wonderful and the people warm and friendly.
Central to all the attractions. Best area to stay, easy walks to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazaar and many other attractions. Brilliant tram service to other areas, easy to use. Loved it !

Historic!!. A beautiful historic district with all historic buildings and bounded by water. Getting to the Old City by public transport is easy. The waterfront has cruise ships, providing passengers with easy, self-arranged access to sights and shopping. Important sights include Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazar, Gelata tower, spice bazaar, Aya sofiya. This city takes you to that beautiful era and shows you a glmpse of the Mighty Empire. An excellent tourist spot.
Enchanted place. Come and visit this place surely you will be mesmerized with the history and the architectural beauty of this district.

Marvelous. You can spend whole day there and not to see everything. From so many historical buildings and all little thigs to so many shops but not just with goods. Food is prepared all fresh. You can see the girl that makes all after your order. Everything is so organized and clean. Simply beautiful. Try to go around Sultanahmet mosque to see parts that is not on the front. Streets are simple with a few restaurant but there is great bazaar with a fresh vegetables and fruits.

Turkey's Culture in 2 days. Beautiful place to visit from monuments , mosques, museums, parks , bazaar, restaurants, cafes , cruise, shops etc etc.I have visited this area during fisrt week of April and this area was full of Tulip flowers.Cheap Bosphorus cruises are available in front of spice market , 15 Lira per head for 2 hours trip.If you are staying in Taksim square , you can catch train to reach this area, which is much cheaper than taxi.I would not recommend to take a tour package for this area, take taxi or train and spend time according to your taste.

all history , antique city. If you are reading , if you are in Istanbul , you have to visit this region , you can compare here with a couple place in the World. Maybe not the best but you can be sure that here is the most EXCITED place.
Go there and start walking in every street .
Interesting and cultural. Really nice and clean environment with significant cultural landmarks. Really fascinating architecture combined with everyday life. Kebab restaurants all around. Great!
Fabulous area and good food. There is so much to do in Sultanahmet and the restaurants and good too. We even found one doing "Happy Hours".
Must See Area of Istanbul. One of the best districts of Istanbul full of archetecture that tells the storied history of this city.

One of the must visit. My second time to visit. It's really nice area, full of history, and you will find more tourist in it. If you decide to stay I. sultanahmet, try staying at Divan yolu cd (street) because this is almost in the middle of the area. There are many shops and restaurants. But always be cautious to your personal belonging in such areas in Turkey. I always carry a low limit credit card and some cash. And now of course we have to bring along our passports due to the tight security which is a bit relaxing to be honest. I'll add some photos later.. I would appreciate a thumb up if you like the review..

Loads of History. This area contains some of the most interesting buildings, streets, markets and history I have found on a single holiday. (Plus good food in endless variety) There is easy access by tram to the wider city as well

Great food, great shopping. Great sights. This district has it all, Touristy but that's the way it is as the must see sites are located here. Small windy streets with shops everywhere beckons the tourists. Buzzing and interesting.

Must visit. There's a lot going on here, from the Blue Mosque to the Hagia Sophia, with plenty of options for food, and huge expanses of grass. There's also a bazaar with a restaurant that has a whirling dervish.

Beautiful vibe . Such a lovely lively bustling area with welcoming locals as well as tourists. It's nice to finally discover somewhere on earth where it's not just filled with drunk Brits. Genuine well preserved buys if history await you as well as streets filled with delicious food. It's slightly more pricey in comparison to where we stayed however it makes for a lovely atmosphere especially with the mosque Athans going off.
The History is amazing. Everywhere you look and walk there is something to amaze an excite the sensors so please make it a must destination when in Turkey.

Step back in time, an explorers heaven. When in Istanbul, spend a couple of hours walking around the Sultanahmet District. You will feel like you have been transported back in time. Start in the new city before crossing the Galata Bridge (great place for pics). Watch the old men in their dozens fishing from the Galata Bridge, we came across a Turkish wedding party, which was awesome.Then immerse yourself in history exploring the old streets and laneways in the Sultanahmet District. We actually visited twice, on a Sunday and a Monday. The best visit was the Sunday. Although it was very busy, it has the atmosphere of families out for the day, all having fun.Lots of bargains to be had too, and lot cheaper than the Grand Bazaar.Make sure you take your camera as you will take so many pics.
Great. This area is particularly rich and has much to offer for history aficionados. The architecture is admirable.

Holiday . This is the must see, feel,touch and breathe area. A blend of history, modern life and religions. Roads that take you to carpet shops, restaurants, gift shops,tea shops and places that would colour your dreams.
Quiet but lovely. With tourism down, it was a perfect time to visit as streets were much quieter and access to sights was without any lines.

So many wonderful historic sites!. We stayed in Sultanahmet for 5 days and another 4 days in the New City on the other side of the Galata bridge. Both districts have their distinctive character. Sultanahmet offers can't-miss attractions such as the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, and Topkapi Palace, to name only a few. It has many hotels and restaurant, some of which are excellent.We visited during the bombing scare and Sultanahmet was not crowded. Some of the restaurants and hotels are hurting financially. We always felt perfectly safe and had no problems. Many places, such as the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market, do rudimentary screening of people as they enter.The only downside to Sultanahmet is the continual and unwelcome solicitations by rug merchants and restaurant staff to come into their shops. We quickly decided to say 'no thank you', avoid eye contact, and keep on walking. If you stop to be polite to everyone who entreats you, you'll never get anywhere.

very tidy and well managed.... my special thanks to the fatih municipality and mr. mustafa demir, the fatih mayor. now, very safe for the visitors; sultanahmet district, herself, is a must for all istanbul visitors!..

Lovely place with history for all.. Istanbul is a unique city with Muslin, Christian and Jewish history. You must visit the sights in the Sultanahmet District to truly appreciate what a diverse and accepting city Istanbul is.
Great city. It is one of the main city sightseeing of the city , but too crowded, touristy place, but you must see them.

Best area in Istanbul . Staying in sultanahmet district was the best decision we took. Everything worth seeing is at your doorstep. Here you will get a real taste of Istanbul with its alleyways shops and locals. Don't stay anywhere else

History all around you. Sultanahmet is an amazing area filled with historical places. Explore the streets and look for hidden restaurants, family business, with better food and lower prices. If they don't serve alcohol do not give up, it usually means the food is better and get a beer later :) While there, enjoy prayer calls in between Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque. Also, take a walk by the sea side while walking by the walls of the Old town.

Amazing neighborhood..... Loved the time spent here! There are so many cool little shops and the people are so friendly!! I would caution about the salesmen that run rampant. Everything from food to rugs....just be ready to say no when needed or just take in the experience and enjoy the culture!!
SUPERB HISTORICAL AREA. Certainly the best area in Istanbul to stay.It has character and charming.I have stayed in the Taksim area but you cannot beat Sultanamet.

If you go once, you'll keep coming back. Every time I visit Istanbul, I feel that I have to go to Sultanahmet at least for one day. There is so much to see and do, that everyone who visits will find things that will make them feel good about visiting and wanting to come back again. I love going to the Blue Mosque and taking a nice relaxing walk at the Gulhane Park. Kapali Carsi is one of my favourite shopping areas and I love going there as well.
Wonderful Area in The World !. Sultanahmet must have been seen ! When you go there you will understand What is The history meens , must go !

One of the 10 top site in the world you need to visit. One of the 10 top site in the world you need to visit. HagiaSophia, the Blue Mosque are an eternal tribute to the history of the world, This place is a must see.
FASCINATING PLACE. Really good historical place, lots of activities that you can do. There are lots of good restaurants nearby.
Full of History. With both the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia and a gorgeous courtyard in between, you can't go wrong. We could spend the entire day here and not be tired of its beauty.

FASCINATING PLACE FILLED WITH HISTORY. Istanbul is a fascinating place. If you only have a very limited time, this is the place to be. With Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, old bazaar, numerous restaurants, souvenir shops, relaxing fountain, one can spend several hours in just this area and have a great time. We were so immersed in its history, landmarks, architecture, food, people, souvenirs, hand made wares etc.that we forgot another engagement.

Old world charm at it's best!. One of the best places to pass time in Istanbul! If you are planning to visit Istanbul, I definitely recommend you to stay in Sultanahmet District because it is a historical hub where most of the tourist attraction are very close to each other and also it's simply amazing to just go out of your hotel and take a stroll in this area at night and as per my experience, it has been pretty safe to walk around in this area. Overall, a great experience!
It rocks. Walked around for much of yesterday. Always felt safe and there is so much to see. Little cafes, so many historical places. Everyone is very welcoming.

We spent most of our time in this area!. Lots of things to do and see in this area. Our hotel was just 3 minutes away. We used to sit by the fountains and eat corn and Kestane! There was lots of activities here during the first day of Ramadan.

A District Full of Life. Spend a whole week in Istanbul. Booked into a hotel in Beyoglu first opposite the old town Sultanahmet. Couldn't get extension for more days, we moved to the most busy area right across Blue Mosque in main street Sultanahmet.Although the old town is easily access by tram and metro. But after visiting a few beautiful mosques and museums, All we wanted to do is to crash onto a couch by the window or a roof top café, just to chill out at the end of the day.There were eateries of all sorts; café, Gozlame shop, ice-cream parlours... they could be on top or underneath of your hotel. If that sounds like fun then, definitely book one right in the middle of it all. Only need to stick your head out of the window to feel the buzz.
Great public transport. Nice area. Lots of nice restaurants. Great public transport. Easy to find. Giant fish platter for sharing. Awesome and very chip.

Main attaraction. Sultanahmet is a main attraction of Istanbul. You can see here Topkapi palace hagia sophia museum, blue mosque. Grand bazaar is also here. You can say 70% of Istanbul attractions are here.

Amazing historic district. Walking through the SultanAhmet district with my wife was a great and fun experience. Getting into the old and historic parts of Istanbul from the great mosque to the Hagia Sophia museum to the old bazaar area with all the little shops to the many monuments and statues and ... throughout the district. My wife and I were walking for almost 5 hours without realizing it as you keep going from site to another. Every where you look there is a something to see with a story behind it. We walked through the old downtown area with all the new restaurants and shops and bars. It was a great experience.Gabriel
The Heart of Istanbul. Had a great time wandering this old area of Istanbul. So much history. Visited Topkapi Palace, Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia and much more. Very enjoyable.

Fantastic. This district is a memorable one. Beautiful flowers decorated the aera.Many tourists from different countries come there to enjoy the very unique ambiance. Magnificence of Hagia Soghia and Blue Mosqe impresses every new comer.People around are kind. Some of them do not know English. But younger citizens can help the tourists.

Beautiful place to visit. I've never seen such a beautiful place in this world like Istanbul. The Sultanahmet mosquee is just wonderfull and an also peacefull place. Such many colours, so many people, beautiful religion and also crazy city. We will come back some day..With kindly regardsErton Z. & Danielle A.B.
lovly attraction. this attraction have great atmosphere . u can have memorable moment , but u have to pay attention when u visit there
Very clean. This area is always full of tourists & sometimes noisy & hectical. So buy yourself a sandwich and sit infront of the beautyful fountain.

Friendly Turkey Blends Old and New. The Sultanamet District while very old and full of history, is modern in many ways. You can find anything at the bazaar, people are friendly, the food is good and the bathrooms, for one Euro, are very clean and modern. I felt safe travelling as a female.

My second Home. lived in various small & friendly hotel through out last four visits to Istanbul. I do recommend it for travelers who want a taste of historical old city, and love window shopping too.

FASCINATING PLACE!. What a fantastic place to visit. Walking thru this area is such a wonderful enlightening experience, full of unique sights and people. We stayed in the Vault hotel which was absolutely beautiful with very friendly helpful staff.

Mike. Have to go once. History and amazing culture. Beware of the over eager merchants trying to be helpful and then get you to visit their shop for whatever. They are plentiful, persistent and relentless almost ruined the day.

A Wonder to the Eye and the Imagination. This area at the waterfront is near all the ferries and the Galata bridge. Lots of street merchants and entry to Spice Bazar. Watch you wallet and expect rug salespersons to approach you frequently.

The soul of Istanbul. I can't imagine visiting Istanbul without visiting Sultanahmet area. Most of tourist, historical and storytelling attractions are located here. It's only a matter of your personal interest - what are you the most interested in, and thus - where on Sultanahmet you want to spend the most of your time. Anyway, this is 'a must see' area of Istanbul

Where a lot of history resides in close procimity. Sultanahmet is where all the boxes can be ticked for seeing top tourist places, such as Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Aya Sofya, Million Stone, Basilica Cistern and many other sites. It's filled with quaint restaurants down side streets, hotels, hammams and is worth exploring. The views of the Marmara Sea are great from this area and catching the ferry from the Ido station to surrounding cities like Yalova, Bursa is very convenient. One is also spoilt for choice with the transport system in this area.
Place is consisting of many Mosque & historic places to visit. Sultanhmet District is consisting of many Mosque, Religious & historic places, worth to visit and admired to.
A must visit . you have to visit this district to find the real taste of Istanbul history. Very nice place for tourism to explore histrory, shopping and eating.

Lots of activities and to ss historic sites and monuments. This is the historic but not the people's centre of Istanbul. There are several Roman era monuments as well as ancient mosques, including the Blue Mosque in this area. Easily accessible by metro. Also Haga Sophia is within walking distance. If you are lucky you might see a performance of Whirling Dervish . There are lots of touristy shops. Due to the recent troubles in Istanbul foreign tourist numbers have apparently declined as it was one of the favourite areas for tourists.

Beautiful place. Close to everything. We stayed only a street away from the blue mosque at the Great Fortune hotel. Great value. Within 200metres of the Grand Bazzar, Basilica cistern, Hagia Sofia & much more. If you are after great food at a great price don't eat on the main streets, the dodgier looking the place the better the food we found.

Wonderful Turkey. We were there during the tulip festival & returned as often as we could. Fine cafes. Completely safe. Enjoyed by the local people. A privileged experience and a wonderful side of Turkey.

Lovely. Wonderful visit. There are many things to see in a short distance. Incredible mosques, a palace, underground Roman cisterns. It's amazing. And Turkish food is incredible. I recommend at least half day for the palace. Hagia Sofya and Blue Mosque can be seen in a relatively short amount of time. Definitely go to the cistern. Very interesting and great place to cool off on a hot day.
Amazing District. The district includes the German fountain with it's incredible colors, garden with very colorful flowers and many bazaars.
its beautifull. great place with lot of shopping areas specially the spice market and the grand bazar. the bhaklava's are awesome by hafiz mustafa

Busy. The city has 7.5 million people in it, and this is a busy part of town, there is just too many people, and taxi drivers trying to rip you off, with the "you only gave me a 5" once you have given them a 50, they are pretty slick at changing the 50, you gave them for a 5, and then getting your attention back, it happened too many times for my liking. Did not like it at all around this area

Bucket list instabul . As a Greek man I wanted for many years to visit this historic city and its crown jewel Agia Sofia whilst a brilliant experience it was also tinged with sadness as this true iconic place needs more attention in terms of its presentation and I accept you never wish to lose its originality it needs attention Took away nothing from its beauty and lived to every expectation The people were awesome

Amazing!. Arriving here you start to soak up the history of the place. The sight of Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque is amazing, the trip across the bridge is a sight to see with the mosques and city buildings. The grand bazaar has hardly changed since I travelled here in 2000. I had no trouble from anybody other than the people persuading me to look in their shop or eat at their restaurant which is expected. Felt safe at all times.

History Buff!. The food here is a little more pricey than other places in Istanbul but its overall affordable. I loved how many of the museums are in the Sultanahmet District, which made it easy to navigate from one attraction to the other. Super nice and historic place. Highly recommend visiting.
Sultanahmat District. What a vibrant district with all historical sights. Quality restaurants and nice people. You will not be bored with all day and night activities.

Leisure. We stayed at Sultanahmat area at the Armada hotel. The hotel is close to Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapi palace. We had our kids with us and we visited all these places and my kids were happy to see other school kids on field trips visiting these historical places. We visited also the Gulhane park that is situated a few steps down Topkapi Palace and it is a very nice park where kids can play.
A slice of history.... A must visit when in Istanbul with a host of tourist attractions like The Blue Mosque, Haga Sophia, Bascillia Cistern & Topkapi Palace

Heart of historic peninsula.... Sultanahmet district is the heart of historic peninsula, Topkapi Palace, Sultan Ahmet Camii (Blue Mosque), Saint Sophia, Hippodrome and Underground Cistern located in same location.You may walk between places and also Grand Bazaar is located in Bayezit which is in walking distance.Note: do not to take taxi from Sultanahmet district they try to overcharge even locals and for sure tourists as well, better to use tram or public bus.

Touristy but amazing. This is without a doubt a must visit. Every mosque was beautiful and unique. Walk around or take the tram. This city is beautiful. Filled with lovely people who go out of the way to help you.

Great neighbourhood. I lived in Sultanahmet for a month, it is a lovely place to live in/visit. It's full of small cobbled streets, a lot of which have specialised shops - such as a whole street of shoe shops etc. The Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Kucuk Ayasofa and Basilica Cistern are all in Sultanahmet. Its also very well connected through the tram and buses.

Cluster of historic sites all within walking distance. Sultanahmet District is the perfect place to book your hotel when visiting Istanbul, as many of the major attractions (Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque, Topapki Palace) are all within a few minutes walking distance of each other. Grab a 2L ear of roasted or boiled corn to eat while you walk, or sit by one of the many beautiful fountains! Plenty of souvenir and ice cream (dondurma) shops, too.

Touring the Old City. You can see most major attractions in Istanbul right in this area. Easy to walk around and see all sites. I visited in late May so it wasnt overcrowded. The Med Cezir hotel in Sultanahmet is charming and very close to all attractions. The Cetin family is so gracious and top notch in their hospitality.

Grand place grand area to stay. I stayed at the Kalyon hotel. All attractions were at a the most convenient distance . Though transport was readily available but the great Fun is to see places on foot. We walked 26000 steps daily food points are in abundance and superb . Shopping plenty . Numerous motels and hotels are available that are decent and safe for people like us ... Two Pakistani women....

Interesting, old, full of character. Our Eurostars hotel was set in the heart of Sultanahmet District - the Old city of Istanbul. Full of little streets, hundreds of restaurants, cafes, sweet shops (baklava, nougat etc) and right next to the port where there are boat trips up and down the Bosphorus and ferries across to the Asian side.

So much to see and do. This area of Istanbul is so easy to walk around. We spent a week here and didn't see everything! Walk along by the river for amazing 'sandwiches' and take a boat trip to see Sultanahmet District from a different perspective!

Lovely place . If you are person that loves old cities and ruines u would like this place and the area around it the only disappointment aboit istanbul in general is that some people refuse to talk with u in any foreign lanuage other than that it is a lively place

'Heart' of Istanbul.. Sultanahmet District is the heart of Istanbul. More then 3/4 places of tourist interest are located in this place. All the attractions worth visiting, including the Grand Bazar are within walking distance. Shops, Hotels, Restaurants and the narrow paved streets are all attractive and eye catching. Cleanliness is superb. Most of the Hotels in this District are 2 or 3 Star but you save a lot of time in traveling from a distant Hotel. As they say, old is Gold and this old part of Istanbul is really Gold.

Stroll around and enjoy!. Here is the place to go with no guide. Just stroll around, enjoy all the great places. Have a softdrink in the the sun and looking at streetlife, Many of the places in Old Constantionopel / Byzantimum is in walking distance to each other. Great!
Amazing in the morning breathtaking by night. Be sure to spend some time to relish that soul-melting sensation of Istanbul. The lights by the fountain at night are not to be missed.

Not so many tourists to spoil the effects, especially if off-season.. This city has to explored....many out-of-the-way places also deserve to be visited. Just beware of the constant 'urging' by local merchants to visit their shops (but nearly as offensive as most cities)....just politely ignore them.

Beautiful ottaman history. Beatiful historical district with wonderful ottaman mosque ,museum , church , .... Every corner of sultanahmer district is full of historical sightseeings which have treasury inside them .A lot of hotels with great view of haghia sophia are the other part of sultanahmet interestings.

The Oldest and Best District in Istanbul. The Sultanahmet district has everything that a tourist goes to Istanbul to see. The Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Topaki palace, the Istanbul Archeological Museum, etc. There are great local eateries (the wrap is the local street food) and just walking the local streets can be an adventure. The only drawback is that some of the locals who want to be overly friendly and helpful can be nothing more than fronts for selling you a carpet or anything else they or their relatives are selling. Getting acquainted with city trams is highly recommended for getting around the city (especially if you want to go the the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market). The public transit is very cheap (4 lire when I was there) and frequent.

Near most sights. I stayed at the Pierre Loti in this district which included Blue Moeque, Aya Sophia, The Basilica cistern, the tram line that takes you to the Spice Market and ferries that go to the Asian side and down the Bosphorus as well as Topkapi palace and the archaeological museum . It was also walking distance to the Grand Bazaar. For these reasons, I enjoyed staying in this area. I unfortunately didn't have a lot if time to spend in Istanbul and I was traveling solo so I enjoyed being close to most of the sites. If you're looking to be near the "touristy" sites, this is where you want to stay.

Great base for site seeing Istanbul . I thoroughly enjoyed our stay in the Sultanahmet district. Close to all the historical sites but less chaotic than over the hill near the ferry terminal and train station. Close to the grand bazaar with good links to the airport. Felt really safe walking around day and night.

Easy walking to all the major sites. Easy walking distance around some of the must see sites of the Sultanahmet district. The Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia and Grand Bazzar are in easy walking distances. Felt nice and safe although there are plenty of well dressed young men that want to show you their range of carpets for sale

The heart of old Istanbul. Although my hotel wasn't the classiest, I chose Sultanahmet deliberately so as to be in the heart of the old city, and I have no regrets. From my 3rd floor sea view of the Marmara, I imagined I shared the view enjoyed from the old palace.. who knows? Regrets? I regret having to develop a thick skin, and an ignorant attitude, to rebuff the continuous entreaties to visit various shops (and when you do ignore them, you get sarcasm, or being told you're 'angry': honestly, there is no alternative, because the moment you respond to their 'greeting' in English, you're a marked man or woman.A (true) plus point: at first the to and fro of competing muezzin was intrusive, but you get to like it. On my last morning, I had to leave early and the promised alarm call to my room never came. But the muezzin at the mosque next door delivered, and I was dressed and ready when my cab arrived. No disrespect, I promise you, just an unforeseen advantage of a call to prayer.
Is it authentic.... ... narrow cobbled streets under the beaming sun. Loved pushing a buggy up and down the tourist filled district

Just take a couple of days.... It's busy... it's bustling... it's what you expect it to be and so much more. Take the time to wander around visit the bazaars, eat from the street vendors. Buy bread from street vendors ... buy frozen water from the street vendors too... dont visit the tourist trap restaurants.... go off the main grid to find some great value quality eats. Embrace everything that is.

Old Istanbul. District that includes the Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Spice Market just to name a few. The small winding side streets are unique. Be aware that it is teeming with people- both tourists , locals , and many people who work or sell items in the area. A unique place with diverse people. The people are super friendly and are willing to help and direct. It is one of the must places on a bucket list. The call to prayer five times a day makes it more magical.

Very Historical. We stayed at a hotel in this area so we were able to walk to the most touristic sites instead of taking taxi or tram. If you are spending just one or two days in Istanbul this is the best area for visiting their most historical sites.

Aggressively touristy. Tourism is down an estimated 70% from last year so the shopkeepers and restaurateurs are desperate for business... which means you will be hassled off the street when passing every single store/restaurant. It really gets old. Sure it's close to the major monuments so if you're only in Istanbul for a couple days it makes sense. But if you're staying for a week like I did, do yourself a favor and consider another neighborhood like Galata.
Great Loaction. Great Location. Very close to Blue Mosque, Topkappi Museum, Hagia Sophia, Tram station. Lots of restaurants around until late night.
Istanbul Must visit. This district in Istanbul is the place not to be missed while on a visit to Istanbul. Most major tourist attractions are concentrated here.

Gateway to old Istanbul. Full of the main attractions with friendly locals who are helpful and greet you with warm hospitality. Most sites are within walking distance, yet decent walking shoes are recomended.

Wonderful City. Enchanting, easy to get around, even if you get lost. The diversity of its people and the misconceptions disappear after a few hours of touring the narrow streets, savory get the superb food , drinks and deserts. I traveled alone and felt safe. I have to add that, above all, what made my stay unforgettable was the warmth of the people. I hope to be able to return soon...until then...

The place for everything. This district is perfect for everyone, whether you are History lover, sea lover, shopping lover, fish lover... anything you want to see or do you will enjoy it here. You must see the Masjid of Sultan sulaiman. And then take a tour in the shops around and the city. It's wonderful.
Exploreration to the Max. If you have only one day in the city, come here and see all the main sites, good food and history. Google map your walk and take note to bring some cash.

just go !!. If you have the opportunity, GO. Istanbul is a very beautiful and inviting city, the historic Sultanahmet area is definitely worth a visit. Our small group had a private guide, and I would recommend this for anyone with "time constraints"

A Must If in Istanbul. I assume everyone who visits Istanbul visits this Old Town. It is where the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sophia reside. It is fun to just wander around too. There are tons of restaurants and shopping opportunities. We stayed at the Sultanahmet Palace Hotel which is a great location for visiting this Old Town area.

Best location for a short stay. Staying for a short time in Istanbul? Wanna see all the "must see" tourist attractions? This is the are to stay in, a great variety of hotels in all price ranges. We stayed minutes from the sultanahamet tram stop but hardly needed it as the majority of major attractions are all in this area and the major tourist restaurants bars etc Busy buzzy Constantly being enticed into bars and restaurants which gets a bit wearing Don't pick up the shoe shine brush as he drops it intentionally and then is very pushy to polish whatever is on your feet

So many amazing sites in a small area.. Some of Istanbul's best sites collected together within easy walking distance, e.g. the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and Topkapi Museum to name just a few. Feel History at SultanAhmet. Sultan Ahmet District one of the best area in Old Istanbul. You can feel history from antique time to today... Enjoy around so many shops & restaurants.. Easy connection to everywhere

Area that includes all. Whether you like to indulge in the historical sites, eat street and local foods, or experience the famous Hammam, Sultanahmet is the place to be. In Sultanahmet, you experience the touristic part or a trip, and feel part of a local community, when surrounded by local people performing their everyday lifestyle.I just love it.
Don't let the threat of terrorism keep you away.. We stayed at the Four Seasons hotel in this beautiful part of the old city. A magnificent hotel created from an old prison.

HISTORIC. Sultanahmet is the historic quarter of Istanbul. I had difficulties leaving it behind. I recommend everyone that loves culture/history/architecture to stay in this area. (of course don't forget to cross the water once in a while)

Fascinating, steeped in history. We visited Istanbul in February, almost on a whim since we were in relatively nearby Qatar for a few weeks. We stayed at the Hotel Spectra right at the edge of the Sultanahmet Square so everything we wanted to see and do was within comfortable walking distance, including the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. This district has so much history, vibrancy, and fascinating places and people. At no point did we feel unsafe, even when we were out in the evenings. The carpet sellers can be quite aggressive in their friendliness; the experience of viewing carpets is interesting and they will bring you copious amounts of tea. If you want to look for Turkish carpet, by all means, but don't feel pressured. You can say no thank you! Don't miss the terraced cafe overlooking the water -- keep walking through the park past the Topkapi Palace to find it. Wonderful place to stay and walk to see so much of old Istanbul. There are fees for some of the places you want to see like the Bascillia Cistern, but others are free.
History!. The mosque is enchanting! The architecture and the 20000+ blue tiles and the fact that this mosque was built eons ago were mind boggling facts! We stayed and took in the aura and quietness.
Istanbul. Istanbul is the most amazing city , Sultan Ahmad mosque is from the ancient history. Turkey is wonderful place to visit and it is number one in tourism. I love it

It was the most wonderful place I`ve been in my life. Sultanahmet is one of the biggest mosque in Europe and it was a place I visitit when I was in Turkey with my family. Sultanahmet is a place where you are always wellcome to as long you follw the rules, if you are a girl you can not have short clothes on and you need to have somting that hides your hair bur everybody need to take off shoes and durty socks.

You can spend a week in this area.. Do you know some about history of Istanbul? This is the area. Starting from 5th century you can find many civilizations in this area. You can't avoid, you mustn't avoid if you are in Istanbul.

It's definitely worth the visit but it's hard to walk far before you're approached (sometimes aggressively) to buy something. We also watched a three person team of cons taking advantage of tourists trying to get money from an ATM, and experienced a taxi cab driver charging triple rates.

You are so central . You could not wish for a better base for your break in Istanbul, you are close to all major attractions. There are plenty of shops, restaurants and hotels. Amazingly pretty in the spring. About 30 mins from the Airport traffic depending, but all in all great place to stay.

Wonderful despite the crowds. This area of Istanbul is so crammed with historic and beautiful sites that it is essential to visit, and/or to stay in, for any traveller to Istanbul, despite the wall-to-wall hotels, restaurants, and shops along the streets, and the crowds of tourists. There are many parks, lots of shade, views of the Bosphorus, calls to prayer from the mosques: ignore the other tourists and just soak up the atmosphere. You can also take the tram to or from here, across the Galata Bridge from or to the "new" city.

I loved visiting Istanbul.. This historic area was amazing. The people were extremely warm and friendly. The sites were stunning! Everything was clean and beautifully landscaped. Thanks for letting me enjoy a safe experience in your lovely country.
Great walking area. Lots of history, art, good food, and interesting people. You can easily spend a whole day walking around here, from before breakfast to after dinner.

A lot to see if you just take a look around!. I had only a few hours so I decided to take a walk in this area. It is gorgeous. It an obvious place to visit when going to Istanbul. Just don't be afraid to put yourself in the smallest street or alley, you will find some nice spots for photos!

This is a very interesting, pretty atea. This is quite a large area. Give yourself plenty of time/don't rush it. Enjoy the fountain and park. Visit the cistern, Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi. Walk the surrounding streets and stroll along the Sea of Marmara. Stop and savor Turkish Coffee while people watching. Relax. There are touts, but don't get angry with them. Smile and say no.

Visit Istanbul - you won't be sorry. We recently returned from a trip that included 4 days in Istanbul. Originally we were supposed to board a cruise ship there and sail for a week to Athens. However, the cruise line cancelled the call in Istanbul and all Turkish ports of call in the wake of terrorism in the area (and more to the point, do to the resultant lack of bookings). We went to Istanbul anyway, and I am glad we did. The old city and the entire town is fascinating and brimming with worthwhile sites and stunning vistas. Security in the city is discreet but reassuringly present. That said, at no time during our visit did I ever feel threatened or unsafe. The Turkish people that we encountered were all very friendly and helpful. Sadly for them, tourism has taken a sharp decline with is really impacting their economy. Please, let go of any fears you have and go visit. You will be glad you did and the Turkish people will be happy to see you!
A Taste of Ottoman Turkey. One of the most wonderful areas of Istanbul, it gives you a taste of the Ottoman era.. Must visit Sultanahmet mosque, Hagia Sophia & Topkapı palace..!!

So much to see! So much to learn!. The Sultanahmen area is so named because it was the area in which the Sultan lived in Topkapi Palace. It is a treasure trove of architecture, history, and culture. There is the Hippodrome where Romans raced their chariots, the Cistern where they stored their water; there is Hagia Sophia, built by Christians, captured by Ottomans, now a museum. Most awesome building I have ever seen. There is the Blue Mosque with its' world famous Iznik tiles, the Turkish and Islamic Museum and a host of other places to see. Beneath what was the stables for the Sultan is the Arasta Bazaar, less daunting than the Grand Bazaar! Hard to spot, but in the Arasta Bazaar, there is a small sign for a Mosaic Museum. These mosaics were in Justinian's palace, which stood where the Blue Mosque stands today, so they date back to the Romans. Take the opportunity to learn something of the history of Constantinople/Istanbul and your trip will be the richer for it!

The Highlights of Istanbul are here.. For a first time visitor to Istanbul this area is a must. The mosques do not bar any recognition to those seen in the UK.. Quite extraordinary in size and structure
worth a visit. A beautiful district, filled with history. Just walk the streets, get lost & marvel at the richness of this area.

Historic district with hidden treasures. Sultanahmet District is a great trek to do while in Istanbul. Not only the mosque of the "Magnificent" sultan beautiful to behold, there are also historical tombs located in the court. The tombs of Sultan Suleiman I, his wife Hürrem Sultan (Roxelana) and their daughter Mihrimah Sultan are all in the complex.The district also the Süleymaniye Hamam (bathhouse) which is open for the public. You want to have a Sultan's bath experience? Try it.Walking down towards the local market street, you will be able to experience the Istanbul hustle and crowds. Just be wary of the surroundings and walk smart; I felt safe walking as there are numerous police presence in the area.
Beautiful district must go around it on foot. My third trip but I still want to go there again next year it's that nice of a place people r very nice & friendly food is excellent

Exploring the District of Sltanahmet.. Oh my God, my wife wants to stop in every corner of this District, My wife is in love with this Area. Lots of shops/Restaurants, and friendly people around. You travelers must take a tour in this District otherwise your visit to Istanbul is not counted as a complete visit. Come and visit and don't forget to enjoy it all.

You should have good shoes. It takes a lot of time to walk around this district. There are a lot to see, from old churches, to small little streets. ANd of course there are a lot of small shops everywhere. To have a little rest you can take one of the hundreds of restaurant.
Spring in Istanbul. Great area of Istanbul, so much going on. Experiencing hundred of years of history was simply amazing. Love Istanbul, can't wait to go back.
Nice place. When you have the Blue mosque and hagia sophia in the area ...A very nice place to walk in the evening aftersightseeing. Lot's of place to eat or have coffee
amazing in every way. Sultan Ahmet is one of my favourite leaderrs in the Othoman history and his mosque is very beautiful very rich with History

Safe.... But take precautions. This is an amazing part of Istanbul. It's the area that contains the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern and the Grand Bazaar. No visit would be complete without visiting all of these places, so Sultanahmet is a must. The area has the feeling of being very safe. The majority of people are either just going about their daily business or sightseeing. But beware, just below the surface some danger lurks. This comes in the form of the numerous scam artists. Conversations will begin with 'hey where are you from?', 'hello my friend are you lost' etc. If you engage a very strong and sophisticated scam will start which could involve them befriending you, buying you a slap up meal, drinks etc before hours later scamming you out of thousands when they get you into a nightclub. Just be aware of it. Decline politely and don't be drawn in. You are not even safe from these people in the grounds of the mosque. They will follow you if they think you are worthwhile. So when approached, take note of their clothing and who is with them. The a couple of minutes later check around you to see if any of them followed you. My group were followed and we were very aware and security conscious. Make sure you keep wallets etc in your front pockets. Terrorism is also something to be aware of in this area. In early 2016, a suicide bomber targeted people near the fountains. This is of course incredibly rare and the Police presence has gone through the roof. The above might put you off, but don't be disheartened. It is definitely worth the visit, the locals are genuinely glad to see you. The current lack of tourists due to the bombing allows for some real bargaining power but it also means that the restaurant owners are desperate to get you through the door. The harassment from staff outside restaurants can put a real downer on a visit. Of course it is far from being a phenomena specific to here but if like me you enjoy minding your own business and soaking up the atmosphere, it can be a real pain in the rump. Even when you politely decline I have noticed with the younger staff a willingness to get sarcastic and rude. Sometimes you just need the patience of a saint to enjoy a holiday.

never expected it to be so beautiful. wonderful area, just walk along and wait what comes next, let it happen, during the day, at night, doesnt matter, wonderful wonderful wonderful.....i´d love to come back

The heart of historic Old Istanbul. SultanAhmet is one of the districts you just can't get tired of in Istanbul. Every time you discover something newPoke around come prepared for thrills and excitement. The historic places mosques museums. The music, the Sufis twirling, the historic information it's as if you been propelled back in time when life was so much simpler.The cafe staff chanting to you flaunting menus of delicious food / BUT watch out the proof of the pudding is in the eating! The jewellery, the leather good and souvenir shops ..The fun starts the minute you step into a store, everyone claims his goods are the best in town. Bargaining and haggling over prices of part of the fun.A trip to Istanbul without visiting SultanAhmet is quite impossible..

One of Our Best Experiences. This is the best place to stay, eat, and enjoy the historical sights of Istanbul. The architectural styles are beautiful. It is the location of the Blue Mosque, The Sophia, the Basilica Cistern, and wonderful, ancient remnants. Food was excellent, with many different streets lined with sidewalk dining. Shops are never-ending and loaded with interesting merchandise. Shop owners never give up trying to get you inside, but smile, be pleasant, and enjoy the experience. We had more fun talking with shop owners, hotel personnel, and the general population than anywhere else in the world. The city welcomes Americans. We loved all of Istanbul, both old and newer areas. It is an easy city to navigate on foot and with the local transportation systems.

Great Place. Marvelous Building, Massive and as big as you can imagine, I didn't like the smell of feet inside as you are asked to take off you shoes before entering ... yet it is a great place to visit
Nice. We enjoyed our visit to the historical attractions, we enjoyed the trip and nice weather, little rain here and there... But overall, nice holiday in Istanbul

Where you'll find the attractions.... In this district you will find the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, The Blue Mosque and several other attractions. There are also several cosy streets and some grand squares. But where to pick a hotel, choose the Beyoglu area instead.

Full of restaurants, bars and shops. We found ourselves in this district after wandering around the Grand Bazaar and spent a pleasant 2 hours sat at a sunny table of a restaurant. However, when we tried to find it again the following day, we got lost and never did find it!

For tourism purposes only!. It's the part of Istanbul with all of the attractions, but if you like a tipple of an evening, you should really stay on the other side of the river as it's incredibly hard to find alcohol in this district.
Great to explore. We had so much fun exploring the Sultanahmet District, there are amazing little shops, an abundance of restaurants and Turkish delight sellers! And it's romantic at night!

Beautiful. I was unsure to visit Turkey, safety was a concern, especially since the latest events in Istanbul, but I decided to go ahead, because I've been wanting to go for a long time. I gotta say that I felt really safe overall and everywhere I went. There were security checks in all the tourist attractions that I visited. And because not many tourists are visiting Turkey (which makes me very sad, it's hurting their economy relaly bad), all the major sites were almost empty, I could see everything that I wanted to see, without long lines, or waiting time. You can book an old city tour or visit on your own, but definitely a must see. I personally used a company used Rock Valley Tours, and they planned all my tours in Istanbul, Capadoccia, Kusadasi, Pammukale and Ephesus. I loved having a tour guide; I loved the Ottoman period. Hopefully you get a tourist guide that knows a lot about history, if you are into that. I would definitely visit again. Turkey is a beautiful country, with so much history and so rich in culture.

5 days . We could have spent more time here. There are so many historically important sites that one must prioritize by reading or planning. The Romans in particular left an impact here but the Turkish people have developed their own heritage that must be experienced.
The core of a magnificent city. Very interesting historical sites and to the west a lovely residential area with classic Ottoman houses

Great place to walk about. We stayed at the Sultania hotel which was outstanding. It is placed smack in the sultanas eat district. You can walk to a significant amount of the major attractions. Interesting busy place.. Its touristy, because the attractions there and there is no where to escape it. Being so, remind yourself of the price and cost. There's always tourist around (this time of year perhaps?) and it seems as if there's no low to it but thats just my lack of experience. First time here there's plenty of place to go ear and see, all of the tourist spot are nearby within walkimg distance and 2 days full exploring is good enough for me.
The place to be!. Book a hotel here if you can, you will have easy access to many of the incredible sites that Istanbul has to offer!

Cultural visit to Istanbul. We stayed in this district and felt very safe the whole time. There is a visable presence of the policy but we want this in this day and age.Lovely area of the city, clean and friendly.

A must visit.. A few words will suffice. The extended area is quite literally a microcosm of world history. Istanbul had been worth fighting over for thousands of years and begs the question why.Major powers and religions have had an interest in Istanbul and it's neighbourhoods. The extended area at Sultanahmet with its spectacular views over the Bosphorous has to be seen to be believed.
Walk away!. Walk around and enjoy the views and the mosques. Plenty to watch. Plenty to eat. The place with all the attractions warrant a minimum of 2 days of sight seeing.

Great experience. Fantastic experience to move around this area especially if you have a local for company. Lots of interesting places to visit, shop and dine. One of the must visit areas of Istanbul.

Perfect place to stay in Istanbul. We stayed in Sultanahmet area while visiting Istanbul. It was super easy and comfortable to visit all the areas of importance (they are all walking distance from here), the food was great, transportation to and from was easy.

Sultanahmet...the place to stay!!!. its a good place to stay! It was during tulip festival and the whole place is so colorful...Travel Bazaar helped me a lot to plan my itinerary around the area.

Majestic and beautiful. Good all the time, Inside and out, its so powerfully majestic. Walking around at night is a marvel too when the minarets have a wonderful immumination.

A walk into the times of Ottoman Empire. This place is FULL of History and Amazing Architecture.. An amazing place with so much history. Cant miss out on the history of this place, its a must see and possibly one of the most beautiful districts in Istanbul. With so much history and such beauty I would suggest to read up on majority of the highlights so you are aware of where you are and what has gone on it all these areas, its amazing!

Sad but secure. There very few tourists when we visited. Security was tight but discreet. Good value to be had soaking up the history of the area and in taking photos or in buying good quality souvenirs.
Fascinating area. loved the mosque and the bazaar was fabulous for anyone that is a shopper with textiles, kilims, bags and so much to choose

What a Delight!. Best place to stay in Istanbul, with easy walking access to most historic sites and some decent restaurants. Quite a different experience walking around Sultanahmet Square by day and by night (with fountains and buildings all colorfully lit up).

Amazing old town of Istambul. Start your tour from here. Number of museums are based in this place. Take a free tour, which starts at 10:30 next to the round fountain between Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque. Enjoy the sights and don’t forget to take pictures!

Best place in Istanbul . I was there for 5 days, my hotel was really nice and this quarter is really peaceful. You can walk by day or night with your girlfriend or family without trouble. I think it's the best choice for an hotel because you will find everything in this quarter like blue mosquee, the palace, St sophia... the big bazaar and many restaurants!

Preferred Location for Staying. We visited Istanbul for 5 days and explored all the different areas and neighborhoods. By far, this area, although touristy, is the best to stay. There are so many restaurants and shops within walking distance. Also, it is easy to visit the Topaki Palace, the mosques and even take the metro to other locations throughout the city. Everything is very contained, and people are friendly, even if they don't speak your language. It is very safe to walk around at night and restaurants are open late in case you want to sight-see and don't have time to eat until later. I found the area charming during the day, but really romantic and electrifying at night. We even found it nice during the rain (which is did a lot during our stay!).
Full of life. The place is full of tourist attractions, restaurants, mosques, museums etc. It's vibrant and beautifull. A must see
History. Beautiful area to visit,feel the ambiance of the old city, museums art galleries, parks all around istanbul is beautiful...

Beauty and diversity. It is no wonder that Greeks, Romans, Christians and Muslims fought over this city for centuries. It's location and geography is stunning to this day. The 2 main mosques in this district are imposing and seem almost designed to be part of the landscape. The Ottoman domes and architecture blend into the surrounding landscape like the hills that surround the city. It is a pleasure and adventure to wander the many streets in this district from the Hyprodrome to the TokapI palace and down to the Bosphorus.

The historical district of Istanbul . Absolutely amazing district. Lots to see. I spent 3 days and still did not cover the whole district.Places worth a visit are the Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmed Mosque. There is a hidden shopping quarter from the square going towards the Galata Bridge or the second stop from the tram. Prices are a lot more affordable that at the Grand Bazaar.

Go there right after the last explosion to make sure you don't see the next one. Turkey has political conflicts with different fronts and explosions in Istanbul are not a surprise.
Not to make you worried unnecessarily but this district has been a frequent target in the past. Istanbul has many other attraction. Google and populate your schedule with other options

must go when u r in istanbul. this district houses many historic sites. a must go if you've not been there. must go places are Topkapi palace, blue mosque, Hagia Sophia basilica cistern. for food, must try sultanahmet kofte. the meat ball, lamb kebab, rice pudding is just superb. went there twice across 2 days just to savour the flavors once more

Fell in love with Istanbul in Sultanahmet. The old area of Istanbul is full of history and so many beautiful buildings. Quaint & Beautiful. Steeped in history, it is wonderful to roam the quaint little streets of Sultanahmet, and there is plenty to see and do. Visit the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, Haiga Sofia etc. Plan to spend a few days here to fit everything in

Historical walk, magnificent place. Flight transit allowed me to visit Istanbul for a day and the memory will last forever. Istanbul is a very beautiful historical cities, a mix between the east and the west. For cat lovers, you can see healthy cats and dogs almost everywhere in the city. There were lots of mosques and it was really soothing when the prayers were called. I managed to walk to the Blue Mosque before continue walking along the tram path towards Yeni Cemi, another beautiful mosque facing the Marmara Sea. Before returning to the airport for my next flight I managed to go to the Grand Bazaar (tips: just grab everything you like at the moment you see them because you will never go back to the same shop, it was huge and confusing! Another tips: prepare to haggle!). The tea was really really delicious and the shopkeepers were really friendly.

Don't be afraid. It is so unfortunate that the American press has made it sound as though the most dangerous place in the world is Turkey! The Sultanahmet District, with all of its historic sites, is an amazing, mystical, spiritual center if you are interested in the history of the world. There is more security, which is a good thing. When we were in Paris 4 years ago, there were soldiers with guns everywhere, and nobody said "don't go to Paris". The buildings are ancient, the history is available and present for the tourist who is interested, and the people are so happy, so friendly, so glad to see tourists. Of course, this is a tourist area, and the people who live and work here are happy to see tourists! The business people we talked to said their business was off by 80% or more, and they were so saddened by that. I never for one minute felt unsafe, even when I was walking alone and the tourist guides trying to sell their services were very forward, to the point of being obnoxious. Turkey is beautiful and Sultanahmet is the place to start your adventure. The hotel we stayed in was unsurpassed - Ottoman Imperial Hotel - the food everywhere was delicious, the attractions were reasonably priced and even though there were lines to get into the most important sites, they were unbearable. I would go back to Istanbul in a heartbeat and I urge you to go, too.

Must do visit for any tourist to Istanbul.. It is the most favorite and visited of tourist area in the oldest section of Istanbul on the European side of the city. So expectedly it is very crowded and bustling with tourists. Situated on the tip of a peninsula it is surrounded by the Golden Horn to the North, the Bosphorus strait inlet to the East and the Sea of Marmara to the South and has magnificent views from vantage points. In this area multiple tourist attractions are situated including Sultan Ahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque), Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia) museum, Topkapi Palace, the underground Basilica cistern, the Roman Byzantine Hippodrome, German fountain, Theodosius obelisk, and many more.This is a whole day affair and involves a considerable amount of walking. It is best undertaken with a tour guide to provide the important historical background of the various monuments and also to facilitate the visits in an efficient manner without wasting time or getting lost. We did these visits as part of our 10-day Turkey visit with Gate1 Travel and we were fortunate to have a very knowledgeable young tour manager, Oguz Atici, who had graduate degree in archeology and history. This background made his narratives all the more interesting. Oguz’ pleasant and courteous personality and helpful nature was very appreciated making our Turkey visit a truly memorable one. Highly recommend both Gate1 Travel and our tour manager Oguz.
Feel the Istanbul spirit. I was living in Sultanahmet and it is great location place to discover whole city by foot or using a tram. Many restaurant, shops and everything is close

Great Experience. The Sultanahmet District includes the premier attractions within Istanbul all within a stone's throw of each other. The Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace & Ayasofya Mosque as well as Sultanahmet Square itself are all there and very easily accessible. It is well worth visiting.

Sultanahmet. Very nice very secure their are security all over the place so it's safe and people are amazing jus don't get into taxi instead take the tram as it's 50p per trip and will stop you getting ripped off by the local cabs you will need a tram card though and don't shop either as expensive in sultanahmet around bazaar area it's cheaper

Best Place to Stay. If you want to be in the middle of things this is the place. We stayed for five nights and had plenty to see and do. You are within walking distance of most main attractions. Couldn't beat it.

The best part of Istanbul, not to be missed. basically istanbul can be divided in 2 european parts and 1 asian part.Sultanahmet is the oldest one of the european's.It is were you can find everything you go to visit. And all is within walking distance as wellThe blue mosque, the Haya Sophia,the hippodrome The cistern, the spice bazaar and the grand bazaar as well!The hotels on this side are more boutique type, smallerMayor hotels chains are on the more modern part of the city is.Is up to you where you want to stay but make sure to spend not less than a day or two around sultahnamet.

Beautifully designed. Amazing buildings, clean streets, many shops and bars and more importantly it is not your typical European old town/down town that you would expect. It is really unique and grand.walking around is an experience by itself with many picturesque places.

Sultanahmet District. Should have to see this place when you are in Istanbul. From taxim it is very easy to Access Sultanahmet District. Metro and tram or taxi...

Unique must be seen. So much to see in this area. Every day was an adventure. The state of the art transit system puts North America to shame. Grand and majestic. Beautiful historic buildings, loved the view, felt like coming home and experiencing something new all at once.

Amazing Istanbul. The frenzy of fear that foreign governments have recently flung at this magnificent city has perversely made our trip to Istanbul an amazingly wonderful experience. In bright sunshine, dense carpets of tulips and flowers made for a spectacular sight in the city. There were no crowds of foreign tourists, no lines for the major attractions. Restaurants with spectacular views have space when it suits. The Sultanhamet district is where we found the Blue Mosque,the Hagia Sophia and the fascinating Cistern. Gulhane Gardens are gorgeous, and the terrace cafe within is a great lunch spot. (We ere going to Topkapi Palace on our return in a few days.) The major attractions of the city are closely clustered, and easily accessible on foot. There are lots of guided tours to choose from, a terrific option where there is so much to be learned about the history and culture of such an ancient city. Turkish families and school tours go about business as usual, making Istanbul feel no more threatening than Paris or London.. . Turkish people are warm, friendly and helpful - a major contributing factor to a splendid visit. We can't wait to go back.

Best area to see. Lots to see here. The grand bazaar. Spice market. Blue Mosque. Probably the best selection of restaurants, but get use to each one having a person in front trying to get you inside. Most will take no for answer the first time. Highly recommend the Old Ottoman Café/restaurant. Transportation system is easy to use and one feels safe in this city even at night,
