Wonderful historical place . Sultanahmet area is the best district in Istanbul. Our choice was to stay in this area because for tourists this area is full of attractions, best shopping place and restaurants.

Must Do in Istanbul..!! Truly Anatolian..!!. This area covers Hippodrome, , Blue Mosque, Hagia sophia, Basilica Cistern.. We had to park our car away so Be ready for walking..Whole area is basically Fusion of Islamic and Christian Culture.. (Istanbul itself is mixture of Asian and European culture)... You can take pictures outside as well as inside but not in Mosque and palace.Do visit in Winters as it is good overall walking experience..May and September are best for visit.Fees are also ok.Overall Very Good experience..!!

Best place to stay, eat and visit sites. We stayed in as all hotel in this old district and we could walk to all the major historic sites in minutes. Not only that the best restaurants in Istanbul are in this area as well.

Worth a visit as its free!. For the day you plan to visit this mosque I advise even if your none religious out of respect to cover your legs, men too. And women cover your shoulders and hair. For myself it was as simple as a maxi dress with a cardigan and throwing a chiffon scarf around me. You will have to remove your shoes also. You are given a plastic bag to carry them in at the door. This is a must as part of the ritual for Muslims before prayer is to be ensure cleanliness (ablution). Therefore you can't bring shoes that have walking outside, inside. A wee pair of socks is ok once you wee move your shoes. Also don't worry if you forget any of this as there is a stall at the visitors entrance where you can borrow scarfs and linen skirts. Muslims pray 5 times a day and you'll be aware of these time by the call to prayer, during these times you cannot enter the mosque as a visitor unless to pray, out of respect. However there will be people praying on your visit as for some they pray when they can possible, so you have to enter the mosque from a visitors entrance once inside the courtyard. This grand mosque is very picturesque and once inside the grounds you feel a certain peace come over you as prayers are carried out and young children are playing, even an option to ask questions and discuss Islam with knowledgable imans. The architecture beautiful and the interior is clean cut. But in honesty it's not as gran as it appears, the mosque is worth a visit as it is beautiful to see but for myself it didn't meet the hype.

Sultanahmet, Istanbul. We visited Istanbul from 14th to 18th April 2016. It was really a memorable trip. I would like to write something about Sultanahmet.Sultanahmet area is the heart of Istanbul. You can find all the major attractions around you, at walking distance. Like Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Arasta Bazar etc. Big Bus tour also starts from Sultanahmet. Moreover you can find very economical hotels as well. You will not believe, but we booked a hotel there in just 210TL, for 2 persons, 3 nights. Room was also very good, with all basic facitilities, the only problem was the wash room was bit small, but that is pretty manageable. Weather was also awesome. Go & enjoy.

This is the must of Istanbul. This place is the must of Istanbul. There are many historical sites and buildings here and you can enjoy local cuisine and sweets,too. This old historical area is easy to walk around and there are many things to see so I think it takes a lot more time to enjoy yourselves. This is the must of Istanbul. There are many shops, too. The bathrooms in this area are clean.

Just GO!. The historic Old City of Istanbul is as full of great sites and things to do as any similarly compact area anywhere in Europe. A unique and truly wonderful travel experience, the equal of London, Paris, Barcelona, or anywhere else in Europe.We just got back for a week in Istanbul, and spent most of our time in the Old City. Because of the terrorism threat, the area was suffering. Hotels and restaurants were empty. Prices were dirt cheap. It was the best vacation we've ever had, bar none; and that's in 30 years of travel. The police presence is noticeable, but we felt 100% safe the entire time.If one avoids doing things because of a perceived threat, then the terrorists win. Don't allow this to happen. Go to Istanbul, and enjoy!

Beautiful but prepare to be hounded within an inch of your life. I enjoyed seeing the iconic sights like the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque, but having to fend off the onslaught of waves of annoying men selling trinkets and wanting to "let me show you my country" ruins the experience. If you're a solo woman traveler, arm yourself with sunglasses and a few phrases of a language that no one knows (Croatian is a tip I got online) to try to get them to leave you alone.

Step on the history. Far back history, different civilizations, religious figures, local diversity...You will love to spend a day, maybe you will go there next day. Lots of souvenirs. Blue Mosque, Saint Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Underground Palzce, Aya İrini and more,,,

The fascinating historic old area of Istanbul. We loved staying in the Sultanahmet area of the city. We walked to all the historic venues and enjoyed them. I would recommend that you buy a museum pass available at kiosks in the Tokapi Palace complex to allow you to enter all the museums in Istanbul. There is even a All Museum Pass available if you intend to visit museums and ruins around Turkey. We enjoyed the exotic flavor of the Sultanahmet area.

Touristy but still quaint. Some people love staying here, some don't and I understand both reasons. We love staying there because although it's touristy, we have an amazing hotel we stay at, there's a sushi restaurant there, and very nice restos and cafes.
Vibrant area. Area is beautiful full of restaurants and nice coffee shops also close to grand bazar. Transportation is easy and plenty

So much to see and do. We were based in Sultanahmet District for our quick 2 day stop over in Istanbul and were able to see all the main sites with our personal guide in a 1 day walking tour. Everything very close together and manageable

Very interesting. Apart from the fact that Sultanahmet is by far the area with the most interesting things to see, the neighborhood itself the other side of Kennedy is a real treat if you are looking for the real Istanbul. Its full of fine hotels, lovely restaurants and lovely little shops where you can browse in peace and buy some lovely stuff. The Arasta bazar is a little gem and is in this neighborhood. Enjoy Istanbul!! I certainly did.

An all rounded great historical Area. I've been to Istanbul Several times and i always make sure i visit Sultan Ahmet and Ortakoy Areas as they're Packed with Culture, Trendiness and Helpful locals!The Area is well located (in city center) with access to Trams and Bus Tours. it is also a quite area to stay in at night away from the nightclubs and bars.I'v stayed in Faros Old City hotel and was really good value for money in terms of room sizes, friendliness of staff and location, really suggest this hotel.

Buy a Museum Pass on your first day. The museum pass is a great buy 85 Turkish Lira, but valid for 5 days. It gets you into lots of places, cuts down on queuing and is a real bargain. It gets you into Topkapi, including the Harem, Hagia Sophia, Archaeological Museum, Museum of Islamic Art, Science and Technology Museum and loads of others. Oddly it doesn't work getting into the Basilica Cistern.

Lovely area steeped in history. This area of Istanbul is really beautiful. It is really interesting with so much to see and do. You will never see it all or do it all in even two visits. We have been on three or four occasions and only for the security situation at the moment we would love to go back again. One of our favorite things about here is the food. The traditional food is just amazing and there are many really nice small not expensive boutique hotels in which to stay.
Amazing . You must visit this area which have many attractions places like blue mosque. Aya Sofia. Grand bazaar and others
Very fibrant!. If you want to soak in the local life in Istanbul, I would start with Sultanahmet district. Very vibrant and walking distance to many point of interests.

A must visit . Sultanahmet district is soo pure Istanbul it is the real face of ancient Istanbul Restuarant Shopping Hustle busleIts a must visit place while in Istanbul Please also dont miss Eminono river ride

Istanbul in an Afternoon. We had a long layer and had just enough time to go down to the district to walk around and visit the Sultan Ahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque). History and culture at every turn.... So much to see and experience here and all within walking distance! Then it was just a quick taxi ride back to our hotel. Any tour book gives you the specifics of what to see and how to get there. Don't be in a rush!
Amazing place. It is an amazing place to visit. The whole district has her own charm. The historical places along with bazaars make this place really amazing.

Worth a visit . Lovely place to visit and watch the people of all nationality's go by. Drinks and food in the immediate vicinity cost more than just outside the main area. To the left side of the mosque (river side) if you will there is a small bazar very pleasant with some unique art and crafts which are very reasonable. Toilets I the area very clean and cost a very minimal fee 1 lira

Transport back in time. This area of Istanbul is the most visited by tourists and rightly so. It is definitely the most preserved area of the old Istanbul that nowadays is just a jungle of concrete buildings and skyscrapers with very little greenery left in between. Here you get a chance to see the ancient Haghia Sophia museum which was converted to a mosque from a church after the Conquest of Constantinople during the Byzantine Empire period. You can also visit the Blue Mosque which is a massive structure still used by thousands of Muslims during prayer time. In the same area you also get to visit the Obelisk, and the Serpentine column that dates back many centuries. The Topkapi Palace is only few minutes walk from these so you can definitely fill your day with the most famous places of Istanbul. Be careful with the some of the street sellers and shops as they may try to over-charge you for some of the souvenirs if they realize you are a foreigner.

This is the Area to Stay at in Istanbul. There are fine Boutique Hotels too.. The History in the Sultanahmet is worthy of a whole week of sightseeing. I did it in 4 days and feel like I should have stayed here longer.
Walking. This area is very hilly with cobblestone streets so can be difficult if you have a physical disability. I managed with a walking stick but I think wheelchair access is very limited.

Not to be missed. Learn about the worlds history and enjoy the incredible art and architecture of Constantinople . A guided tour is recommended. When exploring the bazaar patience is a virtue or should I say become totally ondifferent to the inevitable hard sell ?
great hostorical area.. I lived in hotel in this district and it was great to watch all historical places. I loved this area and it gives you the feel and charm of history.
Sultan Ahmet . Great historical place to visit...Gülhane Park. ..sirkeci... aga Sofya... just near around ...Free entire...
Nice but gets boring after a couple of days. We had a good time in Istanbul and our hotel. being in sultan Ahmet, we were here all the time roaming about

Take at least a day to walk around in a relaxed, safe and interesting place. Take the time to walk around, try to food, have a sit, and relax in this extremely nice part of the city. Yes there's lots of tourists, but also lots to see, and even more to enjoy.Give yourself at least a day to make the most of this area and be sure to get up into the bazaars as well.

Worried about travelling to Turkey? We felt so safe in Istanbul!. Sultanahmet is oozing history, it has been on my wish list for many years and despite everything in the media we went for it, and so glad we did, we felt so safe in Istanbul. The main attractions are the Blue Mosque, the Aya Sofiya and Topkapi Palace all in very close proximity to each other which is great. The only downside is that the queues can get quite long at Topkapi and Aya Sofiya. We visited Topkapi one morning and Aya Sofya the next morning and got there at 9am both days to avoid long queues and it worked a treat! All mosques are free to visit from dawn to late evening but closed to tourists during prayer times. Most of the mosques offer head coverings and long outer garments to those who are not dressed modestly enough to enter so all have the opportunity to see the beauty inside these magnificent buidlings. There are lots of shops and restaurants ( Sultan Kosesi, Buhara Kebab house, Massa were all lovely and reasonably priced). But my favourite bit about our visit to istanbul was the people. If it were not for their beautiful hospitality our trip would not have been as memorable. We were made to feel very welcome and loved every bit of our stay.

Sultanahmet Stay. If you are staying to see the sights this is the place to be. Everything is closely co-located. Very clean area - very well maintained and pretty public spaces. Glad we chose this fab area for our long weekend

rugs spices and more rugs. so many shops and so many selling the same thing. don't get caught up in following anyone to their shop unless it's in front of you and you want to do business! Mostly all the merchants were very nice

Heritage happy. The SultanAhmet area is in the Old City of Istanbul and towards the southern tip. It has the Marmara Sea on its south,the Golden Horn towards its west and the strait of the popular Bosphorus to its north.. It is this southern tip also known as the SultanAhmet which has been declared as the heritage site by UNESCO. It houses the famed Blue Mosque( or the SultanAhmet Ahmed Mosque),the Hagia Sophia, the Faith Mosque, Suleymaniye Mosque, Rustom Pasha's Tiled Mosque and also the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Bazaar, the Museum of Archeology, the Topkapi Museum, the Calligraphy Museum, the Turkish and Islamic Art Museum, Mosaics Museum and the Hippodrome to name the more known places. The SultanAhmet is considered the main tourist area as it has a cluster of artistical venues, hence although the European and the Asian side have more to offer, it is here that the tourism concentrate is found.
Great area - touristy. Good, simple area for tourists - a bunch of the "must-sees" in one short area - you can knock it out in a day - and that's taking your time ...
The sightseeing is out of this world.... Be it the Bosphorus, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Covered Bazaar.. you will be swept away! The food too is delicious!

That is the place where Istanbul inhabitants go. Do not miss to go in that part of the city. It is very lively, many bargaining people in shops. It is highly recommended to step in and let yourself go.
Spend half day. u can spend half day visiting sultanahmet blues mosque, hagia Sophia and at the end eat in some good restaurant that surround the district.
The. One of the main mosques of the city located insultanahmet square. No doubt very elegant. I recommend visiting

One day trip. A place MUST visit. It is better to visit it on Fridays. Visit the Aya Sophia before Friday pray. Pray in the blue mosque the Friday pray. Thousands are there. Visit the mosque area, then go to the grand bazar after that (15 mnts walk). Restaurants are all over the place. Long day activities, but it worths 😄
Sultanahmet district . I didn't spend time in this area but I walked past to get the area for the ferry ride on the bosphorus. It had lots of people around and great atmosphere and scenery

Famous, Ancient, Central, & worth a Visit. The Sultanahmet District is home to many of the world's most recognizable and beautiful mosques, the Grand Bazaar, and perhaps the world's most famous fish sandwiches (Balık Ekmek). Grab a taxi or bus to the Grand Bazaar area, wander Galata bridge, and tour Hagia Sofia or the Blue Mosque. The crush of the crowd in the Bazaar itself can be a bit off-putting for the claustrophobic, but otherwise this is a must-stop area if you've never been to Istanbul before. I personally prefer to stay across the bridge in the slightly less touristy and more modern Beyoglu--think West Village NYC, but, y'know, if NYC were 600 years older than Jesus Christ and had much cooler architecture--but Sultanahment always makes for an interesting visit.

Enjoy the sites - avoid the Carpet Salesman. This district is a hot spot of historical sites and museums in Istanbul. It also is a hot spot for people trying to sell all sorts of wares to tourists.We spent two solid days wandering around the streets of the Sultanahmet District exploring the Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Hagia Sophia, Art Museum, Grand Baazar, Topkapi Palace, and more. This area has a lot to see!That being said, you'll also get a ton of people trying to get your attention and come into their shops. At some points it happens so often that you'll actually start to impede traffic! My advice - avoid eye contact and if you have a particularly insistent person, a firm "Hayir" should do the trick. If nothing else, you'll have some interesting memories of the many creative ways people will attempt to strike up a sales conversation with you. My personal favorites, "Let me guess where you are from!" and "Excuse me, can you stop your heart for a moment?"

Snapchat: iimont. Beautiful & amazing weather ! The food is delicious ! Girls: keep your distance from friendly locals strangers approaching you. And enjoy the historical sites!

Amazing area, not to be missed. Sultanahmet is the name given to the historic peninsula of Istanbul which houses most of the Ottoman architectural treasures.The Blue Mosque - 'Sultanahmet' in Turkish - is an amazing building which dominates the skyline and the area which shares its name. The mosque is well worth a visit; admission is free, but you are invited (not pressured!) to make a donation as you leave.Opposite the mosque is the At Meydani, or Hippodrome, which an obelisk from Egypt and some Roman columns. The other end of the Hippodrome, Divan Yolu, has the tramline and plenty of places to eat and drink. Walk along Divan Yolu a bit further in either direction to find slightly cheaper eateries.Walking out from the mosque's exit you are confronted with a view of Aya Sofia - originally a church, then a mosque and currently a museum. There is a charge to enter the museum but there are some tombs in the grounds which are free to visit. Continue beyond Aya Sofya to the Topkapi Palace. The first part is free to enter, but you'll need to pay to enter the main parts.Also by the Hippodrome and Aya Sofya is the Basilica Cistern, which is well worth a visit. I can't remember how much it cost, but it wasn't much.Behind the Sultanahmet mosque are streets of old, wooden houses. It's worth a stroll down here.If you continue along Divan Yolu heading past Aya Sofya you will eventually come to Eminonu, from where you can get a ferry to Asia, cross the Golden Horn to Beyoglu or visit the Spice Bazaar and, if you wish, walk a little further to the Grand Bazaar.This area is amazing and you could spend a whole week just in this part of Istanbul without getting bored.
Amazing place. Its quite place Full of historyMost needed places are beside u & u can visit them by walking Accessible to other touristic places through a large range of transportation options

Even though the square was the site of bombings earlier 2016, it is a not to be missed area. This district is the heart of Old Istanbul - surely one of the world's greatest treasure troves. We cannot allow crazed terrorists to deny us access to these landmarks. We see strong policy presence as we wander the streets and can only hope they work as a deterrent. The mosques, palaces and surrounding architecture are spectacular. Easy access via Tram from most parts of the city. Not to be missed.

Sultanahmet Area. The best sightseeing is to be had here in Sultanahmet area. I stayed just by Gulhane Park and it was easy to walk around to all of the museums and other venues. Lots of cafes and restaurants as well as the Grand Bazaar and other shopping areas.

Peacefull. I live this neighbourhood with all those museums which are on walking distance from each other, Kebab and mestball places aaaand those carpet Shops.Becareful about quality of the carpets :)

Stimulating area now with a danger warning. If tourists hadn't been bombed in nearby Beyoglu the day we arrived ( and in Sultanahmet two months before), and if the US state department hadn't increased its warning to tourists, my impression wouldn't be colored with any poke of danger, but because of these events, it is. During our six days here there was always a little question of "what's up next?" over our shoulder, which isn't the best way to enjoy a city. We usually go off exploring without much worry, but in this current time we stuck to the main sites where police were visible and where metal detectors were in use. The good news is that during our six days in Sultanahmet, we enjoyed staying in a hotel where the main old city sites and museums were within walking distance and we found we could walk anywhere we wanted to go. We enjoyed walking alongside Istanbulites and sharing in the exercise of going up and down hilly cobblestoned streets, and we found the area very easy to navigate.The city's exotic buildings, restaurant aromas, people in varied modes of dress, and street car and tram buzz make it a stimulating place anyone can revel in. All the most interesting, fascinating, and eccectic historical sites are here. The Turkish people are friendly and hospitable. Let's hope these troubled times pass away quickly-- for the citizens' and the tourists' sake.

A District From History. it's an district where you will always love to walk from a place to another without feeling bored or tired, you will always enjoy walking between the nice views, or historical buildings, read here make a picture there, sitting, watching, active life.it's a nice area that it's full of historical places, nice restaurants, friendly people, easy transportation (Bus, tram, metro, Taxi)you will enjoy it by visitingHagia Sophia (Buy tickets to Enter)Sultanahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque) (free to Enter but to enjoy it so better not in Friday as it's a holy day for Muslim people and still using it for pray)Basilica Cistern (Buy tickets to enter)Suleymaniye Mosque. (free to Enter but to enjoy it so better not in Friday as it's a holy day for Muslim people and still using it for pray)Topkapi Palace (Buy tickets to enter)Bosphorus (Golden Horn View) (you will need to pay for a boat)Grand Bazaar (Free to Enter)Egypt Bazzar (Free to Enter)Sirkeci Train Station (Free to Enter)Hippodrome (Free of Charge)those are the biggest landmarks in Sultanahmet district, that you can easily visit them all in Max. 1 and half days if walking or in one day if moving by tram as it all few steps from tram stations.https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g293974-d1652097-r360747828-Historic_Areas_of_Istanbul-Istanbul.html#

GO NO FURTHER !. SULTANAHMET SQUARE is the ideal spot for easy access to reach most of the major attractions in Istanbul, which can be reached on foot, including your shopping at the Grand and the Arasta Bazaar and all the small shops in the surrounding areas. It is close to The Blue Mosk, Hagia Sophis, Tapkapi Palace, Archaeological Museum and many more. If you like shopping, The Grand Bazaar is the bigger and better option of the two Bazaars. Merely follow the Tram Lines up the hill. It is about a 15 minute walk and is on your right hand side of the road. Take special note of save the position on your Google Map on on arrival. Finding your way out of the bazaar and to the Tram Line once again can be a daunting task if you have not pinned your position. Starting at this enormous Grand Bazaar, it can be followed right through several other Bazaars and down to the Spice Bazaar, which is close to the waters edge of the Bosphorous sea. Prices in the Spice Bazaar are more attractive than in the main Grand Bazaar. Sultanahmet is also within easy reach of the Trams and Metro Stations. This would be the best area to look for accommodation in.

History is all around you. This is a must see if only to "feel" the history of the city and it's activity. This place has been buzzing for the last 800 years and it will hopefully still buzz in 800 years.

Mesmerising!. This place takes you back in time. The blue mosque and hagia sophia are the best places to visit. The street is lined up with small shops and cafes which makes the district more beautiful and worth visiting.

A great Walk around to see all the great landmarks. It has all the major landmarks, lovely to walk and stroll around in the evening.
there are quite a few decent hotels as well near by.
lots of places to eat.
history lovers. Excellent place. Excellent Roman Byzantine and Ottoman work of art.History goes back to ages here..Friendly people ,nice food .

Good place to spend some time in. The old city in Istanbul has an amazing old buildings that can visit and enjoy knowing something about history and architecture. It's a famous area with it's small hotels and Turkish food restaurant....at night it's quite area with no noise where you can relax if you want to sleep little bit early at night.
This is where the blue moske is. The big area where all tourists gather, be warned do not follow a carpet sales man or they will try and push you to buy things.
The mosque. History and architecture of tha Ottomans in its best. The square qas busy and the visitors are from all over the World.

Beautiful part of the city where history meets modern life. I'd recommend this district to visit. It has many historical and cultural places, just like the Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Hagia Sopia, and many many more.

A lot of Attractions but Dont eat there. The area is full of historical Area like TopKapi, Sultan Ahmed Masjed and Aya Sofia its very nice, but i dont recommend to eat in the main street of Sultan Ahmed, coz it over priced.

Blue isn't Blue. The first place that I wanted to see when I get in Istanbul. Outside the mosque is very picturesque but inside is still under construction. But all in the place is amazing and really great.

Lots to Do / But be quick. . This is the real tourist centre of Istanbul with the Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar & Topkapi Palace all very close.
There is lots to do / buy here, but be quick as the museums close at 4pm.
Nice Historical Area.... I strongly recommend to stay in one of hotels of this area while staying in Istanbul. Staying at Sultan Ahmet area you will feel that you are in 1001 nights tales.

Beat the Crowd in the Morning. I spend 9 days in Istanbul in March of 2016. On at least half those days I spent some time in the Sultanahmet district, walking the streets and taking in the site. I started as early as 8am and stayed as late as 7pm, and I can say that the mornings are truly special. Topkopi, Hagia Sophia, and Blue Mosque are peaceful just after they open, before the tour busses and tour groups arrive. Vendors are more relaxed, photos are easier to take, and if you’re luck you can even find a quiet spot. If you’re a foodie, make sure you do your homework ahead of time to scout out the best places to eat – it’s difficult to tell the difference between tourist trap and established top-notch eatery in the Sultanahmet district. (Check out Culinary Backstreets app, and of course Trip Advisor). Don’t forget to visit the lesser advertised attractions, too, if you have time!
Excellent. Not only this place is beautiful but over all Istanbul itself is very beautiful. Love to visit again.

The Tourist Centre of Istanbul. What a contrast - we visited this area in 2012 and then in November 2014. Then the square was teeming with tourists; traders were everywhere and indeed were quite intrusive. February 2016 tells a different story - few tourists, small knots of plain clothes policemen in flak jackets, armed police and no traders to speak of. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, The Cistern Basilica and the Tokapi Palace are all centred here; the hop on/hop off bus terminus too and the grand bazaar is easily reached from here. Check out the great obelisk, the serpentine column and the more recent German fountain.
Oriental Perfection. If you want to see the "Istanbul" this is the place. Center of the old city, certainly will come again. The historical mosques and palaces are a must see
Visit. Absolutely stunning city Loved every second here with the wife will definately be coming back for more wow factors
Good Vibe. I like the vibe of this place. Very lively! I enjoyed the old feel but with some specks of modernity.

Local Variety by the River . Here there was a gorgeous mosque but the surrounding area had a bazaar style setting where you could get all manner of things including some of the best Turkisk Coffee and Turkish Delights, spices, foods and so much more. From here you couls also see the Asian side of the city of Istanbul in the distance and it also has easy access to the metro and boat tours as well as seafood restaurants.

Must go place once, but once is enough. Very exotic, mixture of orient and west world, Ottoman and Christianity. However, there are too many tourist traps and people. Carpet sellers are disturbing while I'm enjoying the city view, and numbers of people told me his cousin is in Tokyo or Osaka even I didn't speak to them in Japanese... and Hey! I'm a legally migrated U.S. Citizen!By the way. I've been there after the previous terrorism - suicidal bomber killed several tourists. Now there are numbers of policemen keep this area very safe and clean, so that you will have lesser chance of encountering pick pockets.Also, newly installed restroom is very nice and clean. You can even pay for it by your Istanbul Card which is a travel card for public transportation. This is very convenient and smart, I thought.

Stunning sites and market. A must visit when in Istanbul. I don't think staying in the hotels at the area is my type of thing, but walking around the market is definitely my type! Beautiful markets, commodities, and bargains. The egyptian market and sharkan are also in the same area. They r mostly closed on Mondays so visit on a different day. Good restaurants are also in the area but check the menu for prices first, some small restaurants try to charge u a fortune by introducing tea and sandwiches for triple the price without showing u any menu for the prices.

lots of history. So many things to see in the Sultanahmet District of Istanbul. Fantastic historical monuments with plenty of information about each site.If you want to go to the Basilica Cistern and Ayasofya make sure you go early to avoid the queue

All in One in Istanbul. Greater place to visit in Istanbul. Lot of local stuff on offer here. Grand bazaar, spice bazaar, Blue Mosque, Aiyya Soffia, and two continent bridge view. You need a full day for site seeing, shopping and of course while eating.

Many attractions in a tourist-oriented place.. Attractions as Aghia Sofia, the cistern and Blue Mosque, and many good restaurants, and coffee-shops. A good choice to spend some days nearby, or visit for a whole day.
Be careful of any hidden charges in the tourist-oriented shops!

A Beautiful Place,. Make sure to dress appropriately. The weather is very hot in the summer and it is very crowded. If you are in Instabul it is a place to visit. Make sure to dress with shoulders and legs covered for modesty.

Good shopping and Tourist Options. Grand Bazar and Spice Bazar are decent places to get some good bargain deals. Lot of local stuff on offer here.
Grand bazaar, spice bazaar, Blue Mosque, Aiyya Soffia, Cistern, Topkapi palace.. all are in this district and one can cover them walking.
so touristic. I really love this place! it seems so crowded, so alive. Lots of tourist places very close to each other, great walking area with a fascinating atmosphere.

Touristy but convenient. I am glad that I stayed in this area for my first visit to Istanbul. I didn't have to take public transportation anywhere for the first couple of days because so many huge sights are within walking distance. Yes, it's touristy, and there are lots of people asking if they can help you find something, but I just kept walking. The restaurants are definitely more expensive here, and there aren't a lot of hot new restaurants in this area. But it was easy to navigate, and I'm glad I stayed here for my first visit to Istanbul.
Very busy and crowded street. The area is very busy and crowded you see waves of people going all around but their is lots of stores and you can find whatever you want

A district that has all kinds of entertainment. This district is probably the most touristic district of Istanbul. Here are all the main things to see and it is loaded with all kinds of restaurants. Everything in an area that can be reached on foot. If you want to travel further there's the subway or tram or if you'd like there are the tours by boat on the Bosporus.

Walking on the rain!. Crossing the bridge over this body of water is just an amazing experience. Both sides of this bridge are fishermen holding their fishing rods. Some sell their fishes and some just do it for fun or for personal consumption. Dont forget to bring good camera. Dont miss any view. The wet market is just around. Fresh sea fishes, any kind of cheese, pickled olives, manually grounded coffee and bazaar.
a must-see. when visiting Istanbul, the blue mosque is a must see, it wont take too much of your time, maximum 20 min...
Beautiful . The most beautiful place in Istanbul. I like a lot these place and highly recommend. You can take the tourist bus from here!

My dream of a shopping place. After traveling through out of ten countries, Istanbul beats European countries in the shopping experience, not even the Flea Markets are as amazing as the Sultanahmet District

Blue Mosque. Many tourists came for visit
Nice view
Great place to hang around
Good street food can be found here
Cheap as well

Nice neighborhood for travelers. Visited Istanbul in June 2015 and stayed here. The district is filled with restaurants and cafes, some good and some average. There's a lot of travelers, backpackers and hostels here so the atmosphere is young and bohemian. The big square is filled with tourists by day and with locals by night. Good walking distance from a lot of main attractions. Would stay there again!
Blue mosque sultanahmet. Sultan ahmet district near by area is must place to roam around ,lots of old and new shop with local lamps and handicraft

An interesting area to explore. This old part of Istanbul is very interesting to explore, therefore it's ideal to stay here as your starting point. There are must-see attractions in this district such as the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofia. This district also has small bazaars and a tram/train station from which you can ride to other places of interest.
reliving history. On our visit to Istanbul we were able to walk around many of the historic sites in this area. We felt safe and in no danger while taking in all the sites.
Great place to stay. Greate place to stay in istanbul, its really close to every where, you can go to eminonu by tram, go to asian side by marmaray and...

A must in Istanbul. You haven't really been to Istanbul if you don't got here. This is where a lot of the historic buildings are such as the blue mosque, the palace, Ayasofia and the Basilica Cistern.

One of the most interesting places that I have visited. Sultanahmet square is truly a remarkable place to visit. Everything from the Mosque to the Palace, Market places, Restaurants can be found here. I loved and enjoyed every minute of my time spent here and would highly recommend it to every visitor to Turkey.

Wow! History and Excitement all in one spot. Stayed at the Empress Zoe Hotel....Loved It! The people are nice! The Sultanmet district will Knock Your Socks Off!
So much to see in such as small area. Felt safe all the time we were there. Try a traditional Turkish shave!
Go in April as it perfect temperature and the tulips are out!

Cozy streets with colorful small shops. I recommend you to see this district at the same day you visit Topkapi (my favorite museum in Istanbul).
Traditional shops and special Turkish culture along with spectacular view of historical architectures beside the sea will be a unique experience.
good historical place. Nice and quaint old worldly charm about this area. Gives a real feel of the Middle East which is otherwise lacking in Istanbul which is very European in character

Old Fort City of Ottoman Empire - Sultanahmet. Whole of Sultanahmet built like fort with walls three side and river front on 4th front. Old traditional single roads and lots of tourist attraction surrounding. A place to live and feels rejuvenating.

A great place. This is the place in Istanbul where you want to return again and again. Blue Mosque and Haghia Sophia, tasty street food and many people. This is a must see place if you are in Istanbul.
Not very Busy. As expected the area was not very busy, but there was a lot of security so we felt very safe. Everything was open and plenty of choice for local restaurants.

Wonderful area to visit. Visited the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi palace. These 3 places are virtually next to each other in this wonderful area. One must visit all 3. The Mosque from inside like the Hagia Sophia is beautiful.As a Muslim I prayed zoher sallath (midday prayer) here and afterward listened to imam (priest) recite the Quran. The echoes of the recitation around the mosque structure was wonderful. My two daughters also enjoyed the internal atmosphere. It was free to visit, but you can make a donation on exit. The Hagia Sophia was a Christian church, later transformed to a mosque by the Otamons, now a museum. Seeing the paintings of Christ and the Angels was beautiful. As Muslims Jesus a prophet, was respected and images were covered by Muslims due to no images of beings allowed in a mosque. The entry was 30 lira. However we paid an extra 20 lira each to get a guide who explained everything in great detail.Topkapi palace entry was 30 lira plus 15 lira if you wanted to visit the residential quarters.

The place to stay. If I come back to Istanbul, this is the area I will again stay in. Our first full day, we just walked around the area and it was a feast for the senses. Historic and convenient - an unbeatable duo in my opinion. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofya, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace and more all within easy walking distance. For early risers (that's not me) you could do all four in a day. Even so, other than a day trip to Ephesus and a boat ride up the Bosphorus (covered in other reviews - both wonderful tours), we never had to venture more than a half hour away to see everything we wanted. I would definitely stay in the Sultanahmet District on any future visit. (Our hotel - the Acropol - is also reviewed separately.)
Holy place . It was magnificent. Recommended. Generally I think the old city is better than the new city. Better view, better atmosphere, better and nicer street.
Beautiful old city. If you manage to get past the scammers, the pushy waiter and pushy shop owner its a beautiful place and a must visit in Istanbul.
Sultanahmet District. Amazing, one of my favorite memories in Istanbul was simply walking at night with a warm nice weather through all those little st.center of many tourist attractions.

Beautiful. Just walking around this area gives you a true sense of how old it is and all the history that has happened here. The mosques definitely dominate the skyline, don't be afraid to eat the street food, its amaing!
Beautiful,different, peaceful!. I have been there twice and each time i felt myself different,each time you can discover new things for yourselve! Definitely place to visit!
Historical. A lot of resturants there , good and cheap food , there is some historical places , dont be fool with shoe cleaners and some scammers there

Chestnuts and simits. We enjoyed the historical sites as Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia very much. And also enjoyed chestnuts baked at small stands and 'simits' (Tukish bagles) around the sites. We can't forget the tastes.

Clean, beautiful, and vibrant.. The district is clean, beautiful and vibrant. There are many shops and stores, however be forewarned that local businesses can be pushy and your best option is to politely decline unless you had an interest in the shop/vendor regardless. Many historic landmarks and the Hagia/Blue Mosque are located in and near the district, and the history is clearly felt. Definitely worth walking around - we stayed in the district, and have no regrets.

I could spend weeks here. I love this area; I love the restaurants, I love the shops, I love the magnificent mosques, the bazaars, the many stunningly beautiful cats walking undisturbed everywhere, the voice of the muezzins, the stalls selling pomegrenade juice or roast chestnuts, the monuments and the buildings... a must in any traveler's to-do list

Excellent area for historical sites, shopping, and food. This is a great area for walking around and experiencing a vibrant and busy city. You have proximity to the great tourist attractions such as Sultanahmet Mosque (and other less well-known but equally beautiful mosques), Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, and Spice Bazaar.The caveat is that Istanbul is a large and heavily populated city. So if you're not fond of crowds, you may feel overwhelmed at times. Tourism is an important part of this city, and it's unfortunate but not surprising that there are a large number of souvenir vendors and they can be aggressive and annoying.
GREAT PLACE. This area is always abuzz and flocking with people going about their daily work and shopping. An interesting area and a must see!
Quiet in February. Sultanahmet is on the tourist trail and can get very busy in high season, but it's just as stunning and much quieter in February! Just take a warm coat!

everything beautiful to see is here. this place is a must visit for tourists. you can find every kind of shopping, souvenir, jewellery, food and more here. it would take at least 1 day because its a big area and lots to do. wear comfortable shoes, try to choose a week day so it may be less crowded, hold onto your bags and valuables. bargain. enjoy.
Excellent destination. Beautiful area with lots of places to eat and many things to see. McDonalds, Burger king all close by

Touristy, yet full of huge history. Different feel compared to Taksim area, but always interesting to see the contrast. Everything is just within a walking distance, basically you can cover Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Basillica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Suleymaniye Mosque, Spice Bazaar in 2 days, top. Budget & luxury hotels are aplenty here, recommenedd to stay around Old city as this is where you're gonna spend most of your times while visiting Istanbul. Such a beautiful city!

Intense- a little overcrowded with shops selling same thing. Fun and exotic places for us coming from the US. Felt a little overwhelmed at times with the many shops selling same souvenirs and restaurant with same menus. We explored other neighborhoods to balance that

The heart of the spiritual Istanbul. One of the most beautiful places I've seen in my life. The contrast between the cold colors of the Blue Mosque and the reddish wal.s of Hagia Sophia are impressive. The call to prayer, thrilling

Great place to stay. Near all main tourist attractions (walking distance). If you want to see them all, you should stay in this area. A lot of good hotels, shopping around this area is amazing. Its also easy to get to the Taksim by tram and by boat to Asian side. I have been 7 times in Istanbul and I always stay in this area.

stay here in Istanbul. it was my second visit of Istanbul, a wonderland on this planet. I was fortunated to find a very reasonable 3stars hotel just in the center of Sultanahmet. considering my previous stay in Taxim area, i would highly recomment to pick Slt disctrict to stay as a tourist.

PSimple visit. Clean well maintained beautiful piece of art . accessible by tram.and funicular from taksim.sea view.a complex of multiple places half day visit in morning then head to grand baxar. It's full of things u can use for interior decoration and so many things.they always demand twice the price.always pay half of what they ask.move around in the baxar. U will find striking difference in prices.but I spent around 150 USD. Pomegranate chocolate is yum.must buy for urself and kids.its v delicious. It's on left side shops the moment u enter the baxar.
Well worth a visit. There is a great big bazaar down here that is separate to the grand bazaar. Definitely worth visiting as it is beside the main bridge over the Bosphorous.
Such a magical place. I was fascinating by this mosque, great location and holy spirit can be feel down there,There's not much to do or saw but still with of spending time on it

Lots of interesting sites in quite a small area.. An excellent area to explore; loads of historic sites and culture. Must visit Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cistern and Grand Bazaar - plenty of other sires. We went for a week and must go back.

Sultanahmet Neighborhood of Istanbul. Very nice neighborhood for shopping, eating out, sightseeing, and wandering around. There are a surprising number of things to see. It;'s a lovely area of the city.

Lots of history, lots to do & see, busy & touristy. I'd recommend staying in Sultanahmet because it is where as a visitor you'll probably want to spend more time while in Istanbul. It is also well connected with other areas with public transportation. Get up, eat your free breakfast and head out to explore the streets of the city, mosques, parks. Now, if you don't like busy places, or touristy places, or being hassled by souvenir vendors, buckle up and prepare yourself mentally ahead of time, or stay in another neighborhood and come here only for your desired visits.

Tourist Attractions. This area is filled with historical places such as museums, churches, mosques and bazaars. Not many locals come to this area except for those who work here. There are many restaurants but the rates are for tourist. Food isnt as exceptional compared to the modern istanbul or asia istanbul.
Totally worth it!. Great location with lots to see and do, close to city centre. A must if you're in Istanbul- can spend a good few hours here
Great for everyone but especially for photographers. This place is a photographer's dream. So much happening. Wander around and you'll find something you'll like, guaranteed.

Great shopping experience. I would recommend any one to stop here as the shopping and dining opportunities are a plenty. Don't even think of visiting other districts in Istanbul and missing this one as the cultural value if this place is on a whole new level.

Like being in a bubble. The area Sultanahmet is a mixture of old antiques and ugly :)As a first time tourist in Istanbul this area feels very safe, due to the fact, that all the major sights are close by, so you just have to move in a small area. I had the feeling, that this was not the real Istanbul. I really felt, that I was in a bubble of sights. I don't mean this in a negative way. After a few days, you will find you way around in Sultanahmet. I think the next time in Istanbul, we will live in Karaköy, as I got a bit more of an authentic feel of that area.

Family Trip. Great area to visit historical places, mosques, churches, bazaar and restaurants, very well maintained with cleanliness and ample place to sit down and rest, WC available, Fast food chains in the area, grand bazaar visit a must, and new tram service is frequent and cheap (Using Metro Card).

In Love with Sultan Ahmet . The Place where the Asia meets Europe with a vast population and amazing culture...First Visit to Sultan Ahmet was a Mark on my memories...Really Good place with historical monuments and city crowd Availble at a single stop....A Must Visit to the Sultan Ahmet Mosque or the Blue Mosque with higher roof tops and writings in gold...a few minutes to sit and pray will make you enlightened...located Near by Hagia Sofia and Sultan Ahmet Metro Station...Good and Amazing Food Availble here Specially for Sea food lovers and Wine drinkers or Alcohol lovers...a fine place to have Kebab Doner in Chicken or in Beef with Turkish Traditional Tea...Tea also aviblable in different flavours like mint tea pomegranate tea ..Apple tea is one of the Best and re freshening..Apple variety of flavours....every first person is a smoker and good place to have shisha or nargile or Hookah...it a smokers and drinkers and meat lovers paradise...will surely visit the place again...as a meat and Alchohol lover I enjoyed the most of my time roaming around the streets of sultan ahmet which will lead to another destination exploring different types of food...the Main highlight of this place is the sweet known as BAKLAVA made up of sweet syrup and pistachio and Kunafa which is Yummy made up of sweet syrup and cream and cheese...the market place and night life is also very good....will Visit this place again for sure....☺

Picturesque scenery. This is a great square to take your photos with the blue mosque and hagia Sophia as the background.
It is also near to topkapi palace and the basilica.
At times there are many dogs around this area but they are very2 tame and do not disturb people.

..that's where I stayed..... ..and I would suggest it without hesitation.. it's located in a rather old area, that inspite of being touristy, retains a heavy Turkish flavor. Located fairly centrally on the southern side of the Golden Horn, it's within walking distance both from the "Great Attractions": Gran Bazar, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque to the south, but also the University (which is brimming with life like all campuses and worth a walk through when students are in session), Little Hagia Sophia and a multitude of little shops, restaurants and even food trucks for the more adventurous, at night. A very convenient trolley will ferry you back and forth from Topkapi and vicinities, or take you to Galata and North along the European side of the Bosphorus. For the more initiated traveller, walking North through narrow and winding streets, one easily reaches the Fatih district, where the flavor becomes very Turkish, with decidedly fewer tourists, but places well worth visiting or simply checking out, like the Fatih Mosque and further North, the Kariye Museum with its spectacular mosaics and even further Eyūp and Pierre Loti, with its beautiful view of the Golden Horn and the City.If you venture to Fatih, DO NOT ignore the small and simply marvellous pastry shops that dot your travel: buy a few pastries here, a few there and eat your way through. Highly advise

Heart of ancient sites. I simply love Istanbul and have been there many times. I always go back to Sultanahmet and learn something. There are small shops, palaces, mosques and just grand people watching. Easy to get to by tram. I prefer the spice market to the Grand Bazaar which can be overwhelming.

Lots to do?. So much to do. We were able to cover most sites in a day. We hired a guide that supplied lots of information. Only down side was he made a few stops, i.e. rug stores, etc. I guess to make a little money in addition to the tour. It was okay though because we enjoyed learning about the art of the rugs. Quite beautiful.

Different streets cater for different trades. Wandered through here en route to the Aqueduct of Valerens. Busy market streets much better (and lower prices than the bazaar). But haggling is harder. The mosque is lovely too.
Busy area. This part of Istanbul contains most of the more important historical and architectural buildings. A must visit zone.

Perfect Location. At the last minute we changed our hotel to be right in the heart of this area and it was such a great decision!Bustling days, relaxed evenings and quiet nights were perfect for us and we were right in the heart of all the must see places.Cracking places and one we will certainly return to
Fascinating. Busy, noisy, mind the trams, but go there! It is interesting with a variety of places to visit and loads of paces to eat - stunning
Nice area. Very nice area to explore on foot, plenty of sites and small streets full of life and shops and cafés.

Its exactly what youd expect. Yes it is beautiful and grand and elaborate but ummm.. somehow it was exactly what I had expected.. like I had hoped to see more or perhaps feel more but... ermmmm not really..it just wasnt as peaceful as I had hoped!

A must see and perfect location to stay !. This has to be the must-see and perfect location to stay, if you are interested in the historical side of Istanbul. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi place are all within minutes walk of each other. Also, 15 minutes walk away is the Grand Bazaar... another amazing experience. We stayed at the Sura Design Hotel and suites - read my other review about the hotel, and you will see it is not only a great hotel, but the perfect place to stay, too.Word of warning - the hills are a bit steep if you want to walk further afield, say to the Spice Market area.There are no words to describe the innate beauty, peacefulness, and spirituality of the place - all summed up by the mesmerizing call to prayer.

Best part of beautiful town. I must say Istanbul is one of my favorite cities. It is really everything that I like, so much history and beautiful buildings, food that you can't resist and sea. Everything in one place.But for me the best spot in town is definitely Sultanahmet. It is all things that I like that are combined and made your visit incredible. Go to the Blue Mosque, and Hippodrome, visit cisterns below the Sultanahmet and dont forget Saint Sophia on your way. But also take a nice walk to the park, enjoy the flowers at Topkapi pallace and get lost in the crowd of Kapali carsi.At the end of the long day enjoy a cup of tea in the one of the cake shops and try delicious baklava (I prefer dolama with pistachio.And if you are some kind of night bird then do not forget to go to one of the local restaurants on special belly dance performance.And you have rounded your circle on Sultanahmet :)

This is where you should be!. Moving around in Istanbul isn't so hard, but if you are a history lover and need the tourist guide this area is where you should be! Close to all the attractions and a shows you a piece of old Istanbul.
Incredible history. We stayed in Sultanmet and we are glad we did. We booked a private walking tour with Turkey Travel Center and Mahmet was terrific.This was one of the best days in Turkey.

Must visit place in Istanbul. The Sultanahmet District is a must visit place. Great place to hang around where one can try the local foods, juices and icecreams. Shopping is pretty cheap with road side vendors giving good prices.

Stay here, eat here, sight-see here!. The Sultanahmet District is an amazing place to stay that is affordable, packed with action and has a BUNCH of amazing sights that you'll want to see! LOVED this area.

Beautiful. Indulge and be mesmerized by the beauty of the interior design. Dive into the history of the building while and appreciate the flavourful Kumpir (stuffed potato) that you can find at the stores nearby

every attraction here. they old buildings parks and streets are all fascinating there are many food outlets from the top quality to street food and pomegranate juice stalls the little shops and vendors have all sorts and the Grand Bazaar is right there as well

All in one. Saulanhamet has everything init, This is a buzzing place through out the year, Shops, Markets, food, drink and History all in one place. The fresh smell and street food with roaming local animal such as cats and dogs- all of which have been tagged to confirm they have been injected. So pet them and love them.
GREAT. Wanted to see this area for years it is just awesome very clean people are very helpful ,get yourself a guide and let him show you around

Istanbul's Iconic Square. It's very authentic and rich by most attractive spots in the city..
Again I have to admit it's popular and crowded with Syrian gangs everywhere , so please be careful here.
The monument that each visitor of turkey must see.... A great place that every curious person must visit to discover the heritage of the ottoman and Muslim civilisation....
History Overload. This area has so much history attached to it. Also there are so many shops around that you can buy authentic stuff at reasonable price
Very nice place. It is an amazing area because most people go there and they sell really good food. lots of history to see and the people are friendly

Amazing. We stayed in Albinas hotel, that's located in the heart of this district, and I can't imagine staying in any other place in Istanbul . The Sultanahmet District offers something for everyone. History, shopping, bars, great food, public transport is very easy to navigate and locate in this area. You'll be close to a few mosques and the Medusa head. Just a few stops away from the ferry piers, you can go anywhere from here. If you are going to Istanbul, stay here!
Great Historical district. Lovely place, full of historical landmarks and restaurants. Quiet at night so you can get good rest. Lots of tourists.

Most enjoyable and safe area to explore. We had a great time wandering through the Sultanahmet District. Nice shops and restaurants with friendly owners trying to entice people into their stores with offers of tea and candies. We visited on Sunday which was more crowded than a weekday in our opinion but very pleasant and well worth the walking tour!!!
very authentic. very nice and authentic , you have whatever you need local shops and restaurants and souvenir shops. metro station just in then middle of Sultanhamet area.a must visit in Turkey

History. yes, this area is a must see. Especially at night. It really comes alive with locals at night on certain streets where you can eat on the sidewalk and watch the interesting night life of the locals while you feast into the wee hours of the morning.

So much history in this area. If you only have a few hours to spend in Istanbul you can't go far wrong with coming to the Sultanahmet district where you will find a huge selection of historical, architectural and cultural museums and buildings.Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace and grounds, Basilica Cisters, Haghia Sophia, Carpet & Kilim Museum and much more.

Worth visiting. My first visit to Turkey - Istanbul. Excellent experience. Turkish hospitality was enjoyable. Thinking of Istanbul as a tourist destination seems a great idea. The district is simply fantastic, worth visiting. One needs to keep in mind that there will be plenty of locals inviting to get into their shops - restaurants, sometimes in a rather persisting and a bit annoying manner. There are many beggars, apparent refugees from Syria, which is not sad, particularly when small children are seen there even in the evening. IT is good to have change.To pay for restaurants and shops one needs to keep in mind that credit cards tend not to work all the time. There are plenty of ATMs, however, to overcome the problem.Traffic is a bit problematic, sometimes, and streets are not friendly to those with limited mobility. The park near the palace if simply great, worth visiting and above all, the great, breathtaking views of the Bosphorus and the city from the terraces at the end of the park where for 10, 15 or 20 Turkish Lira one can enjoy turkish tea for 1, 2 or 3 people while relaxing and enjoying.

Highlight of Turkey. This place was a perfect mix and match of old and new. The streets boasted of 400-500 year old buildings. Every nook and corner offered some interesting fact and history. Rich with the best tourist spots, this is one place you CANNOT miss!

All You Have To Do : Imagine. What can one tell about Sultanahmet District different than thousands of books, movies, travel guides, etc ? Well, being a local, an Istanbul fan and fond of history what I would humbly suggest will not be about what you'll be seeing. On the contrary, the most striking experience lies within what you'll not be able to observe physically. In fact, the neighborhood had been "the" centre, the heart of three real empires for 15 consecutive centuries. So, you can imagine how influential, colourful place it had been. Unfortunately, what can be seen today is just tip of an iceberg. The most interesting part is the completely lost buildings, temples, palaces and most importantly extremely vivid history of individuals : powerful men, women and the people, in general. There are thousands of real stories which goes beyond the imagination of wildest writers. All you need is little imagination and background reading. So here is my humble suggestion : if you have limited time you have to the "touristic musts". It's absolutely worthy. But you have to come back, this time for the "route supported by imagination" episode. If you have long enough time you can do both. I'm sure everytime you will discover more exciting things as I always do.

Full of scamers. Istanbul, particularly Sultanahmet District, is well-known in historical places. However, this is somewhat touristy. Furthermore, there are plenty of scammers who wander around. The classic conversation usually starts with "do you have lighter?" And if you reply them in English, they would know that you can speak English, then, they would try to make friend with you. Finally you will be end up in carpet shops or some night club which are truly expensive. Please be aware of the fake banknote as well. I got the fake 200TRY from Sultanahmet tram station.
Great area. This area is one of the greatest zones you should visit in Istanbul, the historical sense is clear in there.
So much to see!. Take the time to explore the neighborhood on foot. Look at the big stuff, but take the time to enjoy the locals as well!

Exotic for we Americans. We stayed in a 3rd floor apartment whose windows opened to a direct view of the Blue Mosque. After we ate across the street and returned to our apartment, the call to prayer began. I an agnostic Jew and my wife a moral Buddhist but we were moved to tears by the prayers. Many of the shops are beautiful but repetitive, as are the restaurants' menus. The food on our Viking ship was much better. Lots of meat. We especially want to point out Ernemet Carpets--a wonderful shop. The hospitality was exceptional, its products varied and lovely, with little pressure to buy larger as opposed to larger carpets.

Beautiful and lots to see. This is a beautiful part of Istanbul. We had the hotel there and five minutes walk to all the major sites to see. Lots to see, a bazaar, mosques, interesting people and streets and small shops to rest your eyes on things they sell.

A lot of important or historical places to visit. Really enjoy staying here, never regret to book a hotel nearby and everyday walking in this district, although price for food or stuff quite expensive here (shop in blue mosque area quite cheap) but near to everything
Excellent. Sultan Ahmet, wow! I love itIts hotels, its restaurants and cafés+shops.... Just amazing <3Pomegranate juice, ice-cream with special performances....
Nice!. I think it was one of the beautiful places I have ever seen! I took lots of picture there and I really love watching them!

Beautiful and charming!. This area was easily accessable by tram. It is full of gift shops and resaurants. The Sultanahmet park was clean and beauriful. We saw lots of tourist police around for your own security, but we felt safe, even though we were walking back to our hotel at night!

You'll be amazed how well the east and the west meet in Istanbul. This is the place where every tourist should visit to get to know Istanbul as a melting pot of east and west. Although the place is full of tourists (and locals), it doesn't bother, as the place itself is calming. The Blue Mosque is of course one of the main attractions in the area, but you don't necessarily need to visit it to experience the area. Just walk and absorb the culture. You'll be amazed how well the east and the west meet in Istanbul.

A little bit of everything . A very nice cultural district, very busy durin the day and nice for a hangout during dinner, very clos to Blue Mosque, Haghya Sophia and many sightseeing spots. Turkish baths are a must try, not to mention the Grand bazar, the real essence of turkey where you can find the souvenirs, do your leather shopping and find brands copies. A lively experience. Better though without children for ease of transportation.

Excellent in off season. Much quieter than summer tourist season. Easy to get into places if interest, restaurants/cafes and markets. We were warned about it being a very tourist centred location but, apart from needing to be able to resist the touts, it was a great experience.

Best of Istanbul!. If you're visiting Istanbul and don't stay in the Sultanahmet District, a visit or two is still a requirement. All or most of the most impressive and fascinating tourist sites are contained in this one area. Mosques, museums, the Grand Bazaar is very close-by as well as some of the best restaurants in the city. Take the tram into Sultanahmet and roam the streets. There's so much to see and experience!!

I can't wait to get back here!. We did a quick tour of the Sultanahmet District while on a 8 hour layover in Istanbul. This place is loaded with history and many beautiful sights. When visiting I highly recommend getting a tour from a local. There is so much to see that it helps to have someone to point out the highlights and teach you about the history. Tarik, at Istanbul Airport Taxis put our tour together.
Very rich. Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hajia Sophia are the most places of interest in Soltan Ahmet I really enjoyed my stay there in Albatros Premium hotel
Fantastic. Very nice. You get a fantastic feeling when you visit it.This is like a dream come true - very beautiful.

Tourist city. The places to visit here are plenty, many ancient structures and historically significant buildings, it would certainly save a lot of time to book a hotel in this area, as you can pretty much walk everywhere or just use the T1 tram.As a neighbourhood this is extremely touristy, lot's of restaurants, bars, shisha places and shops here, but it's also very touristy, the prices are reasonable for most places, but not really the place to go if you want to experience the local culture, even the very few places here where locals hangout are mainly for people working in this area serving tourists.
Lots to see here. Set aside plenty of time to see everything that this district has to offer. So much history. Lots of historically significant sites to see.
Excellent View. 20 minute walk from Taksim, no need to take Tram. Everything can be done by foot. A lot of stalls to eat, mosque is everywhere.

A lovely public space. We criss-crossed this area on our recent visit, as we were in a local hotel. It is a vibrant public space, with a beautiful fountain, and seats along all the paths to allow people to sit and enjoy the beautiful mosques around the square. It had a lovely, social vibe, and we were terribly saddened by the atrocity perpetrated on the day we left. The residents of the area are very welcoming to tourists. Please visit and enjoy.

Seeped in history - yet vibrant. Such a lot of beautiful and interesting places in just a few square miles plus some hidden gems if you've a mind to seek them out! Loved to walk the area - feeling totally safe. (Though transport system, via trams, is great). People are lovely - friendly, helpful and welcoming. And so many places to have excellent food at great prices.
interesting. Walking around this neighbourhood gives you a sense of what it must have been like so long ago. Fantastic and Interesting and very safe. No one bothered or harassed us.
All of this area is amazing!. I bet you want to return time and time again... so much to see and take in...you can wander for hours...more so if you love classic Turkish architecture.

Great District . Such an amazing neighborhood!Lots of historic places, museums, attractions. Hundreds of coffee shops and restaurants . The only bad thing is that the bazaars and most of the shops -if not all- close really early Try to walk around at least once in the night..
Great bustling Location . Really great place to stay if you want to be close to everything in Istanbul. Good restaurants nearby and close to Tokapi Palace, Aya Sophia, and Blue mosque.

Frenetic and colourful. Interesting architecturally with it's many tall minarets and domes.Lots of small shops selling all sorts of crafts. Lots of activity on the water as boats and ferries criss cross in every direction.

Istanbul - a "have to visit" kind of city!. What a city! I wasn't only in Sultanahmet ofcourse, but that's a big attraction in Istanbul and an incredibly beautiful area. I went there january, my third visit in Turkey, but my first in Istanbul. The locals/the people that lives around Istanbul (and also the other tourists) are extremely kind, helpful and willing to make your visit there as wonderful as it can be. The city is huge, and like you might know, splitted in two sides. The asian side is where a lot of locals live (that's where i stayed) and the more touristic european side. although it's very easy to go from one side to the other. I did that every day. On the european side, there is a place called Taksim and in Taksim Square there is a very famous and long street called Istiklal street where you can find aaall stores and boutiques you want. And if you follow Istiklal street far enough you´ll adventually reach the famous Galata Tower, which costs about 30tl to enter (very much Worth it!).If you wanna go to Sultanahmet, you'll go to Sirkeci (it's the metro station closest to Sultanahmet) and when you reach the Square you'll see the Blue Mosque, Ayasofya and several other museums you definitely dont want to miss! Blue Mosque is free to enter and the Ayasofya museum costs 30tl and if you want a personal tour guide it costs about 50tl.The metro station system is very simple to use! When you find yourself on Ayrilikcesmesi metro station, you can pretty much go everywhere from there, including the rail way system. And Kadiköy is only one stop from Ayrilikcesmesi with metro. So, Istanbul is a beautiful city with lots of culture, attractions and nice people! I truly recommend it. This was definitely NOT the last time i go there!

Exceptional Panoramic View. Sultan Ahmet is a unique place in the whole world. While there are many beautiful places in every country, Sultan Ahmet is distinguished by its peaceful and serene atmosphere. It is surrounded by historical buildings which offer an exceptional view and fill the heart with inner peace and contentment

Historical city center. The Sultanahmet area is where the main tourist attractions of Istanbul are. It is where the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Bascilica Cistern is. It is a must visit area in Istanbul. Other attractions are not too far from this area too. One can easily access the place on the tram too.
overall satisfied. did feel somewhat at home because of simillarities in cultural backgrounds. the souks are too tourist trap.

So charming. So beautiful, so much culture and history! One of my favorite memories of Istanbul was simply walking at night with a warm nice weather through all those little streets, beautifully illuminated
Most of the things in Istanbul are here. Its the oldest area of Istanbul. Most of the things in Istanbul are here, you can have your hotel here it will save you lots of money on transit.

Favourite place to stay in Istanbul!. Love the vibe here, awesome little restaurants and stalls with truly turkey culture! Extremely easy to get around with easy access to the Tram, taxis, buses, even walking!

A travel back in time. This is a part of the old city of Istanbul. The narrow alleys, cobbled pathways, old buildings and numerous historical structures, all these add to the timeless charm of this place. We stayed in this district for four days, and we felt that it was a travel back in time. Most of the major attractions are within walking range, and its such a pleasure walking around this part of the town. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazaar, Basilica Cistern are the star attractions of Sultanahmet district. No visit to Istanbul can be said to be complete without moving around this ancient historical district.

Classic!. Sultanahmet takes you back into time. The cobbled streets and architecture are simply amazing. It is without a doubt the best place to stay in Istanbul. I stayed at Hotel Tulip House and loved it.

You can't get enough of walking around. We stayed in Sulanahmet for a week. i really enjoyed exploring this amazing historical area...There is a lot to be seen there..... that even if you walked the same street for like ten times...each time, something beautiful will catch your eyes to find your self picking up your camera to take a photo.

Stay here for real experience. We had a cheap but very friendly and clean hotel in the heart. Only 2 blocks to the main square Haigha and blue mosque. Met a friendly local to show us around and had beers afterwards

pix from.my visit to Istanbul. nice IStanbul despite it was a very very short visit for just 2 days so fortunately i arrived to take these photos as souvenirs ...I plan to be another time in Sultanahmet nchallah in march 2016...
Quintessential.. Very desirable area for tourists who want everything at a short distance: attractions, dining, shops, do it all here.

Center of many tourist attractions. We had the pleasure of staying in this section of Istanbul for over one week and only touched the high points of all the things to see. It's a great place for tourist to stay. Some many places just within walking distance.
AMAZING!!. This whole area is a MUST see!! Beautiful beyond words and the people are so friendly and helpful, Enjoyed all of Turkey

The Heart of Istanbul. This is THE place to stay in Istanbul, although it can get noisy and bustling with the locals and tourists, and the traffic!Nonetheless, everything you need is right here, and well worth taking a good long walk around the area!Restaurants, take-away stalls, cafes are plentiful along the main street and down every side street too; the main attractions such as Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and the Grand Bazaar are all in the vicinity; there're enough souvenir shops if that's your thing; and both bus and tram stops along the main stretch too!Perfect area and a good spot to spend your time when in the city.
A place one wish to live at forever. I hope it stays safe and thriving for the sake of all people making a living all around the district by serving tourists and making them happy .
Amazing Religious History. This area is rich in history and amazing culture! The people are friendly and ready to help you find your way! A must see while in Istanbul!

Istanbul is worth a trip, wereit only for this area!. I happened to have to spend the night in Istanbul between two planes (from Canada to Switzerland), and my layover (almost 24 hours!) was sufficiently long to allow me to visit this historic and cultural center for a few hours on the morning of my departing flight. I was really delighted, and even impressed. I could see the Blue Mosque (unfortunately the inside was not visible because of a service), the Hagia Sophia Museum from the outside too (the ticket line was too long, and I did not have enough time, and the wide area in between. It was sunny and I felt blessed to be there.

Sultan Ahmet district. Main places of interest are located in the Sultan Ahmet district. But there are also some places of interest which are worth visiting. A market not far from the Blue Mosque. Saw a really huge radish there (just see the photo!). A fish market just the opposite side of the Galata Bridge. There is much different fish and just look at the size of Anchovy. They also cook it there. So you can try some fresh fried fish.

Location, Location ,Location.. If you are staying in Istanbul then this the place you must stay in.All the top points of interest are all in a few blocks in this area and their is good transport and many places to eat and shop.

Yes, the 3 millions daily visitors aren't wrong. Something for everyone. Accessible by public transportation. You can read lots about this area. If you are wondering whether it is worth the bother, please don't hesitate - it is !! You don't need me to describe the sites. You need me to tell you if it's worth the visit.... Clearly, it is!

THE place to go if you have limited time in Istanbul. The must-see historic area of Istanbul is worth the trip, even if you have very limited time available. If it's your first time there, you can do a mini-tour (even from the airport) during a long lay-over. The mosques, markets, and museums are not to be missed.
Historical places!. Hat tip: Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Tram Ride, Grand Bazzar, Topkapi Palace. Do not forget to eat :Doner Kebap, Gozleme, Dondurma
Very Safe - Very Clean. We stayed in this district for over a week - travelled the streets around midnight. Never once felt unsafe. The people are so beautiful and helpful.

Location location location. Friendly owner operater hotel, always more hands on.
Bussiness , pleasure, medical for what ever reason I highly recommend this hotel. Very compfortable
good for shopping and walking. like to walk there with family. noticed that the more you are far away from grand bazzar the more low cost items you can buy.
What a delight. This is a place to walk all over, get lost and enjoy all the history. It is clean and safe. Get a guide to explain all the historical details.

Love the Old City. I can recommend everyone to find accommodation at sulthanamet area!Aya Sofia and the Blue mosque and other historical treasures of Istanbul are nearby.Arasta Bazar is great to shop. You can easily take the tram to go to the other side of Istanbul. During spring or summer time it's nice to have a walk in the evening to visit the nice restaurants in the area or to make a nice walk at the boulevard.

One thousand and one nights!. This was my favourite area of Istanbul, a magic place, with so much to see despite being very compact. Despite the latest sad events causing terror and fear only two weeks after we visited, I'd advise people to go and visit this magnificent testimony of a glorious past where both the islamic and the catholic faith live in harmony, at least inside the magnificent museums and mosques.Sultanahmet is a neighbourhood of Fatih, one of Istanbul's districts. It contains some very unique and glorious buildings, among which probably the most visited are the Topkapı Palace, Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque and Aya Irini. The magnificent Cistern and the Hippodrome of Constantinople are also there.We managed to visit everything in 4 days with a private guide, which I suggest to invest in. There's so much to learn about his city, one needs some expert guidance!Sultanahmet is also very close to the Golden horn and is facing the Marmara sea, where all the Bosphorus cruises leave.
