It stops at the grand bazaar, Blue Mosque and near the archaeological museum and can take you to / from the piers close to the spice bazaar.The area has a great feel - it's obviously not just tourists that are here but plenty of residents live, work and visit here.
Must see landmarks, but overall not a great place in Istanbul. Nice architecture with must see sights, but overall it is far too touristy and too much pestering outside restaurants.

Also known as Blue mosque.. Unlike the traditional 4 minarets it has 6. Also known as Blue mosque. An excellent place to visit for the tourists. It was pretty cold while we landed in Istanbul. Though it was a business trip we hardly had time to spend for tourist attractions and tours.

wonderful place to walk day or night. Everything is in this area. Local people very helpful and friendly. We walked here day and night times and always felt safe. Local merchants are very pushy just like most cities full of tourists. Just walk by them if you're not interested in looking. The grand Bazaar is a must see but merchant are even more pushy. Most claim their goods are family made but not true and if they want to take you to their larger store it is always located a few hundred feet away and used by several other merchants. We were escorted to this type of place more than once by different merchants.

The "Concentrated" Tourist Attraction Area of Istanbul. The Sultanahmet District is definitely where you want stay when visiting Istanbul. From your hotel the many tourist attractions in this area are an easy walk to discover--Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, Istanbul Bazaar...to name a few. (There are so many tourist attractions next to or close by each other that we refer to it as the "concentrated" tourist attraction area of Istanbul.)
Lively old city. Great combination of the amazing historical places and local lifestyles with easy access by walk or tram. People were friendly and helpful.

Be prepared to wander and expereince the essence of Istanbul.. We have spent many days wandering the area and have so much more to see. Istanbul requires several visits to experience all the sites and the city's vibrant life. Don't be in too much of a rush so you can savour the sites, sounds, spice aromas, food, colour, history and so much more.
Area for tourists. I stayed there in hotel at may 2015 , this area is historical place , amazing view of mosques birds and weather
A must see. I cannot imagine a visit to Istanbul without visiting the Old City...it is so full of history, local culture and wonderful people

Classic Istanbul. At least that's what I pictured it will be like. Very crowded, with locals and turists, but a pleasent walk around all attractions is nice. We weren't with any guided tour, so we did it during 3 days at aour own pace. Many nice streets and places for everyone's taste

The heart of Istanbul. This is the old district of Istanbul. It is very authentic, but as in all larger cities there are too many people who want to sell you stuff.. Besides from that, it is a must do when in Istanbul.

Still charming.. This is my second visit to Sultanahmet and it's still is one of my favorite destinations. Lots of history within walking distance, good food, friendly people, affordable. It's changed a bit since my last visit, which is inevitable given that Istanbul has become one of the premier vacation destinations in the world, but still very charming. I'm sure I'll be back soon enough.
I loved it. What can we say,,,,,,,,it's fabulous, never can find similar place in the world, surrounded of everything you can think,,,,,,I realy wish if I can go back,,,,,,,,,best trip ever

Turkish Delight. Sultanahmet is a truly wonderful area of Istanbul. From the many sweet shops selling incredible Turkish delight to the ice-cream sellers who will make you laugh out loud with there special performance serving you ice-cream. There are many restaurants that are quite something and the food is so varied you are sure to find something you like. There are some that you can watch the locals making and baking bread right there in the window. There is also a McDonalds to make you feel at home. You can also take a short walk to the indoor Bazaar that is a must if you want to buy gifts to take back home. The banter from the sellers in the bazaar is very amusing and worth a visit just to enjoy this. There are also the many mosques to see especially the Blue mosque. You will find the Obelisk in this area too. There are many buses in the area to take you about.
Sultanahmet. I went to this beautiful place with my family and my young children we interested to see this place because I heard a lot about it ,so it was a nice day and we enjoyed alot

The best place to stay in Istanbul. If you are going to Istanbul as a tourist to see the sights, this is the place to stay. Everything is close by. Generally you can walk to any of the sights within 10-15 minutes. The tram/metro is also right there. Get an Istanbulkart and ride for $ 1.20 US.

Not to miss mosaics. In this area there is an hidden gem. It's a very small museum there preserves what remains of one of the biggest floor mosaics, I guess it's from the ancient roman age. Extraordinary details of animals plants ad men and you should also think to the original extension of it.

Best Historical places of the Turkey ..Maybe Europe. The Sultanahmet district is the heart of historic Old Istanbul, what 19th-century travelers used to call "Stamboul."
This is where you'll find Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Saray), Binbirdirek Cistern, the Istanbul Archeological Museums, Great Palace Mosaic Museum, and several lesser sights

Awesome!!. Full of history ! everywhere you look at you can see a mosque.. clean city and well organize compare to cities around, lots of good food everywhere just walk all across Sultanahmet during the night or during the day is a greast place to spend time in.
Good and safe place to walk. Have your roadside lunch or diner in the many restaurant allies. All touristic places close together
Fabulous area for visiting. This area has so much to see. Get your walking shoes in shape. Great shopping as well here as well as in the nearby markets.

very touristy and fun. this has everything for the tourists from local food to souvenirs and touristy buildings. it is convenient to check off the tourist attractions and it's close to the asian side of istanbul - just walk over any bridge or take the tram :)

Must visit!!. Whatever you feel like doing - it is all within walking distance. You will love wondering and exploring the area, whether it is the nearby mosque, bazaar or a restaurant, it is the center of the happening. Lots of local and tourists in the district, but it feels safe and comfortable in the same time !

Incredible structure. when you consider this structure was simply made for the storage of water the detailis at the head of the columns is incredable. Hidden medusaz's add a mystic touch but i didnt turn to stone when i looked into her eyes. Maybe the marble columns are of those who did so when it was being built.This is a fantastic site of ancient construction of outstanding engineering.

Everything in one place. There are quite a few attractions in this area so plan accordingly as some will take more time than others. Also, add time to get some food. There are lots of restaurants with much of the same thing. The vendors selling corn is a good deal for 2 TL.As for souvenirs, you might find some good deals in this area it just depends on what you want and how much of it you want. You can bargain if you're buying a lot of trinkets or the basic scarves. I found myself coming back to this area to get some souvenirs b/c they were more expensive in other areas or the selection wasn't that good.Sultanahmet Square is a nice place to take a break and enjoy the scenery.
It has everything!. Whatever you need it's there or nearby. It is full of people but still quiet enough. In the evening is a great place to go to nice restaurants.

A Lovely Place to Stay in the heart of Ancient Turkey. Blue Masque, Grand Bazar, Istanbul at it's best. Always something to do in Sultanahmet. I ended up staying her and was amazed that I never stayed home. I was alway walking the streets taking pictures. No matter which way you turn there's something to see. Some things can be a bit touristic but that's part of the draw.
Beautiful historic area of Istanbul. Well worth a visit to this area. Lots of historic attractions within walking distance of each other.

Awesome!. Very beautyfull place. The most part of touristic attractions are in this district. If you want to be a tourist at istanbul, stay here, if you want to live more like a local, go to Beyoglul.

Stay and live alongside the locals. Five days in Sultanahmet were the best way to see Istanbul and all that makes it unique. We stayed in an Air BnB apartment in short walking distance to the vibrant commercial district where we hopped on trams to visit all the ancient sites and anything of interest was so accessible. The cobbled alleys with the chaotic traffic added to the charm. You need a minimum of 5 days to see the old city and to venture over the Bosporous to the Asian side. Oh what an adventure awaits you.

Excellent. Sultanahmed is the best region of istanbul in my opinion . Our hotel was located in this area and really we loved them ...So traditional , so beautiful and also this region has many good hotels .
Take your time and enjoy. Walking in the district is soaked in history. You need to take enough time to enjoy all the sights properly. Amazing. We loved the old district-such character.

Staying in the heart of it all. I didn't know what to expect but fell in love with the history, architecture and the people were very friendly and great hosts. The food is so healthy and diverse. Great time

Amazing . Amazing place where you can see the mosque and pray there ... you can go out and sit near to the fountain and take a Fabulous pictures with eating grilled corn. You can continue by visiting the nearby places where you can find sovuniires , accessories and food .

A day is not enough. This area has tons of sites to see and places to eat and shop. We spent the majority of our visit in this district. We spent a day looking at mosques the next day shopping at the Spice bazaar and the Grand bazaar. The grand bazaar can be a whole day if you are a serious shopper. There are so many vendors and different sections sells different items. Give yourself at least 2 days in this district.
Interesting. All kind of shops and restaurants. The district is in honor of the conquering Sultan of Constantinople

Getting lost along the beautiful cobblestone streets of Sultanahmet District.... Spent four great days in this historical part of Istanbul. Hilly cobblestones streets filled with many shops, eateries, cafes, and other sites. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, and the Grand Bazaar are all within walking distance of many boutique hotels in the area. I highly recommend visiting and staying in this area.
Good for ppl interested in shopping & living like locals. This place is, I guess, the old side of Istanbul, as it is the hub of shopping places for anything. Staying there shows u how locals live.

Our Visit. Our hotel was in the Sultanahmet District. This is the oldest district in Istanbul, but is a very vibrant part of the City. Our hotel was at sea level and it was a bit of a climb up the narrow streets to visit the Blue Mosque, but all four of our party are old aged pensioners and the climb was very manageable. If you did not know before you visited Istanbul, it is built on hills, just like Rome and Lisbon. But as it mentioned before, it was all very reachable for us 'older' ones.

A wonderful centre of religion, history and architecture. Visiting the Hagia Sofia, the blue Mosk and Topkapi Castle is a must to see and learn about European History. A wonderful place to be for the cultural and military historian. The link between Europe and Asia. All sites very well kept and restored.
Historical istanbul. Lovely area to visit and spend a couple of days. All the sights are here - Hagia Sophiya, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, etc.
Where all the major sights are situated..... Slightly hilly area, where all the main sights are situated totally safe to walk around when we were there during the day.
It's great place!. You should come here for sure! There is many things around and it's on the way to the most sightseeing places in Istanbul. For presents you will find here plenty of stuff.

The centrepoint for everything Istanbul.. Whether its history, mosques, museums, monuments, views, hotels, restaurants, bazaars, shops, nightlife, boat trips, or anything else, Sultanahmet is the place to be, the place to stay and the place to eat. I wouldn't stay anywhere else in Istanbul.

I can die happy. I truly sent home 20pounds heavier and happier. The people were so nice and friendly. I strolled up and down the street soaking up my foreigners. The shops are divine and it is such an easy walk to everything. But just on case, the train is right there
family. nice place for family, every things around ( food soo nice) I love the place better than taksim, transportation by tram very easy to go to other places. I love Pierre Loti restaurant.

A site on every corner. We thought long and hard about where to stay during our visit to Istanbul but are really pleased that we chose the S district. It had a great atmosphere with a great range of restaurants and hotels, many tucked away on quaint side streets but within easy access to the main historical sites.

Best place for shopping and site seeing . It's strategically placed in the middle of Istanbul ... So many shops offering wide varieties ...down side is sometimes it can get a bit crowded so it's always good to keep your belongings close to you .this is the home of aya Sophia and the blue mosque .

A Great Base For Exploring Istanbul. We stayed at a small hotel in this district at the recommendation of a friend. It proved a wise choice. You are I. The midst of old Istanbul and within walking distance of many of the important sites, including the Blue Mosque, Sophia and the Topaki Palace. There are also good restaurants in the area (as well as some tourist traps). The district is a bit difficult to access from the airport, but once you have settled in, the charm takes over.
Fascinating!. This is a fascinating place, quite romantic in a sense, and could take years to truly explore. It's definitely worth staying here for a while.

Nicest area of Istanbul. Best location in Istanbul to book your Hotel. Prices of restaurants and bars are relatively high compared to the rest of Istanbul.All main attractions are in this area: Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, grand Bazar, Blue Mosque, Bosporus Strait, Arasta Bazaar, Islamic Art Museum, Basilica Cisterne and much more.
Highly recommended to see and walk around. So many wonderful buildings, shops, and restaurants. Take the time to walk around the area and go into the mosques and shops.

The District. this is area is similar to other busy district in the world but it captures every historic and wonderful scene around you. take a whole day ferry trip nearby in a cheap price or take a walk in the mosque while taking pics for those fishing on the bridge.

Beyond all expectatons!!. There is more to see here than one can possibly take in on one tour. It is beautiful...November was the perfect time to visit. I can't wait to come back. The magnificence, splendor and workmanship in the mosques is beyond words. The whole area is historic and worth just sitting and taking in as cultures from all around the world travel through this area.

A great place to stay. I stayed at the Darussaade Hotel for 2 weeks and I loved this district. It has so many interesting landmarks, fun shopping and great restaurants. i felt very safe walking around there, even at night.

Our Visit to Istanbul August 2015. It was my earnest desire to have visit of an old Islamic country Turkey and specially Istanbul. I got the opportunity in the month of August 2015 while i along with my lady wife were coming back from our Europe tour. I visited almost all the historical places, including Sultan Ahmet (Blue Mosque) Aya Sophia, Hagia Sophia Museum, Topkapi Museum, Tomb of Hazrat Abu Ayoub Ansari (RA) etc

super city, bad taxi drivers. Our 2nd time in Istanbul Stayed at Hotel Alilass, not on review list yet. Use the Metro/subway. It's easy, but get oriented. it is easy to confuse what is the sub way and what is the light rail on the maps. We also learned there are no transfers. You have to buy a new ticket if you have used up your prepaid ticket. Use the machines that take cash-our credit cards didn't work) We ran out of lira, had to exit the subway (we had counted on being able to transfer from one line to another) exchange money,find the Metro. No, they don't all speak English, and Turkish in the Roman alphabet is incomprehensible gibberish. This time the taxi cab driver demanded 65 Turkish Lira when we got to the airport, though the meter showed 45. He indicated our luggage. He had started to swindle us by noting a traffic "restriction, " on the way, but it was minor so he couldn't use that. (they will use "night fare", demand payment before you are our of the cab,etc.) Previously a cab driver mentioned "traffic" (it was just the usual, and extorted 30 TYL from us)Still, a not to be missed wonder of the world. The Basilica Cistern my number one truly awe inspiring sight. Try to get an accurate map. Street signs are few and far between. If you like shopping, it's paradise.

Touristy but pleasant. As most tourists stay here and it includes the main sites to visit, it is obviously full of foreigners. It may not give a real glimpse of Turkey but it is mostly pedistrianised and feels very safe, even at night.Good transport links, loads of excellent cheap hotels and restaurants, it is the obvious place to stay in Istanbul

MUST GO TO. This area is excellent showing many beautiful sights of Istanbul, along with excellent cafes, restaurants, markets etc. It is a must if going to Istanbul. Easy accessible ferries, metros and for those like me excellent for walking. Definitely a must to experience real Turkish people and culture, history, architecture etc. etc.

Sultana or Raisin......... Your Choice !. This area is the true heart of Istanbul , if not, the rest is an easy walk (or Taxi If lazy) In the area you have the full enchilada, the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topaki Palace, Basilica Cistern, Museums, Restaurants & Bars , Shops , etc, etc !! A great place to walk around and soak up the atmosphere !!

This is a most visit during your stay if you want to see the best attractions in the city.. This is the oldest section of the city where most of the attractions are located. You have to walk around to enjoy the flavors , aromas and culture of the the city that once upon time was known as Constantinople.

Mrs.. Sultanahmet is where the action is, it's walking distance to the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Haggia Sofya, the Basilica Cistern etc., They are very many restaurants and you find people walking late into the night.

The place to be1. Historic beautifully exotic Istanbul - here is almost everything you'll want to see - easy to navigate by tram or walking, lovely large parks, great restaurants, safe and fascinating

Must-see area of Istanbul, no matter how short your visit.. Many attractions, the mosques, Topkapi, the carpet bazaar, extraordinary restaurants, much shopping, open spaces, the Archeological Museum, only begin the list.

Best place to stay for a tourist. All major tourist areas of istanbul is within this district except for a few. A lot of mosques, palace, hamams, restaurants, bazaars etc are within or near this district. public transport is also good to reach other parts. a good place to stay when you are in istanbul.The party areas (taksim, beyoglu) are atleast 20-30 min walk from here.
lots of people. streets are crowded with people at all times of the day, but there are open spaces and plazas big enough

A great area to stay and visit. I think Sultanahmet District is the best area to stay when you are visiting Turkey for the first time as you can cover all the famous attractions at once, such as The Blue Mosque, Ayasophia,Top Kapi and also visit the Grand bazar and Spice bazar or Egyptian bazar where you can find hundreds of things to carry back with you.
visit one of the largest mosques in Europeish. Great mosaic decoration. In blue plant based patterns. Origin of Turkish blue green tiles(tourquoise).Spoilt a bit by queues.

a great place to visit again and again. great views, cheap food and nice people. I have been to Istanbul many times and still look forward to go there again. A wonderful city and there is always something to do at this area.

The heart of 4 great historic parts of Istanbul.. This area holds the Hagia Sophia Church, the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace, and the Grand Bazar. In addition there are all kinds of hotels and restaurants and shops.
Beautiful area. This is the heart of the Old Town in Istanbul. Best area to come. Stay at a hotel here so you can walk around at night also.
Nice Historical Area . I strongly recommend to stay in one of hotels of this area while staying in Istanbul. Staying at Sultan Ahmet area you will feel that you are in 1001 nights tales.

So much to see!. Sultanahmet has it all really - beautiful landmarks, parks, palaces, mosques, restaurants, hotels and hammams. If I only had a day or two in Istanbul and it was my first visit I would wander through this area soaking in all the sights and breathing in all the bazaars have to offer while enjoying the constant calls to prayer - beautiful.
So much to see. Sultanahmet has so many sights close to each other and loads of winding cobbled streets to get lost in. One of my very favourite old towns I have ever visited.
Hippodrome. We had a tour guide who told us all about the Hippodrome ... Lovely wide city space where chariot races took place 400 years ago.

Stayed in hotel on edge . Bext area to stay .more old small traditional. Lots cobbled Arras so nercier yo be award for walking .
Easy reach of all main tourist parts snd markets
History in a nutshell. Staying in this area really puts everything in reach. History, spice bazaar, grand bazaar, eminunu area, gulhane bazaar all accessible on foot or by tram.

The most wonderful places in Istanbul . It's historical and one of the most beautiful center in Istanbul. Beautiful parks, very good view! There always to much people - but if you see it, you can understand why..) the

Sultanahmet District. WOW !! This area is marvellous and so interesting. It gathers some of the most well known historical and religious places in Istanbul. In this area , one can walk from one place to another easily. One visit to the remarkable tourist attractions such as : Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Citern, Hippodrome and Grand Bazar, will be a good experience that will be saved in memory for ages.In addition, the multiple restaurants and cafes scattered everywhere attract tourists.Any visitor to Istanbul should make a trip to Sultanahmet district and surely he will not feel remorse.
Blue Mosque . Mosaic Museum. Blue Mosque amazing but very busy . Mosaic Museum fascinating and quiet . The Hippodrome ... Lovely wide open space where chariot race used to take place .
City Center. This was the center of Constantinople and also Istanbul.Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman, Turkish, the whole Works are located in this area.

Everything gathered in one place!. You have the blue mosque on one side, hagia sophia on the other. Basilica Cistern right across the street, Tapkapi Palace is also nearby. The busses and boat trips all go from this place. So you can call it the Belly of the beast :) There are also loads of resturants, kebab houses and coffee shops nearby!

Sultanahmet. We stayed the Ottoman Imperial Hotel which was extremely old and had a desk and chair on display that had been used for when one of the Popes made a visit to a nearby Mosque. our room was directly above the tram line which wasn't all that great for sleeping the 1st night but 2nd night no worries. Very close to good tourist spots and the Heritage Nomadic Art Gallery. Had a great clay pot meal experience one night and the best coffee the next morning.

very beautiful. We really enjoyed walking in Sultanahmet District. I downloaded Istanbul from Trip adviser before getting there and saved all of our favorite places in my phone application. This really helped us during our trip to find the attractions and our favorite places. We didn't have access to Wifi internet when we were in the street but still we could able to see our location in trip advisory map!! It was fantastic. (Our GPS was on) Try to walk or take public transportation...
Amazing soul and excellent feeling. If you feel the district that it was the point where 4 different countries had been ruled in different periods, walking around will be amazing feeling.

Everything close. Its good to wander about this area Blue Mosque and Haphia Sophia is literally back to back. The grand Baazar is a short walk from here about 10 mins. There are lots of small eating places to sample the local delacies or walk down the hill into the old town and you will eventually come to the spice bazzar.The only thing off putting is Turkey has not caught up with the western world in toilets its a hole in the ground ladies don't be surprised I last experienced this in Bali 20 years ago would have thought be now Turkey would have moved on.

The most beautiful place in Istanbul!. Sultanahmet is the place to stay in Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the heart of this amazing city. If you go to Istanbul ( and you should!) look for a Hotel in this area.

Nice hotel with a great location. If you want to walk to the Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, the Cisterns, Topkapi palace, public transportation (trolley) that goes directly to Dolmabahce Palace (as well as the downtown area) and gaze at the Bosphorus during breakfast, this is the place for you. I can't recommend it highly enough for those that want to skip the tours and do things on your own. They offer a nice breakfast and some pretty nice rooms. The one thing that perplexed me was the bathroom set up. Couldn't quite figure it out until I actually went to a Turkish bath. This is the way many are set up and unless you have an appreciation for that cultural phenomenon, you won't quite get it. Don't hesitate to book here. You won't be sorry

Central location to stay in.. We stayed in Sultanahmet location for 5 nights. It was really central and an easy walk to all the attractions. It was easy to find your way around and not get lost. Check out what is available - check if your hotel has English television as many don't. Great location to get yourself around Istanbul.
Old Istanbul at its best. If you are into history this area is a must see the blue mosque and Hagia Sophia at its heart. Trams to get around and plenty to see and do.

Stay in this part of town. This district contains many of the sights that you will want to visit in Istanbul. Winding cobblestone streets, colorful shops, historical sites and sights, an easy way to get to know the history of the city.

6 Day October stay. My wife and I stayed here for 6 days from 18th to 23rd October. Stayed at Hippodrome hotel right near to attractions. Loads to do had 2 full day tours an afternoon at Topkapi and and evening dinner cruise all very good

Istanbul's historic centre. Most of the top historic attractions of Istanbul is in this district; Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, The hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace and the Grand Bazaar to mention a few, but there is also a great atmosphere just walking around and soaking up the history.

Don't forget to buy Museum Pass. Before we started our tour in Istanbul, we bought the Museum Pass, It costs 85 TL and allows you to visit many of Istanbul’s most popular museums within 5 days. I think it's quite economic because the fee of Topkapi Palace is 30 TL (if you want to enter the Harem, they charge wxtra 15 TL), Hagia Sophia 30 TL and so on,

Beautiful architecture right in front of your eyes. Simply walking around the Sultanahmet District reveals such architectural beauty and history. Whether as part of a tour of simply walking around you will be awe struck with such magnificent architectural beauty that it is definitely worth your time.

Lots of good history. Good experience of the old town with lots of history
Good chance to take lots of photos
Easy to get around and a good choice of trams buses etc
Best way is walking i
Best part of Istanbul. The old part of the city with a large number of hotels, restaurants and shops of all kinds. The bazaar is great even if you do not buy anything. It is somewhat like a musem.

One of the best districts. Sultanahmet is one of the most popular districts of Istanbul. Tourists mostly visit it because of the Grand Bazaar, the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Basilica Cistern. Whilst there, you can take a tram and go to Galata Bridge. Makrell sandwich is a must there. Don't forget to have famous meatballs when in Sultanahmet!

Tourist district. Visit to sultanshmet is inevitable as the blue mosque, hagar sophia, basilica cistern and grand bazaar are all close by. Very tourist orientated area so comes with the usual high prices. The walk around the gardens is free however and very enjoyable in good weather.

Amazing history. Everywhere you turn there is something. The cobbled streets, blue stone, fortress walls, mosques, ancient cemeteries, great food, awesome people. FYI, do not give money to people who are carrying signs written in English claiming that they're Syrian refugees, Syrians don't beg. These "families" are gypsies from the south and if you look carefully, they don't even look Syrian. It's hard when you see them with children, but that's what they do, use the kids. They are not poor, they're gangs.
Beautiful. Sultanahmet is one of my favsorite places in Istanbul. Eventhough souveniers and food is very expensive there...

such a historic and wonderful area. We stayed just off the square in a great hotel, the Magaura, which i will review separately. It is such an nice area with lots of shops and sights, great place to stay and explore many wonderful street cafes, Hamam;s, Arista Bazaar and Grand Bazaar to just mention a few. Great location to stay.

Lots of must-sees and history. This is probably the district of Istanbul to do first. Because all the Mosques and museums that matter are located here.The Hagia Sophia and the Sultanahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque) are the big landmarks and not to be missed. The Blue Mosque is more impressive outside than in, vice versa with the Hagia Sophia.Topkapi Palace would be the next thing to do. These three attractions can take a full day.But it doens't stop here. The Sultan Ahmet Park is a nice little green spot to take great pics...or a well deserved rest. Impressive at night with the wonderful Blue Mosque in the back (check the pics).The Divan Yolu Caddesi is the main drag here. Lots of shops and restaurants, fun to look and a good walk....but most of them cater to tourists and can be a hassle. The best places to eat are elsewhere. The "Cafe Grande" has good Baklava and desserts though.Don't miss out on the Arasta Bazaar, a short street with the usual Bazaar shops....but without the hassle. There's more to see, best thing is you just walk around, it's not like you will get lost easy. The Blue Mosque is always easy to spot.If you look for a place to sleep, I'd recommend the lovely little "Hotel Historia" just 5' away by foot from the Blue Mosque....quiet area, great views from the balcony. And lots of restaurants just out front (try the criminally underrated "Akbiyik Fish House").A great district here in Istanbul, but mostly about Mosques and history. To do some fun shopping I would head to Beyoglu (Istiklal Street). And don't forget to visit Kadiköy on the Asian side: Friendly people, low prices .... great food and products.Wanna know more about me and my trips? Check my profile.

Blue Mosque.... When l read that name blue mosque l think it was blue when you look from outside.Out of mosque is white.When l entered inside all walls decorated with handmade iznik tales.because of that inside was blue.It was magnificent again smells history.

Our hotel was close to the old section Sultanahmet, so we just had to walk up the hill.. We walked up the hill from ourhotel, the walk looked easy but was very steep. WE took our time, but it was a workout, and it was hot in Sept.

Fabulous. This is the old section of the city and many of Istabul's great attractions are here: Topkapi, the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Cistern and more. It can be a bit touristy, but everyone is quite friendly. The Turkish people are wonderful.
Historic center. Just visit around and eat famous meat balls.. Don't make shopping- don't stay in neighbourhood hotels.

Real Oriental Spirit. Sultanahmet offers everything what goes with oriental spirit - the smell of delicious apple tea, mixed with all the spices of Orient, offers of merchants looking for new customers, invitations of chefs cooking traditional food for curious visitors, sounds of mosques calling the prayers... You can get lost among all the shops at the Bazaar, or find some peace in the mosque, you can satisfy your empty stomach with tasty food or calm down your minds with a smoke of sisha.Just let yourself go with the flow of oriental spirit!

Lively area, must visit. If you're looking for hustle and bustle and want an exciting day out then def visit the district. It has everything from traditional sightseeing tourist sections, to the Grand bazaar where some of the locals shop. Turkey at it's best.

Live like a local. Sultanahmet is a must stay district of Istanbul if you want to get the feeling of being with the locals.Wander around the cobbled streets,chat with the friendly local traders, go to a produce market held once a week in a car park.Discover little mosques and local Hamams, much nicer and cheaper than the larger ones.Stay in a quaint Otterman style hotel..fantastic.
Amazing place. Its busy area. Everything is close by- walking distance. The hospitality of people is really nice. Patios are great too.

The best place to live to know the meet the locals and learn the history of Istanbul.. The best place to live to know the meet the locals and learn the history of Istanbul. The district is named after the Ottoman Sultan Sultan Ahmet I This District has almost all the Historical Places around it next to each other and has a park also where people chit chat and relax. it also has a arena where plays and traditional shows are hosted for tourists

Old side of Istanbul with main history. This is the old side of Istanbul but most of the historic sites are here. Lots of walking around and have to be careful as stones/ pebbles. Mainly on foot can access to lots of historic sites.Small streets as old city but loved it - very pretty and beautiful - a must see. We stayed on the new side as more happening in the night.
Famous SultanAhmat Square. It's always a nice stop over there to take pictures and feed pigeons with your family and rest by the fountain park and have chestnut and corn.

cozy. Very nice and cozy Place. Packed with people that were walking around or sitting and having picnics on the parks. It felt sizzling and full of Life. Fantastic sunsets from the restaurant roofs. You never felt anxious at night for some reason. Will defenetly come back

Stepping back in time. Visiting this area is like stepping back in time. Besides the main attraction of the mosque and gardens there are back streets full of interesting and some crumbling old buildings and local shops

Beautiful place with people from around the world. Every time I visit Istambul I go to Sultanahmet District. There is something special here, you can feel it any time of the day or night. Last time I came here late night during heavy rain. So almost no people around, just some lights, drops and voice inside my head "Finally I came back again!"I booked a hostel in this area (there are many of them here - very convenient and affordable). Some hostels even have roof top places so in good weather you can sleep and then wake up with a great view on Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia. So I enjoyed great sunny morning with such view. Very cool!

Short stop over on Turkish Airlines. What a fascinating place this is! I only had a very short time to take in a few sights on a 14 hour turn around in Istanbul, so I made the most of it by going to the Taksim square district at night and Sultanahmet in the morning. Of course, this ould only provide a flavor of the place and one that reqlly demands much more of one's time, but my feeling is that some is better than none. I managed to see the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, do a walk by the Topkapi Palace (but did not pay to go in) and past the new Mosque to the Spice Market) all which were an easy work from my charming hotel (the Berce-- super cheap and very nice-- great location). I particularly loved the Blue Mosque and Sophia. WIsh I could have taken a formal tour and have been more educated about what I as seeing. Still was beyond impressive. I quite liked the spice market too. Wish I had more time, but grateful for the time/experience I had and I would definitely fly Turkish Airlines through Istanbul again. Loved the airline and the opportunity to visit this great city and area.

Amazing and gorgeous architecture. Sultanahmet recalls the gorgeous area including the Sultanahmet Camii (The Blue Mosque) and the Ayasofya museum and the spacious square between and the very special area beyond these limits... Spectacular views, historical monuments... not to be missed!

Good area to visit and walk around but book hotel elsewhere. Sultanahmet is where all the main tourist attractions are located. It is lovely to walk around and take in the surroundings, taste the different street foods and feed stray cats. However, I wouldn't recommend booking a hotel in this district. Almost all the restaurants and shops surrounding the Blue Mosque are tourist traps, with low quality food at ridiculously high prices. I made the mistake of booking a hotel within 3 minutes of the Blue Mosque which made getting to the main sites easy but it also meant on a rainy day (and it rained for the first 3 days of our stay) we were almost compelled to eat at tourist trap restaurants as our hotel didn't allow us to bring food onto the premises. If I am in Istanbul again, I will book a hotel in another district like Fatih or Sirkeci, not Sultanahmet.

So much history!. Ayia Sophia is number one here - but there is so much to see - a littke bazaar - as well as the Grand Bazaar (full of fake designer items as well as good lamps, bowls and carpets of course) . You will also come across ancient structures - like Constantines tower which is next to a busy road and tram stop!

Walkable . We spent hours wandering around the district with lots of things to look at and to visit. There a tram if needed. There was always the offer to buy a carpet but the people were very friendly . A lot of people enjoy having a conversation, a good way to learn about the history and places to visit. Lovely area. Mike

stay down in this district. We stayed at the Doubletree Old Town, and all the interesting things to see where just a step outside the door and a grab of a streetcar/trolley ( grab any of them) and a 10 minute ride. Crowded but fascinating

The tourist centre. If you came to Istanbul to see the mosques then you need to come hear. Sofia and the blue most are both here, facing each other and quite special to experience during call to prayer.Very busy with long queues, so arrive early and remember your scarves ladies
Good Budget Hotel Options. There are many good budget hotels and restaurants to choose from in this old part of the city, as well as shops. Perhaps the most interesting part of Istanbul.

Safe for girls, historical and amazing. Stayed in the heart of this district and loved how small and compact it is. Easy to walk everywhere, or take a tram. Nothing is far, take a slight detour or get lost, and you end up somewhere else but it's not far from somewhere you've been before. Get very lost and the locals will always help, so super friendly. Plenty of mosques, restaurants and things to do. Cannot recommend highly enough

This old section of Istanbul is an ideal location. We loved staying in Sultanahmet, for the old buildings, so many good restaurants and shops, and easy walking to most of themust-see historic sights of Istanbul.

Lot of things to see here. The district is not so big, but it has so many things to see. You can also easily find got food points like restaurants, shops, local food, etc. It is also very safe place to stay.
The area to stay and explore. There is so much to see in this part of Istanbul. Many small hotels, restaurants, shops, sights are within a short walk.

A bit of everything!. Whatever you want you can find here. There is literally a shop for everything here: wedding dresses, lingerie, taps, phones, headphones, sweets, cats cats cats. Take your time to walk around and try not to stress about the amount if people as I did.
Lively and Energetic city. With Hassling crowds of Tourist, locals and sellers and street markets, a sense of culture friendly people and cats.
Wonderful. Wonderful area with lots of exciting history well worth a visit. I would recommend a visit who in istanbul.
Love love love . The best place ever to visit in Istanbul, this place always give me the beautiful memory to remember
Great. Lively and busy day and night. Many food choices, shops to die for, Istanbul at it's best. Easy access, safe and friendly.

Each attraction within walking distance of one another.. A wonderful area to wander at your leisure, for one day or several. Lots of restaurants, roof top bars and shopping close by.
An amazing area to visit with jaw dropping attractions.

Impressive buildings. Impressive buildings especially mosques.
It is very touristy area, and therefore the prices are higher than elsewhere in Istanbul

A must visit. Although a very crowded place this is a must visit in Istanbul.
Great for photography from both inside and outside the building.
Touristy stuff all located here. See the blue mosque, ayasofya, and topkapi palace all within walking distance of each other. Overrun with tourists though. Still a must see.

Fun area to visit. Great place to walk about and soak up the atmosphere. There are lots of carpet shop touts and the restaurant owners are all trying to get you to come inside. Prices are reasonable but expect the tourist surcharge. Lots of tourists but the locals are very pleasant . Good restaurants and shops well wort a day or two.
history.... You will feel the history on there. there are many mosque,museum and church. My favorite place is hagia sophia.

Place Worth Staying/Seeing. If someone visiting IST, it's better to stay in this area than anywhere else. Even if you're here for a short trip, you may consider same. You get to see Grand Bazar, Topkapi Palace, Sultan Ahmet Mosque, Hagia Sophia - all in walking distance. Hotel costs varies with the standard. But the thing is, it will reduce your effort in reaching main tourist attractions.

Amazing mosque. A unique architecture, with soul of its own. great place for worship and visit for its structural design. If you visit Istanbul and if you never miss this attraction, your visit is incomplete.
New mosque . Next to galata bridge and it's very easy to get here ıt worths to see it while you are in Istanbul.I have been here twice

Best place to stay. The Sultanhamet Disctrict is the best place to stay, it has great hotels, lots of very good restaurants and some of the most spectacular spots to see. It also has great shopping and easy access via the tram to other sites you may want to see.
Highlightes of Istanbul. It's the area where most of the highlights from Istanbul are. The old part. People are very friendly and helpful.

The center of the Otoman Empire. The Sultanahmet area has everything: marvelous historical buildings like Topkapi Palace, The Blue Mosque, Arasta Bazar or Agia Sophia, but it is a most lively place to travel to, to enjoy a dinner, to take a cruise (Bosphorus cruise), to just sit on a bank and let yourself feel the greatness, the history, the energy of the area, till late at night....

Vivid historical site. Sultanahmet is the heart of the city with many attractions in close vicinity. The are is full with shops and restaurant, the famous Grand Bazaar is only 0 minutes walk. Sitting in the middle of the square you can feel the atmosphere of the history. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, Palace of Ibrahim (Museum of Islamic Arts), Topkapi Palace with excellent archeological exhibition are the main attractions, but you also can enjoy the view from the terrace of a roof restaurant or walk down to Golden Horn for a boat excursion.
where the main historic attractions are located. All the major Istanbul attractions are here clustered around Sultanahmet Square. Spring for the 3-day museum pass. It'll save you both time and money.
I Would Go Back In A Heart Beat. Loved it. Absolutely loved it. Such a phenomenally wonderful and welcoming part of Turkey. Did I mention I loved it.
Must see!. Most of the historic areas are within the vicinity. It's worth the trip here because several other sites are walking distance.

The place you must stay when in Istanbul. As Joshua D made comment touristic but what city hasn't a tourist district unless you live in a village in the middle of nowhere in Central Asia !!. If time is limited this is the area to stay as all the major sights are within its borders. All are within walking distance 10 mins one way 15 another. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants and shops galore. The salesmen are sharp and regardless the fact they saw you only this morning they'll ask you again and again to come inside and see my range of carpets or handcrafts. If you're new and inexperienced at travelling the world then you can be sucked in, but a polite no thanks then keep walking usually gets you a "have a nice day" comment. This is also where you'll fine all the Foreign Exchange counters, a must for the general tourist especially if you get involved in a shopping exercise. I disagree with a comment that the quality of shopping is poor, as there is a range of products and quality, to be found to suit all tastes. You must know what you're buying and pay accordingly for the quality you desire. There's so much to see and do in this area, it's where you'll find the Blue Mosque, The Cistern, Hippodrome and Hagia Sopia Museum to name just a few. Enjoy Sultanahmet - Dennis

Shopping and eating at Sultanahmet. There's always lots of men asking you to come to their restaurant or shop and as long as you're friendly they will not be offended if you say no. It is more offensive to ignore them or be rude, so don't! They are just trying to make a good living. The shops are quite orientated to tourism but you can still find some traditional treasures. Lots of goods from Turkmenistan and Syria if you choose to delve. Lots of good inexpensive restaurants for basic kebab meals but also great veggie and meat 'casserole' type dishes to eat with rice or bulgar. Have a kebab for lunch but choose the clay pot speciality for dinner. Well served by the tram, only 4 TL per trip.

The past is here. We stayed in this district because we like to be able to walk to the historical attractions. This is the place! The narrow, windy streets are part of the charm and the merchants outside trying to entice one to come in is all part of the experience. The history is staggering. We hired personal guides to take us into the Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace. Lastly the Chora Church. We had two half day tours with different guides. We learned more by having things pointed out than just reading in our guide book. Super neighborhood for Istanbul and Turkish history.
Overrated. Poor district and very crowdy...You get the hunch it is very touristic in terms of prices but quality is poor.

The flavor of Istanbul. This district gives you the real flavor of the old town of Istanbul. Even a few days there and you are instantly emerged in their culture and way of life. Great baklava! I was told it was the best place for baklava in fact. Can't go wrong.

A fascinating maze but be aware of the taxis. In several taxi rides in and through the area we had an excellent view of the maze of streets and alleys. In fact, in most of the taxi rides we saw the same buildings and streets several times each ride as the circular route seemed favoured by most taxi drivers (but its all on the meter!!!). If possible, walk as much as possible and avoid the taxis.
walk about and enjoy the people watching. secure your wallet then go for a walk about. great food and v friendly staff. your in the heart of a world class city

excellent. the mosques are a bit overrated if you ask me, but in general, we loved the area. Most importantly, bring a pair of comfortable shoes because to our surprise, there are a lot of hills and stairs to climb in Istanbul

A must see in Istanbul!!!. Without a doubt this is the area to stay when visiting Istanbul. We were literally less than a 10 minute walk to the Blue Mosque and about 20 minutes form the Hagia Sophia, each absolutely breathless in their enormity size or in the detail in which they were constructed. There is a huge variety of places to eat and drink in the area......we tried numerous restaurants, many outside, and bars and none disappointed. Several streets looked as if they were on the left bank in Paris. Plenty of stores to shop and peek into, a small bazaar. Take your camera with you everywhere. Clearly our favorite area in Istanbul. I am ready to go again.
Heart of Old Town. Everywhere you go has historical significance.Don't forget the cistern below. Night view of Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia are great.

Great Place For Eating n Shopping. This place is great to hangout as the view is great.Greenery is surrounded all the side, beautiful flowers & great crowd around.Lots of restaurants & cafes nearby.Must Visit

Best place to stay in Istanbul. A very iconic area with most of the attractions in this district. Also very convenient to travel to attractions normally walking distance to most of the places if not the tram is also there.
Lots To See. I did not realise that this area has alot of shops and Hotels. There is a tram that allows you to see all of Sultanahmet. I recommend that u walk with a map...lol

Most attractions nearby. Excellent place to stay if you want to visit the mosques, everything is within 10 minute distance, topkapi palace, grand bazaar, blue mosque, hippodrome and Hagia Sophia but be aware of steep hills and it was shattering to push baby pushchair up those hills, downside is not many people speak english
lovely area. stayed there at a hotel in the area. was pleasant for walking at evenings and enjoyed little bazaar which was pretty but not too overwhelming
Fascinating. A fascinating tour around old Istanbul with all major historical attractions within an easy walk. A tram runs around the area which makes travelling very easy
Turkey culture. The sultanahmet has many shops and restaurant in the area , the district itself is nice and give you the old spitit of turkey

Great experince. What a fantastic area to experience Istanbul. The history in this area is amazing. It is a great area to easily walk around to all features of Turkey. Accommodation is great and so are the Restaurant choices. It is probably one of the areas to get best experience in Istanbul
Turkey Delight indeed. This is a great area to do some shopping, eating, drinking. I have never seeing so much Turkey delights choices

The Color of Western Turkey. Almost all attractions of Europe side of Turkey are located here. As long as you have the Istanbulkart, you just have to take their reliable train to Sultanahmet Station and enjoy your vacation to all tourist attraction places here!

Tourist Mecca. As a tourist / traveller in Istanbul you really have a choice of 2 main areas to stay.Beylogu where the shopping streets & tavernas are, or Sultanahmet where all the notable historical sites are.For a first time visitor the Sultanahmet wins hands down, visit the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace , the Cisterns,Sofia, not to mention the grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar etc. etc..There are lots of great hotels [our favourite is the Sultania] -- but there are huge choices, as there are with Restaurants too.Transport is cheap , buy an Istanbulkart and use the Tram to go visit the wharf area near the galata Bridge and catch a ferry to Eyup or a tour of the Bosphorus and if you want to visit Beylogu ,its just a tram and funicular ride away.

historic, walkable. this is the area to stay in, you can walk to all the main sights some of the streets are pretty steep especially heading toward the grand bazaar we walked to hagia sophia, blue mosque, topkapi palace, suleymaniye mosque. there are many reasonably priced small hotels in th area

Crazy but Fun Place to Shop. Most tour guides will want to drop you off to shop on your own, but I would highly advise you hire the guide to take you through the Grand Bazaar. The guide can help you to find items that you want and to navigate through the huge maze of shops. Most shop owners expect you to haggle, especially for higher priced items. I also found that I would pit two or three stores against one another.

Chaos and confusion rules o.k but great for it!. Above the noise of the traffic and the calls for prayer there seemed to be some order to the proceedings - just haven't found it yet!Loved being in the grand bazaar , it was just as it was in the Bond film!Little stuff that we could bring back owing to flight weight limits but took loads of photos and a great memory

Interesting, cosmopolitan and buzzing area. The Sultanahmet area essentially represents the things I loved most in Istanbul: buzzing, vibrant, colourful, but above all, a unique blend of modernity and history. Teeming markets, including the Grand Bazaar, wide open spaces and gorgeous Ottoman walls.
There's a lot to see and do here, including cheap and cheerful restaurants, so its worth just letting yourself wonder and explore.

Not for young people. Actually i had good time in Sultanahmet but this area is not good for young people, no nightlife (if you love to smoke waterpipe and drink tea allnight it's nice) I saw lot of pubs around there but most of theese pubs are not nice. The thng is i spend 5 days in Sultanahmet and i never met a Turkish person, all the staff is middle easterns....
Istanbul. beautiful area lots to see and do put your walking shoes on your in for some surprises great tastes and smells everywhere!

Grand Bazaar. use public transportation...very cheap and easy once you know where you are going and have your tokens purchaseed.......haggle everything!!!!!!!!!! if you just want to browse use main entrance....if you are shopping make sure you have the whole day to visit ....it is a maze! Lots of fun....make sure you do not by the "made in China" merchandise.

Sultanahmet area. This area is full with ancient times and modern times. Once you get in the area you can feel how was big that Othmanine empire's. For sure one day is not enough to walk between old streets, shopping, and eating. If you want to buy anything go to Eminun, the difference in price almost 30%-50% if you have time to go to Eminun.

A safe and interesting place to stroll around.. We felt quite safe walking through the Sultanahmet area. There are endless rows of small shops and we found that the shopkeepers can be a little aggressive if you stop to look at an article. It is understandable though given the number of people milling about. Overall we had a wonderful time, and felt quite safe.

You can find there everything. You can find there everything: museums, mosques, bazar, restaurants and just fun strolling. The only negative is the constant efforts of the shopkeepers to lure you in their establishments.

So Much To See, So Little Time. The Sultanahmet district is packed with "must see" sites from the Hagia Sophia, Cisterns, Blue Mosque,Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace and more that you have to spend an entire day or more her if you want to truly see and experience it all. The Palace alone will consume 3 hours easily .

Perfect place to wander in a nice afternoon. The Sultanahmet district is a very nice area of Istanbul. It is not only where the Blue Mosque (Sultanahmet Mosque) is situated but also a nice place with many restaurants cafes and people around. There is also a small bazar where you can find different traditional things to buy.

Sightseeing and curio purchases. Most attractive part of Istanbul for a Tourist. But beware of pick pockets and bag pickers. Don't get distracted by the locals luring to something else. People are friendly and can manage with English, but police don't accept English only Turkish.
Walk and Enjoy. A great place to walk, shop and enjoy the great history. Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoe and enjoy everything.

Loved the stroll and walk around.. We stayed in the area for 3 days, its the best place to stay. not crowded, lots of things to see and do. you can literally walk the whole time. Not a typical metropolitan with traffic and noise.
lovely people.

Overview of how the locals spend their time. The walk along the main pedestrian street, Istiklal, is very entertaining and offers sights, restaurants, street food, turkish delight & baklava. Be prepared for 'crowded' but we never felt unsafe. Explore some side streets, ride the tram & the funicular, take pictures & choose an upstairs balcony restaurant from which to enjoy the crowd while taking a break.

Walk everywhere. We stayed in this area and loved the fact that all the major attractions are easy to walk to. At night it is vibrant and fun and Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque at night are wonderful. The Arasta bazaar with beautiful shops and no hassling. Plenty of restaurants too. Cats and dogs everywhere most of which seem to be happy and in good condition. Great place to base yourself or visit.

A Wonderful Turkish Delight. There is probably more shops around but the one in the Egyptian Bazaar is where I purchased both the fresh type filled with various cream center and the more common type with plenty of nuts in a melba base. Good quality type lime Hayatt's made with honey. The package is very presentable and they vacuum seal it to keep it nice at no charge. FRESH KEEPS A MONTH AND THE OTHER SIX MONTHS. I thinks this makes a better gift than the ceramic plates etc. Sold
old place . Blue Mosque .Santa Sofia and Topkapı place all is well .İstanbul is best in Thé World.we have to come back again
Crowded, fascinating, affects most of your senses. Lots of people to make people watching interesting. Locals very friendly and helpful. Colourful, food aromatic, noisy, good samples to try.

Our favorite district in Istanbul. The Sultanahmet District includes The Grand Bazaar, small and touristy to upscale shops, a multitude of restaurants and cafes, and many of the major sites such as Hagia Sofia and The Blue Mosque. If we were to return to Istanbul, we would find a hotel in this district because it is so central to both the history and the current culture of the city. There are many small hotels that are worth looking for in planning a trip.

Humongous yet very entertaining!. Not enough space to say all what I want. I think the whole area is the heart of the culture of the great Ottoman Empire. Many historic places, nice water front for walking. The best thing is...food. That where I ate most of nights, I like the outdoor sitting areas, and of course the live music. hotels?.. Not the greatest if you like spacious rooms and latest styles. I stayed there once, my next visit I stayed at Taksim, which is not very far from Sultanahmet, and taxis are not expensive either, although in rush hours it gets very very lengthy.

An excellent place to stay and be in Istanbul . As my title says, Sultanahmet District is "An excellent place to stay and be in Istanbul". It has good transport links with elsewhere, as well as most of the leading attractions and interesting culture. We can only recommend it as the area to base your visit to Istanbul.
Vibrant City. The Sultanahmet district delight to the senses. With thriving market and an abundance of historic sites to visit, this area is a must see for all visitors to Istanbul
The area to see. This area of Istanbul is the most touristic, and practically most attractions are here, but I normally rather stay at Taksim for modern convenience. Yes, for a visit, it is a must.

Uncomfortable time!. A friend and I (both women) had a layover in Istanbul and decided to go see the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque. We got there fairly early in the morning so it wasn't busy at all. Most of the local men there made us feel so uncomfortable with their stares and some of their comments. One guy who was walking down the street, randomly stopped and was trying so hard to get us to go with him to "get some coffee" and visit his "souvenir store". We politely declined. We got to see the outside of the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque, but didn't get to go in them since we had to go back to the airport. There were also stray dogs running around, barking and fighting with each other around the area, which took some getting use to. They have tags in their ears which one of the locals said were a sign that they have been vaccinated. This area is a toursity spot but just be careful of the locals trying to scam you, especially if you are female

Best area for first time visit to Istanbul. This district has many of the most famous attractions of Istanbul, If you choose your hotel carefully you can walk to all of them. I recommend using the restaurant in the grounds of the Topkapi palace, even if it is just for a coffee and a cake as the view over the Bosphorus is quite special.

Vibrant area, day and night. You can just walk around and watch people, search for a restaurant, or visit several Mosques and museums. This area demonstrates the human diversity of Turkey. Another way to see the area is the Big Red Bus, which is on and off and goes around the city as well.At night the museums and mosques are illuminated and the area is well used.

excellent to visit not to stay. this area has improved so much since my last visit 9 years ago, much cleaner. I would advise though to stay on the other side of the galata bridge, hotels are newer and more convenient.
Old and well preserved. Walk around the place to enjoy the bAzaar and the sights sounds and smells. Plenty to see , eat and shop in This unique environment.

The Old Town District. It is Istanbul's beating heart. You are within the real Turkish tradition and you feel like home. One have to be careful because it is very crowded, otherwise it is a good place to get dried fruits and nuts. Also if you are a herbs person you will find it there.
A great place to stay!. We stayed in the Hotel Amira here. A very good choice. Close to the most interesting sites and a great area to just walk around.

The place to stay. First time we went to Istanbul I read endlessly about where to stay. Definitely stay in this area of town if you are a regular tourist wanting to see the sights. The other areas are great but this is the place to stay especially if it is your first time...The locals are terrific but don't get in a taxi without agreeing the price first.

Very moving.. The Sultanahmet was one of the most moving experiences of my life. The energetic concentration from eons of devotional gatherings is palpable and quite beyond description. It has to be experienced first hand.

Every time i come here, i feel the history . One of the places in the world to see, feel and live the history. If you're traveler exploring the world, this place, with its beauties, historic tissues and the scents coming from traditional restourants, is amongst the first ones.
Sultanahmet District. plenty to do and see in this area, spice bazzar, blue mosque, museums some very good resturants as well as bars

beautiful view great locaation. spent two days exploring the district my second trip to Istanbul and this trip I stayed in the district to get a great feel of old Istanbul, from historic sites to the Grand bazza to wonderful small restaurants with excellent local foods
Pastry . You find very cool Turkish sweets, Turkish resturant and I saw some old building also I like sultanahmet district

Great!. It is one of the most amazing parts of Istanbul. There is a lot of lanmarks to see, good food to eat. You will never forget that experience. It is very crowded and noisy, you have to be prepared to be surrounded by thousands of people. But in other way that is charming too :)
history everywhere. buy a museum card .good value and allows visits to several places....check out prayer times at blue mosque before you visit.

Sultan Ahmet. What an area to visit - historic and yet it blends in with the modern world. Great food if you hunt for it. Spice Bazaar and Grand bazaar area within walking distance. Wonderful square to walk around and plenty of photo opportunities with The Blue Mosque and Sophia Hagia in one long line with the Topkapi Palace not far behind. Easy to get to area so do include it in your itinerary.

Eastern & European mix culture !!. A great blend of Eastern and Euro culture fused together with centuries old buildings and warm hospitality of the locals . The shops are colorful and the buildings are beautiful !!Shopping is excellent and food is tasty !! The tourists are a treat to watch as well . The whole ambiance with the Ottoman era architecture is rare !!
We stayed in Sultanhamet district,is great location. Great place to visit Istambul,all the historical places are mainly there and easy access to others.Good restaurants,stores,transportation.

Sightseeing. Very different from where we stayed at Taksim. All sights are here but transport is so good it doesn't matter where u stay. Just hop on the train n u are there. Love the architecture and buildings and walking around the streets. Then went off to grand bazaar to do shopping. Nice restaurants in the area. Personally, I would still stay again close to Taksim and Istiklall street. My teens love Taksim

Beautiful City. pushy vendors. This was our first visit to Istanbul. It had been on our travel list for many years and we finally had the opportunity to tie a visit into a family trip to Europe. We stayed for a week at a lovely hotel in the Sultanahmet district and loved the area. Many historical, cultural and religious sites along with shopping and many restaurants are within easy walking distance. Walking is easily supplemented by Istanbul's fine mass transit system if you want to other city districts. We loved the historical, cultural and religious sites (we have reviews of the individual sites posted separately). Restaurants were plentiful and many had great city and sea views. Shopping was everywhere, and given the current strength of the US dollar good buys were available. Note though vendors can be aggressive. My wife and I highly recommend the district for tourists. We stayed for seven days and enjoyed every minute of it.

Not only Grand Bazaar. I would sugggest to walk through the streets of Cemberlitas,to the seaside,dont skip Küçük Haya Sofya.Gulhane park with its muzeums and cafe terrace,Galata tower view is absolutely adorable and of course the lanes near Vilayet(my favourite parts)Also the area near Laleli with a few Byzanine temples and behind the university gate where some shows are held.
Busy district. Generally nice, lots of must visit sites on a very small area, needless to be said it is very touristy and crowded at times. Get there early to get some breathing space.
Old and noisy, in a good way. It's good just walking around there. No shopping if you don't like it, some good eating and seeing lots of thousand-year-old buildings.

Disney land for adults - Brilliant for unashamed tourism. Disneyland for adults! Great for uninhibited gawping with decent quality souvenir shopping and a touch of culture and history thrown in - and no shortage of restaurants, cafes etc. Makes you wonder where the real Istanbul is.....maybe will find it next time.
this IS Istanbul. For me, this district is Istanbul. All the major historical sights are here including a couple of the "Wonders of the World". There is chaos for sure, but it's a phenomenal area.
old town. old town of istanbul wuith many shops and hotels, big bazaar is very close.also the oriental bazaar. also public transportation(tram)i was several times in istanbul and the last in 2014
wasn't what I expected. This district was fun and not overly crowded. We enjoyed window shopping and people watching. Many of the same types of stores buworth seeing nonethe less

So much to see and do. We stayed in Sultanahmet - the old city and would stay there again. Easy access to all the interesting places in Istanbul, easy to catch the tram, close to the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market, lots of restaurants, etc. The most central and interesting place to stay.

So much to see, so much to do - all in walking distance. It's all here! Glorious architecture and historical sites, bazaars, hotels big and small, restaurants in many flavours, palaces and cruises, museums. You can fill every hour in Sultanahmet with experiences, without wasting your holiday travelling from A to B.Transport is easy despite the narrow streets and traffic. A unified ticketing system lets you ride trams and the metro, while museum passes save on entry fees.Don't self-drive! Take a shuttle, bus or metro from the airport (fly into Ataturk if you can, the ride from Sabiha Gokcen is longer). Be prepared to walk - you'll see and hear so much more. On a budget? Skip the packaged tours and do them yourself. Rent audio guides at the main sites. Get the 12TL 2 hour Bosphorus cruise. Pack a good guidebook, and pick up some maps. Have an adventure! Don't miss the Hagia Sofia, the Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cisterns, the Blue Mosque (dress code alert), and the very fine archaeological museum.Oh, and buying a carpet is NOT compulsory - but expect to be sold one multiple times!
A place to see.. It is good just to walk round and see and smell as you go. If you want to shop then there are bargains. Decide what you want and are prepared to pay and then haggle.
great neighborhood. It was great fun to wander about taking in the sights, the mosques, the bazaars, and the restaurants.
Very cool. Lots of cool bars and restaurants, with some places open very late. Quite touristy, but still with a very authentic feel.

Another must see. All the great monuments are in this area, this is where you will want to spend a lot of time. Wear walking shoes, bring a camera and women should always have a headscarf to cover up when entering the mosques.

You can't dislike this place. The tourist hub of istanbul! Sultanahmet will fill you full of the Turkish culture, the food, the attractions, scenery, the sites, the things to do. You could spend a week in Sultanahmet and still not get it all done. Whether it be the grand bazaar, the blue mosque, the hagia sofya or anything. Sultanahmet is the tourist area with the major istanbul sites. Explore by bus or by the T1 trams that will take you around. Alternatively if it's a nice day just walk wherever you want to go. It's rich in history and culture and you would be absolutely bonkers to go to istanbul and not go to Sultanahmet.
Iconic Istanbul landmarks minutes apart by foot.. This district, in the old city, is the location of the most well known sites of Istanbul. It is easily navigated on foot without the use of a guide.

Condensed history. Testimony to the Turkish good habit of not destroying but conserving history even when religion changes as testified by the glorious Ayasofia, centerpiece of this ancient neighbourhood. Laced with todays hustle bustle, it is a huge tourist trap and must do source of contemplation at the same time.
Best place to buy souvenirs. A lot of local markets, try to always bargain.Be careful with the kurdos around, they are not friendly.
Nice experience. probably you'll visit few times, not suficient with only one, very especial experience , too many people, all very sweet, mixute of frangances

Old City. If you want to get good food, then te Sultanahmet is the place to be. Redtaurants vary from fancy to simple. To get a good view of the blie mosque and Hagia Sophia, choose a restarant that offers rooftop dining.
So much history. It is lovely to walk through Sultanahmet District and visit the historic sites. Roads of cobblestone and so many great restaurants to sit outside and enjoy the area.

lovely little historical suburb close to all the major highlights. Hotels, tourist shops, great views from your hotel if you are lucky, and close to the Blue Mosque, Ayasofia etc. this little old suburb of Istanbul is a must-see, even if you choose not to stay there. Many narrow little streets with smaller, more local restaurants and shops, but almost all shops here are aimed at tourists. Despite this, they have beautiful stuff and one can bargain in most shops. The Arasta Bazaaar is just up the road and is open at night. The restaurants are priced in the mid-to-high range and there are many to choose from. Getting from Ataturk airport to here is about 55lira depending not traffic (take a yellow metre taxi and insist that he has the metre on) and from the other airport much more. We went on to Kalkan along the coast afterwards and prices of curios here were sometimes cheaper than in Kalkan.
Great district to stay. This district is the old city, with so many attractions to see you could spend 3-4 days easily and not leave the area.
Must see. To get the real feel of Istanbul you have to visit here. You can buy just about anything at the hundreds of stalls.

Sultanahmet District old Istanbul. The Sultanamet district is the old part of European Istanbul, a partly tourist partly local district down the hill from the Hippodrome - Bule Mosque - Hagia Sophia tourist area. Lots of local shops, small and historic mosques, narrow streets, parks, and fountains. Historic sites are well marked with signs in English and Turkish and sometimes other languages. A number of good, small, and Turkish style hotels and cafes. Well worth a morning or afternoon just wandering around to experience 19th and 20th - and earlier - Istanbul.

Pictures will never do this place justice. The visit to the Sultanahmet district in Istanbul is a totally sensory experience. You need to be among the people and experience the sights, sounds and smells. There are millions of mental snapshots you will take and never forget.

Touristy but vibrant. This area is loaded with food shops, souvenir shops and 'touts' but it is also central to some main attractions in Istanbul. You don't have to go far off the main drag to experience a quieter more sedate neighbourhood. Its an ideal location from which to explore the famous Blue Mosque, Hagyarsofia and Gulhane Palace.

Must visit or stay!. I stayed one week in the district, every site to visit is there. Nice restaurants and hotels are very popular so reserve in advance. You will be in the heart of its historical sites.

Sultanahmet District. This is the must do district of Istanbul. It's best to get there using the wonderful Istanbul metro system. We never had problems taking cabs in other parts of the city - but even our guide recommended that we not take a cab in this area. Once there you can walk to many of the sites - but be aware that it's a very large district. Give yourself at least a couple of days to visit the sites and shop in the bazaars.
So much to see. The whole place was buzzing with life. Friendly people who were so helpful. Excellent buildings. Quite an adventure.

An assault (in a good way) to the senses!. The hawking, spice smells, vivid colors,, mysterious veils, exotic fruits, both fresh and dried. come at you all at once! You can't look, hear or smell fast enough! Loved it!

Place must to visit. Very beautiful place
BUT
Dont buy or eat in sultan ahmed district
Everything overpriced
Go to another local restaurant same delicious food with reasonable prices

Lots to see and do in Sultanhamet. Sultanhamet is a corner of Istanbul that has history, sights, shopping, restaurants and so much more. You can walk around and find a plethora of options depending on your mood. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Basilica Cistern are within a few blocks of each other, with restaurant row in between and parks for you to rest. Definitely a place to see while in Istanbul. I stayed in the district and it was the best location for my 1st time visit

Sultanahmet is THE place to be to see the highlights of the city and the have some good food! Be aware of the fact that. Sultanahmet is THE place to be to see the highlights of the city and the have some good food! Be aware of the fact that you will pay loads more than you do in other parts of the town but sit down and have sth small to eat... Its nice just to inhale the atmosphere...

Close to all the tourist attractions. We rented an AirBnB apartment in walking distance of Sultanahmet Square and the surrounding Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and other attractions. A great neighborhood with many restaurants, tea houses, shopping and the promenade along the Bosphorous. The five times a day call to prayer from three neighborhood mosques was not too noisy because this is not a dense neighborhood but light sleepers might want to bring ear plugs for the 4:00 am first call. Many small boutique hotels as well.

Best district to stay in Istanbul. I would definitely recommend staying in the Sultanahmet District when visiting Istanbul. It is historical yet lively and a lot of attractions are within walking distance, like the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Grand Bazaar. It is also the start point of the Big Bus hop-on hop-off buses, and we found that a 2 day bus pass is more than enough to see the rest of the city. The first day we arrived in the afternoon and just took a loop on the bus to see all the sites and to decide which ones we wanted to visit the next day. Big Bus tickets are available from the buses in front of Hagia Sophia and cheaper if you buy them direct rather than from the travel agents around.Public transport is also available close by if you don't want to use the Big Bus. From here we also booked a boat trip up the Bosphorus to the Black Sea, and they pick you up at your hotel so no need to worry about that.Airport transfer tip: Book an airport shuttle from one of the travel agents instead of booking a taxi. It takes a bit longer but you will pay at least half the price. They usually leave every hour, just book a day or 2 in advance and they pick you up at your hotel.Tip: Don't go during Eid. We were there over the Eid Holiday weekend and it was incredibly crowded and the ferries and public transport were way too busy to use.
