The restaurants and hotels near Hagia Sophia are expensive, but if one chooses to stay down the hill near Sokkullu Pasa, the prices are reasonable, also the spices and sweets are cheaper here than Grand Bazaar.The main problem in Sultanahmet area is traffic jam often caused tourist coaches and minivans.
Loved the area. It was very interesting to be in the district with so much colour and life.. The lively atmosphere .. So much to eat and look at .. Also a shopper's delight..
First time to Turkey. Definitely a place to check out. However, i wouldn't stay in this area. Stay near Istiklal street. But you have spend a day in Sultanahmet.
Treasure Hunting!. Very busy here but there are so many treasures to be found! Loved all of the spices, shops, art and food. Take your time through this market and find your treasures!

Lots to see. Noisy, busy but fun marketplace. Row after row after row after aisle after aisle of ceramics, rugs, leather goods, jewelry, scarves - it's a shopper's dream. Our guide told us the merchants will sell honest goods, meaning, if he tells you he's selling you a diamond, it is a diamond or a rug is hand woven in Turkey, it's handwoven in Turkey. Knock off bags are sold as knock off bags. Everyone smokes so you can't linger long as the smoke will begin to burn your eyes but you need to pay a visit here.

Lively area. Love this part of Istanbul just wish we had a booked in a hotel there on my next visit we will so full of life, just watch out for pick pockets there were some very suspicious looking people in this area.

I enjoyed walking around Sultanahmet District. Very nice to walk around.Very clean.Need more signs in English.Need more English speaking service providers.Need more seating areas.Not nice when you're alone, having a company is a must, or else would be boring.

Historic center. Very nice neighborhood, very historical, central. Full of mosques, small streets, museums, stores, hotels. Well connected with public transport, port is nearby. Very vibrant. Must visit.

The heart of Old Istanbul. Great place with all the sights! Recommend picking up Turkish delight at one of the various spice stores near the metro and doing your shopping here as well, as the bazaar can be a little pricey.

My favourite are of Istanbul. My friend and I stayed at a hotel in another part of Istanbul prior to starting a tour but came back to Istanbul for a couple of days and stayed in the Sutanahmet district. From our hotel we caught a tram to the Grand Bazaar - 4 TL per trip - then walked to the Egyptian (or Spice) Bazaar and the Basilica Cistern. We didn't look at our map, preferring to wander down quiet streets to experience the area. We also walked down past Galata Bridge to catch a ferry down the Bosphorus Strait. We felt safe, loved the people and would stay in the district again should we return to Istanbul. We had visited the major historical sites as part of our tour - Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia - but they are within walking distance in this district as well.
Perfect area for tourists. I recommend this neighborhood for tourists. It is near all the major highlights, public transportation, piers, and markets.

Pure History. Sultan Ahmed District is one of the places with the most interesting history you could visit on earth. It has all kinds of attractions. The Blue Mosque, Santa Sofia, The Hipodrome, Gran Bazar, Basilica Cistern, good restaurants, everything. It has architecture, gastronomie, galeries, shopping, etc...

Spend a day or two here. There is lots of history and a variety of sites. To get the full picture and take in the depth and richness of this place, I would recommend a tour guide for the main sites. Harun from Meriva Travel blew us away with his knowledge.

Safe and full of life . Touristic, historic areas to explore. Perfect area to stay in if you want to have quick and easy access to the Historic sites in Sultanamet. Using the Istanbul Card is the best way to travel around Istanbul.We lived a street away from the tram line so we had quick and easy access. It was convenient to go back to the hotel to freshen up and continue out touring as it is terribly hot in September with temperatures reaching 38 degrees

Highly recommend. Stayed in Sultan Ahmet district. We loved it. It's close to Marmara Sea, and a few minutes walk to Haghia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Blue mosque. It has a tram station that will certainly facilitate your moving around in Istanbul. I've noticed it's cheaper than Taksim& other areas. It's a foreigners attraction mostly. As a Muslim the only thing I didn't like is that most restaurants& cafe's serve alcohol. Lovely souvenirs for affordable prices, especially near the tram station. If you walk further up the street you'll find leather shoes shops, all for affordable prices. The district itself is an amazing experience, with the small stone alleys and the traditionally- built houses, nos all turned into hotels.
Again! prepare your shoes. A lot of place to visit. And you must try all turkish delicious food in this area. Just need walking to many touristic place.

Great place. If you are going to Istanbul this is the first area you should visit...Sultanahmed district full of historic and spectacular sights like old churches mosques and the Basilica cistern..you can also try a traditional Turkish dishes from the many of the restaurants around..great place for sure fully recommended
Explore!. Sultanment has a stunning array of monuments, shops, restaurants and nightlife. So much for the tourist to see and explore. a great place to stay with so many hotels.

Crowded, crazy and brilliant!. An absolutely fascinating part of the city, wander around through all the markets and massive land marks for a few hours and you can easily imagine why this has been a centre if world trade and culture for well over two thousand years.

charming historical area. Excellent charming area to stay if this is your first time in Istanbul. You will find all major historical attractions within walking distance as well as plenty of shops and restaurants. The area feels safe and is convenient to the IST airport.
A must in Turkey . From old traditional Turkey to modern Turkey, all is available in walking distance. It's better to stay here if you are tourist or visiting first time

Hilly old town. Get off the beaten track and take the back alleys down to Cankurham Park. Then head NE back up to the Palace gate. The old wood multi-story buildings and mixed architecture are worth the steep walk.
A charming area. A lovely area with many nice restaurants. Go to the 4 Seasons and top of Aqua Blue facing the Blue Mosque.

Sultanahmet area !!!. It is the a great area , closed of the most important turistic objectiv. It is an info center wich you can use daily, for all kind of informations, tickets rezervations, transport permit , exchange rate, boat trips,..etc...Also you can find some small restaurants , for fast food if you are in a hurry. In the adiacent area there are all kind of restaurants , but the price are BIG.

The best place to stay in Istanbul. I've been to Istanbul a half dozen times, and find Sultanahmet the ideal place for walking to many of the area attractions. The shopping is great, especially for hand-made leather clothing, rugs and other textiles. The hotel choices are varied; something for everyone. And the street food is out of this world!
Nice place . It is a good place to go to. It has many local shops and restaurants. Also, there is a nice park. In addition to the blue mosque. Easy to reach using the tram.

great area to stay. great location with lots to see and do - all the main attractions are here also lots of reasonably priced restaurants - plenty of them with rooftops so don't be put off by the street facade as all the action is on the roof!

Amazing district. There is just so much packed into this part of Istanbul. So many major attractions are so close together you can easily walk between them. Although not all the attractions are covered, it is well worth getting a museum pass. Not only is it good value for money but it also speeds up you entry not having to queue for tickets. We spent three days here and stayed in the district too. Perfect! (PS plenty of toilet facilities too! Make sure you have some lira coins!)

A must while in Turkey. traditional part of town - more old school than the other parts of town. Usually filled with tourists. Lots of small stores filled with traditional pastries - also with knock off purses and other items. Also great place to stop and try some traditional food. It is known for its small stone pathways all throughout - make sure to bring comfortable shoes.
Good ... took the tram to Sultan Ahmed the area is touristic, good in general. you can find antique shops to buy souvenirs for your family and friends.
You can walk everywhere very easily. The best place to stay and explore old Istanbul. Stayed at the lovely Berge Hotel. You can walk to all the iconic historic sites from here.

Turkish delight. We only had 2 days so we arranged for a local guide. We saw & learned so much more in our short visit & made it fun when we met local venders that he knew. We were treated with Turkish delights & coffee.

Beautiful market areas. This was an interesting area. The market was beautiful to see. There were a variety of shops and friendly owners. I would not go here alone as a woman, but with a male it was fine.
Historic Interest. Very interesting part of Istanbul with lots of little manufacturing sites, restaurants and shops. Good area to stay and walk around and explore at your liesure.
Don't miss it. We had a lot of fun there ,tasting ,haggling enjoying the people and the culture and the surrounding ,we went back 3 time just to watch the people .
Great location . Great location for families and kids. Various kind of food and cafes. Food street in location of sultanahamet closes very late and very nice food.

Amazing Shopping Experience in Instanbul. If you are able to go here, you will not be sorry you spent time in this shopping area. You can find things here you can not find in almost any other location including rare spices in a large selection.
Very many interesting things.. It's very interesting, colorit and historical place. Many local beautiful things, delicious and historical repeates.
Nice experience. Just do all by foot, you want get lost, people are very friendly and helpful. Do not miss a coffe/tea shop and order a selection of sweets

Chaotic & charming. I started walking this morning and just got back.... 20.30! This area is chaotic & there's so much to see - can be a bit overwhelming. Make sure to find a serene corner and Turkish coffee regularly!
Ancient city. You are in the middle of Turkey history, within a minute you can see most of the 'must see' historical places.
great location for all things in Istanbul. Everything is in walking distance and is the 'one stop shop' for many of the must do things in Istanbul

Buzy, shopping and food street. The main street of sultanahmet, have majority of shops, money exchangers and restaurants. Money exchangers are not the best here. the best ones are in front of the grand bazar.
Close to everything, historic, religous, dining and shopping area. Both historic, religious, dining and shopping area. You have a smaller market with the same selection of shops as the Grand Market
Best Place in the World. The best place for chill-out tourism in the world. Lots of ancient buildings, lots of local shops and fast food restaurants if you come to miss them
nothing like this in Europe. just walk around. food, baths and monuments. including 2 of the top destinations in Turkey, Blue Mosque and Aya sofia

Spend your nights here. This area has a lot to offer for you to chill and hang out... especially those nights that you are a bit tired after the day... we spend three nights hereduring our 7 day stay... there are good restaurants with sits outside... souvenir shops... silk and jewelry shops... there is a good vibe overall...

buzzing. when we visited this area it was buzzing day and night - my main reservation is that we were constantly pursued by locals trying to lure you into their restaurant or carpet shop etc etc .... it does wear you down after a while

Must visit. Central location with lots of possibilities to shop for souvenirs (spices, sweets, tea, coffee etc) and spend time eating/drinking at lovely restaurants. Also not forget about ceramics, carpets (kilim) and clothes.

The best area to stay. The place to stay in Istanbul, so much history, culture and life, all within easy walking distance, just as well as I think it would be a brave person that would drive there :)There really is just so much to see and do there, everything from ancient buildings to fantastic food and shopping.I'm not sure as to why people would choose to stay in "new Istanbul"Gary

Most turistic area in Istanbul.. Wonderful district with hundreds of hotels, restaurants, souvenir shops, the Grand Bazar and the Arqueological Park which includes the incredibly fantastic Haghia Sophia, the Blue Mosque , Cistern Basilic and the Constantin Hipodrome (where there is an egyptian obelisc), all of these in a pedestrian area , it is connected with the rest of the city by trams with two different lines that at certain hours are very crowded. There are some other small mosques here and around this area, so you will hear as an echo the loud prayers almost every four hours...very particular aspect of their religion... You should try to book a hotel in this area that includes sights of the emblematic buildings ( Arcadia Blue and , the more affordable Lady Diana Hotel ,both have splendid views of Haghia Sophia ,the Blue Mosque and the Bosphorus Strait from their roof terrace restaurants, among other hotels).
Bautiful district. I stay here and love this place. In winter time here is less peoples and can realax on street and restourants, many small and nice shops

Mohamed, Egypt . Very nice and quiet district with flat streets , no ramps like Taksim area which can be very annoying specially for old ages . Choose place near Tram stations and you can go anywhere.

The place to be based if visiting Istanbul. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia amongst other main attractions are based in this area. Good transport links can get you to other parts of Istanbul easily. But you should base yourself in this part of town.
Its nice, don't miss it. Its a great place to see but be careful for shopping, once they know you are tourist they MIGHT cheat you, having a Turkish friend with you make a big different. Good luck.
To see at least. Sultanahmet is a popular place for the tourist where locals are mostly never going. It is noisy and crowded with too many restaurant serving the same food.

Hustling and Bustling. Tonnes of restaurants and shops located in this area. There is so much to see and buy here. The prices of the restaurants were high, have to really make your own selection carefully. As for shopping, there are different kind of things you can get here, from Turkish delights to souvenirs and clothing.

Best place to base yourself for the sights.. Great! Geared for tourists .eg the precinct between the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofia has beautiful flower beds, water features and benches where you can rest and enjoy the views..
Must see of the city. This is the historic district of Istanbul. Definitely a must see if you are visiting the city. This is where all the famous buildings are located. All within walking distance.
Beautiful. Beautiful and quiet, accessible tram and bus, you could go there and spend all day, then have dinner in the many places nearby.not a good place to buy souvenirs though!

Can't Miss it BUT.... be prepared for the negatives. You can not miss all of the major sites located here. HOWEVER the men on the street, and the shopkeepers ( not all, but too many) are truly rude and obnoxious. This is not a reason to avoid many stops here, just be aware of what to expect. Another surprise, since so many of our friends raved about the absolutely great Turkish food, generally it was disappointing.

Soooo much to see. This area of Istanbul will most likely be your first stop. Make sure you plan your visit here carefully. There is so much to see, and you can get very overwhelmed. There are many good restaurants, but most of them have "pushy" staff asking you to sit.

This is the place that has it all!. If visiting Istanbul, pay the slightly higher prices for hotels (they are wonderful) and walk the cobblestone streets. Window shopping, the Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, Museum of Islam Art, Topeki Palace - everything is within walking district. Many great restaurants, and the tram helps too.

Istanbul Family Trip. If it is your first trip to Istanbul stay in this district. All the major historic sites and attractions are here and you are walking through history everywhere you go, hard to describe the feeling. Hippodrome, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Cemberlitas, Restaurants, shopping. I'm ready to go back

Sultanamet-the Old Town !. This is a major tourist attraction but a must see when visiting Istanbul ! There is the Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia , Hippodrome and Basilica Cistern. There are many restaurants and shops. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar need to be seen but they are crazy places and watch the prices. If you like to negotiatem it is the place for you ! Restaurants like to call you in to their restaurants and others try to sell you tours or look at their carpets, etc. On most occasions if you aren't interested just keep walking or say" no thank you" and keep walking . This area has many kodak moments, a must see and enjoy !

Leisure strolling shopping and eating. Make sure you leave time for leisure strolls through this district. Although shopkeepers and restaurant owners will approach you to check their place out they are good humoured and polite

So Much To See, So Much To Do!. Lovely little twisty cobblestone streets opening out to stupendous views. The Blue Mosque, the Aya Sophia, the Grand Bazaar, the Cisterns----there is just so much to drown your senses in the Sultanahmet district----try and stay there!
Amazing experience. Definitely worth a trip to the spice markets. Lots of amazing colour, smells and variety of Turkish teas. This was one of my highlights from my trip to Turkey.
Great location. Great spot for the new visitors in Istanbul with all the attractions all within walking distance. Plenty of places to eat and drink as well as just to cool off from the day heat.
vibrant and very happening. A very vibrant district, close to shops and eateries, and walking distance to many tourist attractions

Heart of the old city. Excellent spot to spend an evening in Istanbul and enjoy the famous 'air of Istanbul.'Don't bother with the tourist hop-on-hop-off buses - many attractions within Istanbul are within walking distance of one another, centered around the Sultanahmet District, with the Sultanahmet Tram (T1) giving you easy access. The transport system has also recently been revamped so you can buy a single 'Istanbulkarte' transport pass, load credits onto it and use it on buses, metro and tram lines alike.
Enjoy the History. Centre of many civilizations Romans ,Byzintines ,Ottomans..so you should go and see..Blue mousqe.Hagis Sophia ,water cistern ,hippodrome all in same area

Give at least a day!. Because you will need considerable time to see all attractions around! Get there with tram, start with Sultanahmet Mosque -your mini shorts/skirts might be a prob, they give clothes to cover on to get in-, walk on the Hipodrom Str to see obelisks, climb to get to Topkapi Palace -pay for the audio guide, it's worth it- give at least 4 hours to there. Then walk next, Gulhane Park and then, Hagia Sophia. Be fascinated with the mosaics seen under the paint - some part inside is under restoration.
Great views. We went to Istanbul in July, and We really enjoyed it! It was very hot but the best thing was getting lost at Sultanahmet! You can´t miss it!
Shopping!. Enjoyable for fun shopping. Nice place to see. We had visited it several times. We took pictures and enjoyed the space. The visited hours are accommodated. Don't miss it!

an Istanbul must !!!. a must see place in Istanbul, old town, shops and restaurants . The most historical place. It must be the first item at the to do list !!! Tram is passing by the place , and there are the most important MOsques for ex. Sultanahmet, Sofia. Sultanahmet meatball is a traditional eat..
shopping vaganza. marvellous shopping trip at spectacular street with flocks of tourist tasting local delicacies esp the icecream and lokum

great. if you have only one day in Istanbul, this is the first place to visit. great atmosphere, lot of people, different nationalities and languages all over the World. locals are great traders. they are very polite, very quick you are becoming a 'friend', but they know what they wants. they wants to sell, as much and expensive you may suffer...

Knowing an other culture. Is a comercial and touristic city so walking in the shops you can find good and cheap clothes...tukey is a big textil producer...you can find very agreable and exotic souvenirs to your friend and family nice oriental food...itis nice to walk around...

Living the history. I had the chance to do a tour myself like this. I started with Hagia Sophia in the morning when it is not very crowded, then Topkapı Palace, Hippodrome, Blue Mosque and finally Basilica Cistern. I confess that it is too much but if you have a short time to visit it is worthy for a speedy touring.
Nice place to go. Really moving place with hundred faced people from all over the world. Awesome smells and colorful shops.Recommended!

All in one place. The first choice place to visit . Blue mosque, Aya Sofya, Hippodrome, museums.. all in one place. take the metro to sultanahmet station. You need one full day. Grand Bazar is near by in Byazit metro station , which is two stations before sultanahmet station

The starting point in Istanbul. The first place to head in Istanbul is Sultanahmet Square, where you will find most of the must see places. It is also just a nice place to spend time, surrounded by historic buildings. It's size means that it didn't feel too crowded even when it was very busy.It was also very clean and, whilst there were many tour guides etc around, we never felt pressured into anything.Overall, I thought it was a really nice place to be and a great starting point for some sightseeing.

One of the two hearts of Istanbul. The Sultanahment District is where a large number of ths historical attractions are: all within easy walking distance or a quick couple of stops away on the tram. Hagia Sophiya, Blue mosque, Basilica cistern, Column of Constantine, Topkapi palace, Grand Bazaar ... everything is within easy reach. And of course, not to mention the incredible array of restaurants and shops!
Buy Yuans.. Do not step on the lines on the pavements - whenever you do that the Chinese Yuan drops lower on currency markets. Great atmosphere by the way.

A feast for the eyes.. Give yourself plenty of time in this district because there is just so much to see. Buy spices.Buy Turkish delight. In fact you can buy anything around here. Everywhere you look is a feats for the eyes. Enjoy.

great district!. So much to see and do in this area, easy to get around by foot, hop on hop off bus or tram. Great location to stay.Busy with locals and tourist all day and until late at night. Always felt safe and many good places to eat.

Central point, good for accomodation. It is the best place to spend the evening, you can find a lot of restaurants and coffee shops but also souvenir shops. My recommendation is to go for shopping in Grand Bazaar, is cheaper.

A travellers paradise. Sultanahmet District is the heart of Istanbul.All the main monuments are located here like the Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Saray), etcThis area has all types of hotels and restaurants. With all the sightseeing places within walking distance, this isrightly the travellers choice.All the shopping is there for you as shops provide you all you need and buy.
Sultanahmet district. Definitely must stay in the area, so much to see and do, we were able to walk everywhere to see all of the attractions

A breath of the Past. My hotel was a 5-minute walk from Sultanahmet Square. Every night my friend and I would walk through Arasta Bazaar (a very small bazaar with variably cheap and very expensive shops) and up to the square. The area is always full of life. The view of the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia, the tiled streets and greenery, combined with the sea breeze, made the experience extremely pleasant.There are many shops, cafes, and restaurants there, in addition to the tramway station where you can simply pay 4TL and have a quick ride anywhere you want.I've been in Fatih and Taksim years before. But I loved Sultanahmet the most!

Best of Sultanahmet District. There are many interesting places to visit and lots of cafe for dining too. Places of interest is nearby and you can easily walk to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Grand Covered Bazaar and some other interesting places around the district. Food is also cheap and good.

Historical and beautiful . Sultanahmet has a lot of attractions. Starting with the blue mosque was a very special visit to see this place and moving on to topkapi where we visited all the historical sultans and the life they used to have and there old places. It is very special experience. Also in sultanahmet there is the grand amazing bazzar one of the largest in the world. If you are not careful you can spend all your money easily. Enjoy your time.

Senses overload. Immerse yourself in the past and present. Explore the many restaurants, parks, markets and the spice bazaar. Meet the friendly shopkeepers from jewelers to carpet makers. indulge in apple tea, baklava and turkish delight.

Avoid advanced booking. Lucky we got a hotel 5 mins walk to Sultanahmet. Truly vibrant and bustling with tourists from all parts of the world. Don't go booking these tours, a lot of things can be done free of charge. No long queues to any sites, you're normally inside within 15 mins, and only pay the cost of the ticket. Also, and most importantly, all the historical sites are practically next to each other - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace - so avoid bring stung by tour guides and taxi drivers.

A relaxing stroll around Old Istanbul. A great place to experience the older districts of Istanbul. Plenty of opportunities to witness the day to day life of the locals, escape the tourist trappings of the busier/commercial streets of the city and haggle in the undercover bazaar before enjoying a cup or two of apple tea in a side street café.

A must see even if in istanbul for only 48 hours. This is the most significant cluster of structures from the zenith of the Ottoman empire all within a few blocks as well as remnants of the Byzantines,the longest empire the world has seen

Go for the experience, but buy somewhere else.. Go to experience the market, it is very neat. It can get crowded so go early. However, actually buy somewhere else. Their prices were much higher than we found in other areas.
amazing. perfect location to stay, i just love to hear azan on each prayers. love how it so easy to get to other places via tram.

Perfect place to stay in istanbul. The Sultanahmet District is the perfect place to stay in Istanbul especially if you have a short stay. It may be a little touristic but everything is at a walking distance. You could stay at an hotel, eat your meals to close by restaurants, visit the tourist little market on tour way to the blue mosque or Haga Sophia. Best place to stay.
Amazing district. nice place to spend time there walking and exploring the district of old things with plenty of shopping center and restaurants or coffee shopYou will enjoy your time

Sultanahmet is the place to be!. Sultanahmet or Taksim? Sultanahmet it is! If you want to be away from the usual commercialized hustle bustle of city life - this is the place you want to go to. There are way too many sightseeing spots in this district - rich with history. There are many roadside restaurants, lots of tourists everywhere, beautiful scenic places in every alley. The vibe and feel of this place is slightly countryside or town-ish but that's where the charm lies. We loved this place when compared to the busy shopping Istiqlal street in Taksim. All the sightseeing spots are in walkable distance. There are many mosques here, a Sultanahmet square right in the middle of the famous Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia church where you can feed the pigeons. The area becomes quiet by evening time, so its a good idea to retreat back to your hotel by then unless you are in a group. Its a lovely place and we loved it!
Good seeing. A lot of shops around, you can try to drink a Tea, coffee Turc, with some cakes. Really life Turc in Istanbul make shoppings.
It's the tourist area. Coming to Istanbul the first time wet decided to stay in the old city, where all the monuments are. Good area for this

heart or real Istanbul. Best location to stay. Many food hotels in this are. Good food joints for dinners including Indian restaurant and specially for veterinary travellers. Attractions like Hagia Sophia,, Blue Mosque, cistern are in 5/7 minutes walking distance. Trams to go to Taksim are also,available from this area Happening place .You feel you are in real Turkey. topkapi palace is also 15 minutes away

Best of both worlds - Sightseeing and Shopping!. The Sultanahmet district has everything you need. Shops, landmarks, and more. If you do not wish to wander off too much then this is definitely an area to stay in. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, shops, restaurants and more are all in this area.

If you visit itanbul for historical sites, this is where you should stay. If you want to visit istanbul from historical point of view then you must stay in this district, the souther part, near to Blue mosque is quite reasonable and provides easy and walkable access to main attractions. the Taxi fares from Ataturk Airport are also very reasonable as this district is only 25-30 mins drive. with the new trainline it will be even more cheaply accessible hopefully in future. the eat out options are amazing so you dont have to worry about that. plus staying here gives you a feel of Old Ottomon empire :)

Arabian Days. The gold market was one of the most interesting parts of Istanbul. The vendors have almost anything you can think of and the gold is sold by weight, not design. The vendors were all very friendly towards Americans and everything was "no problem".

Mesmerisng istanbul. This is the best place to be in istanbul for a tourist looking to spend a few days in this historic and beautiful city . The blue mosque , aya Sofia and he grand bazaar are a stones throw away from each other and the entire location is bustling with eateries of all cuisines , mainly the Turkish food like kebabs and shawarma's . There is a lot to shop and see along this location such as the spice bazaar , a must for all tourists for the amazing spices and sweetmeat shops , the tramway is the most convenient way to get there from the grand bazaar . To sum it up , this is the place to be for a tourist .

Best area for first timers. We stayed at a hotel in this area and it was very convenient. Most of the sigh seeing , especially for the first time visitor are in this area. Lots of local shops, restaurants, caffees,etc..Istanbul is a gorgeous city and this area is perfect to get to everywhere and do anything you want to do while in Istanbul

Busy and noisy. Lots of tourists and shops in the area. Lots and lots of places to eat as expected for a touristy area but I would suggest that you beware as some restaurants are always trying to lure you in and the food could be most likely sub-par compared to normal Turkish standards though of course I cannot speak for all of them.
Beautiful!. Beautiful area with lots of really cool cafes, eateries and sights. Perfect to relax and take in the beauty and vibrancy of just being in Istanbul.

Historic and cheerful. As many people know, this old city of Istanbul is existing on long history. We were moved by the deep history at Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and so on. And, at the same time, we felt the energy of modern Turkey at every corner of Sultanahmet and were so excited.

Exotic!!!. Wandering around the Sultenahmet District is endlessly fascinating with the sights and sounds and fthe feeling of centuries of history making it what it is today! Beautiful, high quality "Magic" rugs can be yours if you choose to bargain for one - or 2 or any amount of beautiful or cheap souvenirs can be yours. Just take your pick. Remember the people trying to sell you things are earning money to feed their families so don't get upset and rude, Just firmly say No and move on.

Tourist stop. Overall a pleasant place to visit, although the constant calling out by shop & restaurant staff became tiresome after a while. Fascinating place to visit with some very nice bars & restaurants. Sights to see include the Blue Mosque.We stayed at a very nice boutique hotel - Senatus -wonderful staff, very comfortable room & great breakfast.

Shopping paradise. This is a fun and interesting area in Istanbul. Although very focused on tourists the prices and quality are reasonable in the shops and the food in most restaurants is good. The bazaar alongside the Blue Mosque is good value and the range means that most shopping needs can be met in one location.
Liked it. Great places to eat. I really enjoyed shisha. Has a lot of interesting touristic places. This is the place to book a hotel.
great. Great all around. Nice area to just people watch. Very interesting cafes and eateries. Dessert is a must.

a must see. We were here for a brief time on a cruise trip to Istanbul, it was very colourful and fun to visit. I would love to go back and spend more time here as it is very big and it takes time to see everything.

Perfect district to feel real Istanbul. Our hostel was in this district, it is easy to manage with this part of city - Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, beautiful Bosphorus, everything is close and also has many coffee bars and restaurants around. I recommend to everybody who want to feel real Istanbul and Turkey to find acommodation in this area.
Historical masterpieces. This district offers the most important cultural and historical heritage from Byzantine and Ottoman periods.

Convenient for tourists. It's a central district of Istanbul and most of the tourist attractions are located in this area. Blue mosque, Sophia Hagia, Grand bazar,Spice market and Topkapi palace are all in this area and thus the best of restaurants, hotels are also in this area.
Awsome!. I stayed in the Sultanahmet District. It is fantastic! So lively with people, food, bars. I will be going back!

The Best Place to be in Istanbul. The BEST place to be in Istanbul! Old city, cobblestone streets, great markets and bazaars, beautiful architecture! Saw most of Istanbul but most impressed with the Sultanahmet District. Find Baklava, corn on the cob, water chestnuts and kebab almost anywhere.
Very nice area. It is a very nice area , many restaurants, cafés , shops ,you can reach easly by metro. Neas sultan ahmad and haya sofia.

The place to be in Istanbul . Sultanahmet is the place to be in Istanbul: is easy to walk around and you have everything that matter to see and buy!!!Listing the things in the area will fill the bucket list of all tourists. My advice: leave the guide at home and just walk around and see and smell and hear what is around you...let all the senses enjoy the wonder of Istanbul.

A Great Way to Spend a Few Hours!. The district is a great means by which to experience the common idea of what the orient is and what it used to represent. From traditional Turkish delicacies to intricate Persian carpets, one stumbles upon a great way to spend a few hours. However, for all the positives - the food and cafes, the reassuring buzz of activity (local and tourist) and proximity to other important tourist attractions - one must remain perceptive to the occasional pushy vendor eager to take advantage of unsuspecting and naive tourist with a bad deal.

A must visit while in Istanbul. This area is stunning with it's mosques & rich history-delivious eateries, markets, etc, to really imerse youself just weave theough the streets discivering the charms if this neighbourhood,
Unexpectedly amazing. Despite the extreme heat & constant crowd this area has an amazing vibe that you simply can't get enough of
An excellent place to stay. We stayed in this area and could walk to all the major attractions - blue mosque, hagia sophia, topkapi palace and grand bazaar.

Old City Highlight!. Some people say that the old city of Istanbul is too touristy but I found it perfect for what you need as a tourist. All the main historical sights are right there within easy walking distance. Plenty of great restaurants and shopping for souvenirs. Loved staying in this area, chose to stay in Taksim at the end of my stay and it's very different. Definitely worth it to see/stay on both sides if you get chance.

Aroma of Eastern Spices. Great place to roam through although the goods offered are much the same shop after shop. A point of warning Make sure you remember which way you came in. Very easy to get lost!

clean and cozy. The area makes you feel at home, specially for tea and sea lovers; they will enjoy a cup of tea in the open air or have a trip in the Bosphorus at a reasonable price.There are boutiques that sells gifts and traditional turkey clothes they are a bit expensive but you can get deals if you negotiate with the salesmen. Also the restaurants range from cheap to expensive ones so there is basically something for every taste.It is the heart of sightseeing.

A must visit. You should wander through the back alley's and enjoy (much better food than the tourist area).In terms of areas we really enjoyed the area around the Mr Cook restaurant, the shops were friendlier and less pushy.

The heart of old Istanbul. Our hotel was here, in the heart of the old city, and within easy walking distance of all the major attractions that we wanted to see. There are plenty of both very modern and very old hotels to choose from in the Sultanahmet district, which makes it an ideal base for a city holiday. Lots of restaurants too, to suit all pockets.

Good location very nice palace . Walking area good enjoying placed really this district is very ancient and all old and beautiful mosque blue mosque and grand bazaar also otman place and watch tower really every thing is on walking distance .

Tourists and more tourists. I wouldn't say this to be a trap but for the day-old traveller to Istanbul, it could be. Hotels are mostly in this area and hence prices of food and merchandise are ludicrous. Move away 2 kms and you'll find better prices for food usw. The district offers an little piece of Istanbul in terms of food and shopping but this is not the place to go for that. You have the Grand Bazaar for it.

Turisty but nice. If you hate touristy paces you'll probably have your doubs about this area, but it's still a must. The calling for prayer in the evening is really nice, so it's good to spend an evening or so walking around the area for the evening prayer.

This what you imagine Istanbul to look like. What a great area. This is the place to stay. We spent 5 days exploring Istanbul and this part had pretty much everything. As a consequence of having so many landmarks there were a lot of people, but we all managed without too many problems. Walking around just on sunset is magical. We look forward to coming back one day.

a Fascinating Location with both tourist attractions and lots of restaurants. i loved the big open square with the 2 beatutiful mosques, that of Sultan Ahmed and that of Agia Sofia, but there were long queues of people waiting to enter, so i voted to sit in a nice cafe with a big plane tree and a nice breeze.If you want information, look out for the municiple Guides with "ASK ME" on their blue and white blouses, who provided me with a nice free map of Istanbul, which i found a brilliant touch.You can find many shops on the main street where the tram rail is, mainly sweet shops, kebab and some simple clothes stores. The Grand Bazaar is about 2 or 3 stops further down with the tram.however, the nice surprise were the side streets opposite the tram station, which were choc a bloc with nice little eating places, and even a couple of more elegant style restaurants, so we tried one and enjoyed the cleanliness and a tasty meal vegetable dish called Imam Bayaldi, with aubergines.

Vibrating suburb. Probably the best address in Istanbul if you a tourist. Caters for both back packers and with fat wallets. Surprisingly it's neat and well maintained too. Unending street food alleys and curios shop make up the colour in the area.
Everything at walking distance. It is busy, crowded but everything is at walking distance and you can get decent food and reasonable things to do.

Sultanahmet - The Heart of Istanbul. The Historical Sultanahmet District is the place to stay or visit in Istanbul. Almost all the historical places of interest are in this area. The Hagia Sophia, The Blue Mosque, The Basilica Cistern, The Grand Bazaar and some more are located within a 10 minute walk. Its decorated with beautiful fountains, pebbled streets full of nice restaurants which cater to tastes of people from all over the world. The area is well connected to other parts through Metro Train Service.

Old town is the best. Sultanahmet is my most loved area in Istanbul. It is old and has a great history with all its buildings and culture. The best and safest place to stay in Ist. You will be in the centre of history and very safe in cozy environment. It is very calming and comforting at nights, in contrary to Taksim.
Great Shopping. Great for shopping and hanging out. If your Wife is a "Shopzilla" then you can take her there for good inexpensive trinkets and gifts

Istanbul at its best. It is great just to walk around this area and experience Istanbul. It felt safe and there are many renovated buildings and boutique hotels as well as restaurants. The grand bazaar is a must.

Sultanahmet is great location for walking to almost all historical sights.. We stayed at the White House boutique hotel in Sultanahmet. Excellent hotel. We could walk to almost all the historical sights and also to the Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar and lots of outdoor restaurants. Fantastic.

All in one place. There is so much to see and do in this area, food, markets Mosque's and shops, tours for all to choseWe have been 3 times and there's still more to see.Well worth several days at least

Busy and fun . A very busy tourist focused place in Istanbul. A must see if you are in town. You will get hassled a little by people trying to sell you tour guide services but most will leave you alone when you say no. Many things to see an do in this area and some of Istanbul's major attractions.

An experience not to be missed. Taking time to explore this area is great fun. There is much to see, and people are friendly. They may try to encourage you into their shop or restaurant but a simple 'no thanks' is all that is needed. Explore the back streets, little alley ways and of course the bazaar and you will have a wonderful time in the city. Follow the tram lines down the hill and you will find a nice park on the right, and continuing to follow the tram lines brings you to the vibrant waterfront, spice bazaar and a people watchers paradise!

A shopping experience with a difference. An amazing sight but you have to be thick skinned and the hassle you get from shop keepers is overpowering. Not a pleasant shopping experience. If they just left you alone to browse they might sell you something but we just got so irritated from the constant pressure to come and see!!

Great Historical Area. The Sultanahmet District is one of the best historical part of İstanbul. It needs to visit absolutely for shooting great pictures of traditional products, historical corners. I advise you to go to specific restaurants that you are informed before because there are a lot of restaurants and cafes around but i can not say that they are all really good quality. If you go there without having any restaurant advice then try to go to the restaurant where they do not try to convince you to go in, :). It is a safe area in general because it is a very touristical quarter and people try their best to make them content. I strongly advice to go there to see also the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sofia, Topkapı Palace, Basilica Cistern etc.. There is also free wifi area in front of the main entrance of the Blue Mosque but i have never used it, so i don't know if it works.

Beautiful old town. Many of Istanbul’s historical gems, mostly consisting of Byzantine and Ottoman-built monuments are in Old City. Most are located a short walk away from, if not immediately on the edges of, Sultanahmet Square.
Rich with colour. COLOUR COLOUR COLOUR everywhere. It's a feast for the eyes. I found people friendly and helpful and loved Istanbul.

Archaeological areas. Of the best areas to shop and have fun and the presence of Alatrih Ottoman monuments and the presence of mosques as well as shops selling antiquities and rare artifacts with restaurants and shops

SHOPPING PARADISE. Shop, shop and more shop --- But one must bargain as the guys are very persistent and you can get ripped off if you not street smart.
I enjoyed every minute in Sultanahmet and I certainly spent a fortune there. You cannot visit Istanbul and give this place a miss.

Never Dull. This is a very lively area full of historic sites and commerce. Beyogolu a little further North over the Galata bridge has more nightlife but despite some disparaging remarks i our guidebook we had some excellent and inexpensive meals here and it is at the heart of the historic city.

Shopping. This was well worth visiting and spending time in. Lots of crowds and plenty of walking but great shopping with both local and international brands to choose from. An exciting area we enjoyed before visiting a hotel (that used to be a train station) for drinks.

This area has it all.... This is a great area because almost everything is here... I mean Topkapi Palace, Hippodrome, Blue Mosque so much more.. the Grand Bazaar is a bit of a walk but not that far... I love Istanbul and this District - place to see and be seen ... amazing historical places every where I turn .. and you to ;)
do not miss. the hart of Istanbul you will feel thousands of years do not miss the Sultanahmet District any time of the day

One of the world's most spectacular squares with the view of the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. Lively, full of history, like in 1001 night's tales. Many great sights concentrated on one place. You can go back in time.

Great place to stay & see. It's a great place for everything from sightseeing to shopping to dine in. Very crowded though. Better do things by foot since taking taxis will end up in bumper to bumper traffic and the driver's attitude & the costing aren't the best.
HOT SPOT FOR SHOPPING. Great place to get ethnic products in one place.But bargaining is part of the culture and if one is not comfortable then they may not enjoy this bazaar.

A true Turkish Delight - Sweet and evocatively colourful - a great flavour for tourists.. I love wandering markets of all types when traveling and this market is not to be missed while in Istanbul! This is the place to buy your dates, Turkish delight, spices, fruit and sweets while in Istanbul. There is a nice mix of locals and tourists (not a total tourist trap) and the noise and women out shopping in the day make for a great taste of the eastern part of Turkish life. The market buildings are a spectacular reflection of the beauty of tile and mosaic work of the east and keep your camera ready to take some of the most colourful and spectacular 'moment of life' shots.
Lots to see. We had a full week in Istanbul and we spent most of it in sultanahmet. There is a ton of things to do and see. Don't miss it.

Loud, expansive and wonderful. A cacaphony of sounds and an overwhelming array of products. A real treat to experience. You can spend hours going along the rows of items for sale-everything and i do mean EVERYTHING is a available here. You will be cajoled to downright ordered to step into a shop.
Great area with many sites and things to do. Great area to visit, with many things to do and see. It is the best area to establish as your base, particularly if it is your first visit to Istanbul.

Old District Near Historical Sites - Lots of Eateries. If you wish to visit / stay in the area of Istanbul near the Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, etc then this is the area to visit. Lots of hotels and hostels. Many, many restaurants that will cater to every taste.
Historic. All the historic and most interesting places of Istanbul lies here and it is recommended to take a walk around this area to enjoy.

You can walk everywhere in Sultanhmet District, great place to stay!. This area is the pulse of the city! If you can get a hotel in this area you will not be disappointed as tons of sights, museums, shopping, restaurants and ATM's are around every corner. This is a safe neighborhood and not to be missed.
Don't let the guide lead you. Egyptian Spice bazaar is a must do but look around before making a purchase. We were there during Ramadan so relativel "quiet".
Best to go now, while it's still relatively safe.. Forget about the Mall of America. This place has to be the most interesting market I have visited. Check it out!

Must have Turkish coffee!. WOW! The tour books can not begin to describe the energy here. All of your senses will be tempted by the sites and smells. I am so glad we took the time to just sit and have a Turkish coffee which allowed time to soak it all in. A must!
Do go there. For many, Turkey is nothing but Sultanahmat District. Every thing you know Istanbul for, is here. Old bazar, Topkapi, blue mosque, all are here.
Istambul at the time of the Sultans. we had a great time. We visited many sites, Hagia Sofia, the great Bazar andthe palace, the harem and the treasure.

So Much Fun. We had so much fun here! When we departed Suleiman Mosque we found we were on a street with restaurants and shops. My friend was drawn immediately to the first shop she saw (and our first shop in Istanbul). We had so much fun there. The merchants (two brothers) were so friendly and welcoming. It was not crowded like lots of places in Istanbul and we spent a lot of time bartering there.

Not to be missed but try to go early. This district houses some of the top attractions of the city, so of course you should go. Try to avoid the eateries there as they are very touristy. Go early to avoid large crowds.If you happen to visit Istanbul during Ramadan, they have a lively evening market that is worth staying up for!
A taste of the city. Lots to see, smell discover. All kinds of shops and restaurants. everything is easy to locate and to walk to.
nice district. a nice district with a lot of nice restaurants and dining places , at the morning you have some of the great historical places to visit specially the blue mosque and topkapi palace

Great place to stay and visit. We stayed in a wonderful hotel 5 minutes from the Blue Mosque, in the heart of the Sultanahmet district and could not have made a better choice. Apart from all the obvious cultural and historic attractions you have an almost endless choice of eateries and bars on your doorstep. It was great.
Worth to visist. One can lost especially money ;) (with shopping), but is very climatic place to spend a few hours at least

Shopping Arasta Bazaar. Don't miss Arasta Bazaar great shopping! Cotton Pashminas shop 57 good service. The Bazaar also has a great selection of Linen and Ceramics .Don't miss the Kilim Shoes fabulous with Jeans.

Excellent place to visit. Really quite visitor friendly, clean, so much to do and feels quite safe.
So much history in one area.
Is quite expensive.
Also, if getting money changed, much better rate at taksim square

Most popular place for tourists. Sultanahmet district is the first place wehere we went. U can get here easily by train; also if u are staying in Eminonu, Fatih, Aksaray or Laleli, u can get there by walk. Blue Mosque, Agha Sophia and Topkapi palace is located there. Restaurants there didn't have rich menu; it is better to eat in Gulhane district. In Sultanahmet u can taste delicious simit with cheese or nutella(3 tL), corn (mısır 2 TL) and kahramanmarash ice cream (5 TL). If u have little time, Blue Mosque is free o f charge so it is better to go there rahter that Agha Sophia.

Turkish delight and coffee. If you come to this part, make sure you buy original Turkish coffee prepared and packed in front of you. Also don't miss selection of the Turkish delight nearby!The rest is just like any other market in Istanbul

Must see yet overrated. Busy, busy, busy and pushy.Can't get anywhere without hours in queue.Can't pass a restaurant or a shop without being harassed.It is a must see place but be prepared - allow hours for queuing to see major attractions.
Unlimited Wandering. Grab a map and wander around this historic area. Better yet, get a tour guide. The history is incredible and the area scenic. You can easily spend a day or two just in this area.

Amazing experience. Great atmosphere - be prepared to haggle Some wonderful items to buy Your senses get overloaded with the smells of spices and bright colours. Shop keepers do try to call you in to their shops but if you just look straight ahead and don't comment they leave you alone - however worth spending time in some of the shops - even if it's just for the experience.

Walk in the past. Sultanahmet is the typical muslin neighborhood that makes you imagine how would be the life of these people long time ago when the trading was heavily active and everything else wasn't just a tourist spot. Nowadays the area is 90% touristic I'd say. Everything is oriented to the tourism, but it wasn't like that few centuries ago and the remaining architecture and surroundings gives you a good idea on what was in the past. This is one of the mandatory spots to visit once in Istanbul.

Great location, tourist central. We stayed in the area because of the history and pure convenience of getting to the major museums. It's really touristy though. We liked the side streets and out of the way places best.
Gulhane park or bust!. I stayed in Taksim and just rode the tram in and out (I recommend it because I liked being closer to the nightlife). Sultanahmet is fun to just get lost in... and you will :)

The essence of Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the heart of the city, there are a tons of things to do in that area.You can start by visiting the amazing museum and truly experience the greatness of the ottoman empire that spread throughout the world with glory and power.There are many traditional restaurants that you just cannot miss, whether you're a vegetarian or not because there various Turkish foods that will make your head spin.You can definitely enjoy one hell of a day there, as far as clubbing goes for the night, you might be better off in Beyoğlu or Beşiktaş.Must visit first thing after arrival!!!

Diversity. Fun! Just people watching is incredible! I felt as if I was in the first Star Wars movie where the heroes walk into the bar full of beings from different planets. Here, you can see every kind of person wearing every kind of garb speaking one of hundreds of languages. Just amazing! Then, of course, there are the mosques and hippodrome - all incredibly historic and inspiring
Walk the old area. Great to walk the rambling little streets of Sumtanahmet and get the feel of Istanbul. Wear sneakers as it is cobble stones.
so much history within easy walking distance. THE place to be when visiting Istanbul, so much to see and do, enough open spaces to relax, shops, food and drink, a delight

Great atmosphere. We have just returned from Istanbul (plus a 15 day tour of Turkey). Initially our tour group was in a beautiful hotel near the Taksim Square, but after the tour concluded, we moved to the Sultanahmet district. This is a very vibrant area of the city and our hotel was only minutes from the Basilica cistern, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia and about a 10 minute walk to the Grand Bazaar. The hop/on - hop/off buses also depart by the tram stop adjacent to Hagia Sophia. There are many restaurants, all trying to get you to try their menus. We ate at six different ones in the week we were in Istanbul, all but one reasonably priced and met some nice folk at adjacent tables with whom we struck up a conversation. Admittedly staff on the streets tried to get us to buy carpets, leather etc. as we walked past, but usually we thanked them and continued walking. They usually tell you they have a cousin or relative living somewhere in Australia to start their conversation! A great area in which to stay and we would certainly stay in Sultanahmet should we have the opportunity to visit Istanbul in the future.

Nice Vibe . Ourselves hotel was located close by and within easy walking distance of this district. Loads of curio stores as well as restaurants, cafés, candy stores. A hive of activity with hordes of tourists making their way down the hill to the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sophia or up the hill to the Grand Bazaar.
LIVELY HUSTLE & BUSTLE. Great variety of shops, monuments, tourist landmarks, just a great vibrant busy place. Geared for tourists so slightly pricey compared to elsewhere.
Soultamahmet . Soultamahmet has all the historical places of Istanbul. Easy to find and walk. Lot of sightseeing and people

Crouded but Lovely !. Tram station + thousand of restaurants and historical places . A peaceful place at night . It gives an immense romantic feeling if you sit between the benches of Blue Masjid and Hagia Sophia. Enjoyable and lovely !
The Sultan returns.. Fittingly the Sultan returned to the Sultanmeht district to see with his own eyes the beauty of his city.

First visit to Istanbul. This is the place to ensure your hotel is booked, close to the main tourist sites Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque (SultanAhmet Camii), Topkapi Palace etc. If your worried about local food/meats has 2 McDonald's within 5 mins, Burger King and Starbucks all on the main road going up hill from SultanAhmet tram stop. Lively atmosphere at night.

A Delight For Spices and History. A place filled with history and culture with the Turkish realm right in between lies the Blue mosque and Haya Sofiya over seeing the Bhosphrous. With all the wonderful delightful eateries and the flavoured teas.Just walk down the road and you come to the Famous Spice Market and it just tantalises your senses completely.All in all a delightful place to stay and take in the sites.

Nice stuff but relentless selling. Could be great, but you can't go anywhere without relentless hawkers trying to sell you everything. It becomes a bit tiresome at times. Lots to see and do, but it would be nice to be able to walk more than 50 feet with being accosted at least one day.

A place everybody must visit at least once in your life.. A mad mad place with which we fell madly in love with. The people are friendly! Everybody wants to do bussiness! If you talk to everybody, you wont see very much and wont do much more than talking! We are looking to go back already.

stay here and never regret!. people visiting Istanbul for the first time should stay in Sultanahmet!!. I stayed just beside the blue mosque. its like staying in the main attraction point. you would be able to see all the structure in different day light. you can just go for a walk for 10 minutes after 10 pm and you would know how beautiful the nights can be in Sultanahmet. Every structure glows! its a fun place with music, lighting and architecture. the tram stoppage is very near too.

Awesome country. Everything was just lovely , weather, tour buses, turkish food, museums and market , staying in a hotel in sultahmet district made us close to many lovely places.would love to visit again

bello!. Name after Sultan Ahmet l, who ordered the construction of the OUT OF THIS WORLD Blue Mosque, this is for me the center , of everything in the Old part of Istambul, you have here just a few steps away, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, the Basilica cistern, etc, along with several hotels (good prices some) and delicious restaurants, this is the best place to be to have everything just walking distance.

Another bazar. This bazar area is like most other bazars in Turkey, and the Spice bazar that many talk about is very fine but not very cheap as the say it is. Thete is really a lot of spices and the way they display the spices is nice but many tourists sometimes want not to be pulled into the shops and nearly forced to buy. They would sell more if they acted nice and gentle
Fascinating area!. So much to see and do here, you will have an enlightening visit without a doubt. Amazing sights, adorable shops, delicious food. Locals are friendly and speak very good English.
Cannot go to Istanbul without visiting... A lot of history and turkish heritage in the area. There are the historical places to visit. as well as some authentic shopping at Grand Bazar.

Soul of the city. This area could be considered as the city's downtown since it's the oldest place within the city. It's filled with history, beautiful architecture and endless shops.This is the very soul of the city and in order to enjoy it more I highly recommend staying at a hotel in this area so that the main sights are at a walking distance.
Cultural experience. We were there during Ramadan, quite cultural experience after sunset when people stop fasting and families gather
lots of things to see. strolling through the sultanahmet area was a fun thing to do. So many things to see that you won't get bored.

Hustle and bustle place. The place where you are lost with history amazing and stunning views full of turkish food restaurant you meet with nationality lhighly recommend stay in hundreds of hotels with different styles and stars.

Heart of the Old City. A great location where you can walk to everything in the old city with 15-25 minutes. Lots of people and the area is full on all the time so expect crowds of people, it never seems to stop.

Short trip to Istanbul. Even though I visited Istanbul in Winter time, this city is worth a visit during all seasons.Sultanahmet District is full of life day and night with hundreds of shops, cafes, restaurants and interesting architecture. Being located in the city center (where my hotel was), the main attractions are in walking distance. A ferry ride to the Asiatic part (to Harem) is interesting too and very inexpensive!

Top area to stay. If your searching hostels or hotels this is a great area to stay in. Some of the big sights are close by (such as blue mosque) and some of the beautiful old parts of the city. Throw in some lovely restaurants and bars, buzzing with people and atmosphere, you might not need to leave the area at all
great place to eat and see the local people enjoying themselves.. you cannot believe how many restaurants are in this area, and everyone wants you to eat at their restaurant.

Not on a Sunday. I have recently been back to Sultanahmet on Sunday and was surprised to see how empty it feels on that day of the week. Sure, the service personnel is more relaxed and you can find virtually empty gems like a tea garden, but in total I much prefer the area on a bustling workday...

lively place. The place is very lively at night and restaurants are open till late. Its lovely to sit outside in one of the cafe's and enjoy the place.There are some beautiful souvenir shops to visit around. There is one particular shop called SABARU which makes lamps from pumpkin shells you must visit.The art work is incredible.

Highlight of Istanbul trip. Heart of the very historical old city of Istanbul - a must visit. From Suleymanye mosque at one end to the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia and the Grand Bazar, just this are will take at least two whole days.
Dynamic Sultanahmet District!. This part of Istanbul is magical. The sights/aromas of the shops and restaurants are fantastic. Make it a point to walk around this area!

Turkish Delight. I have to come back to Istanbul , the shopping here is any woman's dream !!!! The people are friendly, if a bit pushy , and you have to learn quickly when to say no , but all in all a wonderous and wonderful place .
Lovely place. It was one of my favorite places i have ever been to because it has historically value,great place to eat and have fun day and night

Fantastic area, of interest to all tastes :- archeology, history, religion, culture, shopping. It has it all. What can you say about this beautiful, historic area? The Blue mosque, Ayia Sofia Hippodrome Basilica cistern,the Grand Bazaar, The colour and buzz of the area. A place that should be included in everyone`s travel itinerary.
The place to stay. We stayed in this area so much to see and so much to do. Great night time atmosphere with many restrauants and bars. This area also is home to many of Istanbuls historic gems

A veryli vely area. You can easily forget yourself touring this area. In addition to the best touristic attractions in Istanbul (Aya Sofiya, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi, etc.), there are so many restaurants where you can enjoy a nice lunch or dinner, or just even a break with a nice Turkish wine or beer, or just a tea.
Turkey Travels. I would have liked more time here! So much to see and experience, probably better to go very early in the morning to avoid big crowds.

Sultanahmet and Topokapi Palace. A lovely safe well kept historical area with lots of History and beautiful Buildings. A lot to do and see so do arrive early. The View of the Bosphoros is Magnificent from so High up.

Great area to stay with kids. If you're traveling with children, this is perfect neighborhood. Major sites are right there. Sultanahmet tram stop takes you to Topkapi Palace a few stops in one direction,and to Eminou or Karikoy ferry to Asian side (Kadikoy) in the other direction. You can walk to Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar or take tram there. Easy to get around. Kids can see so many sites just as you walk to and from dinner. It is also true that this is not foodie place - most restaurants are mediocre. But we loved Karadeniz, just uphill small side street from tram stop. Food was yummy, wait staff gracious and welcoming. We had very tasteful meals there including the clay pot fire dish in photo below.

Love this area. So much to see in this neighborhood. We were first time visitors to the city, so this was the PERFECT location for us. Would stay in the area, or at the same hotel (Sultan Royal Hotel) again without hesitation.
Thank you Istanbul!. Stayed in the area during our summer trip! Main attractions are within walking distance and loved the weather (summer).
A tourist trap.. Lots of things to do, see and buy. But definitely a tourist trap. Lots of people that bother you. Hold on to your valuables.

The heart of the city. We stayed in this area at Hotel Ayasofya. Great location walked everywhere as you are right in the heart of the old city. Very safe feeling and plenty of great places to eat and drink at. Be sure to take the time out for a Turkish Coffee experience

Everything you could ever want. A very old but lively area with plenty to offer the visitor. An overwhelming selection of historical sites, great food/eatery places and lots to see in this old area of Istanbul. A must-see area for any visitor to Turkey.
Historical Places. I love visiting places that tell you history about the city you are at, Sultanahmet is one of them .
shopping. great for shopping souvenirs and turkish delights, also to observe the beauty of the turkish people and culture
Traditional Turkey. Narrow, cobbled streets, interesting architecture. Lots of great restaurants and places of interest to visit
Great impression of the ancient Istambul, very busy but interesting area.. It's a must-do if you go to Istanbul. Sultanahmet is where al the famous buildings and markets are. Take about 2 days!

Ancient mosques, grand bazaar,restaurants cafes shops, its a tourist attraction. Sultanahmet is very busy place especially this time of the year, there is a lot to see plenty of shops, cafes and restaurants, you have to bargain before purchase anything, don't miss the grand bazaar,be careful with your belongings, and try the Turkish delight.

The heart of Istanbul. If you have just a few days in Istanbul, stay here. Lots of people but very fiendly. The Old City reflects cultural influences of the many empires that once ruled here. In the Sultanahmet district, the open-air, Roman-era Hippodrome was for centuries the site of chariot races, and Egyptian obelisks remain. The iconic Byzantine Hagia Sophia features a soaring dome and Christian mosaics.Its Byzantium, Constantinople and Istanbul all together in a small area!

The tourist centre of Istanbul. This is really the area of Istanbul with the main tourist sights, but there are plenty of great restaurants, shops, cafes and bars too. It is a very safe area, the usual caveats apply about minding your belongings but it felt fine to me and my husband. The tram system in Istanbul is very easy to navigate and can get you from here to Taksim Square in about 20 minutes and to the ferry for the Bosphorus Tours at Eminonu in about 10. I would recommend this as the area to stay in as a first time tourist to Istanbul
Lively city. So much to do and see. Historic areas intermingled with shops and restaurants. English is spoken in many/most locations.
Fantastic district. This district is amazing close to everything I wanted to see in Istanbul. Great shops, cafes and restaurants. Walking distance to all monuments

always again and again and again.... visited Istanbul and specially Sultanahmet not for first time. It is beautiful historical location with unique places combined with busy bazaar life. Great atmosphere and cultural crossroad between Asia and Europe.Place where You always can find something new and suprising
great place. love this place a definite must go and look around. Lots to see and shopping to do in this area......

Excellent location . The Sultanahmet District is in the heart of Istanbul's major sites. The cistern, Blue Mosque, and shopping are just a few places near by. You will enjoy excellent restaurants and people watching in the old town district of Sultanahmet.

A very fascinating district - Sultan Ahmet. We visited Istanbul for first time in June - and will definately be back:) We stayed in SultanAhmet and enjoyed the location. This area are full of history, but still a lively city. Close to all the major historic sites and eacy to navigate in. We loved it!
Saltanahmet. Clean and friendly. Full of restaurants which were not expensive. Plenty to see and plenty to shop for if you wanted.
Great Location. Fab little area, great shops, restaurants and night lie...nice hotels and locals very friendly...will definitely go back
The sights of Sultanhamet.. Great experience, soak up the diverse culture and bustle with wondrous sights all around, could not go to Istanbul without being in Sultanhamet.

fantastic. in love with the place , very turkish
a touristic area where u can visit aya sophia , blue moseque (wear appropriate clothing) , topkapi palace , hippodrome etc..
also a very nice turkish bath in aya sofia hammam

Nice but crouded. It is a must to be visited the first time you visit istanbl. It is historical area with Bazars and really nice places to see. But it kind of super crouded. If you are visiting in the spring or winter it will be really nice to walk around there. I visited during July so it is hard to walk around during the day. I don't recommend to stay in this area at all. The best area to be visited in Istanbul is Nisantashi (Sisli)

Breathtaking. The combination of both history and the modern technology in Sultanehmet district is extraordinary.The museums, mosques, palaces and the grand bazaar make it the ultimate tourist attraction in Istanbul.I recommend spending a day (Or even two) just visiting the historical places and enjoying the amazing ambient.

Lively if a bit hectic. We moved to Sultanahmet after having a disastrous first night in Taksim -- airBnB flat arrangement fell through as the owner tried bait and switch on us.... Aside from the northern, high priced tip around the square, Taksim seemed like a war zone rather than the lively entertainment district that I had imagined. I had stayed in Kadikoy on the Asian side for three days prior to all this, and would highly recommend a visit there for a rest after you have seen/shopped yourself to exhaustion in SA. Overall, SA is convenient for getting to the mosques/museums/bazaars, but dies down too quickly after 9 pm.
nice. Sultan Ahmed Mosque in Istanbul is a great and beautiful mosques and those who are interested can visit this mosque for free.

Tourist Central. It's cute, handy to all the main attractions and safe to be out at all hours with the light rail running down the middle. The Blue Mosque, AyaSofia, Topkapi Palace and Grand Bazaar (The furthest entrance is 2 stops away) are all here. The Bosphorus Ferries are 3 tram stops away. There's a wonderful Haman at Cemberlitas which is really Upper Sultanahmet. So if time is limited then this is where you want to stay for your first time in Istanbul. Having said that just remember that its pricy and why not they have a monopoly on the tourist zone. Try to go beyond for food at least a couple of times or every time if your on a budget. Much of the food seems quite middle of the road anyway. Just an example a Turkish tea is $1 street price but $4 or more in a cute cafe at Sultanahmet. But they are cute cafés!

This is where everything is!. Wow, what a truly awesome area! During the day it is beautiful with the lovely gardens and fountain between Aya Sofya and the Blue Mosque, with the little cafes with their delicious items. Then at night, it becomes even more spectacular as the mosques are lit up and the fountain is lit and there are tons of people out and about.

Great area to stroll. I visited on a Friday, which we were told was the busiest day of the week. The loads of people are overwhelming - especially since it is high season - but it is totally worth it. Istanbul is a vibrant city, and a lot of it comes from the attractions from long ago. Every tourist will make their way to Sultanahmet District and if you don't, you're by far missing out.
Great!. Historical area with lots to see and do. gets very crowded in the afternoons. Would recommend that you get their early.

Heart of Istanbul. We stayed in Sultanahmet District for 4 days. It was as if we were transported back in time when we stayed there. Every time we walked out our hotel we walked past the Blue Mosque as well Hagia Sofia and we enjoyed it every single time we went past it. Highly recommend staying here.

Excelent trip!. The people are the TOP!!!!dont't Join EU , it will destroy you, your beauty is unique and you'll lose it !!!
All that you can see is original and beautiful! Do not waste time! Visit Istanbul!!!
Amazing Quarter. Many interesting attractions in the area. a lot of restaurants and entertainment, beautiful Mosque, nice area to sit and watch people especially at night.

Amazing Culture. The Sultanahmet District of Istanbul is amazing. It is nothing like anything I have experienced. So many amazing shops, restaurants, and sites to see. But beware, it can easily overwhelm you. Our first day visiting we walked almost 10miles and 20,000+ steps and probably brushed elbows with nearly 1,000,000 people. I felt safe, but it is not a ho-hum place to visit. I loved my visit. I would return in a heartbeat, but this is not for everyone.

the best part of istanbul as a strating point for visiting. I was settled here in 2 different hotels in 2 different visits and was happy both of the times. Everywhere you go there is monument or attraction.
Hagia st Sophia +blue Mosquee + hippodrome and cisterns basilica. I liked this part of IstanbulI love history and I'm impressed by these genius people who let us so beautiful treasures .

Has to be the place to stay. We went round the city on the Big Bus tour and were so glad we stayed in the Sultanahmet District. All of the iconic places are there or are readily accessible. Hotels range from the budget through the boutique to the luxury, and you have everything you need on your doorstep

Interesting neighborhood to explore. This is a great place to walk around in - especially at night! The lights and gardens of the Hagia Sophia are spectacular. People are friendly and the food everywhere is sublime! Wonderful place!
very historical area. recommended for travellers despite their ages or races. area once you visits tells you a lot about Bizintins history and ottoman's .

fascinating historic area. Wonderful historic area of Istanbul with superb attractions like Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Cisterns and quaint streets with interesting shops and lovely restaurants.Great small hotels in historic buildings.We enjoyed wandering around the streets and seeing the sights, as well as looking at interesting shops. We ate at some wonderful outdoor and roof top restaurants with great views.However, we became really annoyed by being pestered by carpet salesmen and restaurant waiters who constantly hassle tourists in the street asking them to visit their particular shop and restaurant. It meant that one could not even look into a shop window without being hassled and asked to visit that shop and buy a carpet.  I am sure that this happens everywhere in Turkey, as it is their way of doing business, but it did rather spoil our experience of walking around the streets.

One of a kind!. This was a very interesting spot, just like in all the movies! Of course beware of aggressive vendors, make sure you know your conversion rates and have fun! You can find some great little treasures here and mostly just take in all the excitement and people watching!

Great part of Istanbul to stay.. Interesting part of Istanbul, great area to stay in, beautifully kept gardens, very clean and tidy streets. Good transport, lots of restaurants and shops. Easy to walk around, and it feels very safe.

Blue Mosque. Truly peaceful, tranquil, and gorgeous. Definitely a must see! Women must wear a head scarf, shoulders covered and knees must be covered as well. You may bring your own "cover ups" or the mosque will provide you with one. There are vendors in town that sell gorgeous scarves. Take some time to look around for a beautiful souvenir that can be used in the mosque as well.
Great variety!! Don't miss it!!. Here you can taste and choose a great variety of products and see shops and other attractions! This is a must!

Great sights, not so great hustlers and food.... Istanbul old town has so many great things to see it can't be missed without missing Istanbul history. From Topkapi to AyaSofya, the Blue Mosque, Basilica cistern, up to the Grand Bazaar and all points between, there are many happy hours to spend here.
