Unfortunately, the hustlers know this and ply their trade charmingly at first, with a number of tactics when rebuffed. There are, officially, more carpet shop owners in Istanbul than carpet shops. This is true of jewellery shop, cafes and any other type of shop in the city. Each appears to have a dozen people out hustling tourists, all of them 'own' the shop, obviously. Their most common tactic on being rebuffed is guilt 'I was only being friendly and offering you tea' - 'don't you want to make your wife happy?' - 'Sir, you can have the cheaper one, but I'm sure your wife deserves the better quality' and the famous line 'trust me, you will be happy with it' - just before whatever it is falls apart - in fact 'trust me' is a common signal that 'I'm about to let you down' . The Grand Bazaar is a great sight, but prices are based on the barter system that starts at about 5 times the value of the goods and a common tactic when you asked for a price is to ask 'how many units?' this makes you feel guilty, as you only want one or two, which reduces your desire to barter. If you start by asking the 'price each', then the answer to his question is, 'that depends on how competitive your price is'. He will ask for 'your price', having started at 4-5 times the value, then be offended if you offer a fair price - guilt is their main weapon. They will insult you, quite subtely, in the process - 'if you don't want to buy something nice, then we have this...' is another common phrase, admitting to selling 'not nice' things - it's a curious one but most people seem to miss it and say no, no, I want the good one - guilt is the main weapon!General rule, if you pay more than one third of the opening price, you've paid too much - you can't 'win' against them, it's only by how much you lose!I try to avoid the high-street cafes too, better, cheaper cafes are off the track a bit and service is variable. The best service is great, the rest is off-hand - it tends to reflect the quality of the food, so a recommend from your hotel can be a bonus - telling the cafe the hotel have recommended you and asked for your feedback may also help.Istanbul:- do it, but be aware of the common tricks
Cool place. I had a good experience and also a surprise. Everybody said that it was a unsafe area, but I felt very safe there.

Great area to stay. Close to all the tourist sites and very busy, day and night. Easily walkable. Some good restaurants as well. My wife and I were hungry late one afternoon and we stopped at a sidewalk cafe for a bite to eat. A lovely way to people-watch and spend an hour or two.

Interesting area. Liked the Grand Bazaar, Blue mosque, aia Sophia etc etc.Especially the fact that we could walk to all these places.The trip on the Bospherous was fabulous as well. Nice lunch on this trip included. Swimming in the black sea was very nice.

variety. Great variety of shops, bars, shops, attractions, transport and places to eat. Suggest you dress in a conservative manner as alot of locals who dress quite traditionally in this area.Look around for cheap gifts and souvenirs.
Must visit. Spirit of ancient times makes this place very special to visit. Well preseved, clean with nice atmosphere and plenty of restaurants and cafes around.

See it All!. So many of Istanbul's great sights and attractions are in this district. In the green square you have fountains with the Hagia Sophia on one side, the Blue Mosque on the other. Walk around and enjoy the sights and smells and soak in the culture. Hundreds of eating options. Yes, people will try to sell you stuff, but we weren't pressured and everyone is friendly. Say hello and no thanks and they move on. One of the great experiences we have had on our holiday.

Very interesting, colourful and quite crowded area. This district is kind a must for a tourist visiting Istanbul. There you will find the main tourist attractions: Hagia Sofia. Blue Mosque and Topkapi (palace & harem of sultans). Also the big bazar is located there. We visited there during Ramadan time (or Ramazan as they call it there) and it was interesting to follow all details of this Muslim culture. Some sellers and shopkeepers are a little bit too "enthusiasts"... :)

Great area...very safe. Sultan Ahmet is the main area where many attractions are based like the Blue Mosque, the Basilica and even Topkapi museum. There is a large square full of icecream sellers, coffee shops and beautiful areas where you can sit and relax.There is a tourist info centre here as well as the Big Bus Company that do bus tours of the city, aothough I didnt take the tours as I didnt feel there was a need.My advice? Go to the tourist info centre, get a map and go around istanbul yourself on the tram. Cheaper and much more fun!

Full of life, love and happiness!. It's a place where I used to stay in a lot since my hotel was on this district..Doesn't matter if it's a 11a.m. Or 11p.m. It will always be full of life.. And if the weather is good.. That's it, you can stay their all day long.. Specially if you're a person who didn't like to stay trapped in a hotel.. The district is close to everything, the grand bazaar, different shops and restaurants. One day of your trip should be spent in sultan ahmet district.
A Walk Down Past Empires. Clearly the Byzantines and Ottomans have left their marks around this area. Clean, well preserved and the atmosphere is absolutely amazing.

Fantastic area, THE place for Tourists to stay. The traditional Old Town of Istanbul houses the Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and a host of other 'must-see' sites all in a very small area. Easy access to public transit but walking distance to other parts of the city including Galata. Street activity stops around 11-midnight while it is still going strong in Galata but this can actually be a plus for those who want to spend full days touring.

The heart of Istanbul. There are the main sights of old Istanbul — the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Basilica Cistern, the place of an ancient hippodrome — in this area. There is the best beginning of acquaintance to the ancient city.

Good location. Great spot for history and culture. But beware of the tourism and aggressive merchants. They play on politeness........anything to start a conversation.......and make a sale. But again, if you want to see history.....this is the neighbourhood.

takes you into another world. The most touristy yet mesmerizing area of Istanbul. The blue mosque and the Hagia sofia are a must visit. Make it a point to visit the square post sunset, for a beautiful view of the mosque. Area is touristy, hence a bit more expensive than other areas.
Charming. Wonderful old area of Istanbul. Full of life, great food, charm and lovely people. Nice neighborhood restaurants and unique shops.
Beautiful place. We rented an apartment in sultan Ahmet, it very good choice , near a lot of amazing places a lot of good restaurants in the neighborhood
An area to visit... This area is called old city,the heart of the history,museums and mosques,very easy to reach Taksim square and emin önü

Lots of nooks and crannies to explore. Beautiful old area of Istanbul, so many interesting buildings, both the majestic ancient buildings, and the quirky side streets. Good to just stroll around, lots of amazing ( and some not so amazing) smells. Plenty to explore, places to eat and places to wonder at. We always try to stay in Sultanahmet when we visit as we never get tired of our explorations.

So much to see in such a small area of the sprawling Istanbul. So much to see in such a small area of the sprawling city of Istanbul. Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sophia, Bascilia Cistern, and more! And don't forget the many restaurants.

Magical. This area has all the good things within easy walking distance -- Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern,and the Golden Horn. It also has excellent restaurants, pleasant shops, modern trams, and incredibly clean streets. You can walk to the pier where you take a Bosphorus cruise (across the street from the train station that served the Orient Express). I had never been to Istanbul before, and didn't know where to stay. A friend suggested a hotel in this area. He was right.
Stay here..... Vibrant, bustling and great fun. The old city has SO MUCH to see and do. A visit to the Spice Market and the Grand Bazaar are musts, but just wander and take in the atmosphere

Best Area to Stay in Istanbul. This is where you'll find Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Saray), Binbirdirek Cistern, the Istanbul Archeological Museums, parks and Grand Bazaar.. All walking distance.
Location, location, locaation. Everything we wanted to see was within walking distance. There were lovely shops and restaurants and everything was convenient

Old district / more turistic. This area is very packed with tourists during the day due to the enormous amount of attractions here. You need to come here to visit the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, Palace, etc. and to feel the area. I recommend you visit this area but stay in a Hotel in Taksim.

Fabulous area of the city. There are so many sights to see, and very little traffic since the pedestrian area connects Topkapi, Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque, with the Cistern just across the tram tracks. Clean, not very crowded, friendly people. The square was FUN to walk through at night when hundreds of muslim families break fast during Ramadan, sharing family meals on the grassy grounds of the courtyard between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia. Safe, our teenage kids walked all around here and the small bazaars on their own.
History-You are standing in it!. With an historical setting spaning Byzantium and the Ottomans, the district groans with the wonderment of civilizations come and gone.

Istanbul's heart is here.. Most of Istanbul's chief attractions are in Sultanahmet. Very tourist friendly and easy to move around in. We walked and used the excellent tram service (with Istanbulkart). My pocket got picked but that was my own carelessness - and something that can happen even in my own country.

Back to the past. It was like being in a city that was 1000years old
but with all the modern conveniences of today,
The trams were fantastic,

Magical Istanbul. It is a place where you may spend a whole day with out realizing time passing by. The Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque complex, just a few mins walk to Topkapi palace complex, few mins walk back to Cistern Basilica.. then catch a tram to Grand Bazar.. ask directions for Suleymania mosque, catch a glimpse of Bosphorous from Suleymania mosque compound.. walk back to Grand bazaar.. cool your heels with awesome turkish sweets and tea and time to time refuel with kebabs then keep on walking to discover ancient Constantinople, Istanbul the seat of Ottoman empire and modern day life in this bustling cosmopolis ... We were in Istanbul for 3 days and every day we were at Sultanahmet for most part of the day and many of my fellow tourist to whom I got a chance to chat were visiting Istanbul spent the most of it in Sultanahmet.
A must!. Nice and vivid. Sometimes crowded. But nothing you wouldn't expect. A place to feel the pulse of touristic Istanbul. Must do.
Fabulous place to stay. This area is full of historical sites, restaurants, shops and bars. It is easily walked, and the perfect place to stay.
must see for all. A lot of things to view, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Yerebatan Sarnici (cisterns) and they are all relatively close to each other.
Busy area. Lots to do, many restaurants and from here you can take the bus tours or find out about boat tours in the area

Walk walk and walk. If you're here to see the main sights, get your walking shoes and enjoy it. There are lots of 'guides' but they don't hassle you. The three main sight, Topkapi, Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque and very close together. Once you're in that area its a lovely walk with a few little hills but it's shaded in many areas. Enjoy the day.

Beautiful and cool. This area is the centre for finding the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Basilica Cistern. This is one of the busiest area in Istanbul.it is one of the best area to stay in Istanbul , this place thrilling and great and discoverold area and read history of Istanbul.

spices,teas, souvenirs. here we bought the most fresh spices-similar to those of Tunisia-and a big variety of teas.entering the district you are cought from the different smells so none can leave without a souvenir

lovely atmosphere. enjoyed the expanse on the place and the fact that som many important monuments are surrounding it. quite touristy but if youre there enjoy it! can sit along the roadside and enjoy a beer and watch the world go by!

A very happening place. The town centre of Istanbul housing three of its most remarkable landmarks ie the Blue Mosque, Ayasofya and the Basilica Cistern (and many others)- best explored by walking around.

A great place to wander. We got the sense that if time was limited in Istanbul, spending a few hours exploring in this area would give a reasonable idea of the city. There is much to see and smell as you walk around. Be prepared for the very charming 'agents' for the local shopkeepers to invite you for a tea to look at usually rugs and leather. Don't be afraid to go and don't be afraid of saying NO. It is one of the experiences of Istanbul. There are so many attractions in the area you'll be busy for days.

Is this the busiest place in Istanbul?. This area is the centre for finding the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Basilica Cistern. This is one of the busiest places in a very busy city. We visited just before the beginning of Ramadan which may be why it was so busy. You can spend an hour just sitting and watching the world go by. There is an ice cream kiosk in the square. You must visit. The ice cream is good but the comic performance of the vendors has to be experienced!!The gardens and fountains are magnificent. We went on a Sunday and it was lovely to see all generations of families enjoying the area.
Busy and nice. We liked the area as had a lot to see.Also was spoilt for choice to eat....make sure you wear comfy shoes as we walked everywhere but really enjoyed!!!!

Hyper-touristy, but that's probably the point. It seems a bit superfluous to review the district (much like reviewing Times Square) since the many of Istanbul's iconic locations are concentrated here and probably why you came to this city in the first placenevertheless, a few quick tips from a first time visitor1. The hotels are really convenient if your goal is to hit all the historic spots, but not so much to get to other parts of the city, especially the Asian side. If you are planning to be in Istanbul for a few days, it may make sense to split your stay between the historic district and other neighborhoods2. The restaurants in and around the historic district are mostly mediocre and almost every one of them has a "barker" standing out hassling passers-by to look at their menu. This sometimes gets so aggressive that we noticed many folks walking in the middle of the road just to avoid them. Some restaurants actually tout their "no hassle" policy with large boards :-)3. The Arkestra bazaar (at least in our opinion) and the shops in that vicinity is a pretty good place to browse, haggle and buy things. It is far far better than the over-hyped Grand Bazaar4. Take the tram/funicular if you need to go past the historic sights. The ups & downs are pretty deceptive and you will suddenly be out of breath walking uphill

History all around. Be prepared to be lost in time as this district has all history and culture at its finger tips. You have everything you will want to visit on your door step and will not need taxi's or trams as this is one great walking city and hassel free.
Places to go in Istanbul. Full of history with the Blue Mosque, Haga Sophia, ham ams, the bazaar, cafes and restaurants – a lot to see!………………………….

Very interesting. You have not been to Istanbul if you hadn't visit the old town. We were here during the fasting month of Ramadan, every evening, especially during the weekends, there were night markets busting with activities. Best time to try some Turkish desserts like Kunefe or the freshly made Turkish delights.

Simply Beautiful!. This area is the best place to stay when in Istanbul. The hotels in this areas are so affordable and the service is good. Once you stay in this area, it is very easy to visit many interesting and historical places on foot. Literary just walking distance to those places: grand bazaar, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, etc.
Best place to begin your journey.. Great place to begin your journey in the huge Istanbul! Shops, food, cafes, museums, mosques, churches. Its a great place, but it is very very crowded.

Sultanahmet to Taksim Square. I want to help you make this trip as easy a way as possible. I studied Google maps and thought I had it figured out. Luckily my Sirkeci Mansion host (see my review for hotel) showed me the way. Istanbul is like San Francisco. My plan had me walking up what I didn't know was an extremely elevated street. Instead, take the Tram from Sultanahmet to the last stop: Kabatas. Get off, cross the street and pick up the funicular to Taksim Square. It's a snap. All in 15 minute or so. Then, from Taksim Square (which didn't really impress me, but it was raining) you can walk DOWN Istiklal Street. You will thank me you didn't walk UP this street. Down near the bottom, pass Galata Tower and some amazing musical instrument shops. Great window shopping all along the way. And, we did it in the rain.

The colours, smells, atmosphere and the most amazing people!. Did not disappoint, had very limited time in Istanbul due to a conference but loved it. We went in the evening, very atmospheric. No hassling at al and have been twice now. Felt very safe

Take care! Don´t believe them!. Be careful! How they do it I do not know, but they are ready to get your money and you will give it to them without realizing you are paying ten times what it is worth, whatever that is! I am a natural bargainer, I know how to do it and Ilike it, ... I still got ripped off

Area to stay in Istanbul. We stayed in this area meters from the Blue mosque and other attractions of Istanbul.This is an excellent area to stay and plan your visit to Istanbul. Four of the top attractions are with walking distance. The Blue mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace and the Basilica Cistern. There are also lots of shops and some great restaurants. It has a lot of tourists and is busy but we found it to be a good base for our travels.

No cars please. A wonderful place to stay - but do not take a car. Hell to drive and to park. Wonderful to amble around, shop, window shop, eat and drink.Less harassment from touts than in other areas.So close to all the major attractions.Walking around in the early morning before the city awakens is ideal for photography.

Nice neighborhood. Märkte, Gassen, Handeln, Leben erleben. Slender over the markets of Istanbul, watch some locals and many tourists who the barter with the stall owners to cut the best price for themselves. A vibey, busy environment and fine to walk through on foot. Do not miss this while in Istanbul - Even consider to stay in this hood.
Great Area. My wife and I liked walking the areaand local shops. You can find great bargins here, better then in the Grand Bazaar

Too many people hasseling. I understand that touts and hasselers come with the territory of visiting a touristy place, but the locals here are brutally annoying and have zero regard for females. Let me preface this by saying I've been to extremely poor parts of asia, eastern europe, and north africa and no one was as forceful & overly-persistent in begging or trying to sell something as the locals in istanbul. My girlfriend is european and has dark features and she dressed conservatively. Nevertheless, she was treated like a second-class citizen by every single male, regardless of whether they were selling something or not. Even when you say "no thank you" or "teşekkürler" to show them you are disinterested, they mimic you or shout some obscenities . I'm sure this is only experienced in heavily touristed areas, but it sort of turns you off to the rest of the country. I'll take the bazaar in Cairo over the istanbul bazaar any day.

Interesting Area to Walk Around. In this District, we were in various shops that displayed all kinds of wares. It was interesting how they stocked their shelves and set up the displays, as well as the merchandise that was in these shops. Great place to walk around and meet the people and see the sights!
Old Istanbul. Good to roam here looking around especially if you are not in a hurry. Local atmosphere can be felt here for sure.
Really nice!. It was very confortable to spend an entire evening walking in there, it's very beautiful! I Recommend!
Great historical neighborhood. Full of life up until the wee hours of the morning. More monuments than I can count, amazing architecture and people watching.

Great place to stay on a first visit. The sort of easy walking neighborhood with family run hotels and local cafes which eschew the homogenizing effect of large chains. Everything is in walking distance so one feels free of the fear of getting lost. Yes this is a tourist area but overpriced stores share sidewalks with family restaurants where pride of service is sincere and warm. Just lovely.

Beautiful Sultanahmet. So much Culture in this district! This is where you can find the two main Istanbul attractions... The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. The smells and the colors in this place are unique!

Old charm..... Beautiful area, with a lot of history and old charm. Plenty going on during the day and at night, One must experience this area (especially restaurant and fountains near beautifully lit Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosques) in the night time, just as one must during the day. Some of the big attractions are in this area including ones mentioned above, and Topkapi palace, Grand Bazaar, to name a few.
Very Vibrant. We loved staying here, exciting during Ramadan and always felt safe.Centrally located and easy walk to just about everywhere.

Lots to see. We stayed nearby and walked through this area every day. We were there during Ramadan and in the evening thousands of families gather in the evening for Iftar (breaking of the fast). Lots of life and colour.

The old city. A great older section of the city with pleasant clean streets with sidewalk cafes and restaurants -- including our favourite,the Mostra Fish Restaurant.home to the Amira Hotel -- pound for pound one of the best hotel buys in europe !!A location affording easy walking access to virtually all the key sites in the city
Wow. Beautiful area! The mosque is something everybody should visit and learn about. Need to keep in mind it has prayer services and will be closed to visitors at these times.
Lovely district. We really enjoyed staying in Sultanahment district, it was very well "packed" with things to see and there is a huge variety of eateries as well.

Just amazing (:. This vibrant district of Istanbul combines all that one expects from this great metropolis where East meets West in perfect harmony .Name it it's there : breath taking historical monuments ( Aya Sofia, Sultanahmet Blue mosque , the Cistrens , cosy restaurants where each tasty dish has hundreds of years of history behind it or more , gift shops , no hassling and that's very good ; public transport , the tramway , very comfortable and easy to get by as well as economic , you'll need to get the Istanbulcard sold at almost every kiosk .I found the team of young English speaking Turks , both sexes , with their blue uniforms with the words "Ask Me " extremely help and smart on behal of the city council . The area is exceptionally clean despite the hundreds of thousands of visitors that invade the area every day . Well done Istanbul

Great to explore on foot. Lots of interesting sites to see, as well as some good food options. The Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and Blue Mosque are all within easy walking distance of each other. When we visited in June there was also a fun street market at the Hippodrome to walk around.

Great area. we stayed in an airb&b in this area. It felt like staying in a local neighborhood. We were in a very centralized part of the city, and all the major "touristy" stuff was in walking distance. And if we couldn't walk, the tram was right there to take. Very easy to get around. Felt safe, secure.....perfect spot.
Summary of Istanbul. Awesome food, spoilt for choices. Could do with a doner in a bun with chips. My wifes missing the shopping.

Great Historical Sites but Very Touristy. Of course the square, the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Market, the blue mosque and the Ayasofa are beyond compare, but the district is sooo touristy. Everything is overpriced, though still relatively cheap for Europe. If you want to stay close to all the major attractions then stay here, but the public transportation is great and not sketchy. Getting to the historical areas in this district via public transportation wouldn't be difficult.

Beautiful Istanbul. This is Old Istanbul. Has a very good public transport. Nice people. More crowded but still good. A place full of Historical Monuments one would not want to miss when in Istanbul. Better to book your hotel in and around Fatih area, of Sultanahmet District.

So much to see and experience. This is a must see district. The Hagia Sophia, The Blue Mosque & Basilica Cistern should not be missed. The park between Hagia Sophia & The Blue Mosque is a unique place to experience during Ramadan. Families gather there to break their fast and it is amazing to see so many people gathered there eating and drinking. A cultural must.

A Visual Feast. I had considered Istanbul many times, but I had begun to believe that it was too popular with visitors for my travel curiosity. I was proven so wrong. I avoided the very popular sites where cruise ships dumped off hundreds of people who stood in queues consuming time with me the solo traveler left to wait and wait. Instead I set out on foot to explore the Sultanahmet district. I spent a good hour sitting outside a carpet dealer's shop drinking tea with the owner an discussing the state of the world, family, and carpets. What an insight and joy to share our common experiences. I bought sweets in small shop, watched an older lady kindly feed the pidgeons, and viewed the city from the rooftop restaurant at Pierre Loti Hotel. A bowl of lentil soup was unforgettable. The best was the hookah cafe where the charcoal braziers heated the pipes and I drank yet more apple tea and watched the world go by. This experience taught me more about life in Istanbul than any museum ever could!

Touristic place without any regulations. Area is no different from any un-organised market place in Asia where ''bargain'' is the name of the game and every local shopkeeper looking to fleece/rip the tourists. Not a place for weak-hearts and implusive buyers...... One needs to have stomach for bargain and suggest quoting 1/6th of the price

The history of Islam in the mosque. The history of Islam in the mosque
A place for prayer and a place to display the greatness of Islamic history and beautiful place for tourists. Safe and well
Prayer inside the mosque is closed

I am allways again visiting the two Big mosques !. Although I am allways visiting a carpet Shop and Büdingen carpets in Istanbul ! The Blue Mosque especially is my Favorit,but I am allways very early there,that there are Not thousands of People Around !

What does your uncle do?. We loved every minute of our time here. You do hear of taxi scams we did not experience it personally but we did witness an uneasy scene of an irate taxidriver an an uncomfortable passenger. Enjoy all that there is to see and do but be aware of people coming to you asking where you are from to start conversation and tell you they are not a tour guide. They will have an uncle who has a carpet shop and insist that you go and see it. We fell for it once and became quite tense at one spell. All was OK but there is no bargins though I am in the trade and can assure you. Don't be put off it became a joke when approached and a let down is accepted with grace.

Sample heaven. Great fun to wander around this area sampling different foods and finding little souvenirs and gifts to take home. Sit in one of the small cafes or restaurants and people watch while enjoying tasty and reasonably priced food.

the best zone in a metropola of the world to find so much hystorical and architectural masterpieces. the best zone in a metropola of the world to find so much hystorical and architectural masterpieces in a easy way to walk and walk arround,...this way make you to want to know more and more and to come back as soon as you can and to like it,more and more
Beautiful, grand Sultanahmet. I stayed here and if you want to experience the old Istanbul stay here. It is clean and you live in history.

A must location for a first time visitor. I was sceptic to stay in a touristy area, but Sultanahmet was well worth it. We stayed at the Levni which meant all the big attractions, Beouglu and the Bosphorus all within very close proximity.

Visiting during Ramadan was exhilerating for sure. My husband and I had really no idea what to expect when our tour guide suggested we visit the hippodrome park area after the end of the days fast during Ramadan; Well it was fascinating to see in a city of 17 million the families pour into the park meeting the men who had been at prayer in the mosque. There were picnics with not just coolers but coffee makers and grills and tea sets and the buzz in the area was full of joy peace and love. My words cant describe it but this district in Istanbul is lovely with great hotels, shops, and restaurants, Its close to all the major attractions and parks. Stay here for sure!
I was happy there. i was happy there . i can smell lovely smell of the ancient turkey.sultanahemt mosque , hajyasofia , and topkapi , all are amazing

Lots to see. There is so much to see in this small area. We only got to one hammam; there were two others we would have liked to go into. The underground cisterns, the Archaeological museum is a must see, as well as the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia

You MUST go here in Istanbul.. If it's your first visit then start here and do 4 of the main sights in one easy go. Walk down to the river from here and you can take in the spice market and the grand bazaar too.

very rich and authentic. A very rich historic area with a lot of cafés and restaurants but double check the places that you intend to sit or to shop from as this is a touristic are and the locals take advantage of that
take a tram and step out at sultanahmet station

Wonderful Day of Sightseeing. I travelled around by foot throughout the day and into the evening, there were so many sights to see, and the area is well maintained. I felt very safe, considering I was alone and it was after dark in a strange city.
Good Area to Stay In. Amazing place to be staying in. Lively, good food. Just note its also crowded as this is a touristy area.

Fun time!. A great place to visit. We stayed in the Sultanahmet District during our time in Istanbul. There are many shops and places of interests to visit. The people were friendly and the area was extremely well-kept. We felt very safe walking through the area, both in the day and at night. Definitely recommend visiting this area if in Istanbul!

Blue Mosque. Sultanahmet is the name the Blue Mosque in known by. It is in the same park area as Hagia Sophia. This is a very nice area with 2 of the most famous sites in Istanbul. It has many restaurants, pick one with seating area on top of the building and you can see all the way to Marmara Sea. The Tram (public transportation) goes right by the park area. It is very easy to use, just buy the token(s) at the vending machine and you can take this Tram to the water front by the Spice / Egyptian Market. From there you can go just about anywhere.
Old Istanbul. Lots of restaurants, interesting shops and historical sites. Many people from different countries. Easy access to tram service

Cultural and historical open air museum. Sultanahmet district offers cultural and historical treasure from Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman era. If you have limited time, make your priorities and make every minute of your visit worthy. HOW TO GET TO SULTANAHMET DISTRICTIt is easy accessible by tram line T1 or metro line Zeytinburn - Kabataš /get off at Sultanahmet square stop/. A more beautiful option is drive by tourist buses get on&get off. They have stop in front of Blue mosque.WHAT TO VISITThe major attractions represent: Blue mosque /Sultanahmet mosque/, Haghia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and Basilica Cistern. These sights are located within walking distance. Only problem are long rows in front of these sights. The good idea is to plan one day for two major attractions. For example, only visit to Topkapi palace involves four hours at least. Also. long rows plus visit to each of other mentioned attractions involve a half day. Walking along narrow and winding streets of this area is really beautiful experience. Don't miss it! I came cross charming traditional Turkish houses beautifully painted in blue, green, red color. Also, walk along Soqukcesme street, that runs parallel to the walls of Topkapi palace and you will find the wooden houses, typical examples of Ottoman architecture. I would like to mention two beautifully decorated fountains worth your admiration - the first one is the Fountain of Ahmet III in rococo style with adorable tiles and valuable inscription in front of Topkapi palace and the second one is the Fountain of Emperor Wilhelm II with polished granite columns and gold mosaic dome in front of Blue mosque. TAKE A BREAKWhen you get tired, and when you are thirsty and hungry, it is time for break. There are stands with refreshment at Sultanahmet square. They offer traditional Turkish ice-cream, different kinds of fruit, freshly made natural juices of melon, carrot, lemon, orange, pomegranate. If you are in mood to have a break at table, don't miss cafes/restaurants located at top of the buildings in this area. You will be rewarded with an amazing view.PAY ATTENTION TO:Be ready to wait in long rows in front of attractions. Because of warm, even hot weather during summer days, bring with yourself a bottle of water, put a hat on your head, sun protection creme on your face, sun glasses on your nose and don't forget city map in your pocket.Enjoyable time guaranteed!

The place for everything. at Sultanahmet area you can get the real experience; shopping, eating, sightseeing while enjoying the sea breeze. You will always feel that you haven't got enough of the city neither seen everything, but this is the beauty of Istanbul.
Perfect Place to Stay. Many nice reasonably priced hotels and a perfect jumping off point for walking tours for the old city and access to most of the historic sites.

Sweetest area ever!. I wish I could have a little bite of every single piece of sweets that you can find here!!! Love it! Love the smell around, love the colours and the warm people welcoming you... Do not miss a walk around. At least for the beautiful scenery!

Brilliant. Not at all what I thought. Very easy to get around. We felt perfectly safe and were able to linger in the shops without being pestered to buy. Very atmospheric walking around taking in the sights and sounds.

Calm and Peaceful. Stayed in Arena hotel in Sultanahmet District. Even though all the tourist destinations are nearby, the hotel area was very calm. Most of the places you need to visit in city are located in this area. Food and dining options are amazing. People are warm and courteous.
Incredible, Magnificent, Historical.... Sultanahmet district of Istanbul and is a very important area in the history of the world. The visit should be felt in every corner carefully and history.

It's all amazing - the place to stay to see it all.. This is the real Istanbul and where you really need to stay to be close to ALL of the major attractions.
If you are staying in this district you can literally walk everywhere within 5 - 15 minutes.

Bleh not a great family place to visit but worth to spend 10 minutes and then go see something else.. Every store sells the same thing, prices are crazy as we found the same things at a local grocery for 1/4 of the price. They will hassle you to enter and if they hear one of your names they won't stop calling you. It smells so good and things do look fantastic but how much time can you really spend looking at spices. If you are looking for rugs or genuine fake watches and purses go to Taksim.Our kids really did not enjoy it
Unique. What can I say? A most unique area of the world with ancient treasures everywhere. I could happily live here forever.

A feast for the senses. Unfortunately we had little time and it was freezing weather but this area needs plenty of time to take in all the sights, smells, tastes and sounds. Always crowded with both locals and tourists, take care not to buy at your first stalls or outlets as you will find greater value as you progress. I found the crowds a bit too much, being unable to get served quickly or investigate more closely but then I guess that is all part of the experience.

Some good sites to see, but for the real Istanbul, go to Taksim, Istiklal, Nisantisi, Ortakoy, Bebek, etc. There are definitely must-see sites in this neighborhood, but it's mostly now tourists and not many locals really living, with a few exceptions around the gold and diamond exchanges in the Grand Bazaar. To rally soak in the real Istanbul and the cool local areas, go across the Golden Horn to Taksim, Istiklal, Nisantisi (the upper east side of Istanbul), Ortakoy, Bebek, etc.
Disapointing. There is nothing European about this city.It's dirty and very polluted. The traffic makes it only possible to do one outing a day. Plan wisely.
Charming walking district. This is a charming area of Istanbul. It was filled with narrow streets, colorful store fronts, and interesting architecture. It is very historic and beautiful.

Tantalising to the extreme. Even if you do not have a fat wallet, all the shops and stalls are a feast to the eyes. From Gold to spice and everything in between, one can only find what one was looking for. Don't forget to bargain as well.
You will not be disappointed and a tick in your bucket list.

Best area for attractions, hotels and restaurants and shopping. This is the place to be for tourists: choose a hotel close to the Sultanahmet square - so you can enjoy the atmosphere in the evening, there are plenty of restaurants, several with a roof top terrace and spectacular views: the blue mosque, the Hagia Sophia and the Bosporus.

Great architecture, good food,. Visiting during Ramadan means less people in the daytime and more after sunset. We still found it to be quite busy, great shopping, lots of food choices. Very enjoyable area for walking, people watching and learning the colorful history of Istanbul.
Good food, museums shops. Great for turist ill stay here if im back to istambul. Everything is near here!! great turistic spot in istambul.

Enjoyable. Forget of having and organized tour.. Just go there and walk in comfi sport shoes. Plenty of products from all types, new and old. But do not buy old things thinking it is valuable unless if u r an expert in treasured antiques

An interesting area. Lots to see and do. Lots of places to eat and parks to sit and watch the world go buy. Just resist the carpet sellers - if you don't want to buy a carpet. They are all very friendly, but we found a firm no was easily accepted.

Intriguing. Well worth exploring the whole area but especially the suqs (markets) . Don't be afraid to haggle, it is expected and can be fun but personally I'll only do it if I really want the item. It'd anoy me if I was a stall holder and spent time trying to get someone to buy an item and they didn't want it at all. People in Istanbul are courteous and friendly.

One of the best places in the world.. From many other places that you can go in the world, this is probably the most or one of the most interesting places with total security, here you can enjoy shopping or visiting museums, moskes or the cistern and spend easily more than two days without finish seeing everything. This is the very old center of Estanbul, and if you never been there, you dont know what you are missing.
shopping till you drop. mad busy, fun and plenty to see, the locals are friendly to say the least, but you need a full day really to enjoy the sights and sounds and of course the ffod

sultanehmet. magic magic place specially at night with mistery lights and a thousand +1 nights environment...
good hotels, best restaurants, excelent attention, magic market...

Loads of things to see!. Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Hippodrome, German tower, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi palaces all in one place! The area is alive well into the night with retaurants, eateries, world class hotels and shopping... what else could one want.

A MUST WHEN STAYING IN ISTANBUL!. We like to immerse ourselves in the 'heart ' of a city and this was it!! This is why we chose to stay in this area and also to be close to the main 'attractions'. It was a couple of minutes walk that's all. Every street, little alley or avenue was a joy to explore and take photos of. We could have spent another week there at least. Taking the tram to places slightly further afield was so handy too.

Intriguing Istanbul. Intriguing Istanbul. Any visitor to Istanbul will visit this historic district. The hustle and bustle of the crowds, the noise of traffic the many sights overwhelm the senses. The many restaurants, sweet pastry shops, carpets, jewellery attack all your senses. Colourful, overpowering.

Sultanahmet: A Must for Your First Visit to Istanbul. Choosing lodging in the Sultanahmet District was a no-brainer. Several of Istanbul's top sites are in the District and within easy walking distance of lodging and many are visible from hotel rooftops where good meals are served.

really lovely area, so much to see!. but watch out for hustlers and scams, they mostly speak very good English and seem friendly, start a regular conversation with you then invite you to his shop to buy carpets or some other stuffs, or invite you to some scam bars/clubs which cost you an arm and leg.

Absolutely lovable area.. There are so many sights you just need to see. And if possible, choose Ramazan time to visit. The Hipodrome area between the two most famous mosques are the gathering place of families during Ramazan. The start to gather already about seven to choose a place for spending ti.e together and eating after sundown. It is a wonderful family time for everybody.

Expiriencing the old Istanbul. I liked the old Mosques and all the people there. Also we visited in the period of Ramadan. So there was a fair of genuine Turkish products there, where we could buy original souvenirs and didn't have to negotiate the prices. But if you want to buy something in the shops surrounding Hagia Sofia or The Blue Mosque go a bit further to the next tram station - the shops are cheaper there!

The heart of historical Istanbul. Sultanahmet District is were the blue mosque, cistern, Hagia Sophia and Grand bazaar are. It also has many shops and restaurants and has a lovely buzz about it. The tram is easy to catch and can take you to may other places in Istanbul. It is really worthwhile booking a hotel in this area esp if you only have limited time in Istanbul!
spice markets. the markets are awesome. have never seen such an array of spices, treausres etc. Don't miss them as they must be amongst the world's best
The very best. Istanbul is an incredible city, with amazing sights and people. Honestly, I have traveled the world, and I put this place at #1 for awesome!
Interesting and great place.. Very central to the main attraction. Eg blue mosque, cistern, Hagia Sophia, Turkish bath, grand Biazzar. short tram ride to the ferries.

Be sure your hotel isn't at the bottom of a hill!. Be sure your hotel isn't on the bottom of the hill! I recently spent 16 days in Istanbul, which is a stunning city. I was shocked when I learned that our place was not as convenient as I hoped. Check not only your distance from sites, but also elevation. One more bit of advice is to bring earplugs...it is not quiet any time during the day or night

A Little Bit of Commerce at the Blue Mosque.. Right at the feet of the Blue Mosque in Istanbul is this quaint and lovely shopping area where you are still treated to tea as a guest of the merchant where you are perusing the variety of Turkish products available all day every day. You can sit and read or actively participate in the life of the district. While it seems so unasuming and modest, if you ask a taxi driver at the Istanbul Airport he will take you right to the District.
Stay here!!!. This is the Istanbul you want to visit! Most of the places you've heard about are here: Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, The Grand Bazaar, etc.

Soak it all in.. I loved the views from all directions. The Grandeur of the mosques and the open spaces in front of them. We liked the fact that there were so many benches where you could just sit and watch the people go by. Its a buzz with shops and restaurants. Great place.
Liked it!. A nice place to walk around and maybe do some shopping. Full of colours and life. Good place to take some photos.

Wonderful authentic Turkish restaurants and close to the Spice Bazaar.. Include lunch or dinner at any one of these authentic Turkish restaurants when you visit the Spice Bazaar. Lovely shopping area and very popular with the locals at night.

The best place to stay in Istanbul... This is the best place to stay in Istanbul. All the key attractions are just a few minutes walk away from the Blue Mosque to Hagia Sophia, the New Mosque, Topkapi Palace etc.. The Grand Baazar is also in the area and depending on where you are staying, it is only a few tram stops away. This is the place to be if you want to also enjoy to some great street food and feel the old city of Istanbul.

Great area to stay as you can walk to all the main attractions. Its very busy, very noisy, has an amazing atmosphere, found some great places to eat not as cheap as we thought but where is these days.

unique ambience with locals doing picnic. I was astonished how many Turkish people gathered around at 8 to sit down in the grass and spend the night eating with their families. This place is full of life and prices are not that high considering it's a major tourist center. There are some local people walking around in 'ask me' shirts who can help you if you need to find something

Plenty to see , do ,stay. Glad we stayed on this side of town, so much to do and see and very easy to get to the other side of town via the tram or ferry or walking. There was business going on at Taksim square the day we flew in, and people we ran into who were staying on that side of town said it was a nightmare to get to their hotels from the airport, No issues on the Sultanahmet side. Having said that we enjoyed our daily trips over to Taksim, shopping is great.

Everything is here. Everything is here, walking distance to most of the big, most popular sites. It is very easy to get around. If you want to venture to the Golden Horn, you can take the tram, and then the funicular. Or, it's just a few dollars to get on a ferry and check out the asian side of the city. I enjoyed staying in the Sultanahmet district, on a quiet street that was a 15 minute walk to the main tourist area.
Not to miss. Not to miss that beautiful coloured place with ancient scent! With people smiling and bargwing. Zrade is here way of life.
Sultan Ahmet. All major attractions are nearby in Sultan Ahmet district. Beyazit is excellent for Shopping. There are shops outside the tram station which offer cheap good quality products
Just love it. Perfect place to be. Watch the history and modern life integration. Amazing historical places. Topkapı palace Hagia Sophia and others

Throbbing. Pulsating and couldn't get better..Lively..and action oreiented..something to see and discover at each bend and nook or cranny..it is a visual treat.Some or the other street play..music..is on at hippodrome to enthrall you..it had the ramadan flea market when I visited..totally joyous..1000s of cafes to sit and select from the plethora..dime and dozen souvenir shops..and leather goods and shoes which btw..Are a steal if u bargain and find those who are tucked in winding streets on the left...leading towards grand bazaar.Just walk down towards grand bazaar to towards eminonu from the basilica cistern lane..it is so much fun and so much to stumble and discover. .Keep a day extra only to explore and do all those quaint little things which a fixed itenrary doesn't provide in a set plan..This place deserves so much more tjme..An arasta market that leads to the hubs..friendly cats who purr away...friendly hosts who call u to their shops and cafes..select those which are away from main touristy spots if u need something reasobale..don't forget to explore those streets in its backyards..total gem and a joyous feeling..I totally totally loved turkey

Best Area to Experience Old Istanbul. So many local historic sites to see and experience, like Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Palace, etc. It's a compact and walkable area with many winding and charming streets with many wonderful shops and restaurants.

Old City Area. Stayed in this district for 5 days and had a lovely time. Very close to all the major attractions of Istanbul or certainly a tram ride away. Fairly calm area with some nice eateries when you look around the back streets. Felt very safe also.

exotic,enchanting,delicious. It is a tourist area but it is a great tourist area. cobblestone roads, great food, friendly, safe and close to many major attractiona. Fun to walk around, eat shop or just sit and have a cay and baklava and watch the people go by. Delightful!
Great sights and shopping. This area has it all, the important sites one must see, the best shopping for almost anything, and great restaurants. also a very safe area to walk around.
Good time. This district has it all: many restaurants and all kinds of food, shopping and rtiendas ams where bargaining or just looking, historical monuments that will leave you admired
Nice very emblematic. Just a few days in Istambul? Don't loose time driving frome one place to another, Stay at Sultanamet
Buzzing. Very busy area - can spend hours people watching. Plenty of historic sites to visit. Some great places to eat, drink and shop

Istanbul in a capsule. The original 550-year-old buildings created after the 1453 conquering of Istanbul. Three of the greatest mosques, three major museums, gift bazaars, food bazaars...everything to be discovered. Read your history to get the most out of it.
Interesting area. Pleasant area to stay. It's full of restaurants, so you do not have to go far to get great Turkish food!

Exotic, romantic, engaging and bursting with history.. Istanbul is one of the most romantic cities. The Sultanahmet area is stuffed with historical buildings, local colour, a huge range of retail outlets, street sellers, sites of interest. If exotic hustle and bustle is your thing, you'll love it here. The locals will try to engage you in conversation, invite to see their shops, carpets, ceramics.... offer you tea and of course will want to part you from your cash. It can get a bit much sometimes but we never felt threatened, there was never any bad temper even when we drank the tea and didn't buy anything.
Superb location. Great area for wandering about if you are interested in the history of Istanbul, Turkey and the Ottoman empire

Sultanahmet,. lots of different places to eat and shop, from budget through to expensive as you wish. Sultanmet and the other local areas in the city are vast. But you have most of the historical places we all want to visit within easy walking distance,

BARGAIN!. Mix of Greek, Roman and Osman cultures makes this place unbelievable! The heart of Istanbul, full of small shops and places to eat, beautiful Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia, two beautiful temples oposite each other, it is such a beautiful place to see go inside, don't be lazy :) The Spice bazar is the place you can buy very good asian spices. The Grand Bazar is extremely overpriced, don't buy strait, BARGAIN!

Beautiful & Rich Insight into Ottoman Empire times. Beautiful & Rich Insight into Ottoman Empire times
The only reason you would want to go here is to admire the architectural marvels's. It wouldn't be a great fit in the 21st century, but this mosque is over 500 years old!
Amazing place. Brilliant area to hang out have nargile... and blue mosque is just 5 min walk ... food and kebab area amazing...
Neighborhood. Safe and nice neighborhood Walkable , wear good walking shoes since its hilly and lots of cobblestone
Great Area to Stay. We enjoyed the area and found the approximity to the historical sites a real bonus. Pleasant to walk around in the evenings and enjoyable restaurants.
So Interesting . A great central place to stay or visit. The streets are winding so bring a map to explore this area steeped in history. Their are many restaurants and shops to explore aswell.

Marvelous but too touristy. This area used to be less touristy 15 years ago. Nowadays it is like the tourist hub of Istanbul. Still had a pleasent stay in the district. The major sighsees are in the area, so def worths booking a hotel nearby.

Sultanahmet Grand Market. The Grand market is really GRAND and you can walk there after visiting Blue mosque.The shops are very clean and you can buy almost anything here.There are leather goods, gold jewellery, clothes,home decorations,food,tea,spices andmany more items.You actually have to bargain BUT that is half the fun.There is no pressure from shopkeepers and they do speak English.
Great experience. Very good atmosphere and wide variety of items to purchase. One needs to negotiate as the are is aimed at tourists. Never accept the asking price

beautiful place but do not trust everyone.... it is a must place in Istanbul that you should not miss but pls be careful about so called guides(!) especially at the entrance of the blue mosque who are offering free service...it is not free at the end...they seem to be friendly in the beginning..but watch out...use our common sense...nothing is free in life... :(they may also propose to skip the lines and get you inside before the other tourists..do not listen to them..it is illegal what they are doing...so it will be illegal what you are doing as well...apart from that , enjoy the most historic part of the only city in the world on 2 continents... :)

Good Hotels to Stay & Blue Mosque. Superb area to stay in addition to many places to see.Very close to sea and pleasant breezee will take you for sleep.Nice view in addition to fine dining restaurants & cafe.

meeting with istory. great place if you are interested in history and Archeology...majority of most interesting sights are concentrated here...it is a really wonderful place to encounter and see the remnants of the roman empire, masterpieces of old masters and of course enjoy famous Turkish sweets... you can see so many interesting places there that it might take you days to see all famous landmarks of this district...
Great walking. Great to walk around and do some shopping. The Blue mosque and the Hagia Sophia are there and tell grand bazar not too far.

Too little time in Istanbul. Hotel was within walking distance of Sultanahmet Mosque, Ayasofia, Topkapi, Covered Market. There are many wonderful sights, sounds, foods, and shopping right in this very small area. I have been there several times before and highly recommend time in Istanbul, the city that is in 2 Continents.
Interesting area with lots of shopping opportunities. Interesting area with lots of shopping opportunities, good for bargaining and lots of areas to take photographs. Interesting selection of shops.
Ottoman splendour. Here you can see what the Ottoman empire amounted to ! Awesome bulidings, exciting environments and beautiful parks
Great time. Just sat and ate from the street vendors and watched all the people go by. Listened to the muezzin and enjoyed the day.

Lots to explore. There are so many things to see and do in this area. Take time to browse and enjoy the ambiance and history. The streets are very narrow and cobblestone so wear good footwear! The local people here are very honest, friendly and helpful so if you have a question, don't hesitate to ask.

difficult to 'escape' this district !. as there is so much to see and do concentrated in this area, that travellers really don't feel the need to leave it ! by day it's the historical places, and by night, sultanahmet park is where everyone gathers for a stroll, a meal, an ice cream and also haggling with the various items being offered by street vendors.

The best location in Istanbul. So pleasant and easy to walk in. Most of the historic stuff is here. In June there were dancers/musicians performing in the Hippodrome every time we walked through on our way to see something else. There are so many cafes and restaurants to stop and have a beer ( if not next the mosque) or a coffee or ayman (drinking yoghurt). The flowers are beautiful and there are lots of benches to watch the world go by. The tourist police on their segways are friendly and helpful- unlike the tourist information man who managed to look surprised we were asking for info and bored at the same time.
A must go to destination in Istanbul. The biggest market and bazar I have visited but it is fine in the spice bazar but the grand bazar is up hill but lots of shops with haggling

sultanahmet. this historical district attracts you strongly because of it`s originality and it`s multiple touristic scenes which give you real fun and pleasure , especially the : BLUE MOSQUE , HAJIA SOPHIA MOSQUE , and the space between them is full of beauty that you can not imagine it unless decide to visit there , any time i go to Istanbul Sultanahmet is the first program for me , really i enjoy very much with ancient shops and historical markets , the narrow streets and antique homes attracts me strongly , i suggest everyone to visit this wonderful district and express there opinions fairly

Old Town in Istanbul. Apart from the historical sites, Sultanahmet is a place where you can just relax. Eat, shop, people watch and enjoy the cool evening air at the Hippodrome. What we liked was that everything was within walking distance. Dislike : Huge crowds with nowhere to go...

Bleah. Oh dear, I hate piazzza! Many people wanting to sell things that I don't need.. one seller wanted to give me to taste an idiotic turkish delight.. I didn't want to taste it! I will never go again there.maybe only if I really have something to buy but otherway is useless.

A MUST for Istanbul Travelers. This is a MUST for all the tourist who will visit Istanbul. It is in the Old City, which is not just a daily attraction program. You should spend at least 2 days for visiting Hagia Sophia Museum/Church, Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and Spice Bazarr. PS: Just be careful with your belongings and try to bargain like crazy =)

Best Area to Stay. The best area to stay when in Istanbul as it is where the Blue Mosque, Hagia sophia, Basilica Cisterns and the Grand Bazaar are all situated, it is also within walking distance of the Galatta Bridge.

Grand Bazaar - full of predators and perverts. Very disgusted by recent experience at this cesspool. Slimy shop operators groping and fondling women at every opportunity. Be real concerned when they close their sliding doors to the booths with your female companions on the other side. Sleazy high pressure barkers nearly every ten feet in this place of over priced tourist trinkets. Experience sickened me with the human garbage that worked at several shops in the labyrinth of junk.

SPECIAL -- A MUST to visit. This is one of the best places I have been to in my various travels. The various Sites and Places of interest, BLUE MOqsue, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, TOP KAPI, etc.. it does not matter if it is day or night .. something special .. A BIG MUST to visit

the best place to stay n enjoy for a tourist. sultanahmet or travellers district has so many hotels and restaurants u can easily choose from historical attractions like blue mosque ,hagia sophia ,topkapi palace are at walking distances arasta shopping bazaar adjacent to blue mosque metro station at walking distance famous grand bazar next to metro station hop on hop off bus starts near blue mosque free shuttle to vialand near blue mosque and so on

Excellent place to look surrounds (Historic Places). Sultanahmet is one of the best historical places in Istanbul. It covers Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, Gulehane park, Grand Bazar and many more.

Busy, vibrant area. Lots to see and do.. We stayed in Sultanahmet and it was the perfect base for sightseeing while in Istanbul. Everything is within walking distance or easily accessible by tram. Istanbul is a very busy city, we preferred to travel by foot or tram as the traffic can be chaotic. it was Ramazan while we visited which added to the busy feel. Everynight thousands of locals would be out celebrating the breaking of the fast after sundown.

fascinating, bustling place. the area has lots of tourists but also lots of narrow streets full of interesting shops and great restaurants. It got very congested one day when 4 huge cruise ships were in port and it appeared that all the passengers were touring the area

the egyptian and the grand bazar is a "must see". You can walk for hours in the bazars of Istanbul. You see, smell, feel, hear the mix of hundreds (thousands ?) of shops where you can buy really anything. The atmosphere is very pleasant and not at all agressive (like in some other souks in mahgreb countries)

A Wonderful City. This was my second visit to Istanbul and first during the month of Ramadan. The month of Ramadan transforms Sultanahmet into a city of festivity. It was a very enjoyable experience with hundreds of families with children sitting on the lawns and other specially arranged tables with food and drinks to break their fast at the end of the fasting day, every day. Non-Muslim tourists were also there in huge numbers enjoying the festivities and the Ramadan Arts and Crafts Fair near the Blue Mosque.The eateries do a roaring business and in some restaurants there is live music and a show of the whirling dervishes. Very enjoyable.The municipality does a marvellous job of keeping the place clean and neat.

Fantastic area to wander through. So much of old Istanbul is within the Sultanahmet District, from the Bazaar at one end to the Spice Market and ferries at the other.Topkapi, Blue Mosque, New Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Cistern are all within walking distance, and the tram route rails can keep you from getting lost.

Exciting shopping district!. Lots of stores! Prices may start off too high but you can certainly haggle down to 50% or 60% of the original price! Some of the kitchenware such as plates and bowls are all handmade and are quite lovely.

Historic District. I liked this place because it is close to every historic place we wanted to visit. It has easy access to public transportation like ferry system and tram. It is easy to walk, and you have everything you need around the corner. Could be a problem if you want to have some drinks at local restaurants. At least it was difficult for us because you have mesquites everywhere, and you can not drink any alcohol close to this places. At least in Ramadan. We were there during this month. This is the only disadvantage of this district. If you do not care about this, then this is the perfect place to stay.
Sultan Ahmet. Walk around slowly and take it in. On top of the historical sights so much to see in the streets around such as Nurosmaniye Cd and Divan Yolu. I recommend not rushing through.

A must when going to Istanbul. and to get the genuine oriental feeling , you should stay thereas well. There is a huge numberof hotels, many of the botique hotels of very good standard,- so enjoye. the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazzar, the Topkapi, the Yerebatan-cistern etc., etc., etc.........

My experience in Sultanahmet area, Istanbul. We took metro and tram and went to this area on our first day in Istanbul. Great place and easy to get to all important places from here. First thing we did was to exchange some US dollars to local currency. By the way the two local currency exchange offices are not the best ones, although they are better than airport. For a rate of 2.76, one was giving 2.56 and another one 2.60. I have seen places near Aksara and Grand bazaar that gave 2.66.After converting money, walked into a Turkish delight and pastry shop that is like downstairs. We got samples of some fruit flavored delights to take and munch on our bus tour. We then head to red bus hop on hop off tour. My husband did not want to get off anywhere yet, so we took the whole tour. It was a great first experience of the entire city. Commentary during the tour was awesome. Then we went to the same pastry store which also had delicious baklava. We tried some baklava and cappuccino there. Although the place looks very small from outside, it has very big seating area inside and very good customer service.We then walked by some stores in the area. Watched a lady make Gozleme, went to couple of souvenir stores and bought some. By the way, I have so far been to Arasta bazaar and Grand bazaar on my second and third days, but this place seemed to have good prices. We then got some dinner packed and head to hotel. Great experience and great energy in the area which made me go there every day and try different things. Walking distance from there to Blue mosque, Arasta bazaar, etc. There is also a Starbucks and Mcdonalds in this area.
Sultanahmet Area. We stayed locally and it is a great place, both in its proximity to the main attractions and for reasonably priced restaurants

Awesome place to stay all day. It's an awesome place to stay all day, there are museums, cafes, historic buildings, attractions, hotels, restaurants and much more. Besides you will find it to be a very safe place for tourists, with all the facilities like, toilets and ATMs.

Really nice after 9PM. We were there during Ramadan, so there wass lot of people after sunset. Grab a Kebab and have a improvised picnic in the park. Feel like you are part of people there. There is amazing restaurats around this area - most of them quite expensive. Park and multiple attractions make this District best place to stay if you are toursit that really want to enjoy local culture.

Sultanahmet District is the place to stay. Sultanahmet district is the old city & as it sits at the top & is relative flat is easy to walk around. there is no trouble going down to the Bosphorus to the spice market as you simply catch the Tram back up the hill.Everything you will want to see in the area is there, grand Bazzar, Mosques, Cistern, Panoramic view from Hotel roof tops. Great as the sun is setting.

Best place for tourists. This is absolutely the best area of Istanbul for tourists to stay in. I stayed in Taksim and really wish I had stayed here instead. It has all of the major sights and a ton of great restaurants within walking distance
Sultanahemet. Everything within walking distance of each other. The Grand Bazaar is a great place although the shop owners could really do with taking no for an answer.
Amazing but crowded. It is such a big place you could basically find everything. But too many stores and two many people. You get overwhelmed easily.

Everything is here. All the great sights were within walking distance: Blue Mosque, Ayasofia, Cistern, Grand Bazaar, and the Bosphorous. If you stay within the district you have pretty much covered all the must-sees.

Great but expensive. The sights are amazing, and most things are walking distance from one another. The food and restaurant choices are excellent. The only downside is that everything is very expensive, and obviously are catered to earning tourist $$$!
Old town. Love this district. Many boutique hotels, close to main attractions. Everyone very friendly and restaurants are many and quite good.
Quite good.... The Sultanahmet area is one of the more interesting historical districts I've seen. It well laid out and easy to get around once you've orientated yourself.

History everywhere. There are so many layers of history in this place. Next time I go I hope to be able to spend more time here just sitting and soaking up the significance of the capital of the Byzantines and Ottomans.

Y. I was surprised it s a beautiful place rounded with history monuments and can said poor and rich styles can see in this place .hope government take care more about this place and get back to their splendor .very crowded and wonderfull desserts store
Spectacular. From the moment you set your foot on the Sultanahmet square you're taken by the amazing beauty of the historical structures surrounding it. Ironically Basilica Cistern was my favourite.

We stayed in old city. Our hotel was in the old city ,you got a real feel of the place , we walked to blue mosque ,topkai palace ,cistern ,bazaar ,we stayed four days , it's very easy to get around ,if you want to go further a field the tram is the best way ,cheap quick easy to use . If anyone looking for a small hotel ,the hotel we stayed was voted the best in its price range ,I cannot say enough about it ,helpful ,the first thing they do is give you a map of every where to go plus the good restaurants & the ones not to go to ,the staff all friendly ,because it gets such good reviews on trip adviser always busy ,the name is The Basillus ,you need really comfy foot ware it's all cobble stones ,before I got there I had read to look out for pick pockets ,we felt perfectly safe & never heard of anyone who had a bad experience .

Lots to see and soak up. It gets a bit humid out here, so, be prepared when walking around here in the summer. The Blue Mosque is nice, but we did expect a bit more 'blue'. The palace complex is very impressive, and you could spend an entire day or two, but we hit the key spots in about 2+ hours. The Hagia Sophia is not be missed, worth your time, and be sure to walk upstairs (they have ramps, not stairs) to get a better view. Afterwards, walking thru the two bazaars and surrounding areas is very neat.

THE HEART OF ISTANBUL..!. This is the main area of Istanbul's tourist area, and has all the major attractions to hand not to mention the many overpriced restaurants who are expertly geared for parting the unwary from their holiday cash. The best way to get here is to use the tram lines from the Egyptian market to Sultanahmet using a multi travel card which is a brilliant way to utilise the public transport including ferries and even the public toilets, you just top up your card from a tobacconist / newspaper shop and away you go..!Upon arriving, you're immediately in the hub of everything touristy, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazzare, etc..Just bear in mind this is one seriously busy place with all the coaches arriving dumping tourists everywhere etc.. It's even better if you base yourself here like we did which meant we just walked to the attractions and took a tram anywhere else. As for the restaurants, it's a buyers market with inflated prices to match just be careful with your choices. You can also stay as long as you want, as the Sultanahmet never sleeps, and armed with a trusty free map you'll never be lost...Enjoy.

Great atmosphere. This is a great area to stay in. Everything is within walking distance including major historical and cultural attractions, several distinct eating areas and shopping. I would definitely stay around here again.

Walk Sultanahmet. Loved Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkai Palace,the Cisterns, archaeological Museum, Mosaic Museum.,Walk through Bazaar early in the day, Spice Market, shopping, Rooftop bars & restaurants. Loved the 500 yr old Hamam !!!
Lots of great restaurants, bars, shopping. You get some exercise walking around but everything you need within a few blocks of this area, or hop on the tram to get to other areas of Istanbul.

Nice experience to visit the old city.... A short tram ride from Karaköy to Sultanahmet area will give you some significant information about the important sights of the city as you are going to see Galata Bridge,famous old part of European side,Eminönü district with Selimiye Mosque on yr right,Mısır Çarşısı (Spice Market) on yr right,Haliç (Golden Horn) on yr right,Gülhane Park,Topkapı Palace,Saint Sophia,Blue Mosque,German Fountain etc.When you walk through the small roads and streets in this very famous and crowded area,you will come close with any nation available on the earth as this is a kind of final meeting point for visitors.Always very nice to be here.
Not to miss. Very lively pittoresque and animated , full of colors , aroma and feelings. need to be visited , and dont forgett to eat in one of the food stand

Home to so many attractions ...... Home to so many of Istanbul's cultural attractions, it's a lovely place to wander and people watch. The Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia etc are all within a short distance of each other along with several other lovely mosques. It's always bustling with both locals and tourists and the only downside is the inflated restaurant/cafe prices. A must-see area for anyone visiting the city.
Sultanahmet. One of my favorite place in Istanbul. You can find everything and feel like a citizen. I always book my hotel here. You will be near the spices market, the Blue Mosque, Agia Sophia..

Beautiful and modern, fashionable!. My friend and I stayed 3 days in Istanbul from May 9 to 12,2015. so we walked a lot! Sultanahmet is on the European side of Istanbul. It is a great spots, a good kitchen with traditional dishes, turkey delights at Hazer Baba in the Egyptian Bazaar are awesome! Its main thoroughfare is Divan Yolu, which runs from the Grand Bazaar to Hagia Sophia. You can stroll along this route on foot. You can also ride the tram which travels along Divan Yolu. Sultanahmet is the heart of historic Old Istanbul, what 19th-century travelers used to call "Stamboul. In this is where you'll find Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan Saray), Binbirdirek Cistern, the Istanbul Archeological Museums, Great Palace Mosaic Museum, etcetera.... Simply wonderful!

Touristy but very pleasant area. We stayed here, in Sura Hagis Sofia, and while quite a touristy area we really enjoyed our stay. Everything is close at hand and we rarely ventured furthecafield during our week, although when we did the team T1 was very easy. Lots to see and do, and if you look carefully, lots of great food choices.

Excelent for walking around. This neighbourhood is beatiful to walk around, lots of attractions are there and are worth at least a couple of days to walk around. But it's very touristic, so it's much more expensive thatn the rest of Istanbul. Just walk 10 blocks to the north and you'll have lunch for litteraly 4 times less than there...

Bustling hive of touristy trade actvitiy. Despite drizzly weather in June, this district is a hive of activity with as many locals as tourists bartering and buying - from dates to home-wear, to spices and tourist gimmicks - you will find it all. Don't forget to bargain, or you will leave broke. prepare to walk up inclines and down busy walkaways. If you want anything other than turkish cuisine to eat - get something before you stroll around in the district as there isn't much of a variety. the public transport is great, so if you fit, make a day of spending it in the district and the surrounding cultural sites and the edge of the Bosphorus.
Great Place. Great Place Istanbul is amazing would live here, soaked in history well worth a visit. Try the amazing pastry & desert shops rivals anything in Europw

Beautiful but very touristy. Stayed here for the first half of our Istanbul stay. Loved the narrow cobblestone streets but we were surrounded by older couples and nothing but tourists and businesses that catered to them. Glad we stayed there for a couple of nights but no more.
Interesting. The whole area is interesting with mosque and church so close to each other. Not to be missed,] Be aware of touts and other possibly "light fingered" people.

Core of the historic city. This area includes all the major historical monuments. If you are short on time, spend it here. Includes Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, the Orient express train station... excellent night life. There is a wide choice of smaller, more typical hotels to choose from.

Spend a lifetime enjoying the sites. Safe to walk around all day seeing the historic sites enjoying the atmosphere, no guide needed pick up a booklet from the main Information Office you will love it!

Best Place to Stay. It's very close to the main attractions, lots of options for food & shopping, but not as busy & noisy as Taksim. You can also see real life of locals. I like that we didn't need any means of transportation to reach Blue Mosque, Grand Bazar, Ayasofia & sea. We'll definitely stay in this district again if we ever come back to Istanbul.

Sultanahmet District. A tourist trap but then if you want to walk to all the attractions, it is the best place to stay. You can walk to the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sofia, the Hippodrome, grand bazaar. Fascinating place.
Lively streets awesome food!. This is heart of Istanbul. Streets full of restaurants, shops and people. You can smell hookah in the air! And all the major attractions are situated in this area.

Visitors' Heaven. The sights, hotels, restaurants, shops - and, of course, the Grand Bazaar - Sultanahmet has it all! Every time I'm in Istanbul I stay in Sultanahmet, because almost everything is within walking distance and the vibrancy of the city is very obvious here.

Bustling at night. Lots of restaurants will pull you in. I didn't visit many of the shops but they seem to sell everything. The place is alive at night but super quiet in the mornings.If you are a runner or walker, mornings are the best, just be wary of the uneven sidewalks and streets. There are many cats and a few dogs that hang out. Most look healthy.The cobblestones can be treacherous and slippery. I sprained an ankle, but the same thing happens in suburban California where the streets are not as old.People are super helpful and will help you. At the major sites, you will find people acting helpful but then following up with a pitch to visit a carpet store.
Wonderful place to be. Liked: The grand mosque, activities there for tourists, fantastic in "Ramadan"Not liked: nothing...

The heart and soul of Istanbul. Brilliant vibrant area with so much to see and experience. Just the part between the Hagia Sophis and Blue Mosque with gardens and a beautiful fountain is magic!
