Yes, inevitably very busy but such a great atmosphere of people from all over the world enjoying being there. If you are thinking of visiting Istanbul, this is the area to stay in and enjoy.

The Grand bazar. Its like being in Aladdin, the grand bazar has thousands of shops and its an amazing place to see. You can buy jewellery, souvenirs, baclava ans spices. There are cash machines inside the bazar in case you have spent all your money.

Interesting Walk - and Safe. We walked all over the place it seemed and never once felt threatened. The streets are narrow, some cobbled and can be confusing but the folk are friendly and willing to offer guidance where needed. Major attractions abound in this area so don't miss it.
Easy Tram Access to Historic Sites. The historic buildings - Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia were set in very attractive parkland. They were easy to get to by tram.

Touristy but lovely. The district is ground zero for tourism in Istanbul, and as such you really have to expect the crowds and the persistent sales pitches. But it is a lovely place to stay, filled with lots of fun shops, good restaurants and lovely hotels. Look for the rooftop terraces, the best locations to watch the sun go down and the lights come up on the Blue Mosque and the Haiga Sophia.

Authnetic Istanbul. If you want an authentic traditional Istanbul experience Sultan Ahmet District is the place to be, with the Blue Mosque, Ayia Sofia and The Grand Bazaar amongst other great attractions to visit.
Sultanahmet. Packed with history and places to visit. Great place to base yourself in Istanbul. The Yasmak Sutan hotel was great and only a short walk to all the local attractions.

Great area. Great area full of shops, restaurants and bars. The carpet shop touts are a pain at times but just ignore them and they lose interest in a short space of time. Wander the small streets for great restaurants.

Centre of Everything in Istanbul. It is close to most of the landmarks such as Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazar, Spice Bazar etc. The trams provided great connectivity to all the interesting places across the golden horn. There is nothing that I disliked about the place

A must see in Istanbul. If it is your first cisit to Istanbul then I think this will be the best place if not to stay at then to visit. All historic places are within walkable distance. The general atmosphere is incridable there with lots of bazaar, cafe and resturants.

Fantastic old part of the city. Stayed at Hotel Sultania in this area. Lots of places to visit. They have kept the area relatively clean and well looked after. A place to go to if you are looking for the old historical Istanbul.

So many first-rate touristic sites in such a small area.. Not only are there several historic mosques here, but also other tourist attractions, such as the Basilica Cistern, the Mosaic Museum (both highly recommended) and several others as well. Try to get tickets in advance for any site for which tickets are required, or be prepared to spend time waiting on a possibly long queue for each one. This area is one of the best tourist destinations in the world. You could literally spend several days here and not see everything that there is to see.

Key sights, bazaars, cafes, street culture give for a great atmosphere. Great area of narrow streets bordering the key sights. Easy to walk around and get in and out of by tram. Feels safe and welcoming. Take in a key sight then lunch down a busy side street, afterwards walk through a bazaar have an ice cream/coffee stroll around and observe. Istanbul being centrally located attracts tourists from across the world and feels a true melting pot. Sultanahmet is the size of a large Disney park and totally for tourists. However it is steeped in history, more colourful with a greater variety of food and surprises. Main downside is constantly being approached by touts for boat trips, restaurants, carpet shops, guiding services etc which although done politely becomes a real drag having to fend off.I'm sure the area loses more tourists as a whole who get fed up off having to spend another day fending off 5-10 touts when all you wish for is a stroll through the area at your own relaxed pace

Special. There is so much too see and do in this district, the historic buildings alone are almost overwhelming. As the area of Sultanahmet is set on the top of a hill the views from the many vantage points, are again overwhelming.Great choice of food from the humble simmit to exotic Turkish flavours. Great cafe's, with local or western coffee, wonderful baklava. You won't want for anything.If you want to explore further the wonderful trams will get you the quickly and cheaply.Sultanahmet suited us very nicely, I think the best choice to stay here for your first short trip. Absolutely loved Sultanahmet.

Central. A great area to use as a base for exploring with pretty cobbled streets and lots of cafes shops and small hotels. The major attractions are all within walking distance and its simple to pick up transport here to visit further afield.
Be prepared for tourist crowds. The Hippodrome is very impressive but also the most popular spot for groups from the cruise ships. Avoid the local restaurants and cafés.

Tourist mecca. Many big tourist sites along with innumerable places to stay and eat. Hard to know whether the restaurants are good or ordinary but for fast food 4 Doner beside tram on way up hill to Aya Sofia is recommended. Great to just walk the streets.

Surprise, Surprise. I have to admit that I was very reluctant to go to Turkey. Mainly for the reason of their aggressively anti-Western and pro-Islamic Government. An after traveling all over the globe for many, many years I new that Government may easily impact the people's behavior. So it came as almost a shock that during out trip ---first in Izmir district and then in Istanbul - we met only wonderful and warm people, going out of their way to explain, show, point toward, answer the question etc. Clean streets, unbelievable sales skills --- nice, polite, warm ( I know that I use this word a lot but how did it feel) and educational. The private guide that we had in Istanbul (Nesrin Ulupinar, Delightful Istanbul Tours) was very knowledgeable, very personal, open and helpful. Could not ask for the better companion ( and all 4 of us are very picky as far as guides are concerned). And Am not even touching the architecture, history, FOOD, Highly recommend the city, the Guide and the People of Turkey.
Great area. Loved this historical area, so much character to it. Lots of great grand sights. Highly recommended to visit at least once in your life.

many sights in one place, but thats it.. very touristy. which is good for like 1 day. everything is closed late a night which is annoying if you come back from a night out at 2-3 in the morning, in comparison, places around taksim are generally open later than here. lots of stray dogs too roaming the backstreets in packs which can be a little unnerving.

food not great. Shopping fantastic. Check out Jennifer's Hamam shop. There is a little location in the bizarre behind the Blue Mosque but a bigger location close by. They can direct you at the little shop. Beautiful natural organic eco-friendly cotton. Not as cheap as found in many other places but the quality is outstanding and Jennifer (A Canadian) sources only the best quality products created in a respectful manner.

mixture of good and bad housing. disliked the sound of big birds screeching in the air at 5am in the morning.also lots of dirt lying around on certain street corners.The area is very old and can come across as eery in certain places at night.Food in some parts of the area such as the kebaba house has good affordable food

brilliant clean. explore the area on feet its very interesting, we went in march it was still called and bit windy which made it difficult but still enjoyable, save and clean very suitable for families with older children. young teens enjoyed the cultural richness to the maximum to only issue was very limited english singes which made it harder to navigate find a good map the internet and goggle map is very in consistant
So much to see!. So many historic sites to fit in. You need 4 to 5 days to fully explore! Get some good walking shoes, there is a lot of ground to cover, not for the faint hearted!

Cultural but extremely busy city. Love all the cultural aspect and weather of the city, but the place was also super busy. The metro and trams are also packed with people. And the locals may be over-friendly at some times to an annoying state. Overall, a good place to travel.

Sultanahmet District is lovely. Atlantis hotel was located in this area. The hotel was very good. The "Old Town" neighborhood, including restaurants and souvenir shops, was ideal for tourists. It's also very near to several important touristic spots. It's a pleasure to visit and revisit
Live district. It's a very nice district to stay in, very live and has all the attractions within walking distance, shopping area and many food facilities..

Great area to walk around in. We truly enjoyed our time in the Sultanahmet District of Istanbul. This is the old city with many old buildings. The biggest downfalls were that it was at least 20 minutes from public transit and the constant attempt to sell you something by the local merchants.

loved it. this place is like going back in time.you can feel the history, see it, hear it , smell it and taste it. food of all types , for every budget, . allow yourself to get lost into the alleys, and use your ear to find your way back into the mainstream.will be back again
Stayed there. A great area to base your visit to Istanbul. Central to all the main attractions some really nice restaurants. Lots of touristy shops if needed.
nice. it's a historical district and you can have wonderful time by walking through its streets. moreover, there are a lot of candy store which present traditional turkey candy .
Historical area. The area is very clean and has lots of different shops. There is the "small bazaar" worth visiting. The shopkeepers are very friendly and most speak English. Istanbul is delightful.

Great place to stay to see all the historic sights. We stayed in the Sultanahmet District area and arranged for a guided walking tour of the Hagia Sophia, Byzantine Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar and Basilica Cistern through Daily Istanbul Tours. It's the perfect place for our first visit to Istanbul.

Buzzing Istanbul. This is a wonderful area of Istanbul and there is history everywhere you turn. Great historic attractions and wonderful places to explore and as usual, friendly people to assist you and help you spend some Lira. Places for eating are everywhere, from fast food and street vendors to lovely restaurants. Very good for wandering around at your leisure and the sights and sounds are wonderful as are the aroma's from the spice market.

So reminiscent of Turkey's fascinating history. The cobblestone streets that wound in all directions with buildings from another time clamoring for one's attention. Hats off to the bus and mini bus drivers who manouevre their way through this potpourri of impossibly narrow streets and humanity.
Nice, but expensive. As here is the place where all important things happen, it is an unmissable spot in Istanbul; however, the prices are double or even triple - food, for example.
Wow Area. My wife and I with a friend of ours walked at this area just after a light rain. it was a part of heaven. flowers, trees, streets and shops were wonderful. you should visit this district

NEVER HIRE A PARKED TAXI. Parked Taxis are always waiting for a customer to "rob". Especially in tourist places they park and wait for a tired customer. They never have a working taximetre and propose a fixed rate 3X the legal. You have to walk some hundred meters until you reach a road with traffic and hire a taxi there. Ask the driver to turn the meter on, if not, disembarge. Police is not goin to help you, they know what is happening, but they dont care

Most of what you want to see in a small area. Nearly everything you want to see is contained within or borders this area, with plenty of accomodtion to suit to all tastes and pockets. Good modern transport links to other parts of the city.
Shopping!. The old city, oh yes please, it's a must see! Take a few hours and a big bag, find a coffee house and enjoy the experience, the sights, sounds and smells....

Can't miss it. The area is the touristic hub of the city, so you can't miss it, as it is home to the major attractions, but it is also touristic. We would advise staying over on the Galata/Pera/Tunel/Karakoy side and walking over to see the sights, which are definitely worth exploring. Sunday morning was the most empty, as Istanbul is packed with locals and tourists most of the time.

Such a fascinating district of Istabul. The Sultanahmet district deserves all the praise it gets. There is just so much to see and to do. The Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar surprised my wife and I by being so well organised. We were expecting chaos, but instead we found the greatest possible range of wonderful things to buy, without any hassle from shop/stall holders. The colours, the smells, the whole experience in both bazaars is memorable. The warren of streets throughout the Sultanahmet district is amazing - busy but safe. You don't need to have a plan - just walk around and enjoy. The district is so accessible by tram that it would be a waste of money to use a taxi. We cannot recommend the Sultanahmet district enough!

The place to be in Istanbul. This is where you should go to do some people watching, eat Turkish food for every budget and see amazing sights. The Spice Bazaar is a must. Sit somewhere and just watch the people go by. It is busy, busy, busy and full of people all the time, but it is worth it. We have been to Istanbul twice and stayed in Sultanahmet on both occasions. It is definitely worth it and close to all major tourist attractions.

Wonderful place to stay. We stayed in a hostel. It was within walking distance of all the things we wanted to see. We strolled through the neighborhood on the way to town enjoying a coffee and small plates of food - visiting the merchants making nice with the nieghbors.
Fascinating. A required visit. History, history, history. Get a good guide and enjoy. We all learned a lot during this trip. Try to take the time to know this area.

Lots to see and good starting point for other places. The tram goes right along Sultanahmet Square. Get an Istannulkart card (like the Oyster card in London Tube system). You can use one card for your whole family; works on buses too.Just like any big city, there are pickpockets, so sometimes you should keep your hand on your wallet in your front pocket. I will say that I liked the Turkish people.
impressive and busy. huge market with dozens of similar little paths and tons of similar stores alongside. Great for clothes and textiles, souvenirs and lamps.

1st thing to do in Istanbul Centre. this is really first place to visit in Istanbul Centre, the mosque is huge and outstanding. Beautiful architecture of the building attracts every day thousands of tourists from all over the world.
A perfect location to spend endless hours on the streets. Spend your evenings walking along the alleys and streets of Sultanahmet. Street food and Turkish "Chai" recommended.
very busy area plenty to eat and drink for all budgets. great variety of shops - traffic is a nightmare as streets not that wide leave early to ensure reaching destination on time

Spice bazar fun. We visited this bazaarr with Hansen from travel shop Turkey. He showed us plenty of stalls and we bought the most amazing made with honey Turkish delight. Bought a beautiful Turkish ring with the 5 colour changing stone. We didn't feel pressured at all and it was fun.
Awesome.. We stayed in the Sultanahmet area for 5 days and never had a dull day. There is so much to do and see. Everything is so close and if you need to venture further the trams are easy.

Everything is here.. The Sultanahmet district is where all the major tourist attractions are, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Underground Cisterns, Topkapt Palace, The Grand Bazaar, and more, close to harbour.

Busy busy busy. Hustle and bustle..I'm not into the touristy things in a city so I didn't engage in these, however, the area is a delight with a mix of cultures, the "icecream performances" at the icecream stand, beautifully maintained landscapes and lots of cafes etc. Definitely have to visit even if it's just for a beer :)
Fascinating destination!!!. Only city where most tourist attraction can be visited within walking distances , depending on where you stay . Traffic congestion, overcrowding on tramways ,
It has Everything. You have to come particularly if you're in Istanbul for a short time. This and the Bosphorus are must-dos. Though there are fees to the museums the Mosques are free.

Beware in this tourist trap. The constant touts for restaurants gets very irritating particularly as the restaurants are relatively expensive and the food is mass produced of at best average quality. Having said that this is where all the main sites are and the metro system is really easy and frequent.

Over and over and over again - and again. This is the very heart of Istanbul. No matter where you look you see minarets and beautiful flower beds. You see happy people, you see busy people and you just keep seeing. You can literally walk everywhere from here and if you get tired, there are trams and taxis all over. There are shops, coffee shops and places to eat everywhere. It isn't far from the Bosporus either. This is the perfect place to get lost!
Instanbul's Poster. Sultanahmet District has Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar & Spice Bazaar. You would require at least 2 -3 Days to enjoy this District.

The Bustling Sultanahmet. Roadside cafes with myriad aromas, trams, vendors with souvernirs..this place captures the very essence of Istanbul. A must visit and also recommend a stay for those who want to savour the local flavour.
Can't get tired of it. Lots of cultural attractions in this area. A pleasure to walk around and explore, if you can get past the hard-sellings

Great place to stay and walk around. Our hotel was in Sultanahmet. I highly recommend staying in this area. We did most of the major sights on foot and took the tram to explore further. Sultanahmet is lovely

Lively, very special!. A very central area in the eternal Istanbul, Old Constantinopole. Sultanahmet combines art and pleasure for every sense with unveiled commercialism. Many of the main sites are within walking distance. Or take a tram and explore!
Very Busy but great attractions. You are in the middle of the ancient history of Istanbul. Great places to eat and shop for the wonderful pasteries of Turkey.

lots of history and culture. took an early morning walk when the baby was jet lagged and discovered a city just waking up. Savoured architecture of this historical district and enjoyed walking around seeing where locals lived, ate and socialised without the hussle and bussle of tourists.
Blue. good neighborhood but carpet sellers annoying, if you don't pay attention to servers and carpet guys you'll enjoy very much
Bazaar of senses experiences. Unbelievable sights, tastes, smells, a trip in itself, nearby beautifull Bosphorus, good place to hang.

Best of Istanbul. I prefer the activity of Sultanahmet. We stayed in the district and found it clean, convenient, and friendly. Everything is close by and there are plenty of restaurants. All the main sites were within easy walking distance.

Perfect. What can I say about this historic district that would do it justice.. not much! as with the majority of Istanbul's attractions, this is an area you have to go see for yourself and get immersed in the wonders of an almost different era ;)

Top Sites. Surely, it would not be possible to visit Istanbul, at least for the first time, and not go to Sultanahmet? All of the top sites are there, within easy walking distance, and there is a tram stop close to the Blue Mosque for journeys further afield. Topkapi, Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque are breath-taking in their beauty, as is the underground gem the Basilica Cistern. There are plenty of places to eat and drink, and there is a row of ATMs in the coach park area between The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia. Outside Hagia Sofia, it is possible to buy a MuseumKart from a mobile shop, which gives speedy access to a number of sires including Hagia and Topkapi - a good investment.

An Open Air Museum!. This may be touristy, but it was so wonderful to be right in the heart of this district. The Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, markets, even the Grand Bazaar were all right there! The only place we needed to take a taxi was to get to the Bosphoros Cruise.

Loved this area. The complexity and myriad of little streets and lanes making this whole area work, was a delight to experience, that's apart from the magnificent mosques and museums in the area.A must see.

Vibrant and busy. Amazing bustling full of exotic smells and sights. Can become very busy at times, keep tight hold of children the bright colours and shining gifts are irresistible to children. Worth visiting at the beginning of the holiday to see whats available and to return for purchases day before you leave.
Buzzing place. Very nice buzzing place with lots of places to eat. The main tourist sites all within walking distance. Just need to follow the tram line T1.
So many step!. The Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace. All worth seeing. However there are many, many, many stairs. If you have bad knees, think twice.
Sultanahmet District. The place to stay to take in the sights and sounds of Istanbul. Lots of variety and diversity. Markets mixed in with modern shopping. Lots of cafes, bars, restaraunts.

Enjoy it a lot. Perfect for people that love walking. Ok, its really touristic, sometiimes the people disturb you, but this is part of your trip :) I spend 3 days there walking around, including Grand Bazaar. Please, be careful with your stuff and do not accept invites to go to bars bla bla bla specially if you are alone. Nevertheless, you will be in one of the most amazing cities in the world :)

Great Location Close to Major Istanbul Landmarks. I stayed in the Mevlana Hotel for its great location and good value for the money. The breakfast terrace has a beautiful view of the sea. Walking distance to a big bazaar, restaurants, pastry shops, Basilica Cistern, and the Hagia Sophia. This district is the most convenient location to major landmarks when visiting Istanbul.

Good place to stay . We chose this district to stay as it is where most of the attractions are, but it is more than that.Plenty of walking,shops and restaurants plus parks to chill out in.The main tram runs through to take you up to Kabatas or west in to the old city.We had no problem getting around or finding things to do.Down side ? Shops and restaurants are touristy expensive, wander a small way in any direction and you can save plenty

Old City of Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the old city of Istanbul. It would be a better idea to stay in hotels near Sultanahmet district because most of the popular tourist spots are in Sultanahmet district such as Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazar.

Tourist trap. Most of the historic sites are in Sultanahmet, so it makes sense to stay in the area, which is what we did. However beware that it does feel like a complete tourist trap, with simple lunches being ridiculously priced!

Sultanahmet definitely is the place to stay. Stayed here for a week. So central to all the main historic sites of Istanbul , Carpet Sellers , Markets and Great Cafes and Bars . Tram way runs through so get Istanbul Card to travel about .
So much to see. lively and bustling. Get the Big Bus from here. Also good tram stop. Eating in the square is mediocre and pricey walk a few streets away for better value.

Trip to Istanbul. Great area with lots of attractions. This area in the Old City houses the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and other attractions of interest all within walking distance from each other.
Beautiful. Loved this area. so many beautiful buildings and antiquities, the gardens were stunning and overflowing with tulips and the local cats and dogs provided a unique feeling.

Great fun to be around. Chaotic and thrifty shopping mixed with a variety of history and culture - superb! There are many bars and restaurants to choose from - both the busy ones as well as quiet ones around the back streets. Even just walking around the streets is fun, but a visit to at least one of the mosques is a must!
Lots to See. This is an excellent area of old Istanbul with lots to see and do. Many things are happening. Worth a visit.
Nice area to visit. A busy area of Istanbul with a lot of tourists and souvenirs shops. Food is a little more expensive. A lot of major attractions to visit all around.

is a must! No Sultanahmet No Istanbul. Is the area where most of the sights and Arasta Bazaar are.
Not only that, some lovely restaurants are in here too.
Def worth a visit otherwise why coming to Istanbul?

The Real Istanbul. Everything you need to see in Istanbul is right here (well, almost everything)! It was a wise decision on my part to book a hotel in the area. Every attraction of note is within walking distance. The old town feel makes you feel like you're in a different era as you're walking around. Food may be a bit pricey, but you can find cheap eats if you look around. Some complain about the crowds, but I say it's part of the experience!

Commercial but necessery. . This part of Istanbul is very touristic and commercial area. Cheap tricks and imitated goods all over. Sticky mobile or shop sellers are racing for making irriatation the people. There is many Restaurants also and you must read from the guides before decide to get in.  But here is hearth of historical part of Istanbul. There is mostly old style restorated streets, mosques, tombs, avenues, Rest-cafes, bars, hotels, souvenirs and many more attractive things. Check the route and take a walk. You will never regret to seeing there.

Tight neighborhood with landmark attractions. After one week in the neighborhood, we met many of the local shop owners, people who work in the restaurants and shops, and heard many stories about people's lives. The landmarks brought us here, the people made it special.

Million stone district. Historical, crowded,busy and most worthy area of Istanbul to see. Topkapi palace, Hurram Sultan,Hagia Sofia,Blue mosque are the main points to visit. Hippodrome square also has few other things to explore Million stone and Open Auditorium of Fateh Baledesi is within this point. Best place to explore and to spend time. So many shopping and dining points in surrounding area makes you busy and Tea spots to find culture in them.

Perfect area to stay for exploring the city. We stayed in the Sultanahmet District in a small guest house. Location is perfect for walking to most of the sights in the Historic Areas of the city. Lots of small hotels, lots of restaurants, shops, etc.Perfectly safe for walking around.

The real Istanbul. What a buzz this place has! So much to see and experience.All the attractions like Topkapi Palace, HagiaSophia, Blue mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar,Spice Bazaar are here. Authentic Turkish cuisine at roadside cafes is a treat. But one has to be careful of pickpockets and shopping is mostly bargaining with the result you never know what the real price is-very frustrating. Cabs generally tend to overcharge by 100% and travelling by metro or tram is anyday faster and safer.
Too many tourists and fake food. Was great for a day to take in the sights but then it all became to touristy. Couldnt wait to get away

Lovely Place. This district is a blend of all - cafes, history, nature, shopping is all available here ! If you are a shopping buff just pretend not to be interested in a high priced item and walk away the shop keeps will drop the prices steep low ;) I was offered a table mat for 800 Turkish Lira and when i walked away the shop keeper shouted back and said, "okay come back 200 Lira for you only" :)
Very nice!. Great neighborhood! It's nice just to walk around. Historical buildings and pretty parks. Try Mr. Cook restaurant. It's delicious and the most pretty and romantic setting.
Old World Charm. The Sultanahmet district is an old world charm area. Very crowded, every thing moves slowly. All the important sights are in this area. Several eating joints, great shopping.
The old city. If you would like to visit istanbul,first you must visit to old city area. Hipodrom, Topkapı palace and hagia sophia and blue mosque. You can see all historical place in this town .

Crowded but worth it. Having stayed in two different areas of Istanbul on previous trips, we finally chose a great little hotel situated close to the Blue Mosque and highly recommend experiencing this area. Even though the crowds are overwhelming at times, there are so many attractions all within walking distance.
Tasty. Food is delicious local and reasonable. A great experience. You will find both, lots of locals and a few tourist here. You get to see what you are ordering!
Time On Your Hands. This place is awesome as there is so much to do in this district. Make sure you have plenty of time on your visit as it WILL creep away as there is so much to look at
History everywhere!. One of the great sight seeing districts in the world. Everything is close and within walking distance.
History at your doorstep. This old area of Istanbul I consider is the place to stay, lots of various priced hotels, good tram system to save some walking and heaps to see and do.
Excellent. We stayed in the area and found if very convenient to the attractions, restaurants and metro. A close walk to the Grand bazaar. On the whole we found the area clean and tidy.

Intriguing city. Interesting place. The tulips in April are spectacular. The Roman water reservoir is worth seeing also, and is directly across from Sofia Hagia. The Grand Bizzare is very busy but amazing to get lost in. The trams are a great way to get around, tickets are in machines at tram stops. Always carry 1 lira as toilet breaks are charged.

Lots to see and do. I took my brother here on a visit to Istanbul. Not knowing the area like a local, I am sure that there is much more still to see, but even taking in the Topkapı Palace, Blue mosque, Aya Sofia, Cisterns, etc, it's a wonder to behold. One absolute must is to visit the spice bazaar then stop for lunch at the Balık Ekmek (fish and bread) floating cafe in Eminönü. Marvellous.
Always Turkey!. Always Turkey! It summorizes all the landmarks you have to see. Nice pit stop for toilette and coffee.if you are in Istanbul you will have to come here!

Just poke in for a little look see. It's HUGE.. All I can say about the Bazaar is keep track of where you came in if you want to get back on the same tram. It's an easy tram ride from the Square with Hagia Sophia. I've never found any bargains on big items but they have everything.
Amazing. It's amazing to see all the movement of people at any hour! Good shopping, nice restaurants! Nice to walk about and stroll

Lots of tourist attractions concentrated in one place. This is a good location to stay in if you're visiting Istanbul for a short time. Most of the tourist attractions are concentrated here and it is easy to find a hotel or restaurant of your choice in this area. Everything is within walking distance and it is easy to take the train to other farther tourist spots.

the area to be for historics. we stayed in this district.. and its perfect for avoiding (well attempting to avoid!).. the mad taxis.. the constant attempts to gain your hard earned! whats really good is that you can just walk.. and walk.. and walk.. it feels 'safe'.. and there are plenty of things to see, do and eat..

Historical centre. A Great location for visiting museums, and historical sights as well as the jump off point for ferry excursions down the Bosphorous. Hundreds of restaurants - The tourist centre of istanbul.

Old town. We enjoyed this area as it has all of the main attractions. Not the area for nightlife. It is older and less polished. The carpet salesmen can be annoying but just politely and firmly say no. They will get the message.

The very city center. This is the real city center where are almost all landmarks. It is beautiful, clean and usually very crowded. When you become hungry and want to test something of the Turkish cuisine, go to Cakmaktasi Street... there is a street full of restaurants of all kinds and becomes very animated during the night. It's a little bit far away though....

I you like the "touristy" this is your neighborhood. All the most touristy places are here, and although I loved every single one of them, it could be a little overwhelming at times.
Take your time and be patient with lines and huge groups of people. It's worth it, I promise.
Great Place. Great place to walk around, drink some tea and watch the people walk by; I guess this is really Turkey

Short visit to Sultanahmet. I had a great 2 days exploring Sultanahmet, both on guided tours and by myself. Walking on my own in the immediate vicinity of the Hippodrome there were a few charming gentlemen who were a bit too determined to talk to me, but no one was intimidating and I found I was left in peace as soon as I moved out of the area. I was wary of visiting the Grand Bazaar but found that shopping there was actually more relaxed than elsewhere,
Make sure you spend some time here. There are a lot of sights in this area that are on the to do list. Take some time to sit and watch and wonder. Make sure you vist the Mosaic Museum.
Good location.. Walking distance to most attractions, and close to tram line and currency exchange booth. There are many restaurants, and the Museum Pass is available outside the Aya Sofya.
A lovely place. Its definitely a nice place to walk around and experience a bazaar. But you definitely need to bargain and haggle for a good price in the jewelry shops.

Stay and see. Staying in this part of town puts you within walking distance of the biggest attractions, the Arasta Bazaar, lots of restaurants to walk to and more\
We walked about day and night and enjoyed the beauty of the mosques.

Where to go in Istanbul. In Sultanahmet, the Blue Mosque faces Hagia Sophia across acres of public gardens, where the citizens of the city meet each other and tourists gather. The Sultanahmet District is where you will find Haghia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and its amazing Arasta Bazaar (our favorite shopping in Istanbul), the Istanbul Crafts Center in an old caravansary, the outstanding Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art, the Hippodrome where the Romans raced their chariots circa AD 200, the Mosaic Museum, the Baths of Roxelana, the magically echoing and cavernous Roman Basilica Cistern of 1001 Columns Constantine's Column, the Church SS Sergius and Bachus, the Bucoleon Palace, the Skollu Mehmet Pasa Mosque, the Tomb of Sultan Mahmut II, the Marmara University Museum of the Republic, the Roman Obelisk, Firuz Aga Mosque, both the brazen and the Serpentine columns, the Fountain of Kaiser Wilheml II, and many other splendors, including some excellent restaurants. If you miss Sultanahmet, you have missed Istanbul.From Sultanahmet, the land slides down to the Sea of Marmara. The streets are full of traditional wooden Ottoman houses directly on top of the former Great Palace of the Byzantine Emperors. Rarely has an area been more historic, full of more stories, and more delightful to visit. Enjoy not only the obligatory mosques, museums, and squares, but stop to enjoy yourself with fresh squeezed fruit juices in the local cafes and coffee houses. At the cafes around the blue mosque, you can see Whirling Dervishes dance daily, as well as hear live traditional music. At the Arasta Bazaar, housed in the old stables of the Blue Mosque, you can find some of the best shopping in Istanbul. Enjoy yourself. You can also pick up an inexpensive several hour boat tour of the Sear of Marmara and the Golden Horn from the street tour guides in this area.

Amazing area to explore. All of the major historical sites are within this area. You can spend says just visiting everything available to you. The culture and history are second to none. And staying in this area makes everything more convenient and enjoyable.

Tremendous historical area. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Underground Cistern were the highlights, with people watching and great photography as a bonus! Spend some time here, keep to the shade, bring some water, and take in the incredible architecture, sights, sounds, and bustle of Istanbul.
Enjoy the day... Hang out, see historical attractions, walk, experience the taste of Istanbul... and don't forget to try the Lu'kum :)
Beautiful. It is such a beautiful place with the culture and the history there is nothing to dislike. There are all cultures here and everyone is respectful of each other

The Center of the ols city. Very lively and touristy, you have her the main sights, good transport, restaurants, shops coffee, Typical area to stay on your first visit to Istanbul.I post my trip and pictures of Istanbul in my personal travel blog:www.travelera.es

Unforgettable. Loved the people but not the salesmen. Much too aggressive with their sales tactics. Watch also for people who say they're guides to a famous mosque or some attraction and can get you to the front of the line for a fee. They will just cut in line and expect you to follow. Any jerk can do that for free but he will gladly take your money.

Beautiful but extra high prices. This is obviously the beautiful side of the city and packed with historical places to visit. However everything here is much more expensive then anywhere else in Istanbul.
dreamy. One city i would move to ...hopefully one day..weather..people..food.and the relaxed and chilled.out atmosphere.

A lot to see. Massive crowds each day around The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace & Basilica Cistern. Best way to get there if not on a guided tour is by tram but take good care of your possessions as they become very crowded and friends were robbed of cash and credit cards. Not to far to the Grand Bazzar so allow a day if going there. Worth doing and plenty of restaurants around for a drink and a feed.

Must visit. This is the loation in Istanbul you must visit, not enough one day, so many things to do and see. Take the tram T1 from Kabatas to Sultanahmet. You have mosques, palace, parks, restaurants, historical streets and so on...

Want to wake up around 5 am?. Well, you will if you stay in this neighbourhood. But it doesn't really matter. It's kind of charming. And you certainly know where you are. This is the place to stay when visiting Istanbul, especially for the first time. You will find lots of culture - new and old - and you will find annoying people who try to sell you anything. If you have no intention to buy, then don't look at them and just walk away. But as in any other large city, there are too many tourists....
Great for major historical sites. All the major attractions are in Sultanhmet district and the transport system is great, make sure you get a Istabulkart for use on the varios modes of transport.
great to walk around and stable on sights. we walked all around this area as there were so many sights to see and some we just stumbled upon. stopped for breaks in the many small baklava/lokum cafes

Perfect area to stay. It's central & safe even at midnight. The streets are full of lights & most shops & restaurants don't close until late at night. You can go everywhere from here catching the tram, ferry or even a taxi. Most of the historical attractions are here so you can walk to every where from here including the grand bazar. The area is so busy with locals & tourists alike, but it gets even more crazy when the big cruise ships arrive to the port. Istanbul is a great city & Sultanahmet is definitely the best area to stay.
the hub of Istanbul old city. I liked the Food, history, shopping and nightlife. It's all here on all differing levels of quality and styles. But the locals can be aggressive and rude on occasion.
Islamic history. The old city has so much islamic history......Eyup Mosque,Sulimaniya Mosque,Fateh Mosque all recommended along with Blue Mosque, Sophia Hagia an Topakapi palace.
very nice. mosques and old city buildings are very beautiful,very heart touching movements,coming back to İstanbul soon

a must see area of this great city. all the historic sights, the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, Topkapi and its assumed ancient splendour, great to enjoy. The traffic is almost as annoying as its totally off-putting salesmanship anywhere
lots to see. lots of attractions in close proximity to each other. Beautifully kept grounds around them made walking easy and enjoyable.

In the middle of the old City. When I look which area I need to visit the most in Istanbul, I choose Sultanahmet District because I find out this is where my most area I need to visit. It is in the 1st area in 3 areas that you must see in old Istanbul. I suggested to stay in one of the small friendly hotel all around the district, it is close to the attraction and the Metro to take you everywhere.

Fun place to walk around. The Sultanahmet District is where all the historic places are, as well as most of the museums. Other than that, it's just a fun place to walk around, especially towards the evening and night when majority of the tourists are turning in.

Something for everyone. Don't bother taking packaged tours, you'll have a lot more fun just wandering around at your own pace, exploring the lanes, bazaars, Turkish delight shops, parks, mosques and heritage sites. Some of the prettiest spots are found just by walking about. Sit at one of the zillions of cafés, try a fresh pomegranate juice, or the roasted corn, pretzels, hot chestnuts sold at street carts, and just watch the locals go about their business. Feel free to play the game with the folk touting for business - they laugh as much as you do when you turn their stories back on them. Only one warning - apart from the usual gypsy kids hassling you for money - don't fall for the taxi line that there's a political rally and so much traffic that your usual taxi fare of 20TL has risen to 170 or 100 TL. Insist on the meter and tell them it's only 25TL of whatever your usual fare is. They'll object but just hold firm, insist you'll get another taxi and they'll soon realise you're onto their scam. There's a political rally and mega traffic every day in Istanbul and it doesn't affect the meter fare.

The place to stay whilst visiting Istanbul . If you are planning to visit Istanbul I suggest to stay in Sultanahmet. This is the historical district, the majority of the city highlights is close by walking distance, it's easy to reach by train from the Ataturk Airport and it is clean and safe!I loved strolling around this part of the city, every where you look there is something catching your eyes and attention.If you fancy exploring further out make sure you have the IstanbulKart which is essential to go around on trains, ferries, metro and buses!

Heart of Istanbul. This is the heart of Istanbul, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar everything is close by, a good shopping location for Turkish lamps and Turkish delights, baklava. And don't miss the pomegranate juice its just awesome.
Great to walk around . Killing time this place is great to just walk around. It is a nice break from other sites in a really nice area of town. Always offer 30-50% less for things.

You must stay in the Sultanahmet when in Istanbul. Following other reviews, I stayed in the Sultanahmet district in the Apricot Hotel. Without exception everyone was nice, pleasant, and friendly - literally I met not one person who was rude, nasty, or mean. While alone, when I fell and skinned my knee and nose, lots of people stopped to help while I recovered my bearings. A shopkeeper took me back to his store, cleaned me up, and iced my knee. This is the area with most of the tourist attractions and is very walkable. It has lots of restaurants and shopping. Many people speak English and are very helpful.A woman I met while dining had stayed near Taksim Square for business and had the opposite impression of Istanbul - rude, unfriendly, little to no English, and too far away to get to the Sultanahmet after her meetings. She was quite pleased to find this area much more friendly.
Gave us the shower of history. Could enter the mosque even at night, every piece of the stones on the floor or wall is showing the long history.

You find everything in Sultanahmet. This is my favorite district in Istanbul. Not because all the major historical aites are here, but because it is compact, vibrant, a gathering place of people from everywhere and you can just wonder and get lost in its winding side streets where there is always a new discovery to be had.

Amazing. Another must see in the wonderful city of Istanbul. The vast market is comprised of thousands of shops in a covered area and if you close your eyes you can imagine time in the distant past when these traders would have been shouting their little "come and buy me" chants to the locals, as they tried to sell their wares. Even now you can hear the distant cries of "Lovely Jubbly" and " Cheaper than Asda" as you walk through the market streets. There are still bargains to be had if you try to barter.

Great place to stay. This is in our opinion the pick of the areas to stay in Istanbul,you have a lot of the historical sites and you are also close to public transport to get you to places like taxman square etc.

What can I say?!. I loved this area of the city! Don't be afraid to wander off the beaten track a little. There are great photo opportunities to be had (if you have a passion for architecture!) Behind The Blue Mosque there are still examples of traditional ottoman houses, also Kuçuk Hagia Sophia is worth a visit too....
Old part of city. I liked all historical monuments, Mosqes, Aya Sofia, old Bazar, the streets and buildings, shops with turkish products

Great for walk about. Lovely restaurants and coffee shops, fresh juice stalls and kebab stalls. The Grand Bazaar is lovely but the vendors hassle you too much. Also they change their prices daily and don't honour previous day prices. We also did the Cemberlitas Maman near the Bazaar and it was lovely.

versatile and beautiful surroundings. In this area everyone can find something for themselves ... there is a lot of the landmarks as well as the possibility to eat or just drink some tea in the cozy bar.You can walk the whole district, but if you want to go to another district there are many tramways and metros...this area is really a tourist, but in many streets you can find your peace and feel the charm of Istanbul.
Fabulous Place to Stay. Great sights- great walks make this a spectacular choice for a stay in Istanbul. Is it busy? Yes but in a strange way that adds to the appeal.

All in!. Yes most of the must see in istanbul is here. Better start early in the morning like 730 so you can have much time to take photos with less people around.. at around 830 this place will be crowded.. restaurants and shops are everywhere so you will really enjoy everything here..oh dont forget to feed the pigeons :)

The Mosque is the best thing. If you visit Sultanahmet District, make sure you pay the Blue Mosque a visit, there is a lot to see, the only down side to it is the beggars, they are all over the place, this is so shameful as they will ruin the good time you're trying to have, they hassle you and never leave you alone, most of them are just lying, a kid told me he was very hungry and just wanted the money to buy something to eat and when I got him the food, he ate a little bit and threw the rest, so be careful not all of them are as poor as they look.

Beware the taxi fares charging TL50 to get OUT of the area!!!. Beware coming from Taxsim/Beyoglu to SH will cost TL20 but God help you to get out of the tourist trap!!Hilarious meeting point just outside Aya Sophia mosque for the tourist guides. All in good fun touting for business! Shopping excellent in the neighbourhood and eateries galore. The whole area is a shopping bazaar for all tastes. Everyone of course speaks English. French rarely spoken but German is common.All the dealers are very friendly and I did not find them pushy! Cay offered often! Busy during the day but I as advised not to stay in the area at night but to head for Taxsim/Pera district where there is nightlife.
History Abounds. The area contains almost all the major historic sights. They are all within an easy walk of each other and all the staff are very knowledgable and approachable. Excellent.

Very charming and lively area. I stayed at Sultanahmet District Area both times I visited Istanbul. I must say that I will love to go there again whenever I get a chance. This place is home to many tourist attractions like Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi palace. The Grand Bazaar is also very near and accessible by foot. This is a totally hang out and chilled out place with shops, restaurants, traditional turkish humams, you can never stop asking.....A must visit in Istanbul.
Nice place to spend some time. A lot of tourists are around in Sultanahmet but the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are worth to visit and also the Cisterna Basilica.
must see. One of the areas that you just can't miss. Lots of history and beautiful buildings. Topkapi Palace is one of my favourite buildings in Sultanahmet.

Take care on uneven streets. Great shopping, fantastic experiences in the old part of the city. So much history . The bath houses are everywhere with one I saw claiming to be 200!years old. Be prepared to bargain as the advertised prices vary from store to store. One word of caution, watch you personal possessions closely as there are some dishonest people around. Don't waste your time in rug shops if you don't intend to buy , you may find you end up buying just to get out of some of these stores.
great but more outside too!. Nice area to walk round but some much more interesting pockets of isntabul can be found outside this very touristy area.
Great area to stay in. Lots to see and where to eat.. Close to all the attractions. Easy walk to the Blue Mosque and Hagie Sophia and the Grand Baza. The tram runs through this area.
Central. Close to all the visiting spots, cafes, busy shops& transport.Lots of small narrow streets to wonder around, the ferry to Canukkale is close...

Best place of Istanbul. All the major sightseeings are there. You can stroll at any time and feel the old atmosphere. Recommended for hotels. Few cars, less noise. You have the feeling of being in a smaller city
Tourist Area. A great area despite being very touristy, shops, cafes, restaurants and many historical buildings, this is a great area for strolling...

wander the side streets. The streets here, often small and crowded, are always busy and full of life. Check out some of the smaller side streets to get a sense of how the neighborhood functions. Stop for a coffee or tea, plus some excellent sweets, at Ulusoy, a long-time, family run pastry shop on Bakkal Sk, just off of the main stretch of fish restaurants in Kumkapi. We made it a daily stop. Sitting outside we watched the neighborhood operate. From there we planned the day - most of the major sites are within easy (and interesting!) walking distance. Convenient yet not over-run with other tourists. Spend a lot of time wandering the area, even though we were told to be especially careful at night. We were also told that there is a large police presence (not uniformed!) to keep things safe. We never felt insecure here.
Buzzing like a bee !. Lots of people, so many different cultures.Find a spot to sit and just people watch. Excellent restaurants, loads of shopping, beautiful people.

Great place. Was a great place to wonder around and see historical places.The shopping in the area particularly the Grand Bazaar and Spice market were very interesting. We were there when all the tulips were out and they were spectacular.
great atmosphere & food. clean, friendly & fascinating. Great restaurants and general vibe of the area. Easy to get to. Parks & gardens in great condition and great general atmosphere.
Walking through another world. get a map and then ask for directions! Not easy to do on your own. Even after several visits. Very hilly so plan out your path from the sites to the bazaar.

Amazing experience.. Read some reports about scams and 'tourist' type restaurants and rip off prices. NOT my experience. Great place buzzing with people. Plenty of eating places and we tried a different one every night and like anywhere some were better than others however the food was always good, service excellent and friendly and without exception all were excellent value for money. You can eat a hearty, good quality meal with beer and including a tip for £20. Try doing that in the UK!Yes you do get traders and restaurant owners trying to get you into their establishments but that is the same world over. Even the pushy ones are friendly and if you have a smile on your face they are happy to share a laugh and a joke.The history of the place is all around you and it is truly a place to be experienced.There is begging and seeing children without shoes is upsetting but beware they are controlled by gang masters who collect the money the beg. There are also a lot of people claiming to be from Syria but when we offered to buy a woman and her child food she refused and just wanted money.Don't let this put you off visiting Sultanahmet is one of the truly great experiences.

Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet is really a centre place for the tourists as most of the historic buildings and museum are loacted on this square. Most of budget hotels are here. Transport facilities are fastly available.Great Bazar and Spicy Bazar are there.
So many things to do. Place is wide and you will have so many options to do. Must visit during evenings and night times and great restaurants for food and wine or a quiet romantic candlelit dinner

Enjoyable walking experience. We walked throughout Sultanahmet, and felt safe and secure all the time. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and Topkapi Palace were interesting places to study history. The Grand Bazaar was a great place to study the art of polite salesmanship. Walking the streets afforded the opportunity to see the mixture of old and new cultures in Turkey today.
The history is amazing!. We stayed within the District and were able to walk to all of the attractions. There is so much to see and plenty of shopping and good restaurants.

Fantastic Place. It is amazing to see so many historical places in the same area!
It can be disturbing to stand in the line especially when it is too hot!

Bit touristic but always fascinating. As any other attractive block with a condensate of art and culture in the world, it also attracts bad taste stuff salesmen and beach style and low profile tourers but it's still so magic and beautiful that makes you forget certain fauna. Get lost in it.

Spoilt for Choice. An amazing selection of historical sites all so close together. The Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque lead the way, but there is the Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome, the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art and the Grand Bazaar all fascinating places to visit. Our hotel was placed here and it was brilliant to see all these places on our doorstep.

Great place to base yourself. We are staying in this district a place full of small hotels designed to cover the tourist market. A plus is that it's walking distance to the big ticket buildings.Small back streets that in large part have been blocked to car access, with a tram providing transport up the hill.We had dinner in a back lane with numerous restaurants service good food, it was hard to choose a venue, spoilt by choice.I love Turkish delight and there is no shortage of places to get my fix, as it were.Lovely park behind the Sultans residence, especially on a hot afternoon.Lively area with good services.

History and culture abound. Study up on your Byzantium and Ottoman history, or just wander through the sites of Sultanahmet. The Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, and Hagia Sophia are not to be missed. Be prepared to say no to the many shops and restaurants trying to shepherd you into their stores.
Salon Kadir Cankurtaran Meydani #10/A Sultanahmet, Istanbul. Theis unisex salon was recommended by our hotel. The owners were very helpful, spoke English and gave my husband & myself a great cut.
Convinient place. This place is very convinient. It has the st sofiey church and blue mosque. Also it has lots of places to eat and to shop
Sultanahmet, Amazing Historical Centre. I love Sutanahmet and have visited many times. I love the way it is preserved so well. Highly recommended to visit.

Lots to see!. Lots of historic sites to visit in this area, including the Blue Mosque, Agia Sophia, tombs of the Sultans, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar and Basillica Cistern.. If visiting Topkapi go early so that you don't miss the Treasury as later the queues are horrendous! Our guide spent so long telling us about the history before we went in, rather than as we went round, that we didn't have time for the Treasury.

We keep on returning. Our five trips so far to Istanbul, somhow keep us returning to Sultanahmet's old town. We say we will try the modern or the Asian side for our stay, yet somehow we keep on returning here. It has a character and charm of its own, especially if one has a penchant for history and archaeology. Sultanahmet is always busy and bustLing, sometimes overcrowded, but that is also part of its attraction. Next time I am in Istanbul I,shall probably return to stay here.

Atmospheric, lively and happening place. Major attractions close by and within walking distance. The place comes alive in the evening and night. We visited during Ramadan time and it was vibrant and magical. Strongly recommend staying in the Sultanahmet area and enjoying the ambience.

Good shopping area.. The Sultanahmet District is a great area for shopping. Prices can be negotiated at most stores. Lost of various good available at teasonable prices. The dried fruit and apple turkish teas are really delicious.

So much to see and do and so much to learn.... We only had a few days in Sultanahmet so we did a day tour with Istanbul Private Guided Tours and it was amazing. Would definitely recommend the extra cash for a private guide as the experience is much better and far more informative. We stayed at Hotel Arcadia Blue in Sultanahmet and were close to everything. If you are female, remember your scarf so you can visit the mosques and the tombs. Be ready to be charmed off your feet by the locals. Just wonderful.
Beautiful mosque, but no comparison with Blue mosque. It is a beautiful mosque, but no comparison with blue mosque, which is across from it. Make sure you visit blue mosque too.
Blue Mosque. It was a very impressive building whit's silk carpets, tiles and crystal lamps-- it's the only mosque with 6 minarets.
Historical. The historical part of Istanbul, where almost all the touristic attractions are located. Restaurants are too touristic.
Interesting. This an interesting area but clogged with tourists trying to enter the Blue Mosque and other places of interest. Go early to avoid the crowd but it is definitely a must see area.
Fantastic. What a great area...so much to do.....near excellent shopping and places to eat....plus a great cooking school.....a must do

Best place to buy Turkish delights in Istanbul. Every time I come to Istanbul I have to stop at this place  products are always fresh located in the spice bazaar if anybody planning to visit Istanbul I
Great Experience. Long Lines perhaps it was the weekend , better avoid Fridays , Saturdays and Sundays , nevertheless a lot to see and enjoy around the area

The Largest Mosque in Town for Suleyman the First - the Magnificent.. And only 8 years to build - you have to be kidding! Only survived 2 fires and the 1766 earth quake. The usual 'largish' carpet inside and the 3 ringed 'chandelier.' Supported by the huge porphyry monoliths. The usual beautiful stonework and the superb designs and patterns - with 4 minarets.Out back are the tombs of the sultan and his very 'pushy' and power hungry first wife Roxelana, and their daughter. Brian, from Perth. W.Australia.

Felt like I was home. This district is a must see in Istanbul. I am from Iran and there are many things similar to our culture and history in Istanbul and when I visited sultanahmet district, I felt like home , even most shopkeepers were trying to speak Persian to us and it made me feel so good. It was a great district that I forgot how much time I walked around and I was really tired at night.

nice area. Our hotel was in the middle of Sulthanahmet. The area is great: east meats west everywhere. Relaxed atmosphere with lots of bars and restaurants. Contains the historic highlights of the city.

Energetic, Rejuvenatic, therapeutic and undoutedly the place to stay for tourists. No visit to Istanbul can be complete without exploring the Sultanahmet District. It truly is the heart of Istanbul. Buzzing with tourists visiting Topkapi Palace, Hagaysofia, Blue Mosque during the day and filled with energy around restaurants and marketplace in the evening, this place never sleeps. This place simply defines Istanbul - history going hand in hand with contemporary life style - it offers them all.Just loved our stay at this place. Surely a no-miss while visiting Istanbul
Very 'local' location. Great location for all the sights, easy walking to Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, plenty of eating and drinking establishments, looked a very typical suburb
The only place to stay. I will definitely return to Istanbul and the only area I'd stay in is Sultanhamet, it is close to everything.
Süleymaniye Mosque. I guess Best mosque in istanbul.My last university is same area with there.You can visit to Sultan Süleyman and his family, mosque is great. Finally bosphorus viev is very nice.

A great city Break. We stayed in the Sultanahmet region for a long weekend! A great area for all the main sightseeing venues! Be prepared for a lot of walking on uneven & hilly ground! You need to get up early to avoid the crowds( or visit late in the day) Use Public transport it's cheap & very efficient, we loved the tram! Instead of a " Cruise" we went on the Ferry for a trip on the Bosphorus, a return trip,spending a couple of hours on the Asian side at Anadolu Kavagi, with time for lunch! If you decide to visit Taksim Square walk down into the town, it really worth a stroll, less "touristy" than Sultanahmet!You will get a lot of hassle from local traders, the worst of which are the carpet sellers! Go prepared & have banter with them! The sights & sounds are great, an ideal city break.

The heart of Istanbul's beauty. The Sultanahmet District is where ones will find the beauty of Istanbul. It has a lot of historical sites such as the Hagia Sophia church and the Blue Mosque. The square is historical and absolutely beautiful to see both days and nights. Everything is in walking distance there, including the markets.Definitely, when visiting Istanbul one must visit this area.
Charming, busy, lovely. Loved the old charm, was too busy on certain days popular with tourists (weekends), central location

LOVE THAT PLACE. Centre of attractions in Istanbul and the place to be, attractions,
shopping, local restaurants and much more in this lovely historic area.
Magical. Lots of shops to browse love the Arasta Bazzar no pressure lots of restaurants and coffee shops no time to get fed up

Busy but always entertaining. This neighbourhood is the hub of the tourist attractions in Istanbul. We didn't sleep in this area, but it was lovely to go into, explore the sights and see the attractions. Go to the major sights (eg Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and Blue Mosque) in the early morning at open (9am for most), and then see a secondary sight in the afternoon or explore the culture.

Best area of Istanbul. This is where all of the main attractions of Istanbul are. You must stay at a hotel in this area and then you can walk around to all the attractions. Traffic in Istanbul is a nightmare and its better to travel on foot, so stay in Sultanahmet and walk to you attractions. The hotels are at least one star off, maybe two stars off from US standards. Also, some of the hotels are not official, the official ones have the star rating posted at the front door on a gold plaque.

The area to stay when in Istanbul . Th best thing about staying in this district is that everything you'd want to see is within walking distance. And for a few attractions you can easily take the tram. We had a great time and left feeling that there was more to see but the week was over.

The place to stay. everything is within walking distance. What you want to see, what is worth seeing is there. From the Grand Bazaar to the Blue Mosque. The area of Tacsim square is not anything like as interesting as Sultanahmet. The Istanbul you dreamed of is here!

A beautiful Ancient Part of Istanbul. The area is a beautiful area filled with historical monuments and places. The Haia Sofia Church and the Sultanahmet Mosque constitute two historical moments that are face to face and that give a glimpse of the historical background of Istanbul/constantinople. There are a lot of places where you can find traditional turkish food, as well as souvenir shops. The Grand Bazard is a place where you can shop for thousand of things

Sultanahmet is the heart of Istanbul. I highly recommend staying in Sultanahmet when visiting Istanbul. It is the older and more historic part of the city, with many sights to see. Don't miss the Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, and Bosphorus Cruise.

Eat drink and soak up the atmosphere. Every street ripples with history. This is where istanbul began! All the major sights are here and all within comfortable walking distance of each other. And if it's restaurants you need. They are here in abundance. Bon appetite!
adore heritage tour. Brilliant only had one day so only got overview. Not really suitable for anyone who cannot walk far would probably be very hot in high summer the bazaar was exciting

Historic and more. This whole area is worth a walk around and all the sights are fantastic. Go early to avoid the queues which make it harder to enjoy the historic delights thatvare around every corner.

Excellent area capturing the character of Turkey.. This area offers convenience to the tourist who is interested in seeing the most historically important sites in Turkey. e.g. The Blue Mosque, Ayia Sofia, Kopkapi Palace etc. an area full of character and convenience.

Continuos Restauration. I liked very much that they are improving the maintenance of monuments.
Do not like the lines to get into the monuments

Proximity, Heritage, Culinary Delights. This district has it all, fantastic hotels, great restaurants, amazing sites, and delightful desert shops. Beware of the scam artists!! Be they fake shoe shine guys or fake guides!!!
Best area to stay for weekend break.. Most main attractions within walking distance. Plenty of restaurants and bars for evening. The big bus starts at Sultanahmet.

Overload. You need to go for the experience but after a bit, it's too much.There are hundreds of shops and it seems like thousands of men (yes, all men) trying to sell one something. You'll not want to hear the words "excuse me" again for a long time.There are sections more heavily devoted to certain goods and it seemed prices were a bit higher as soon as you walk in.It's a pretty unbelievable place, it's just how much shopping you want to endure.We were told if you get 30% off asking price it was pretty good- we did but still found things less expensive in other places so kinda know what something is worth or at least be happy with what you pay and don't beat yourself up later if you see it less expensive.

Best place to stay. If you are a tourist in Istanbul, do yourself a favour... stay in Sultanahmet. Most hotels here are walking distance from every key monument in Istanbul and if it is not, you can always board a tram from near Ayasofia tram station. Great places to eat. I could find umpteen options across price ranges from budget to fine dine for even vegetarian food. This area is also the best for exchanging your money to Turkish Lira. You get the best rates here! In all, Sultanahmet IS the place to stay!
lovely architecture and tulips. really enjoyed strolling in the area, though it was crowded.the blooming tulips were very lovely. the blue mosque and hagia sophia are worth visiting

Truly exotic. We found it easy to navigate our way around this area. It's an amazing and intriguing place with it's profusion of narrow laneways, exquisite mosques, fascinating shops and beautiful cafes. There is just so much to see and do and it's all manageable. We stayed in this area and never needed a taxi. We saw everything on foot, just took a tram down to the Spice Markets.The parks are so beautiful. Gulhane Pak must be one of the world's loveliest. We were here in April when the tulips bloom...an absolute riot of colour everywhere. Should be on every traveller's bucket list.
loved it. so much history and wonderment! a must see.... everything is within walking distance....food is everywhere and inexpensive and most of all...good
Sutlan Ahmet. Nice place to stay, nearby everything you need, mosques, museums, shopping and restaurants, different levels of prices available , quality is there..

This is the place to stay. Staying at one of the small hotels in the Sultanahmet District puts you in the middle of everything, so makes it easy to get the most out of your visit. For a first time visitor, staying here really makes sense. If flowers are your thing, consider coming in Mid April - early may for the tulip festival. Just an amazing display of flowers. See the world's largest tulip carpet in Sultanahmet Park. Enjoy Guilhane park with the best tulip displays I have ever seen (sorry, Holland, but it's true). Of course, once you have hit the highlights, there is so much else to see and do here.

Most historical sights within a small area. Very crowded, but geared up for tourists. Take a tour you will learn so much more. Beware the umpteen scam artists and pedlars, you either find this constant pestering charming or just plain annoying. There are folks trying to stop them, but our tour started early so they had us to themselves for a good hour before the Hippodrome was cleared. You can easily walk between the main attractions here.

The place to Stay for tourism. Agya Sofia, Cistern Basílica, Blus Mosque, Tokapi Palace, restaurants.... All in 5 minutes to visit the historic places of the City. This Is the old Istambul. I Like It must than other modern areas of the city, if you travel for tourism because it's so near. But be sure to Book a Good hotel, because so many houses that have rooms Like a hotel, but they are not a hotel. Anyway you have a low budget, so many nice a really hoteles. Just search for pictures of all areas of hotel and not only the room.

Important historic sites but LONG lines. This is the area we all go to Istanbul to see and experience. The problem is that everyone else goes too! The lines to buy tickets could be 2-3 hours long. We missed seeing two of our desired sites because the lines were so long and we couldn't fit in two sites or more per day. GET IN LINE BEFORE the site opens and your wait will be only about 30-45 minutes. Any later and take lunch to eat while you wait. The area is full of shops and restaurants but beware of the overly aggressive sales people who try to lure you and even pull you into their shops or restaurants. To be honest this aggressiveness almost destroyed our visit. It was a valuable experience but not one I would repeat or recommend to timid travelers. Don't miss the chocolate baklava!

Great area to indulge in a little trip down ottoman history lane. The architecture alone makes this one of the most unique places to visit. Coupled with the bosphorous views from the seaside restaurants and the great food (albeit expensive) outlets nearby make this one of the best places to visit. Also for first time tourists lots of easy guidance brochures and directives everywhere. so no worries about getting lost

Wonderful old area of Istanbul. This whole area of Istanbul is steeped in history. It easy to get around as everything is so close together. All you need is a good map. Can't get list. It's a Great area to stay in.

STEPPING BACK IN TIME. We stayed in a small boutique hotel right around the corner from Sultanahmet Square and were able to walk and soak in all the history and culture of this area. We loved it in the morning, at noon, and especially at night when the Blue Mosque and Haga Sophia were lit up and the crowds were walking the square with vendors selling their wares. There are some great restaurants off the beaten path to explore with terrific fare.

All The Must-Sees in Ietanbul are Here. This is truly the city center, where Hagia Sophia, The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Place, The Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome and Aya Sofya Hamami are located within a few steps from each other. There are many restaurants, cafes everywhere. The Grand Bazaar and Arasta Bazaar are also here.

Travel with a group. I went alone but now wish i had traveled with a group. This is the main area for tourist attractions and has a nice park but as i was on my own i was constantly harassed by men insisting that i go to their shop and when i eventually got rid of one another appeared. They don't pester groups for obvious reasons.On the first evening i tried to sit in the park by the fountain and relax but again they appeared and i had to give up and go back to my hotel.

Rich historical area.. Like the blue mosque, Topkapi palace and all the historical area there.
dislike the long ques in some area.

Always a top place to stay. There is no doubt that Sultanahmet is one of the world's top districts and the best way to enjoy it without being overcome by tourist numbers, is to stay here. Favourite hotels for our visits are Blue House Hotel and Empress Zoe, which never fail to impress.

Historical, great place to visit but so over run by tourists. As the title says. And I believe my trip was probably at the start of the busy season. Can't imagine how it'll be when the season gets into full swing.
Packed with history . Great place to visit anytime of year. Amazing food, great atmosphere and friendly and helpful people everywhere. At night the city is especially beautiful.

The place to stay when in Istanbul. We booked an hotel in this district for our vacation in Turkey and enjoyed every moment. The area around our hotel is nice, friendly, shops stay open till midnight and when you stroll around you do get a sense of safety. Everybody was nice, even though walking past the restaurants in the evening may be a struggle as they try to entice you in. If you stay in this area, you are within walking distance of all main attractions, which means you can easily get there when they open in the morning and beat the crowd.

Sultanahmet, the beating heart of Istanbul.. The title says it all. This was our 2nd visit to this vibrant friendly city of Istanbul and specifically the 'Sultanahmet district' as we previously stayed in 'Taxsim' in the 'Beyoglu distict' on our last trip. The tram is ideal and cheap way of travel, if staying outside the district and has stops near the Blue Mosque. Have a good map and walking shoes as Sultanahmet has excellent Turkish Restaurants/eateries, accommodation and there is always a McDonalds for coffee and toilets if stuck, but do your research. What to see, well just look around as the standouts are the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia Museum, Topkapi Palace and Basilica Cistern. When walking to the Blue Mosque view the Egyptian Obelisk when walking through the flat Hippodrome, outside the north western entrance to the Blue Mosque. Outside there is always someone just waiting to take advantage of the unwary tourist, should they want a taxi, turkish carpet or a guide and I suppose it is part of the experience, but be courteous and continue walking. Just on the north western edge of the district is the Grand Bazaar (have a map and know your entrance No.) and Spice Bazaar Just enjoy the experience and venture down streets, though it will not suit everyone. Take your camera, especially when visiting in April for the stunning tulips gardens on display.

Istanbul's heart. While in Istanbul we stayed in the centre of the Sultanahmet district. So whenever we left our hotel we were within walking distance of just about everything. Definitely the area to stay in.
So many attractions. Beautiful, walkable area, with all sort of beautiful old Byzantine and Ottoman buildings. So much history.

Vibrant must see part of Istanbul. A vibrant area which is a joy to walk round if you have a good pair of walking shoes. Bustling with people - plenty of shops and restaurants and hotels in the area - a must do is the Grand Bazaar. Be prepared to be hassled by vendors though.Also within easy walking distance of most of the great sights including Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque. Our hotel was near here so no need for public transport.

an assault on every sense!. an amazing and fascinating area to wander around, with lots of attractions in close proximity. Expect busy bustling activity everywhere, which is Istanbul's charm. Wonderful shops selling everything from carpets, tablecloths and pashminas to spices, nuts, pastries and apple tea! just dive in and experience the noise, bustle and excitement of this vibrant city...

A must. A great place to taste the flavor of the city, full of shops, restaurants, mosques, noise, smells, colors and where you see people from around the globe. Always lively, a place to go without haste and with an open spirit.

Old and new intertwine with actual generation. The Sultanamet District is full of music and colors of every nationality that feels the same attraction and love I feel for this exotic place. Every time I come I feel like I could never get tired of seeing it, or I discover things and beauty I have never seen before.

A great central place for all the tourist spots. Sultanahmet was a great place to base ourselves to explore Istanbul. It is a vibrant bustling area with no shortage of shops and restaurants. If you stay centrally all the major tourist attractions are within 10 minutes walk. It is very touristy but still retains the atmosphere of an old city. The retailers are very skilled at picking where you come from and engaging in conversation to hopefully lure you into buying their wares. But they are very friendly people

All You Need is a Good Pair of Shoes. An amazing place bristling with history. Hired a personal guide for the day, very reasonable price, who spoke good english.
