His insight into all the historical attractions made the day very informative. If your hotel is in the district there is no need for any transport except for a good pair of shoes.
See everything quickly. Stay in easy walking distance and see most of the great sights in a ten minute radius. Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque, Agia Sophia etc.

Istanbul's heart beats loudly. A vibrant and eclectic area of Istanbul, that seamlessly blends old town charm and architecture with the modern day tourist and resident. Simply walking down the street never fails to bring a smile to my face, from the relentless carpet sellers, with their unique way of attracting attention, to the beautiful tulips of spring, fresh pomegranate juice and amazing pastries and sweet treats.

The key sites of Istanbul in one convenient location. The city is gridlocked most of the time so thankful the major tourist sights are all very close to one another. But the area is very very busy with tourists. So expect to queue for all the major attraction but the sights when you eventually get into them are worth the wait.

The heart of Istanbul. Great spot to wonder around. You'll find something incredible around every corner! I recommend taking the tram into the Sultanahmet District, then going to all the highlights by foot!

A must visit place. Such a lovely area with amazing historic landmarks and a wide variety of things to do such as shopping within the Grand Bazaar. The restaurants around the area serve traditional Turkish cuisine at a reasonable price. Must do's within this area in my opinion are the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar and Basilica Cistern. The only annoyance is walking within certain area's and getting hassled by the locals to eat in their restaurant, buy their carpets or leather jackets etc... Some of the restaurants are so competitive they do anything to get you into their place such as offer you 20% discount, free desserts, free bottle of wine, etc... Make sure you check the change they give you, we was under-changed twice in four evenings there. Overall, a must-do thing if you visit Istanbul.
Explore history at Sultanahmet. Lots of history and great cultural and historic heritage. You need at least half a day to see everything.

Most peaceful place on earth.... Everything is within reach. Historical places, Museums, Sourvenirs, Shopping, Hotels and Eateries are located in the beautiful land of Sultanahmet. A place that could give you peace for your heart and soul..

Beautiful. Don't miss the historic bath houses- not the sleazy tourist mixed ones.
The real deal is so worth it

Merhaba Istanbul. If I visited Turkey again then I would definitely stay at Sultanahmet District and not at Taksim. I found that the main tourist attractions are situated here: One can easily access The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and The Bazaars and Market places. Turkey is full of tourists and there are constantly people trying to sell you things. One has to learn to be firm to say NO. I found that it was much better to walk from the Egyptian spice bazaar through the back routes which leads to the main attractions. If visiting the attractions in the Sultanahmet region then best go early as the crowds turn into hoards and hoards of people. Most tourist attractions close at 4pm so get there early or you will miss out. My personal favourite is Topkapi Palace which needs a whole day to visit and don't miss The Harem section. Also The Basillica is not to be missed. All these places are within walking distance of each other. There are also alot of exciting restaurants and an exclusive Turkish Hamam which must be experienced. If travelling out of Sultanahmet to Taksim then the cheapest way is the tram and the funicular which only cost 4Lira per trip. One can also take the Big Bus which has two routes, via the Asian side and the other via the European side. The Turkish Delight and Baklava is like nothing you have ever tasted.

It can be a little hard to review a district. The Sultanahmet District effectively encapsulates the main reasons anyone goes to Istanbul as a destination. It holds the big ones - Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi Palace and the Basilica Cistern all in an area around the Hippodrome which has several attractions either in it or adjacent to it.As such you'll be spending a fair bit of time here and my best advice is to get yourself a cheap, clean hotel in this area. Don't fret over the amenities of your hotel, you'll only be there for sleeping anyway. The area has a mountain of places you can eat, tourist tat on sale and alas annoying - and sometimes aggressive - carpet touts. The latter can be a real nuisance.Those issues aside the area is well kept, patrolled by tourist police and is quite civilised. Some of the winding narrow streets are a pain as you can easily get disorientated in them but it's not that big an area and you'll get your bearings quickly enough.There is actually little point in recommending this area of Istanbul. Quite simply if you don't go here you didn't go to Istanbul.

Be Ready to Pay $$$!!!. You don't have too many options in Istanbul. You either have to stay in the European side also known as Taksim or the Muslim side, Sultanahmet if you want to be close to the action. Sultanahmet is beautiful, easy to get around, on a hill so a good work out! Lots of cute smaller hotels to choose from but it is sooooo expensive! Also in general cab drivers in Istanbul are scam artists. EVERYONE knows this. They pretent like they don't know the address and drive around and then charge you an unfair price. Also they charge depending on traffic. I paid 15 turkish $ to come back to Sultanahmet from Taksim at night and 50 turkish money to go to Taksim when there was traffic. So, it pays off to stay somewhere that you can walk to everything. If you can't travel to other countries like Americans, I can understand why you would go to Istanbul, no visa needed. But if you are an American and you can go anywhere in the world, don't go to Istanbul. It's a total tourist town. I guess I just don't really like places that have lost all of their authenticity because the people there have to rely of tourist money to make a living.

Perfect landscape!. I visit Istanbul once in a year, and this was my ninth visit. You need to go here, if you are in Ist. Wonderful mosque, park, water, a lot of people are walking, enjoying, sitting, taking photos. Wonderful atmosphere. Then go to the Gulhane Park which is amazing and very close. You will have a perfect afternoon or even better, night. Lights are amazing! Very accessible, tram station named Sultanahmet. Dont miss!
So much!. So much to see and do in Sultanahmet! The mosques, the palace, the markets and bazaar. Spice market etc etc etc. I reckon stay here as everything will be walking distance for you.
The centre of the old city. Great architecture, shops, history, restaurants, winding streets, mix of the east & west, blend of cultures and clean.

See Istanbul before it is flooded with people. This was my sixth visit, and I could not help but notice the gentrification of Akbiyik and the crowds early on a cool April morning in the Hippodrome. I love the sights, smells, food, sounds and the friendly and well-cared-for neighborhood cats.

Food and tourist shops great plus attractions. this is a great district but just be aware that you don't get targeted as a tourist and ripped off. Many items don't have prices attached- price for tourists and price for locals .Don't trust the taxis- get a price before you take off and many taxis are illegal.It's great to walk around this district although the cobble stones can be a little uneven

The old district. Our hotel was in this district and we had an easy walk to the sites. Actually, I'll say a short walk. Istanbul has lots of hills and you are often walking up or down. The hill by our hotel was a challenge to this old lady from the prairies. But the area feels safe. Lots of tourists and cats. It is also amazing to see a building totally burned out on an active regular street. Parking is a nightmare! DO NOT THINK OF PARKING A RENTAL CAR HERE! Good luck!

touristic heart of Istanbul. This touristic center is very nice with beautiful gardens en flowers everywhere surrounded by the great mosque and minaret skyline but the downside is that this place is so packed with tourists that it get's overwhelming.

Splendid!. Turkey, this city is splendid, Sultanahmed area is a very nice place to visit and stay. Easy to find local food, shopping and many places to seeI really like Turkey especially during the winter, Very Very nice ...

So much to see. The district has most of the historic relics and sights including mosques, palaces and markets. You can walk between sights or choose to hop on the tram or red bus. Worth spending the day in this area.
Nice place . We stayed in hotel lausos at sultanahmet . This area is very nice to stay and eat and full of famous and historical sight seeing .we just loved our stay

History and crowds. Everywhere you look, there's something captivating to see. Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque. If you like haggling you can get some bargains at the Egyptian Bazaar and the Grand Bazaar.

One exciting city!. Istanbul, particularly the old city and the newer city for the night life, has quickly become one of my most favourite cities! The people are wonderful, the food is delicious and the tea is amazing. It is simply organised, chaotic brilliance. It wont disappoint.

Excellent tourist district. This district is where you find main attractions in Istanbul. Many small hotels in this area, and the surrounding district like Fatih. There are so many restaurants you can choose. If you are into cheaper price food, good walk further from this area. If you stay in or around this area, basically main attractions are just walking distance, and you can easily walk a bit further to Eminönü for ferry, or even walk to Galata/Beyoglu.

lovely old city. clean, historic yet modern, hilly, reasonable food prices, easy to find places with clear directions, wear comfy sneakers because of cobblestones, be careful when walking on the street since some drivers are not too careful and streets are narrow
Location location location. In the midst of such incredible antiquity. you can get small hotels that don't cost the earth while you are exploring.

Touristy but Loveable!. Beautiful district for toured sightseeing or a casual walk around with dinner in a cafe and beautiful sights. Enjoyed the Turkish Ice Cream Experience - and yes its an experience.
Loved it - could easily spend a lazy walkaround day there!

Tourism central. With many of the famous sites of Istanbul in this area, such as the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar and Hagia Sophia, the place is full of tourists and the local prices reflect this. Having said that the Turkish people are friendly, genuine and very helpful.

Nice area..... ...but the locals are a big pushy trying to get you to buy from them or go into their stores. It was a little uncomfortable for me because you can't walk 15 feet without being harassed.

~History.. History, scents, views, people ...
Amazing place to be. Expect a little of everything.
Just go and take a walk.
Colosal district. Very known historical place with one of the most beautiful mosque in the world - Sultan Ahmet Mosque.. There is also Hagia Sofia opposite. Nothing disliked.

History of 600 years. likes sultanahamet Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi palace, and spice bazaar also good. emminono has fish place and Local people are tourist friendly, didnt like Bosphorous tour, because no hop on hop off.

Colorful Sultan Ahmet District. So much to see, so much to do. Beautiful architecture along the cobbled streets leading into the Sultan Ahmet district. In this district you will find, the Blue Mosque, TopKapi Palace, Basilica Cisterns, Hagia Sophia as well as an array of colourful and beautiful trader shops selling trinkets, lots of tea houses, turkish carpets, and divine turkish delight.There were mini vendor carts along the road as well selling fresh bagels, corn, pomergranate juice as a quick and easy snack on the go. Very safe enviroment filled with years of amazing history.

Great area to stay - many historic sites at walking distance!. If you are a tourist or for that matter a travel loving business traveller, you must stay in this area. Nice boutique hotels, nice eating places and walking distance to major historic sites and monuments are the hallmark of this area. Amazing tourist vibe. I loved this area.

Beautiful area. The place is very beautiful, since you can find most of Istanbul important monuments altogether. It is busy with many cheap restaurants and there are many hotels and souvenir shops. There are a lot of terraces you can climb to have a drink and see the mosques and the Topkapi palace, a totally recommendable experience.However, it is VERY crowded

Surround yourself in history. Good location as I was interested in historic landmarks, and good food. Plenty of interesting eating places, not enough time to try all that I wanted to. Easily accessible to the tram and The Big Bus Tour. Loved walking around the Blue Mosque area as the sun set. Fun to shop at Arasta Bazaar. Too many tourists make it difficult to get good clear pictures. But a fun place to be in.

Even if you don't Love Shopping.. This is a Must See. This is a must see place, even if you don't love shopping, take some time to enjoy the stores, you can learn so much from just watching the stores, must sell the same and how one differentiates from the other is very interesting. I had read that the people we very pushy, and yes compared to Western Standards this might be, but most people are very nice and all the ones I encountered were very respectful. Take some of the side streets and sit down in a cafe outside and just enjoy watching faces.
Pulsing neighborood. this is the heart of Istanbul and it changes shape and colour at every corner-try to get out of the beaten path and you will not rergret!

Sultanahmet District centre of attraction when in Istanbul. Great area to stay in or to travel through or even to visit. Many tourist attractions with something for everyone. Barter on prices and deals. Lots to do and see and relative safe area for foreigners. Keep money/wallets safe from pick pocketers and watch out for dishonest taxi drivers that will triple charge you if you do not know the rates/fares. Ask locals for advice- they are more than willing to help.
Too many tourists. This is a great place to visit early in the morning otherwise there are far too many tourists. You get to see the real locals working just a block away from the main tourist area.

Nice follow up to the Blue Mosque. If you are looking for a place to shop after visiting the Blue Mosque, this is the right place. There are quite a few nice shops that you would typically find in the Grand Bazaar, but it much more affordable rates. There are also a lot less people so you'll be able to take your time.

Beautiful & clean!. The whole area is clean and very tourist friendly. The locals are friendly and helpful when ask for direction. Yes, they do understand & speak the English language just enough to make you feel welcome to their town.
Unforgettable. There's nothing to dislike except the expensive currency exchanges. Just go a block down and you'll get a really good deal.

Sultanahmet Square at Night: FANTASTIC. My wife and I visited this square each night during our visit to Istanbul. While packed with tourists during the day, the evening has only a fraction of the daytime crowds. Although Ayasofya and most other major attractions are closed, these sites are illuminated with soft golden light. Families and lovers walk this beautiful square and visit a reasonable number of street vendors selling corn on the cob and roasted chestnuts. Benches are on hand to take a break on. The fountain in front of Ayasofya is illuminated with multicolored lights. STRONGLY RECOMMENDED!
NICE SPOT. Love about everything here and the restaurant :))) be carefull with most people who is so friendly and offer you everything, just say NO in polite way and they will stay back

As old city centres go, this has everything. If you want historic sites, a web of little streets , restaurants, a grand bazaar and more - look not further. I have previously stayed outside the old city district but this time we stayed within Sultanahmet, with the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, the Basilica cistern, the grand bazaar, the hippodrome and more all within an easy walk. fascinating.

Shear charm!. We originally had doubts as to whether this would be the best area for a week in Istanbul because of the boutique hotels and high tourist prices but we booked a mid range hotel in a lovely street and were so pleased to have done so. The area provides everything a traveler would require. I changed £100 on arrival in the Grand Bazaar where you get the best rates and on leaving at the airport changed what I had left 42€ so for a week in Istanbul we spent very little, breakfast at the hotel included in the price so lunch was a snack and we found super restaurants for 25 lire for two. Much much cheaper than we imagined and great fun. Super people and plenty to see and do.

Awe inspiring, safe and fun with the locals.. It is so much fun to walk around, see the sights, banter with the guys who want you to hire them for a tour, to buy a carpet or to go into a restaurant. Just smile and say maybe later if you are not interested. Some just want to talk to you to improve their English. See the major sites and be amazed because they are amazing.

awesome place!!. This is the best place to experience istanbul..all the major sites and attractions are in this area only...you can visit the blue mosque, cistern, Hagiasofia, Topkapi palace....and enjoy the various eateries like sultanahmet koftechi...Grand bazaar and sulenmaniya mosque are also closeby...completely loved the place at night when these attractions lit up....beware of pick pockets and avoid taxis...the taxi drivers fleece tourists and are scary...! take the trams instead!
Way too touristy.. Go if you want to follow the crowds. Too many vendors hawking maps. But very close to the metrobus line.

Awe Inspiring. Spent 3 days touring this historic area of Istanbul. Did not know where to look/visit next. Even if you are not religious, just the sheer beauty, design and workmanship makes you feel humble. A buzzing area filled with history, tourists from all over the world and attractions that Disney can never match make this a place to visit before you die

Touristy but a lovely place to visit. This is a very touristy area but still a lovely area to visit. It's easy to get around for visitors, arriving by tram or walking, has clean toilets (right near the tram stop), affordable snacks (eg bagel and cream cheese from a street vender for 2 TL), great attractions (like the carpet of tulips outside the Hagia Sophia) and lots of shops selling everything you could want to buy (although prices and quality are not necessarily as good as elsewhere, particularly at the shops right next to the tram stop). Touts can be quite annoying, but will leave you alone if you are polite but firm that you aren't interested.

Great Food. This area is close to all attractions but the benefit is the number of excellent food outlets. Expect to pay 60-70TL for lunch and a bit more for dinner. Alcohol is fairly expensive, beer is reasonable.

Bustling centrepiece of the city.. From our hotel we had a 150 meter walk to the square between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia,truly one of the great spaces of the world…full of life and activity, flowers,fountains,food stalls and trees.Going the other way from our hotel Sultanahmet offers small streets full of shops and restaurants which are slightly quieter and where you can wander at leisure looking for bargains.Gulhane park,The Topkapi,and the Hippodrome all rub shoulders with the area as well.

Beautiful. you can easily reach this by tramway. and all big attractions are in walking distance. it is a bit busy and maybe it is good to check with your hotel when the Blue mosque is open as it has opening hours.

Cobbled streets seeped in history and beauty. Loved walking around the Sultanhmet area. All the main attractions are closely packed and walkable. We were there in April and the blast of Tulips all around was plain fabulous.

A wonderful place to stroll around.. Sultanahmet is the historic heart of Istanbul. There are so many things to see and experience it would take a book to cover them. Get a map or just follow your instincts and you will see many wonders. Just walking around the Hippodrome and looking at the columns is special in its self. Lots of tourists but also many local people make people watching fun. A little bit off from the main run is the Arasta Bazaar, well worth a visit with many little quirky shops (no alcohol though).Take the time to walk around Sultanahemt and you will be well rewarded.

Best place to stay. Sultanhamet is definitely the place to stay when you are visiting Istanbul. Some of the hotel areas are quiet and it is walking distance to the major tourist attractions. Getting here from the airport takes about 40 minutes depending on the traffic.
Nice neigbourhood. Lot's of shops in the large shoppingstreet across Taksim Square. Also a lot of lovely bars on the right side of the shopping street.

worth visiting. I chose to stay there for my brief 2 day visit. it is absolutely beautiful. all important landmarks are within a walking distance and the narrow paved streets are really sweet. it is full of restaurants (most of them touristic) but it is a fun place to stay

Integral part of Istanbul. This is a great area. There are a lot of restaurants, either for a snack or meal. A great square, when I was there the tulips and daffodils were blooming, and the attractions are close by, The Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, etc. There is also a tram station.
best area to live..... I was staying in sultanahment best area to stay all historical places on walking distance all bus tour starts from there....ttram service also easily available

The best area. Wow - all the main sights within a few hundred yards. There were a lot of tourists and large groups around but queues went quickly. Take time to chill out and people watch - it is worth it !!

Must visit!!. We were staying at Celal Sultan in Sultanahmet District. All historical mosques, museums, palaces, cemetery, delicious shawarma spots, Grand bazaar, night market, branded stores, tram, cafes, McDonalds, BurgerKing, all were at this district and we were always exploring and looking around during our 6-days at Istanbul.
Very vibrant area.. We stayed in this area& absolutely loved it. Virtually everything you need/ want to see is in this area. Local trams are a cheap & easy way of getting around.
Buzzing and so interesting. Trams, History, Wonderful shops, small back streets, clean, small area so no long walks. Fabulous cultural history of the area.Top tourist place.

It's ALL here. Sultanahamet has a number of interesting places to enjoy and more within a short tram ride away Travel is so cheap it is unreal to to western standards with trams you could set your watch to .EVERY 3 mins.holding almost 200 passengers ! Most of the SULTANAHMET ttractions are within walking distance ( ie) Blue mosque , Topkapi Palace, Hipodrome , Grand Bazaar,Cisterns,Hagia Sophia Mosque ( now a museum) S/A park plus the hipodrome nave recently been repaved making walking so much better.There is an abundance of great eating places everywhere.including the usual " Western " ones. If your budget is low EAT where the locals eat as the prices are reasonable.Evening entertainment is a bit sparse,but that may not be a bad thing ------as you may just need a REST !! (by the way I did not mention that the trams are massive , (About the size of two railway carriages ) ENJOY!

A world in one space. You can spend days and weeks in the Sultanahmet district and never really see it all. By really spending time here you can feel the history of Istanbul. Just beware of the overcrowding in peak times.

sultanahmet area. it is the historic center and you need more than a day to see all and visit all.but let start from the main points.aghia sofia.top kapi,blue mosque and royal kinsterna and so on.pay a visit to the market and be one with the locals..eat street food which is mostly safe and visit the cafes all aorund the area.

The best in istanbul. This is my seventh visit to istanbul and every time i have to come and enjoy sultanahmet area. The food, the turkish delights, the show the rush, cafes, restaurants, arcticture. I really enjoy it very much.

great areas. This area of Istanbul is packed with historical places and building, magnificent mosques, great restaurant's to suit different budgets, great views of the golden horn,parks and markets.There are hotels ,its easy to just walk around or take the tram,a great place to see all that this city has to offer.some of the major sights are Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topaki Palace Basilica cistern and the grand Bazaar to name a few.

Hotel niles. We loved our little hotel in sultanahmet and the whole area was fascinating. Lots of the famous tourist attractions were within walking distance and there are plenty of cheap clean trams available. The grand bazaar is here, several bath houses, various restaurants... Just be aware that you will hassled for your patronage. In the grand bazaar there is lots to see and buy ... Including very good hollister copies - some of them better than the originals!!!!!

heaps of sights. nice compact area with heaps of sights... great for a day trip to tick off some of istanbuls must see places.... good affordable restaurants can be found as well so its no issue if your on a budget...

Happy to Be Back. It had been 18 years since we had last been here and still it has such a wonderful feel to wander and explore. This time we were with our kids and they too loved it. The dogs and cats are an added bonus to pat and enjoy. The streets are clean. The sights are amazing. The spring bulbs are gorgeous. The feeling is safe. The hospitable nature of the Turkish is glorious.

Great central place for an Istanbul visit. It's all here - great sites to see, good shopping, the city life - enjoy! For best prices though, avoid the tourist shops on the streets and check the outside of the Spice Market, where many locals get their dried fruit, nuts, and halva.
Charming area. I would stay in this area again as it had everything we needed close by. Plenty of restaurants to choose from,. Close to most attractions so they are walkable.

Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace and many more. Just a few of the prime sights to see in this fabulously interesting district with an amazing diversity of historical, religious and cultural gems. Don't overlook the many smaller, less visited museums such as the history of carpets which we had all to ourselves!

The heart of old Istanbul. Wonderful buildings, the Topkapi, Hagia Sophia and Blue mosque are all very close together, walkable, as is the Grand Bazaar, which was much less overwhelming that I had expected

So much history in one place. Blue Mosque was the highlight to me, but the Aya Sofia, Topkapi palace and the museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts were all very nice. Beatiful from the outside and inside.

Where most things are. If it's your first time, you have to stay near this area. You can set off from here and walk to the Aya Sofya, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Little Aya Sofya, Mosaic Museum, Arista Bazaar, and just a bit further to the New Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar and maybe a tram ride to Galata Tower and Dolmahbace Palace.

Central to all attractions. Sultanahmet is perfect for visiting the sights of Istanbul. Close to Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, etc. and links by tram to all other districts. We like to walk the city and see the sights and this district is alive. This is the old city and great for getting around and seeing.
Inspiring. One of "must visit" places, indescribable with words, beautiful area around, don't hurry when you decide to visit the place
Architecture and history. This part of Istanbul is not something I can describe easily.You must see and enjoy.You could see at the behavior of most tourists that they really enjoy.

This is THE area. This is what makes the stay in Istanbul as is the old area, with most of the main attractions close by. I was lucky to stay in a hotel in this area (there are plenty to choose from) and everything is handy, with great restaurants in abundance. Lots of places to sit and peoplewatch. Yes it is the tourist centre, but it is also the historical centre.

A must touristic site to visit. If this was your first visit to Istanbul then this area is a definite to visit. All is in one bunch of area which you can pan out the whole day in if you start really early in the morning.if you arrive at Vezneciler metro station, find your way out of the station to the right onto the main road and then head left to the University. in front of the university you will find the Kapalı Çarşı then continue turning left and you will find the tram rail, where you will see Ayasofya and Blue Mosque. if you continue on to the bottom of the street you will find Topkapı palace and garden then continue straight down still to find the Bosphorus where you can take a non-guided municipality Boat Cruise for TL12. Why not?

Walking. It is such a compact area that we found ourselves instead of taking lots of more or less expensive tours we were able to walk everywhere quite comfortably.We are in our seventies and average git but could cope because everything we wanted to see was located there with the exception of the Bosporus cruise and the spice markets which we can warmly recommend.The Topkapi Palace we have seen about 10 years ago when we were there for just 2nights and can thoroughly recommend.Crowds are there all the time so ask when it isn't so crowded but it's interesting all the same.Make sure wherever you go that things aren't closed.Hagia Sofia is closed on Mondays for example.

Touristic area. It's very nice and safe área in Istanbul, but be aware while walking through. The restaurant's employees in this area keep on pushing The customers to join which becomes very uncomfortable. Take care to people trying to take advantage of tourists.
Famous area. Loved the atmosphere and the shops. Lots to see and do.Try the local food and enjoy people watching.

Stay here!. This is definitely the area to stay in if you want to be on the more historic and charming side of Istanbul. Everything is within walking distance and there are many places to shop for souvenirs as well as amazing restaurants. After going to the taqsim side and seeing how business like it is, we were definitely very happy about staying in sultanahmet.

Too many hucksters. Please don't take the modest three stars as pertaining to the several five star attractions in Sultanahmet. The district is also full of great restaurants, views of the Bosphorus, and many lovely people. We loved our hotel and went to a great hookah bar. But the constant attack by rug merchants, "friendly" guys who love Americans and happen to have a restaurant nearby, and others schemers is a real turnoff. Do stay in Sultanahmet. Its safe and close to the best stuff in Istanbul. But be prepared for annoyance as you go from place to place.
Love it! Stayed right in the heart of the Sultanahamet District. It was amazing experience, I love this District in Istanbul as everything is in close walking distance. Trams, absolutely everything!

It's amazing. If you like to see this area , make lots of photos, visit all the beautiful places over there, then go very early, cause in afternoon lots of tourists groups come, and it's will be hard to enjoy that time, to find place for make clear photo .
Tulips in April. I went in April when the sidewalks and the Gulharne park were full of tulips and hyacinths, and they also made the tulip carpet. It was most amazing.

You can spend days exploring the district. It's like being on the mall in Washington, DC, except everything is within a SHORT block of the center. So many photo opts. The most important and well known museums are here. Very crowded with tourists and buses and shops are overpriced - but this is a must location to hang out for a day or longer.

Highly engaging. Lots of shops, markets, cafes, ice cream vendors, and more in the area. Lots of benches. It's a tourist area but doesn't quite feel like a tourist area. Really rather pretty area and historical.

The ancient part of the city. It's the part of the city which has the most known attractions such as Ayasofya, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Yerebatan Sarayi (Basilica Cistern) and many others. Really, really beautiful.

Lots of shopping opportunities. Lots to see and do in this area. Plenty of places to eat. Where a lot of Istanbuls historical sights are located. People very friendly ( but only because they're trying to sell you carpet or something ). Atmospheric area. Be aware there are a lot of children begging on the streets. Can be a bit intimidating at times.

Intresting and traditional. Good place to shop,eat and have a traditional Turkish tea.Loved it! If you feel tired you can relax on many benches around. This is also a great place to buy suveniers for home. Highly recommend it!
Great Sites near to each other!!. Bought a Muzeistanbul Kart. Good deal for both 3 and 5 day if you can keep up the pace to take advantage of all the sites.

easy access from airport/locals friendly. access from Ataturk is excellent. prices are cheap compared to other to other touristy places. Locals friendly and would not try to push you in selling their carpets or boat tours. they are so used to tourists and they at least know another language aside from English/Turkish. I speak spanish and some arabic and they can also converse in these languages. The sights are close to each other so you can leisurely walk from one place to another. If you wish to go something farther, there is tram, though slow, will take you to your destination. The district has lots of souvenir, food stalls to choose from

Our second visit, as wonderful as the first had been. This old city area of Istanbul is amazing, home to at least two of the wonders of the world: the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia museum. Just wander around, look and absorb. Mini-skirts brush against full burkas. The calls to prayer are heard amidst the modern music in all the restaurants. It's an experience not to be missed.
Enjoy the locals. Loved walking around entering into banter with the locals,they are only trying to make a living and are very friendly if you take the time to talk with them.

Great Old Town. Great Mosques and restaurants, and close to all the major attractions. Some of the Hawkers that spill over from the Grand Bazaar and tour guides from Hagia Sophia can be a bit annoying, but we make up stories to tell them as an entertainment.

Outstanding. This is a fantastic and outstanding district. i spent 4 days and still not enough to do all the activities I wanted to do. You need at least a week just to digest the place. This area is so rich in history, so much to see and not enough time. Then there is the shopping, the tasting and testing of the many foods on offer. This has to be one of the best tourist destinations around. Try to stay in this location because everything is in waking distance and very pedestrian friendly, otherwise the transport system is fantastic.

Great walking area. All the major sites were within walking distance in this area. Lovely gardens, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Spice Market, Topkapi Palace, Grand Baazar, shopping, restaurants. Be aware that if approached by young friendly men, they will entice you to their carpet shops.
Wow. You must visit and experience such a big market,which always filled with lot of crowd. Huge number of shops

Experience old Istanbul . The time we spent in Istanbul was only in old Sultanahmet district, what a pleasure, cobble stone walks, Old men pushing their fresh fruit and veg carts, kids playing about, great vibe and safe!

You need to go there. For the tourists visiting Istanbul for the first time, visiting Sultanahmet District is a must as many historical mosques and museums are located in this area. However beware of heaving traffic and if you can don't drive or take a taxi to Sultanahmet as you will end up in the car for a long time and will lose time. The best to/from Sultanahmet is by tram which would cost you YTL 4 only.

Wow, just wow!. Sultanahmet - you must stay in this district for at least 1 night. It'll be a crime not to. Try to get onto local rates if you can...it's a tourist heartland so I think food (i.e. restaurants) can be really expensive if you don't shop around. Use local transport, shop at one of the many local markets and you'll be fine. But a word of warning re. local markets - they know a tourist when they see one. Most traders were brilliant though and I paid local prices. Check opening times for the big attractions. Often seasonal variations and renovation works mean that the guidebooks can be out of date really quickly. If you're into Museums and monuments etc - definitely recommend the tourist card. But big savings only if you actually visit all the places it gives you access to.

Fascinating and hectic!. What an amazing district - everywhere you turn there are sounds and sights to enthrallThe area has historic sites, shops, cafes, restaurants - everything!You could spend days exploring - it's so walk-able and you can't get lost in the maze as the water always serves as a reference along with the mosques!
Stay. I would recommend visitors to stay here if you're a first timer in Istanbul to easily visit the must-see sights. Mostly walking distances.

Sultanahmet. Good place to begin exploration of the tourist attractions in Istanbul. The Basilica Cistern is right there and do venture just a little further down the road to find restaurants where they make and bake their own bread on the premises.

Shopping!. Found it a little intimidating walking around as a single woman - the shop keepers can become a bit over whelming. I did purchase a lot of Turkish delight in the market, but very little else.
Crowded. Throngs of people . The tulips were beautiful at the park. Many historic sites. Travel there by tram, very easy.

Fuzion of Civilizations. Apart from religious part ... Sultanahmet is a place of multicultural polarization with extensive colorful tourists in peace and relax environment at the edge of an intersection of east and west The Bosphorous

Sultanahmet the magnificent. what a truly beautiful place and with the different colors striking the buildings from dawn to dusk it's like going back in time Best and most interesting place I have ever visited with so many things to see within walking distance

This is what you come to Istanbul for.. History, religion, culture, architecture, food, arts and crafts, and shopping. All in walking distance. Plan to be the explorer of this area for three days and you will still be missing a good part and want to come back.

historic. Visited the with 2 children the Aya sofia, Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern in one day. Children liked the Basilica Cistern the most and being underground and cool helped in August. The blue Mosque beautiful and Aya Sofia historic. Best to buy the tickets at automatic tills at Aya Sofia rather than queue up.
fun place to wander. if you have nothing on your program, you can simply walk around and enjoy the scenery.. tulips are in bloom during April which made it extra beautiful!

A series of strolls through history. The history, the nostalgia and the Ottoman ambience in the district is mesmerising. Having said that, beware of tourists scams like people coming up to you pretending to be a friendly local and trying to take you to a carpet shop or belly dancing or a bottle of beer.

Lots to do. This is a great place to visitin Istanbul. Some really nice restaurants/cafes and most of the tourist attractions can found here including blue mosque, grant bazar, typkapi palace to name a few.

Historic heart of Byzantine & Ottoman Turkey. So many attractions closely located: Agia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace & Museum, Islamic Art Museum. Spring tulips. Clean. Quite crowded but safe. Exercise prudent safety precautions.
Beautiful. Lovely old area to explore on good, the Grand Market is beautiful inside with all its colourful shops.
In the presence of Giants. This area is so beautiful - you feel so little amidst the monuments around you - The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, The Hippodrome and its Obelisque. Magical!
Must see. The flair, the openness of the space, the friendly vendors, the many shops and the good and low cost restaurants, all a good start to grasp and sense the turkish culture.

Impossible to get bored of. The place is beautiful, it is full of people and life and it is rich in history. We visited it everyday for 6 days before or after other attractions. The tulips play a great part of the beauty of the view, try to visit during spring or summer time. Day and night visits are recommended, they both have their charm. There is a lot of lazy dogs there and you can pet them!

In the heart. We are staying five nights in the Sultanahmet area and are finding that it is a great central location. We have been walking to all the major tourist attractions and with the congested traffic I believe it would be quicker then hopping on a hop on hop off bus, every time we saw a bus they were hardly moving due to traffic. Also walking one gets more of a feel for the area and you can explore those little side streets. Lots of restaurants to enjoy of an evening, a great location.

Less crowded market area. This area is smaller but far easier to get around in than the Grand Bazaar. There are plenty of vendors to stop by and get turkish delight, turkish cotton, or other turkish souvenirs. This area is just behind the blue mosque. There is even a side entrance into the grounds of the blue mosque through the market. I did all of my turkish shopping in this area and i was very pleased with what i found.If you don't have time or the energy to go to the Grand Bazaar, this is a great alternative. I myself don't like crowded streets and enjoy my personal space. There was a good variety of vendors and most seems less pushy.
Not a tourist trap. Definitely a place to stay and explore the sights from. Quick ride to/from the airport, plenty of history, restaurants and shops

Excellent historic sites. Bustling area. Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia Church, Cisterns,Topkapi, carpet museum. Just about everything is here. Tour guides trying to get your business. Pay them to avoid big lines. Regular big tourist attraction hassles. But well worth it.

Crowded and lively. So much is going around these markets that it is hard to walk with a straight concentration. This is definitely your place if you are looking for some shopping experience but hence it is also the first place any tourist head first, the prices are massive and you have to have a strong presence of mind to not end up paying thrice the actual worth. Even if for not shopping, this is one of the lively parts of the city and is practically midst to every attractions

Central, convenient and fun!. Yes Sultanahmet is aimed at tourists and yes it's a bit cheesy as a result, but I loved the area. Bustling with restaurants, bars and of course close to all the major sites it's the best area to stay in hands down.In the morning I would drink my coffee while looking at the Blue Mosque and by night you can smoke shesha and drink beers while taking in the buzz that erupts in the evening as travellers transcend into the plethora of restaurants...I wrote about it on my blog: http://www.pilgrimwithaplan.com/istanbul-expect-the-unexpected/
One of the musts in Istanbul. Strolling through the bazaar and visiting Sultan Ahmed Mosque is an absolute must for any first-time or returning Istanbul traveller.

The Place To Be In Istanbul. This location is full of history, all the major sites, public transport, cheap good restaurants along with a great selection of pocket friendly hotels and more if your budget stretches to it. You can walk everywhere in Sultanahmet at any time of the day or night as well as being able to walk to all the most important historical sites. We have been to Istsnbul twice now and wouldn't stay anywhere else. Did look over the bridge towards Taksim but then thought better of it.

I prefer this to the Grand Bazaar!. The Grand Bazaar can be quite overwhelming for a lot of people because of its sheer scale. This market which is known locally (if I am not mistaken) as the Persian Spice market is much smaller and doable and has a better mix of products and handicrafts on offer in a concentrated area. The range of spices, teas, Turkish Delight and other commodities is extremely attractive and inviting. There is also an outdoor Turkish equivalent of a garden centre nearby.

Tourist area. Melting pot between East and West. Fascinating to sit down and watch all the people passing. Locals and tourists. Toilet fascilities were much better than expected (good when you are travelling with kids).

The heart of Istanbul. The most remarkable part of the city: Hagia Sophia, Sultan Ahmet and underground water reservoir, are unavoidable monuments. If we take Egyptian obelisks into consideration, more than 2000 history, and if you find a terrace, beautiful view to Marmara see, makes your tea brake unforgettable.

The district to stay in Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the district to stay if your are going for a short time to Istanbul. We decided to go to Turkey 6 days (3 in Istanbul and 3 in Cappadocia before going to Italy taking advantage of flying combinations and fares). The district was great due to we could maximize our time. We were close to everything that matters in Istanbul, walking or using the excellent tramway service. We enjoyed the people, the food, the landmarks. Walking around the district and from there to Taksim square -despite the long distance - was a great and incredible experience: we could taste Istanbul from all angles.

Great location to see many things. Close to major attractions. Excellent location for walking and exploring the side streets of the area. Access to the tram made it easy to explore beyond the area--take the tram to Kabatas and then on to Taksim. And, enjoy the cats!
Beautiful historic mosque.. Incredible restoration apparently by art students and lecturers from the University. Fine and intricate work. A must see!

Mass of Bodies. As others have said this is THE place to stay, but really, really crowded. Be advised that walking in the street is sometimes the only way to get by the throngs of people who are moving slowly at best (beware of the trams and buses though). This is the taste of Turkey you need to experienced. With all its fun, yet somewhat gaudy exterior. There are shops every where and little historic sites will pop out at you from no where. Wander the streets, but be warned of the crowds....

Holiday. Great location. Right in the middle of things. Brilliant location especially if you only have short time. Public transport near, Good restaurants on your door step. If on a long weekend visit major attractions very close. Your budget is your own choice all catered for.Great shopping opportunities. Grand Baazar nice if you haggle. Loads of other fab local shops. I have been twice once for 5 days second time for 16 days but still feel I have so much more to see.

Spice and sweet market. Its a big market they sale spices and traditional sweets and tea cups and traditional stuff of turkey and tge prices not cheap it was average and out side the market there is a place to feed the doves that was amazing

Touristy and crowded. Inspite of my heading for this write up it is worth staying in this area if it is your first visit to Istanbul and you plan to do the tourist stuff i.e. Hagia Sphia, Blue mosque and other mosques, Grand Bazar ,Spice Bazar, Galata Tower etc.Everything is within walking distance which is good because Istanbul is absolutely crowded. No doubt we went over Easter which therefore had a few more tourists than usual. We also could walk to the Sultan Suleiman Hamam which apparently was built in 1600. Lovely experience.
The area to stay in to see Istanbul. This district as all the all the sights in Istanbul . Easily walkable to all the major sights. Stay in the area for great food,sights and culture

Essential area to visit, good to stay near and good to eat in.. Sultanahmet contains several of the main attractions in Istanbul like: Sopha Hagia; The Blue Mosque; Topkapi Palace; The Basilica Cistern; Hippodrome. Also close by is the Grand Bazaar. Plus a lot of restaurants and shopping areas. So its the essential area to visit if you go to Istanbul and you will need several days to explore it and see the sights. Its connected by Tram (one of the main lines) so is easy to reach and easy to walk around in as a 15 minutes stroll takes you to all the main sights. You will be pestered by vendors and 'guides' to the tours as you walk, and there are lots of carpet shops (some quite high end). Buy Turkish Delight and spices (sold in bulk at very low prices) at some of the stores. Stay in old Istanbul nearby and walk here.

The centre of the three main attractions.. This area covers walking distance to four main attractions all close together. Is a very good place to stay with hotels to suite every pocket price wise. Likewise there plenty of eateries from very expensive to the good Turkish family kitchens where the cost reflects the local clientele. Walk the local streets away from the attractions and you will be surprised to find the real Istanbul. Stay a bit further from the attractions and live the dream without spending a fortune and at the same time meet the friendly locals.

Just a great place to hang out!!. We loved this area of Istanbul! Actually we loved all of the areas of Istanbul where we traveled. The shopping was fun, there was easy access to transport, great food and bars, great historic sites… do I need to say anymore???

Good area to stay in.. The Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, great shopping and restaurants. I didn't dislike anything. There is a wonderful shopping bazaar, the Arasta bazaar,much better then the Grand Bazaar.

Almost everything you need to see are here!. It was wise for me to have stayed in Sultan's Inn Hotel at Sultanahmet where everything is on walking distance, from good restaurants, parks, shops and the tram station.I walked along Kennedy Avenue that took me to Gulhane Park, strolled in Sultanahmet Park and proceeded to Grand Bazaar and Laleli for shopping. It's very strategic. My 9 days in Istanbul and a day trip to Troy were relaxing and I was able to maximize what I want for my holiday. It's where you need to be if you're going to Istanbul.
History in all directions. Experience centuries of history and cultural transition as you walk the streets and lane ways of this compact district. I fell in love with it.
Must see. Walk around - all the big sights are here. Very pretty in April with all the tulips in bloom and cobblestone streets.

The best place in Istanbul. You are not in Istanbul if you don't step foot here. All the attractions, food and souvenirs are here. The Grand Bazaar also has much to see and buy. We came here every day for 3 days and yet found time to be insufficient...

Most attractions are here. Nearly everything your I'll be visiting are located in this area so itmight be a good idea to find a hotel here. I would definitely avoid restaurants as they are very low quality and pricy in this area. Sleeping here, you will hear every morning the call for the prayer which can be disturbing to some, we found it fascinating.

Touristic area with most of the biggest sights in Istanbul. It is very touristic part of the city, so it is not the best part to get an authentic picture of the city. But since most of the biggest sights like Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace and Cistern are there, you should visit them. But other than visiting the sigts, I would not hang around here, I would I head to Beyogly, bazaar disctrict or Karaköy instead.Since there are lot of tourists, there are also lot of those touts selling Bosphorus boat tours and so on. It can be a bit annoying saying 'no tank you' over and over and over again, but they are not too pushy.The tram is handy way to reach the district from around Galata bridge.
Historical area. I need 4 days to complete the historical site in sultanahmet!! The sites are all worth it!!! Hagia sophia, blue mosque, Roman Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Obelisk of Theodosius

Byzantine Empire Feeling in Istanbul. The are some amazing remaining of the Byzantine Empire in the Sultanahmet Square which attract every visitor. The Walled Obelisk, Serpent Column, and German Fountain are worth seeing. The background scenery is wonderful facing the Mosques. Apart from the Sultanahmet Square, there some other eye-catching places in this district including the Grand Bazzar, Hagia Sofia Mosque, Topkapi Palace, etc., each of them requires separate reviews. In addition, enjoy the small traditional coffee shops and try a cup of tea (Chai).

Fantabulous!!!. I could spend days here and not get bored! Just walk around and soak it all in. I doubt this experience and charm could be matched anywhere else in the world! If language weren't an issue I'd be looking at settling here! Loved it! Stay only here if it's your first visit. If staying for more than 3 days then you could spend a night on the Bosphorous (budget permitting as all the hotels are luxury).

Best attraction in Istanbul. Best attraction in Istanbulnice for touring and shopping many Turkish delights shop and fine restaurantsa lots of old Ottomani historical sights it is must for wonderful tour

Getting a Little Scary. We've stayed in this area in the past and have always had a good time. The area to the north east of the square (near the Four Seasons) seems lively, lots of action, contains a small bizarre and feels safe. The other side, the South West end of the square, near the Arcadia Blue, seems more seedy. Streets are more dark and residential and run down. We were followed by beggars one night on that side. It didn't feel safe.

Shoud see there. You should go to the Sultanahmet district to visit the Masques and also Topkapi!also you can see every angles of traditianl city and enjoy museams!You can go there by Subway from Besiktas,also you can go there by bus to Eminonu and then get to there.Don't forget to go there early,forexample 9AM so you can see Topkapi without too much crowd!Also try to eat acorn and they traditional bread for just one time and for just about 1.5 Turkish Lira. Be aware that everything you might buy in this district has much higher price than other districts!After visiting all around there,You should eat the Turkish traditional Ice cream!Unfortunatly I missed the Ice cream!
Mesmerising.... Not much to say here, other than that it is clearly not an area to be missed. So much history... and it is wonderful to be able to visit all of the various sites on foot.

The center of the historic (and tourist) district. This is where you will find the cistern, the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, a tram stop, Topkapi, lots of carts selling delicious simits (1 TL each, 2 TL with Nutella inside - heaven!) and roasted corn and chestnuts in season. Plenty of police presence keeps (most of ) the begging children away, but you will have lots of opportunities to practice ignoring the very friendly young men who are not selling anything but you do look like you want to buy a rug. Take some time to just sit and enjoy your simit while watching the crowds.

Unique. So many fabulous sights within a small area. This city is unique. Beautiful mosques, great restaurants, palaces, museums, Egyptian Obelisks, Roman remains trams, the bazaars, beautiful squares, bustling shops and friendly people - all within easy walking distance of each other. Best to stay in this area in one of the many cheap hotels. We went in March/April. Take layers of clothing. We got sun burned on Wednesday, drenched in torrential rain on Tuesday and chilled by the wind on Thursday. Coat on and off, umbrella up and down - be prepared for all. Take comfy shoes and a head scarf if visiting the many mosques. The restaurants sell traditional Turkish food in this area and not all serve alcohol. This is a fairly conservative area of the city and there is not an abundance of bars, although you should find enough to keep you amused. There are several places to change money and they offer a good rate of exchange. Go to one of the many cafes selling the filled 'pancake' style creations you will see the women rolling out in the windows. Several just past the Roman Cistern - carry on down the hill towards the park and look on the right hand side. Delicious!

Best part of Istanbul. I really think this is the best part of Istanbul. All the attractions are close by. There are a lot of restaurants and hotels in the area and you have small stores and mini markets too.

Super toursity. This place was so packed with tourists and hawkers we had to get out as soon as possible. I guess if you have 48 hours in Istanbul, it's OK, but staying in Sultanahmet actually made us like the city less. Impossible to get good, reasonably priced food. Shops are all overpriced. It's hard to enjoy the sights here.

Stay here for the major sites. In this district many of the major sites are located including the Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern.
It is a more traditional area and there are plenty of restaurants selling typical Ottoman food.
Be sure to visit this area on a trip to Istanbul.

Interesting buildings. Loved the architecture and parks, which could not be said about all sales people trying to earn a buck from selling different trips and stating things are closed at the moment...

fantastic location to see and feel the best of Istanbul. Excellent for most sights and culture, good access to trams if you wish to travel further. Or catch the ferry, just get a travel card for all these modes of transport.
Excellent range of restaurants and eateries. You also have the hammam for spa and pampering between the mosques, a real must!
very nice. very nice, a lot of old small strats bars and restaurtans, fantastic hagia sophia. you can feel real old times walking around there

Market grounds. Sultanahmet is the place to hit if you are looking for shopping experience in Istanbul. These alleys bring you everything from gold, spices, rugs to everything that Istanbul is famous for. Though one has to be prepared for the crowds and the aggressive marketing around here. Vendors are screaming and shouting and then there is the push and pull of the enthusiastic shoppers and tourists. The District also happens to be located in the center to your way to all the important tourist destinations in the city.

The old quarter of Istanbul. If you want ancient history this is it. The most impressive sites such as Topkapi, Blue Mosque, hagia Sofia, Suleymaniye and teh Grand Bazaar are all here. A maze of winding tiny street, traffic jams and shops alike. Wander about freely. We were impressed that in most parts of Istanbul the shopkeepers are not too intrusive or badgering. Start from the bridge and walk up the street of spices. Enter the Grandbazaar from the north after wandering through a maze of narrow passages of spice, sweetmeats, fabric and jewellery shops. Expect that any taxi or buss will want to drop you well away from the centre of the area as the traffic is so bad and we were tthere at the end of March. What it must be like in mid season in June/July I read to think. So walk! At least from the edge of the area. But so much to see and not just those monuments mentioned above. There are hundreds of mosques, the Hippodrome, old churches, bazaars, shops, the old waterstorages and much more.

Street Vendors. Buy the Nutella covered bagels they are so yummy with the freshly pressed juices that are on offer. I loved the smiles and friendly faces that greet you on the street. The locals are always curious as to which country you are from. They always give you advise about things like where to go, watch out for taxi drivers that cheat and we asked them questions about where they recommend we should eat etc. There is so much history and love in this city that I will definitely be back . My kids enjoyed the freedom of having to walk around on the cobble streets. They were amazed by the colours of the building and the small corner coffee shops. It a really beautiful place

Best place to be. We were lucky enougho to stay in this area, all the main landmarks all withing walking distance as is the grand Bizaar. You could spend hours getting lost in back streets, looking at souvenir shops, stopping off at amazing cafes and the general hustle and bustle of life.

Cok Guzel! (So pretty!). I have been to Istanbul 3 times, and all times I have decided to stay in the Sulthanamet area when in Istanbul. Sulthanamet has a little bit of everything, yes it is mainly occupied by tourists but you cant beat the historic places, breathtaking views of the Bosphorus and the Mosques, and walking by many shops, outdoor restaurants. From Sulthanamet you could easily go to TaksiM Square area by tram/train and walk to not so "touristy" areas. Sulthanamet is a Great location for seeing some of the main attractions in Istanbul.

A place in history. We liked the diversity of shops and souvenirs that reflected the historical significance of Istanbul and its rich culture. It is a shopping haven. The historical sites like the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Grand Bazaar were all in walking distance of each other but you could also take a tram for 4 KM to any stop on the tram line. We found that some of the shops outside of the Grand Bazaar were sometimes less expensive. Of course the secret is never to start buying at the first shop but to check prices first as you could easily pay double. In between all the sites and restaurants were many restaurants who offered traditional Turkish dishes and the popular Turkish Teas and Coffees. You must have a lot of time.

Allow up to a week to explore the wonders here!. The Sultanahmet District has it all:The Blue MosqueThe Topakali Museum,The AyasofiaThe Mosaic MuseumThe HippodromeThe CisternAmazing eateries.Street dogs and catsOld meets new shopping and dining experiences.Discover even more for yourself....In five days we barely scratched the surface!Behind the Topakali museum there is an amazing little local eatery and teahouse where only locals go with unbeatable views over the Bospherous.Iznic pottery, Turkish carpets galore and the very finest of cotton and silk Turkey has to offer!Ice cream at the square.Pomegranite juice, squeezed before your eyes!You could find the essence of Turkey here without even leaving Istanbul.One of the most overwhelmingly beautiful, beguiling and fascinating districts to explore in the entire world by day, or night!

The perfect location for your Istanbul visit!. Our family of 3 visited this area for 5 days and it was the perfect location! All of the attractions we were interested in touring were within this area; the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Bosphorus Sea, bazaars and so much more! The people are friendly, hotels convenient and the food is amazing! We highly recommend a trip to this area of Istanbul
Attractive and interesting. Many historical, spiritual, artistic and architectural sites; many restaurants and bakeries, hotels and shops. Pleasant environment, well organized transport.
Historical buildings all in one place. The blue mosque, the Aya Sofia and the cistern were all in this one place! Three buildings that are a must-see

Istanbul Stay. The area is close to everything. Travelling around 22 million people is not as bad as what you imagine. Walking distance to the major attractions. A most amazing city and definitely worth the visit
beauty of architect. you must check it out if its your first time in istanbul...i go to this area even though its maybe my most frequent place to visit.

worth to visit. lots of interesting stuff around the city. like the night time walking in the silence. easy to find somebody who speaks english and it was good for me to communicate and orentation of the area.

A treasure trove of a district. You could spend days here just wandering around. The jewel of Byzantium, Hagia Sofya is here, as are the beautiful blue mosque and others. It's like walking around Dan Brown's latest novel, Inferno. This district is also home to the main market and tons of lovely cafes. This district is what Istanbul is all about.
superb. traditioanl and rich in culture, small streets, advisable for traveleres for calm stay in istanbul and near by blue mosque,topkaki etc
must see. has a big variety of many thing tourist like to see and do in this city sight seeing shops restaurants and others
OMG. Really really in love with Sultanahmed area! So historical, splendid, powerful and magnificent. At night time it has a different "face", so experience both!!

nice place to stay. it's a small area in heart of Istanbul, full of hotels, hostels, apartments and so on. so it's easy to find a shuttle bus from/to the airport. + in this area everybody speaks english) here you can get all the museums in few minutes+ great number of restaurants will provide tasty meals 24/7. nearby there is a tramway station, in 12 minutes walk there is famous galata bridge. if you are lazy and plan you use often the tramway/ bus/ metro - by the istanbul card, in such case you'll pay 2 liras instead of 4 liras

Plenty of things to see and experience. i would say the main attraction would be the Sultanahmet Camii also known as the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia and the Topkapi Palace. In between them there were a hamam, restaurants, view of the Marmara, shopping, and entertainment.
Amazing. turkey always surprise you but there is more is like in story's is magnifiq if you like shopping is a dream if you like history is like alive dream

huge and beautiful. this area around the most beautiful mosque is excellent. it has very good eating out places and shopping bazaars. the two huge mosques add to the beauty of the place. never knew that this region could be so beautiful.

Best Area of Istanbul!. This is the best part of Istanbul. We stayed in two different areas. I loved Sultanahmet. It has many historical sights, good shopping and great restaurants. There are many parts that are very cute and cozy. It is quite hilly, get ready to walk!
A deep sense of history. Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Galata bridge, Galata tower, all of them at walking distance in Sultanahmet

Hagia Sophia Ottoman Sultans' shrines. Just backside of Hagia Sophia Museum, five Ottoman Sultans and Ottoman princes were buried in memorial shrines really worth visiting and watching beautiful sarcophagus as well as headgears. The splendid 16th century İznik tiles are the nice decorations to go with the sultans' tombs to make a holy atmosphere under the domes.
Nice historical location and perfectly safe. Walking distance to many important attractions like Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome and Topkapi Palace.

Must visit place. There are some places you must visit at least once in your life. Historic areas of Istanbul must be visited. During strolls along old streets you can physically feel how tons of historic events were happen here. Sultanahmet has its unbelievable charm as well as lots of sightseeing.

Give it A Whole Day!. If you have time, give this area a whole day without any planning. You will stumble upon great shops, restaurants and historic sites.
If you prefer a more planned walk, join a walking tour

8000 years of History all in walking distance. Istanbul's old city is all here. Greeks, Roman, and Ottomans all left their impressions here. A comfortable pair of walking shoes and a good guide book will reveal all the significant memorials, buildings and people that make this area a World Heritage site not to be missed. It is a unique opportunity. Better is hire a guide to sort it all out. Be sure to leave home with extra room in your baggage as there are lots of great shopping. Bargaining is expected.
So much to do.... This part of the city is so alive. Things are open all hours and there is so much to do and see you can never get bored. Stay in this part of town and enjoy the atmosphere.
Everything is right there. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Cistern, etc. Everything is right in the same area which makes it very convenient
Beautiful. The architecture is amazing. The history that is represented and the understanding that this city truly was the crossroads to the world was incredibility fascinating.
must see. it is the best part of the town. Ancient and new together. I love it..take the tram to go all parts of it.
Back back back. Go back as soon as possible. I saw lot of places, but this part of Istambul is full. Full of view, food, historical interests, etc...Athmosphere is amazing.

So much to see!. Sultanahmet is the perfect place to spend quality sightseeing time. You can walk to amazing historical sites and learn so much about the various empires that ruled Turkey. We highly recommend joining a one day walking tour of the area to get an understanding for the history and the best way to see everything.

Full of things to see and eat. This area is alive with history and service. Within a short stroll you will find the bulk of inner city attractions. One item that did stand out was the information on items in the area. they are on obelisks, about 2m high and in 4 languages with details on each item - we found them very useful.There is plenty to see, do and eat here and apart from the odd tourist annoyance ( and unlike other places they do take a no for an answer and leave you alone) this place is a must for any visit to this city
Wonderful experience. I visited Sultanahmet a few times and I'd return any time I visit Istanbul. This is one of the places you want to visit as the history behind it is amazing.
Touristy, but in a good way. Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Cafes... What's not to like! It's the perfect place to spend a day or two soaking up the sights.

A world heritage area. The area is a world heritage area, a lot of Istanbul's high lights are located here. This place is really really old. The atmosphere breathes this antiquity. This area is really special for the world history.

A feast for the eyes.. One of the top places to visit in Istanbul. The opening scenes of Skyfall (2012) was shot around this area. Places of interest such as Blue mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazar, Basilica Cistern etc are all located in this region at a stone's throw distance from each other. Most of the places require a ticket and entry closes quite early in the evening (time varies with season). So reaching the place early in the day and sparing ample time for the area is recommended as there is much to see. The district if full of eateries and public transport is readily available with cabs, buses and tram going around all the time. This is a very beautifully planned and maintained district that is a feast for the eyes. The sea shore is nearby offering a grand panoramic view on both sides of the shore. Metro station and ferry port is situated nearby at Eminonu. Ferry cruise up the Bosphorus can be taken from there. A must visit place of Istanbul.

History and Food. The area is an ideal place to get a hotel - I recommend the Orient Express Hotel, which I have written up elsewhere on this site. As well as the many historical attractions there are endless eateries where you can sample Turkish cuisine the traditional way with the day's offerings set out in the front of the restaurant. Don't forget to try balık ekmek at Galata Bridge!

A great place to visit for a few days and even a few hours. I've been visiting Sultanahmet since 2002 and feel as though I know it like the back of my hand. I've felt safe there, even walking at midnight (but, as with anyplace, you must walk late at night at your own risk). My children enjoyed this place when they were teenagers, as well. Now that I live here, it has been fun to meet friends at the airport who are passing through and bring them to Sultanahmet for a few hours. Usually I take them to Hafiz Mustafa for tea and baklava (and relatively clean restrooms). I make sure they go to the Aya Sofia and the Blue Mosque. If they have time, they check out the Basilica Cistern, too. It is relatively easy to reach by the Ataturk Airport. A taxi would cost about 50 TL (currently about $20 and it may take 25 minutes if there is not too much traffic) or one can take the metro to Zeytinburnu and then transfer to the Tram (about 8TL per person and about 60 minutes).Allow an hour to take the taxi back to the airport, unless it's rush hour, then you've made a big mistake :)

Arastar Bazaar and great restaurants. this area sizzles with atmosphere. The Bazaar is very classy and the merchants do not pester you at all. There are scores of interesting restaurants with great food and entertaining wait staff. We dined at Babalonia and two others that I cannot recall but basically you cant go wrong.
Has everything. This is the old city with most of the main attractions within walking distance. Comfy shoes are a must.

Wonderful Area!. This is a wonderful area to sightsee, shop, and eat. We stayed in the heart of Sultanahmet and was able to walk to all of the major sights. Make sure to try Turkish Delights. There are so many flavors to pick from. Many of the stores will let you sample the flavors before you buy to make sure you like the taste. In the evening, pick a restaurant and sit outdoors. You will be able to hear the Call to Prayer, which is something I will never forget. If shopping is something you enjoy, make sure to buy some beautiful scarves. You can haggle with the store owners for lower prices. I will be definitely coming back to this area during my next visit. I felt very safe, and everyone was really friendly.

Jewel of the City.... It was our 2nd visit this time here.We again preffered staying at this area close to all major attractions.Area is full of vibe and home to Blue Mosque,Hagia Sofia,Basilica Cistern and Topkapi Palace.Lots of shops,Restaurants and eateries here.Many hotels,tour shops almost in every street.Easily connected to the city and Airport via tram line and metro.Tip: Beware of tourist traps.Check the prices of souvenirs and tours from different shops because lots of variation in the prices and bargains are involved.

Nice old district. Sultanahmet District has all the historic sites within walking distance and can be completed in one day. Watch out for vendors who try to get you to go into their shop and restaurants. The moment you start talking to the vendor in the front of the store or the restaurant, they will attract you in and try to get you to buy something. Know where you want to go before you go into the district.

Lost in Istanbul. Great part of town, ended up in the historic baazaar. Fantasticcc shopping but be prepared to bargain! Good deal son carpets and scarfs if you are willing to spend the time. Not sure on the gold but there was plenty of it. It is still a fantastic experience though for the westerner with little arabic experience.
Charming. I stayed twice in this part of Istanbul and cannot wait to be back. I love the feel of Sultanahmet with many restaurant, shops and historical buildings.
Istanbul. Proximity to the Blue Mosque area . Sunday fruit and veg market a delight . Small family run hotels in the area which are affordable and again in the heart of the main attractions .

Wonderful District..Definitely the best. Sultanhamet is by far the nicest place to be, it's vibrant but not at all intimidating, which we found in places like Taksim Square, a very different atmosphere..

Wonderful place, but be ware of scammers. So much to see down here. Make sure you visit the turkish bath. Blue Mosque and Haya Sofia are amazing. The only draw back is that there are tons of turkish men always aggressively trying to force you into their restaurant.
We kept going back!. Visited this area for 3 days- there is just so much to see! Don't fall for tourist traps - getting pulled into restarants etc. And always bargain in the shops.

beautiful grounds area and mosque. hey you will love this place and you will love istanbul the turkish people are not religion freaks they are like us americans christmas catholics and yom kipper jews just your regular holiday only religious people just like most of us, there is a call to prayer 5 times a day and its kind of beautiful to hear the city bursts with song to praise ,but it does not affect your day in any way.what i love about the men is that at all ages, friends, family, brothers cousins boyfriends they walk arm in arm like true brothers a strong bond and they dont care what tourisits think about it ,we americans can learn a lot from them you dont see them taking out there pray rugs kneeling in traffic to pray unlike in brooklyn they are nice helpful wonderful people dressed in everyday clothes jeans n teeshirts n jackets n dresses n makeup working hard to provide for themselves n there families and to have fun as well, they picnic on the grounds with there families couples straight n gay in no way did i feel uncomfortable as a white american who stands at 6'3 230 marine haircut n gay and they knew it at our hotel cause there were 4 of us and we were always joking n having fun n asking questions to the staff they only knew that we were nice and good tippers and we were interested in there culture. this area where the mosque is is a huge area with many things to do shopping eating breakfast lunch dinner coffee dessert turkish dvds n cds the grand bazzar is close they have these trolleys n trains that ride the streets, the food is cooking in the front windows there are dogs laying around the grounds sleeping with there ears tagged there are magpies squawking, all around. with the many men hanging in groups all over the place at all times there was never any fighting arguing cursing drunkeness, i never saw any harrasment of women or abuse they are very kind people i do hope you will go and have a great time thanks david

Old Quarter. This is the area you want to stay in. No mater how many times you go you fall in love everytime. Everytime I go I feel like I'm at home. There are so many great boutique hotel and wonderful resturants in the area. You are close enough to walk to the spice market, the Grand Bazar however it is easy to get a cab also. The Blue Masque, Hagia Sophia and the beautiful Cisterns. I love the Arasta Bazar because it is small and cozy with cute shops (less overwelming than the Grand Bazar). There are individual shops/resturants all around. Also check to see when the wirling dervish perform in the resturant tea area of the Arasta. Get totally lost wandering around you and you will love it. There is always more to see. I have been at least seven times both with friends and alone and have hardly scratched the surface of what there is to do in the Sultanahmet district.
