What a Jewel.... I've been here six times from the US... and never grow tired of walking around Sultanahmet. Beyond the Aya Sophia and Sultanahmet... you have the Spice Bazaar, Grand Bazaar, amazing streets, Cisterns, etc. etc. Just stunning. This is definitely going to be the center of your time in Istanbul... and you wont grow tired of it!
Spectacular. True heart of Istanbul. All the prime attractions are there as well as good restaurants and hotels. The first place to visit during your trip.

The Golden Horn of Istanbul....Magnificent. This is the old quarter of the city from the Roman and Ottoman times. If I had any vision of Istanbul prior to coming, this was it: the grand mosques, the bridges, the waterways. There are tens if not hundreds of wonderful restaurants and endless shops full of touristy things to buy from chintzy tschotkes to fine antique carpets, but they all come with pushy salesmen. Be friendly but firm if you don't care to buy.

#1 attraction in Istanbul, but dead at night. All of Istanbul's most famous museums and sights are in Sultanahmet, so it is not to be missed. However, beware that there is little to do in this area after about 9 PM. If clubs/discos or bars are your idea of nightlife, try staying closer to Taksim square. However, if your idea of the perfect nightlife is quiet or a stroll among the sights, it's worth while to pay the premium and stay in Sultanahmet.

open museum. Waow, the experience of this city was unbelivable. I have tried so many good food, and visited many historical places. But sultanahmet was the best place to be (except the hotel i chose - sura hagia sophia was awful)

Shopping & Eating Out. Huge selection but worth investigating as we nearly missed the Arasata Bazaar behind the Aya Sophia. Wonderful restaurants whether you want to snack or a full meal. Shop owners a little persistent but never offended when rejected. All part of the atmosphere!
Ideal for tourists. Atmospheric Sultanahmet is ideal. All historic buildings are within very easy walking distance. Lots of restaurants, cafes as well to rest the weary legs.

Great Location. It is a great area. So much to see. Great shopping. Good transport options. Restaurants and cafes second to none. Cannot find anything I disliked about this district. Thrilled to have been there.

Historical place. This is the place for which you come to Istanbul due to fact that everything is here. You will find most of the Istanbul's best attractions here. It is easy to reach Sultanahmet via T1 tram in direction of Katbas you just hop off on Sultanahmet station. Be awere of the scams here especiallx for offers for Bosporus tours via boat as they tend to charge you triple from original prices. Bars and restaurants in this district are also much more expensive comparing to other parts. My advice id do not buy anything here only visit attractions,all other souvenires which you want to buy you will find elsewhere for st least half of the price oftenly even more.

If you want to see the "must see" stuff. If you want to see the big sites this is the neighborhood to stay in. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bizarre, etc. All short walks and the tram runs through the middle if you can't stand a short walk. Be aware it is caaled the OLD Town for a reason. Its not glitzy just historically fantastic
Unique and historic. The feel of the area is one of a kind. Walking in narrow alleys among the mosques and hearing the prayer calls is really fantastic.

Quite nice but not great.. You have to pick your times between prayers which I guess is the same for all mosques. Very pretty ceiling but the outside a bit similar to many others. Well worth seeing though.

Visit to Sultanahmet. I like the Architecture and the clean environment of Sultanahmet
I do not like the way people want to put some cloth on your head

Soaking Up the Atmosphere. How can you not love walking around here, listening to the traders eager to get your business, sometimes they be a little over eager. The sights & smells are nothing that I have witnessed before. Its like walking back in time , this is the way they have been trading for thousands of years and the only thing that has changed possibly is some of the products. The smell of spice is so powerful, take a walk and take in the sights and smells.
pretty religious buildings. pretty religious buildings. Maybe a bit disaoopintet that I didnt see more of the "old" constantinopel.

Frenetic, mad, busy, fabulous...... Brilliant area to visit but be prepared to be hassled to the point of distraction! Amazing things to visit, see & do. Keep your wits about you & be prepared for hawkers. It gets very busy as the day gets older and is a bustling centre at night. We found being ignorant worked far better than engaging in any type of communication to avoid too much hassle but it goes with the territory, so embrace it rather than fight it.
Another area to visit. This is a beautiful district of Istanbul and certainly worth a visit, lots of monuments and mosques to see, take your camera!
Beautiful!. you cannot get bored of you are staying in Sultanahmet. So much to offer! History, culture, food, shopping etc. Blue Mosque and Topkapi palace are my favorite.

Spice bizarre mad . Although you are haggled and hounded to your hearts content in the markets it is such a fantastic atmosphere! Going in winter is better as it isn't so hot and you really get appreciate the tea and was a lovely walk
ottoman empire. cisterna basilica is one of the strongest impacts in the past years. The Hagia Sofia is incredible either!

the most important attraction to visit in istanbul. You can easily get to this area by city train.Most of important atractions of istanbul located in this area. Including Hagia Sophia and blue mosque, topkapi palace and some other things. The area is full of bar, restaurants, hotels and stores which sell really great turkish things. Like sweets and hand crafts.you will enjoy your visit. I visited this area twice! Because one is not enough!
the most importent place. ı think the best and most importent place to go Sultanahmet arera if you ever go to the İstanbul you shud vist that arera for sru
Great Istanbul. is the best pleace to stay in Istanbul, for sure. there is the Blue Mosque, Topi Kapy Museum and the Hagia Sofia. great place. who want know Istanbul must stay there

Landmarks close together. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern all in the same area. At night the fountain between them is beautifully litted. Area is rich with history and culture. There is even a turkish bath there - be it a bit more expensive.

All The Sites Are Here, So Are All the Tourists. We stayed in Sultanahmet, which was the right thing to do, but even in March it was crawling with tourists. There are some restaurants and bars that locals favor, but you need to dig for them. There are also some great places that you won't mind sharing with other tourists - Seven Hills, Altinkupa). But you will want to stay here, if you plan to focus on the historical sites.

new old street!. a good street and places for families and couples, if you lucky you can see street tether.take a chair on street, drink or eat and watch people!... and rail bus is really good for short travel!

The heart of touristic district in Istanbul. Sultanahmet Bölgesi is the heart of all touristic attractions and historical venues of Istanbul with thousands of foreigners and locals passing through every day.Walking in and around Sultanahmet area is very nice and interesting as you can come close with something either a historical building&monument or an area.Strongly recommended to spend some days in this area.
:). Great experience! Wonderful people.It's worth ur time - absolutely. Not so great tho if it is bad weather.

Beware of scams!. Be extra careful in the touristy district. Beware when you are buying something, looking at something or simply walking along the streets. Check the price of everything before you buy or order something. We got scammed at macdonalds, at cafés and even while walking along the street. Lesson well learnt! But it's all part of the excitement of getting to know a new city.

Very Crowded, Very Touristic, But Worth It. This whole area is jammed with tourists, but also full of history. Make sure you go off the main streets and wander around the side streets. There are hundreds of tourist shops with touts trying to lure you in and fleece you, but there are also many really nice shops. Distinguishing between the two is hard! Going with a local helps.
Stay In The Heart of the city. The area are located in the heart of Istanbul, were most attractions are nearby, and you have access to variable food cusines and transportations are very easy.
Great to walk about and see all the old architecture.. Loads of shops and good atmosphere. Shop owners trying to get you to buy their items - but they do take no for an answer

Great location!. We stayed at the Biz Cehavir hotel in this location and couldn't have been happier. It is in the old part with cobbled streets and within walking distance of the major attractions and plenty of restaurants and shops. The tour buses and trams are also nearby. I would thoroughly recommend.

Historical Square Mile. This area has lots of fantastic places to visit quite close to each other. There are lots of restaurants and we never had one bad meal whilst here. There is a great park in this area too which is must to visit as its so serene amongst the business of the city.

Chock full of sites. Sultanahmet is the densest collection of historicat sites in Istanbul. Once you are there, you can walk to scores of sites, all worth visiting. It is, of course, a tourist trap. Upon exiting our taxi, we were met by a very well dressed, English speaking gentleman who insisted on "helping" us, and who brought us into the Blue Mosque and elsewhere, and then asked us to visit his family's rug shop. We accomodated him and it was fine, but an annoyance. Overall, this quarter would be the focus of any visit to Istanbul.

Istanbul never sleeps. This area is on the old city, u walk around and find everything you wanna visit, the basilica cistern, hagia sophya, topkapi palace, the turkish hamam, shops, old cementeries, good food, simit bread carts.....

Great Area. Before I got there, it sounded like this historic district would be too touristy. Of course the whole city is full of tourists, but I found this neighborhood to have an authentic, down to earth vibe--completely unlike the walking street on the other side of the city, off of Taksim Square. I loved the hotel I stayed in here (Empress Zoe) and the three big attractions--Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Topkapi Palace, along with the Basilica Cistern, Arasta Bazaar (a small, not-overwhleming shopping venue).
The place to stay. Find a hotel in this area (see Eresin Crown Hotel) and you will be in walking distance of many of Istanbul's iconic sites

So much to do. In the off-season there was still a bustle and bump to all the sights in the area, and for seats in the many eateries and restaurants in the evening. Great atmosphere all day long with cut-throat shopping opportunities, entertainment and much much history. The alleys leading away from the main roads were a source of intrigue. As were the hamams. There just isnt time to do everything in this place.

fascinating cultural area. I loved the sense of history. The people are friendly and welcoming. You see people from all parts of the earth here! I found it fascinating to see historical sites from thousands of years. Of course there are tourist traps but overall, I don't think anyone was trying to hide that. Most things were fairly reasonably priced, all things considered.

one of my favorite areas. Old Istanbul or Sultanahmet area is one of the most historical area and should not be missed. Specially Hagia Sophia, Basilica cistern, blue mosque, old houses, arasta bazaar, grand bazaar, hippodrome, caferaga medresesi (A school that was built by architect Sinan), Gülhane park (a large park), Hürrem hammam, four seasons hotel (it was a jail in the past),spice bazaar.

Pricey but worth a visit. Yes, it is true, all the "must see" places in Istanbul are located here, but if price is an issue, don't worry, there are still a few free things to do. During non-prayer times of the day the Blue Mosque is open to the public at no charge, the Grand Bazaar is free to walk through (you are of course not obligated to buy anything and looking is always free!) and there are numerous other buildings and neighborhoods to peruse and photo at your leisure and delight. There are small markets in which to buy food and even the ubiquitous Turkish kebab can be found everywhere for reasonable prices. Keep in mind it is a pricey place and full of tourists but you can still enjoy it without spending a fortune.

Old City Charm. I love strolling through the Sultan Ahmet area to the grand Bazar, the area is very charming and you pass by a lot of stores selling souvenirs and plenty of places to visit like the blue mosque and Hagia sophia etc

Historical Sultahnamet. This area has many of the historical sites within easy walking distance of each other. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Hippodrome, Basilica cistern. The Grand Bazaar is too far away. I was fortunate on my recent visit to see everything covered in snow.
Good selection of restaurants. Plenty to choose from although, I thought their wines were overpriced so I didn't over indulge like I normally would on my break.

Fantastic place. Great place, all the landmarks at walking distance. A little touristy which meant a little pricey. But worth it i feel.
Only downer, not much dining options.

So much to see. This area could keep you there the entire trip if you only have a few days because there are so many museums, mosques, and restaurants. From the water front the Marmara Sea side, there are many seafood restaurant. At night, many musicians went out to the restaurants and perform for a small fee/tips. It was a fun place to be in.
Always a joy. Always a joy to visit the older part of Istanbul with their majestic buildings and stunning views. The food although is disappointing throughout turkey.
Great place to vesite. Beautiful place to vesite great history in centre of Istanbul city the place more expensive to eat not far from aha sphia

historical and beautiful place but not good price. i saw this mall last month . every thing is beautiful.its far from taksim and its better to go there with metro station(with folikolar then take a metro) from taksim - when you go there you can see topkapi musem and some mosque.many local restaurant , but i think not good for shopping.price is so different and you should to bargain.gold shop and spice shop and many beautiful hand made earthen . its good experiment

You could spend hours here and not see it all!. This place is a must see when you visit Istanbul. There are so many things to see and do in this just little area. Food, shopping and even some relaxing can all be done here.

You must be there. All the area is beautiful to spend your evening time there with a lot of restaurants and cafes. Don't forget it is more expensive then the other places. Even the money exchange rate is low.

Great winter experience. The sultanahmet area is excellent and has many historical buildings , very good restaurants, markets and a general friendly feeling from the locals. The overall view of the parks and historical places will be spectacular over the next few months as the trees and spring bulbs are get now starting to show there heads above ground. Wish I will be here to see the spectacular floral show. The markets including the grand bazzar are a wonderfull experience in the hussle and bussle of the maket place together with the trill of bartering for a bargain. The overall cost of resturants, historical places and markets is in line with any other major capital city. Sultanahmed has a buzz about it when the town is full of visitor, truely a great and wondefull experience. Well done . See you again.many thanks you all made my 14 day holiday memorable.

Friendly and extremely interesting historically. Worth a stroll through to Sultanate. Place a little expensive to enter however it was worth it. Staff taking your money could undergo customer service training.
Great place to visit at midnight!. Absolutely delightful. Great place to go for after dinner to have a turkish coffee or sit at the cafe and play backgammon. Did I mention the amazing waffle stands?
Great location!. Everything is at your doorstep in this district. Shopping, sights, and great food are everywhere in the area. If you can plan to stay somewhere here, you won't regret it.

THE place to stay in your first visit to Istanbul. beautiful historic area that's not touristy, with a lot of locals purveying the local businesses. there's lots of restaurants, the grand bazar, the 1000 year old hamam, aga sofia, topaki palace and the blue mosque are all literally a nice quick stroll away from each other. I did a lot of research on the distance between these locations, it's hard to tell online. seriously it's so central. I may stay in the Galata next time to get to know istanbul more, but maybe not. Love sultanahment.
The place to stay in Istanbul. If you're visiting Istanbul for the first time, look no further. Sultanahmet is the place to stay because all the "must see" of the city are very close.
Top. Worth a go around this region. Beautiful but very crowded. People around are friendly but be careful as the price will also be blown out of proportion.

Beautiful place. You can just walk to most major attractions, at the same time shop and eat to your hearts' content. Lovely park with wonderful sights. Going to other parts of Istanbul is easy with the tram service. Friendly locals will not hesitate to help. My trip was incomplete because of the snow which limited my movements, but I'd love to go back maybe in the summer.

Right in the middle of all the main attractions. My Husband and I were here for a long weekend - Friday to Monday. This is just about the right amount of time to see the main attractions if you go on foot, however we would have liked to stay longer to really explore the district and go to the Grand Bazaar again. There are some awsome places - the Blue Mosque is breathtaking and I have no doubt we wlll be back for a longer stay.

All the sights rolled into one location. Sultanahmet is fantastic FOR A DAY. Visit; see the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, Hagia Sofia, wander around and have a snack and a break. After that see Topkapi palace then if you've got any energy left the hippodrome or mosaic museum. If not, you have no reason to stay here. You've seen it all. As delightful as it may have been, better evenings await you. The evening brings all of the usual trappings of an area based entirely on tourism: overpriced restaurants, beggars (usually with heartbreakingly Young babies exposed to the elements), touts touts and more touts - if it needs promoting like this then I don't need to go there - rip off taxis who won't take you anywhere local (and cheap) and all sorts of vendors, promotors and tradesmen all trying to separate you from your money. Don't get me wrong. I really enjoyed the history, the architecture, the culture and the fusion of East and west. What I don't like is being ripped off. I could compare it to the west end of london or any other metropolis in this respect, BUT this is not the centre of the city. My biggest issue with the old town is the lack of reinvestment. I am aware of a number of refurbishment works underway but outside of the actual Sultanahmet square where all is neat and tidy, the side road pavements are at times impassable due to the poor condition of the pavements, the bags of rubbish piled up, the encroaching shop fronts or the presence of touts or street vendors. To walk in the road in the face of badly driven traffic (specifically the taxis) is to look the reaper in the eye, so not an option to be taken lightly! It's not just that but to walk to the grand bazaar over irregular pavements littered with pot holes, protruding LETHAL metalwork, sacks of cat infested garbage and NO street lighting in the pitch black, snowing, January skies left us bruised, hobbling, tired and pissed off. When we got there is was far from worth the misadventure. Again - don't get me wrong! The sites here and the treasures contained within are beyond compare. See them. Enjoy them. Don't stray off the beaten track and then go somewhere more conducive to a great evening, like the new town!There are a few bars dotted around but they are more cafe style bistros. We ventured around a few behind the palace area but most were empty or closed. One we ventured into was very welcoming but within five minutes the owner was trying to coerce us into taking tours, boat trips (-9 in a gale) or shopping excursions. This proved to be a theme with the businesses in this area and while I do not knock someone for being enterprising in a tourist trap I do resent being held to ransom in bars, shops and restaurants a la captive audience while waiting for the sales pitch to be exhausted before finally being presented with my bill. I have not experience repeat occurrences of this kind in any other City. The best thing about the attractions here are the proximity of each to it's neighbour. You can walk out of one and trip over the next. You may be accosted by sherbet vendors in between but they really are a hop skip and a jump away from each other. For nightlife, head north to the new town (not too far north, just over the bridge and you'll be in the right area: Beyoğlu, but Taksim is also good). You could spend all night stumbling from one bar to the next, but as there are so many up and coming trendy new bars worth exploring, we busied ourselves drinking in these. They are slightly harder to locate but all well worth a visit. To sum up, a great area for sightseeing but our priority was nightlife, so a mistake on my part staying in this area on the recommendation from a resident friend. Enjoy!

Easy access to most famous sites. Recommend staying in this area if in Istanbul only for a short period. All attractions - Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Archeology Museum, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Galata Bridge and Sulemania Mosque are within walking distance. Take the Tram if you want to give your feet a rest. In terms of markets and restaurant, the "mall" area is very small - if you are here more than a day, you may want to try out the restaurants near Galata Bridge, Spice Market and Grand Bazaar too.

Dining experience of a lifetime.. We dined every night in a different place and the food was excellent. For a meat eater and vegetarian it is food heaven. The staff were all multilingual, polite and attentive.
Wonderful!. The sights were fabulous, like nothing we had seen before. Easy to walk to everything. The Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar were highlights.
first time travellers to istanbul should stay here. Best place to stay for a first time visit to Istanbul. The old part of the city has beautiful museums and buildings to visit
Also beautiful in a snow day. I didn't expected that I could see Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia in snow. They were incredibly beautiful. It was so amazing that I went to see them again in the evening.

The whole of our recorded history. This is a place to just get lost and enjoy. The attractions are mind - blowing, the restaurants legion and the hotels can be very good. It is walkable and at the end of the day you can always go to a Turkish Bath. Great retail therapy and entertainment in the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar. Mind - blowing experiences at the Topkapi Palace, the great mosques and the many museums. The Turkish people are friendly and helpful.

Go early. This has been on my bucket list for a long time!When I walked it I could see the tea, spices and Turkish delight I was in heaven!By the 9th~10th store which was exactly the same I'd had enough.EVERYONE is friendly and helpfulYou get to try~taste Well worth a visit but go earlyOne of the parts I didn't like was the younger seller comments'Come here I want your money'The more mature or older sellers might have been thinking it but we're not rude, they were so helpful Like I said worth a visit but doesn't take long

Passage through time. Sultanahmet District is a great place to relax and unwind after so much walking. Take a rest stop at one of the many cafés for a Turkish coffee and a game of chess, or be more luxuriant and get all of the day's dust and ware off at one of the many Turkish Baths in the area - the neighborhood is famous for its Hamams! This is the perfect spot to unwind and rejuvenate while enjoying the metropolitan atmosphere.
Great Area. Loved the shops and the food. The heart of istanbul which will always keep you busy and open till 2am

Easy to get around and a joy to do so. Even in 8 inches of snow it was still and really good area to wander round, huge amount of different shops and eating places, a great easy to use tram service which was so cheap and i think in different conditions a really pleasurable stroll, as it was the snow did take it out of you, we slept well that night.

the heart of the city. Here is the old city where you can find all the main attraction from mosques to restaurants and shops.
One of the best places to stay during journey in isanbul

Nice but very touristic. One of the area's you'll need to visit when you're in Istanbul. The whole area is keen on tourists which sometimes can be rather annoying. This while yhere are many other nice area's with nice little shops such as Karaköy.

I heart Sultanahmet!. Let's not complain too much! A tourist trap? What isn't ? I have not been anywhere that hasn't resembled DisneyLand in more than 20 years. Here's what I love about Istanbul, and especially Sultanahmet. Touts, of all kinds, especially carpet sellers, they are smart,funny and hungry and to keep up they have some very humorous come ons. Don't get annoyed, just laugh and keep on walking. Laughing always works, for both of you.Here's another thing I love. Those back street outdoor restaurants, pick any one, it doesn't matter because the food is all pretty much the same, good enough and not that expensive. This trip I sat down near an intelligent,friendly,couple from the Nederlands. We talked and talked, exchanging book and movie recommendations, and ideas. Sitting outdoors drinking and talking with new friends in the gentle Istanbul breeze, does it get any better? Yeah, it does. We continue to think of new movies and book and so we email often.Overpriced hotels, of course. Try a hostel, not just for youth anymore( I'm a 65 +female solo traveler)This trip I stayed at "Antique Hotel and Guesthouse", $20 or $25, 4 bed room with a clear view of the Mamara, breakfast included. Quiet and clean. Take a chance.Don't only stay in Sultanahmet explore the whole city, bypass the taxi drivers, and take the public transportation, keep your money on your body, and do not wear a fanny pack, even on the front, it marks you as an inexperienced traveler. And please don't wear your best, or even any jewelry! Take the ferries back and forth on a hot summer's day and catch the breezes, like the locals do. This is Istanbul, it is beautiful, fun and an adventure. take it.And even though it is the most touristy place of Istanbul, it is also the power spot, those Ottomans knew a few things, the Topkapi, the Ayasofya, the Blue Mosque, how much history can you take in one small spot?

Full of sightseeing opportunities. You can easily dedicate a whole weekend city break to this area alone especially if you add some shopping opportunities and plenty of coffee stops. Take time just to sit outside at one of the many cafes - or even a rooftop terrace - to soak up the atmosphere of the monumental Blue mosque and Hagia Sofia and watch the world go by
Great area. Really buzzy area to staye we loved it. Get hassled to buy carpets or go into restaurants but just laugh and walk by. Easy to get around from here.
That's the place!. I liked the smell of history. There was not anything that i dislike. It was a nice area with full of tourists.
a must. It's a must, as many turistic attractions are in this area: Blue Mosque, Ayasofia and other mosques, Yerebatan Cisterna, Grand Bazar, Spice Bazar, etc
Shopping!!!. Visiting the Mosque was very high on my priority list and was glad I made it. And then I experienced the shopping!!!! Especially the Bazaar
Best area in Istanbul. I love Sultanahmet District, all the attractions are in that area, also the restaurants and hotels, the ambience is really nice.

Ultimate tourist visit area in Istanbul. This is the ultimate "touristy spot" in Istanbul. As a local, when I go there, I always have mixed thoughts ranging from "is this what most tourists come to experience in Istanbul, mostly-made-in-China souvenirs everywhere? But then again, how many experiences can beat a visit to the Blue (Sultan Ahmet) Mosque, Ayasofya, and many other attractions in the area" to "Hey, this is a mini-all-Turkey experience: congested, crowded, filled with people from literally everywhere around Turkey and from around the world." Fantastic mix of history and contemporary life. More and more variety of accomodation and food becoming available each time I visit the area, from posh to how-come-it-is-so-delicious-yet-so-cheap. Restaurants with a rooftop view of the Bosphorus and/or the Golden Horn (Halic, prounced as Halich) are my favourites. If you wish to support the local economy, buying a hand-made rug, metal work or pottery might be a better choice, and staying away from international-chain-fast-food restaurants.

Could get lost here forever. This market is a maze of twists and turns ... you can got lost inside forever. The shop keepers were all inviting and cordial. Assume that everything is fake and you won't be disappointed.

the most beatiful things in Istambul. You can´t miss it. Please do lost yourself in the tiny streets and let go with the croud. Almost everywhere you will be amazed with the beauty of the shops where are sold the most fine seets: lokum and a lot of so called turkisk delights. Andthe spice bazzar and the under galata bridge with all the very cheap fish restaurants. Please don´t dare to miss it
Great area for wandering on foot. Plenty of little stores, bars, restaurants, lively during the evening. Very friendly staff at all the eateries.

Magnificent mosques. Stand in between the two mosques at prayer time and listen to the call to prayers it must be one of the great auditory experiences. The mosques are closed at prayer times but you can go in before midday prayers and it is worth it. Try to go early in the morning to avoid the coach tours following ribbons attached to a brolly
lots to see. man i loved this place. we've been walking around about a week and still there are lots of places to see in this area.
Historical place. I like it ;-) , all what you need is walking distance, from museums to shopping area and grand bazar. A lot of places with nice Turkish food, delights and other stuff.

The Heart of the Old City. The one place to be for first-time travellers to Istanbul, as the main attractions are all within reach, and always brimming with people from everywhere. Interesting sights and sounds, and is especially magical at night, when the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia glows against the dark sky.

The best area to see in Istanbul. Everything that is noteworthy, or at least most of it, is within a few hundred meters walk of each other in this area. It is well serviced by public transport and only a few minutes from the Bosphorous and Galata bridge. It is a nice walk down from the mosques and cisterns via the bazaar to the bridge.

One of the Must See places of the World. Pros: So much to seeCons: Crowds with LOTS of HustlersAdvice: Go in off season. Have a Map and a plan. Have Turkish Lira before you arrive in the district (use ATM recommended by your Hotel. The Archeological Museum is equal to the other famous sights in the district. Istanbul card for the Tram is well worth it.
Magical. I loved walking around the markets at night. The smells was so clean and exotic. Loved the tea shops. Especially Viagra tea

Wander, enjoy, and discover. Take your time here and discover the city. You're going to be inundated with tourist propositions and vendors, but guess what, that's been Istanbul's business since the second Phoenecian trireme pulled ashore. Enjoy it, smile, and keep going. Keep a pocket of change so you can pay for the public toilets. Attendants can usually make change, but in crowded times those with their own coin are quicker.

All the attractions here .... Most of the historical places of Istanbul are here, Ayasofya, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Archaeological Museum, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern and many more minor museums and attractions. Good place to taste typical turkish food, drinks and sweets. If you planning to visit all of the above you may find many hotels in this area.
Best location to stay.. We stayed in this area and it was the best Discission we made, as it was our first time in Istanbul and turkey, most historic attractions are walking distance from here.

Spend time and money !. The busiest area in Istanbul, Walking is the best way to explore this place where you can find everything you want in this city it's is a good place for shopping souvenirs,clothes, food, Turkish sweets even spices... and cheaper than other souks, boredom does not exist in this street.

Everything you want to see is here!. The Sultanahmet district is the busiest and most accessible area to all the main sites in Istanbul. I stayed just 3 mins from the area (walk) and it was safe at all hours. The beauty of Istanbul is in the way she is alive every hour ... Sultanahmet is buzzing throughout the night. There is plenty of security guards around which makes the area safer and you can always ask them for anything. Directions are in clear English so you won't get lost very easily. Wear comfortable shoes if you plan to walk ... some parts are uphill as well and lots of cobble stone like pavement.
Excellent vibe. Always buzzing and full of things to do... if there was one place you could go in istanbul, this would be it... easily accessible by tram or metro....
gorgeous. the scenery at the sultanahmet area is lovely, there are booza (turkish ice cream) stands, a lovely park, and a turkish bath in the area

perfect area to stay. I love evertyhting about Sultanahmet area. There is so much to see and do. I felt very safe wondering around. There are tons of shopping and prices are really good. Many restaurants options with great turkish food.
Close to main monuments. We stayed in this area, safe area. Close to main monuments. but beware of morning prayers. And the tourist trap restaurants
interesting. nice and interesting área full of places to see, feel and walk, safe for tourists, nice specially in the sunset
A Historic Must See. They have redone many of the walking areas and it is much improved. There are many sites to see and historic places to explore.

Loved the Hustle and Bustle. This is the heart of the historic district of Istanbul. Ayasophia, The Blue Mosque, The Cistern, Topkaki and all the shops, bazaars, restaurants and everybody walking everywhich way. It is a great deal of life right here. Even men trying to sell you Turkish carpets. Its just a lot of fun with people watching and good food.

Sultanahmet. Wonderful place , the blue mosque is very big near to the aya sophia church , a cafe is very near to the mosque serves turkish tea with nargile and several things, the grand bazar is very near also.
Enjoyed. It's a very pleasant experience, to see all these historic a beautiful places that are just minutes away walk from each other.

At home there. if you are staying more than a few days there as we did you will soon feel like you are at home. The district is the Old City, the historic district that contains the Hagia Sophia , the Blue Mosque (Sultanamhet) the Topkapi palace and the seaward walls of Roman Constantinople. You have all about you good inexpensive restaurants and a bazaar You can catch the tram or trolly to take you to other parts of the city the metro and any of the many ferries. The fast catamaran ferry across the Sea of Marmara to Bindurma is close by at Yepkapi. I loved the people, the waiters and rug merchants and the other store owners who -- particularly in January with tourism slow -- were pleased for our company and invited us into their shops for tea or coffee. Many spoke not only English, but Spanish and German as well.
Great viewpoint. Liked view of Aya Sophia and Blue MosqueDisliked Museum of Mosaics shutting an hour before advertised closing time
Enchanting. Amazing architecture. Felt like going back in time. even better than the postcards. Resturants serve delicious food.
great area. Great area to stroll around and a good place to start your sightseeing. If the weather is good, get a chay and just sit on a bench and watch the people go.
Bustling. We stayed in Sultanahmet area and didn't regret it even one bit. I loved the food, the local sweets, Turkish delights, mosaic art and lamps etc. Blue Mosque was good. Loved my stay there.

Shopping hub. It is one of the heavy traffic places around the city A good option to visit if you are looking for a bit of shopping experience especially spices or gold jewellery. It also lies almost to the center of all the attractions around like the Topkapi palace and the mosques. If you are a bit apprehensive of crowd and shop keepers grabbing you, then you might want to rethink going there.

The main district!. This is one of the main districts most easily navigated by walk since the streets are narrow. Plenty of places for sightseeing including the main Istanbul hotspots - blue mosque,haggia sophia and of course the monstrous grand bazaar.There is a shop just outside the grand bazaar where you can create your own perfumes with a cocktails of scents akin to any designer brand. A burger king incase you long for a touch of home - I wouldn't recommend it, it was simply awful. Better you take a turkish tea by the inner corner cafes. The place is overall clean and well connected by tram/metro.
History and Great Shopping!. What a fascinating part of Istanbul! There are some excellent shops in the heart of some of the worlds oldest and grandest buildings. Worth a visit.

Fascinating and busy. The Grand Bazaar is an experience not to miss. A warren, large and varied, of everything you can find to purchase in Turkey.I love these type of markets.You can get lost in them and lost in the color, sounds, and smells. Spices, carpets, tapestries, lamps, jewelery, clothes......it's endless and enjoyable. The Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Mosaic Museum, amazing sights, well worth a day or two visit.
Clean and safe. This area is easy to navigate, plenty of restaurants, bars, cafes, public transport and of course the amazing cultural monuments and buildings. So clean everywhere, and very safe.

Great area. sultan ahmet area is a great area to visit but you should be carefull due to some shop keepers goes around and comes near to you and will say i can guide you for free and then he accepts you to buy jewlery or carpet from him

A Good Mix of Architecture and Shopping. The Sultanahmet district is home to several architectural wonders of Istanbul, like the Blue Mosque, the Aya (Hagia) Sofia Musem, the Mosaic Museum, and the Grand Bazar, the Archeological Musem, and Topkapi Palace are within minutes from this area as well. There are lots of good restaurants and bars in and around this district, and along the the shopping areas, the night life is quite good in this area. All the museums close at 5 pm, but most of the shopping is open until 10 pm.
the greatest mosque ever. used to be the biggest mosque in the Islamic word. it is definitely one of the main attraction of Istanbul
Stay Here!. This is the heart of Ancient Istanbul. We stayed here and had everything we wanted to see right on our doorstep. Read more on our blog.

There are some beggers. as a tourist (especially moslem),this area was so interesting. But there were some beggers there following us and asking for money..even though they didnt harm us,but it was a lil bit disturbing

We love it here!. We've had the good fortune to be in Istanbul twice (and would go again in a heartbeat), and both times have stayed in this area. We love it. You can sit in the park between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia, people watch and enjoy a coffee, wander the markets, roam the Hippodrome, make friends with the shop keepers, wander up to the Grand Bazaar, visit the Basilica Cistern, and easily catch the trams to anywhere you want to go. Wandering the less travelled areas - like down to the Little Hagia and beyond, takes you to a whole new area that is just lovely. We highly recommend not just visiting, but staying in this area to really enjoy all it has to offer - and get out and wander. You can really get a feel for the people - they are so lovely - and the culture.

Whatever you do around this area, dont buy ice cream.. I just wanted to share my experience in this area. While walking around this area, we saw the ice cream vendors teasing people around while serving ice cream. At first we thought that it was funny and very skillful for these ice cream vendors to do all of those tricks, but when we finally decided to get an ice cream we realized that we were being ripped off with the price. We thought that this was just another scamer trying to take advantage of us foreigners, but the following day, another vendor did the same thing to us. :( so we came to the conclusion that it is a common practice among them. Literally, a bittersweet experience.

Sultanahmet. We divided to extent our stay on Istanbule and there was no doubt in our mind that the area was going to be Sultanahmet. And what a great choice that was from all the wonderful restaurants, hotels, mosques, palaces on our doorstep. We felt very safe and had no problems what's so ever.

Great area to walkabout. Most attractions are here and within walkable distances. The trams are also easily accessible. Food, drinks in abundance. Beware of touts/trickster wanting to use your lighter etc. This are is also a United Nation World Heritage site. Must see are the Blue Mosque Which is free. The Sofia Hague which cost 30 TL and the Basilica Cistern which cost 20 TL

Its like the heart of tourist spot in Istanbul.. The district lies almost in middle of every worthwhile places in Istanbul especially the Topkapi Palace. The markets around the place are what make it popular as you have so much of options around here from spices, rugs to traditional clothes. The walk around the place will not be easy as the crowd of shoppers, tourists and then the screaming shopkeepers will make it a difficult task but nevertheless there is a different appeal to the place but not for everybody
Crossroad of the world. Soak in the history of this amazing neighborhood, hear the voices of so many cultures, enjoy the hospitable people, and learn about the Istanbul of today.

Interesting old city. The good: History and culture. The bad: People trying to hustle the tourists. It's got some great places to see, shopping at the Grand bazar and spice bazar. Avoid the taxis, take the trams.
Cool City. I had a lay over for a day so I took in as much as I could. Lots of interesting shops and entertainment. The history in this city is amazing! I hope to come back again!

From Sali Pazari Pier to the center of attractions. The tram (www.istanbululasim.com) is very efficient and easy way you get to the center of attractions, SULTANAHMET from where the ship docks if you travel to Turkey by cruise. It is 4TL for one single trip. You can purchase token from vending machines at tram stations and it accepts only TL. It is the station TOPHANE when you turn right from the pier (around 5 mins walk from the custom) or the station KARAKOY when you turn left from the pier (around 8 mins walk from the custom). Take the direction BAGCILAR, get off from the 4th stations, SULTANAHMET after across the Galata bridge. And you can visit Hagia Sophia (30 TL), Underground Cistern (2 TL), Blue Mosques (Free Entry) and Topkapi Palace (30 TL) all at one stop. Please check out the opening time of each sites.

Fascinating area. This is an important area in history not only for Istanbul but in the world. Some of the most iconic religious monuments are here and then there is the grande bazaar. The streets these days are filled with traders , selling everything you might imagine , then there is the famous Topkapi palace complex.
Central and Great Place to Be. If you come to Istanbul you cannot beat the centrality of this district. The main attractions are within walking distance which makes getting around simple and easy.

This is the Grand Bazaar. Must buy tea, spices , dried fruit . Thousands of little shops . They sell everything here . Lots of rug dealers who must be worn down . We never got a price we were comfortable with .

A lot to do here. This is the old quarter of Istanbul but the good thing is that not only you can visit historic sites but there are many other activities to be done here. It is a shopping haven. Good restaurants are everywhere and at night the historic features transform into vibrant nightlife

So much to see!. We spent 6 days in Istanbul and stayed in the Sultanahmet District...about 7 blocks away from the Blue Mosque. This is a thriving, beautiful, interesting, and busy 'neighborhood'! You do not have to leave this area to enjoy history, architecture, shopping, good food, and so much more. Plus the tram stops are just 5 minutes away and you can go explore! Great area to stay, specially if it is your first time in Istanbul!

Everything is near, love it during nice weather. Went to the mosques, beautiful places and everything is cheap and close by. The bazaars are nice. Some taxi won't take you to places because they believe it is close by, so we had to walk 30 mins or so. Bread from the little stalls are not very nice, horrible. Baklava is amazing and the Turkish delight. People are nice, Arista bazaar is amazing
perfect. there are lots of historical places. grand bazaar hagia sophia,sultanahmet mosque,basilica cistern..

if U r in Istanbul then visit Sultan Ahmet by Night. It is one of the Old Historical Areaver lovely Trams are thereso many Hotels are thereHuge shopping Mall nd Shopping Area is thereLoooots of Restaurent with multi cuisine nd specialise cuisine as we found one Lovely Indian Restaurent there..nd Near the Mosque by Night U can see lot of Birds are Flying..This is very new things...Must visit by Night...

Never Got Lost. Of all the places we have been in the world, the Sultanahmet District was the easiest to navigate. We stayed in a hotel in the district, of which there are many to choose, then just took off on foot to see the sites. There are places to see, places to eat, and a vacation's worth of shops to keep a person content. We never got lost once! Everyone seemed friendly, safe and hospitable. It was a truly enjoyable experience.

Everything is close enough. Most of the historic monuments are present here. Well connected to airport by public transport. Trains are off course heavily crowded. There are lots of shops for shopping, number of restaurants from cheap to costly one. Bazars are good option for shopping.
Fantastic. Be it day or night, the place is very nice. There's lots of food options around. All you just need is just walk. And amenities like public toilets are well kept and easily accessible.
Astonishing!. Every little aspect of this place makes me happy! I can keep wondering for hours there without noticing that time passed by!

Easy to get around. For our first visit to Istanbul this is the area we wanted to see. It is really nice and the main points of interest are all just there. The hawkers get on your nerves a bit but mostly they have a pretty good sense of humour and as long as you pleasantly refuse you will be fine.
shop until you drop. shops eatery history the works transportation very good easy to get around Turkish bath's wonderful, city very clean and well kept up.
Fantastic old place. Nice winter break in and around old city with food glorious food. And tea and bread of course. Without fail.

Touristy. Very beautiful architecture but filled with lots of tourist traps. People rather forcefully trying to sell you things on every corner. Also, it is very lively during the day time but quite quiet at night. Next time I'd rather stay in the Beyoglu area and spend days in Sultanahmet visiting monuments.

very old city atmosphere. near the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and former Ottoman Palace, Grand Bazaar, spice bazaar too.
Also good public transportation.

History and Art. Sultanahmet Region is one of the old locations of Istanbul. You can visit Sultanahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque) and Hagia Sophia Museum, Obelix Statues, and stores. If you do not want to take a taxi, there are always trams within the region.
nice safe clean. For a well known world tourist destination, it couldn't have been cleaner, I felt safe, people were very friendly.

Great old town. It was a shock first of all as there is an old side which is very shanty looking then 10 mins away are several bars resturants and shops. We ate twice in pacha once a meze and then a testi kebab.the tram stop is right by the blue mosque so its a fab focal point to use when getting about. The bug bus tour starts from here also. Topkapi palace is nearby.

Old Downtown of Istanbul. A wonderful part of Istanbul, with restaurants, shops, mosques, parks and plenty more to see. One of Istanbul's classic areas, very lively and perfect for tourists. Check menus outside restaurants, and watch for prices marked up in anything other than Turkish lira. Everyone speaks English.
Beautiful. Rich of culture and you can feel the old city ambiance. Everything is there, places to see, food, shopping and easy transits.

Sightseeing heaven. There are so many attractions to view and visit in such a small area you could almost make this area your Istanbul experience. Would suggest that you head for here if only staying a short time and certainly stay in one of the local hotels if only visiting for 1 or 2 nights
Nice District. I loved the idea of walking there at night and being in one of it's restaurants and the hotels are almost Good..

Great neighborhood to stay in. The Sultanahmet neighborhood is the best, and should probably be the place where you set up basecamp. It has some great shopping, and restaurants and is in a great location in reaching some of The major sites.
sultanahmet district. incredible history at every turn… amazing architecture, delightful shops, warm-welcoming people - glorious tiled interiors of mosques and museums

Beautiful place with great architecture. Sultanahmet was beautiful and the architecture in the entire area was really marvelous, from the Blue Mosque to Hagia Sophia.
While you're there, make sure you try the traditional Turkish meze lunch.
Excellent location. This is location where every traveler needs to come and see all the attractions near Sultanahmet. Istanbul is very mild in January and you can enjoy you trip even in Winter.

The best district in Istanbul. The best district in Istanbul. It's very much old buildings, the Grand Bazaar is here, Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet mosque. It's near to everything! I recommend to have stay at a hotel in this district.
Beautiful. The best neighborhood to stay, no doubt. Safe, beautiful, easy to walk everywhere. And there are plenty of nice spots to discover!

Perfect area to start exploring Istanbul. This district is the major place you want to be when exploring historic Istanbul! Around this area you will find so many attractions (mosques, museums, etc.) that it will be hard for you to miss any of them.It's very "touristic" here and if you want to buy souvenirs and have lunch you will not have any problems.You can easily walk on foot everywhere and visit the attractions yourself.
Constantly prestered by street sellers. The area was very historical, but with street vendors bothering and hassling every few metres, it simply wasn't worth the effort

"definitely a photographers dream". Istanbul is unlike any place you will ever visit. Surrounded by a proud people and a city that wraps you with rich history and culture at every turn. The new and old meld seamlessly to make you feel right at home. The main historical buildings, museums and of course the Grand Bazaar are located in the Sultanahmet District. A wonderful place to explore and enjoy. There are hotels and restaurants to accommodate every budget and taste. Absolutely loved the time we spent here and are already making plans to return. Istanbul is a definite must for your bucket list.
Great area to stay if you are in Istanbul. Fantastic area which has everything you need on your door step. Bars, restaurants, the sights of the city are all in walking distance.

Something old. Our hotel was in this area so we really enjoyed in walk in this area despite bad and rainy days we had during our stay in Istanbul. Plenty of ancient places and items to visit and see in this neighbourhood.

THE Place to stay & see in Istanbul!. The historical Sultanahmet area is THE place to stay for the sights, history & majesty if you have limited time in Istanbul. The restaurants near the Sultanahmet Tram & blue mosque & hagia sophia are expensive but a short walk along the tram line toward the Camberlitas Tram station yields yummy food at 1/2 the cost.

So Much to See!!!. We used the Square as our baseline each day and traveled from there. Amazing structures!! And the real treat is to experience the square at night as a simple pedestrian...especially a Friday night. You see families come out in full force and the young people meet up and fraternize. No unsavory characters or violence.... Loved it!!

Old city. This is the most popular tourist spot in Istanbul. Once you reach to the old town, all the places are less than 5 minutes walking distance fom eachother. Watch out the carpet guys around Blue Mosque while you are in Istanbul.
Simply love it. there you will feel very homy cause this area is not known for tourists only. alot of locals are living there so you feel like a home guy for a while .. i simply love it
Breathtaking. Simply beautiful with so much history attached to it. Neat and clean and very tourist friendly. The Blue Mosque was the highlight. Topkapi Palace has some good views of the Bosphorous
Walkable places. Friendly people. Blue Mosque is spectacular, Hagia Sophia Museum, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazar are can't miss places. Just walk around on the streets of Sultanahmet.

More History Than One Can Ever Imagine. Sultanahmet is where its at. Everything is within walking distance. Find one of the many Boutique Hotels in the district and prepare for the history lesson of a lifetime. The only dislike is when I had to leave.

Virtually everything you will want to see is here!. This is the place to stay if you want to be within walking distance of many of the main sights and attractions in Istanbul.There are the usual hustlers that will attempt to strike up a conversation in order to sell you something or take you somewhere. Typically not pushy if you make it clear in a polite but firm manner that you aren't interested.The atmosphere is generally buzzy especially at weekends and peak holiday times. There are plenty of seating areas and well maintained park areas if you just want to sit and absorb your surroundings.At the time of writing a lot of restoration is going on and some has been completed. This area just gets better and better.I have been here many times and never get tired of wandering around and taking in the sights.

walking around the area during the Christmas holidays. Loved the area. Once you get your bearings you really cannot get lost. So much to see and eat. The people and the architecture are fascinating. A must see.

Soul of Istanbul. This part of town is simply the soul of Istanbul. You will feel how the city wakes, breathing every day with thousands of tourists. You will have the opportunity to discover this destination of Local restaurants, shops and historic buildings. In this part of town is obliged to shopping. Plan to discover this part of the city slowly but surely and so you need at least three days. If you want to peacefully meet him then it is January or February.Enjoy and let the magic of history.
Colourful and full of character. Lots going on in this area of Istanbul. Easy to walk to all the main attractions. Plenty to see and do with ease.
Lively atmosphere. Very buzzing area.lovely atmosphere and plenty of cafés and restaurants around.very friendly people. Lovely to just sit by the fountain and look at the majestic mosque(blue mosque)
This is where it is all at, in terms of history!. Loved the area where the blue mosque and Hagia Sophia are.It has to be the most beautiful square in the world.
historical istanbul. fantastic! beautiful architecture .Great Islamic history. very friendly people. all attractions are within walking distance.

Lovely. I like this region so much.. It contains the main sites of istanbul.. Sultanahmet mosque, Aya Sofia, topkapi Saray, yerebatan church (Basilica Cistern), so take your time to visit all these sites in one day.. They deserve
sultanahmet. cobble stone streets full of little restaurants with fireplaces (winter months), hotels and cafes. Old buildings - beautiful to look at
Heart of Istanbul. Like many before me said, this really is the heart of Istanbul, it's so lively with all must-see monuments and attractions! Lots of shops, restaurants, people...

All in One area. Loved that so many historic, breath-taking sites were located 10 minutes walking distance from each other -- i.e. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Islamic Arts Museum (Ibrahim Pasha's palace)
lively. its a very lively district, i strongly reccomend the visit to this area, shops, restaurants, markets are everywhere.

The heart of Istanbul... Hi guys!As all the city guides say this area is the heart of Istanbul. Here are concentrated all the main monuments of the city: Aya Sofia, Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome Cisterna and both Grand Bazar and The Bazar of Spices. This thing makes the area very very touristic so my advice is to avoid this place for lunch or dinner because there are other areas where you can find typical Turkish foods better and cheaper. Anyway about the neighbourhood it is easy to reach from the North part of Istanbul (Beyoglu) thanks to a tram (N1) that goes from Taksim to Sultanhamnet. The cost of each ticket is 2 TRY. I think that it is not necessary to buy a pass becasue this city needs to be explored by walking to understand the real Istanbul. From Sultanahmet you can arrive also in the West area Fener and Balat of Istanbul on foot or by bus. This area especially during and after the sunset becomes amazing thanks to all the different lights that comes from all the monuments that are there. My advise is explore explore and explore this area. All the little streets you could have a big surprice. Have fun!!

Oh thanks I think we are a 'nice couple' too!. So this area is very fun to walk around and check out stores and buy things if you're seeking to do so that day. However, if you turn down one of the blocks lined with restaurants be warned you are stepping into a gauntlet of sorts. You will have to do a few 'no thank you's' and 'sorry we already ate' before you reach the end of the block. However, overall it's a nice way to see a little bit of what the old city is all about. The food, the baklava, Turkish delight and kebap. It is an area that caters to tourists so haggle, haggle, haggle!

Must walk around. If you ever come to Istanbul, number one place to walk around and maybe shop is this area. You can visit amazing Mosques, Hagia Sophia, the Grand and the Spice Bazaar, fantastic historical places, restaurants, etc. You'll definitely enjoy your visit.

Home away from home. It is a good feeling to have while you are away from home that there is another place we can call our second home. The people of Turkey were very hospitable and made us feel we were in our home. In all places of Turkey we visited (Gorome, Capadoccia, Pamukale, Ephesus, Istanbul) there were warmth assistance everywhere. It was good chance to know other's culture and tradition similar to what we have in the Philippines. We are definitely coming back to Turkey.
A visit to sultan ahmed. The place is historic and amazing i've been there four years ago and it's still an amazing place & everything around it is nice

Beware of locals trying to sell you carpet. The constant nagging of locals following you around trying to get you to "buy carpet" made it hard to walk around and enjoy the area. If they would just leave you alone it would have been an awesome area to walk around, explore and shop.

One of the best buildings in the world, but dont stay. I have spent several months of my life in Turkey. I love the place and the people, but this area needs a reality check. Our feeling was that they just wanted to rip you off. Unhelpful, confusing and expensive. Do go to the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and the Topkapi Palace, but don't spend any money in the area. Maybe then they will appreciate the visitors.

Fabulous!. So much to see and very friendly and welcoming to tourists. the Blue Mosque is a must along with the Aya Sofia, Topkapi Palace, and Sunken cistern. the Grand Bazaar is only a short walk away.

Lively in the centre of energy. The old town Sultanhamet is one of my favourite places in the world! I suggest wear comfortable walking shoes because you will be working around for hours exploring all the shops, tourist venues, possible lunch spots!Go out and enjoy, I have been there twice now for vacation, it is so woorth your time to experience!Tip: Take the tram around, it will save your legs and feet from aching come evening time.

A lot of history. The most interesting area in Istanbul. Everyone who visits to Istanbul goes here. The place is walkable. Don't miss the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. If you have some time and want to spend money on entry tickets, Basilica Cistern and Topkapi Palace are also interesting.
Mesmerizing! with all the History and Grand Bazar. Enjoy the walk! and the road side food its marvelous! Be a good bargainer :) for Grand Bazar, but they have some fantastic pieces.

The heart and soul of Istanbul. We stayed in the Sultanahmet District and we were so glad we did. Most of the places of lodging may not be a fancy as in other parts of the city but no where else to you have such ready access to the great sites that we really cared about. To experience Istanbul you have to walk it and there is not better district to walk then Saltanahmet. Be warned that there are hills. Taking taxis are not really easy in these narrow roads although possible and they are plentiful. The famous mosques, Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sophia, are all within this area. Most people who deal with tourists speak a little of several different languages, especially English so if English is a language of yours you can get along fairly well. If you do not visit the Sultanahet District I don't know how you will really see Istanbul.
Very nice, in winter. As everyone knows, here there are most of Istanbul places of interest. I just can add that in winter (very hard weather!) the area is not too crowded and it's very enjoyable
The place to stay. The district is relatively small in area with so many historical places, markets and places eat and shop. Gives you a real appreciation of istanbul and its historical significance.
Best place to stay if wanting to visit a lot of sights. Everything historical is close, which makes you avoid additional costs for traveling across the city.

Pure magic. Enchanting, mystical, fascinating...feelings of awe as you walk back to ancient times, empires and antiquity in a modern city..the unbelievable ability of the people of the distant past to put up such magnificent structures with the resources available to them at the time. I thought I had seen it all in Rome until I embarked on a largely unplanned trip to Istanbul and Sultanahmet in particular. Even the hustlers failed to spoil it for me. I am certain a lot has been written about this place, so I will avoid repetitions. All I can say is, if you have not been, maybe it is time to start thinking about it.

First tick on your itinerary.. Its the happening place in Istanbul, with all the requisites for a touristy visit.food, history, travel, loiter, gawk, snap and yes snooze....you name it. Its all here jam-packed liked the crowds in a rather small place.No visit to Istanbul can be worth a mention without being here.
Best local place in Istambul. This place has every nice corner and nice wakings on the streets you can take in Istanbul, it has all the nice restaurants and pipe places hidden on small streets
All in one. Unique combination the most important historical monuments in one are. Blue most in Istanbu is more beautiful then it's copy in Cairo

Amazing District. love to spend time here and shop at Grand bazzar, eat local food, chest nuts and bhuttas. Bargaing is style and Turkish people love it.
Shop lots eat lots and enjoy the history !

Vibey and historic area. We stayed in the Sultanahment District (Sarnic Premier Hotel) and so spent a lot of time walking around the streets, drinking apple tea, eating in nearby restaurants and shopping for souvenirs. Yes, it is a bit touristy - but with the various historical sites and landmarks that is to be expected. Do visit the Mesale Café right next to the Blue Mosque - we spent many a night here, drinking tea, smoking waterpipe and listening to traditional music (even a Whirling Dervisher!)
Mind Bending. Arguably my favorite part of the city – if you're into bazaars shopping restaurants and culture this area is a must to visit – won't hesitate to come again!

Stay here!!. I would highly recommend staying in the Sultanahmet District. It is where most of the "must sees" of Istanbul are located and if you are able to walk some distances, you can just walk to the Grand Bazaar, spice market, and lose yourselves in the area for a true taste of Istanbul. We wandered around a lot in the evenings.

great place to stay. If this is your first trip to Istanbul and you want to see this historic centre, this is the best place to stay. We were minutes away from the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Cathedral Cistern and the Grand Baazar. The restaurants are a bit pricy, but I didn't come to Istanbul for the food.

A must see complex with a great view of the golden horn!. A visit to the suleymaniye mosques is mandatory to understand more what the complex of a mosque usually consists of! you can see the hamam the madrasa the kulliya...the complete complex is still standing on the hill safeguarding the golden horn and a bonus is the grand view you can see from this hill of the golden horn & Galata Tower. Stroll the calm and residential streets around or keep walking to see the next attraction the Grand Bazzar ( a nice walk through the streets full of markets and mosques)

Interesting. My hotel was in Sultanahmet District so i got to visit it every day.If your hotel is near the main street it will be very noisy because of all the people wandering the streets and because of the Trams and all the cars ( turkish people love to honk alot :)) )You have many restaurants where you can eat international dishes as well as turkish ones.The prices at those restaurants are special for turists, the restaurants reserved for the locals are way cheaper and have better food.

Great for early morning runs! A great place to stay, wander and dine. We stayed in the district as we had 2 kids in tow. It was great. Beautiful and clean, picturesque too. Very safe to wander at night or for a dawn jog (which I highly recommend!) the local shopkeepers all greeted me with a smile and a wave on my runs which was special. The trams are easy to negotiate and the district is an easy ride to the Spice Bazaar in one direction or the Grand Bazaar in the other.

Great atmosphere. Lovely center in the midst of tourist attractions. Highly recommended for families, and those who are NOT seeking nightlife. If you wish to have night life, rather stay in Taksim. It never closes- all night long.

Touristy but brimming with history. This area is touristy and crowded but that shouldn't deter you. After all, most of us are tourists. This area has something to see at every corner. Especially of you are interested in history and architecture. The major attractions of Istanbul are in this district and if you find a place to stay near Topkapi, you can even cover most of them on foot. Or use the excellent tram service. Even Taksim is only a short ride away. As you walk around, keep in mind that each corner has a history going back centuries.

Glittering domes and minarets. Sultanahmet is essentially the "old town" of Istanbul, and is characterised primarily by the glittering domes and minarets of the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque, with an abundance of other places of interest in between. The whole area is breathtakingly beautiful. The stunning Hagia Sophia and equally attractive Blue Mosque mirror one another, and are linked by a lovely park adorned with pink flowers in summer and a large fountain. The park is bordered by the historic Ayasofya Hurem Sultan Hamam - originally built by a sultan for his favourite wife, Roxelana and now converted into a luxurious Turkish bath (highly recommended!). In front of the Blue Mosque are the remains of the hippodrome featuring the column of Constantine, the serpent column, the obelisk of Theodosius and the German fountain. Also in the Sultanahmet area you will find the Topkapi Palace and Basilica Cistern - both of which should be high on your list of places to visit.The Grand Bazaar is a short walk away, with the Egyptian Spice Market a little further away (take a tram here, it's a bit too far to walk). You'll also encounter several other mosques, Turkish baths, shops, cafes, restaurants and bars. It's always buzzing, but is especially beautiful at night when the monuments are illuminated and the call to prayer rings out from the various mosques in the area. As most of the sights are here in Sultanahmet, I would recommend booking a hotel in this area. There are plenty to choose from, to suit all budgets and tastes from backpackers to luxury hotels. But there is no point staying elsewhere in Istanbul, since Sultanahmet is where all the action is.
Lovely. Beautiful area, ideal for walking, eating out, seeing the architecture and feeling the atmosphere. So many restaurants and hotels.

Plenty to See. This is the place to come to see historic, iconic symbols of Istanbul, such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace and much more. Restaurants, cafes and shops abound. Alas, so do touts, who greet you with, "Good Morning. Where are you from?" If you respond, expect to have a new friend, who will walk with you for a while, trying to get you into his shop, which usually specializes in rugs. A new tactic was used on us during our most recent visit when a man said, "Come into my shop so I can rip you off." We had to laugh, but we generally ignore these guys.The area is easily accessible by tram, so there is no problem getting here from other parts of the city. But we usually stay in Sultanahmet during our visits to Istanbul. That allows us to walk around not only during the day but at night when the tourists and tour buses are long gone. It is a special treat to have the place mostly to ourselves and it is absolutely safe.There are many nice hotels and B&Bs here. This time, we stayed in the Esans Hotel, a renovated Ottoman mansion with eight rooms, just a 5-minute walk from Topkapi Palace. It was wonderful lodging with incredibly helpful staff.The Sultanahmet District is certainly a "must see" for first-time visitors, and it remains a draw for many who have been here before.

Amazing area to explore, get ready to bargain..... Get some tips how to bargain....get early in the morning but don't push it if they are still cleaning the front of their shops they are not ready to negotiate with you, Monday mornings are the best, if you are the first customer they will do the impossible to close a deal! got an amazing price on an area rug and paid 35% of what he initially asked me for!. Kept coming back by 9-9:30 am and scored big! It is their culture to negotiate, don't show to much interest and keep money hidden in other places so you can play it is what you have left.......

Enchanting. the best part about Istanbul is, most top attractions are located here. we covered Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi palace and the Park here. very lively place buzzing with energy. beautiful cafes and restaurants. it is well connected by trams. both grand bazaar and spice bazaar are only few stops away.
a lovely old town area. this is a beautiful area to stay, close to the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque, with trams nearby to take you further afield.
A delightful part of the world. Great area felt Italian in its layout. Wonderful restaurants and so much to see and do. Will happily revisit again.

Something to see on every corner. OK its a huge tourist area but you must not miss it . Loads of shops resturants and of course history . See the splendid Blue mosque and Topkapi lit up at night in the square

Safe and lovely place. Nice walk, good restaurants, historical place. This is the ideal place for tourists to book a hotel. You can get an Istanbul card and take local metro train from Sultanahmet train station to all the tourist and shopping locations in the city. Enjoy thepublic transport and avoid taxis or ask you hotel mgr to arrange limo
True history. True history, real pearl for past, present and future generations! Must see, do not miss this amazing historic center in Istanbul!

The Center of Istanbul. Plenty to do and see in this very busy district. The businesses are located on both sides of the T1 metro line. There are also plenty of cafes and restaurants where you find all types of cuisines.

Quaint, Touristy but beautiful. I went at the end of December, 2014. It was warm, then cold, and not crowded at all. I'm sure it's a zoo in the warmer months.PACKED with history and museums. Easy to enjoy a walk down a street or spend the day at the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque or any of the other sites. Wear socks as the mosques require you to take off your shoes, and ladies bring a scarf.Great restaurants, too.

Beautiful, historic, shopping and food!. A beautiful area of the city. The amazing Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are highlights along with a well hidden obelisk and arts museum in a square behind the Blue Mosque. Lovely photo opportunities wherever you turn. Of course there is Topkapi Palace up the hill, which is stunning. (Advice:get a museum card if you are going to go to all the major museums as then you can see most of the main things at a bargain price. 3 or 5 days. WARNING, though; check when they are open so that you don't end up missing out!) Archaeological music interesting as is the Museum of Islamic Science and Technology. There is a little road heading towards Topkapi Palace entrance where there are a few lovely restaurants that have people making Turkish pancakes in the windows. They are really delicious and excellent options for vegetarians too! There are also some amazing Turkish Delight place here too. Good place for lunch. Love seeing my food made right in front of me.Go there by metro and tram depending on where you're staying. Very easy once you know how! Get an Istanbul card from a 'newsagents' and top up as you need. Then take the cards back with receipts at the end to get your deposit back.We kept finding ourselves back in this area. Was lovely with so much to see and so.

Amazing historical district. Definitely one of the most important places all over the world. You should visit this area when you come to Istanbul, and at least one time in your life. Full of attractions and there is a story behind each stone.Sultanahmet mosque, Hagia Sofia museum, Grand pazar and Top kapı saray are all in a walking distance from each other.

LOTS TO SEE AND DO. The area is a warren of places to eat,drink and sight see.Beware of touts trying to sell all sorts of things as they are poor quality and expensive. Make time to spend in the Grand Bazaar where you can buy and barter in over 4000 stalls - pay a third of what the seller wants and everyone will be happy.

historic and pretty, but unreal. Although most historic places in istanbul are in this area, once you have seen the modern part and the asian part of istanbul you do not feel like it reflects enough of turkish culture. There are too many restaurants and cafés with mediocre food and waiters waiting out of the street offering passers donner kebabs at all hours of the day. Walking around sometimes you feel as if they don't realize that even tourists are human being with taste and not only money bags. Shops practice prices way too high.
Xmas Break. Fascinating city - would highly recommend. People are so welcoming, lots of history and some fabulous restaurants. We can't wait to go back.

Worth a visit. We spent half a day in the Sultanahmet area - its beautiful and a must visit, especially for the general experience and the wonderful historic sites of Hagia Sofia, Topkapi palace and the mosques. However, we felt the area was a bit too touristic for our taste and had lost a little of the authentic charm you would hope for. Still its definitely a place to see.
Too much to do in one day. Most of the "major" sights in Istanbul are located right here. This is also the area to change hop on-off busses. Eat at a rooftop restaurant in the area.
Typical Istanbul at Sultanahmet. If you are keen of exploring the heart of Istanbul, this is a place that you should visit. Plenty of people, food outlets, baklava on offer, with attractions nearby.
great area. loads to do and see go to grand bazaar but do not get carried away or you will go home broke or credit card maxed out,which so easy to do.

Spend 2 to 3 hours. It's the market area. You can stroll around 3 to 4 hours. There are variety of stores, cafes. Cafes have cheaper food prices 10-15 Lira you can have a doner and drinks. There are cheap dresses 10 Lira, T shirts avialble. Its good to walk inside and look around. If you are taking a taxis be aware of touts. Particulalry when you are paying the money. show them and tell them. else if you will give 50 lira then will take immedialty show you a 5 lira saying you have given and will demand more.So be cautious while giving.

Here are some advice and tips. We stayed at some hotels in the sultanahmet area for about 9 days and it was overall an awesome experience. If you stay in this area, it is touristy enough for you to be touted everytime you walk past a restaurant, but none of them have proven offensive, so don't be afraid. Just say no thanks, if you don't want to enter. 95% of the people we meet are generally amicable and honest, some even endearing, but there are some restaurants that may try to fudge your bill at the end, adding an extra dish hoping that you will not notice.
