Or send you dishes you did not order, feigning miscommunication if you call it out. Just be firm when you are ordering, ask them to repeat your order. We encountered this cases only in restaurants, both of them selling fish which are seasonal prices and hence easy to fudge.Restaurants near the attractions costs twice as much as those away from it. You can get pretty good food for 20 lira per person, large portions. Those near attractions or good hotels tend to have routers and cost more, including tips. Do not be afraid to venture out of the immediate area for cheaper and good food! Istanbul is very safe, from our 9 days here.For attractions start the day early, like at 8 or 9' and you will be able to avoid the crowd that usually comes at about 10. Or you can visit during off peak season, the winter months, but not during Christmas, year end period. Use the tramvay to get to most places, it only costs 4 lira per trip, no matter the distance. No need to tap out when you leave the station. Istanbulkart gets you a discount to 1 or 2 lira per trip, but you can't get the card at every station. God bless and enjoy!

Whole day of exploring. This whole area is full of restaurants, must do sites, shopping, people watching and is very easy to walk. Istanbul is very much a clean city and this area is kept clean. Most interesting sites are free, souvenirs can be bartered for.

Visit to Istanbul/Sultanahmet District. Stayed in the Sultanahmet district in Istanbul two times during our trip to Turkey Summer of 2014.First stay was on 8/24 - 8/26/14 at the Hotel Basileus, which was an awesome hotel and blocks away from the major tourist attractions in old Istanbul. The second stay was 9/12 - 9/16/14 in Sultanahmet at the Angel's Home Hotel, which was also conveniently located to the Grand Bazaar, spice Market and the various mosques.
Historical treasures. So many things to do-area includes Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Cistern, Grand Bazaar, and city wide tram

Top Area when you visit. This is the center of Istanbul's Old City. You can see the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Palace, the Cistern, and so many other things. The old Roman Hippodrome was also here 500 years ago and the history of the chariot races, and the remaining artifacts were very interesting to me. The area also has a lot of friendly cats and dogs which love to be fed. Bathrooms are 1 TL, but are clean.
Take the time to walk around - rewarding. Many, many restaurants and interesting shops. A new surpise around every corner. Walk around quite a bit before trying the tram and you will be rewarded.

The Old City. A hive of activity day and night from the Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, the Ayasofa Hammam, gardens, parks, restaurants, and and abundance of colour and texture where ever your eye rests.Very safe to walk around.
Very nice area. A lot of historic places here! We enjoyed the walks in the area after sunset - the place looked magical!

History and art with culture. In a very small area you can really experience the long and interesting history of Istanbul. Use the tram system to get around Istanbul but go on foot for the full experience of the Sultan Ahmed district or you will miss the traditional restaurants and the small by ways.

Everything in Istanbul is centered from here. If you come to Istanbul, Sultanahmet is the heart and soul of the city, both old and new! All of the historic landmarks and attractions (Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, etc) are all located here. The streets are kept clean and all business here caters to travelers from carpet stores to restaurants. We stayed in a hotel one block away from the Blue Mosque and walked to everything we wanted to see. The Grand Bazaar was a ten minute walk away while the Egyptian Market was only twenty minutes away. We also had a wonderful view of the Sea of Marmara from our hotel. My only complaint is that sidewalk salesman, who stand outside their business courting you, are very good at what they do. They are extremely good on using Western "niceness" to their advantage. If you are not interested in a carpet, say "no thanks" and move on; otherwise, you can spend a significant amount of time having tea in establishments you had no desire to visit in the first place.

BEST LOCATION. All the monuments are very close by, also tram, ferry to Vosporos and train is very close. A lot of restaurants wih trtaditional Turkish receipes are around the area and of course Vosporos brigde is in walking distance
Euphoric Sultanhamed area of Istanbul. This historic area has everything that a visitor looks for, history, entertainment, food and friendliness of locals.
good market, great location. Fantastic place to go . We had a very good time here and we felt it was very authentic. Walking distance to many things

Very Busy, But Do Not Over Look. Very busy, over-crowded, and vibrant. Visited by both tourists and locals alike. It could be quite overwhelming on the first day because of how busy it is. But this place should not be overlooked. You have to visit it at least once during your Istanbul trip.
Elegant, clean, historic with plenty of shopping and food outlets.. Absolutely loved the pebbled streets, the historic tram, the cleanliness , the Baklawa shops displays, and the overall atmosphere.

Great Location. I liked staying in the Sultananmet District because it is within walking district of everything: restaurants, historical sites, the Grand Bazaar and the Blue Mosque. However one must be VERY aware and sensitive to many "cons" that locals have of getting you to purchase over-priced items from the many stores than line the streets and small souks in the area.

Sultanhamet is so much what defines Istanbul. Many of the must seen attractions in Istanbul are found in Sultanhamet so you cannot avoid it. It is imperative however that you walk the small streets, get lost to be found again to discover a slightly less commercial but fascinating part of this wonderful neighborhood!

Over-touristed. The Sultanahmet District is the old town of Istanbul and is, in my opinion, now a mainly tourist district that doesn't represent the contemporary city. The overall feel of the area, sadly, is a theme park version of Turkey during the Ottoman period. If you are looking to experience the 'real' Istanbul, rather than ticking off a checklist of famous tourist attractions, I would travel further afield. Most of the shops and facilities in the area are selling to tourists, e.g. souvenir shops, 'real Turkish baths', bubble pipe cafes, belly dancing, kebab restaurants, blokes selling carpets, etc. etc. There is also, as others have reported, a lot of touting and street selling - not all of it by humans. Yes, even the famous stray dogs and cats of Istanbul also have their own begging pitches (if you're a dog lover, you can watch them moving 'pitch' as the attractions open and shut).Modern Istanbul is predominantly across the river in Beyoglu. We found better souvenirs around the Galata Tower. If you want to shop for brands then the area south of Taksim Square is also excellent. There are also fascinating, but less touristy, sights in the new part of the city such as the military museum - which is huge - and the Galata Tower, which has amazing views of the Golden Horn. And, yep, you won't get bothered by one tout or carpet seller...
If you did not visit Sultanahmet, you did not visit Istanbul!. Definitely hart if Istanbul, beware of tricky locals trying to sell you cheep tickets to Sultanahmet Camii.
Plenty to see. This area has many old buildings, restaurants, and shops. Well connected to other parts of Istanbul with the Metro.

Basic meeting place during walk time!. Sultanahmet District is the main area that we visitited again and agian and again…Is the place were all the tourists meet and nearby you can find AyiaSofia, Blue Mosk, Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, Agia Eirini and much much more.The Tram T1 is the easiest and chepiest way to go. With the Instabulcard it cost 2,15TL and if you use the tram in a short period of time (i think 1 hour) the next fare costs only 1,45 TL
Tourist Infestation. This historic district has been destroyed by mass tourism. Don't stay in this district. Try to see the mosques and museums on slow days. Don't eat here.

Fascinating. An area of considerable charm and style, it is full of hotels yet somehow manages not to feel too touristy. Very close to the old city sites of historic interest, it is worth using this area as a base for any visit

buzzing with activity. Its a overload to the senses at some points,but so worth it. You feel the buzz and you are aware of all the history around you. Some people might think its magical. Takecthe time and wonder around ,there is sooo much to see and experience
Heart of Istanbul. Everything a visitor should visit and enjoy is here in Sultanahmet. The streets are lovely, many boutique hotels and nice places to eat.

Delicious place. If you have a chance to visit there you can find too much turkish delight round. And the historical places are nearly all round there. You gonna like this place. if you go there follow the smell of coffee and you gonna find Mehmet Efendi. He has the best coffee so you can buy some of them. I think coffe is the best gift

Heart of Istanbul. Sultanahmet is magical and almost untouched by passing time. It is a perfect location not only for the sights, but also to stay - if you would like to experience the real spirit of the old town/ city.
nice area - good sight lines. Lots to see and experience. Lots of spots to take interesting photos. The tourist information office had a super book about Istanbul.

lively and fun. I could have just as easily titled this review "touristy and annoying" but that would not be fair to the guys who are working the curbs trying to make a living. They want you to eat in their restaurant, buy their carpets and take their brochures.....sure there are a lot of them and sure they can be aggressive, but that is the vibe...hustle and bustle. Enjoy the ride! After all you are probably a tourist if you are there so why resent the tourist vibe?

Wonderful area to shop and eat. My wife and I spent three days in the Sultanahmet District. We stayed at the Empress Zoe Hotel right in the heart of the area (highly recommended). There are literally hundreds of shops, restaurants, and bars as well as many of the historical sights you will want to see. There are lots of hotels and hostes in a variety of price ranges, starting as low as 15 euros if you are the young adventurous type. At the other end is the Four Seasons. It is definitely worth spending at least a full day in this area, and you could easily spend 2 or 3 days, like we did. Besides the restaurants, there is a wonderful little cooking school (Cooking Alaturka) where you can learn to make some of that delicious Turkish food.

Old world charm. The place feels like it is from long ago with little, small shops along each block selling a variety of items from souvenirs and clothing to carpets and ceramics. There are many small "markets" around which are more or less convenience stores. However, while it is not over-commercialized, it is difficult to find everyday conveniences like a drug store...especially on Sundays!

For 1st time visitors. Sultanahmet is a very good starting point esp for first-time visitors. Yes, there is a lot to criticize but it's a vibey area and one of the only central places with affordable accommodation compared to the rest of Istanbul. Everything is within walking distance incl the main sights, other parts of Istanbul and loads of eating places. Yes it's tourist-trapp-ish but it's a good basis from where you can explore Istanbul and see loads. At night you are within a stone's throw from bars, restaurants etc although the food & drinks are overpriced for what you get and the quality not up there.

True essence of Istanbul. The whole area is beautiful and you must make sure to have time to explore the streets and wander the winding paths around the mosques as around every corner there is something new. You must be prepared to wave aside the numerous shopowners or restaurant owners who will approach you.

Secrets on the traditional path. While the Sultanahmet Square is a not to be missed joy in Istanbul, don't miss a few highlights off the main plaza for exquisite photos and the understanding of Byzantine and Ottoman Culture. Head to the Marmara Sea side of the old Hippodrome, head left i.e. southeast down a small grade and enter NAKKAS a rug store with a phenomenal underground storage, one of the only remaining cellars from the Byzantine Palace Complex not destroyed by, Sultan Ahmed, when he built his mosque. Peaceful, ancient and serenely quiet, enjoy your time in pure silence...Venture around west to see the curvature of the old Hippodrome, where you can still see the elegant arches, masterfully crafted standing in time, and a few filled with bricks. Imagine this was the south curve of the hippodrome where, if inside, thousands cheered while chariots, horses, or gladiators and took hairpin chances for glory around the stellae.Having this small part of Byzantium, where you can create your own story, staring so closely, without recognition, is one of the true wonders of ancient Constantinople.

As a tourist stay here!. Think nowhere but to stay here if you are a tourist in Istanbul.All the attarctions are closeby within walking distance.There are also variety of foods available on streets as well as many types of restuarant.Only thing is the tourist agents haggle you like anything so best is to say you have already done it and they go away.You should wear good walking shoes and be careful with money.

A great place to visit for Tourist. What's good: Definitely a visit for tourists for the architecture, people and food. Of the attractions, the grand bazaar and the blue mosque are better known.What's bad: It is of course too touristy, with prices tagged to the locals' expectations. Beyoglu would be a better place to stay and to begin Istanbul with.

The only place to base your first trip. You are right in the middle of it, the call to prayer from 2 maybe more mosques was beautiful (I even learned to sleep through the early am one). No need for cabs, just comfortable shoes and you will keep busy for many days. This is where all the important sights are. Pace yourself!

Amazing architecture and ambiance. You can easily spend several days here just visiting the many places to see.The Blue Mosque is free - wear shoes with socks or bring something to put on your feet as all mosques require you to take off shoes, and for women I advise you to bring a square or most will provide you with some fabric.The Hagia Sofia - expensive but I definitely believe it is worth it. A bit of a shame that it was under renovations but slowly walking around and admiring the history and differences between the Catholic side of its history and the Muslim side is really interesting.Other than the 2 main places I would recommend walking around, seeing the other main sights such as the Suleymaniye Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace (no real need to pay to go in, walking around the grounds is great).
Walking in the Sultanhamet neighborhood. Must see visits....the Hagia Sophia museum (formerly a cathedral and then mosque) the Blue Mosque, the Cisterns, the Grand Bazaar and Topkapi Palace

Lively and full of great places. It is a lively place with a lot of good restaurants and lovely shops. Attractions, like Ayasofya, the Blue Mosque, the Sunken palace and Cemberlitas are in there. The tram line that goes through here gets you to anywhere important on the Golden Horn part or the Beyoglu part. The streets are clean and are full of these small cart vending simit/pogaca/kestane/corn. Worths to see and try!
This wonderful place. I will stay in this historic area if I am fortunate enough to re-visit Istanbul. Everything about the area is enjoyable.
very nice location. very nice location to spend your day and it's easy to travel to any where in Istanbulwe like it very very much

Amazing. Again very clean and organised. During years Westerners ready and study classic history. Something that surprised me was the tolerance and respect environment. Hagia Sophia for example is not a mosque, but a museum which is a clear sign of respect to and tolerance to all visitors, in particular us as Christians.

Must Do!. I cannot imagine a tourist who does not visit this area which is the heart of the "big" attractions. However, for a more interesting experience, plan to sit in the Sultanahmet park just before prayers and listed to the haunting voices from three different mosques.

Heart and Soul of Istanbul. out of our 8 days stay at Istanbul, we visited Sultanahmet district on 7 days!! It is so full of life, great food, monuments and mosques, shops and almost everything!! The place is great during the day and in night, sunshine or raining, weekdays or weekends. It is so well connected by tram, if you are around Taksim Square then you can take the funicular from Taksim to Kabatas and then tram to Sultanahmet. Just stroll around the streets and experience it!! Loved it truly!!

Wonderful Istanbul. Had an amazing time in Istanbul despite the fact that my baggage was delayed and had to bear the cold weather without my winter jacket, but I enjoyed much the beautiful architectures, the breezy weather and the food. Sultanahmet is a place where you can find the famous landmarks of Istanbul, about 20 mins walk from Laleli, the place where I stayed. As a solo traveler, its best to stay around Sultanahmet district, coz most of the tourist attractions are just around the area and its is very safe to walk at night. Bosphorous Cruise is a must coz you get to see Europe and Asia continents. Pierre Lote also is worth to visit coz it is overlooking some parts of Istanbul. Great food, friendly people, such a beautiful country!

Beautiful Istanbul. Had a great time in Istanbul, such a beautiful country. Sultanahmet is a place where you can see the famous Landmarks of Istanbul. About 20 mins walk from Laleli, the place where I stayed. As a solo traveler, its best if you stay around Sultanahmet area coz most of the tourist attractions are there. Very safe to walk at night. Plenty of restaurants around the area, Mc Donalds, Starbucks etc. Bosphorous Cruise is a must coz you get to see the Europe and Asia Continents. Lovely people, great food, nice weather above all, a beautiful Country!

easy to explore, safe and entertaining. this area of Istanbul is where most tourists would end up staying/visiting as it has all the main attractions and many restaurants. it is easy to explore on foot and by tram. there are many shops, sweet shops, good restaurants and dance shows hidden in the alleys. as there are always tourists aroun it feels safe. but to get a feel of the true local area of istanbul you would have to get out.
Friendly neighbourhood. Friendly people in shops and cafes and felt safe enough to go for a walk late a night by myself. I got a very peaceful and historic feeling from the city

Just get lost :). Get lost, be found! No need to know exactly what you're looking at, spend some spare time to watching the old world passing through your eyes. Yet, please ignore street sellers who are trying to ruin your adventures!

For atmosphere the best. This district us the main area where the grand bazaar is. You must take a couple of days to go thru the bazaar at least it's too big. All the major mosques are in this location a must see. Must try to make it for Friday lunch prayer if you want to see it coming to life. Take the time to walk all around the streets follow the tram line as there is little markets everywhere. We stayed 2 weeks not nearly enough to see this beautiful city. Then source out a beautiful Resturant to have your dinner that evening as it never sleeps. Just a mezmorizing city.

The Soul of Istanbul. If you can only visit one district in Istanbul, this is it. All the famous landmarks are here (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Basilica Cisterns) and one of the top 25 bakeries in the world--Hafiz Mustafa--is situated in Sultanamet, although they have many locations now. To see all the sites, purchase an IstanbulKart from the tram station yellow machines for 10 Liras (6 liras for the card and 4 liras in ride credit). Each ride costs 2.15 liras and 1.45 liras per transfer (from a bus to a tram, for example), as opposed to 4 liras without this card. Simply scan your card to get into a tram or metro station and the fare is automatically deducted from your acct, making it quick, easy, and cheap to travel around town. The T1 tram line will get you to all the major landmarks: the Grand Bazaar stop is Beyazit-Kapali Carsi, the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Basilica Cisterns are all near the Sultanamet stop, and the Spice Market is near the Eminonu stop. Just hop on and hop off where ever you wish and enjoy the heart of Istanbul.

The heart of historic Old Istanbul. Here are the best Istanbul Sights. You have to visit Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Basilica Cistern, Istanbul Archaeology Museum, Byzantine Hippodrome. Old wooden buildings are hotels now. Very good city transport. Polite people. Great food. Spirit of Ottomans empire

Home of Most of Istanbul's "Must Sees". Sultanahmet is touristy but with good reason. Most of Istanbul's "must see" sites are centrally located within the easily walkable district allowing you to accomplish much in a short time. With advanced tickets, you can see the Basilica Cistern, the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, and Topkapi Palace in a day. Depending on crowds and seasonal hours, you might even be able to squeeze in the Grand Bazaar. Sultanahmet is clean and felt quite safe to walk at night as a solo female. Other popular neighborhoods like Eminonu and Sirkeci are easily accessible by tram.

Fantastic. Sultanahmet is the place to stay if you are visiting Istanbul. Will be very close to many of the city attractions like Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque etc ... You will also find plenty of restaurants for lunch or dinner serving nice turkish food, Hotels, Hostels, take away kebabs, starbucks, cafes, ATMs, public toillets and the Tram line, that can take you to and from the airport and other attractions like the Galata Tower and Bridge and Dolmabahçe palace. amazing touristic infrastructure.

take your time and enjoy. Most of the places you need to see are here or hereabouts.Lots of interesting places to see and just a short walk from the gardens ( follow the tram line down the hill) which are in themselves worth a visit.i spent a very relaxing day in and around the square and its restaurantsits also close to the Bosphorous and Old bazaar and a must visit area of Istanbul
Great. All the historic things and shopping all together. Lots of restaurants to eat. Just prepare yourself to be asked to visit rug stores. Not overly pressure just say no if not interested
It needs at least 3 days for a full visit. Sultanahmet District has a lot of touristical attractions even if it can be done in half a day on foot. But visiting all there is here needs about a week.
Street life. Walk around, try the cafes and rooftop bars. If possible, stay at one of the boutique hotels in this part of town to get the feeling.
fatastic. this area of Istanbul is full of suprises. discover more on side streets than the main road. full of little bazaars and small shops and cafes
Just walk around, It's amazing. If you like watching people and getting a feel of the city, this is the perfect place to go and stroll around for a whole day, or at least half a day.

Wonderful area. If you are limited in time, this is the area to visit in Istanbul. In two or three days you can visit many of the most famous historic sites: The Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the Cistern, etc. Shopping is fantastic and you can find items at all prices ranges and of all qualities.
vibrant. vibrant lots of energy with a traditional,twist , showing Istanbul,at its best. bury yourself in the history of Turkeyn

An Amazing Old City District. Sultanahmet maybe, is the most visited area by tourist. This is the area if only one place to visit in Istanbul. Sorround the area are Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Tohpati Palace and the Grand Bazar.

Fascinating, crowded, ancient, visual !!. Sultanahmet is a feast for the senses. So old, so compact, so much Ottoman and Byzantine history !!Topkapi, Ayasofya, Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern ... so close to one another. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district and touring the sites was relatively easy. Close by, the Grand Bazaar and the surrounding district are a wonderful explosion of colour, aromas and people. Want great Italian food in Istanbul? Faros is fantastic. Çemberlitaş Hamami was a great place for a turkish bath.

Histoy, Character and Charm. are the corner stone of this area. Once you meander through its cobble stone streets you cannot help but want to explore more. Between the endless selection of street restaurants all the way from local fair to odd combination of foods in some its fascinating to wonder through. Then add in all the various curious shops, street vendors, and general activity and you have a recipe for a fascinating and eclectic area to spend your time in.
Must see place. This place is absolutely amazing and very worth visiting. Its a once in a lifetime experience and the area is sensational. Highly recommend.

Old city center. It is most busy district in Fatih, old city of Istanbul within few meters from all main attractions, the only problem is if you are not in a good shame find a location close to the transportation means because the district is on a slope right down to the Bosporus. Closer to Beyazit is better coz the walk down the museums is not so difficult, and there is tram going to Ak Saray and from there a metro for fast and nice sightseeing :)

Timeless. Loa to see, do and eat... Just window shopping is great! There is a tram line running through the area so it can be linked by loads of other places across Istanbul. Loads to see... Worthy of a visit.

Absolutely everything in walking distance - if you're relatively fit!. This is where I get off the tram when arriving back in Istanbul. Pretty much all of the places I have stay in are right here in this part of the city. There are a plethora of eateries to suit all pockets, and you're close to the famous mosques, parks and markets that the city is know for.Not to be missed!
Historic but ...... You get the feeling that you're just a bag of money to the locals. I liked the history but disliked the constant harassment.

Go back in time. A place that you must see.It's impressive to see the blue mosque and Hagia Sophia standing in from of each other. Both the blue mosque and Hagia Sophia are impressive pieces of human engineering and culture.
Sultanahmet. nice place to see history, to try nice coffie and enjoy in time Istanbul.Place with beutiful energy...
eat outside the area. Food more expensive than you need to pay if you just leave the area a little and eat what the locals are eating

the center of the history. If you like Turkish Delight this is definitely the place to find it, The beauty of this place, combined with the culture, history, good food and service.Great day spent visiting all the historical monuments in this district!!

Great area. A fun area to visit, very walkable and interesting! Lots of shops and small restaurants, convenient to public transport. Great historical sites, Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, you'll love it!

Sultanahmet Area is the Heart of Istanbul city. The best Historical Area in Istanbul a connection of Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque , TopKapi and the Grand Bazaar a real and amazing journey in the Ottoman civilization

good place but very weak guiding system. i have visited this place, there are many rooms but not a description for any, you have to guess, and unfortunately they hardly speak English, only Turkish and Arabic
Top District in Istanbul. This district has most of the top sites of Istanbul - good place to stay - Santa Sophia church, Blue Mosque, Topkapi and Grand Bazaar are all within walking distance.
Grand Bazaar. I love the area with all the shops and kiosks dotted along the area, it is a shoppers' paradise, the sight and sound can be a little overwhelming at times but it is exciting after all.

Awesome and altogether unique experience.... Describing what one may feel like in this area of istanbul is quite difficultthis area is historic yet modernquaint yet beautifullocal people sipping coffee local vendorsspice market.historic buildings,lot many restaus n eat outs City metro train all these clubbed up together make ones stay /visit here worth a thousand wordsloved the aura..loved the local cultureMust visit for those who are interested and mingling up or experiencing local culture

History and tourist hustles, together in one place. The park areas around Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are handsome, but are also full of vendors of tourist guides, who are aggressive in attempting to sell their wares, and salesmen for rug merchants, who are smoother in their approach, but equally persistent in attempting to sell the unsuspecting something which they might not want.
A holy site. you can feel the energy of centuries that past in that place containing all religions and beliefs, a holy site indeed, if you can ignore the tourism business hassles...

Sultanahmet District. So much to see in a small area. Easy to get around and the transportation makes it easy to find. It contains the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Basilica Cisterns, all of which I highly recommend seeing.

Great area to leisurely stroll through.. We thoroughly enjoyed strolling through this area, finding interesting areas such as the street with artists supplies, stationary street, small restaurants etc. it was reminiscent of old areas in many other cities. Delightful!

The beating heart of Istanbul. If you want to experience the real Istanbul and also see all of the "touristy" bits then this where you should go. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace are all within a short distance of one another.From previous reviews you might get the impression that this is a vipers nest of thieves and cutthroats and I'm sure there are some. However, by simply being sensible and taking the kind of precautions which all tourists in a large multicultural city should take you won't have any problems. The Police are very visible in this area so just keep your eyes open and don't be naive.Small cafes in the streets close by the Hagia Sophia can provide a tasty lunch if that's what you're looking for. They serve the locals so are usually very good value and quality. Larger restaurants on the hill alongside the Hagia which follow the tram line are also in general good value but beware of them pushing "extras" onto you while you wait for your ordered meal. This will usually be a tray of little plates and dishes containing starters. If you don't want any just say so, they won't be offended. Service at slack times is very good but can suffer when they get busy - don't get stressed just enjoy a more relaxed way of dining!This area is close enough to the ferry terminals to walk to, as long as you are mobile, so don't be pushed into taking a taxi. If you don't walk you will miss all of the lovely little shops and cafes I've mentioned.

Heart of old Istanbul . Like Istiklal street and taksim square are the heart of new town. Sultanahmet is the heart of old town. Situated between Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque, it is full of hotels and restaurants. Lots of tourists prefer this part of Istanbul to live the history of the old city. You can get there by tramway Sultanahmet station. The gardens and fountains between Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque are very nice, you have also the basilica cistern in front of Hagia Sophia, and you should also visit the part situated at the other side of the square just behind the Blue Mosque where you will find the exquisite Four seasons and many nice hotels and restaurants with a great view on the Blue Mosque and a very nice small bazar. If you are not staying in this part of Istanbul, give it time to visit. It is worth it
Exploring Istanbul. The history, architecture and the people of Istanbul is amazing. You can see the past, the present and the future in this beautiful city.

Sultsnahmet. Have been here a few times however I enjoy this place in the evenings great vibe and some nice restaurants as well
Close to tram and access to other destinations very easy example raisin square
Amazing Sultanahmet. Many, many attractions within the area - as well as hotels!! it is the hot area of Istanbul. Old and new alike in the area.

The tourist area of the old city. This is the heart of the old city and has some of the main attractions. It can be a bit bustling at times which adds to the sense of the city but the touts near the Mosques are a nuisance.
Best distrikt in Istanbul. I love this part of Istanbul. Lots of Place to look at at lot of People in the street. I stay her 4 times and will do it nett time to
must visit!. Sultanahmet District is the center of old town in İstanbul.Blue mosque is here,Pope has just vizited here a few days ago.
Fun to Walk Around. It's pretty lively to walk around. My friends and I were visiting during a tiny bit of inclement weather so there were a lower number of tourists.
Vivid. You can find everything around. Good food (Sultanahmet Köftecisi) , attractions, history. Check out the red hop on hop off bus.

History at its peak!. For those history buffs, Sultanahmet District is the must-see prime historic site in the city of Istanbul and has plenty to offer. Historic structures and monuments are in abundance, and you will find many of them belonging to very different periods of time. 6th century Hagia Sophia and 17th century Sultanahmet Mosque are top sites; many other scattered around the district. Spare at least two days!

Loosing its significance. The major sigths are worth for visiting but Sultanahmet area need to build its own identitiy.Full of Doner Kebap shops, all the suvenior shops are same, nothing interesting or worth to spend a penny.Only two book shops are worth to spend sometime. No art galeris which is a pitty.

Breathtaking views of 2500years history. Must do visits:
1- The Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet) is one of the world’s most famous religious mosques
2- The Haghia Sophia is also must-see religious landmarks
3- Topkapi palace - Otthman's empire palace
4- Basilica cistern - Underground waterway built in year 532
Have lunch at:
Tarihi Sultanahmet Koftecisi
Try Turkish bath:
Cagaloglu hamam

Lots of history, but too much "stuff"!. The big attractions are really unique and set Istanbul aside form anywhere else in the world.
Markets are fun to experience, but honestly after a block or two of shops and stalls, the vendors and wares are repetitive.
Best to mix up the sites and shopping, lest it feel overwhelming with "too much stuff" being hustled for you to buy.
Tourist overload. The majority of Istanbul attractions are in this area-- definitely can not miss this district. I would not recommend staying in this area- seems to shut down after sunset.
Great to visit but a bit dull in the evenings!. Fabulous location for all the historic sites but a bit mainstream and touristy for shopping and dining!

Proper Choice. if you want to explore Ottoman History you should visit this District. Especially Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sophia would be perfect and proper choice. Beside this you can taste all traditional tastes around.

Must see. Beautiful experience! Still feels like back in the days, atmosphere is very nice early morning. Aya Sophia and Blue mosque were magnificent views. Need to come early as queues can get big. Wear comfy but decent clothes, you will need to take off your shoes in the mosque and ladies, bring a scarf!

Just amazing.. I am in love with this part of the town. If only it hadn't rained, I would have just sat in the park for the whole day. I loved this part of Istanbul despite the people offering tourist-y things for me to take part of. I didn't mind it. I loved the streetscape, the tram, the architecture. Will definitely come back.

the old city. Here you will find the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, cisterns, mosaic museum, a small bazaar and restaurants. They are all within walking distance of each other. Lots of grass, flowers, trees and benches to sit on. The history of Istanbul is here!

Fun fun fun. Lots of shops and fun places to visit. This is a very happening area, very safe for walking at any time. You should know that the Grand Bazaar is closed on Sunday but the spice market is open.

Tourist central. This part of town is central to nearly all tourist attractions. That's not necessarily a bad thing given how much there is to do for tourists, but beware of subpar food in many areas. TripAdvisor reviews are your friend :)
shopping. many boutiques for souvenirs ,handbags , shoes , lamps ,food (we loved baklava) had the fish sandwich along the shores of the bridge downtown .
Old city. This area is rich with all the popular monuments - a good mix of old and new. Beautiful to walk around

best area to visit. Great place,,everything close. Blue mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topacapi palace, Bosporus cruise...well connected and clean. Walkable range. Cosy restaurants. Grand Bazaar to boot. Can spend a lot of time there. Soak up the sun and the Istanbul feeling.

Historic Heart of Istanbul. We decided to stay in the Sultanahmet "Historic Old Istanbul" for a number of reasons the main one being its the central location to many of the attractions we were interested in visiting. Also, are many hotels, restaurants and cafes in the area. Transportation is excellent, but we chose to walk everywhere in our five days here. The locations that we visited included; Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, Archaeology Museum, Basilica Cistern and the Grand Bazaar to name but a few.

Best area in Istanbul. The most historical and beautiful area of Istanbul. Every corner it's simply impossible to be missed. Wonderful for walkings, for city seighseeing, for eating and for enjoying the importance of this city in the history of mankind. I miss it already!

Excellent location . When I arrived to Istanbul with my friends we relaised that we were excellent location. Everything close to each other. Hagia Sophia, Topkapı Palace and Basilica Cistern etc. Walking distance max.10 minutes. I love this historical places and I would definitely come back.
good location. its ther heart of the all historical places and you can go by walking from taksim.We have been there many times during our stay.
Not to miss. the place had its own significance,history,culture and beautiful people all around made it worth visiting

A touristy area.. Sultanahmet is where a LOT of tourists go because of its close proximity to everything. If you like Turkish Delight this is definitely the place to find good Turkish delight. Also 100% pure olive oil sold in bottles that are shaped like the Blue Mosque. A very busy area and good public transportation. If you're young you go go from Sultanahmet district all the way out to the airport using their several forms of transportation & it will cost you a fraction of their taxi or shuttle prices!
My best area in istanbul. Every thing is near to you:Tram stationHistorical attractionTurkish restaurantsBut it is not suitable for shopping since every price is multiplied by three.

Sultanahmet. This is one of the most exciting shopping experiences I have ever had. My eyes were fixed on all the most amazing Jewelery displays in 22 carat gold. Semi precious and precious stones the sizes not normally displayed to such opulance. The staff are very friendly and not pushy, in fact very educated. We bought a beautiful Turquish carpet and several local souvenires.... very hard not to ;-) Good bargains. A lot of the Denim and leather goods to be visited at good prices. The Turkish Delights with pistacios are delicious and were very much appreciated by our friends at home. The apple tea was very warming a tasty. We visited a lot of the local sights, this area is buzzing!
Very warming place. This district is the true istanbul. You feel that you are from another era just by walking in the streets
Great area to stay. Great area to stay for cost efficient lodging and walking to sites, metro within a 10 min walk. Safe area, lots of restaurants and historic sites.

Jaw dropping. Very few words can describe such a relevant place in the history of our world. The beauty of this place, combined with the culture, history, good food, service and goods, is one to be remembered forever. I would definitely like to live in Istanbul to experience this amazing city for longer. Hagia Sofia on its own is enough to justify a visit to Sultanahmet. Adding the Roman Cistern, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace and the gorgeous view from up there, you have it all.
excellent location. excellent area for shopping, restaurants and historical places. best area in Istanbul for vacation and family
Walking tour easy. amazing that the historic sites are all so accessible, easy to reach in a commercial city. Coordination with other groups so the lines weren't that long

Great place to explore, lots of history. we loved the Roman ruins dotted everywhere. Spent half a day just exploring these, let alone the Ottoman historical sites. you could spend days doing this, but it was our fifth visit to Istanbul and we still found sites we'd not seen before.
Small, quaint and historical. enjoy the history and exploring around this area - there are lots of restaurants and bars, plus ceramic shops to look into.

Must Visit when in Isatnbul. Its just as simple as that, when in Istanbul you really need to spend at least one full day in Sultanahmet, its stacked with all the world famous sites. You might want to consider not staying there as their are better places and the local public transport is pretty good.Beyolglu or Besiktas would be my recomendations, better resturants, more nightlife and a more local feel espesially in Besiktas
Sultanahmet. Great area, bussy bussy bussy, lots of people, tourist atractions, be ready to negotiate for the price on Grand Bazar

Sultanahmet District. It would be very strange not to visit Sultanahmet District. at some point you will think that you are lost in the past or in the shooting of a film. This is exactly why people should come and create an unforgettable experience.

Best district in Instanbul with all historical attractions. Sophiya Haque, Blue Mosque, Underground Cistern - all in one place and within walking distance of each other. Great day spent visiting all the historical monuments in this district

history..old wonderfullbuildings. Beautiful area. Full of history. Amazing structures. Many attractions close to each other. Many impressive mosques. Hotels are good. You can enjoy the area, and inexpensive.
In my opinion, a disadvantage of the place is some people who are looking for you to log their store or restaurant.
Open Air Museum. So much to see, so much to do... and yet find time to put your feet up and enjoy a drink in this open air museum and watch the world go by.

Roaming the area is fun and educational. There are any number of historical things to see but in addition are the people and the commerce that is going on in the are today. Be sure to try the pomegranate juice squeezers - or orange juice, if you prefer. It is perfectly safe and certainly part of the entertainment - also it is very healthful. But just the people watching is also interesting - tourists from all around the world - and "selfies" being taken everywhere. There are hawkers to sell you anything but there are fascinating things to be seen in Topkapi, Haiya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Cisterns, and many archeological pieces that have signs nearby explaining what they were or were used for.

Old City vs Modern. Definitely a must see for all the historical sights : Sophia, Blue Mosque (I enjoyed more than Sopia), Spice Mkt, and so on... A gorgeous, tranquil park leads down to the Bosphorus, where you'll find many fisherman, dogs, and the typical Turkish beautiful stray cats ambling around the rocky coast. Friendly hospitality staff, catering to many tourists. Obviously I AM a tourist (and speak virtually no Turkish). I spend several nights in this area and also several near Taxsim Sq over on the Modern District. Personally, I preferred the Modern District, as it seemed more authentic... less "hello Lady, come look at our menu"s, and more everyday Turks and international tourists just bustling along the energy of Iskital Street. And a lot less American music in restaurants. The Flower Passage and other small shopping alleys tucked off the main drag are great. Most speak some, or fluent, English. Just exotic enough for a first timer like myself. With an open attitude, Istanbul seems like a city you can just plant yourself in and become part of the scene. However, Sultanahamet is an area I think everyone should see while in Turkey!
very lively. nice, clean, full if history though located in the heart of the city, I liked the monuments, the administrative building which is an old castle and the German founting.

Typical of Turkish ( Ottoman ) architecture.. Perhaps the best Ottoman mosque built by Sinan the quintessential Ottoman architect. The vegetative, geometrical and calligraphic motifs combined so beautifully that present a feast to the eyes.

Nice but overpriced. This is the area that says - ISTANBUL- I've arrived ! with its magical Mosques and historical past. Take a few days here to explore this lovely area. Food prices are much higher here than the rest of Istanbul, cheaper up in Taksim. A must visit area even if u are only in Istanbul for a day.
Old Mtsque. The mosque is close to the spice bazaar. Has lots of old tiles and design to see. There is lots of stores and shops just below the mosque. Nice place to see.

Charming. The place every first-time visitor to Istanbul should begin. But don't stay here the entire time. After a few days, venture over to the 'real' Istanbul - the Galata Tower area and neighborhoods like Cihangir and Bebek and Balat for a well-rounded experience of Istanbul.

our favourite area. It's got the lot, the Aresta Bazaar, wonderful restaurants and shops and historical sites. lots of gorgeous little hotels. A few people trying to get you to go to their carpet stores but that's par for the course in Istanbul.

Culture vulture's heaven. If you enjoy history & culture this is the district to stay in when visiting Istanbul. All the must sees are situated in & around Sultanahmet Square. There are loads of trendy cafes & boutique shops to be found in the little alleys. The tramway & buses etc make it easy to venture to other districts. Head to Eminonu for boat trips up the Golden Horn or along the Bosphorus.

Great fun and wonderful souvenirs!. I just loved the marketplace - colorful, energetic and crowded! There's something for everyone - I bought lots of spices, tea and Turkish towels. The gorgeous bath soaps make great gifts, as do the votives and jewelry. I also took a lot of photos. Who can resist Turkish Delight? A must-see!
Historic splendour. You could easily spend 2 days in this area alone visiting many of the historic sights. Walking distance to grand bazaar.

Expected a More Exotic Location. The Blue Mosque lines were EXCREDIBLY long. Hagia Sofia interiors was disappointing. Men would approach us on the streets and flollow us trying to entice us into their store, which might be several blocks away.

So much to see. The whole location screams history and with so much to see it is hard to know where to start, the places I saw in this area are all a short walk from each other and include The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topaki Palace, Basilica Tavern and The Grand Bazaar is a short walk too. The area also contains some amazing restaurants, bars, coffee shops and one or two Carpet shops!

Much to see. This is a hub of activity. You can get tour buses,visit mosques, shop in a range of different stores. You can sit and watch the hustle and bustle or you can find a place to eat or drink. It's a pleasant, if noisy place to be.
Full of locals and never felt threatened.. it is an amazing area to walk through, offering a variety of things to do. I loved the mosques, the architecture and the people

Definitely the center of all things historic in Istanbul. The Sultanahmet District is definitely in the center of all things historic in Istanbul. We were there as part of a Tauck tour so went in by bus and left by bus. The traffic is a nightmare so I would probably not suggest venturing there without the proper guide or guidebook.

History, great food, shopping. I always stay in Sultanhamet whenever I have a business trip to Istanbul. Everything is there to see. There are streets lined with outdoor restaurants (a little expensive, but you're paying for the ambience and it is the tourist area, of course). Every time I go I purchase one of the beautiful mosaic lanterns. This year, I even found a shop to custom make one for me for a great price. He did it overnight based on my own colors and pattern. Saleh Handicrafts on Mimar Mehmet Aga Street! They are beautiful.

Good for history buffs. An interesting combination of new and old in this corner of Istanbul. The place is packed with restaurants like any other touristy spot on the face of the earth but the history of this spot is overwhelming!
Very busy. Busy but lot to see, be careful too many people targeting tourist to buy nonsense. Nice cafes, try kebab houses rather than up market waste of space restaurants.
General hub. I liked being so close to all of the attractions such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, etc. and the many eating places.
very good district. foods,trip,change offices , excellent sweets,very near to any place in istanbul,metro station a lot of hotels with good prices
The Old Historic District. The Highlight of Istanbul! Everything within walking Distance, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern,Grand Bazaar & Spice Market.

Get Out & Walk. Spent four days in Istanbul & stayed at a most convenient hotel in the Sultanahmet District (Seven Hills Hotel ... already posted a very positive review on this place and her staff!). From our hotel balcony we could easily see beautiful mosques, palaces, gorgeous skyline, and even whirling dervish dancers. We were able to easily walk to all these places and more ... Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, the underground Cisterns, down to the coast where took a couple boat trips (across the water to the new section of the city and to the Asian portion of the city). Although our hotel offered guided tours, we had done our homework in advance and got out & not just saw, but experienced, the city, its people & its culture. If you are going to Istanbul, highly recommend basing your visit out of the old District.
awesome. Gorgeous, splendid, magnificent, to feel the history in this area, to feel the spirit of this city experience necessary to detect it, You need to live it to detect

Vibrant exciting historic area. In this one area you can see the Blue Mosque, the Sophia Haggia mosque/museum, many restaurants, shops and of course the World famous Grand Bazaar which is a 'must see' on any trip to Istanbul. FULL of shops selling food, jewellry, clothes, you name it. Most fun is bartering/haggling with the store owners who are always willing to bargain with you.

Many of the main sights in this relatively small area.. We were on a 4 night stay so really only 3 full days in Istanbul. If you want to see the main attractions of this wonderful city then Sultanahmet is a good area to stay. You are close to the Agia Sophia, Topkapi, Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern and the Bazaars. Nice open spaces with fountains to view the Blue Mosque and Agia Sophia and plenty of restaurants. It is lovely in the evening too when the light is fading and many of the main sights are illuminated and people are strolling around. It doesn't feel threatening and it has a good atmosphere.We were so pleased to have stayed in this area of the city. Unless your visit to Istanbul is for a party weekend, then this is the place to stay.

Rich in history, mind blowing building and structures.. Variety:from grandiose to ramshackle; quirky narrow cobblestoned streets; traffic; hustle and bustle; variety of eateries; old and new; boutique accommodation; everything in walking distance of one another.

The top area of Istanbul and near all the Historical sites!. We are lucky that we choose our hotel to be on this area. All the historical sites are so near and is one of the most famous and quite but also busy sometimes of the week area. It is very well organized and clean.Apart from the historical buildings everything is so near, shops, markets, all famous sweet shops, restaurants and food kiosks.From this area it passes also the tram that can connect you to all the other areas of the city.If you would like the best area for your stay choose this area!

The area where you would like to stroll. If you really want a change its definitely worth it. the whole area is great. From the new Shops, restaurant, you go through an alley and you find yourself in a whole new era. e walked down from Top Kapi to the Grand Bazaar then the Spice Market to end up near the Galata Bridge with a fish sandwich to eat. just passing each street and sightseeing is a pleasure to the eye.

The best location. If you really want to experience the true old Istanbul. be sure to book your accommodation in Sultanahmet. This cobble-stone old city is steeped in history and character and you would be surrounded by historical buildings, dozens of small hotels and restaurants plus very close to taxi and tram transport.

Heart of Istanbul. This place is really called heart of Istanbul, mixture of hestrolical place with religion with old market all in one place .Every visitor must try the Turkish ice cream in this place and the food in public restaurants ( shawarma

Bustling, amazing historic area. Where else can you stand in the middle of a park like setting with a beautiful fountain and stare at both the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia! And lit up at night they are beyond belief.

Everything on your doorstep. This is the area to stay in if you want most of the historical must sees in Istanbul within walking distance. I have a slight disability but managed to walk to most of the sights. The old cobbled paths can be a bit of a problem but with a bit of care shouldn't be an issue. Be wary of being approached by strangers who we found were usually trying to sell you a carpet or get you to take a tour.Make sure you allow plenty of time as most sights have a queue to get in and make sure you have plenty of water to drink.

The best area to stay in Istanbul. In our opinion, we found this the best area to stay, as everything was in walking distance from our hotel (Constantine). Very quaint streets, lined with plenty restaurants and shops.
Good Area. This is where most of the history is.It is a great place to visit. Some nice cafes and restaurants around there.However, I preferred staying in the Takim area

Convenient and historic!. We stayed in the Sultanahmet District when we were in Istanbul for a few days. Getting a hotel in this district puts you at the heart of all of the historic attractions; including the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the Topkapi Palace and the Grand Bazaar. There are alot of restaurants and cafes in the area as well as a number of shops to explore.

Fantastic area. Being centrally located to all the major attractions, its very convenient for travelers who loves to explore the city by foot ! Everything is only walking distance , especially the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia , Grand Bazar and much much more. Loads of restaurants, sweet shops, hotels and many shopping centers all around the area. Bustling with activities everywhere. A very vibrant place to stay ! We loved our six day stay there recently.

Food for all the senses!. The area of the Sultan Ahmet is jam packed full of interesting things to see and do. It is worth staying at a hotel in the area as everything will be within walking distance. You will be spoilt for choice with mosques: Ayia Sophia, Blue mosque, New mosque....to name a few. The Grand Bazaar is the place to get lost with lots to see and buy. Avoid the weekends as it is heaving whereas the weekdays is less so. Treat your taste buds in the numerous restaurants, there are some with roof terraces so that you can get the best views. Relax in the gardens by Ayia Sophia or go to a hamam. Whatever you do, take a pair of comfortable shoes because it's the best way to explore this fascinating place.

Historical and Cultural. All the museums and historical places are in a kilometre radius. The ideal hub to discover more of Istanbul by tram/metro/ferry. The business and restaurant touts are inoffensive and take a NO with a smile and a wish for the day.
Best area to stay. The area is a walkable area, and surprisingly not very expensive. Hotels are nice and the two mosques are a stone throw away.

Everything you need for a one day trip to Istanbul. Very well preserved historical city center. It has everything that you need for a short trip to Istanbul: Landmarks, great views, good restaurants, bars. Easily accessible by public transport

A must see area in beautiful Istanbul!!!. While in Istanbul, as a tourist, you will most likely visit the Sultanahmet District. Most attractions are here, as are many, many restaurants, shops and "must-see's" in Istanbul. Bring good walking shoes & hire a private tour guide as we did for 2 full days.... worth every penny.

Bursting. With everything, incredible amount and diversity of history and artefact. Spent the day walking and always something new round the corner. One tip "can you take me to the airport" may be interpreted as "can you take me to viaport" (a shopping mall seeming unfrequented by any taxis)!!

Nice moments. A historical district with many different things that you can enjoy while walking there. If you're tourist spend one day for this area. If you want to buy some souvenirs or traditional things is good choice. Dont miss photography at there. And don't forget to speaking about prices with sellers ;)

Best part of Istanbul. Great area. With a lot of accomodation and dinning options. Great restaurants with great food Everything is walk distance. Amazing small bazzar and square between Aya Sofia and Blue Mosque.
Great shopping great fun. Easy to get to, just hop on the tram. The shopping is fun and the food is great. Great atmosphere, just walking around the old houses and buildings.

Heart of old Istanbul. Great to wander the alleys and streets of the markets and bazaars. Something to photograph and see on every corner; from the shoe shiners, corn and chestnut sellers, spice barrels and pretzel (city snack) vendors to mosques and flower stalls. Sensory overload --- in a good way. :-)

So much to see but beware the aggresive salesmen!. This place has so much to experience! The shops, the food and the historical sites are wonderful but there is a darker side to it too. If you are an animal lover be warned that there are literally thousands of stray cats that live in this area and sometimes it can be very hard to see. They can be dirty, starving and some have broken bones or are missing eyes. The city is working to control the stray dog population but they have done nothing about the cats. The people tolerate them and some of them even feed them and leave out water but these cats are starved for affection and will literally jump into your arms if you offer to pet them. We stayed in Sultanahmet for 9 days and fed strays every day we were there. I couldn't get over how friendly the cats were. I was never bitten once! Of course you have to respect them if they don't want to be touched but 90% of the time they wanted food and love. Of course you must wash you hands after every time. I bought a package of wet hand wipes and kept in it my purse.Another thing is that there are beggars from Syria who use their children to beg for money. The Turkish people we asked told us that most of the Syrian refugees don't beg but that a small minority would rather make their money from tourists than to work. It's just had to see the children bare foot and so dirty.The last thing is that in the Sultanahmet district there are hundreds of shop and restaurant owners just waiting outside their businesses trying to get you to come in and spend money. The constant harassment can be very wearing and quite frankly it was the worst part of our trip. Brace yourself because no matter what excuse you give for not coming in they have an answer to counter it. Just say no or ignore them completely and just keep walking. Otherwise you'll never make it down the street.I hope this info helps to give you a better idea of what to expect when you're down there.

So much to see and do.... The area is bursting with interest, historically, architecturally and culturally. You could easily not leave this area for a week but my advice would be to visit the Asian side too as this is only half the story.

so much to see. Lots of good hotels within 5-10 minutes walking distance of so much history and beautiful architecture. Locals are so helpful and pleasant. Ladies don't forget to take a scarf to cover head and shoulders in the mosques. Lots of very reasonably priced eateries. We even watched a Dervish dancer whilst we sat on cushions in the open air eating a lovely dinner in November. Loving Istanbul

A great place to spend a day. Lots to see in a small area - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Cisterns, Topkapi Palace, and a mini bazaar. You can spend a whole day walking around this area, just make sure to watch your step on the cobblestone streets.

It's All Here!. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia Museum, Basilica Cistern, Tokapi Palace and the Gran Bazaar AND the T1 Tram line that connects you pretty much to every thing and everywhere. A not to be missed experience. Oh! Take a pass on the rug merchants. They will drive you nutz!.
history speaking. amazing places, history up close! a bit crowded but very well maintained. with good eating options and street stalls.

Like a mosaic. I think is not possible to avoid this place if you visit Istanbul. And is better not to do it! There are so many historical attractions in not such a wide area … well, relatively not wide. There are also a lot of other places loved by tourists: shops, gift shops, restaurants, cafes, pubs, street vendors … It is like a mosaic. Take your time and pass by as many times as you can. All the time is different.
Tourists. Great area for a nice and quiet night out, the area is full of turkish style coffees with hookah and lots of Souvenir shops

Lost in Instanbul. Get a good map that shows all the streets, and/or a good GPS with Istanbul maps before you go. Old town, few street signs. We got lost every night, and couldn't find a restaurant we'd already been to before. Hardly could find the way back to our hotel the first night, and it wasn't much better the 2nd.

Stunning BUT warning on carpet sellers - expecially for Australians and New Zealanders. Wonderful shopping for cheap, good gifts, and leather jackets. However, carpet sellers are to be avoided at all costs unless one really wants to buy one. If you are an Australian or New Zealander you need to be particularly aware as they play the Galliopli card (especially with the centenary in 2015) in order to soften you up with "we are brothers now" to get you into a carpet shop. They approach you, ask where you come from (say Istanbul!), look genuinely thrilled to meet you as they have a best friend/ex-wife/daughter who lives in a named city in your country and converse in a very convivial way...the next thing you know you are in a shop with VERY hard sell. They are very unpleasant when you don't buy. All a shame because otherwise the Turks are very friendly, relaxed, and offer good service.

Amazing place. What a condensed, life filled, vibrant area - never a dull moment. Restaurant after shop after cafe after gathering area - there is something for everyone here. I love the little windy streets - be careful though - they try to (and succeed) take large vehicles through the area.

I like this area. For the first instance it's lock like Egypt (Azhar & Khan Al Khaliliy) but its more organized, is this area Middle East and Europe are meet together. It's a unique mix of cultures. Starting from Sultanahmet until you reach Kabatach you will find awesome places. Try to take it walking you will enjoy it a lot.

cultural aspect of Turkey. This are is where all the must see attractions are located blue mosque, museums, grand bazaar. Make sure you have good walking shoes,, plenty of time, relax sample the Turkish tea and Turkish delights

more modern and cosmopolitan than i expected. very nice area to stay, near the main attractions, all kinds of entertainment... hundreds of restaurants surrounding the area, too many choices, you will not know where to go...

The most preferred touristic place in İstanbul. Sultanahmet area is the main central touristic area in İstanbul with its lots of historical monuments,mosques,museums and others.Here you can meet every kind of person from any country on the world as this is the gathering and meeting point for all kinds of touristic attractions.Strongly recommended to go around for round o'clock.
avoid carpet sellers. carpet sellers etc are a real PIA around here. Best to ignore them. Walk quickly and claim to live in Istanbul :-)

The Heart of Old Istanbul. You cannot say you have seen Istanbul until you visit Sultanahmet District, or, better still, stay there. Find a hotel with a view so you can see the Bosphorus or Sea of Marmara while having your meal. The Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, and Hagia Sophia are all at your fingertips. A must!

many interesting activities. There are so many things to see and do in this district. The Blue Mosque, the Aya Sophia, the Little Aya Sophia mosque, the Mosaic Museum in the Arasta Bazaar (to say nothing to the varied and affordable shops there), the Cistern. This October, several sites were being renovated: the Aya Sophia, the Archeological Museum, the Museum of Oriental and Islamic Arts on the Hippodrome. Most of these are open even while renovations continue. Even so, there is quite enough to keep the visitor busy. Just walking around is a treat. You can easily walk to the Spice Market, the Covered Bazaar (not my favorite spot as it's crowded and not especially affordable), and to many historical places. In the Arasta Bazaar, for example, we have shopped for 15 years with Harem Carpets and have found their prices the best in the city.

Cats Everywhere!. During a brief visit in late August, my wife and I spent an evening in the Sultanahmet District. Interesting vendors, plenty of restaurants, little traffic (for Istanbul anyway!), and plenty of people watching. We never felt unsafe at any time.One odd thing, there are cats everywhere. Each block has 2-3 cats, sometimes more. Just very weird. :)
Best Area to Visit in Istanbul. Sultanahmet District is the best area in Istanbul with Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia Museum, Topkappi Palace Museum and much to visit.

Pure history. Agia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, The Orient Express train station, the Grand bazar including the Egyptian spice section, the old streets, the fish market and I can go on.

How do not buy everything?!!?. Your eyes won't know where to look,you will never be scared for your hand bag or wallet unlike Paris for exemple,sometimes very crowded but no matter!The only thing is:play the game and don't pay without discussion the price they ask but your own price,the one you can afford,you will be more appreciated!!
Hush Bush. Center of all the action , too many tourists / shopping places / cultural centers and most importantly the restaurants

Wonderful place. Wonderful place to be visited, walking distance to Blue mosque and Aya Sofiya, Great area for almost anything who might want to do, You can feel and smell the breeze of history in this city. Give yourself plenty of time, there's a lot to see

Good location for tourist sights. I from the airport we took a train, then transferred to the tram very easy. There are many hotels restaurants and shops in the area. From our hotel we could walk to the blue mosque, Hagia sophia the topkapi palace the cisterns and the grand bazaar. All well worth a visit. The restaurants we found very the food similar, and there are always trying to get you to come in, but we're not aggressive . The trams are frequent and fast. Buy the istanbul card as the fares are cheaper and you can top it up easily. The area was very clean there are bins for rubbish , staying in the area means you can choose the best times to visit the sights.

Such an experience. Istanbul has culture,a sense of fun and brings lots of excitement with so much to do for adults and children. So many beautiful restaurants both authentic and modern, coffee shops galore with any shops with lots of excellent gift ideas

Good safe district but pricey. Convenient location for visiting attractions but things are pricier here compared to Taksim. Even money exchange has the worst rates. But it is a safe district for tourists. Very little shady people.

World heritage peninsula. Sultanhamet Square and district with magnificent mosques, and architectural treasures, St Sophia Basilica, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, amazingly rich Archeological Museum, cobble stone streets and centuries old buildings and city walls in an unbelievable geographical location. Watch out for tourist-trap taverns where they will pile dishes upon dishes without you ordering on your table and on your tab, or for the tourist menus with scribbled on unofficial prices with a hefty mark-up. Otherwise safe in the daytime and while there are people around.
Certainly worth the time. The cistern, AnaSophia Church and Blue Mosque, all of which have long history and are beatiful to see

Best neighborhood to stay in Istanbul. You will be close to everything - walking distance to the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofiya, Basilica Cistern, the Bosphorus, etc. Most of the hotels in Sultanahmet, however, are very small - so if you are looking for space, you might want to look elsewhere. When you book a hotel, make sure that they pick you up at the airport - most hotels will do this for no extra charge.

Perfect location to see almost everything of importance in istanbul. With almost all major tourist sites within a few blocks this is the area to stay in. There are many hotels and restaurants and you can easily spend a few days here comfortably exploring. It IS a tourist area and expect to be approached almost constantly on the street by hawkers for everything from rugs to tours. But it's all part of the great color of this wonderful city

Good Shopping and Historic Area. i m Hindu but i must say, one most visit to all mosques of istanbul, it's very beautiful and amazing...!One must viisit between evening and midnight to see the beauty of light decoration..If you are planning to shop, sultanahmet is perfect area to stay and roam around...it's grand bazar is superb...! we had visited it's gold market which was truely amazing...!

HQ of the Roman Empire East. If Rome is amazing, Istanbul as the HQ of the Eastern Roman Empire matches it history and substance. Having wonders of the world competing for your attention on the same pitch is an experience that competes with The Taj Mahal, St Peters and Igacu falls. It is certainly among the best in this world.

So much to see. Magical and historic area of the city with some of the most famous sights in the world. Also great restaurants, baklava cafés, boats depart to go up the Bosphoros and to the Asian side.

marvellous. read lots of reviews before visit, but still was so impressed. liked every thing I ve seen. in addition, really admired the Islamic information centre located in the mosque, it is a rich source of information and would really recommend it for knowledge explorers
Stay in Sultanahmet!. So much to see & do...even if you've been to Istanbul before.Never get tired of these charming streets, these beautiful mosques and monuments, these great restaurants.
People watchers paradise. Great area for almost anything who might want to do. Great for relaxation and people watchingDislike crowds. Crowds crowds.
Lots to Visit in this Area. This area has many attractions all worth visiting. Liked the atmosphere of the area, the accessibility and cleanliness

Great place to meet and start tours!. We were fortunate enough to have a hotel 2 minutes from Sultanahmet and pretty much started every day there. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Basilica Cistern and Topkapi Palace are all either right there or a couple of minutes from the heart of the square.You will get lots of unsolicited friendly tourist advice from well spoken, English speaking "marketers" for the carpet shops. Always polite, they moved on when we made it clear we weren't in the market.Also, shop around for the tours! Hop on and off bus tours are expensive and not that well organized. Finally, make sure you have a good look at the German Fountain domed structure...what a lovely example of civic pride!

One big tourist trap..overpriced. Long rows of tourists for every "attraction", and people trying to sell you things on every corner. Main sights like Topkapi are way to expensive compared to the value they offer (there is very little real historical info offered when you visit hem). Much better to spend your time in lively Beyoglu drinking Raki and eating Mezze

Nice Place, To Crowded. It is a very nice place with many cool mosques, though it can be incredibly crowded sometimes. My suggestion is that you don't stay in the district but stay in Besiktas or Beyoglu districts which are less crowded but still have many things to see. Main things to see in this area are Rustem Pasha Mosque (must see), Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern (must see), Hagia Sophia (must see), Kucuk Ayasofya Mosque, Topkapi Palace (must see) and The Archeological Museum. Also visit the grand bazaar if you have time or like shopping. PS: If you like ice cream go to Mado which is near sultanahmet tram stop.

One of my best places. I just love this place, I don't know why?! The atmosphere, people, weather, and food all of these makes the place such a great escape from your routine. The food is delicious and visiting the mosque is a great experience. You can feel and smell the breeze of history in this city.

Center of the historic earth. The square is in the middle of all historic museums. One to another just a couple o' mins. Except Topkapi Palace Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosqueyou may visit a dozen of other historical places. I've been to the cistern burnt column carpet museum Hagia Irene Arasta Bazaar and the coliseum. Although you may stick with the top ones, go for the less popular ones. Easy access and less que.

The heart of Instanbul. Where all the main sights are - Mosques, Cistern and Bazar. Compact and very atmospheric. Constantly bustling and noisy and with all the large Mosques in the area, the 'call to prayer' can be very loud
So many things to do here. Lot of shops in Grand Bazaar that you can spend whole day in the roofed huge market. There were so many mosques to visit too.
Amazing Place. I like this place very accessible of many historic area to visit: Ayasofya, Arkoloji, Yerebatan, blue mosque etc.

feel the diffrencies and breathing the history. I like the streets and Blue Mosque,Tomb of Sultans, Kaizer Willem water tomb, Column,Obelisk of the teodious, and many more,,But evening also so nice to get picture miidle of the St.Sophia and Blue mosque....unbelieveble view for memorial as postcard

Enjoyable part of the city. A vibrant and enjoyable part of the city, provided you don't mind lots of people. The vendors are not as bad as some other cities but they do get in your face a bit and if you are not used that it can be a bit stressful, just be clear with them and remember everyone is out of make some money off you so if you feel a bit pressured just walk away. Great area to grab a coffee and just watch the street life go by, if you keep the main areas its very safe area, even very late as it seems to be when everyone else is out as well.Give yourself plenty of time, there's a lot to see and if you are in Istanbul for a more than a couple of days you would want to return and explore in more detail or try some restaurants.

So many great things to see and do in Sultanahmet!. This old town part of Istanbul is filled with some of the most beautiful and interesting sites and activities you'll find anywhere. The mosques are spectacular, the shopping is terrific, Topkapi Palace is one of the most beautiful palaces you will ever see, the food is great and the Turkish people are wonderful. My wife and I had a private guide from Meli-Tours (highly recommended if you are willing to splurge a bit), which added so much to our explorations of Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome. Our guide, Tan, even helped us know which shops in the Grand Bazaar had authentic Turkish goods rather than cheap knock-offs, while we shopped for family and friends back home. The only complaint with Sultanahmet is that it tends to be quieter at night than the more modern part of the city and be prepared for very bad traffic when going to and from the airport to your hotel. It is easy to get around this district on foot to see the attractions and we also found it very easy to use the tram system to get back and forth to the newer side of the city.
Saltanahmet. We stayed in this area for three days...I would highly recommend, easy access to everything in the old city.
The main heritage in walking distance. Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Cistern, Hippodrome, Oriental Express, Archaeological museum and Topkapi palace are all here.

So much to see.... Forget the crowds at Topkapi. Head for Hagia Sophia, Hagia Eirene, the Basilica Cisterna, the Great Palace Mosaic Museum, and the Blue Mosque. A little further out are the unmissable mosaics at Chora (near the Theodosian Walls) which are in glorious condition.
Very interesting. Very interresting but everyone tries to rip you off - even the money changers are way off in this area. Ask the price before buying anything and feel free to say no

Sultanahmet. Love this area, beautiful gardens around all the mosques and public buildings. Great street food, lovely restaurants. Really great place to stroll around and take in the culture of a great city.
OLD CITY. This area is the old city.the historical sites are in this area or close by. You can go to the Grand Bazaar, do some shopping

Miraculous!. This is the place where cultures and religions meet in a blend that it's unrivaled.It's hard to describe the feeling you get when you visit , the abundance of things to see , from museums and historic landmarks to restaurants and vibrant nightlife spots, it's overwhelming for sure.This is the old part of town, from here you can visit the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cisterna and the Bosphorus Straight, this is a must see part of town, the old Istanbul one of the most amazing places I have ever seen.
