So much history within a few feet of each other. Visit the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, the Hagia Sophia, the Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazaar all very close to each other. Area is filled with many delightful restaurants.

Stimulation of the senses. The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia are so beautiful! The architecture and history are amazing. The shopping around the area is entertaining. Venture further out along the smaller streets for good finds.

Great historical area. This area is the old city. Pretty much all the historical sites are in this area or close by. You can go to the Grand Bazaar, do some shopping and once you get tired from all the negotiating you can sit down close by and have some Turkish coffee, Baklava and smoke some hooka. Great thing is you can take the tram from this area to pretty much anywhere including Taksim sq.

Perfect area to stay to walk to Blue Mosque etc. Liked.Atmosphere, culture.
Disliked Pushy restaurant touts trying to persuade you to try their restaurant.

Loved it. Which is saying something since I don't like to shop. But I do like new experiences and like to explore. So if you want to shop, explore or experience something very different this has it all. Take your time here. Before coming it was very hard to imagine what we would do here for a few hours but we didn't have enough time.

Great area. This area is close to Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Grand Bazaar. Lots of interesting cafes and restaurants, ATM's, and shops. Easy to stroll the area and stop off for a cup of Turkish Tea, beer or wine. An enjoyable area and very safe.
Bustling with life!. Shops, restaurants, historical places and landmarks, all in one place! You can almost taste the history of Istanbul! Amaizing place! Must-see!
Sultanahmet District. The whole place is awesome. I cannot write enough. Gotta go again someday. skip the Cab and walk. Do not forget to check out fast food places. Hammams are over rated....

Buzzingggg. Great Food.... Culture... History.... Friendly People.... Shopping... Hamams.... basically for all the good things you must come to Sultanahmet District...it will surely blow your mind away.
Sultanahmet district.. Classical building and palace. and market is so nice.Many interesting things in there. You should go there. :D

Plenty of attractions in a small area. There are several attractions within a relatively small area here, including the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace. Tram T1 has several stops close by and is cheap and easy to use.There are also lots of inexpensive local shops around Sirkeci Station for things like spices and touristy stuff.

so much history. best to do tours by yourself you got more time to explore and you will save so much more money. we found the tour guides to be a little boring. google as much as you can about the area first or get yourself a good tour guide book.

Great area history mixed with modern. The area is great to explore, from the Hagia Sophia & Blue Mosque to Topkapi Palace down to Galata Bridge.. Lots of shops too, for shopping for presents and clothes. Also loadssss of food places, dont be fooled by the first person you talk to, they all come upto you asking you to eat at their place. I usually say thanks and explore my options as there is plenty.Recommended to base your stay, with friends or family.

So many restaurants and shops...so little time. When walking through this area prepare to be annoyed by the constant invitations to come inside the restaurants and shops. Everyone knows you are a tourist and they want your business. They are not in any way unkind about it, but you have get your game face on and put on the blinders. We purchased several wallets and trinkets and scarves, and bargaining ALWAYS worked.

Bustling Place. You can find shops all along here for your doner kebabs, baklavas and your exchange rate. The better exchange rate shop is the shop nearer to the station as you go up. There is also a sultanahmet station for you to purchase your istanbulkart or for top up. There is also a nearby bazaar smaller than the grand bazaar called arastaa bazaar. Its quieter here and the shop sellers do not harass you to buy items. slightly more expensive here and lack choices as lesser shops. Still a good place to go for last minute shoppers to get spices, cushion covers and other souvenirs. There are also cafes located there. We did not like the presence of beggars who will harass you once you sit down at the park ..at first it was sad to see them but after a while it became a nuisance as they can be disrespectful and harass you for money.

You have to experience this!. This was an eye opening experience for us. The city is beautiful. Very busy. We loved experiencing the Turkish cuisine in the little family owned restaurants that are on the street corners. You really get a good feel of the people and area just sitting there watching everyone go by. It is impossible to drive there. But everything is within walking distance.

Everything is close by. Major monuments and lots of restaurants are in this area so all is done by foot. The major space with Church Sofia and the Blue mosque is very nice so as walking around. We had a guide with us which cost 150 euros but surely is worthwhile as we did not have to wait on lines with her. We stayed at the Four Seasons so were just few minutes away from major attractions

best location for tourists. This is the historic area, so the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, the big Cistern, and many restaurants are located here. We stay here, and it was convenient to see the tourist attractions and had a tram that could take you to other locations in the city. Lots of good restaurants close by, small shops as well. It was also very safe, even walking around at night.
Very busy area. This area is very busy with auto and foot traffic. There are a lot of stores and restaurants, and also people selling goods on the street.

Nice place to relax and watch people in the core of the Golden Horn. If you want to sit and watch it all from between the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque and like watching people, come to the Sultanahmet District and its park in the center of it all!We first walked through here on the way from the Hagia Sofia to the Mosaic Museum and then spent some time on a lovely summer afternoon watching the people simply enjoy the day, the sights, their friends and families there. It's a great place to relax and take it all in!

Sultanahmet District. A prime area within Istanbul for visitors to see. Many major attractions including the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, and the old Cisterns among others. Small curvy streets, loads of restaurants and of course the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. The area is small enough to wander around and enjoy on your own, or if you desire more detail about the main sites you should engage the services of a guide.
Historic SultanaHmet. Nice and historic area to visit. A must see in Istanbul. Very accessible and gives you a glimpse of the past.
Nice. Main touristic area in Istanbul. Full of restaurants, shops and people. The annoying thing are the sellers who keep trying to push things for you to buy. Just ignore them.

Beautiful at night, but a mixed bag. You have to come to see the sights, but otherwise it's a tourist trap with huge crowds, long lines, overpriced hotels and middling restaurants. Really the best thing is walking at night, when the sights are lit up, and the streets are virtually empty. Then, and only then, it's magical.
Fascinating area. This is an area full of hills, corners, cats (well fed) and a large selection of things to visit and places to eat and watch the very bustling crowdes walk past.
Break with friends. A fantastic area to stay in. So close to attractions and a few very nice fish restaurants locally so no need to go far to eat.

Just ignore the rip off cabbies and vendors and you'll be fine. This is one of the great cityscapes in the world; everything is here, from the Aya Sophia to the Blue Mosque. We spent a lot of time here on our recent visit, because it was on the way to or from just about everything in the city. Several cautions: don't take one of the cabs parked nearby, and try to ignore the numerous vendors. The hippodrome is wonderful, with hounds all over the place, most of them seen to by the municipality. There are also kittens everywhere.
Heart of Istanbul. The best place of Istanbul for sightseeing, shopping and walking.It is a very beautiful area with lots of things to do.
old city. in sultanahmet there are so many options of restaurants and shops. there are hotels options too. its very nice 'get lost" in the small streets...

It's fun to run the rug gauntlet ;). LOL. Lots of great eats, good drinks, and lovely shops. The only ... issue, is that there are tons of beautiful men who want to strike up a conversation, offer to show you around, hang out a bit too much, and press you to come "back to the shop for a glass of tea" -- which is really code for "buy a rug" lol. Rugs, pillows, leather jackets, glass ware, you name it, and someone is selling it. However, it's also a shopper's paradise, and if you're in the market, you'll find really lovely deals. Good luck!

This is a very central part of the city, very vibrant!. Of course it is where the Blue Mosque is, the Agia Sophia and the Topkapi Palace (the best) and the Grand bazaar and also the Square with a beautiful fountain lit up at night ! Teh most tourists attractions are in this area.
All major attraction are in this area. Great area major attractions in this area. Lots of great restaurants.highly advise to stay in a hotel in this area.
Must see / do. Visited area several times from hotel which was walking distance away. Great feel. Lots of energy. Lots of things to see, do....good food and shopping (if you need it)

Best area to stay. This area is the best place to book a Hotel if you want to be near all the local historic attractions.We only had a 5 min walk each day to all the local sites, buses shops, river etc and the area has some great resturants. Very safe area to walk at any time of day or night.We had a great time and will stay at this location again.Steve UK

The place to be!. This place is THE district! If you want to be in the heart of Istanbul, you must stay in this part! You have everything in walking distance, super well comunicated by public transportation and very calm and safe even at night. So nice!
Great. Faboulous. Loads to see, many lovely places to eat with lovely little streets to eat outside under the heaters.

Take a walk into the past. An interestingly quaint place filled with things like spices and souvenirs for sale. Just walking down the street makes you feel like there is a nostalgic scent in the air. We visited sometime in April 2013, and the weather was lovely to take a walk and find a nice bar/restaurant to chill-out. Nice place to take a stroll and definitely romantic for couples. Not quite interesting for kids though.
Good area to stay. This area is away from the bustle of the city but is a short walk to the Grand Bizaar and plenty of nice restaurant and bars. We stayed here for 3 nights and really enjoyed it.

Good place to stay and explore.. Sultanahmet is the center of Istanbul's history. There is so much to see in this little area. We stayed in Sultanahmet which was a great choice. There were plenty of sights and restaurants to keep us busy, plus the tram made it easy to explore the rest of the city.
Quaint neighborhood. European style neighborhood with quaint restaurants and unique boutiques, very pleasant to hang around.

Aromas, places and gentle people everywhere. This historical district in Istambul is a banquet of wonderful scents of tea, spices, amber, musk and fruits. The only city in the world that I've visited whe everyone and everywhere the smells are pleasant. The tolerant attitude of the people and the sights of this city should be in any true traveler's list.
a good day. I thought this area would be dark, dirty, a little seedy but its fantastic with a hundred things to see, smell and eat at every turn

walker's delight. The area/district is nice! It is the main place for several historical sites and many shops, restos, among others. you can walk all day long and will never be out of anything that can intrigue you.allocate at least half a day or if you are with a "shopping-addict" friends...you might be surprised your day or 2 is not enough.

Take a slow walk around. Our hotel was in this area, The Old Town, and we had the opportunity over 3 days to walk the many narrow streets to explore, both day and night in safety. Lots of small shops and eateries to try the local foods that you must do for both lunch and dinner. Wine is very expensive so have a beer with your meals, the local brew is great.

Felt like a sultan. On the crowded and small streets of the Sultanahmet District you can almost touch and feel the legends and secrets of sultans. Most of the greatest attractions of the city are here.

Impressive but a little disappointing. I`d prefer a category between `average` and `very good`. They don`t impress with variety and style as Venice and Rome or Granada do. However, they are interesting if just too large. better viewed froma distance, lit up at night.

Just the facts, ma'am. OK, the district caters to tourists: hotels, restaurants, bars, shops, sight seeing attractions for which Istanbul is famous. So, if you are a tourist, this is the place to be. If you need to reach other areas of Istanbul the tram will take you there. Virtually everything which is interesting and connected to the Old City is within easy walking in this area. Considering the congestion on Istanbul's roads today one may very well think walking is the superior manner in which to see the sights.

This Is Where You Want to Stay. This is the district with so much to see. Staying here is so convenient to the sights. Lots to see within walking distance. For further a field sights, buy a tram/light rail card and use the local, efficient and clean mass transit system.

A riot of colour, activity and people. Our Hotel (Arena) was well situated to access all areas of the Sultamahmet.Our points of reference were the Hippodrome and the Blue Mosque - both easy to find even after dark. Endless shops, little streets, restaurants and coffee shops. Safe at night. Photo opportunities also abound.The Tram and Sultanahmet Station were close at hand and the trams were very reliable (albeit crowded). Get hold of a Tram Route Map and be sure to buy enough tokens. Also be aware of where to disembark and to change trams.of course, the Grand Bazaar is an attraction. Be prepared for crowds, noise and learn to haggle - otherwise you will be ripped off. You will get lost in the bazaar so just take note of the number of your first entrance and work your way back there. The locals are very helpful and do not be afraid to ask.One can also break out from the Sultanahmet and take the tram across the water or get on the Sehir Hatlari Bosphorus Cruise.We focused on the walking, shopping, eating and photographs. Conventional site seeing opportunities are many. (buy lots of Turkish delight and other sweet things !!)
History. We fell The history . Every tourist must see the blue mosque and hagia sophia.most inportant touristic place in İstanbul

A place full of character. We loved this area of Istanbul. The buzz in the atmosphere was electric. There was so many sights, smells and sounds to take in. Plenty of historical sights, as well as restaurants and shops. You could not come to Istanbul and not visit this district.

Check out the back streets. Very historic area with all the must see sites for Istanbul. Do wander off the beaten path and check out the quaint back streets as you will still be able to find the real Istanbul, away from the crowds.

Your first stop when visiting Istanbul!. Sultanahmet District should be your first stop when visiting Istanbul and you may well find yourself visiting daily! This is the Old Town district of Istanbul and the location of many of its historical sights. Easily accessible by tram, metro, and bus, when you arrive you will be a short walk away from Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Archaelogical Museum, the Basilica Cistern, the Grand Bazaar, and hundreds of shops and restaurants. Purchase the 3 day or 5 day Museum Pass that includes most of these sights and return daily to make certain that you are able to enjoy everything! When in the public areas, watch for hustlers trying to befriend you - and then lead you to their carpet shops. Finally, just enjoy some time sitting in the square, getting a snack from the vendors - we loved the cinnamon rolls - and watching the people - it actually reminded us a bit surprisingly of Paris!
Tourist hype. Very touristy. Touts are very annoying, persistent and rude. Endless requests to buy some crap carpet I don't want or need.

Visitando castillos y museos en Anatolia/ visktk g castle and musium in Anatolia. The market of species is magnificent, you bigger after all,'s most popular attractions are within walking distance from the spices until the that does not come to America, also its owners are of different races, faiths and lifestyles. Are long corridors and filled with color, smell and taste. On each side there are shops that compete for your dollars or euros. Some priductoa are edible and others are of adornment. It is a must while in Istanbul. There are bathrooms otientales in its majority and little western park also.
old city. very historical, with lots of shopsand cultural landmarks (Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Grand Baazar, Egyptian (spice) Bazar.)

Good Luck Leaving. Once you arrive in this area, it is so hard to leave. Many of Istanbul's main attractions are in this area. You can find tasty eats here also. If you are able to, book your accommodations in this area.

Images. Great images and historic sights...dont mind all the tourists. Easy to walk around, something to see around every corner. Look hrs to find there good coffee stops - they are there but not easy bro spot.
Must see place.. Mist see magnificent mosque, women no skirts, guys no shorts, and you will need to take shoes off. I really did nit dislke anuthing was perfect visit.
The Old City. So much history, I could have set on a bench all day and just watch people, people from all over the world enjoying the beautiful area. This is must for anyones Bucket List.
Soul of Istanbul!. A must place to visit; Hagia Sophia on one side, Blue Mosque on the other and a kaleidoscope of Istanbul natives and tourists in the Square in between!

Walking Tour. We stayed at a hotel in Sultanahmet during our trip to Istanbul. Nice area with a number of good hotels. Very clean surroundings compare to the New Mosque area. Lots of good restaurants. The mixed platter Kabas we had in Doyo Doyo restaurant was fantastic. We took a walking tour of the whole area conducted by Kaz. Plenty of history here. The Blue Mosque with the 6 minarets is amazing. The Hagia Sophia and Grand Bazaar were really woth visiting. Be careful of your wallets though. The locals are very helpful, even with their limited English. Enjoyed a Turkish bath too. Buy some excellent Baclavas at Guiloil.
Wow!. This place is so clean. The people are very friendly and helpful. I felt safe at all times. Close to all attactions!

Lots of history!. Had limited time so saw Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar - all unique and special to see. Although we were there in late season, lines were still long at Sophia and Blue Mosque but they do move quickly. You will get approached when getting on line by "tour coordinators" trying to pull together an ad hoc tour groups to bypass the line. Grand Bazaar was wall to wall people - but fun to walk thru. If you shop, know what you are doing and how much should you pay.
Back in Time. Well. well. Cause I like the kind of oldie place. Yes! I would recommended you to this place. The old architecture. Everything in there, I like the most! High recommended to go there!
A pleasant stroll around. be careful of the excessively touristy traps, but there is plenty of charm and interesting sights to see outside of ticketed entry.
A taste of old istanbul. This is a taste of the old Istanbul with loads of nice cafes, twirling darvishes and loads of museums.

One of my most loved placed on earth. I love this place a lot. We visited this time using the tramway and walked around the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophia, Topcapi Saray. You will really sense the great great history of Istanbul.
Perfect. This is the best area to stay in if one wants a feel of Istanbul.There is hustle bustle,you don't waste time in commute,everything is walking distance.
Best district to stay in. "The Old City". Easy walking to everything Blue Mosque, Basilia Cistern, etc. Nothing I disliked about the district
fantastic.... not ı am impressed. especially the blue mosque a huge temple. muslims must be lucky. also embraces different religions everyone should see this historic place.

Best district to stay in. This is definitely the place to stay on a short trip to Istanbul. It is within a short walking district of all the main attractions. and has a wide choice of hotels. I would not stay in any other district.

Old stuff all around. You have to keep your eyes peeled as there is lots of old ruins all over the place, you can trip over some, look above your head as well and modern stuff has been put on the sites of ruins so you have to scan the area intently, Beware the cobbled roads as they can trip you up, they are not kept repaired.
Best area to stay in. All of my trips to Istanbul, I stay in Sultanahmet area. So nice area in the old city of Istanbul with a lot of restaurants and traditions shops.

Fantastic. All the major attractions are here. Wonderful! Blue Mosque,
Sophia Hagia and Tropaki Palace are a must.

must visit. Mosque designed by Ottoman style, huge and services available, you can visit this place by metro, the organizers of this edifice are nice, and can speak in Turkish, English and some Arabic
rich in history and culture. A lovely place with a historic charm. Lots to do and see, and plentiful to eat . Easy to get around, just watch out for the trams.
most historical place in Istanbul. You can find like Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia Museum, basilica cistern etc. historical place there. enjoy the trip!

Beautiful place. Very interesting place to visit. Full of so much history and beauty. The whole environment is so nice. So many iconic buildings to see. This area deserves a whole day so one can visit all the surrounding mosques, walk down to the waters, watch people fishing while taking in the beautiful view. Real nice place to visit.

Wonderful. We liked the area very much especialy during the cloudy days. There are plenty of sightings and bird feeding going on not to mention the Blue Mosque,Aya Sofia and the great Turkish restaurants that are found everywhere on the street.

Electric atmosphere. There is so much action going on in Sultanahmet! It is crowded and can be chaotic where there are multiple cruise ships in port but listening to the prayer call from the Blue Mosque is amazing. The food is great (although a bit pricier in this area than other areas further out) and there are great shops to stroll through.

Istanbul tour. We have nothing like it in Australia. We were blown away with the History and beauty.
Our tour guide was excellent and we would love to come back for more.
Fascinating and approachable. I thought this area would be dark, dirty, a little seedy but its fantastic with a hundred things to see, smell and eat at every turn

Beautiful!. The heart of culture, history, good food, and entertainment. Very busy during the day time and is a sight to see. If you stay in the district you can walk to the grand bazar and sample the wonder sights, sounds, and food along the way.

Do not miss the tram !. Sultanahmet district is a historic area where you can easily walk and visit Blue Mosque,Hadgia sofia mosque,Hurrem Sultan Hamam,Basilica cistern, Topkapi palace and some other historic sights ..Also,there are lots of shops selling Turkish clothes,foods and souvenirs that makes your day ful of fun.However, I suggest to take a ride on the T1 tram and enjoy traveling with it from narrow streets of this historic district to Kabats ferry ports.where you can continue visiting Istanbul on Hop-on Hop-off ferries.

History comes alive here. the beauty, the grandeur, the magic!!! Aya sofia, the blue mosque, basilica cistern, topkapi palce, archaeological museum, all are here. shopping at the grand bazaar, food places all round, strolling parks and places of leisure, what more can you ask for.
great area to stay. Great area to stay and experience Istanbul. Close to everything, sites, good restaurants and good hotels.
Walk and explore this ancient city. Just loved seeing the history. The Grand Bazaar, the Blue Mosque, Agia Sophia and The Cisterns are so close.

History everywhere and shops. Plenty to see, do and buy in this part of Istanbul. It is quite fascinating. Ancient buildings, mosques, bazaar, delicious food and much more. You won't be disappointed. Excellent tram system too. Frequent and cheap.
Easy walking. We enjoyed meandering around, taking in all the sites and shopping. People were helpful if you needed directions.

Convenient. We stayed at the Four Seasons in the Sultanahmet Distric. This is a great choice if you want to do the main tourist attractions. you can walk to most of them and there are plenty of food and shopping options nearby.
Istanbul OO-LA-La. Great hotel location, great weather, convenient vistior places,all within brief walk of Osmanhan Hotel. STAY THERE!
aggressive sellers. but they understand a firm no, and don't take offense. many of the products are of low quality, and it is reflected in the price. grand bazaar might have more.

Beautiful but crowded. Beautiful old buildings, bustlig streets filled with shops, sweets, doner kebabs, simit and other mouth watering stuff. The central avenue with the Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque is simply amazing. However, it can be tooo crowded. Cafes and Restaurants are a bit overpriced here.
Touristy area. Someone to visit during the day.. Lots of cafes and street vendors. Most people giving directions will likely direct you to their stores just located off side streets.
Walk to see all how local live!. You got to walk along this district and feel how did local enjoy themselves....nice weather will also make your visit more enjoyable.

Key to main historic sites. Sultanahmet is the centre for the key historic sites. From here you can easily visit the Topkapi Palace, The Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque all within a short walk of the tram stop. All well worth a visit but be prepared for long queues though you seem to be abale to queue jump officially by buying the services of a tour guide who all seem to have a stash of tickets on their person! We engaged a very nice guy at the Topkapi for 120TL plus the normal entry ticket price per person of 30TL plus 10TL for entry to the Harem. This gives you an hour and a half of his/her time which is plenty to see the Harem, The treasury and the main buildings. They then point you in derction of the other areas worth seeing. We thought this a great deal.
Buzzing area. This is the best area of Istanbul for visitors. It is so close to the main tourist attractions, tramway, train, bus station, boats etc.

First time in Istanbul? Stay here!. Sultanahmet (the old district) is amazing. Stay in a nice little boutique hotel, walk around the random streets and feel the old world charm of cobblestoned pathways, wooden houses, decrepit mansions. And of course, all the major attractions such as Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia etc. are just a few mins away!Once you're done exploring the old district, take the 15 min tram ride across the Galatta bridge to explore the modern Istanbul!

Nice being in Sultanameth. This is a tourist area, we felt good in that area, near the blue mosque and Topkapi palace. Lots of people at daytime, very quiet at night. As tourists, we felt safe in the area. Lots of restaurants and hotels. The Tramway is there for those who wants to get to the airport using the public transport system... very effective.

Loved the Sultanahmet District, with one exception .... We made the Sultanahmet District our base for our 10-day stay in Istanbul. I would not have wanted to stay anywhere else. It was so nice to have our hotel located just a few minutes' walk from so many of the major attractions of Istanbul, including the iconic Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque which dominate the skyline. There are thousands of years of history in this part of the city. It is also easy to take a tram or a ferry to other parts of the city. The one significant detraction was the number of hawkers blocking our way or interupting our walk in an attempt to get us to buy a carpet, a city bus tour, a cruise on the Bosphorus, a city guide, a meal in a restaurant, etc. If we stopped to engage in conversation with every "friendly" Turkish merchant we would never have got anywhere in our sightseeing. We certainly felt harrassed at times, but we would smile, say "no" in Turkish, and keep walking. At times I wanted to take a peek inside a store or have a look at a restaurant menu. But I kept on going, knowing that it would be even harder to get away, if I stopped to look at the goods and decided not to buy. Otherwise, we thoroughly enjoyed our stay in the Sultanahmet district.

Lovely area. Sultanahmet is simply a lovely district full of restaurants, cafes and attractions. It's easy to spend hours strolling round the streets totally absorbed in the atmosphere. Definitely a must see area and ideally get a hotel there if you can

Good location. We enjoyed this location, relatively quiet but with everything you need close by including most of the historical sites in walking distance. We particularly enjoyed going up to the Blue Mosque area at night after dinner, so pretty lit up. The tram is the way to travel in Istanbul.

Great Location. Sultanahmet District is the place to stay if you are planning a trip to Istanbul. It is right in the heart of the must see places like the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace,the Grand Bazaar, etc.There are lots of hotels and restaurants - from touristy to neighborhood places and all sorts of price ranges.We stayed by the Little Hagia Sophia Mosque and felt very much at home and safe and everything was in walking distance.Perfect spot for a perfect trip to Istanbul!

Bustling City. Sultanahmet is the place to be while visiting Istanbul, because most of the attractions are in this area. Most others can be accessed using the Tramway/Subway. I relied totally on this mode of transportation during my visit.

Lovely Area to Stay. This is the area the Hotel Tan is in. There are mosques all around and a beautiful square with coloured fountains. You feel as though you are in the heart of Istanbul. Plenty of places to eat and many shops.

Diversity where ever you go.... You find there everything you are looking for when you'd like to discover a city the first time. A high concentration of the top rated landmarks like Hagia Sophia, Top Kapi and so on, nice renovated buildings, top restaurants and shops are located here, but you can also find here the other, the less fashionable and poor istanbul. Move away from the overcrowded touristic pathes and have a look around through the old and traditional part of this famous district. Walk down to the water front direction Kennedy Cd. and you can see old houses and feel the atmosphere of old istanbul. By the water you'll find some very good seafood restaurants where you can finish a remarkable day. But be careful when choosing a restaurant and start selecting the sea food and bargaining the price at the entrance where the fish is presented. Some of this places are just waiting for tourists!
visited two times. the shops and restaurants are of good service and decent prices. place is visited by locals and big number of tourists.
LOVED IT. Our hotel was here (Sultans Royal Hotel). Lots of food restaurants, great shopping places, could call it a mini grand bazaar. All tourist attractions are nearby.
A must see historic site. The architecture was great. Amazing how ceiling paintings and the patterns have lasted throughout the years.
i'll be back. small are with loads to see and do, very crowded but thats part of the attraction, easy to get to know where everything is
Better this side of the Horn. If you want to do all the normal touristy things then staying in this area is by far the best, and I believe generally cheaper than the Taxsim area.

Nice place to hang out, enjoy the surroundings. This place has so much going on, the centuries old attractions, buzzing and energetic crowds, pretty walkways and tons to eat and shop. If you just think about the significance of the square over the centuries, it gives you goose bumps. But even without that, there is just so much right there. All your major attractions are off the square. You can spend a couple of hours just hanging out, it is very picturesque...
Centrally located, all is close by. History, culture, beauty and fun in one place. Walking distance to key attractions and great restaurants.

It is a good area to visit. The whole district it is a historical site.
What I did not liked it is that the sellers some times are very agressive.
Wonderful To Walk Around. This is the area in which we stayed while in Istanbul (see review of Acra Hotel). Fabulous experience and walking distance to just about everything.

Fabulous Area. The Sultanahmet district is a very walkable area. Lots of hotels, restaurants, gift shops, and of course the great historical sites of Istanbul are all nearby. The city's tram line can take you almost everywhere in Sultanahmet as it cruises across this area.
Fabulous district. full of attraction and tourist places. Love it and surely will go back and visit it, grand bazaar, blue mosque, suleymaniye and yani mosques, and many other attraction

An amazing trip back in time!. I have been to this place a number of times, and I never get tired of it. It is crowded (much like the whole city) but gives you a strange sense of privacy and intimacy regardless of all the hustle around. Home of some of the major sights of Istanbul. Plenty of restaurants, shops, hamams etc. Excellent opportunities for people watching.

Nice Place. Found yourself back to History with different period, Ottoman & Byzantine era.The problem we had that we went during the Sacrifice Feast which all the Museums like Aya Sophia and other were working half day after 1:00 PM.

Great Buzz. It was our first visit to Istanbul. This is certainly the area to live in. There are easy connections with the tram. The 3 big attractions of Istanbul are in this area. Lots of hotels and restaurants to choose from

A great place to sta. When in Istanbul I recommend this area. The choice of accommodation and food is endlessThere are lots of streets near the square with accommodation prices ranging from low to high . The streets are busy and alive.try to locate near the blue mosque , so walking to all the main sights is easy.

Central. This area was very easy to get around and all the main sites we wanted to see were within walking distance. Excellent restaurants and shops. The roads and pavements are not the best so it is advised that you wear flat shoes at all times.

Just same than a latin market. Since I'm latinamerican this is only the same than a popular market region in every country here with a lot of noise and plenty of stores with people asking what you want and trying to make a deal from the street...
History. Becuase the area is full of historic places like Sultanahmed Mosques, Hagis Sophia Museum and the Basilica Cistern, the area is the most crowded part of Istanbul.

Old city charm. Great area since all of the major attractions are around there. There is a lot to see,and no need for a car. You can just walk everywhere or take the train/tram. Plenty of good restaurants with great prices as well.We stayed in the old town area and really enjoyed getting lost and wandering the streets. Make some time for shopping as well. Lots of fun finding goods and negotiating for them. Make sure you experience drinking tea outside with the vendors.
Really beautiful. Really a beautiful district but not a real picture of Istanbul. For that you need to leave Sultanahmet and visit the asian side
Great Area. Beutifull area in istanbul, sultanahmet is the historic and is one of the oldest places in istanbul.

The Old Town of Istanbul where a lot of shopping and sites are situated. Really loved this part of Istanbul with the mosques and bazaars. A lot of walking to expect though if you are not staying in the area, since the trams and metros are situated a bit apart sometimes (like for us staying at Taksim Square).

Most of the Historic Venues are within walking distance.. The Blue Mosque, Cistern, Palace..... Are all within walking distance...less than 10 minutes away.We used the Big Bus Tours and highly recommend this because both the Red and Blue lines meet just behind the Blue Mosque and from this point you can travel throughout the city.The best hint....Arrive at the historical ventures/attractions early...you will save hours waiting in queue. The crowds are huge.Another hint....you will be approached constantly by "friend" with guidebooks asking you "where are you from". They are big-time scammers who are just looking for your money. Do not respond to there friendly chat. I did and then couldn't get rid of him....they have no shame.
Great place to walk. All the major places to visit in Istanbul are in this area; it should be mentioned also the Hippodrome.Just walk and enjoy the view.

fascinating. Lots to see, great shopping, good restaraunts. Whitehouse hotel was very nice and close to attractions. Our third trip, so we went to the asian side vegetable market and some lesser known places.

Wonderful history. we stayed in the area and really enjoyed wandering the old streets. You will find lots of touts selling souvenirs, cruises, etc and all the restaurants have a tout out front. Enjoy the experience. Food is fantastic and reasonable prices. Wonderful area and buildings are magnificent. Stay for extra days, Istanbul is a wonderful city. We had no issues with fraud or theft but heard of one bag snatch. It felt safer than other big European cities.

The Right Place To Stay. We considered other neighborhoods in Istanbul, but nothing else would have matched this area. Yes, the area is filled with tourists and can get crowded at times, but that's part of the experience.
amazing. The buildings themselves were beautiful even though Aya Sophia was being renovated. Lines to get in but they moved quickly. Not to be missed!

Best district to stay. I think that if you are going to be only a few days in Istanbul you should stay in this district, since there is so much to see. You can walk to Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, and other beautiful mosques, the spice bazaar...
Unbelievable. The crowds ,the Great bazaar ,the Spice bazaar, the hustle and bustle and the traffic. Walking is easy but bring a map

Full of History. So much history in such a small area. Wear good walking shoes as there are so many places to visit. The Blue Mosque has spectacular decoration, The Hagia Sophia Museum has wonderful fresco,s and the Topkapi Palace has lots of wonderful treasures including an 86 carat diamond.

Stroll in the footsteps of history. Evocative and charming. Promenade through history. Photographs fail to capture the atmosphere. You can be as relaxed or as intense as you wish, either way you will capture some amazing memories.

The place to stay. This is definitely the place to stay in Istanbul. You are central to so much and are able to walk to all of the compulsory sites - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topaki Palace and others. The people were all extremely friendly and helpful - just watch out for the carpet sellers! You can find excellent smaller hotels which provide a very personalised service. I did need to pay more attention to the traffic instead of being distracted by the sites and architecture regularly.Immerse yourself and enjoy.
Istanbul Highlights. This area is the heart and soul of the City. Everything is at your doorstep. Not much to dislike; even the street sellers and touts are easily dismissed.

A lot to see. (Why does Tripadvisor force you to enter a fictional date if your visit was before Nov 2013??) Sultanahmet was not very touristy during the off season. Most of the area is made up of very old low buildings lining very narrow one lane winding streets running up the hill. There may be more big hotels than appeared to be because they mostly blend in with the general architecture. The elegant Shura Design towards the top of the hillside was a good choice. The streets are not marked one-way so many times a line of cars was backing up the hill to make way for others coming from below. The distance between the Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, the cistern and Topkapi with the Sultan's harem next to it down by the main street and the Great Bazaar above (interesting mostly because of its historical context, otherwise hundreds of shops selling mostly the same items. If you are a poor haggler like me you will end up paying way too much for everything) can easily be covered on foot in 20 or 30 minutes. There are lots of shops and restaurants all around and a number of interesting spice bazaars along the narrow back streets. A few miles down below the view of countless ships lined up to go through the Strait of Bosporus is fascinating.An amazing sight to see - a little girl kneeling on the sidewalk late one evening playing some kind of flute for money. I assume that the parents were in one of the shops across the wide main street but there were few cars or pedestrians around so it looked like a very unsafe situation.Watch out for the street kids and be careful where you give money to anyone. Late one evening I walked across a wide empty square and gave a dollar to two young boys. They immediately ran to tell others and quickly I was surrounded by maybe 20 6 to low teens boys. There probably would not have been any violence but then again you never know. I had difficulty moving along and one small boy had his hand on my front pocket where I had my wallet. I kept yelling 'NO' and finally got to the edge of the square where a man sitting on the sidewalk shooed them away.I also would not go with any of the hustlers on the main square. One tried to get me to go with him to his family's store. I said I could not buy rugs or whatever they were selling but he insisted that I should just 'accept their hospitality', tea or coffee. I did not want to find out what would happen if I went and did not want to buy anything. He followed me a good 10 minutes on Topkapi square and finally I got away by saying I needed to get batteries from my hotel.I had a most fascinating experience at 9 one evening listening to the call to prayer from Sophia Mosque. After a while the call ended and then another started from a small mosque somewhere behind me and the two continued this call-and-response for some time. Overall a very interesting place to see. And the main street has a number of travel agencies where you can book any number of day tours or longer to other areas of this part of the country.
all you could want. Everything within walking distance too much too see. Too many touts trying to sell things, some were rude and aggressive

Very convenient location. This is the district where most of the top attractions are located in and many cafes and restaurants are here. Staying at a hotel here will be convenient especially if you are rushed for time. In addition, the eminonus pier is also here where you can take various ferries to the different spots along the bosphorus, both European and Asian sides.
great area to visit. All the main places to visit are here, loads of good eating places and shops, everywhere is very congestive so be careful with your belongings, a great area to people watch

Expect tourist-centric, obviously.. People going to Sultanahmet neighborhood - you will be one of many, many tourists. The area is ideal to be in walking distance from the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and a handful of other Istanbul must-sees - but don't be surprised or overwhelmed by the fact that this has led to the neighborhood catering almost exclusively to the tourist population. You will not see the "real Istanbul" here - but what do you expect in an area holding so many Byzantine and Ottoman treasures? Any city in the world with such amazing history to offer develops a similar area to cater to the visitors they receive each year. I had a great stay here, however felt more at home in other parts of the city. You're a tourist, enjoy the touring!

Bustling Sultanahmet District. Sultanahmet District rich in history. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern plus all the old houses with cobbled narrow alleyways make up this fabulous district. Place is "stacked" with hotels built between historical walls co-existing with old homes of bygone era. The most amazing thing is that we saw dogs & cats living freely among residents & tourists, no mess or smell. Cobbled alleyways very, very clean. Don't bother with heels, flat shoes best for walking around this historical district. lots of roadside cafes & restaurants together with shops selling their wares, all seem to have similar /same items. People are very friendly, polite.

Interesting place. This place was full with culture of Turkey. Many things to see and can be found in this interesting place.Full with many tourists.We had a good time here enjoying food at different restaurants and the Spa Hamam here.Would love to return to Istanbul..

Frenetic Marvellous Istanbul!. Istanbul is not for the faint hearted as the crowds and traffic can overwhelm. But the history, the friendly people and just the pure DIFFERENCE between Australia and Turkey in general is a wonderful sensory overload.GO THERE!!!!

Amazing Cultural and Historical experiance. The History and Culture is really well preserved and offers a good insight. Istanbul is very tourist friendly and geared for the discerning traveller. You have to plan carefully as the museum passes can prove expensive if you are not planning to visit all and in detail.

Beautiful, but very touristic.. Definitely the right part of town to stay in, if you are here to see the historical sights og Istanbul. Really enjoyed walking the backstreets. many lovely, small hotels,Fantastic sights!

old district. we stayed in a hotel within walking distance to all the main sights in this district and to connecting transport to other sights. We stayed 5 nights and we could have stayed more! Istanbul fascinating. One day we had a guide: well worth the effort of finding one.
Very Touristy. Nice easy place to get used to Istanbul. Very safe to walk around and lovely places to see. Great to walk along the waterfront also.
Must dos in Istanbul. Take an all day organised tour with a dinner included, to see the main sights, particularly if time is limited. Usually available via your hotel.
wonderfulll !!!. Turkey is a must see for anyone coming to the region. you will surely be affected. ı am sure. good outings.
Love it. I really just love this area. Good Food and Nice Places to sit, friendly People, and all main attractions in walking distance or easily reachable by tram. I will sure visit again

Safe to walk around. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district and felt safe walking around, even at night time. This area is close to get the the sites to visit. Only took a few minutes to walk to the Hippadrome which was the political center of the Byzantine and Ottaman Empires.

Istanbul/Constantinople. We took a Magical Steps tour and could not have been more pleased. We saw Haghia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, Topkopi Palace, Hippodrome and wonderful local tavernas. Loved this city. Just be prepared for lots of people. Use of guide is a must to help navigate.
Landmarks!. The district has all the major attractions within easy walking distance. There is a beautiful fountain inthe main square, many street vendors selling all types of culinary delights.

Just keep Waking. A enjoyable place to be, keeps you busy all the time. Ensure you have plenty of energy to walk.
This is where you find the historic buildings, the bazaars etc. Though the streets are quite steep the attractions are not too far away from each other.
Good part is that, you don't get tired even Window Shopping
Ancient. The history in this square is fascinating, and the families and tourists alike were enjoying the summer sunshine.
Great area to stay in. Handy for good shops, great restaurants and easy access to the trams and main attractions. felt very safe walking around this area at night

A must see. If you go to Istanbul, the Sultanahmet District is impossible to avoid. The Blue Mosque, Haya Sofia, Topkapi Palace, the hippodrome... Plenty of restaurants near by, as well as benches by beautiful fountains to relax when you get tired of walking.

Welcome to Istanbul! :D. The Sultanahmet District is the place to be & see when in Istanbul! We stayed just a short walk down the street at the Perula Hotel so this area was right at our doorstep. Once we left our hotel, within 2-3 minutes we were at the Hippodrome with the Constantine Column, the Serpent Column & the Egyptian Obelisk of Thutmose III & German Fountain (Fountain of Kaiser Wilhelm II); the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmed Mosque); AyaSofya (Hagia Sofia); Baths of Roxelana; Basilica Cistern (with the 2 faces of Medusa); Arasta Bazaar; Topkapi Palace; various restaurants/cafes/food vendors--roasted chestnuts/roasted corn/fresh , shopping stores/vendors, public transport (tram/ferries/subway). The entire 'district' is close-knit so it is easy to walk from one attraction to the next. While there is no fee for the district as a whole, there are fees for the individual attractions. For example, the Basillica Cistern costs 20TL (Turkish Lira), the Ayasofya is 30TL & the Topkapi Palace is 30TL. I have fotos but I will post them on the individual attractions. Oh, and if the weather calls for rain, make sure you buy an umbrella (usually there will be street vendors selling them in the rain if you get caught without) because when it does rain, IT RAINS. Have a great time....we did! :D

Only shades of the past can now be seen!. I did enjoy staying in this district and the 3 stars may actually be more about me than the place itself. Its just that it wasn't what I expected and I've visited many places.The local attractions are definitely worth a visit, the Blue Mosque looks almost ethereal in the day light but inside it is quite disappointing, there isn't a great deal to see inside other than stained glass and expanse of red carpet and lots of lighting so it is a short stop off after a long queue. The Hagia Sophia and the Hippodrome and palaces are all worth a visit but I didn't find them as inspiring as the past dictates and I love history and architecture.Istanbul to me is definitely worth a visit and the Sultanahmet district is crammed full of great places to eat and drink and there is plenty to do but Istanbul has a pretty grey landscape there is block paving everywhere and I have to say that although the bazaars, shops, restaurants and attractions are worth a visit.Istanbul has lost its Turkishness, its that simple, its now ultra European (which I know is what it is) but it is almost cosmopolitan. I wanted dusty streets and an edgy atmosphere like Marrakech but again as I said before this could all be more about me.

So much to see, do and taste. Wonderful district with many Landmarks to explore all within walking dstance of Sultanahmet Tram stop : Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofya, Basilica Cisterna, Hippodrome, German Dome, Sultanahmet Park and Fountains, lovely eateries and great ambience.

Everything you need is right here.... We stayed in this district for 3 nights and appreciated how close it is to all of the historic attractions. There are plenty of lovely restaurants close by and it was a quick 15 min tram ride to Taksim Square from the Sultanahmet station...
old beautiful Istanbul. you should not miss this district if you want to see the complete city since most of monuments, mosques and palaces are placed here,in the old region of Istanbul

Everything you need. Offcourse the area with the Blue mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hippodrom, Ayasofya, Basilica Cisterne and de Grand and Spice Bazaar. But also a place with a great collection of hotels, restaurants and bars. Also good connections with public transport (tram), subway and also at the Golden Horn ferries towards lots of places of Istanbul and around!

This is the place to be in Istanbul. If you are staying in Istanbul do yourself the favour and book a hotel in Sultanahmet District. This is where you find the historic buildings, the bazaars etc. Though the streets are quite steep the attractions are not too far away from each other.
Don't miss it. Lively, friendly a great place to wander taking in the sights, culture, sounds and smells. Lots of great places to eat and drink. Good to sit and watch the world pass by

Feel Istanbul. You feel what is Istanbul in this area. You have many attractions near by and you can go by a little walk, good and not expensive hotels, nice restaurants. But it's not a place to go out by night, if you are a night person, choose another area.

lovely place to walk around but no to hang. you don't go there just to hang aroundwe've been in the area when visiting sultan ahmet mosque or the so called blue mosque, aya sofia, and the palacewalking around from place to another will be withing this areafun to walk around actually and get some ice cream !

Best choice to stay in Sultanahmet District. We loved the view from the rooftop restaurant of our hotel, the Ferman. We had a variety of shops and restaurants and could walk to Tokapi Palace, mosques,Grand Bazaar,etc. The streets are narrow and sidewalks uneven,so walking is challenging,but views are charming

Typical tourist area. The main area for tourists and therefore geared towards them all the same very interesting and enjoyable to walk around. At times very crowded which is offputting. We stayed in Beksitas and caught the tram here, glad we did as this area is more expensive and less authentic

The Essence of Istanbul. This is the area where you want to stay if you are in Istabul for tourism. This is the area containing most of the historical sites including the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cisterns, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, and many others. There is a good tram system in the city, but the ability to walk from your hotel to these wonderful sites is much better. Dining, Turkish Baths, Shopping, and even just walking along the old city wall are best here. Try to get off the main roads and explore some smaller alleys. Definitely find a small food stand, one where other Turkish people are stopping for lunch, to try some of the world's best "fast food". Get off the path of tourist shopping and into the alleyways where locals shop. Foreigners will find even everyday items interesting and the prices much lower. Sometimes it's nice to rest from the aggressive haggling needed to purchase items in the Grand Bazaar.

Beautiful!. The square is absolutely beautiful, full of vendors selling the local street food and drinks. It can get crowded though so going early morning is a better option. We stayed in the area for a night and were never short of restaurant options. There were souvenir stores everywhere. Overall great!

Best area to stay. Accessible to amenities and very safe, you will find tiny nice shops, great pubs to some shisha and have great Turkish coffee. Love the small market near hagia sofia and sultanahmet mosque.
Shopping. Excellent place for shopping but do whatch out for the grand bazar it's more exspencive then you'd think so shop for places out side

Historic Area. This is the area of Istanbul that contains many of the historic sights and is a great area to stay in because you can walk to these sight. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, The Grand Bazaar, etc, are all located in Sultanahmet and walkable. There are lovely restaurants and great hotels here also. Very convenient!!
Great Area. Absolutely amazing area to walk around and take in the flavour of Istanbul. Could spend days just wandering around the district.
PEOPLE. Your guide will take you here.You can walkabout have bite and turkish coffee.Like other Istanbul tourist spot.

Lovely to walk around. This area of Istanbul sure is amazing. Lovely to walk around and see the sites. Also some nice shops as well.You do get some hassle and some beggars however still enjoyed coming here. Nice to sit and people watch, take pictures, have a drink or generally walk around. Would definitely recommend and stay longer in this area if in Istanbul again. Happy that our hotel was in this location!

Do explore. The obvious tourist attarctions will demand youir attention. If you have time step off the beaten track and wander around the side lanes. You will find small bazaars, interesting buildings and unexpected delights like whirling dervishes. If you have taken the trouble to learn some basic Turkish you will also find food and drink in places that are not priced for tourists At night you will hear the muezzins calling out from the mosques in a coordinated crescendo..

Nice to stay here. This district contains many of Istanbul's historic attractions, and is a must see for tourists. As a business visitor to the city I have not stayed here before but did so this trip and enjoyed the experience. It's certainly true that being pestered, however affably, to eat in the many restaurants that line the cobbled streets is not uncommon, and the area gets crowded during the day, but this is a great place to stay and I'll do so again.
Very nice. I like the area many people from over the world and area is magnificent , the blue mosque beside topkapi the place for ottomans sultans and agia sofia the famous museum

Sultanahmet is Turkey. When in Turkey Sultanahmet is a must visit. It is the center for Turkey's history. Turkey is Sultanahmet and Sultanahmet is turkey.Do not miss this place that is full of tourist attractions: mosques! Hammams! Palaces, parks and most of all traditional Turkish restaurants that serve the most delicious Turkish dishes as well as the traditional Turkish delights and other mouth watering sweets.

Our favorite area in Istanbul. We stayed in Sultanahmet and it was by far our favorite area in Istanbul. Close to many restaurants stores and major attractions. All the shop owners will plead for you to come in have tea and look at their shop but you have to start saying no or you will spend your entire day drinking tea.

A popular district. We visited this area based on our guide book recommendation. It said that many people who visit Istanbul never wander this area if they are based there. There is plenty to see, with loads of bars and restaurants. Well worth a visit.

Visit. Many landmarks within same location, expensive and very busy at all times.Long queues, noisy. Too many hawkers,a real drawback. No separate tables for smokers/nonsmokers- outdoor lunch experience ruined by chain smokers on either side!!

Good food in Sultanahmet. Lots of restaurants to choose from here. Lively outdoor atmosphere and very friendly. Rami Restaurant and Amedros were particularly good. Disliked places where you are hassled in the street to get you to come in. Liked places where dishes not all photographed on outside menu in lurid colours; instead food made from fresh ingredients as and when .

Amazing historical area. There is a lot to see in Sultanahmet area. I loved the history and culture, but hated the crowded congested places. Eid time was the worst time to visit because of that. I love cats, however, I wasn't very happy about having cats all the time intruding at my table in restaurant. Lots of cats and dogs every where!!

All tourist attractions within close walking proximity. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia (Ayasofya), Basilica Cistern, Garnd Bazaar and Topkapi Palace etc. are all there. Visited by many people this district has a good selection of restaurants serving all variety of foods. There are other small markets to shop in. The place is clean too.

Great sights, great base. This is a great area. There are many good sights (including 4 losts of cisterns) within a few minutes' walk, and more a bit further in on the Eminonu peninsula if you're prepared to walk up to half and hour or so. For example, Chora museum, Sultaniye Mosque, New Mosque, Grand Bazaar... There are plenty of hotels to choose from in Sultanahmet, and places to eat. You pay a bit more for food here, but it's not too bad, and they are better geared up to tourists with their dietary needs than most places are. You'll also have lots of people trying to sell you carpets etc., but you don't have to buy them! They can be persistent, but just relax and ignore them or banter with them - it usually works.One could happily spend a few days here. If you really use your time well and pack in the sights a bit, you can see a lot in a couple of days.
Good. very nice place, lot of museum, nice and friendly people, the transportation is very easy, Tram, Metro, Bus and not expensive

If you are hungry for sweets :). Great thing to see and eat (try) real turkish delight. I wouldn't recommended buying there because it's expensive. if you want to buy delight buy it outside the bazzar. there are cheaper places to buy right after
A lot to retain. Putting sayings and facts into everyday life as we know it now, not so keen on standing listening for such long periods

A great place to stay!. The "old" heart of Istanbul, it is full of attractions, all within walking distance of one another, such as the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazaar, etc. Lots of good restaurants and shops.
The best place to stay in Istanbul. Here you can find everything, historical places, beautiful sightseeings, nice restaurants, shopping, and everything on walking distance!
The beautiful tourist area. Pro: Beautiful buildings all around!Con: Tourists everywhere at every time. Harsh turkish people trying to sell you things and "help" you do not want or need.

Not to miss area. Sultanahmet mosque is a must visit, and I liked the rituals they have after the prayers: Quran reciting and supplications. I also loved the Ayasofia though queues can be long in the summer season and gets very warm. Food abundance is very well welcome by tourists (huge variety, good quality and prices). What bothers me is the marketing people on the street trying to sell you a cruise, a dinner, etc (but that's their job in the end).
Staying at Sultanahmet District. The Sultanahmet District of Istanbul is the place to be. It is in the heart of all the sights that you need to see and lovely area to stay in

Stay in this area. Find a small hotel and stay for super reasonable rates and have the ability to walk around late, eat at small local restaurants. My hotel had an awesome view of SutlanAhmet Mosque, nice clean room with air and breakfast. All for well under 100. I felt safe walking around late at night...helpful and friendly locals out...
Istanbul old town - charming but always very crowded.. Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia , Topkapi palace and Cisterns all within easy walk of each other. Very compact. Good tram service.

Most of the major attractions. The old town with a lot of the major attractions and places to visit.Agia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace etc etc.Busy area with lots of restaurants and shops and lots and lots of tourists but a place you have to spend time and close to good transport for the rest of the city. Beware of touts and pickpockets and you will enjoy it.

Week stay not enough time. The district includes much more than just the historic sites, there is a vibrant neighborhood as well with many friendly people and the opportunity to see the daily habits of local community.
Touristy.... amazing number of tourists Good walking distance to some good sights but totally packed with tourists.

Good for a walk.. Its only10 miniutes away from the main tourist area, but if you have the spare time it's worth the walk, beside it will be good to get away from the tourist and prices are much cheaper in this area.
Historic & convenient location. Convenient area to stay in. Can walk to many sights. Recommend metro and tram when needed over taxis.

My favorite area in Istanbul. It is of course probably the most touristic area of Istanbul but is is so beautiful.Whether you go during the day or at night it is an area full of good energy. Do not forget that some places have been built 14 centuries ago..
Old City. Best area to stay. Close to every attraction of the city, walking distance. (the traffic during the day is terrible).Don't miss the Turkish Bath. Cagaloglu is the perfect hammam for that.
The best. My fave part of Istanbul! It has it all, the main historic sites, bars and restaurants, shopping, crowd, etc... I found myself coming back to it many times during my stay in Istanbul.

Great historical district.... Sultanahmet District is great historical district of Istanbul that you can access to Aya Sofia museum, Sultanahmet mosque, Capli Carsi or grand bazar, Misir carsi or spice bazar, Yerebatan Cistern and Topkapi Palace. this historical areas are reachable by tram, subway or funicular. you can enjoy night life after you visit the historical parts or shop from Grand and spice Bazar. be sure to check bazar's behind alleys from Aminonu district and shop there from nice prices. you can enjoy Turkish tea and sweets and meals!

Away from noisy nightlife. We loved that you can stay fairly close to the Blue Mosque and other major sights but affordably (we went with airbnb) and far away from Taksim, an area that never sleeps. Challenging those cobblestone sidestreets, however, the area is hilly and the sidewalks narrow.

Touch History. Having travellend to Istanbul several times, this area is the one I prefer to stay in. Everything is at your finger tips - the Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi, Galata Bridge and the port for boat trips around Golden Horn, Bospherus etc. Many streets are cobbled, with restaurants, shops lining them. The main street where the trams run makes moving about very easy particularly if you like to hop on and off trams - but otherwise,just wander and enjoy. There are the beautiful gardens that stretch between Afa Sofia and the Blue Mosque - food venders are here - but if you take a photo of any of them, particularly those in national dress, do expect them to ask for some money....it is part of why they dress up.

All there!. restaurants souvenir shops, yummy delights, annoying pick pockets. all there. it's very expensive comparing to Fatih area, shopping is good at Fatih area. especially Wednesday Bazar is awesome. SultanAhmet District and Aksarai area is very expensive. make sure you bargain, or visit some other area for shopping.

Nice walk. I like to simply take a walk around the area, visit the mosques, buy some souvenirs (and bargain). It is crowded on weekends but still worth it. Then finish the day with a visit to the spice market, which is just about 15mins walk away

Hub of activity, day and night. Whether you like street or architectural photography, history and culture or just people-watching, day or night, then Sultanahmet district is just thrumming with activity that will delight you any time of the day or night. Plenty of food and drink available and some of the best sights in Istanbul. A must visit.

An absolute must. This area is just choc full of atmosphere. World class sights, Hagia Sofia is one if my all time favourite spots. Lots of decent restaurants, tourist shops & one particularly good Turkish delight shop up the hill. It's clean, I always felt safe, quite a bustling feel to it. Come at night & sit on the benches between Hagia Sofia & the blue mosque, listen to the music, the shouts of the tea sellers, smell the street food & just soak it all up. It's the cross roads if east & west & it's not to be missed!

The heart of the city. In a city of more than 25 million inhabitants and almost equal number of tourists, there's no wonder why is this area so crowded... But this is just part of its magic. You can spent your entire holiday wandering its streets, admiring the historic sites, enjoying excellent food and spending money in traditional shops. Everything is easy accessible and we felt very safe on the streets in spite of street sellers. Public transport is the best way to go around the city.
Perfect area to stay when you visit Istanbul. Well recommended area to stay during your holiday in istanbul, close to museum, blue mosque, grand bazaar

I left my heart in Istanbul. Istanbul, Turkey, may not be the most beautiful city in the world, but it is definitely one of the most exotic ones. after years of dreaming about it, we just made our first visit to Turkey, to Istanbul, in mid September 2014. it is the best time of the year to visit, the weather was just perfect, sunny and pleasant every day, except for one rainy day during our nine days stay, to start with, we made our reservations for a nice, spacious apartment instead of a hotel room, X Flats Gumussuyu is located near Taksim Square and Dolmabacha palace. it is a great location with easy access to transportation. the city offers a great mix of old and new, east and west, modern and historical, sites. all sites share some common qualities, they are simply beautiful, charming and exotic. the beautiful hills combined with the Bosphorus and the sea of Marmara add the blue water and space for some of the most beautiful, colorful scenery. ferry boats use the water ways to travel to amazing spots like Prince's Island and Ortakay. the narrow hilly streets near the Galata tower with all the art stores and restaurants, are more charming than similar places in Paris and New York. the old town is filled with old monuments, bazaars and museums , one can smell history in the air, the sound of the call for prayer adds the sound effects for one to be lost in time. did I mention the Turkish people, they are simply beautiful, all young ladies and young men around could be models or beauty queens anywhere else in the world. and food, every restaurant offers a great selection, Turkish cuisine is just delicious, and prices are very reasonable too. I have always enjoyed getting myself lost in a new city which I have never seen before, discovering the virgin beauty of Istanbul was an unforgettable experience, now I am in love, cheers.

Major Tourist Area. Tourists congregate for a reason--There are wonderful things to see and do. This area has to be on your short list of wonderful places to visit.I always felt safe (apart from one experience with a carpet dealer) and saw no evidence of the pickpockets that seem to swarm in Italy. And clean!! My goodness, they don't litter there or, if they do, it gets picked up every night. Also no grafitti. Great travel destination.

Very unique historic area. Sultanahmet is one of the most unique places I have ever been. On the down side, it was very crowded with tourists and locals. Every time we spoke english we heard some scammer or seller trying to get our attention. We got caught off guard on the first day with a friendly man asking if we were from the states, it soon lead to too many personal questions. The cafes are also very aggressive in trying to get you inside. With that said, it is place you have to see. We were in Istanbul for 10 days and we kept going back to this area. If you want a great lunch away from the madness and crowds, check out the Kilari cafe across the street from the Basilica Cistern (a must see). Amazing food and relaxing atmosphere. Beware of taxi's in Istanbul, especially this area, you will most likely be scammed. The Tram will get you where you want to go. If not, just walk. Its very safe.
tourist area. If you travel to the historic properties then you will be in the Sultanahmet District. You will enjoy it.

Historic Charm. Really enjoyed staying in and touring this historic part of Istanbul. Yes, there are many touristy things that can be a bit tedious, but the sights are truly breathtaking and access to all parts of the city is great.

history. The place is wonderfully kept historical buildings. The view from Topkapi palace is amazing. Walking around and drinking fresh orange juice on summer afternoon with maze of people. Very nice and safe. Food is every where for different budget .

Happening Place. No matter what anyone writes you will end up here during your trip to Istanbul as it is the center of the historic sites. Easy to get to on the tram or by cab. Many many sites and shops and restaurants. Be adventurous and enjoy.
Best place in Istanbul to be. A hive of activity whole day and night. All the attractions, Tram station, all types of restaurants to cater to any one's taste. Must be seen to believe.

Orintal. v. good place to visit with your colleagues, family , you can smell , feel all orintal and islamic feature there , the place full of traditional shops ,restaurant and plaza you will never get bored try Hip Hop bus , unforgettable one
fantastic collection of landmarks. world famous buildings with incredible history and atmosphere. buy the pass which gives you a discount on entry and prevents queuing
exhausting. brilliant and magical but its full on. Every where seems to be up hill,but all walk able. The blue mosque square at night is fabulous.
Loved it!. This whole district is amazing. The shops,dining,and fantastic historical sights and museums are all within easy walking distance. And several great tour guides are available.

The best part of my time in Istanbul. A tourist area, packed with all the carpet shops etc that one could imagine. But interesting, plenty of places to eat and relax, plenty to see. Prices probably high relative to other areas where tourists might shop and stroll, but understandable given location.

very touristy. but you have to be there to see everything. We loved using the Big Red Bus to get started on looking at things, reasonably priced and hop on hop off so you can spend as much time as you like
Central. The place to stay if you want to visit many of the historic places. Great hotels and restaurants. Be prepared to walk up and down a few hills.

Really nice atmosphere. This district has a very nice atmoshere certainly in the evenings when all the main sights are illuminated. It looks like a fairytail. The only disadvantage is that it's really crowded.
Magic!!!. A big WOW and love at first sight!! Truly magic atmosphere and history just flows from every corner.... A must see!!!

Cobbled streets and restaurants. I suppose the best description is its the old part of the city. That's is another way of saying if you are fussy stay somewhere else in this city. Lots of street restaurants, traders ,Rubbish strewn, Cobbled stones and generally rundown.having said that its where you need to be to really get the feel of the real city and all the places of interest are closeby

An exciting area. This area in the old city is thriving with humanity. The sights and sounds, the smells of cooking and the noise of the city is mesmerising. Whatever you could wish for is here in spades. Shopping, food, cafes and restaurants all condensed into and exciting area.

World heritage, unsullied. Get yourself to Istanbul before it gets overdeveloped like the EU's big cities. I felt grateful to see this while it's still affordable and not over run with tourists (like me!)

Historic adventures, lots to see and do. The center of old Istanbul, the Sultanahmet area is stunning and packed with old-world sights second-to-none. If you only have a day or two in IST and it's your first visit, this is where you go to hit all the not-to-miss sights housed in the old part of town. Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia are amazing. An easy to miss spot is the Cistern - which is magnificent and the quickest sight to see among the mix. Plan to spend the day (at least) in this area of town. Plenty of good restaurants nearby and hotels. Other key sights like the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market are a short distance away so also easy to navigate. But also be careful - many Sultanahmet street sellers are pretty pushy about you buying trinkets/postcards, etc - just keep walking and don't stop unless you actually intend to buy something. Be extra cautious about your belongings - this area of town is a key focus for pickpockets.

Best place to live. The Sultanahmet area is really nice! Calmer then other areas of Istanbul. It has all the sights and a wide range of shops and restaurants. We visited alot of districts of Istanbul on our vacation, but was always glad to come "home" to Sultanahmet and the end of the day.
Sultan Ahmed. Sultan Ahmed area is the place that you dont miss, its busy, plenty of shops restaurants cafes, history markets its a place keeps you busy.

All jewels in one place. Prepare your self to spend almost a day in this area, as u can find Topkapi Palace, Blue Moaque, Hagia Sophia and Basilica Cistern all in one place. It's good to start your day early by visiting Topkapi then check all the other places.Entrance fees are below:Topkapi: 30 TLHarem: 20 TLHagia Sophia: 30 TLBasilica Cistern: 20 TL Blue Mosque: FreeIf u plan to stay for more than 3 days and to visit museums get the museum pass (115 TL/ 5 days) or the (85 TL/ 3 days).Keep in mind that Topkapi is closed on Tuesdays, while Hagia Sophia is closed on Mondays.The Grand Bazaar is not far at all, and the surrounding area is good for food and shopping, and always never pay the first price u hear.
Lots to do in a compact area. Enjoyed all the historic classics here - Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque,Topkapi Palace. It is especially lovely at night, lit up, walking back to hotel after dinner.

Istanbul's center of open air monuments and museums. Sultanahmet is a vast area of parks, squares and Istanbul's most famous museums and mosques. No need to describe their obvious attractions and importance. But word of warning: if you travel at peak season (July and August) arrive early to avoid the bus crowds and have a museum card purchased through a travel agent or at a kiosk in the main aquare in advance. This lets you in to most museum sites ahead of the line. Take a lunch break at the lovely outdoor cafeteria within Topkapi Palace museum overlooking the Bosphorus, and return to finish your tour of the building in mid late afternoon when crowds disperse. The extensive park within the walls and outside allow for rest on the grass. At night, Sultanahmet affords lovely walks around the flood lit monuments with minimal crowds. Many of the local restaurants have roof top dining facing the Blue Mosque.
Watch for the hustlers in the market. I love this area, but I do warn watch out for the con men and women. If its too good to be true then its not a good deal. Buyer be ware. Careful as you go.
Istanbul. This district is really special. You can buy good stuff, eat, drink a nice coffee and enjoy amazing buildings. I just loved visiting the grand bazaar
lovely :). The heart of Istanbul . Blue mosque . Topkapi Palace. Ayasofya.... and many other ancient monuments are there. it is also full of restaurants...
