Best area to get a hotel & spend 3 full days in!. I definitely believe THIS is the part of Istanbul you need your hotel in. It's lively in a very different way from other parts of Istanbul. It's historical, filled with cobble-stone streets, small shops, amazing restaurants, and just close to ALL the major top 10 of the top 30 things to see in this area. You will ABSOLUTELY be pleased with choosing a hotel in this area.

The old town. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Cistern are must. Stroll through the gardens and take time out to visit the terraced tea garden at the end with stunning views of the Bosphorus. Always queues to get in but arriving early in the morning helps. The area comes alive at night with many many restaurants to choose from.

Immerse yourself in History. Such a lovely district with a rustic atmosphere. And then you take out our map and discover that there is a mind-blowing amount of historical areas in this region!The best way to appreciate Sultanahmet in my opinion is to dedicate one day for a single attraction. Then use the rest of the day to walk around in town and imbibe the culture of Istanbul and its people. And remember to thoroughly appreciate the food, as it is amazing! I agree that some merchants and their overly persistent nagging might cause a bit of displeasure, but the beauty and magnificence of this place more than makes up for it. Frankly, I found that the people here are generally friendly and helpful. But I would not advice going out alone late at night.Start your visit early to avoid the crazy long waiting lines at the historic sites. And make sure to take your time.

The heart of the cultural city... I liked very much walking on the narrow streets with old buildings, reflecting the complex history of Istanbul.. This district is amazing.. I mean that the mosques and the Topkapi Palace, the Yerebatan Cistern, the Grand Bazaar are just some of the nicest touristical attractions in Istanbul. The gardens of Topkapi and the Sultanahmet square are also very beautiful and animated.. Don't miss spending a few hours walking in this magnificent land.

Amazing historical area. Sutanahmet has an amazing collection of historical sites -- the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, the Cistern, the Grand Bazaar, among others, and all within walking distance. The only thing we found increasingly annoying was the aggressiveness of the rug store salesmen -- they approach you on the street with polite greetings ("oh, where are you from"; "how do you like Istanbul") that instinct compels you to be polite in response. But then it becomes a sales pitch to come and just look in his strore. And the aggressiveness may last a block or more and he won't stop even when you say "no". So be prepared and learn your own way to wave them off or ignore them.

Beautiful historic center. The best way to start your Istanbul trip: Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cisterna Basilica, The Hippodrome. Comfortable tramway crosses Sultanahmet and stops by the most attractions.

Magical. Beautiful... Magical ... Full of things to do, places to see and good food. I visited this area last at the end of August with my mother and it was the end of our turkish trip. We stayed in Senatus Hotel which was lovely cuz it was so close to every historical land mark in sultanahmet. I would suggest not eating in the cafés and restaurants right down the hotel erea. That street is over priced and the food is so and so. But the restaurant across of hgya Sofia are all ok food wize. Spatially the Hurem sultan restaurant and hamam.

In the deep heart of Istanbul. If you are the party type, maybe you woud rather be in the European part of Istanbul, if not, this is the place to be. Surrounded by the most important historical building and attractions of the old city, Sultanhammet has restaurants, cafès and hotels with better value for money than the more touristic areas. Only shame, it is also the strictest observing muslim area, so, if you are a wine/beer lover, you might as well consider sleeping somewhere else, but still, dive into the magic of this are all day long.

Old Istanbul. The romance of the oldest part of the city with all that entails - severely run-down properties cheek by jowl with plush apartments, rough territory under foot a lot of the time BUT - such atmosphere. History at every turn of the street (and are they twisty). Enough restaurants from the awful to the excellent to keep you fed all year round. Monuments ranging from the internationally famous to the search-out-the-gems-for-yourself by walking about; artists and authentic handicrafts alongside tourist tat; chaotic traffic on streets, especially the side roads, laid down two millennia before the motor-car arrived on the scene. There is so much to enjoy - you could spend weeks exploring this one historic area alone in this vast city. See how the locals live right in amongst the frenetic tourist scene. Something for all tastes and budgets e.g. hotels ranging from hostels to 5 star just yards from each other

Circle Tours with Medhills Travel. Wonderful history and easy to walk around occasionally using a van. Small intimate group were very interested in Polat (tour guide) and his vast knowledge of places.
Lots to see. Great area to explore with shops and restaurants as well as Palace, gardens, markets and more then a few mosques.
Excellent. Great place to tour around. We walked all over the place and lot of attractions to see around. Nice area for shopping various things around as well.

Greatest place to visit!. Lots of places to see and lots of food to eat! Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Aya Sofia etc.... People here are super nice as well! Get an Istanbulcart and take the tram... or better yet, walk, walk wak!

great for sites and daytime, not for food. this is a great area with most of the sites in it, plus all the bazaars.we walked in the alley ways between grand bazaar to spice bazaar and was amazed at the views, smells and volume of people, we had no plan just walked in and out and came out at the spice bazaar.it is amazing how many linen/clothing shops there are all close to each other, it`s hot, everyone smoking and no way a fire engine could get in, well worth a meander.you will visit the area many times however i`d recommend never eating dinner here as it is very expensive compared to all other areas..taksim area best for food and bars..
Location, location!. It's one of the best places to be in order to visit the old city. Many things are within walking distance
Evening Magic. As the sun goes down and Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are illuminated, the feeling is difficult to describe. Watching Turkish families enjoying their city makes it even better.

Tips to help make your stay easy while in Sultanahmet, Istanbul. 1.It’s mostly a 5 min walk from most hotels in Sultanahmet to the main road, Excellent restaurants, Tourist agents, Money Changers and everything else all over 2.Most Hotels have a free safe deposit lockers available at reception to keep your passports/extra cash/cards etc.make use of it and remember to empty it when leaving.3.Sultanahmet tram stop is 5 min away from most hotels. Some hotels give you a card which you can top up at the machine at the station and use for your journeys. It is very cheap. Have Turkish Lira ready for all purcahses. you will save money. Do not use Euros. You will be ripped off.4.Amazing food choices available. Do try as many places and be more adventurous .5.All sweet shops and ice cream/dessert shops in plenty along the main road footpath. Absolute heaven! Loved them.6.Turkish fruit tea like Apple tea etc tastes a lot better than normal tea at an average of 3 TL per cup.7.Do try the bottled AYRAN (buttermilk) after every meal. It’s delicious and settles the tummy and costs just a couple of TLs.8.Turista is a great travel agency who can do all your bookings for sight seeing in Turkey at great rates, which again are negotiable. Dont feel shy asking them for a discount. There are many other equally good agencies and most are friendly. We used Turista.9. Grand Bazaar is about 10-15 min walk away in a different direction Ask the guys at the hotel before every venture, most of them will guide you very well.10.We found the back streets near the hotel to have much better priced items than Grand Bazaar.11.Spice bazaar could be a waste of time and the spices could be rubbish, but if you have nothing to do, please do visit.Very interesting place and colourful12.There is another market called Araasta bazaar behind Blue Mosque which we had no time to go to.13.Most attractions are 5-10 min walk away.(Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern etc) from most hotels in Sultanahmet. that is the beauty of Sultanahmet. You are in the heart of the activity and never more than a 10-15 min walk to anywhere of interest.14.Catch a tram to the Eminomu stop (3 stops away) and walk 5 min to the water front ferry station to catch a ferry to do a Bosporus River cruise. Just go by ordinary ferry, it costs about 5 TL return and many options available. Go in the evening just as it is about to get dark, to take advantage of the lights on return and enjoy the beauty. The actual cruise of 3 hrs or so costs between 10 for basic to 50 Euros for the fully loaded cruise each but may not really be worth it, especially if you are hard up for time like we were.. If you go in the afternoon, you might do the European and Asian quarter on the other side of Gallatta Bridge too. Taksim is another interesting place to visit..15.Hard Rock café is there if you are inclined..16.If shopping, start your offer at about 30% of the asking price and settle for about 40-45% of the asking price. Price in TL is always better. Have cash ready. Don’t use card. be prepared to walk away and 90% of the time they will get you back. its fun bargaining and they don't mind either.17.Assume everything dessert/sweet has nuts, so be very careful if you are allergic to nuts.18.Delicious freshly made Gozleme is available in some restaurants only.19.Beware of Turkish baths. Need to go to a reputed one or you will end up with a bad experience. They do pretty heavy thumping/cleaning/scrubbing.20.Buy water in big bottles of 5 litres from about 3-5 Tl . Most places charge you up to 10 Tl, but is worth only about 3-5TL. Shop around. Keep them handy in the hotel and fill up and carry smaller bottles when you go out. It will save you a lot of money21.Exchange $/GBP for Turkish Lira directly at the money changers shops lined all along the main road. One of them usually has a better rate than most of the others. Take a walk and look at their electronic display. Also at Grand Bazaar the exchange rates are even better.Do not convert your currency to Euros in your country of origin, its not economical. Its smarter to do it with reliable xchange shops here.22. Lastly for people who are used to eating delicious Falafel rolls in Australia, Europe and USA, please remeber these are unheard of in Istanbul and not available. At least we could not find any. In fact we had to hunt for Gozlemes.Overall a lovely, colourful and vibrant place. We loved our 8 days in Turkey with 3 in Istanbul. Will definitely go back again.

Love it. Love the area, it has it's own magic, the shops around the area. They have local market there, the streets nice, restaurants in both sides, small and decent hotels as well. Sultan Ahmet mosque one of the breathtaking place in Istanbul

This is Why You Visit Istanbul. Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Arrasta Bazaar, narrow twisting interesting streets, Mosaic Museum...to name a few. Watch out for the carpet sellers, especially if you're American, unless you're seriously interested in a carpet. They'll reel you in for 2-3 hours of hard sell.

Best part of Istanbul. This is where all the hustle and bustle is in Istanbul. As this is the district where a lot of the attractions are, it is also the best place to stay. Most hotels in this part of Istanbul are within walking distance of attractions such as: Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Basilica Cistern, Gulhane Park, Galata Bridge and Topkapi Palace.

Enjoy. Take your time when you visit this area. So much to see and do. Drink water! Luckely the do offer water several places along the way. It felt safe to buy from streetsellers 1 L for a small botle of water. Bring your camera and take a lot of pictures. Take a walk into the smaller streets too there you can see some original old Ottoman houses and feel the citys backyard. Enjoy!
Many Things to Do. The district contains many shops and local foods and peddlers and you can enjoy on visiting this area at any time of the day.

Best location to stay. Within reach of all the attractions, blue mosque, Ai Yah Sophia, Cistern museum, walk to grand bazaar, spice market, Topkapi Palace. Great restaurants and night life, hookah bars, shopping.

Historical area. This is the older part of Istanbul with so much to see. It is easy to get here by tram or bus and once you are here, you will be able to see many historical sites and museums. The Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Sophia Museum, Topkapi Palace are all in walking distance. There are walking tours that will give you the history and include entrance into the attractions which is a nice way to do it. The Grand Bazaar is within walking distance but you can get closer to it by tram. There are many restaurants to suit all tastes and budgets as well as carts with drinks and food. It is certainly an important area to see in Istanbul to see and not to be missed.
Busy and exciting... Lots of things are happening here. If you don't like crowds, stay away. Food, shopping etc... Everything anyone could want
Best district in Istanbul. The old town of Istanbul is certainly full of culture and history. The main atractions of the city are there along with several restaurants and cafes

sultan ahmet area. diverse.. lively .. the area has many restaurants,, also is near aya sofia ,the basilica cistern..blue mosque,,gulhane park,,topkapi.. there are benches where u can rest and snacks on which u can munch on

I loved visiting the area at night. As I already saw this place, but heard from my friends that visiting at night is really nice, and I did, from 7.00pm onwards, it's completely different than visiting this place day time, u will find a beautiful fountain, many ppl around, selling stuff, and you'll have a good time.. that's all I can say about the place.

Historical District. Sultanahmet district is my favorite place in Istanbul. It is easily reachable by tram, full of historical landmarks and there is a plenty of good restaurants. The place there is not very crowded like Taksim and Istiklal st.
old type of city with almost all attractions. it's an old type of city in istanbul which has many of attractions like Aya Sofia, Blue mosque, hamam and many more.

Culture Vulture Heaven. Amazing for history, art history, archaeology buffs! Something jaw dropping around every corner. From the Romans to the Byzantine and Ottoman rulers of the city, every culture that came here has left its mark on Sultanahmet. It's a living time warp.

The best district in Istanbul. Walk around the amazing historical mosques, sit on the benches surrounding the fountain for a great view of Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. You can find good clothes and souvenirs sold in the streets, also you can enjoy a corn on the cob or some pastry while walking in the area. You can also find a great variety of restaurants and cafes. Also you can head to the Arasta Bazaar behind the blue mosque for great handmade antiques.Mu advice for any one coming to Istanbul for tourism and leisure to stay in the sultanahmet district.

Right in the middle of history. Loved it. So much to see. East really meets West here. Beautiful buildings and pleasant area near fountains to people watch and relax. Loved hearing the call to prayer. Very atmospheric area.

I go there every weekend. I like to take photos of Istanbul and I go Sultanahmet area almost every weekend. There is Hagia Sofia symbol of Byzantium and symbol of Christianity in Istanbul. When Istanbul is conquered by Ottomans Church Converted to Mosque. There is Blue Mosque which symbol of Islam and build by Ottomans. When you come to Istanbul from Marmara Sea these two huge symbols are remarkable. There is Topkapi Palace which represents Ottomans life. There are many small and big museum around Sultanahmet area. If you come to Istanbul you will spend at least 3 days in this region without noticing the time.

The Sultanshmet district. The historic center of Istanbul it has most of the historic sites, easy access even a rail trolley, good hotels $35 night safe,clean, historic, plain cloths police stay up all night for your safety.Myasia Travel agency can arrange all your travel for a very low price. I think this area is a MUST SEA for any world traveler who thinks they have seen it all!!

wow. Ok I wasn't here in Oct 2013 but in July in 2011 & 2012.I loved exploring the Grand Bazaar and going into Aya Sophia,Gulhane Park,my appologies for the misspelling,Blue Mosque and just wandering around the streets.I disliked being approached by vendors and having them trying to talk you into going to another shop.However I loved when you did go into a shop they offered you tea or water.Very friendly overall.Especially if you attempt to speak Turkish.

Great place! Make sure you know where you're going!. We have been to the Sultanahmet District on two occasions, two years apart, and both times it was amazing but incredibly busy. If you can handle the hustle and bustle of people absolutely everywhere then you're ready for this place. It is beautiful, historic, and foreign. We felt lost, welcomed and accosted all at once. The folks selling the carpets are leaches. Pretend you don't see them by not making eye contact. Most of the rest of the folks are nice and helpful and, really. It seemed to us as if the entirety of the world was plunked down there and they all loved it and decided to stay! (Except for the carpet beggars, who should be shot!) Go to the Hagia Sophia very early in the morning because the lines are very long. Take a boat ride on the Bosphorus and buy the scarves that they sell on the boats. They are $5.00 there and sell for $25.00 or $30.00 in the States. Our favorite restaurant there was The Antique Turquoise (a block or two off the main drag). A wonderful hotel is the Armada (like The Ramada Inn except with an "A") You can see the Bosphorus from your room and the lights from Hagha Sophia from their restaurant. This place has my heart, although I had to fight off the carpet beggars:( Be Bold. Be strong!!! This is a must see!!!
Busy bee. Great tourist spot with lots of historic attractions, food spots, shopping and souvenirs. Down side too overcrowded.

Appealing district. Love this district. It seems slightly quieter than Fathiye district and easier to immerse into the local way of life. Wonderful assortment of restaurants close by, and easy walking distance to the grand bazaar, blue mosque and Topkapi Palace. A walk to the fish market is a must to experience.

only hagia sophia. only come here for the beautiful hagia sophia or walk through the square to go to the topkapi palace and the fabulous archaeology museum. The blue mosque is overrated and the rest of the neighborhood is filled with tourists and touts

Only place to stay... but I love history..... I would suggest you read up on the history of this wonderful place - it's just so invigorating ! I did a lot more reading after my visit, and it's made me want to go back... and I will!

Great place for 1st time. This is the most convenient area to stay in for your first time in Istanbul. Most of the major sites that everybody must see are in this area. The tram is a great and inexpensive way to get around.

Nice area with good restaurants and shopping. The area is very nice with restaurants, shopping, banks with ATMS, and even small groceries and bakeries. I would recommend staying in this area as it has good access also to the sites.
Best location in Istanbul. The best part of Sultanahmet District is it's location. With all the city attractions nearby this has to be the best place to stay in.

Everything ancient in one place.. Loved exploring the Sultanahmet district.Ayasofya absolutely amazingly beautiful and huge.Sultanahmet Mosque great experience - must cover up though. (Gowns & head scarves are given)Basilica Cistern was my absolute favourite place. Takes you back in time.Topkapı palace is extremely big and beautiful. Sidewalks and walls are even ancient, steeped in history.The cafés, patisseries & restaurants around are delightful and quaint.

One Stop: Sleep and Shop and Eat. Hotels here are fantastic. I am picky about a place to stay. There are few 'name' hotels but lots of former residences that are now up-scale boutiques. Ours had a roof garden overlooking the Blue Mosque. Restaurants are plentiful and you can not go wrong with any choice you make. And shopping is everywhere. This is THE spot to stay in Istanbul.
What a culture rich spot!. It's so interesting to see and meet the people of Istanbul. Everyone is friendly and a few could even speak to us in our native language, Afrikaans. So impressed!

Awesome Mosque. If you want to see a magnificant mosque then you should take a look at this one, its absolutley massive, it gives you a great sense of being in "the" moment. Great location, easy to walk to and from, accross the bosphurous and has many sorrounding restaurants.
Best place to stay. If you have a short time in Instambull, choose a hotel in Sultanahmet, it is walking distance of the main attractions like Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Haya Sophia, Grand Bazar

Old city of Istanbul. I liked that we could walk to everything from our hotel. The culture, history & people were great. The only downside would be the peddles selling there goods & everyone had a relative who could sell us a rug, just don't be shy and say "no tks".

All in one place. A wonderful district with many monuments to visit! Yerebatan, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome etc. In case you get lost, many tourist guides are more to ready to help for a lira or two. :)

Back into History. With the design of the area and the noise take you back into history .. you will smell the old times , if yo are into it , the shops , mosques, and everything will attract you in ancient comination
The place to stay. You can find everything you need there. From restaurants until some of the most importants "musts" of Istambul.Prices are a little bit higher.

super touristy. I went to Istanbul in the early 2000s and did most of the historical sights then. Coming back now made me feel like running to Taxim or Karakoy ASAP. Too many buses, people and annoying guys trying to sell you boat trip / guided tour / whatever else

Deep history, not so well-maintained. Istanbul has one of the richest histories in the world, and it was incredible to be able to walk around such a relatively small area and see such a variety of history.Make sure to bring a tour guide or good guidebook with you though, as the government labels and plaques don't nearly do justice to the richness of this history.
Beautiful :). i loved eveything there :) go visit them all, all the historical places, mosques, museuems, churches, everything..

Must See Historical Sights in Sultanahmet Area. Many of the key sights are within walking distance of each other. Alternative to walking is the tram system. The area is steeped in history and you are surrounded by Istanbul's wonderful culture. The must see sights are The Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, the underground Basilica Cistern and Topkapi Palace and Gulhane Park. The area has an abundance of places to eat - wander a few streets away from the main attractions to find slightly cheaper food.

Loved this area. Everything from shopping and historic places! Clean place , tons of cats everywhere lol . Restaurants have very aggressive people trying to get you in. Beautiful area tons to do and , could walk around for hours!

People of multi-ethnic backgrounds lived peacefully. Coming together of people of different beliefs and living peacefully before the Middle Ages, should be modelled actively to help bring peace to our planet today.Guides were explaining to visitors and we picked at least six different languages being spoken in one area. The 'glorious' past must not remain an illusion. There is a lot to learn from what has been preserved for posterity.

Wonderful area. I travel to Istanbul rather frequently and always stay in Sultanahmet because it is adjacent to so many historical and interesting sights and sites. Perfect location to soak up Turkish culture, both historic and current.

All of the sights within walking distance. Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern... they're all in this neighbourhood, and the Grand Bazaar is just a ten minute walk away. On the upside this makes it a great place to base yourself as there's lots to see and do, on the downside it's very touristy with a lot of overpriced restaurants and tacky cafes. It's hard to go five steps without someone trying to sell you a Bosphorus cruise or inviting you into their bar/restaurant/souvenir shop.

Busy and touristy but worth a visit. Lots to see and do, from Palaces, to cisterns to great shopping and some interesting people watching. Food is touristy and average. Watch your wallets and stay safe as there are many Turkish people trying to rip you off.
Nice picturesque district. Lots of activities to do. Ver nice and vibrant, and plenty of eateries. Good by day and night time. One can do shopping but beware of bargains... .

Visit. There is so much to see and do in this part of the city. The best advice I was given is to follow the team tracks a great orientation point. Wandering around the old town of Istanbul you get to meet some very friendly people, some wanting to sell you something of course!
not to be missed. try a terrace on a top floor in a nearby hotel at night, the views are breattaking: you realize where you are in only one minut. The Lady Diana Hotel top floor bar is a good option

if you love history, you will love it. it is very beautiful district, with many attractions in it.
Sultanahmmet mosque and its surrounding were very nice to walk around especially the old bazaars.

Night place to wonder around - but ezpensive. The Sultanahmet area is large and it includes the Grand Bazaars, many mosques and Topkapi palace. The walk from Sultanahmet to Galata bridge (by tram line) is definately worth the time.

Best area to stay in istanbul. Location couldn't get any better, loved the cobble stone streets, the proximity to all main attraction, tram, airport and the sea. All within walking distance ( except airport 20 min taxi ride). Many convenience stores and souvenir shops as well
Architecture. The mosques are too similar to spend the whole day going from one to the other. Hagia Sophia is significantly more interesting than the rest

busy, hectic but so worth it!!!. Full of historical places to explore such as blue mosque, topkapi palace, hagia sophia , etc. Lots of turkish charms and character to enjoy. There are a lot of places to eat and most of them offer great tasting food. My advice is to visit this area at night at least once as it becomes more lively, colourful and exciting.
very good. this place is very modern and full of lots of things to do, and and all of my family enjoyed vesting sultanahmet a lot!
Very crowded & interesting place. This is exactly like how bazaars would have been in the old days. Lots of little shops, restaurants etc. all major attractions are in this area.
Plenty of shopping in between the sight seeing. Lots of restaurants, lots of tourists, transport is easy to catch. you need to cover up to enter the mosques

Probably best place to see in Istanbul. I think what most people wants to see by coming Istanbul is it's historical sites. And the biggest place to see old historical Ottoman and Byzantium buildings are in Sultanahmet and Beyoglu district. This places are crawling with tourists.

Fascinating. When you get off the tranvia, right in this stop and look to your right, only an expression: WOW!!!
The Big and the Blue Mosque are rivalry if we are talking about beauty. The Egypt obelisque goes with you to ancient times and the noise of people walking and shooting their cameras around you come to the real life again.

History at every turn. What a magic place. We visited on a tour and while seeing everything on one day we were delighted when the tour ended and we commenced 5 days on our own in this fabulous place.From the mosques, minarets, colourful street vendors, underground water cistern and the amazing bazaar everything was totally mind boggling Found it a very safe and friendly part of the city to get around

Stunning views, average food. Batterra is In the old district of Sultanahmet in Istanbul. The views are superb of the Blue Mosque and the Bosphorus. The service was excellent. The sea bass filets were a tad over cooked and when I requested tartare sauce it arrived and had fresh dill..the salad was tired and without dressing. Another friend had the roast lamb- see photo. It was ok but not memorable. So it's worth the view, and they have good wines but limited to only one white selection by the glass .
THE district. If you want to experience Istanbul, Sultanahmet is THE district where you can feel the genuine Turkish culture.

heart of Istanbul,. This is Istanbul, that from the time of the famous Sultan.At each corner can feel the spirit of old times.All significant historical value are the in Sultanahmet.It is best to visit on foot all.You can not get lost, if you do not know how to read a map, there are kind people to help. Everyone on the street will instruct you where to go.

Mix of Old and New. Convenient public access to transportation. Centrally located to view all the attractions - Sultanahmet Blue Mosque, Aya Sofea, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, etc.Shopping at the Grand Bazar is mind boggling

Immerse in the old city. Loved this part of town - yes it might be toursity, but its full of tourists for a reason! Definitely feel safe as a female walking around, and they are less conservative the other parts of Turkey. As a tourist its easy to navigate and get to the key sites on foot. We loved having our accommodation in this part as it made everything so easy to get to.
Lots of landmarks to see. Don't miss the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace (and Harem), the Grand Bazaar, and a lot more!

The Core of Historic Istanbul. Don't miss the Museum of mosaics from the Byzantine Palace, or the cistern just by the tram-line. Or the carpet museum or -- now that it's open -- the Church of Agia Irene, on the way bto Topkapi, another must.
Stunning. Really beautiful place. Flagship of Istanbul! I think everyone has to visit this place while in istanbul :)
lovely place!. its a lovely place! plenty of things to see, places to visit (topkapi, blue mosque, hagia sofia, basilica cistern, bazar), places to eat, and shop! just go walk there!
Fantastic SultanAhmet. Steeped in close to 2000 years of history with the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Cisterns, hammams. Istanbul is an exotic city and SultanAhmet is the icing on the cake
A lot of culture and history. Street side food and local attractions are a treat, the .............................................................................................
Just go!!. It is very exotic and beautiful area, shops and foods are good. People mostly speaks English. Negotiate more

a must when in Istanbul. so many historical things to see, 2 days at least.
When hungry dont miss the real Sultanahmet Koefte restaurant, one of the oldest in the area

Lots to see and do!. Wonderful area with a ton of stuff to see and do. You need at least a full day to wander around and enter all the monuments/exhibits/etc. Tons of picturesque bars and restaurants.

Must see. It is the very historical centre of Istanbul. Haiya Sofia and Blue Mosque r situated here. here is a fountain in the middle of the square. Especial beautiful when sakura is in blossom. Be ready for big-big-big crouds of people. All entrances are for fee.
day visit to istanbul. we were taken by our tour guide around this area and given a chat on the area n history etc..very informative...
Magic Area. If you travel to Istanbul and not visit sultanahmet then for me it's very strange because you really have to visit this place with so many things to do and visit :)
Lot of shops, hotels and tens of historical monuments. The whole city is abuzz with many hotels, shops and ofcourse host to many of the city's historical and beautiful attractions.

Avoid the tourist ambushes!. Sultanahmet is a must see in Istanbul but I mostly try to protect my guests from eating and staying in Sultanahmet. It's to touristic so better eat and stay some other place to get a better service for a better price. Eminönü is right next to Slutanahmet area and has better food for better price (for now) and many new hotels are starting now. I would also recommend young couples to the Cihangir part of the City. It's walking distance to Sultanahmet with a local experience of Turkish modern night life!

Amazing place. This is the place you go back in time to the Ottoman Empire. There is lots to see: from palaces to mosques and from bazaars to cafés with roofviews. Remember that it can get really crowded though, especially in the grand bazaar area where the streets are pretty small.

Great Vibe. The Sultanahmet District could easily be likened to Leicester Square in London. It's such a bright and busy place with so much to see and do. The best part is that there are little gardens where you are free to sit and enjoy your afternoon lunch like a picnic in the middle of a busy city. The volume of people is great so it is really busy. The security and staff are quite friendly and helpful to tourists. The tram runs through this area so it is easily accessible but a great walk too. Many shops to pick up all manner of souvenirs. Great night life too. Loved it!

Byzantium and Constantinople by a different name. This area probably has had the most diverse history of any city in the world by far. Originally settled by the Byzantines in 657BC this city has had more change of leadership than some political parties. Many have laid siege to this great city. Greeks, Romans, Slavs, Persians, Crusaders and finally the Ottoman Turks just to name a few... but I digress, sorry. Do some research then visit this area and enjoy the wonderful Turkish hospitality, the food and of course the magnificent historical sites.....WOW! and I thought Rome was good.
Historic. Its a museum in open air.A lot of mosques and everything that Turkish culture has to offer.Its a mandatory place to go.

lots of history. many old buildings and sights,museums mosques,vey nice restuarants and road side cafes, food is delicious ,live music in many open restuarants. Good for family as well as friends and groups visits.
Amazing place to stay. If u are in istanbul then stay here not in taksim. U need to do sightseeing, shopping, bosphorous. Everything is just here.
The Islamic History in one Location. I have liked mostly the Blue Mosque & Aya Sophia Mosque & Top Kapi Museum. What I did not like is the big amount of kids asking for help & money

This is so Turkish. All the main tourist attractions are in this part of Istanbul and within walking distance of each other. A definate high priority is to visit The Spice Bazaar (also known as Miri Bazaar). There are many shops in this building and most of them sell similar stuff, but it is pleasant to walk around and to have some chats with the friendly shop keepers, who obviously hope to make sale. Play along and try your best bargaining skills! We were surprised by the colourful and neat displays of the merchandise. The huge pyramids of nuts, dried figs, dates and other kinds of fruit, look so beautiful. An open invitation to taste everything! All the bags with different kinds of exotic tea and spices ensure sensory overload, especially when you are a foreigner and not used to this way of browsing. And not to speak of the huge variety of turkish delight (locum) choices. If you do not have space in your bags to take a few boxes with these treats back home, at least visit the Spice Bazaar for your own eye-candy!

Stunning Sultanahmet!. All of the major sites are located in this district and all are so very close together. I was nervous about not being able to find the sites but this was not an issue at all, you can easily visit all in one day and enjoy sitting in the lovely square people watching. Enjoy beautiful Istanbul!
Perfect Location. The heart of historic areas, a very majestic square and close to most of attactions, and mony things to see in this area, and close to tram station.

Give you a great feeling being their.. Safe place to walk around. People are busy sightseeing, bargaining and eating on the way. You can walk all the way to Taghsim square. Do forget to try Turkish ice cream some of them put a nice show for you to get your ice cream.
Sultanahmet District. Sensory overload....but in the best way ever! My overwhelming sense was that I didn't have enough time and that I could in fact stay forever!

History at its best!. A very majestic big square with lots of things to see and stories to hear.
A historical delight with lots of street vendors selling corns etc.
One of the great attraction is The Great Bazar in this district which houses around 4000 odd shop selling everything you can think of... reminds of narrow by lanes of Chandni chowk in India.

Close to most major attractions. If you want to be within walking distance to most of the major attractions, this is the best area to stay. It's very safe and there are plenty of shops, bars, and restaurants close by. Prepared to be haggled by people trying to sell you carpets and lamps. A nice place to just wander around and get lost.

So many things to see in this area. This is the Golden Horn area. So many things are within easy walking distance: Topkapi Palace, Sultanahmet (Blue) Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Hipodrom. Spend at least two days in this area if possible.
Perfect location to see the city. Starting in this part of the city created an easy to navigate itinerary which allowed us to see many places
The Heart of Istanbul. So many incredible sights, fabulous food and friendly people. A few days is never long enough! All the must see sights are within walking distance.

Sightseeing and Eating out District. One stop place in Istanbul for sightseeing and eating. The Blue Mosque Grand Bazaar Egyptian market Hippodrome Aayaa Sofia and the Topkapi Palace and Museum are all located here.

Best District to stay in ... It gives you the taste of old Istanbul , staying there will keep you close to the most historical places in Istanbul like Blue Mosque , Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Saray .Beside that , you can enjoy the natural by visiting Gulhan Park , also you can do shopping at Grand Bazar .... its really the place that every visitor seeks for .

Most of the major historical attractions in one place. You can see many of the major historical attractions in this district. It is just wonderful. Get a guide to take you around and bring the history alive. Don't forget to visit the other districts in Istanbul. It is immense and fabulous. Go to the Asian side too.
Best area to stay.. It's electric and great for people watching from the many restaurants and cafe. Very close to all the museums etc.

Everything you want to see is here. All of the main tourist attractions are in this area which is quite handy- the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and the Grand Bazaar. We visited Istanbul on a cruise ship and had 2 days in the city. We did a day trip one day which brought us to this area. I thought the vendors would be a little bit more pushy but yes they are everywhere. Definitely not as pushy as I thought they would be though. It's a nice area and the area in front of the Mosque in particular is lovely. Very clean and just generally a nice area to walk around.
Heart of the city. For history buffs, this is the place. A must see for all. I explore this area on all visits and it never gets old. Looking forward to my next visit.

Busy District, word of caution!. Probably the busiest district in the City. A word of caution here, when dining in this area, check the menu on the table after seated.The servers may bring a menu after you have ordered with altered pricing and claim the new menu to be the valid one.

Fascinating History, but Watch Your Wallet. This is the reason nearly every tourist visits Istanbul. Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, the site of Constantine's Hippodrome and more are all right here within easy walking distance. It is a place not to be missed. However, as other reviewers have noted, everyone is trying to sell you something, always at inflated prices. I felt like a girl running a gauntlet of construction workers. Shopkeepers and street salespeople call after you, try to engage you in conversation, follow you offering to guide you to "the antique shops" (of course their own), all with one view in mind--to get as much out of your pocket as they can. You can bargain down for some things, but if you are visiting multiple places, you will find better prices outside Istanbul. Both Cappadocia and Izmir have better prices for most things, including the smaller souveniers. Turkish Delight is a ripoff in Sultanahmet shops and the spice market--they sell it in boxes that are artificially large. If you are going to other cities, wait to buy anything until you go there. Do NOT be polite. Ignore the salespeople and when they pester you, tell them no and walk the other way. Most of the restaurants suck too. They are overpriced and underwhelming, with a couple of exceptions. I'd just look for a kebab stand and get dinner outside Sultanahmet unless you choose one of the few restaurants that receive good reviews. It is the price of enjoying the world-class historical sites here.
Best Bazaar tours ever. If you like crowds and variety when you're shopping and couteous salesmen with old style shops, and want to have not-the-malls-again experience, you need to be here

Exciting and Enjoyable. We stayed in this area and found it such a lively, exciting area. From walking to and from the main attractions you can encounter the typical Turkish lifestyle of the people. Men playing backgammon, cards, attending to their shops, generally just filling in their day. Women selling souvenirs, or busy buying supplies for home. The Spice Markets are a must to visit, the smell is delightful of all the products. The shopping is immensely concentrated along all the side streets, which have a lot of steps, small alleys and culture. The restaurants are spread out over this area as well.

money is not valid in here all free. you can find all kind of shoes in this store which is shoe manufacturer. you can ask everything about istanbul. they are istanbulian people who makes you feel better.

Sandyman we need you!!!. Where is the best free walking tour agency in the world when you need them?! If you have not come to this area of Istanbul you have not been to Istanbul! I only wish there was a free walking tour group to tell me some great stories about all the history. Overall a must see!

So many great things to do here. Could spend so much time here and did. The architecture of the mosques and other landmarks is breathtaking. Tourist central, but very much worth the wait and the time walking around. The Basilica Cistern was my favorite and is out of this world.

Old World & History. We stayed in the district at the Golden Horn Sirkeci, and we loved this district with lots of shops, restaurants, and tourists from around the globe. It was safe, clean and full of activity. There are public toilets. Lots of small parks and areas with benches to rest and eat ice cream and watch the world go by. There are dock areas with boats and ferries for trips of the Bosporus. The Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace and the Old Markets are all in this district.
Amaging. The mixture of many kind of culture and history made us very excited. Especially, Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque were impressive.

Mindblowing and expensive. About 3000 years of history crammed into a small corner of the metropolis... no wonder that prices are high. Service at restaurants is high too, food generally is very good. Visit the restaurants off the beaten track to get a taste of excellent, plain turkish food, yummi. And do go visit the Grand Bazar.
Historic area. Stroll the area to capture the past and present Of Istanbul. It encapsulates the city well. An escape to the past.

space to wander. Love the cleanliness of the entire area and finished pavements and practically no rubbish. Lots of little streets mean that you can wander and still find your way back as the Minarets of the Blue Mosque guide you back.
Great place, but prepare for crowds and pressure selling. Bazaars were great. Area is wonderful. Too hot and humid in August. Beware pickpockets and pressure selling.

Your connection to the past. If you ever dream of bringing back the days of walking on cobblestone streets, this is your area. The clubbers might choose Taksim, but every street of Sultanahmet is history.

It's hard to believe but they're all real. Landmarks, mosques, church, antique ruins and fragments are at every corner of this district. It's hard to believe all those historical relics of different eras and cultures have been preserved together so harmonically.

Convenient and CROWDED. So I thought Sultanamet was AWESOME until I went to Beyoglu and realized I liked it better. Good points about Sultanamet: It's close to 90 percent of the big attractions in Istanbul. It has it's own metro stop that can take you just about anywhere -- including the airport. You can also walk easily to the harbor for boat trips. While it's crowded, the hotels that are set back in little hans off one or two main drags are pretty quiet. There are some very charming side streets in the area where you can escape and look at real Istanbul. This is the Old City, so its the architecture is really cool and there are many charming historic buildings along the back streets.Bad points: I've lived all over the world, including freaking Shanghai, and I was annoyed with the crowds here. Starting at about 7 am and late into the night, the narrow streets are packed with tourists who are walking en masse very ... very ... slowly. So just walking somewhere like the tram stop, which should take 2 minutes, takes 10. After a few days, it was starting to feel like a form of torture. Really. I have never seen crowds like this. It's sort of astounding in and of itself to see so many people from all over the world (including many muslim people) who apparently love this city and feel a connection to it. But yeah, after a few days, the crowds were a constant source of bemusement or rage (depending on my mood).Next time, given the awesomeness of Istanbul's public trans, I'd probably stay in Beyoglu where it's less crowded. That side is also quite cool and atmospheric, and though it's also crowded, it feels a bit more Turkish and a bit less like a Disneyland-type world inhabited entirely by tourists.
History comes alive. What a beautiful district. So much history. Beautiful hotels, restaurants, turkish sweet shops, bakeries and magnificent historical sights everywhere.

The grand mosque, sophie Hagie and the hippodrom. A must see. The mosque was so grand and the architecture was fabulous.So was the Sophie Hagie the church built by Emperor Constantine. A whole day walking tour. Worth every bit of it.

Central. If you are visiting Istanbul for the first time, this is where to be. Everything you would be here to see is close by. the mosques, bazaars and squares are all within an easy walk. There is also the tram shuttle running continuously and have a car would be a waste of time as the traffic situation in Istanbul is a nightmare. Watch the taxi drivers, they have a reputation for taking you the 'long' way round. Apparently they do it even with the locals.

Good location for Museum visits. The location for good to visit all of istanbul be it the tram , hop on hop off or organised tours. The local tourist company Turista was the best and very proffessinal in organising every thing .

The Belly of the Old Town. You might feel overwhelmed as where to start and what to see as there is so much to see there.I usually suggest to do it in three days not to get what I call: "Sight Seeing Indigestion!"But if you don't mind it it can be done in one day if you follow my path.1- SULTAN AHMET or Blue Mosque2- YERE BATAN or Roman Water Cistern (a great place to stop when it is hot!)By now you must be hungry go back to Sultan Ahmet cross the street and you have the BEST Kofte Restaurant of Istanbul (kind of hamburger but much more tastier!), don't expect a big menu that is all the do, with yoghurt or without, with amazing pickles and pide, there are two, the fabulous one is called "SULTAN AHMET KOFTECISI",3- Now with your belly full you are ready to appreciate one of the 7 Wonder of the World, Ayasofya or Santa Sophia. You need a good two hours to really appreciate it.From there walk the back street, full of old houses and shops (don't buy there it is cheaper at Kapalicarsi!) and get to your:-4. Topkapi Sarayi, the home of our Sultans, don't miss the Harem, different door and ticket. Do see the kitchens, the Room of the Porcelains, the 7 Carat Diamond, the amazing huge Emerald, which was featured in a film!If you are hungry or thirsty there is a very good Restaurant cum Coffee House down the stairs with a not-to-be-missed view of the Bosphorus, ideal place to take pictures!If you did it in one day, you will be ready to have a soothing bath and go sleep, dreaming of the many splendor a of Istanbul!

Everything together there!. The good thing is that you have all the attractions there. You can go to Hagya Sofía, Blue Mosque, Top Capi Palace, the Cisterns, grand bazaar. The city town hall put young people to help tourists in the streets, and they are very helpful indeed when you get lost. The only thing I don´t like is people trying to sell you stuff all the time, but it´s part of Turkish culture, so you just hace to run away from them.

fasinating. such an interesting area to explore, not only are there a lot of historical places to visit, I also got a lot of pleasure just exploring all the little side streets with their amazing old buildings which are or have been restored, and visiting the many roof top restuarants

So much to see. You can't stay in Istanbul without a visit to this district. full with history . A BK guide is a must if you want to explore the area. The best way to explore the area is by foot.Allow a full day if you want to visit Topkapi Palace, go early to avoid the Q.
Good location. Center of Istanbul main attractions. Great architecture, cobble stoned roads, access to the tram system and other public transport. Best travel is by food
city center. It is the real city center of Istanbul, always busy, always crowded many important historical sites and popular restaurants with many shops.

Fun, but if you are tourist phobic, it's not for you. Great energy, busy, colorful, interesting, and endlessly entertaining, this heart of the Istanbul Vacation has an endless supply of shops, restaurants, clubs, hotels, bars, and attractions like the Grand Bazar to keep just about anyone entertained-unless crowds of tourists, souvenir shops, and noise aren't your thing. Then, it's pretty much hell on a sugar cone. That being said, if you are looking for a chance to get some food, people watch, shop for souvenirs, have some drinks with friends, it's pretty much a don't miss. The usual summer swelter and cruise ship in port provisos notwithstanding, it's a lot of fun, as long as it's your cup of Apple Tea-and yes, try the Apple Tea, it's excellent.

classy. this is the most touristic area of Istanbul. Though it also has at least 4 major sites to see - St Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cictern, Topkapi...I would recomend to have lunch by the sea - you can just walk down from Topkapi exit. Walk along the sea and take a fish sandwich they make right in the street. Dont be afraid - it is fresh and clean. Take your sandwish and seat at the rocks by the seaside and enjoy teh atmosphere. I normally come there to have a break for lunch and give my legs some rest, or by the end of the day to enjoy the sunset.

Full of History. Being a peninsula bounded by bodies of water to north, east and south (the Golden Horn, Bosphorus and the Sea of Marmara, respectively) and by the old city walls to west, this part of the city is essentially what used to be called Constantinople, as the rest of what is today Istanbul was part of independent cities, towns, villages, fields or even complete wilderness later absorbed by the city. This process is still going on as Istanbul grows with increasing speed. Istanbul, or Byzantium as it was called then, was first settled by Greek colonists from Megara in Greek mainland in 667 BC. They founded their city at Seraglio Point (Sarayburnu) which is now occupied by Topkapı Palace. However, recent discoveries in a metro construction site in Yenikapı (on the southern coast of the peninsula) dates the very first date of Istanbul's settlement back to about 8000 years ago, which makes the city one of the oldest still-inhabited spots of the world. This peninsula was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1985. Sultanahmet, walking distance to the all historical sights of istanbul named old city.

Nice historical site - handfull street vendor. I can say it was a nice visit. Sultanahmet is just a melting pot of all tourist attraction in Istanbul. You have 4of the top ten list (Ayasofia, Topkapi. Blue mosque and Basilica Cistern). The street vendor is a little bit handful to handle, I may say. Is not that they're trying to rob you or something. But, Seems all of them comes from the same school of salesmanship. They will ask you the first question: "Where are you from?", then "Are you two married?" if yes, "How many children" and so on and so on until you start askign questions about the surrounding- then after that, they will never leave you. So, it will be better just show them your palm and say "Thank you". Quite interesting to see almost all of them are using the same approach like I mentioned above.

only area to stay. As a tourist this is the only area of istanbul to stay in due to its location nearby to all the big hitting tourist sites.I have stayed in both new and old istanbul as well as on the Asian side this area will save you a lot of money in cab fares as all the major sites are within walkind distance.

Istanbul!. Memorable place! So much to see! Loved the busy, crowded place...but superclean! Blue Mosque was beautiful! Hagia Sophia was fascinating, impressive and a symbol of tolerance! The Sultan instead of destroying the biblical art covered it up with plaster! Now with ongoing restoration we are able to see the beautiful images and millions of gold chips! We used a local guide at the entrance paid 60 TLR in addition to the tickets - was well worth it! We did the Bosphorus cruise for 100 TLR for 4 people - the vendor just across from Sophia. It was spectacular way to see this sprawling city and the tour guide was great! Dinner at Motbah next to Hagia Sophia is a must to experience the Ottoman Cuisine! Don't miss the Dondurma, freshly squeezed juices on the streets! Grand Bazaar is an experience ....but low quality goods. We bought the Turkish Delight at Hafiz MUSTAFA in Taksim Square....the best dont miss it! Hafiz Mustfa has the best coffee and pastrie! The ceramics sold at Grand Bazaar are certainly not handmade! If you visit the pottery making store in Cappadochia you will appreciate the difference! Tram ride is an experience! Put on your best walking shoe and walk everywhere! Visit the Istiklal street in Taksim Square....late night...just bustling with people! And the street food are excellent! 4 days is Istanbul was not enough to experience this great city! Certainly going back! BTW if you love fish make sure you eat by the we shore!

Definitely an icon of Istanbul!. This is pretty much where the hub and the hustle and bustle of Istanbul can be found, NOT sayin that the other parts of Istanbul arent worth seeing and going to, like the Galata, and the Istiklal area, but the district is distinct as this was the main square and main are where the sultans of old made their home, loads of site to see, landmarks to visit and so on and totally walkable and accessible by foot!

Fantastic historical sights,. I would say this is the main area that all the historical sights are it is very much worth a visit. great atmosphere, great eating places and everything is in walking distance
So much to see. There is so much to see and do in such a small area one could spend weeks going through the sights. Majestic and beautiful.
you walk through the history and culture. a nice area to visit mosques, eat good meals, have fun walking or even shopping some souvenirs.. good transportation

Heart of Istanbul. Great place for history buffs and bluffs. You almost feel sorry for the tour guides who want your business but it seems life is difficult for them. Good place to eat and get your transportation but shop elsewhere.
Best place to stay. There are a lot of hotels and restaurants, and the area includes the main things to see in Istambul. Some streets can get noisy at night time. More turists than locals for sure.

Best part of the city. If you are a traveller looking to explore and feel the historical part of Istanbul, this is the perfect place to stay... The old city... just put your walking shoes on and start visiting... Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, German Fountain... many restaurants and cafés are around... too many even... lively district rich in history and tourists... tram would take you to all places so no need to worry about transportation... and dont fall for tour operators in the square... all cruises you can have them for lesser prices at Kabatas (port) which you can reach by tram for 2$... in summary, best place to stay...
Amazing District. I stayed in Sultanahmet area and enjoyed everything I saw. The atmosphere and environment was so warming and people are friendly. Didn't like many street dogs around the area.

Really beautiful place !!. Our Hotel was not far from there and we stayed in Istanbul for a week , we had a great time going up and down the street , full of shops cafes and restaurants , I loved the Chocolate Baklava !!! The more you go up towards the Bazar the cheaper the Prices ! Recommends !
Put your walking shoes on.. Lots to see including of course the Grand Bazaar and the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace. Make sure you don't miss the underground Cistern.

City is fabulous. From the Hagia Soohia, the Blue Mosque, the Spice Market, the Grand Bazaar, the area is endlessly fascinating. Parts of it can be extremely crowded. I wasn't sure that I knew that there were so many people in the world.

This is the Historic Old Town of Istanbul. Sultanahmet district is the old city area of Istanbul. If you are keen to read the reviews before planning your time in this area, make sure you also look at the Trip Advisor reviews on the Historic Area of Istanbul. Essentially this the same as Sultanahmet.I have reviewed the Historic Area (August 2014) and suggested that the key is to pre-plan your visit, there is so much to take in. That review goes into a lot more detail if you are interested.All of the key attractions demand time, the queues unfortunately in the August - October period are long, and there are tourists and Turks everywhere. Do persist however, as the rewards are immense. In particular, endurance is required for the Topkapi Palace and its vast surrounds - warrants a half day at least, with lots of walking. Remember the hat for the sun, a water bottle and camera batteries.The hours that attractions are open is a challenge for Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and the Basillca. They are also closed on certain days. So plan ahead with your guide book. Do not fail to wander the Hippodrome and admire the minarets in these vast open spaces amidst a city of well in excess of 20 million people. And eat locally in the many many sidewalk cafes with such great vegetarian food in particular and a cold beer. If you are still to choose where to stay this district is superb, it gives easy walking access to all of these attractions, and if the queues are too long, you can head back to your hotel and then come again 2 hours later. I can recommend that the Erboy Hotel is a great little hotel with a very good international breakfast and is ideally located in this district.
Too busy.. It is something to see but it is just so busy with tourists. But you must go here to get the smells and the huge array of goods for sale.
smell old, buy modern :). Many old buildings located there. Museums, tombs, mosques... You can taste some otantic food and drinks. Mostly crowded streets.

Sultanahmet , the historical heart of Turkey. I liked the shops and many restaurants and walking in the busy streets. The Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia and Topkapi are awesome.I stayed in Sultanahmet district for the second time and find it the best area for short stays.

We stayed here .... We chose this part of Istanbul to stay, as this was our first time here. It was absolutely the right choice, even though our accommodation was a little more pricey than had we stayed further out. Truly everything is within walking distance - mosques, museums, trams, busses, markets, bazaars, teller machines (!!!), restaurants, night-time entertainment. From here, it's a pleasant walk over the Galata Bridge, past the dozens upon dozens of sardine fishermen, up toward Taksim Square. It's a reasonable train trip to/from the airport. Lots of young people (students), old people (long-time residents), small business of all types ... friendly, warm, and welcoming.
Plenty of of choice to eat!. Great vibe and selection of eateries, watch the world go by with a cold beer! Close to major attractions.

Hippodrome rocks. I went with my wife and kid near the end of ramadan.. we loved the turkish atmosphere where everyone was bustling around the hippodrome having their picnics and just enjoying life with family and friends. Only downside was that food is more pricey than other areas - guess its a touristy place but overall, i prefer the people and scenery more than the historical monuments whose entry fees are pricey for their worth.

All in one. In Sultanahmet area you will see every things and you will enjoy walking in the old city where the palace, Blue mosque, Aya Sofia are very close. Many restaurants and attractive thing also around.

Well worth exploring. The old city is the best place to explore and feel the city. The European side offers a lot of landmarks, shops, local food. If you are not in a hurry, you can enjoy the gorgeous landscape of Istanbul by taking a ferry (2 hours arr).

Always a treat. Love just leisurely walking around in the area, discovering little hidden treasures around well-known grandeur every time I visit Istanbul. Go there at least once in your life and you are bound to have some unforgettable moments.

So much to see and do. What a fantastic area of a fantastic city. There are so many things to see and do in the Sultanahmet area. Be aware that in summer the crowds can be killjoys and the lines to all the attractions are longer than long. Also you will get hassled by touts selling carpets or tours but this isn't a huge worry. Just relax and take it all in.

so much to see.... The main attractions are very close and easy to walk between. Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace are must sees. Suleymaniye Mosque is more impactful than the Blue Mosque but at a greater distance from the main area. Basilca Cistern is also very interesting. I recommend walking as traffic is extremely heavy in the city. Grand Bazaar and Spice Market (Egyptian Bazarre) are interesting and a good place for kitchy souvenirs, but I found then to be overwhelming. Get an early start everyday as there is so much to see!

Superb!. This is the place to be! All the historical monuments are located in this area and so are the restaurants. Very safe place and was were impressed with the over all city. We even ate street food!!

Better in winter. Many do not know that Istanbul is not always hot, being close to the Black Sea and Russia, it gets cold, sometimes below zero and snowy as well. In winter Istanbul and Sultanahmet gets even more mystical.

Main area of istanbul. this area is nice if it is the first time you visit Istanbul. all sightseeing are around you. just few minutes to arrive the places.
tram, bus and ferry stations are steps away.

Has it all. Great concentration of shopping, major attractions such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi palace and the Hippodrome. Plenty of restaurants to chose from. Most seem to have a terrace or street cafe tables available, which is nice.
All the attactions in one area. This area is a must visit in Istanbul. All the key attractions are here and it is a great area to walk around. There are also some great restaurants.
Best place Everr. Culture..pleasure...people..Turkish Hamam..mosques ..shopping...nightlife...great place to spend time
Sites. Great area to walk around and check out sites. Plenty photo opportunities and people very friendly...and I found locals very helpful...

Central to all Attractions. If you visiting Istanbul then this is the area to head for, known as the Old Town, Sultanahmet was the beginning of the historic city of Constantinople named after the Emperor Constantineus. All the key attractions are within a mile radius and the open top bus tour leaves from Sofia Square has both of the largest Mosques at either end, Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque.The Basilica cistern and Topkapi Palace are also on the edge of the square whilst Dolmabahce Palace and the Egyptian Bazar are a 15 minute walk.There are plenty of hotels in this area and the further back you go the more economical the price will be. We have stayed twice in Istanbul, the first time was in the Sumengen Hotel a little way back from the main square at £65 per night and great value for money. The second time we stayed at the Hagia Sofia Hotel at £145 per night but the price reflects the close proximity to the square and a more luxurious finish.Arguably the cleanest city I have ever seen and Sultanahmet retained a magnificent historical and traditional ambience whilst providing a vast array of bars and restaurants to cater for every taste.

Lovely place for an evening walk.. We stayed at Sultanahmet, and this was like our pit-stop daily for food, sweets and may be other needs.This place is filled with people, and lots of outlets - sweets, food, light shop, souvenir shops etc..It's better to rely on trip advisor before you get in to eat. More the reviews, more reliable is the eat-out joint.Only issue is - people calling for you forcefully to get in to their shops(desperately) which gets annoying after a tolerance limit :) , but can't help that, if you think at their point of view. A brilliant walk through the district in the evening is much recommended.

Key sites all within 10-20 minute walking distance of each other. Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace are all quite close to each other, we also popped down to spice bazaar, Soliman Mosque (great rooftop bars there). Did not make it to a Hamam..still on my to-do list

Lovely space. This was a real surprise having come from the busy streets of the main city, the fountains and greenery set off the background views of Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque and made for some beautiful photographs.
Lots of major attractions in the one area.. Easily reached by tram, big open spaces around monuments, easy to spend hours here. Wonderful museums and other places to visit.

Amazing. Being among all that history that has influenced our lives today was amazing. Old and new working alongside was great. We hired a guide to explain the historical facts of the area and guide us through the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. An amazing place where we could spend more time and certainly consider visiting again.

Great collection of Old World sites. The Sultanahmet is full of tourists because of so many sites in one area.
The Hagia Spophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Basilica Cisterns, Pash Rustem Mosque, etc.
We didn't find the carpet salesman particularly aggressive as others have. We merely politely declined.
A must visit for anyone interested in culture, history, civilization, religion, architecture...

such a rich cultural heritage. interesting area - a mixture of archeological/cultural items and religious ambience. Ample opportunities of observing the religious life of Islamic world. However, the best part was to visit the strong and rich cultural heritage of Islamic tradition.
We felt safe. As we were with friends we spent most of our time walking between locations and felt safe, with friendly locals.

Always amusing. The whole area is always of a lot of interesting activities around. Just to sit and watch the fasting moving life, tourists, the stalls is enough. I have gone there for several times throughout my stay in Istanbul for 6 years. Always I had things to lift my camera for. The minarets, architecture, streets, people, artists, sellers and a deep long history of it's every single stone. Lot to wonder a lot to imagine. Everyday is a new day. Every weather brings it a different colour.

Unbelievable. It has Local Culture, History, Architecture and the Hustle and bustle of a City all wrapped up in one place.From the Blue Mosque to the Roman Cisterns under the city, the Spice Market and the Grand Bazaar something for everyone.Really worth a visit just for the atmosphere that goes with it.

Life is where Sultanahmet is.... An area bustling with activities, full of life, people, hawkers and the aroma of Turkish food around the walk ways. Walk past the streets with shopping delights and I assure no restaurants will miss you when you walk past. Truly Istanbul.

Buzzing with life and activity, foodie's delight. Beware of shop keepers as most of them want to get the best out of a tourists pockets, heavy bargaining upto 50% on almost everything, has many Turkish delight(sweet) stores and some really cool clubs/pubs, good hookah bars

Bustling area, some good restaurants, centre of historic tourist stops. Liked sitting in the small restaurants and watching all the activity. Initially we really disliked the constant hustling, particularly relating to the Bosphorus cruises and the incessant carpet shop hustlers; however we did find that a polite but very firm 'No thank you' was often enough to dissuade them, provided we just kept walking and didn't engage with them in any conversation or explanation.

This is a must do ....spend a couple of days. amazing village type feel, laneways, access to grand bazaar, extraordinary little shops, boutique, pastries, art etc ...this is a must wear good shoes pound the pavement and get lost

Very easy for Do It Yourself. Initially we went on a guided tour which costed 50 Euro per person for a whole day. Next 3 days, we did the tour ourself. It is really easy to do the Sultanahmet district trip yourself. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Basillica, Hippodrome, Museums are all close by and walkable distance. During month of July, weather is around 70ish and awesome to walk. We walked close to 16000 steps/day. We are a family of 5. Kids are around 15,11 and 5. We are also vegetarian and there is a falafel place(Makarana.sarayi.com.tr) near Grand Bazaar, this is very inexpensive and high quality. There is also a Hamam place next to this. We went to an Indian restaurant near sophia called Dubb restaurant. Food was good and service was great, but expensive. Taxi are very inexpensive and drivers are honest. They didn't want to take tips and we literally forced it on them as we were 5 people in one taxi.Also, take the bosphorus cruise offered for the local turkish people which is 20lira per person.
Awesome. We loved staying in this district. Many historical monuments as well as several bazaars are in the area. Many local and authentic places to eat that fit all budgets. Shoppers paradise.

Wonderful neighborhood to stay in. We stayed here for five days in a rented apartment. Awesome place to stay in: gives you a real sense of Istanbul history. Walked to all major sites: blue mosque, hagia sofiya, Topkapi, grand bazaar, cimberlitas hamami, the Bosphorus for breezy walks along Kennedy Cadesi. Sultanahmet square was bustling with a traditional outdoor market late into the night for Ramadan. Convenient access by tram to other parts of the city. Lots of stores, restaurants and markets right there. Beware of crazy driving in the narrow streets and stray cats by the dozen.
Great location in Instanbul. Popular attractions were within walking distance, and the area was very tourist friendly. Restaurants, shopping, museums, and more were closely located.
bustling area with tons of restaurants. There are lots of city attractions to see and experience. Lots of restaurants and vendors very eager for tourists to patronize their businesses.
All the biggies in one place!. Topkapi Palace, the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, New Mosque, Suleymaniye Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Cistern, and Hippodrome are all located here.
Sprit of Othman History. I can not feel the Othman history if I stay out of this district while I stay in Istanbul .. Buildings, roads, masjids and every single stone is telling me a story ..
Impressive but tourist trap. Impressive museums and sights, but brutally touristic. Beware of high priced, well, everything: tours, meals, drinks :D

So much history here. For first time visitors I would highly recommend that you spend sometime exploring the areas, visiting some of the famous sites such as Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Archaeological Museum, the Grand Bazzar and many more. Even if you don't stay in one of the hotels in the area, a trip to the Sultanahmet will leave you with the spirits of Istanbul and Constantinople. There are many nice restaurants in the area that you can sample the fine Ottoman cuisines, it is such a vibrant city that makes you want to come back again as soon as you can!

Sultanahmet is the heart of Istanbul. This lovely square is between the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque, also near Topkapi. Go for a visit at Iftar, when the fast breaks, great atmosphere! Many great restaurants in the alleys nearby.

History wherever you look. A great area to discover the old part of Istanbul on the European side. Wherever you look, there stands a piece of old history. In the night, floods of people occupy the streets in a nice carnival as everybody is celebrating this city.

Bustling!!. We stayed at two hotels in the Sultanahmet district within walking distance to all the tourist attractions (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace etc). It was lively and bustling with activity. Restaurants and shops were everywhere. Bargain! Public tranport was good. We took the tram to the spice market and hamam. People were quite helpful but be sure to ask for clarification when ordering food at the restaurants. We found ourselves with a lot more food than we could eat (and ended up with a big bill besides). On the whole, the food was good especially the fish usually fresh and substantial.

Enjoyed the Grand Bazaar, Haifa Sophia Muzee and the Blue Mosque. Must see is the Topkapi Palace Muzee.. Clean environment everywhere we went with easy access with Fast Pass Museum cards. Shopping was interesting as everyone is seeking to bargain for the right price but once you get into the negotiation, its fun.

This is Istanbul. The heart of Istanbul where everything is around you, if this is your first time in Istanbul, then choose your hotel in this district and you will save on transportation (time and money).Most of the attractions are a walking distance around you.Big variety of restaurants in the area to serve all tastes.

Should be more lively. We have expected nice Istanbul atmosphere but maybe because of low season it was very quiet. Some of the places were closed, we have meet many lazy waiters. I hope the higher season is better time to visit Sultanahmet

Amazing Vibe!. Sultan Ahmet district is the place to stay when visiting Istanbul. The area probably has literally 100's of quaint hotels and B&B's, and probably an equal number of charming restaurants. The major historlc sites such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, the Grand Bazaar etc. are all within walking distance. Not to mention all the narrow, crooked, cobblestoned streets which give the whole area an extremely charming and old-world feel. After a hectic day of sightseeing and on our way back to the hotel, we would just park ourselves on a bench near the fountain between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia, and enjoy the sights and sounds... the hawkers and vendors, the children playing, the fresh watermelon and the roasted chestnuts! And watching the world passing you by... like the Liecester Square of the East!
Fantastic Diverse Are to Visit... SO much to do and see in Sultanahmet District. There is history, shopping, people, food.I recommend 2 or 3 days to explore!
must seen. this is a great tourist area. Full of restaurants and landmarks. Easy to get around walking or by public transport.
Great atmosphere. Lots to see and do. Hive of activity. Historical attractions and parks within walking distance of restaurants, bars and bazaars
Most amazing town. Brilliant! I stay in the Sultanahmet district every time I'm in Istanbul! So much life and the most fantastic restaurants around!

A wonderful area. This is a wonderful area to stay in in my opinion. So close to all the big attractions with a variety of well priced restaurants. The tram gives easy access but we were able to walk to both the Grand and Spice bazaars and you are also very close to Eminonu and the Golden Horn. We were there during the first weekend of Ramadan and there was a wonderfully festive and community spirit throughout

Great vibe of people. Be prepared to be hasseled walking down the street - for invitation for cafe eating, souvenirs and street vendors.Lots of gorgeous food stores, cakes and sweet shops - a real buzz down the main street.
Beautiful. A great place to be- you can see the blue mosque and the fountain - there are great restaurants there too - try Sultanahmet kofte and ottoman kitchen
Jungle. Nice - but be prepared, it is the touristic jungle of Istanbul. I recomand other cities for shopping (at least other parts of Istanbul!)
sultan ahmet istanpul. sultan ahmed mosque beautiful place and see agood turkish and Ottman history the place is worth a visit and I advise you to visit him
Fabulous area. The whole area is interesting with incredible history. There is so much to see in a small area plus all the great restaurants and shops means there is something for everyone to enjoy.

Great Location: Close to major attractions and Very safe at night. I stayed in Sultanhmet for one week.
