I enjoyed the restaurants, the shops and the proximity to the Hagia Sophia, and the Blue Mosque It was also close to the Metro for those interested in doing exploring across the bridge. There are no shortages of good restaurants/cafes with wonderful views of the city.

A Great Area To Roam. This was a short walk from our hotel and we passed through here many times during our 4 day stay in Istanbul. Yes, the hawkers can be annoying but your best bet is just to keep walking and say no. We found it best to not tell them where we were from from as invariably they would know someone in your home state and talk and them push you to visit their shop (carpet, pottery, etc.). But we never felt threatened are worried about our safety. We had an added bonus that on the first night of Ramadan we were there and it was jammed packed with thousands of folks sitting at tables waiting to eat and we inadvertently were in a prime spot to see the Prime Minister of Turkey as he got out of his car and with his body guards got to the stage and made a speech. We were less than 10 yards away! But this is a great area to stroll and people watch. Lots of cafes and such and again, we never felt threatened in anyway and always felt very safe.

Memories of Istanbul. Our stay in Istanbul was coming in the month of Ramazan or fasting month of Muslims. therefore we wanted to to stay in a hotel which was close to the blue Mosque so that we can easily walk to the mosque to attend the prayers. Thankfully we got such a place. Though it was not very close but was reasonably close. One can easily get lost in the small streets of this district but in order to find your way you just have to ask about the blue mosque. The main market of this area is on the tram line but if you want to buy some cheaper stuff my advise is to try out other small streets and never forget to bargain. If you have booked a hotel here then keepits phone number with you and make the taxi driver and the hotel talk to each other. While roaming in the streets be ware of pick pockets. Preferably leave your credit cards in the hotel, Turkish merchants also like cash payments. Here you would find many students with the "ask me" shirts, they speak prefect English and can be excellent interpreters for you. There are many attractions very close to each other in this district it is advisable to dedicate at least a full day for this district

Soaking up the atmosphere and history in the Old City. For a short city break, the Sultanahmet District of Istanbul provides an excellent base and there are some great hotels in the vicinity. Naturally the Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque are key attractions in this area, but do take time to enjoy the parks, bazaars and don't forget to wander down to the water's edge.Having visited during Ramadan the atmosphere in the evenings, as the devout broke their daily fast was very special indeed.

The area to stay when in Istanbul. If you are going to stay in Istanbul, you should stay in one of the many boutique hotels in this area. Take your time to walk around, go to the many restaurant and even walk around the Mosques areas. It is very safe and the people are very friendly.

Nice Attractions - Just be Cautious. I echo those who felt hounded around much of the area. I learned quickly that anyone in Istanbul who said hello was not being friendly, instead they were trying to sell you something - a tour, a book, a quick visit to their carpet company etc...There were some great attractions that were must see but you have to be prepared to deal with the local merchants. Anyone who has ever done the tours/taxis/timeshare walk at Cancun airport will be able to relate....but rather than one strip, this is an entire area of constant harassment. I had no problem with this in the bazaar, in fact that's where I expected it, but everywhere got to be a bit much.TAXIS: BEWARE. Despite being licensed, you will have to be very firm and specific. Provide EXACT addresses to hotels. By the end of our trip I was having to hold up the map/GPS on my phone to show them how far away from the route they were supposed to be on. Rip off merchants who drive like lunatics. Literally every cab I went into I had to dig out the belt receptacle. Overall Istanbul is a must-see....but I can't help feel glad it's one I've check off the bucket list and wont have to go back.

Busy, Busy, Busy.... A incredibly busy pedestrian shopping area, it is full of locals and tourists shopping at the many shops selling all kinds of items and eating at the many restaurants/cafés. Wander and enjoy the many sights and smells you will encounter. It may be crowded but it is a wonderful experience to take in on you visit to Istanbul. Should some people hassle you to buy on the street, just don't touch the item or you will never be able to give it back to them because they refuse to take it. To save yourself time and trouble, if you aren't interested then ignore and say no and move on.

Tourist's Delight. The Sultanahmet area is the perfect blend of everything u want during a vacation.Has ample hotels to stay with all the main tourist attractions like the Blue Mosque,The Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace within walking distance of each other.Its a crowded street with many different restaurants,small cafes and eateries,the traditional Turkish sweet shops.One can keep walking along the tram rail and reach the Grand Bazaar in ten minutes.Overall a good experience,but gets very crowded in the evenings.

Something for all the senses. Came here with a group of x5 and a guide. Loved the vibe & buzz of the busy market stalls. We found the people to be warm & genuine,not pestering us to buy (which we have found in other souks) There was something to stimulate all sights,sounds,textures and tastes,fascinating place.

You will be surpised. There is also a pedestrianised shopping street Isticlal. There are many shops and eating places. One we tried was Midpoint, they have drinks food and free WiFi with additional views at the back. We have already established the amount of Mosques in Istanbul, imagine my surprise when we bumped into a church down the same street. Admittedly behind iron gates but nevertheless it was there. Have a wonder around you will be surprised what you will see. www.blogface.co.uk
be careful. from the east and from syria turkey constantly around here. Take your head can come at any moment. Never take anything from street vendors because of the pain so you do not encounter.
impressive.. all 3 main sights to see are here. pleasant garden and fountain. masses of tourists. other sights nearby. the heart of old Istanbul.

tourist hangout place. this area is basically a massive tourist shopping area..you will see the same thing over and over again everywhere. it is nice no doubt :) but shops are quite repetitive. one can spend a day walking around , enough restaurants and things to see and do in that area.metro T1 passes along that area.this is a must see area....

VARIETY. Everything happens around here. Turkish Baths, pedicures, social activities, festivities, McDonalds, traditional food, all type of shops including cellphone and camerashop. Clothing here cost more or less the same as at the market. The light that can be bought here is stunning. Walking around at night is a sight for sore eyes.

Tourist Trap that you are delighted to be trapped in. Yes, this historic ancient district is a tourist trap. Yes, the street vendors and tour guides hawking their wares are an extreme annoyance. Yes, the area can become overwhelmed with tourists and tour groups and buses and OMG more tourists from around the world than you can imagine. Hustle and bustle abound. But, what a fantastic area!! Within one square mile you have more ancient, early Byzantine church, medieval, and Ottoman history than one can imagine. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, views of the Bosphorus Straits, the ancient Roman Hippodrome. And much, much more. Dining at all levels and prices are available. Shops selling everything from tacky mini-replicas of the Blue Mosque to authentic Turkish rugs. And, about a mile away (within walking distance) is the Grand Bazaar. Definitely not to be missed!

Exhilarating...Lively...Stay There. I can't imagine staying anywhere else in Istanbul unless you are there simply to shop in an area like Istikal Street. Lovely boutique hotels, charming cafés, quaint cobblestone and brick streets --some narrow others winding, with little shops bursting with traditional Turkish products and friendly but not bothersome shop keepers are just the beginning. The most significant historical sights populate this area and it is just as wonderful o be there until late in the evening as during the day.
The shortest best day tour I have had in Istanbul. All the main attractions are within short walking distance. With a comfortable shoes, you can cover most of this area within 5 hours. So beauitful!

Loved every minute, want to go back!. Fantastic old city district, surrounded by history, incredible!We stayed here at the ottoman park hotel and walked our feet off.So many sites to see and your amongst the real people going about their daily lives. All so friendly and helpful. Never felt unsafe!The food! OMG THE FOOD! Did I mention the food :)Stay for a week at least and get amongst it and walk the streets.Istanbul and sultanas eat was our favourite easily!
Find a hotel there!. Please find a hotel in old town to stay there. The wonderful streets, sights and the loud call-to-prayer at night are just two of many things too good to miss.

average. Sounds exotic, but if you've grown up in Europe, you've probably seen a lot of old buildings and ruins. If your first time to see ruins, you may enjoy it. Not for the "sporty" adventure activity types. You might get bored.

Great area to see all. Most of the mosques and historical attractions are in this area. It has also different markets . Late night cafés and restaurants. There are Indian , Chinese and international restaurants . As well as Turkish ones. Nice place to enjoy evening walks as well as day walks. Taxi modern tram and metro are available there . One of the best places I have visited in Istanbul and I try to visit it every time I go there. The area has an excellent variety of hotels too.

Georgeous part of Istambul. Our Hotel were located in Sultanahmet Distric, near to Big Bazar. what can i say about this? full of life, stores, turkish culture was amazing and unique.If you go to istambul, this location is a must.

Love the old city!. Eclectic tourist part of town with all attractions and shops/ restaurants/cafés within walking distance. A highlight was the Spice Bazaar, a 15minute walk away from Hagia Sofia. Do this on your own, before a tour if you can. Explore the surrounding markets on a saturday with the locals and pay "local resident" prices. Prices go up on Sundays for the influx of tour groups. Buy turkish delight from "Hayat" the store, its fresh and delicious! Careful of the traffic as a pedestrian!

A trip back in time. What an incredible part of Turkey this is. The sights, smells and sounds all are from a long time back. Millions of busy people on countless buses, trams, boats - even the odd float plane! Can't describe it properly, just go there. Oh, and don't change your money at home - best possible rate in UK was 3.42 to the £, the exchange bureau down the road from the Grand Bizarre was 3.62 with no commission! That's an unusual exchange difference in my experience. Just go there!

Traveller. If you come to Sultanahmet,you should see Blue Mosque and you should go on a trip Sultanahmet Square. I must say that you will enjoy because this place is very active and crowded. All people had better see this good place.
Perfect area to see many sites in Istanbul.. This area is well served by good hotels, restaurants as well as the Blue Mosque and Grand Bazaar almost on the door step.
"The Best". Sulthanahmet district is everything one can think of.All the landmarks and places of interest are within walking distance.This is the area to stay in Istanbul.
Just love it. The atmosphere, restaurants,buildings, people watching, exploring streets and markets. Liked especially the variety of entertainment and restaurants.

Be prepared to haggle!. Lovely district and lots to see and do. You must haggle with everything even the cost of your drinks. Not all restaurants serve alcohol and those that do have hugely different prices so worth haggling before you go in as they all have street staff encouraging you to use their restaurant.
Wonderful sights, shopping and restaurants.. From the beautiful Blue Mosque to fun eateries and great shopping all in a few blocks....everything you need at your feet.

Heart of Istanbul!!. This district as it all, 1500 years old church, turned mosque, turned museum to beautiful mosques, bazars, streets, palace, parks and museums. bustling with culture and history! dont miss the night cruise and the whirling dervesh! oh but be weary of the the taxi drivers. know your way and keep an eye on that meter!
So much to see. This area is filled to bursting with sights, sounds, tastes & so much more. Always something to find around the next corner.
Family holiday. Worth seeing, plan your day as there is plenty to see. Very safe and clean. Locals are very polite and helpful.

Old town. Well sign posted , easy to walk around and many things to see which are close together . Did not find any problems with queues and easy to see the main 5-6 attractions by foot in 1 day . plenty of local restaurants , the usual carpet / suit / fake watch salesmen are everywhere but thats part of the fun.

Unforgettable. The Sultanhamet district if Istanbul is a fabulous place. Everything is within walking distance and the views over the sea are wonderful. The red bus is available if you want to do a bit of hopping on and off in order to visit other districts and also the tram. Taxis are a cheap ride too. If you like walking like we did you can walk from here to Taksim Square in the European part of Istanbul which again is a wonderful place to visit. It's more upbeat than the Sultanhamet district but still worth a visit and there are many sites to see and explore on the way. Some of the attractions in the Sultanhamet district are free to enter but others have costs involved which are not exorbitant.

This is the place to be. This is the best part of IST hands down. We stayed at the Doubletree by Hilton Old Town and this is right down the street. This is where are the main sites are: Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Haghia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, tours, restaurants, hop on/off buses, etc. There is also great shopping. I recommend staying in this area and eating at the House of Medusa – our hotel was about 25-30 minutes from the airport. There is a tram that goes through this area that we rode once, but it was so packed that we could hardly breathe – walking through the district is best.

Awesome. This is really a place where East meets West. All the great sights are unbelievable. The Blue Mosque is great, the Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cisterne, Grand Bazaar, the German Fountain the Hippodrome are all within walking distance. Also some great food and shopping. The only thing that is annoying is that a lot of men will hit on you if you are a woman alone. In my case (I am blond and curvy) it got to a point where I was almost unable to sightsee due to those distractions. I ended up putting a scarf on my head, which helped a little bit but was uncomfortable in the heat.Some of the men were pretty good looking so it was only partially annoying. If you take it with humor it can be a little fun, too.
History !. aya sophia, basilica cistern, blue mosque, different little shops, food, narrow streets, stone trough from bosphorus. A real great place to stay around.

Great area. The whole area had everything close at hand. We walked everywhere but could have used the tram if we'd have wanted to. It had historic buildings, good places to eat, lovely shops open in the evening, so you could shop after you'd eaten. We loved having everything all within a maximum of 15 minutes walk away from the hotel.
Old Istanbul. This was a fantastic area to explore. Take the Big red Bus and stop off for a couple of hours. Find a nice restaurant with a roof top terrace.

The Heart of the Old City. The Haghia Sophia, Blue Mosque and the Topkapi Palace are all located within this historic district. The narrow cobblestone streets filled with restaurants and shops make for a memorable experience

Colorful chaos. It is a history rich area in Istambul, with plenty of historic sites but also a lot of sellers of everything, from fresh orange juice to imitations of brand polo shirts. It is rather chaotic but the colours, odors, exoticism and history there contained make it worth using 3-4 days there.

Best part of Istanbul. You cannot and must not visit istanbul without spending a day or two in this area. You get the real feel of the place and what it must have been like. Check out the attractions on a map and you will see the majority are here.... Along with ample restaurants and bars and shops.... Plan a good day or two here!
Historic centre of the old city. We stayed here and so were so close to many magnificent sites and excellent restaurants. In the evening the main sites are tastefully illuminated.
Cute historic district. If you like little shops and crooked little cobblestone streets, this is the place for you. Just watch out and don't leave ALL your money there. It's very easy :)

Many historical attractions. This area has many attractions in close proximity (within walking distance of each other) and is close to public transport, restaurants and shops. Pity all the tourists know about it because there are hundreds everywhere :-)

Postcard. This is the spot. Hagia Sophia is 30 liras(10 euros), Blue Mosque is free, the squares are lovely, walking the Hypodrome is great, The Basilica Cistern is 20 liras and also worth a visit, the Topkapi Palace is just around the corner, really this is the place. Lots of restaurants and coffee shops, lot's of places to sit around and enjoy.

Grand Bazaar. Go there. It's a real bucket list kind of thing. You can easily get list, but what a wonderful labyrinth to get list in. Sample all the Turkish delight you are offered then take a bunch Home!

Must see but touristy. The Sultanahmet area includes most of the important landmarks of Istanbul and you must visit the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. In summer though the area is full of large tour groups and food prices in the close vicinity are high.

The essence of Istanbul. All major attractions of Istanbul are located here. If you have only one to half day, you can visit the mostly visited places, such as the palace, the mosques, grand bazaar, the shopping street and the underground waterway. Even you can take a Turkish bath in a historical bath room.

Nice place to walk around. This is the historic "Old city" part of Istanbul. It' has an old world charm to it. This is also where most of the tourist attractions are located. There are also a lot of souvenir shops littered through out he district. We found that pieces at these places were better than he grand bazaar. The tram line goes right through most of the parts of the city that may be of interest to you as a tourist. Also beware people can spot that you are a tourist and will harass you on the streets to come inside their stores restaurants or travel agencies.

Compact historical area in a huge city. Walking around this area really brings history as well as modern Istanbul to life. Take the time to visit as many sites as possible. Be sure to find the fountain between Hagia Sophia and the Mosque of Sultanahmet (the Blue Mosque). Look to you left and right and take in this amazing view point. Be sure to find the Hippodrome with its amazing columns and obelisks.

Best place to stay. Not knowing Istanbul we were so pleased to find our hotel was in the Sultanahmet District. This area contains the finest sights in the City - but it is intimate, friendly and full of intrigue too. The Blue Mosque, Ayia Sophia and other major sights are all contained within Sultanahmet - along with a plethora of excellent small restaurants and coffee shops. The best way to see the District is to walk - armed with a good map. Most of the hotels provide them.
A Passage through History. The old city is the real city. Full of history and a lot to see. The Blue mosque, what an amazing architectural structure. You could not miss this at any cost.
full of history. it would take months to se it all and to understand the background of the split beetween the two parts of istanbul
Walk through that great district.. Small streets and great old buildings with restaurants and shops all over the place. Enjoyed the atmosphere with so many friendly people all over the place.

A wonderful place for photography!. The whole area round Sultanahmet is well worth a visit. There are markets, kiosks, restaurants, shops but most importantly you really see Turkish life here, especially during the period of Ramadan.I photographed extensively here, both in the day and at night too.

Sultanahmet Square, the best!. The best place to walk around, relax, have a meal, ice cream or just people watch. The iluminated fountain as well as the mosque are beautiful to take pictures at night, and if you happen to be there during the month of ramadan, you won´t miss all the locals´ gatherings having their dinner after their call for prayer sitting on the grass. It´s beautiful to see. One of my favourite places to visit at night. You can also take the sight seeing tour bus from there. Don´t miss it!

Sultanahmet District. This was an amazing opportunity to walk around such an eclectic area of the city where there was so much to see in a relatively condensed area. It was easy to fall in love with Istanbul and everything Turkish.

ANCIENT CITY. We loved walking everywhere. So fascinating walking on the brick streets and narrow sidewalks through time. Eateries everywhere and the old and new mixed. Shops, parks, peoples, architectural form from centuries before. Smells of cooking in an ancient part of Istanbul equals the best trip so far and we are 70 years old.
very nice. I liked historical buildings of this area and Sultanahmet mosque and Aya sofia museum and grand bazaar, and also its good restaurants and shopping's Souvenirs.
Fantastic. Full of character and atmosphere.Great mixture of history and leisure. All within close proximity.Friendly and chilled people .

The pretty town. This city being overpopulated as it is was extremely clean. The landscaping is beyond compare with the red and white begoinias making beautiful Turkish designs in the greenscape areas. A beautiful part of Istanbul - and outstanding shopping!!

A lovely area in a lovely City.. The area has a old world look,with very pretty buildings,and a good area with lots of busy ,good ,trendy restuarants,We were pleased we chose the Sultanhamet area,it was perfect for our stay,and we would go back..

my istanbul trip -day 1. first day in Istanbul-24.06.2014-departure from Budapest at 11.10 from b3 gate,terminal B...arrival in Istanbul Sabiha Gokceh airport-took the Havatas shuttle for 13 lira to taksim...from taksim,was insaine the traffic,we took a cab for 85 lira-(a way of 10 min lasted 40)...the driver stopped to buy us water:) was sooo hot the weather! in the middle of the street are people who are saling water(1lira)...at 16.35 we arrived at the hotel(efendi)-really nice!!! the terace upstairs for breakfast really preety! and plus its soooo close to the main attractions:topkapi palace,mosques,basilica cistern,plus the parks and hippodrome!we just walked around for about 2 h and the we stopped for kebap from sehzade cag kebap(new york times,oct 2nd,2011 article)i'm not eating lamb or veal so i eat a nice salad, next we stopped on the same street at Hocapasa pidecisi for the chicken cheese pita(kind of turkish pizza),we bought some sweet stuff from hafiz mustafa, sekerleme(bahcje kapou n5)-quite expensive-had a apple shisha next to topkapi park at Gülhane sur cafe and some apple tea/apple tea with rosehips-tip: buy a istanbulkart and top it up so u can go by tram -cheeper and faster! -from newspaper kiosk...first we top it up with 10 tl but we payed 18tl...u receive 5tl back when u return the card...and btw,u can use it all the group(we were 2pers)...if u want to go by tram a lot top it up even more...we remained without money on the card and we needed to buy jetons(coins-4tl one) by istanbul card its 2tl one way-or something like this,if u go more by tram in 3h the take from your istanbul kart even less money,like 1,70 tl

Short visit this is the Istanbul this is the to stay. If you have limited time then this is the district to stay. If you stay in the modern part of Istanbul you will miss the history sights and sounds. You will also more the travelling into the areas you want to see.

Sultanahmet. the sultanahmet district is a great bustling area. most of the must see things in istanbul are in this area. its a nice walk as well or take the tram through. Coffee shops in gulleys, as well as shops on the main road for fresh turkish delight. its a great area to stay in so you are near the main attractions. love the cobbled streets.
Everything close by.. Everything close by, this is the area to stay when visiting Istanbul. Also good restaurants around. Dont forget to visit the Dervish Cafe.
seeped in history. The area is well geared towards the tourist, is clean and safe. I loved that the most well known historical sites in Istanbul are within walking distance of each other.
Magnificient!. This is the place to stay. Very beautiful and full of historic places to visit. Very well signed and clean. Easy to visit all the places you want with just a map.

Really nice specially for families. I have really enjoyed the sultanahmet area, me and my wife with the kids used to go there almost everyday during our 5 days visit it was really fun for the kids, nice to walk as the weather was great and you have many places to visit and see and have healthy snacks :)
Amazing. One of the best districts in Istanbul, nice resturants with outside tables, excellent environment, delesious dishes, good access to tramua,

Loved it!. We stayed in Sultanahmet and were not disappointed. We walked around drinking chai, eating kebab rolls and savoury pancaked sold by the local vendors. What a delight! Spent hours just walking around with our kids. Support the locals! We had fun bargaining and appreciating the history. As a first timer to Istanbul - this is the area to stay!

Istanbul visit. We stayed in this area,has lots of good Hotels,it is clean,well maintained.Most important has fantastic access, ten minutes walk, to the wonderful sights of Istanbul,the Blue Mosque,the Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace,The Basilica.They are plenty of eating places,we did not try them as we crossed them way out or back to Hotel.

Character filled area. This area is alive with history and lots too see. Vibrant athmosphere at night and great places to eat. Good mixture of food for the whole family. The main attractions thought are the historical sites. A must see if you are in the area. I personally like the view at night it is very mystical.

Istanbul made easy. the district is the perfect place to stay, easy walking distance to all of the sights. Restaurants tucked away in side streets, visit the English Book shop on the way to the bazaar - interesting place. I would have loved to stay more than 4 days, so will arrange a longer stay next time.

Fantastic. Sultanahmet is pure Turkey. Just do it. Its like the heart of the old city that never seems to sleep. Hustle and bustle all the time. Our last trip was the start of their summer so there was thousands of people still out late into the night. I love it.

Sultanahmet District is the place to stay in Istanbul. We stayed at Hotel Novano. Within walking distance to Arasta Bazaar, Blue Mosque, restaurants, tram, Hagia Sophia, Spice Bazaar and so much more. Charm and character as well as numerous shops and historic landmarks. This is the area to stay.

Central Old Town Location. Great Base for Exploring.. So many of the city's sights are located in this area. There's lots of good restaurants, cafes and bars too. Keep your camera handy, they'll always be something to take a photo of!If you're only in town for a couple of days, this is the perfect location to use as your base. There's also lot's of good small hotels in the neighbourhood.The tram runs right through this area, and you can venture further afield quite easily. It's only a short ride to the Grand Bazaar in one direction and the Galata Bridge in the other.

Sultanahmet. Its just a nice historical place to wander around or sit at one of the many café/bars and have a glass of wine and watch the world go by. Obviously caters for tourists mainly so prices in shops are probably a little high in this area but plenty of not so expensive little gifts to take home for friends and family

sultanahmet district heart of stanbul turkey, a flower vase of history of great turkey. in istanbul turkey always get recently published tourist map as it shows all hotels , attractions ,all types of transport routes.it is advise to all visitors visiting to Istanbul that they don't have to book tours and guide. book hotel in either taxim square or sultanahmet district. all major historical attractions are located at sultanahmet district square.( hagia sofia , topekapi, blue mosque). grand bazzar ,egyptian bazzar and sulemania mosque at 1km from sultanahmet square(walking distance).tram and bus also available. 4 turkey lira /person adult for tram and bus. put lira in machine and push button for required number of tickets and rest of money come out with ticket coins. if you coming from taxim square then under ground metro right at taxim square go to kabash then come on to road and sit in tram which go to sultanahmet square. ticket price and procedure again same. English speaking guide not available in and around taxim square , only Arabic translators available. English speaking guide available in old Istanbul even Urdu and hindi speaking guides.in turkey only turkey language is speaks and understand.it is advisable to visitors that before payment to touring company , make sure that your guide must know , speak and understand English otherwise you will be helpless. we arranged our full day city tour through aroma travel Karachi Pakistan and yuppi tatil travel agency turkey. initially day defore full day city tour ,they given us time of 8 am for departure to city tour. on day of city tour we got up at 6 am to ready at 8 am. we wait till 9 am then at 9am they again inform us that now time of start of tour is 10 am , 11 then 12 mid noon, then at 1 am again informed us that tour time now would be 1.30 pm and will take us only to topkapi palace. now we decided that we do tour our self. we took ticket of 90 euro for 5 person from big bus right at taxim square adjacent to under ground metro terminal(train) and did city tour for whole day. this bus from 8am to 8 pm and visit to western and eastern turkey with all information in English about all attractions of Istanbul city. in one ticket we can visit all attractions throughout day and no matter how many times you get on and off the bus. you can visit sultanahmet square also by this bus.blue mosque: it is an Islamic ancient mosque and represent Turkish Islamic culture.it was beautiful ,with amazing constructions, tombs, balconies, monuments. blue hue to mosque gives very magnificent look . all kind of food stalls, transport facility at door step .hagia sofia : it is closed on sunday and Monday. it is few walking steps to blue mosque.it is amazing construction with true representative of typical old Christian religious construction.topkapi palace and haram: ticket are 15 lira for harem and 30 lira for adult per person.it is true picture of old Turkish muslim architecture. it is closely mimics to lal qila of Lahore Pakistan. The sacred belongings of Prophet (pbuh) have been put on display as well as ottoman treasures. Do take out time to see the harem because it is exquisite and whoever has not seen the harem has not seen the true ottoman architecture at all!. from now onward if you stand in front of blue mosque , on rt side road to grand bazzar at distance of 1 km .you can can go either by walking or by tram , bus. at enterance of grand bazzar . sulemania mosque and egypcian bazzar. located.at left side tram track is present whih takes to kabash where take under ground metro tain and go to taxim square in 4 leera .
Great - so much history. This is a great part of Istanbul full of things to see. From the Blue Mosque to the underground reservoirs, the place is full of interest.

Perfect place to stay!. This is the perfect area to stay in if you are there for sightseeing and soaking up the culture. It is right in the middle of everything and there is always something going on. I won't ever stay anywhere else when in Istanbul!

Beautiful place. Lovely tone with plenty of delicious restaurants that serve traditional Turkish dishes, also shops and stores selling local items and souvenirs, a lovely busy little stretch ideal for an evening meal or afternoon drink or walk.

A magic mystery tour. You have the Grand Bazaar (4,500 shops) but also the Alaster Bazaar (perhaps 40-60 shops) and less stressful as vendors do not pester you. You have the wonderful mosques, Topkapi Palace, Agia Sophia and so much more, Restaurants galore.

a Travellers Paradise. All the sites are within walking distance. Wonderful shops, restaurants, markets in cosy and sometimes hidden cobbled roads. You can pick up beautiful paintings too. Just a walkabout is brilliant!

History abound and great shopping too. Loved every minute of this beautiful abundant area. A must see!
No lines when we visited. Clean, safe and beautiful!

Clean and Tremendous. Everybody here is very, very helpful! Yes, it IS a touristy area so things are overpriced, but for us, Sultanahmet was an absolutely fantastic experience. There are many attractions to visit - many you must pay for, but some that are free, like the Blue Mosque and the various shopping bazaars - as well as a veritable bouquet of foods, shopping, and flavors. I would recommend this area to anyone in Istanbul for a short time!

Harrassic Park!. There is probably no other geographic area with more fascinating and historically important sites in such close proximity than perhaps, Florence, Italy. Truly fascinating and splendid! The biggest problem, however, is navigating the area through constant hassling and harassing of rug merchants, store and restaurant employees, who do everything short of sticking out a foot to trip you, to get you to come to their store or eat in their establishment! They follow you everywhere you go, start off politely, appearing to want to befriend you with personal questions about your nationality, then extend invitations which cannot be politely refused, then descend into mild abuse when all else fails. The worse place for this is, naturally, the Grand Bazaar...I only lasted 15 minutes, even though I had originally wanted to buy some gifts there. I couldn't take two steps without being uncomfortably 'swarmed'. There is much less of this behavior on the other side of the bridge, but it's not as historically impressive.If you can run the gauntlet, the Sultanemet is astounding. But be prepared and don't kid yourself into thinking you can dissuade these guys by just ignoring them

Heart of the city. It is Istanbul in a jist. Everything you want to do can be done by staying at this place. The District holds some of the best gold and spice markets . Also there are a whole lot of restaurants and cafes for food. This is everything that a tourist can ask for. You get good accommodation at right price so you can stay at the place, shop and explore without travelling too far as all the major attractions like the Hagia Sophia, blue mosque are all close to the place.

The place to be in Istanbul. This is a great district to stay in. There are many historic sights to see and most of them within walking distance. The district is crammed with hotels and restaurants. So good to just browse your way around at night for dinner and a drink. I could stay here for another week and not be bored. Definitely a place to spend at least 4 days in.

Great area of the city to stay. Istanbul is huge and we researched all of the areas of the city before we decided what part of the city we wanted to stay in. Since we only had a few nights before our cruise, we decided that we wanted to stay in the middle of the historical area. We found it to be charming, fun, safe and we were surrounded by things to see and great restaurants to eat at. We might try a different area for our next trip, but for a short and first stay...I think it is a great choice.

Great sites..... You can see the highlights of the Old City in one day with a good guide. Go to Topkapi very early or you face impossible crowds in sweltering heat. The tram is a good way to get around the city.

Centre of historic area. Liked being In the centre of the historic centre. It's an old area with windy streets. Blue mosque, topkapi palace, basilica cistern, grand bazaar, hippodrome all there. Tram v easy to negotiate and cheap, easy to get from airport 4 lira!

Nice Area, many things to do. If you are planning to visit Istanbul, try to stay anywhere in this area as it is a nice historical area, has 3 major attractions (Sultanahmet Mosque, Topkapi, & Ayasofya), has many restaurants and cafes, and it has many affordable hotels.The location is perfect even if you are planning to visit other far areas (Taksim, Sisli, Minaturk, ...etc) and it has the metro connection. Saying that, the area is still the busiest area in Istanbul during the day and night (during weekends). In general, I don't think anyone can avoid going there when visiting Istanbul.

perfect spot. We stayed in an appartment here and it was an easy walk to all the sights. There were good local shops, bakery and cafes as well as a lively park, enjoyed playing backgammon in afternoons amongst the locals.
Perfect Site. Outstanding architectural structure.Crowded all the time.Perfect oriental site.Visitors from all around the world.

The Heart of Tourism. This is where a lot of the action is…tourists everywhere. It can be overwhelming but find a place to just sit back and look at these magnificent buildings. It's an incredible place. The crooked little streets, the buildings…so cool. People watching from an outdoor restaurant is fun here. There are tourists from all over the world.

This is the place to stay !!. If you decide to come to Istanbul make sure that you stay in the Old City, it is so worth it !! You might not get the big popular hotels that you might be used to ....but you get much more ....the CULTURE and real life style of being in such a historical place.

Sultry Sultanahmet. An amazing mix of history and culture of Istanbul. The heart of this is the square around Blue Mosque and Hagia sophia which has fountains and gardens. It is alive with tourist at all hours, and suprisingly safe. Sultanahmet also has the grand bazzar which is amazing and lots of great restraunts and shops. A great place to stay.
Historic center. So much to see and do here. Noisy and lots of traffic! Location is so convenient to everything. Great to have a Starbucks lose by our hotel.

ITACA. Most beautiful place I've ever seen!! Old but good district. People are so kind nd helpfull. And also dont forget to visit grand bazaar. There are lots of traditional stuff and typical spice. Higgle when you buy something in grand bazaar. Very safe place. You can explore the area alone.
Perfect Area. active area with pleasant view specially afternoon and night time, full of restaurants and activities. you must visit the area at least once.

Multinational, modern, clean, safe. liked:safety, clean roads, well-maintained monuments, friendly and interesting people;many restaurants and bars of good and very good quality with attractive prices and delicious food.no 'cheating'dislike:crowds of people - but it is what cannot be avoided in interesting places - it is just my personal feeling:)wild traffic (but it seemed to be safe :-]), noise of hoot

Best place in Istanbul tips for stay. Sultanahmet is old part of Istanbul but it is must visit place n best place to stay in coz every attraction is just on walking distance like blue mosque metro , bus station yenikapi tram station where u can get ferry to different part of Istanbul spice bazar grand bazar is also near by, almost all type of food resturant is also on the same walking distance ,hotels r very affording with complementary breakfast r also available at low cost u can get travel agents with attractive tour packages a must visit n stay place Gud luck

Really what Istanbul is all About!. We had a short stay overall in Istanbul prior to a cruise. It was all spent exploring this part of the city. In fact, we deliberately chose the Double tree Old Town so that we could walk out the door and be in the area rather than endure many taxi rides. The Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque all within a day's activity.

Shopper's heaven. If you love shopping the Grand Bazaar is the place to visit. Amazing gold and diamond. Local crafts and tourist tat if that's your thing. The shop keepers are all lovely and there is never any pressure to buy things you don,t need. You will always be asked if you need a carpet!!!

Great historic reasonably compact area. I am sure istanbul and turkey have many other great things to offer but in a couple of days you can cover all the wonderful historic attractions here and also cruise the Bosphorous. The major mosques are all magnificent externally and due to an aversion to insanely queues we haven't ventured inside one there is another free mosque just by the wonderful spice bazaar and with no queues an far fewer visitors it was amazing internally and a ver peaceful place to reflect in even if not of the Islamic faith.(even those of the atheistic faith might have enjoyed the experience).We made an effort on a Saturday to then walk to the grand bazaar but soon we're enveloped in hordes of excited Turks shopping in the street markets by the spice bazaar to the point where we felt we didn't need the grand bazaar experience. Re the spice bazaar the most amazing produce we found was at nourish but watch out or they will try and sell you everything in the shop in a very skilled sales approach and this is no cheap shop. Loved the choc pellet coated pomegranate etc confectionery logs and the smell of the amazing spice blends. Also forget the many very average restaurants for lunch and instead go to the the Maui bufe by the major post office.fresh,tasty, cheap , fresh juices and mainly locals in virtually a street food setting.For a fancier eating place with amazing views go to the seven hills rest but only order seafood - the rest is really disappointing . Check out the review I am about to post if interested. Easy to get lost here in areas where some lanes and roads cross and intertwine in a romantic but jumbled confusion so be prepared. We haven't tried it yet but apparently the huge queues can be avoided by hiring local guides who approach you. Don't know about it but sounds a great idea in principal On another note beware being ripped off in bills and short changed (as we were twice in the same transaction in the British style port shield hotel - those guys were tryers) . Also beware of kebab overload food wise:)

If you have just a few days this is the place. In an ancient city of 14 million people there is more than enough to see, but this is the heart of the tourist area. There is enough here to spend at least a week. This is a working part of the city with people everywhere going about their business. It all works amazingly well.
Must place to visit. Sultanahmet is a place not to miss when in turkey. Ample no of eating outlets , places to visit , old charm in modern way.

Great vibe, lots of shopping choices and attractions. This area houses the Blue Mosque, Sophia Church and other major mosque plus key shopping precincts such as Arasta and The Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. An absolute must go on your first day in Istanbuk.

The conquorer's footsteps.... Sultan Ahmet the conqueror is the Ottoman Turkish emperor who drove his ships over the hill, on land to enter the inner Istanbul (than Constantinople) to by pass the section of the chain that was stretched across the waterway in order to stop and sink with cannon fire as part of the city's defense. Ho took over Istanbul and this district was named after him. This is an area to do almost everything a tourist wants to do when visiting Istanbul. Many places are within walking distance to this area where there are mosques, churches and many other historic structures not to mention the restaurants, bars, street merchants etc. Do search this place to see the pictures or perhaps some videos. Walk on the very blood stained soil where the Crusaders ransacked Hagia Sophia, Sultan departed and returned from wars with his mighty military following behind and where the decisions were made that lead to the unintended discovery of the American continent. Surprised? Read up! :-) If you are a photographer, history buff or fascinated with details, you can easily spend 3 days in that area alone. If you rather be on a beach, just a lunch and a half day or less will suffice. Happy roaming!

THE Place in Istanbul.... Its the place to stay and see in Istanbul. Everything is walking distance and there is one attraction on the back of the other. You will enjoy your experience here 24/7 and you will feel the turkish hospitality to the fullest. The smells, the sounds, the lights, the places, everything its unique and would not change my desire to stay here for nothing in the world. The true heart of the city and the Mecca for tourist. You would love it.

A great area to stay and explore. We spent 3 nights and 2 days here and fitted in so much that we were exhausted!We did everything on foot except for a cruise on the Golden Horn. There is a great choice of cafes and restaurants and we never had a disappointing meal.

Old City. Really enjoyed people watching and tasting the various foods. Visiting the historic sites and mosques is a must.Watch out for people trying to scam you at all times, fake tour guides, shops, dining. Just ignore them or shake you head act like you can't speak the language they are talking.

charming district. Very nice galleries and boutiques. It was a nice area to stroll through and get away from the hustle and bustle of all the touristy areas. Next time I come to Istanbul, I will stay in Sultanahmet
Amazing Istanbu;. A wonderful mecca of great shopping,wonderful food . The sights sounds and colour make Sultanahmet District a wonderful place to visit. Don't miss out.

Real Life in Istanbul. What a fascinating area. It's like going back 50 years but with mod cons... the milkman walking around with his churn and measure calling outside houses for custom... vendors with carts selling melons, potatoes, salads, the rag and bone man..... wonderful. Be prepared for rich aromas. holes in the pavements and lots of wild cats; traditional houses with peeling paint and people sitting in the streets, talking, until the street lights go out. Away from the Blue Mosque area is a run down but intriguing insight into the real Istanbul. It's safe to walk around and certainly not to be missed.
Don't miss it!. I love this part of Istanbul. It has everything you want from Turkey. Amazing buildings, great people-watching opportunities, souvenir shopping, photo ops. Lovely
10minutes by bus or trainway. You can get in any bus to Sultanahmet or trainway. It's very easy to go. Personels will tell you how to go, show you on the map
History at your feet. A lovely place to stroll surounded by history, beautiful buildings, gentle people and cafes and restaurants vying for you business. I smile when I remember it.

Living in a Historical area. If your planning to stay in Istanbul i totally recommend staying in Sultan Ahmet area,walking distance from all historical area..very nice to walk through at night...very near from spice bazaar and grand bazaar...you got all transportation,Marmaray and bus stations around...Simply all what you need is there...You must try corn,fish sandwiches,nuts,icecream and of course Turkish tea and baklawa from every street corner and street seller :)

Favorite place to walk. Lovely bustling part to walk through. Many things to see! Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia. You will find carts selling fresh bagels (with Nutella-delicious!) Hot chestnuts and Mealies! Wonderful experience.
Food stuff .... wow, check out the cake and Turkish Delight shops! also lots of stalls selling corn on the cob and hot roasted chestnuts (delicious) and freshly squeezed orange juice.

an area like my old Bombay ...serene, lovely, full of life and happiness. a lovely, bustling part of istanbul..old houses, winding streets going up and down, cobbled squares, honking cars, hardly any place to walk.----i loved it!!
it was just like my crawford market or south mumbai areas...full of history, beautiful, lovely cafes, chattering of people, markets and roadside shops.
i want to go there again..and i surely will.

Hippadrome, million mile, fountains and an obelisk. Fun to people watch. Hopefully the city will keep this as it is and not mall it over. The fountain is lovely. Interesting Kaiser Wilheim gave many buildings all over the middle east.
My favourite place for a walk. It`s just very nice an comfortable place for walking around. When I`m there I just grab some coffee from McDonalds and walk around the streets.

history and romantic. Istanbul is a huge city, i can tell it as a person, who lives in Moscow. But if you have just a few days to visit this place, its no better way to spend your time, then to discover the historical part of the city by cruising at Sultanahmed. You'll see the mosques, the old museums, the grand bazaar and the Topkapi palace to get the real impression about the greatness of the Osmann Empire.

Self service restaurants the way to go for budget minded tourists. I found out about these self service restaurants in Istanbul by accident. These are like cafeteria like restaurants where you choose your food then pay for it then go grab your table. These are very affordable, unlike the sit-in restaurants. For example, just last month, my wife and I were able to have a very nice lunch or dinner for just $8 equivalent versus an easy $20 for for two in sit in restaurants. These self service places that we went to were all very clean. The food is very good. I suggest trying the meatballs (they are not really ball shapes but flat long ones, but make sure they are fully cooked). In Taksim Square, there is one Self Service near the square itself - that was expensive. If you walk along Istiklal Caddesi from Taksim to the other end, if you just walk about 10 mnutes, you will see St Anthony church on your left. The Self service right to the right of the church (facing the church) is very good and a lot less expense than the one near Taksim Square. I recommend that place if you want to save on your dinner.

Beautiful area with so much history. This area is simply amazing. You will come across amazing buildings, mosques, shops, restaurants, palaces and so much more. You'll see dervishes in restaurants performing beautifully. Try to visit this place both during day and especially at night. Its turns into one of the most beautiful and peaceful places i have been at night!

Great location. Brilliant location .... buzzing atmosphere, relaxing cafes, bars, restaurants and sooooo much to see in this historic quarter. Now I have been I won't be staying anywhere else .... I will be back!

nice place in Istanbul. Sultanahmet District is very nice place to stay in Istanbul. You can find most of the importance attraction in walking distance. Restaurant is wide choice there from the cheap lunch to a nice dinner.The district is tourism place so people are also very nice. Even they invite you to buy or eat in their restaurant but it does not mean that they are impolite if you do not choose them.The bustling, hectic area and I really happy to stay there.

Shop till you drop !!. Did lots of shopping here, very crowded but worth the adventure, strongly suggest walking past the beginning of the market then off to the right and left of the main block. There are many small places with great bargains, and a few streets over all kinds of items , shoes,undergarments housewares, etc you name it, they have it! The fresh spices are delightful !Put on your comfy shoes and shop!
Bustling. I imagine that the best time to visit is sunrise - when everyone else is in bed and you can enjoy the place without being bothered by touts and tourists.

The only part of Istanbul we wanted to see. Historic, colorful, bustling, delicious food, friendly people, comfortable hotel, muezzins, shopping, con artists, dogs, cats, constant entertainment. It was perfect! When the street scene became overwhelming, there were lots of quiet places. The tram was easy to use when we traveled outside the area but we walked everywhere in Sultanahmet, day or night. See individual attractions for specific reviews.
If you are in Istanbul, gotta come here.. Historic, touristic, crowded, worth visiting. Walk around in the smaller streets are better cafes and shops.

sultanahmet district is were past and present join hands. For people interested in the most beautiful ottoman buildings, this neighborhood is the place to stay. from our hotel (Arcadia Blue) we could walk to Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Arasta market and many other museums. There are plenty of restaurants and small shops and for travellers with just a few days, this is a very convenient place to stay and shop. It also has the tram which for 3 lire can take you to other parts of the city including the Galata bridge. The park is lovely and if you like cats, you might want to bring dry cat food to feed them. We even saw a dog who slept in a small cave in the park in the mornings as we walked by, while children ran around and families enjoyed the beauty of the city.
Beautiful old stuff. An amazing area to visit, just wander around and see what you see, soak up the city and see where it takes you

One & Only. Sultan Ahmet is the One and only place really didn't want to leave, the district has so much culture and attractions that you don't need to leave it. but if you so happen to leave the district , you'll find its so close to everything in Istanbul. SultanAhmet is surly the Heart of Istanbul

Magical. This "old city" district of Istanbul is like going back in time centuries, literally. The hilly alleys, cobblestone streets, shops, restaurants and stunning mosques will take your breath away.

Ancient Center that should not be missed. Sultanahmet is a hodge podge of both rustic residential, ancient sites and shopping areas. It is a great walking city. The areas towards Kennedy drive behind the Blue Mosque provide less touristic sites restaurants.

Nicest place in Istanbul!!!. This place is the most amazing one in Istanbul. You have Blue Mosque at one place and right across there is Agia Sophia. A lot of other turistic objectives in that market. You can take nice pictures there. And you should definitely visit it at night as well, it looks really nice to see all those big old building how are lighted. Good food around, a lot of nice restaurants in that area too. And surprisingly around the area there are a lot of small shops with a lot of suvenirs, scarfs, and a lot of things which are much cheaper than Grand Bazar and you don't even need to negociate for them. I would recommend it for sure.

Steeped in history. Very walkable area. We stayed in a hotel that was 200 meters from the "Blue Mosque." While very crowded on the weekend, weekdays were very manageable. The area is great for sightseeing, eating, and people-watching.

Vibrant & Lively. Great area to stay while in Istanbul! Lots of local restaurants and cafes. Local bazaar is good quality and high quality. Fabulous carpet shops. Great for the tram service and this takes you right into the centre of Istanbul. Use it! It is great and so easy!

Place to practice price haggling. Nice place to stroll about but just be aware about the pricing of products. We have purchased stuff that were priced much higher than the actual price shown. When we made the payment and realized the price difference, a refund is not available.

A must see. Brilliant, see history with your own eyes. I can only advise to take a private tour. We used Mehmet Raci Elci which knows Istanbul as his own pockets! Details you would not find in printed guides and the beauty of the district can only be enjoyed to its full extent, when understood.

Unique, magical, wonderful city.. Sultanahmet is like a city within a city. Everything you want is so close that you can walk from one breathtaking place to the next in minutes. A melting pot of different nationalities are all staring in wonder at the magnificent sights.

Most sites are here. If you're coming to Istanbul you're most likely going to make a stop in Sultanahmet. All the major attractions are here and the tram will get you pretty close to all the sites.
Mosques, Churches, restaurants, you'll find them everywhere.

I Highly Recommend Staying In This District. Our 4 day trip was much more enjoyable because our hotel was central to most sites in this Old Town area. We would not have been able to walk to as many sites as we did if we were not staying in this district. Sultanahmet has so much to offer and is an excellent location to stay and sightsee.
Mood and Restaurants. we liked the mood and the huge variety of restaurants, meat, fish and typical turkish kebab. we also liked the old and nicely restored buildings

Historic. Been there on March and even it was not so worm - its very pleasant part of town to walk around, sightseeing and dine at many many restaurants / cafes on the area. Also very attractive ground for souvenir shopping as there is many small and bigger authentic staff shops.

essence of istanbul. Sultanahmet delivers the Istanbul experience that most people expect and want - old city walls and buildings and cobbled laneways littered with great restaurants and places to stay. Shops and markets, tourist attractions, good public transport, parks and all completely safe to wander around at anytime. Turkish people are warm and welcoming. I highly recommend Eyewitness Travel, a few metres from the southern end of Arasta Bazaar - Hussein, Esra and Oya ( a great Aussie girl from Melbourne) were fantastic in their professionalism and friendly help which went way beyond the call. Istanbul is huge and has a lot to offer outside Sultanahmet, but a visit to Istanbul without visiting this area would be to deny yourself the essence of Istanbul.

Serene atmosphere out here. Stayed in Sultanahmet area during my visit to Istanbul; each street is unique with the different architecture designed for hotels and houses; close to the sea; one gets a mix of all kinds of weather during a single day.All the major attractions are just within a kilometer away and even the tram station. IF you are in istanbul then this should be the place of choice.

Excelent place to stay. My favorite place in Istanbul. Historical, ancient, the see the people all of this is together in the Sultanahmet and you can go by Tram in a very fast way to the other city center (Taksim).

Hanging out in the Sultanahment. The center pices are the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia and the Topkapi palace. Apart from that, this is a great area for lazy afternoons drinking Efes beer, enjoying Turkish cuisine, going to a bar overlooking the Bosporous or whiling away some time chatting with friends and smoking a nagile water pipe. Greta vacation spot.

Stay Here. Best place to stay when visiting Istanbul. Everything is close by, from attractions to shops and restaurants, and your pick of Hotels, there's plenty of them down every street. Easily accessible Tram that gets you to the Metro that takes you to the Airport. Plenty of shops to buy souvenirs from, and you can haggle them down, so never except the first price be you buying a t-shirt or fresh Baklava, cause theres plenty of other shops doing the same thing, who are willing to undercut their competition. The fresh orange and pomegranate juice is delicious, and so are the ice cream and cakes sold in the shops, but don't leave without trying the baklava, otherwise you just didn't experience Istanbul.

This is a must-see in Istanbul. I stayed in the Sultanahmet area (most tourists do) and this is my favourite part of Istanbul.Love the alleyways, the street sellers, quaint stores and even the stray cats! (lol). Lots of restaurants and stores to choose from but beware of the tourist traps. Arasta Bazaar near the Blue Mosque is a good place to buy souvenirs and scarves. Not as crowded as the Grand Bazaar. Try a delicious Simit bread for only 1 TL or watermelon slices for 5TL on the streets. And I can't get enough of delicious Pistachio ice-cream! Sooooo good! All the main sights are in Sultanahmet area and yes, it's normally crowded with tourists but it's still worth a visit and I wouldn't stay anywhere else in Istanbul, as you are right in the middle of the action!

Gives you a good feel for life in Istanbul. The sounds of the tram, the noisy street food vendors, the Dondurma (ice-cream) seller doing his tricks and arts and crafts shops are a real delight. All the ancient sights are nearby and every time you pass an alley, you can catch a glimpse of the sea.
Walk and Enjoy. Great place to be! Place to fill how East can blend with West or Old with Modern! You need at least full day to enjoy this part of Istanbul!

Vibrant!. I live in Istanbul currently, and I can not get tired of Sultanahmet. It is crowded with tourists, that is for sure, but it is such an interesting place: all the monuments, smells, views... it is just amazing!It is well connected by tramway,and easy to find... I love it!
Peaceful. There were only a few tourists about and it seemed to be just as big and grand as the Blue mosque. We had Turkish tea opposite for only TL2.50 each.

Nice place to stay. We followed some reviews and stayed in Beyoglu but ended up going to the Sultanahmet a lot, even during the night to eat. It was lovely. You have lots of the main attractions in this neighborhood.
Best place to base yourself for a visit to Istanbul. Lovely area full of character and life. Would definitely choose this area to stay in if I came again

don't miss. One of the most interesting districts of Istanbul
Culture, history, traditions, the starting point to get to know a wonderful city

Be Careful to tourist trab. While browsing round in Sultanahmet area, especially in the garden of Blue Mosque; somebody can stop you or looking like helping you by showing entrance. You can think how nice they are. Even they can ask you to skip the queue to get into mosque. At first it can sound good idea. But later, you can find yourself in a touristic rug store where most of the stuff are fake. Even they can introduce themselves as tour guide. They are not. Turkey is such a beautiful country and Istanbul is the best place to buy cultural handicraft. They have really good stuff, but if you find right place.
Sultanahmet. Great area. Stay here. Restaurants and shops are great. Forget the grand bazaar. Shop over here, less hassle.

Staying in Istanbul. Excellent location to stay in Istanbul. Although the hotels are not top rated. all the major attractions are in the vicinity. you can also catch a tram to go to other locations if walking is an issue. Also possible to catch a tram to the airport from this place and takes about an hour.

The main attractions.. Tourist central for Istanbul. All the big attractions are here and its inevitable that you'll find yourself spending quite a bit of time here. The streets are crazy chaotic to navigate if you leave the main ones, and prices are really high.

Hub of Attractions. Sultanahmet is where the blue mosque, hagia sophia and the majority of attractions are. They're all within walking distance of one another and there is a variety of restaurants around to eat and have dessert from. Plenty of little shops near the blue mosque to buy bits and pieces from. I definitely recommend spend the day there.

Historical area but beware of spammers. For first time traveler to Istanbul, I highly recommend stay in Sultanamhet as it's tourists hot spots such as Aya Sofia located. Public transportation is very easy to access. Restaurants, bars, and souvenir shops are around.But beware of spammers especially at night. Someone pretend to be kind to you and then offer you to have drink and then charge you $250. It's very common at this area. Just be careful to a Turkish man that you don't know well and speak very good english. Spammers usulally speak english very well.

The old quartier of the Ottoman Empire. This district shows you a totally different face of Istanbul. Narrow streets, woodden, painted, colourful houses make the area a romantic place for tourists. A restaurant square is found here with much lower prices than the city center restaurants. A must visit district.

Amazing historical area. This area has everything the traveller needs and staying in one of the many hotels on offer is highly recommended, there is just so much to see and do and most of it within walking distance. There are many restaurants to choose from, shops on every corner and a wealth of religious history. Will definitely visit again!

First trip? Stay here and explore on foot day or night.. The Sultanahmet area is the place to start exploring Istanbul. You can get around day and night and start to know where you are is such a huge city. Walking is easy and we were told that all is safe and it certainly seemed so to us. Street restaurants are brightly lit and open late. Families are out late at the fountains and parks. Businesses do not close early here. The street life is one of our fondest memories of Istanbul.

Great Place. We stayed right in the heart of this district, so much too see, we spent a week here and still didnt see everything we wanted to. its worth getting a Muze pass which gets you into most places and gives you discounts too at some shops and places to eat. A vibrant, friendly and spiritual place. The local policeman is wonderfully friendly and helpful too. The place itself is one of the cleanest places I have ever visited, everyone takes pride in their surroundings. A truly beautiful place.
sense of energy. when you get sultanahmed u can sense energy in yourself and combination of Islam and modernity is seen in this place. mosque is very great and beautiful

great start to explore Istanbul. April 2013 was the first time I visited Istanbul. I chose to stay in the district so that it's easier for me to explore the city on my own. It's got everything I wanted to see in 4 days within walking distance. There are also many affordable places to stay in the area.

Absolutely amazing. Quite simply one of the great tourist destinations.The Hagia SophiaThe Blue MosqueThe Grand BazaarAll must-see attractions, and all in an area packed with many more photo opportunities and the chaotic bustle of Istanbul.

Well placed. This is surely the best district to be based in for tourists.All the main sights are here, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Cistern et al.A little crowded (especially when cruise ships are in town) but sooo convenient

Fun, fun and fun. Everything is here, the palace, the mosques and the cistern not to mention the laneways, restaurants and shops. Enjoyed our 5 days immensely. Safe and tidy. Beggars are there, pay if you can. Everything is closeby.

Our choice for IST. Easy to get around once you figure out the public transportation. The best time of the year is mid April when all the tulips are in bloom. The Turks love their tulips, and it shows!
Narrow street and mental traffic. Great area with lots of places to eat.The streets are very narrow in this area and the traffic does not "Give way" even for pedestrians.

Very busy but with a few MUST DO's.. Of course visit (with museum pass for easy access) the Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi.Walking around the Aya Sofia (lonely plan map 4). Some tips from Aya Sofai• Aya Sofia Tombes (1) (was closed)• Sogukcesme Sokak (3) – street behind Aya Sofia with wooden houses (nice)• Drink tea / coffee in Caferaga Medresesi (4) – a bit hidden and very peacefull. This is a former theological school. They organize art workshops (e.g. make ceramics). On the terrace you can have drink. (recommended).• Little Aya Sofia bekijken (7) – Not worthwile to go inside, but nice to walk there, to see a bit of the neighborehood. • Nakkas Shop in the basement there’s a restored cistern (we didn’t do this)• Arasta Bazaar, small, less crowded bazar. Not spectacular but doesn’t take much time either.

Even better than expected. We thoroughly enjoyed our 3 days here. We particularly liked the park between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. There was a lovely atmosphere, tourists mingling with local families enjoying the flowers, trees, fresh air and spectacular views. Although fairly crowded, there was a relaxed, friendly and safe feeling.So many things to see and do in just a small area: apart from the two fabulous buildings mentioned above, we went to the Topkapi Palace, the Archeological Museum, the Basilica Cisterns, Suleyimani Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, and took the red route Big Bus tour.Lots of restaurants have roof terraces, with lovely views over the roof tops to the beautiful buildings and the sea beyond.
lovely. great place to walk, to feel the old istanbul, lively district, you can find good turkish bath and good stores for souvenirs, we haved a great day there

Touristy? Yes... but interesting and fun. More restaurants, cafes and shops than you can count, lots of people, interesting buildings (not even counting the historic ones), atmosphere is fantastic, don't miss the cobblestone side streets. And the carpet shop salespeople can be very aggressive (they come on friendly and then get aggressive..Just say No and be FIRM)

Historical area. Welived in this historical area and walked on history every step we took. We walked without guide and missed many historical things. But it was that we wanted. Sometimes we like to do like that because you discover other things and places you normally had missed..

Exciting, historical and, yes, touristy!!. Of course, the Sultanahmet District is crowded, noisy and full of tourists. Isn't that what all those wonderfully historic buildings and sites are suppose to do ..... attract tourists? We stayed in Sultanahmet for three days and hated to leave. With the boutique hotels, café restaurants, Turkish delight shops, souvenir shops, rug merchants, street vendors, and dealers in all sorts of merchandise, it was exactly what we had hoped for. Everything is within easy walking distance, well lit, clean and safe. Are there touts? Of course there are. Touts exist in every major city around the world. Why not just relax and play along? No harm done. Buy a simit, sit on a park bench and enjoy the show!

Local to the main sights. We chose a hotel here as it was close to the main sights and once we figured out the subway/tram system we could get anywhere in the city quickly! This is a vibrant area with plenty of shops, restaurants and exploring to be done...just a short jaunt to the Grand Bazaar and the Mosque's!

This is the area to stay in when in Istanbul. We stayed in three different hotels during an extended visit to Istanbul (and Turkey, Greece and Bulgaria) and two were in Sultanahmet (the "Old Town" of Istanbul). This is the area to stay in as you can walk to almost everything and public transportation, especially the tram, is available (and cheap) for everything else. Most of the tourist attractions are in this area, especially the top ones (Topkapi Palace, Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, the Spice or Egyptian Market, the Cistrern, the ferries on the Bosphorous, etc.) and many good restaurants.The area runs roughly from the ferry terminals on the Bosphorous in the north to the Sea of Marmara in the south, with Gulhane Park and the Topkapi Palace taking up the northeast 15 or 20% or so of the region. The tram runs from the train station next to the ferry terminals to Gulhane Park and then down to Sultanahmet station (near the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia) but extends far to the west (and to the north from the train stn)--trams are easy to use, just find a station, put your money into the automated ticket machine and take your red token (about 75 cents US) to the tram entrance.Two great small hotels in the area are the inexpensive Soliman Hotel in the northern part of the old town (close to Topkapi Palace, the ferry terminals, Gulhane Park, the Spice Market, Hafiz Mustafa, etc.) and the White House Hotel in the south-central park of the old town (close to the Grand Bazaar, Aya Sophia etc.).The Sultanahmet region seems very safe and we had no difficulty during the eight days and nights we spent walking in the area, even late at night (of course, take appropriate precautions and don't make yourself vulnerable, as anywhere else). People were friendly and accommodating, with recommendations or directions and meeting people on the street and in parks became "half the fun" of the visit. While all the great tourist attractions are certainly worth visiting we found backstreets and such to be just as interesting. Sultanahmet is a walker's dream area with lots of atmosphere.
Buzzing area. The presence of tourist all over was fun for a solo traveller. I made friends quickly and my trip wasn't boring

Historic Center of Istanbul. Sultanahmet District is a very general name to refer to the historic center of the city of Istanbul. This is where most of the things you would want to see as a tourist are located, from the Grandbazaar to the mosques. Sultanahmet is the name of a district, and most of the tourist attractions (sightseeing wise) are located in its vicinity.
sultanahmet zone for tourist. nice area with many historical attraction point located very close to each other , must spent at least 2 days

Amazing. You can spend a whole day here, there is so much to see and do. Most of the major historical sites are all within walking distance and the opportunities to take photos are endless inside the various monuments and outside where you can view several things in one sweeping glance. It gets busy early so best to go in the morning as soon as everything opens. There is a wonderful atmosphere about the whole place.

Diverse area with a bit of everything. This area is by far the place place to stay in Istanbul. It is close to transport links, restaurants and eateries, markets and the main sites of Istanbul. The markets being my highlight! Look no further, if you want to be well located stay here.

Fantastic area for your stay while visiting Istanbul. I highly recommend staying in charming Sultanahmet for your Istanbul visit. My husband and I rented an apt. in the centre and we recommend this over hotelling it. We could walk to all the major attractions, beautiful mosques, and bazaars. We also did our daily food shopping with the local people which gave us a very authentic experience. The Turkish people were uniformly friendly and helpful, and we have never seen such a hardworking lot! Age didn't seem to make a difference, at dusk you would see people in their 70s, sometimes 80s, pushing their carts up the hilly alleyways after a long day at work. You can find the oudoor flavoured hooka lounges and many cafes and restaurants there as well. At night we founnd it quiet in our area, important for sleeping.The apartment was on the 3rd floor but managed by a very helpful & courteous young man who left us a big breakfast outside our door every morning. A typical Turkish breakfast of salty cheese, pastries, tomatoes, olives, processed meat, tea.If you need the western shopping experience and are a good walker, Taksim is a good walk away.All in all a fantastic tourist experience with many wonderful memories.

Don't miss. Great area to visit lots of things to see and do,as stated by others very busy area,if visiting by cruise ship very easy to walk up to here from cruise terminal.bit hilly to get up to but footpaths are very good,lots of bars,Restaraunts and cafés in the area

The beating heart of Istanbul.... This place of great suggestion will always give you a strong feeling of turkish life. I have been here ten and then five years ago, and even if Istanbul is more and more looking like a western big city, this is still, and will likely remain a place of its own. It is definitely worth a visit.

First Historical place in İstanbul that has to be visited. The center of Ottoma history. You have to visit to say that I was in İstanbul. Many choices for musems - food and sight seeing. Guarentte to have fun, do not talk too much with the street salesman you might end up giving many just to get ridoff. Say hello and walk slowly away.

The best area to stay in. I was happy I stayed at the Sultanahmed District because all the main places of interest are situated there. While other tourists have to go by bus to visit them staying in this area allows to look at them every day. There you can see and visit the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Topkapi Palace, the Cistern Basilica, the Gulhane Park, the Archaelogical museam, the Carpet museum and a few beautiful mosques which are situated nearby. Besides it is a very interesting area because you can meet people from all over the world and it is especially interesting to watch a rich Oriental culture, people and to feel inspired listening to azan from everywhere. It is a very special experience.

Lively and crowded Sultanahmet, Istanbul.. Sultanahmet is a very popular and central area in Istanbul. It is very crowded with tourists, restaurants, cafés, pastries and sweet shops as well as little souvenir shops. All major attractions like the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Arastha Bazaar and Basilica Cistern are located here and within walking distances apart. The Bosporus and Golden Horn cruises are also just 3 tram stops away with easy access to the Dolmabache Palace.This is the place to be if you want to watch a “Whirling Dervishes” show and eat at local restaurants, have sweets at the numerous sweet shops and enjoy the antics of the local ice cream parlour man. At night the place is so very lively and beautiful; the mosques and fountain area is beautifully illuminated and you will enjoy walking around.We chose to stay in a boutique hotel in Sultanahmet and we would strongly recommend the same as it is just minutes walking distance to all the attractions.

Historic centre. All the great historic places of interest are situated here. The area is the most popular with tourists. It is very busy at all times but there is so much to see that you don't even notice. There are plenty of guides available at small cost and most languages are spoken throughout.

A Great Starting Point. Very interesting introduction to Istanbul, and as a base. The Mosaic Museum and the Hagia Sofia are both fabulous.
