The nearby underground Basilica cistern-the Yerebatan Sarnici- is also worth a visit and quite atmospheric. A staff member at our hotel recommended the Sultanahmet Koftecisi restaurant for traditional Turkish food. It's near the tram stop and it was a brilliant first meal and very reasonable.
Everthing is here. We loved every minute of our time here - as history people, this is the center. The Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Topkapi palace and museum are all here.

Best District in Town. This is the old part of the city. The part that places host to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Kaiser Wilhelm's Fountain and more. It is also home to great restaurants, souvenir , and carpet stores. Everything is within walking distance in this neighborhood...providing you like walking, and don't mind some hills....if not, the tram is the perfect solution and only costs about $1.50 per journey. The area is quite safe at night, although, as a woman, I'm not sure I'd be out alone in any big city, but in a group, or with your partner, then it's lovely to walk around at night. We rode the tram at 11pm and it was as crowded as after work rush hour. There were tons of locals and tourists out and about.

Everything walkable in 10 minutes. Very busy with huge groups in from cruise ships. Yes, one is approached all the time by people trying to sell tours and guide books, but polite refusal is met with good humour.

A MUST. If you only have a few days in Istanbul or in Turkey, this is the place were you should stay. This is the major touristic area of Istanbul, with most of the historical highlights located in this district. All the big attractions are beside each others all within easy walking distance.

Sultanahmet: A Very Busy Bustling City (center). I couldn't believe all the people all over Istanbul, especially in the center. I've never seen so many people in all my life out sight-seeing and going here/there, etc. No matter where and when you went out, there were people. The lines to get into Aya Sophia were really long. It seemed like the whole world decided to come to Istanbul. I really enjoyed the famous lokum candy, the breads and the local and always available doners. I enjoyed the shops and the occasional lengthy chats with local people. I like to travel like a local and also like to find the face and a heartbeat on a country, so I always try and watch for this. The landscaping is beautiful in the center of Sultanahmet too (trees, flowers, fountain, lighting, benches, etc.). One thing I did have trouble with was the aggression of people who were selling from their establishments or on the streets.

In my opinion,this is the heart of the city. This old part of the city is one of the most beautiful gathering areas where you are able to see thousands of tourists from all over the world.Different kinds of historical monuments,museums and historical ruins can offer you all the best available through many centuries.Just stroll the streets and feel how nice this athmosphere is.Very much recommended for every age.

Istanbul's disneyland. It's the disneyland of Istanbul, according to the Turkish people I met, because it is devoted to Tourism of course. Very agreeable. Quite safe. However, be careful with fake "Turkish cypriots" business mess who roam the area and try to attrack lone tourists to bars or something. NOT recommended.
Amazing Istanbul. Beautiful city full of beautiful historic places beautiful atmosphere and humble people . I was most impressed by princess island what a place to live

At one time, the center of much of the world. History seeps out here. We are fortunate that we can still see much of the original buildings from the Ottoman era, when much of the known (Western and Byzantine) world was headquartered here. One of my favorite place on the globe.

Unforgettable Place. There is just so much in the Sultanahmet District of Istanbul that makes it easy to spend two or three days in that area alone. Having several of the great tourist sites of the world and along with the endless shops and great eateries this is the absolute place to be when visiting Istanbul.It is almost addictive in personality and character and it will leave you wanting to return.In fact if I were to recommend the most important place to visit in this world then this would be it. So try it and you will not be disappointed.

Historic, relaxed and friendly. We stayed in a hotel in Sultanahmet so we were able to walk around on a daily basis. Too much to see in one week and it goes between the magnificent, the quaint, and the dilapidated. Really good open spaces and squares, felt absolutely safe everywhere, carpet salesmen and people wanting to 'help' you have to be got used to, but not a problem really. A stroll through Gulhane park is good, and try the open air cafe there just behind Topkapi.

Beautiful sites but.... You cannot walk two feet in Sultanahmet without someone trying to sell you something. "Bosphorus tour!! Best deal!" "Guide to Istanbul!" "Private tour of Blue Mosque!" "Come eat here!" It's kind of wearing after a while, and it's CONSTANT. Just say "no" strongly and walk away. Obviously, come to Sultanahmet though. It's where all the historic sites in the city are. You'd miss out on the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, and so much more. It would be silly to not come.
Lots to see. Tons of historic sites, and the streets are great for window shopping and people watching. Worth a half day of just wandering in between sites

Clean and chaotic. This area is the main historic centre and according gets thousands of tourists. The pavements can be either beautifully clean and in perfect condition, or can be uneven and broken. Be prepared for the inevitable salesmen, though they are charming and will take 'no' for an answer.

Gorgeous area with so much history.. We really loved wandering around this whole area. As our hotel was overlooking the Topkapi Palace gardens, we didn't have far to walk to get to the major attractions. Yes, there are lots of guys touting for business, but a firm but polite 'no thank you' worked wonders. Saying 'maybe later' at the restaurants worked for us too. Not once in 6 days were our arms grabbed as others have said, nor were we followed and pestered. In fact we found everyone polite and friendly and helpful when we got ourselves lost in the back streets.A really great area to explore with so many beautiful buildings with such a lot of history.

Close to everything!. The Sultanahmet District is where it's at in Istanbul. You can spend a couple of days walking to all the things to see. The shopping is fabulous at the Grand Bazaar which is a nice long walk or you can hop on the tram for a short ride. Remember to negotiate your discount of 30 to 50 percent. Most shopkeepers are helpful and friendly. The Hagai Sophia, Blue Mosque and Hipodrome are within easy walking distance.

A feast for the eyes. It was our 1st time, we were a bit nervous, but I must say we had a great time. We are older and thought it would be dangerous but the visual feast for the eye makes going to Istanbul a must.
Old town beauty. This is the old town of istanbul and feels far removed from the fancy hotels and modern buildings in other parts. Great area to stay in to feel like you're in a more authentic place

SCAM central. Wow, I really was disappointed my with the experience. I was really looking forward to visiting Istanbul but left with a different opinion. Istanbul is a beautiful city filled with gorgeous sights however; you have to watch out for yourself. I felt like everywhere I went, the people were trying to rip me off. I am only going to discuss my experience with the Sultanahmet District. People will try anything to scam you.While waiting in line for the Hagia Sophia, we were bombarded with people trying to sell you tours. It's not just one, it was a whole flock of people. A simple, "no, thank you" does not work. They are like flies and you can't swat them away. After about the 3rd person, I just ignored. It seemed to work but then another one would quickly approach. Another scam, that took place was the "Do you speak English" scam where someone will try to sell you their Museum Pass. This couple approached my husband and I and told us that they were just visiting for the day on a cruise and bought the three day pass. They assured us that there was 2 days left. They seemed "sincere" and wanted 55 lira for them. We denied their offer. If it sounds to good to be true than it usually is. After waiting in line, we bought our Museum Pass and then discovered that they scan your pass. From what I understand, each location can only be visited once in the three days.Next, we were walking towards the Blue Mosque and were approached by a local man. He told us that the mosque was closed for prayer and to come back at 7. He recommended somewhere for my husband and I to eat. Luckily, the restaurant was recommended in the Rick Steves' book so I know it was a safe choice. While walking us over to the restaurant, he told us that he owned a carpet store (eye roll). He left us and I was surprised he didn't try to get us to visit his store. We finished eating and were walking back to the Blue Mosque around 7:15 and there he was again. He spotted us and came over to us. He wanted to show us around. There was a long line but he took us to the front and gave us a private tour. I couldn't help but feel uneasy. My husband had money to give him as a tip and thank you. He wanted us to take a look at his carpet shop. We felt suckered in. We told him that we were NOT interested in buying such items. We looked at this shop and then were led upstairs to talk to his "cousin". He tried offering tea, water but I declined. He was not happy. I understand the culture, but I wanted to be straightforward and tell him no thanks. We quickly left and vowed that we wouldn't be put in that situation again.The next day, we were walking by a restaurant and the food looked delicious as it was displayed in the window. We walked in and I noticed that there were not any prices in front of the cafeteria style food. This was a major red flag. My husband asked how much and told the guy he wanted to pay BEFORE we ate but the owner got angry and demanded that we eat, then pay. I knew he was trying to set us up for a scam. I read numerous reviews that you always pay BEFORE you eat when at a cafeteria style eatery. Basically, they can charge you whatever amount and you can't deny as you ate the food. We left QUICKLY and didn't want to eat anywhere else.Also, besides trying to sell the tours, people are trying to sell you books, beads, Bosphorus cruise tours. On the topic of the Bosphorus cruises do not buy from them as they charge way too much. Buy your tickets from the official cruise company which is located by the Galata Bridge.One more thing is that I do not recommend taking the public transportation. The trolley always looked crowded and the people were crammed in like sardines. All I could think of was that this was a perfect scene for pickpockets. We walked everywhere. We walked from our hotel in the Sultanahmet District to the New District. It was a nice walk besides the flies trying to rip you off.It is too bad that a few bad apples can change your experience. I am just glad that we were smart enough to not get scammed although I left Turkey feeling like I missed out. I understand not all people are bad, but the scamming is just unreal.I am in disbelief that TripAdvisor recommends Istanbul as the top destination to visit in 2014. It is beautiful and unique but I believe that changes need to be made before this is recommended with such a prestige title. Like I said earlier in my review, not all people are bad.

Only come here for key attractions otherwise stay away. The area hosts some of the main attractions most tourists come to see including the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Grand Bazaar, etc, so is convenient in that respect, however it also hosts thousands and thousands of tourists and hundreds of very pushy vendors who will grab your arm, follow you along the street, try to lure you into their restaurant or store, pretend to be from your home country, and stand in your way so you cannot keep walking. This is very fatiguing and not at all charming.Do not stay here unless you are only here for a night or two at the most and only here to see the main listed attractions, otherwise head for Taksim or Beyoglü.
sultan Ahmed. sultan Ahmed is very charming area in Istanbul especially the blue mosque and the square very nice area to hangout :)
Tourist central. Old part of Istanbul, lovely apart from being bombarded with items for sale which is unescapable. All main attractions within short walking distance.
Dont drive here. The streets are narrow and with huge tourist buses operating, you will have tough time driving here. Best way is to walk and see all the interesting places.

what an experience. Do the Blue Mosque, Do Hagia Sophia, and definitely do the Sultanamet koftecicce established 1920 next to the Pudding shop, to die for 7 kofta, with crispy dinner rolls, and a bean salad, you will go again and again, just look for the queue at lunchtime, you cant miss it.
Love the old city. Always stay in this area if you want to walk and explore. Great restaurants including the Sultanahmet Koftechi which is a must go.

Cool little neighbrohood with lots to see. The spice shop, and very picturesque streets. We walked around for a while and arrived early in the morning to catch the call of prayer, very nice areas to walk around take picture sand have some early morning coffee.

Vibey, exciting in the epicentre of everything!. Most of the historical sites , restaurants ect are in this area. Best area to stay in as a tourist. Also close to the grand bazaar, spice bazaar and the Bosphourus river so location is superb.

wonderful neighborhood. everything a neighborhood should be. narrow cobble stone streets, lots of small hotels in old buildings, fine dining, hookah bars, carpet and pottery shops, and people galore./

This is the old part of the city. Plenty to do here lots of walking though trams are available. Small roads so taxis get stuck for ages so if in a hurry forget it give yourself plenty of time
Stayed in this area and most attractions within walking distance

Ottoman empire review. You can easily smell the history…wonderful environment with every turkish traditions....Sultanahmet Park is very beautiful as well as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the museum....also the grand bazzar.

Nicest People, Beautiful Shop and I didn't buy anything-But got great service!. Folks, This is a "Karmic Payback" post. I highly recommend El Rincon de Fehmi in Sultanahmet. The kindness shown by Nedim Kaya and his family went far and above in aiding myself and my wheel chair bound mother. Pouring rain, no taxis and at no time was there anything beyond concern for my mom. Nedim walked 7 blocks with us to hail us a cab and ensured we got a fair price. If you have ever been in Sultanahmet and seen the traffic, as well a competition for customers; you will understand how special and wonderful he was.The shop is lovely and I regret not making it back there on this trip. However I will shop there sometime and HIGHLY recommend that if you are looking for authentic goods, at a fair price (which can be hard to find in the tourist area), I honestly believe you will not find a better place.Check out their website: elrincondefehmi,comNedim, many thanks to you and your uncle!
Center of gravity in Istanbul. Sultanahment Park is the top choice area for foreign visitors. It accommodates Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia as well as museums and shops
Fantastic. Well worthwhile a visit.Istanbul such a fantastic vibrant city. Staying in old city nearby and also walked to Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern etc

There are Dating Scammers in Sultanahment.. There are Dating Scammers in Sultanahment. An interpreter or a tour guide or an apartment owner named N? Ipek, he is the most dangerous man. He loves to exchange his passport with out of one marriage into another. Be carefull, Ladies!

Very cool!! Improved a Lot!!. The District improved a lot, and walking through the narrow streets full of small store, bazaar, full of color transmits you the brightness of the city and drives you back to the past " Constantinople" , a time tunnel form the Byzantine time to the Ottoman empire..
So many places of intrest. You can visit 4 major historic places in one area of the city. So many fascinating things to view. The Four Seasons hotel is close by.
Lovely to walk around. It is beautiful in this area. Easy to take in the history. Love the view of the mosques. There is nothing to dislike.Tulips are beautiful at this time of year.

spent an entire day walking around. We had 3 maps and still got lost! ha ha. It was a great way to see "back street Istanbul". People were very helpful and kind. Rick Steves has a walking tour in his 2014 Istanbul book

Great location, good value. Great energy from all the people and the most spectacular sites within east walking distance. The area is full of great restaurants, and all the tourist sites, like Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Topkapi Palace, where you can wander around the grounds for free. This is like an adult Disneyland, only so much better.
Stroll. Great to have a stroll through the old city of Istanbul. So much to see.Great to see the covered bazaar, Aya Sophia and see the Bosphorus all from a short walk.

History and life. I would recommend to stay in the Sultanahmet District. This is the lively part of the city with the Bazar, the little shops, the markets, restaurants, bars and where most of the historical sites are located. You can enjoy going back in time and at the same time enjoy the bustling city.
Amazingly clean and quite magical space. No doubt it is a tourist area, but the place is kept very clean with street sweepers coming by often and there are sanitary workers cleaning up constantly.

Amazing. That is all.. I don't even think words can describe how I felt when I was here. I love this place, there's so much going on. So much modern mixed with ancient, so many things to see and foods to try. So many people to watch. We were lucky enough to stay in the Sultanahmet District and it was well worth it.

Very Crowded. Too many people trying to scam you to buy something. Turks have become very dishonest and the prices have gone up. Not a great place to visit. Turkey overall has changed significantly and has lost its charm. Prices are high service has deteriorated.

It is a why you are here place. -First place to visit in all visitors agenda's. Must see!-Very handy. All the important places are located very close to each other. -Local life and touristical life is combined.-Safe and clean but still be careful (very slightly).-Prefer and do not hesitate to ask local people for any kind of help if you need which I mostly believe they will be pleased to rather than being offered to help. -I was surprised to see that the prices were really very reasonable. I live in İstanbul and I most probably spend more money in the local places. Compared to my touristical visits in the world it is really very reasonable.-Be careful for tramway when you are on the street.-You can cover your all needs around easily.I wish you have fun and leave my country with nice memories.

A must stay area. We stayed in this area at The Celal Sultan Hotel and couldn,t get a better place, the whole area is fascinating, lots of shops, cafes, restuarants at night its all lit up and safe to walk around, the streets are cobbled and wind up and down just magic

The place to stay to see Istanbul . As long as you make the extra effort to avoid tourist trap restaurants (tripadvisor recs are all great) and know the grand bazaar will be an overwhelming experience with millions of shopkeepers hounding you-- this place rocks! Everything is easily accessible by walking, ferry or metro from here.

Sightseeing, cafes, and shopping. Compact and chock full of history. The main attractions were impressive, if crowded and somewhat expensive. If you'd rather avoid the lines, the Archaelogical Museum at Topkapi was inexpensive and has an impressive collection. Plenty of inexpensive lodging and restaurants. Lots of shopping with Spice Bazaar particularly interesting.

Magical place. I liked everything. People are great, restaurants are nice, the streets are clean, it's safe to walk in the night and there are always a lot of people out in the night. The neighborhood has a great atmosphere.

Best area to stay. For me a first time visitor this was the best place to stay close to iconic sights such as the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia....access to other parts of Istanbukl is quite easy by tram,boat and road....
Beautifully Preserved. Very authentic,old area of Istanbul. Has a definite ,ancient feel about it. Well maintained and preserved. Noisy, bustling and alive. Loved staying here.

Fascinating but avoid the touts!. Great place to sit or wander around daytime and early evening. Sitting by the fountains was lovely people watching and taking in the views.The touts are a pain, they are like irritating flies. You deal with them as best you can but don't get caught in conversation with them if you don't want anything.After declining politely everything one offered, he said, 'So what do you want'? I replied, 'You to go away'. That worked and he did. Result back to the views and watching the people go by.
Great area to stay. really lively area with a lot of restaurants and shops. Nice to walk through the cobbled streets. Close to quite a few main tourist attractions.

The place which should be attended. This is historical place of the Istanbul. A lot of musems (artheological, etc), blue mosque, palaces are conventrated in this district. Also you will find the market here. But it is very crowdy there. Better time to go is morning because after 11 AM will be a lot of turists here and the huge lines everywhere. One more pluse for this place is train station near by. Spend one day in this district and you will see a lot of interesting place.

Old Town Charm. Very impressed with the district, its shopping and food attractions. Please do not miss the grand bazaar with all of its charm and shopping. Make sure you research prices in two or more shops before you buy. We loved the street food and the variety of Kebab and seafood.

Fascinating and very busy. I can't imagine any tourist going to Istanbul and not wandering around Sultanahmet because there are so many sights of interest to see, some of which are unmissable. On the other hand the area is very crowded with other tourists and busy with people trying to shine your shoes or sell you a guide book or carpet. And I don't think it's the best part of the city for a drink or a meal. Try to go mid week if you can, when it seems to be a bit less busy. And retire to a safe distance for dinner.

Its not the 'wide brown land". The mixture of the historic sites and the bustle of this older section of Istanbul was wobnderful. After a few days there; the intricate maze of streets became very comfortable to wander through.

Great atmosphere. Cobbled streets in the center. Good sites like the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sofya. Reccomend that you stay at least 2 nights in this area. Great shopping and good Shesha bar in the area as well.

the area to be in. lotsto see,an area steeped in culture and tradition with beautiful gardens to sit in and enjoy the views from all aspects including the fountains.where both blue and red tour buses leve from,worth purchasing a ticket for the big bus tour,hop on hop off

Excellent Base for your Stay. Loved the historic old town that makes up the Sultanahmet district. So glad we chose the old town instead of basing ourselves in Beyoglu (new district). Comfortable walking distance to everything including the Hagia Sophia, mosques, Topkapi Palace. You're also near the Bosphorus, the Galata bridge, bazaars, etc. Hands down the best area to feel Istanbul's rich culture & history.

Istanbul May 2014. Architecture and main attractions absolutely fabulous. Be prepared for lots of crowds and queues. Signs could be better to segregate queues for those entering monuments with Museum Pass from those queuing for immediate tickets. With queues 1km long, this is not a whimsical thought. You can spend lots of time quieuing and if hot, not a pleasant experience. We walked away from visiting Galata Tower because of very long queue (not included on Museuem Pass listing). City so very interesting, Shame to have obstacles to maximising opportunities to enoy it all.

Old city worth visiting!. It is indeed one of the best and most touristic parts of Istanbul. Very lively, with impressive historic monuments to visit - a trip in time! However, one need to pay attention to the crowds and to people selling all kinds of things that sometime can be really annoying. Don't stop if you are not interested, just ignore them - same thing you should do in the bazaars. Devote some time in visiting the museums and reading a little bit of the history of the place - otherwise it's just buildings and shops. Nice hotels of all kinds are available, restaurants too touristic for my taste. Sultanahmed District is definitely worth visiting when in Istanbul - however do not underestimate the more modern part which is the "face of today".
Not to be missed. Full of fabulous historical monuments and quaint little streets, boutique hotels and eateries of all sorts - a delight!
best part of istanbul. If you really want to enjoy your stay this is the place to be. Hotels available in all categories and touristic and not so much business hotels.

April Visit. We stayed in Sultanahamet and it was amazing, the main tourist attractions are there and it is so easy to walk around the area. People are incredibly friendly and want to speak with you. But there are so many people trying to sell you something, it can be very disrupting. We tried to be friendly at first, but we found that if you start speaking with someone, most of the time they are trying to get you into their shop, so our best advice is to be nice, but firm if you are not interested.
Lively !. At the heart of things, so hotels, shopping and cultural activities all readily available. Maybe a little noisy !
Siva Cafe Restaurant. Great place to have dinner.Entertainement is amazin.the Waiter is putting 3-4 bear glasses and dance

Sultanahmet journey. This area has amazing history and so much to learn from.If you want to really get a feel of this you should get a guide. Never a dull moment here....walking in and out of Topaki Palace or Hagia Sophia is fantastic.A turk myself....cant get enough of this place

just watch out for the rug sale's men.... If you are not in the market for a rug, just walk past them. pretend like you don't hear them. Whatever, it's all a scam. They will offer you tea or raki, but just say no, or nothing and keep walking. THis is a beautiful area outside of that with lots to see and do!!

impressive. The Blue Mosque especially looks good with it's 6 towering minarets and it's expertly balanced design. Some good bars/restaurants where you can sit at the 5th or 6th floor terraces and get good views.

One day not enough. Looking for tourist attractions, buy some souvenirs, spice or Turkish delight even Turkish coffee. Want to try traditional Douner, Iskander even street food, or have Istekanat (cup) of Turkish chai everything at Sultanahmet District.This district is full with tourist and local peoples all the day. Very crowded especially in the weekend, so I recommend visiting it in weekdays.One day not enough to walk around this district and see all tourists attractions like Top Kapi Saray, blue mosque, Aya Sophia, grand bazar, Egyptian or spice bazar and many other place, so in my opinion you need at least two days to see most things at this district.Note: there is No wheelchair access in many places at this district.
Lots to do!. Loads of touristy shops selling souvenirs and some of the major tourist attractions. There are so many restaurants and cafes too, it's impossible to be bored here!

Touristy but Charming. I would definitely stay in this District again. The sights are easily walkable. Although men tried to persuade us into the restaurants, they gave up with good grace and a smile.
Full of history. Historic area. Mosques, museums, underground cistern, hippodrome, palace and gardens, along with restaurants, cafés and shops

If you can't find it here, it doesn't exist!. When in Istanbul, do as the Turkish people do and shop where they shop. Many cities have tourist areas, of which this one is jammed with sites, but the best part includes locals who shop and live in this area. Many speak English and are not afraid to help you find what you are looking for.We walked freely and without issue through much of the district taking in all this area had to offer. We sampled food at 5 different stands, bought some spices and ended the evening with hand-made, fresh Turkish Delight candy!It doesn't get any better than that.
great to walk around. While a little too organised for tourist, you can't help but feel impressed and inspired by the history and achievement embodied by the beautiful mosques and palace.

Truly a treasure. LOVED Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque, didn't have time to tour Topkapi but did enjoy the amazing gardens outside the palace walls to the Bosphorus overlook. Was a wonderful experience to be allowed to sit inside the Blue Mosque during final prayers of the day at sunset, very peaceful. Hagia Sofia is bright and beautiful, hard to imagine is has stood for 1500 years.

Prepared against crowds. The area is crowded as much as other areas in Istanbul. On weekends, it could be much more crowded so it is better be prepared for it. Amazingly things move somehow even if it is in this condition.Nice to take a night walk around the area when it is bit quieter observing lighted up historical monuments like Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque, etc.

Explore this area of history!. Brilliant area to explore, This area was named after the Blue Mosque.You will find the Egyptian Obelisk, the Horse Square (originally the Hippodrome),Basilica Cistern, Serpentine Column, the Hagia Sophia and much more. Go and enjoy the sights
Extreme crowded. A very crowded area with lots of tourists and the prices are too high. There are lots of other places near Taksim or Sirkeci which are better for shopping.

Everything is just at your foot step. Close to everything; Blue Mosque, G Bazar, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, restaurants, and tram line which is very important and handy. We enjoyed everything in this district. It might be a little bit hilly for buggy users and that's something to keep in mind if you have a baby or a wheel-chair user.

This is Istanbul!. If you're travelling to Istanbul, this is where you need to stay, after all, it's what you came to see! Outside Sultanahmet, Istanbul is like any other big city in the world but inside, you get the true flavour of Turkey, the hospitality, the friendliness and the sights, sounds, and history of this wonderful city. The streets are very busy with people and traffic, you need to have your wits about you, it is hilly and not really suitable for people with mobility problems.

Lots to see within walking distance. Must see area of Istanbul with all the main sights within walking distance. We particularly enjoyed the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace & Grand Bazaar.Lots of places with good roof top views, we liked the Hotel Nomade Terrace bar and the food at Teras Restaurant at the Hotel Armada.Other good restaurants we tried include Matbah and Pasazade. For drinks try the garden at Yesil Ev and Kybele Cafe for stylish, quirky surrounds.
Cultural overdose. Gives a taste of the local culture. Lively and filled with various things to see and do. Perfect place to be around to soak in the essence of Istanbul.
Not Recommended. Initially I booked in a hotel in Sultanahmet area, but checked out after 5 hours. The area is nice for few hours visit, but not longer.
Great day out. The old part of Istanbul is a must, the history is fascinating and has a great old town vibe. We loved it !
A Very Funny Must See. Go and Eat that delicious Kofte ! it's close to the tram station. Lot's of place for good food and in every corner there is a historical thing... You will not regret

Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace and Blue Mosque. Brilliant, just a few of the different places to visit. Would also recommend a boat trip on the Bosphorous fantastic views. The tram system is also very cheap and reliable - a great way to get around.
Old Town. I believe old town is in the Sultanahmet District. This is the district where the blue mosque, basilica cistern, hagia Sophia are all located. An absolute must see!!!!!

Go walk-about. To walk through this area is to step back in time and be transported into an exotic world of people, small shops, street traders, ancient sights and sounds. It's an easy walk but give it enough time to linger in the markets and maybe eat a Donor Kebab!

Depending which part.... The Sultanahmet area is very busy and geared towards tourists -- we are very glad we chose Karakoy as our hub while in Istanbul. The areas closer to Sirkeci and leading to the bazaar districts are the less attractive parts of the district. However, the area near the Arasta Bazaar and the Four Seasons Hotels is by far more beautiful and enjoyable (great restaurants, boutiques, view of the city from roof terraces, etc.). Definitely a part of the city to visit, but would not recommend staying there.
Amazing. So much in one place. Historic structures, museums shopping, food. Istanbul has turned into one of my favorite cities. You don't need to leave Sultanahmet, but it's easy to do on the Metro.

A must see. Great area to visist, with most of the famous attractions in in. The Grand bazaar is a must see, but also look for the hidden jems like the traditional Hookah bar close to the Grand Bazaar and on the main road . One tea, one coffee and a Hookah came to TL25
Lovely. There's so much to do in this district and my favourite being the Grand Bazaar (Kapalicarsi) and the Spice Bazaar. There's so much culture and character in this district!

The soul of Istanbul. There were all tourists meet to take photos of the great sultanahmet blue mosque, Hagia Sophia museum, Topkapi palace and the basilica cistern. Its easy to reach using the tramway.

Full of life. The Sultanahmet district is a street full of life, restaurants, shops, pubs etc.. and far from all of this mess you can still feel the silence of the Blue Mosque with its Majestic building.

Bustling area, beautiful. Sultanahmet was the ideal place to stay to have close access to all the touristy things, close to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Spice Markets, Grand Bazaar, and the quaint little tourist shops for some bargins!

MY FAVOURITE NEIGHBOURHOOD. Sultanahmet is the heart of the old city of istanbul. A special flavor between orient and occident.Stroll among the spice shops, artisanal crafts and turkish delights. Bargaining is a must and you can get the prices as 50%.The restaurants all around are fantastic, great service and great food.On the other side of the neighbourhood, you'll find special houses with colorful paint and design

Like being at a Fair!. We just loved walking around this area. There was everything you could ask for: History, interesting people, shopping, wonderful treats. April is a beautiful time to be there as all the tulips and spring flowers really make it incredibly festive and beautiful. As with every popular area, beware of prices... I had luckily bought a small gift at one of the shops for 8TL and found it elsewhere for 22TL. I can only imagine the difference between big ticket items.

A vibrant old town. All the major sights are here in Sultanahmet. Plenty of hotels and restaurants here. Small and expensive. Super busy here all the time. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Suleyman Mosque, Hippodrome, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, Egyptian market and so much more here to see. Restaurants are great. Shops are aplenty. Turkish baths aglore. Must spend days here to get the truest vibe.
Fascinating and so historic. Everything about the old city is fascinating . You do need good shoes,good feet,knees and legs to cope with the very hilly walking but it is worth the huff and puff.

Centre of ancient civilization. Probably one of the most impressive historic centres that we have ever visited, So many important and impressive sites in close proximity of each other, complemented by many wonderful hotels, restaurants and cafes, the city bus tour starting point, quaint shops and a very efficient public transport system (tram).

So MUCH history...SO close together!. I am spending one week in Istanbul, one week pretty all in Sultanahmet District, which is easy to do if you are a history buff like me. If there is anything a person did not like about this district I would suggest the problem was with that person, not the district. This is a venerable area with a great variety of historical buildings with lots of beauty and interest to keep you interested. In addition the hotel/restaurant area has an abundance of cafes and restaurants, with more than a handful of roof top restaurants that provide a variety of beautiful views, some featuring the Blue Mosque, others the Hagia Sophia, others the Bosphorus and Marmara Sea. As far as I'm concerned Sultanahmet is a bit like a drug, easy to get high here. :)

Cheap Souvenirs. Take the T1 Tram towards Kabatas direction go own in Eminonu station and walk about 100 meters towards the spice market. Do not go in the spice market, the stores all around the market are cheaper than inside and a lot cheaper than the souvenirs found in Sultanameth square,ex. 1 Key chain is 1TL in the spice market area as compared to 5TL of the same kind of key chain in Sultanameth

lots to see. Went sightseeing for 4 days, but just was not enough days to see & enjoy Sultan Ahmet. So much breathtaking sceneries around the area. Highly recommend the bogaz boat trips & only 10 lira per person.
A cultural must see. This area must be seen to understand the cultural history of Istanbul. Crowded but safe. Historic buildings and mosques. Look for some of the less we'll known structures
Lots to see. There is enough to see and do in this District. From the famous mosques to the Topkapi palace, the museums, the bazaars... A must for all visitors to Istanbul.

Place to live when visiting Istanbul. Sultanahment district is where all the hotels are. It is in the heart of the historic Instanbul. It is very clean and mostly safe. Good food is everywhere, and the trinket sellers are not pushy.
Just fabulous. We wouldn't stay anywhere else in Istanbul - wondering round soaking up the atmosphere in this fabulous city
Loved the place. It's he'll of a place, every thing is available here. Shows the true culture of istanbul. Good restaurants and good people around!

Incredible history and beauty in this old city . Just amazing.. Loved visiting Istanbul and staying in the old city. People were very friendly. Felt safe walking throughout the city of Istanbul. The mosques were breathing taking. Are returning on July 14, 2014.
The Place to Be. This district has the most tourist attractions concentrated in a small area. You can walk to most of them in about 5 minutes.
Turkey at its best. The old part of Turkey, with beautiful mosques. Plenty of restaraunts and carpet shops!!! The Grand bazaar is a must! A really beautiful part of Istanbul

Exciting and near to everything... :). The ocean is visible from this area, and I stayed at Double Tree Hilton and could walk to this district with ease..... it seems all the activities are concentrated in this area and it is within walking distance to many other attractions like Beyoglu and Grand Bazaar...It may be a good place to stay for the first 2-3 days in Istanbul before moving to a hotel in Beyoglu..... :DTry this small little restaurant serving fish in a small street near the Blue Mosque... not cheap but good food. :D

history everywhere. sultanahmet its a very nice place to walk around and see, you have the 2 most important mosques, a lot of turkish snack stores and street food wich is super tasty!! if you wanna be adventurous you can try to use the metro that goes acroos the distrctic and start walking back to see all the stores and good places to eat!! you just need to buy 1 token on the machine to get on = )overall the best place ever!!
Walking through History.. A place wlere there are many things to see & do, also places to visit. Many historical sights, including Grand Covered Bazaar. MUST go and see.

Istanbul atrractions are here, but stay near to Taksim. Sultanahment district has almost all Istanbul attractions. Hagia Sophia, Topkapı Place, the Blue Mosque, The Basilica Cistern (Yerebatan), Gulhane, Grand Bazaar are walking distance to each other. You can see the authentic side of Istanbul in Sultahmet. You will enjoy walking here. But be careful when you shop, remember to bargain a price.but...if you want to stay in a lively place of Istanbul, then you should stay at a hotel near to Istiklal Street, Taksim. Because you need to take a taxi to go back to Sultanahmet after 11pm, it can cost at least 7€. But if you are a tourist in Istanbul, the taxi driver would choose the long way, so it can cost much more.
A must visit area.. Every tourist will spend time here. Lots of sites, museums, mosques with many, many (countless really) small hotels and restaurants to suit all price points.

Lots to see and do. We were based in the area for 10 days and found it a very interesting neighbourhood . Lots of little shops , not so touristy and friendly people. Easy to get around and just across (a very busy) road from the sea front walks and wonderful fish restraunts. If I am lucky enough to return to Istanbul I would stay here again. We were there in April 2013 which is tulip season and it was so beautiful....

good. sultanahmet was my favourite place is Istanbul. happening, fun and crowded. i loved how happening it was, with the best restaurants and the blue mosque and hagia sophia and topkapi palace so close.

Start here in Istanbul. All the ancient sites are here, restaurants that cater to the tourist taste as well as traditional restaurants, people, shops, hotels, it's all here, and mostly within walking distance. You will find the most english here, the most carpet salesmen, and the area is managed very well. Trams are minutes apart and it's easy to get around the area.

None like it. This is a must see for all. There is probably no such place anywhere else - culture, history, commerce and gastronomy in one big place within walking distances. The true soul of Istanbul!

One of the best historical destricts I've been to .... I stayed in a hotel in that destrict before moving to Istiqlal street and I really regret moving from that one ... Very nice historical surroundings, amazing mosques as well as other important attraction you'd need to visit in that place like Bisilica Cistern, grand bazaar, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi palace ... etc. Restaurants are good, I'd recommend you go for local food reastaurants. You can find a lot of souvenir shops where you can get good buy's.
absolutely the best part of the city to stay in. contains the most important attractions and easy to walk to the docks (for Bosphorus trips) and not that far from the city centre Taksim square

Visit this area but eat & shop somewhere else. I liked the area as it has majority of historical attractions (Basilica Cistern, Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, Gulhane Park, Grand Bazaar, etc) in close proximity and one can visit them on foot. However, what I didn't like was the fact that restaurants and shops in this area were overpricing at least by 30-40%, if not more. Also, SultanAhmet closes too early (around 7pm) as compared to Taksim which stays up late in the night. But during day time SultanAhmet is the place one would like to be!!!

History surrounds you. This area had so many sites in walking distance. Our hotel was here and we were able to walk to most of the sites and the tram is close by if necessary. The area can be busy in the middle of the day but either side it is wonderful just to wander and enjoy the architecture, sites, shops, restaurants. It is the centre for all the things that most people wish to see while in Istanbul. Clean, lively, lots to see and do.
Dolce vita at Sultans' Place.... Charming area that you could ever seen... You could feel both the Byzantium and Ottomanat the same time, really hard to express....

Close to everything!. Staying in the Sultanahmet District was wonderful! We were close to all the historic sites and within walking distance from the Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, numerous restaurants, and the tram line to get anywhere else.
Lovely cobblestones streets. Very cosy, scattered by hundreds of cafes, most historic attractions walking distance. Loved the feel of it

Excellent location. Just ignore the touts.. This really is a great area to stay as 80% of the attractions you would want to see on your first visit to Istanbul are easily accessible. The tram also stops here and helps you to access most other attractions.Take care not to respond to the touts though. They are not aggressive but are constantly trying to sell you guidebooks, trips on the Bosphorus (always very expensive - you can do it loads cheaper on public boats) and bus trips.The shops here are quite expensive and don't have the selection, or quality, of goods found in the Grand Bazaar, just two tram stops or 15 minutes' walk away.

The old city. Everything you want at you fingertips. A romantic & beautiful section of the city. We stayed here. The hotel we stayed at was wonderfully close walking distance, to most the great sights we wanted to see. If it wasn't in Sultanahmet the train is just a short walk & will take you anywhere you else in the city & beyond.

Must see part of visit to Istanbul. Very busy and crowded but you get a feeling for the old part of town in a good. This is a vibrant section of town with many shops, restaurants and things to see this is an area to experience on foot rather than by car or van.
Many things to discover!. The streets in this area offer so many things to discover and shopping can be really fun. Food is also great. I will come back.

You hav to come here. It's not really a matter of rating -- if you want to see the important historic sites in Istanbul then you have to come here and put up with pushy carpet peddlers, restaurant owners, etc all trying to pitch you on their business. This is an entirely tourist focused area where there are no locals other than those selling to tourists.
You'll enjoy this area. 4 of the most interesting sites to see as well as the start of the grand Bazar is in this area. Don't forget to visit the underground water reservoir that is 1600 years old.

So many attractions in and around Sultahnmet district. So many attractions in and around Sultahnmet district like Blue mosque,Haghia Sophia,Isalmic museum,Archeology museum,Grand bazaar,and even spice museum is near by near Eminonu.Vast variety of restaurants,turkish delight sweet shops,money exchanges etc.well connected with tram lline T1.

Walking in History. I was overwhelmed by the sense of history that I was walking in around this area. The bustle of people and also the nuts and corn vans made it all interesting. I lost count of the number of fellas I met who had a cousin in Sydney or Melbourne and whose uncle had a carpet business where I could have an apple tea.! All a part of a wonderful experience

We loved it!. My friend and I just loved it, for these reasons:- It's beautiful & lively with a lot of main attractions close to one another- You can either walk or take a tram to explore the area- Various inexpensive (and also expensive) cafes and restaurants- Breathtaking flowers decorating the area- You can shop for almost everything at the Grand Bazaar and its surrounding area- We joined the crowd - sat for hours, doing nothing on the benches at Kabasakal Cd (between the Blue Mosque & Sultan Ahmet Park) - and really enjoyed it. Very relaxing and we thought that we could do it everyday. The only con is the pay toilets. But, they are almost anywhere in Turkey - it's hard to find free toilets.

Feel the history!. The area is magical! You can actually feel the history as you walk! Sultanahmet distict is abundant in amazing sightseeings, restaurants, cafes, souvenir shops, turkish tea and coffee shops. Aya-Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi palace, Grand Bazaar and many more are all located here. Everything is at a walking distance! You'll need at least 3 days to see, feel and experience the essence of this magnificent place. You can actually smell and listen to the city here! Istanbul is for sure a magical city that makes you want to come back again and again and sultanahmet area is key to that!

Cover all main attractions in 1 visit. This district has most of Istanbul's attractions all in 1 location which includes:Blue MosqueHagia SofiaBasilica CisternTopkapi Palace MuseumThe best way to cover all major attractions is to first arrive at Blue Mosque, walk across to Hagia Sofia which is just behind the Blue Mosque, then walk another 7 minutes to the Basilica Cistern and 10 minutes to the Topkapi Museum. If you wish to cover Istanbul in 1 day, you get Hop On Hop Off Bus Tours from the area between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia for about EUR 33 which could be a good option but you need to arrive in the morning to make the best use of the day and your money

Sultanahmet walkable neighborhood. Sultanahmet provides a great walkable experience. You really don't need a restaurant reservations as there are so many that you can just walk in. Many attractions are located within a few blocks and there is also good shopping. We felt perfectly safe walking throughout the area. Our hotel was about two blocks from the Blue Mosque. Very beautiful.

great area to stay & visit. Lively interesting area. Everyone wants your custom. Be choosy. Visit Topkapi palace, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Cisterns, Archeology Museum. When tired visit the Guylhane park. At the end of march the flowers were amazing. The cafe is inexpensive - a great place for tea/ coffe & cake

Marmara university museum. We visited this museum in late March when they had a stunning display of patchwork art. Entrance was free and so was a beautifully printed colour catalogue of the exhibits.
It was a thoroughly enjoyable diversion.

Great views!. The worst part was that my camera battery died right as we were walking into this. The view of the harbor is just breathtaking.
Really worth the time to go and wander around. Make sure you go in nice weather as there is a lot of beauty to see outside.
great. Great place, so close to all the historical places, lots of lovely restaurants, few bars,shops, cafe's that have fab cake's, mmmm. trams, tourist bus's, it is all here, and more.

Salon Kadir Men&Women Hairdressing Istanbul. We found this Salon incidentelly. We were very suprised by the friendly and familiar atmosphere, great service. Haircut, eyebrows and manicure were made nearly perfectly. The shopowner offered us his helpwith finding local places that were not crowded by tourists.We are lucky to find this unique place and warmly recommend the service!We wil surely get back to Istanbul & say hallo again!

Easy to get around. This was a great place to be. All of the major touristy sites are within short walking distance. Beware of the venders offering "Turkish hospitality". It's just another way to get you into their store for some hard core sales pitch. This is especially true if you are a single woman. The men are quite aggressive when trying to get you to come into their shops and buy their wares.

What fun, what history. Fun just walking around looking, but most of the most important attractions are in this area, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, plus lots of little streets going all over. We always felt safe.
Nice ancient city. We were loitering there for more than 2 weeks and I'm pretty sure that we haven't seen a half of all it's awesome places.

Happy memories. You'd expect the main tourist area of a huge city like Istanbul to be a stressful sort of place, but it isn't like that at at all. Lots of small restaurants, shops for tourists, hostels for Australians, hotels, etc, but no traffic and on the whole relaxed, un-pushy, friendly people. We loved just sitting watching the world go by.

Very touristy but pretty. You can visit many tourist destinations such as Blue Mosque, three obelisks, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica cistern, small bazaar next to blue mosque, Ottoman Hammam, water fountain, park, souvenir shops, and countless restaurants/cafes.
food and bazzar. take the tram from kabatas to this district , visit the famous mosque, the hagia sphia museum , the shop for gifts and hand made carpets from the bazzars
The #1 tourist area. Be aware, that this area and most shops cater to tourists. The catering is to the real need and to the needs, local people believe that tourists have.

Crowded, noisy, an assault on the senses - you simply have to go there!. The second time in Istanbul, we wanted to stay here. It is a great place to stay and almost never stops. The only real downside is that its popularity has driven prices up; and where accommodation is concerned, the quality hasn't necessarily tracked this.I have to say though that in the twelve years since my last visit, it has bee a bit sanitized (probably due to the Olympic bid) and some of the little 'backstreet eateries' are no more. The price I fear for catering to modern 'travellers' tastes.'

Definitely visit this area of Istanbul. On our first trip to Istanbul we remained out of the city and did not go into this area but on our last visit we planned to spend our whole time here and it was the best decision, infact from now on whilst I am travelling through Istanbul we will stay here. There is so much history, so much to see and do and some of the best restaurant in Turkey are here.
Safe and Fun Area. Beware the salespeople and never pay asking price for anything. The salespeople are harmless but very aggressive.

Spiritual calm. In the hustle and bustle of this enormous metropolis, there is a lovely peaceful area in the Sultanahmet. It is the original Constantinople center and - perhaps because of multiple religious sites in close proximity - there is an air of reverence in the visiting public and local hawkers alike. The pedestrianized street is key to the lack of commotion and the atmosphere is calm as you wander about. A lovely place to walk and absorb the immense influence of antiquity. The city planners were wise to ensure there is an excellent metro link to enable easy access to this lovely district of Istanbul.

A historical experience. The Sultanahmet District is where most of the historical attractions are. It's a very busy area and it can be a bit much at times but the sights are a must see. During my visit in January, it was busy but not too crowded. I can only imagine what it might be like in the summer. The sites are all within walking distance including the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market. Beware of all the people trying to sell you a carpet though as you walk the streets.

The place to visit. Without question this is the location of several of the main historical sites within Istanbul. They are all located within walking distance of each other. Because of the sites being located in this district you will find it is usually very busy with tourist throughout the day and at night, you will also find many people touting for business and approaching you, simply so no thank-you and most of them will leave you alone. Within this district you will find many hotels and places to eat.
Istanbul. The European side of Istanbul seems to be never far between the facade of vibrant prosperity to crippling poverty.

Very Historical Place. We enjoyed the Basilica cistern, the blue mosque and the hagia sofiya. The cistern was built in the 6th century by the Romans to bring water to the city. Later it was revitalized by the Mughals as the water had gone dry. There is a statue of the MEDUSA HEAD. As legend would have it she had fallen in love with Roman king. But he came to know that if he showed her face to his enemy in war, the opponent would be defeated. He exploited her head to win a war!

the best of istanbul. if you do not go to sultanahmet,you havent been in istanbul. The very essencial part of Istanbul is Sultanhamet district. Its where all the most importante monuments are. KIts the historic district, the real Istanbul, Here you have the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi palace, the hipodrome, the cistern, the walls, the grand bazaar, the agia sofia, the obelisk, the german.. and so many other importante sites. The resauranjts and souvenir stalls are a must,

Istanbul's history is all here. Here you can find many of the historical attractions such as sultan ahmad mosque, hagia sophia mosque and museum, topkapi palace, grand bazaar, spice bazaar, basilica cistern, sulemaniya mosque, and the walls of constantinople. This area breifs a hundred of years when the ottomans were ruling. It is a crowded area but safe.

The old city of Constantinople. Essentially the Sultanahmet District of Istanbul encompasses the old city of Constantinople. The majority of the historic sites are here - Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern, the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Spice Market, etc. The area is hilly but walk-able, and there an excellent tram running to the Golden Horn. Hotels are everywhere and there must be hundreds of restaurants with panoramic views of the Bosporus and the city. This is a MUST SEE in your life. Allow several days at least.
Good area for attractions and tram travel.. Close enough to be able to walk to main attractions.Must see Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia

A place where you find ALL the touristgroups. There is not much to say. If you have not been here and seen the area,- you must. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace minimum - but for people with interest: The Archeologic Museum. Also the Mosaic Museum nearby is worth a visit.

history and shopping. The area is close to most of the toruistic places such as Sultanahmet mosque, Hagia sofia, cistern and Grand bazaar. You can enjoy the history and some shopping in the bazaar. Very otantic.

Wonderful to wander. This was an amazing area to wander around. We had a guide so we wandered all the back alleys and old Ottoman Inns as well as all the main tourist sights. There is so much to see it was amazing

Old Istanbul. This is the old part of Istanbul(and the most interesting part of the town,in my opinion).Here you can find a lot of interesting old buildings such as HAGIA SOPHIA,BLUE MOSQUE,GRAND BAZAAR,SPICES BAZAAR,BASILICA CISTERN.There are a lot of cafes,restaurants,souvenir shops.Extremely crowded.Almost nobody speaks english,no traffic signs or other indicators in english.

Beautiful and clean. It is obvious that Istanbul has prepared and is preparing for welcoming more and more tourists: the historic district is being renovated, streets are clean and museums. Staff is friendly and helpful everywhere. Istanbul is preserving and shoing off its history in a beautiful way.

Old Town Istanbul. Everything is within walking distance once you get to Sulthamet. The area felt safe at night. The restaurants were mainly catering to Tourists and generally OK. You would be better going elsewhere if you are looking for fine dining.
A good area to stay. A very lively place full of cafes, food stalls, shops and places of interest like the Blue Mosque, Ayasofya, Hipodrome etc. Walking distance to Grand Bazaar.

Best area to be for HISTORIC monuments!!. This part of the city is HEART of Istanbul. For tourists its the place to be. All other areas like Asian side or Beyoglu, IStiklal, Taksim, Bebek etc. are easily accesible from here. Lots of cafes and eateries here too.

Be careful. A lovely place in Istanbul, good to sit back and enjoy the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sofiya in the background.. but be careful with your belongings. Also too touristy.. people are constantly trying to sell you something.. that is the most irritating thing about this place. Avoid buying anything here because you will be fleeced. Just walk a little away from this place and prices are almost halved, be it food, bottles of water or even the turkish delights.
Best area to stay. If you are going to Istanbul to see the historic sights - stay here. You will be a short walk from the majority of them!
historic. Area of everithing important you have to see- Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet camii, Sultanahmet park, hamami, and part of topkapi palace
The best place. Amazing district, where you will enjoy visitng, Topkapi palace, Hagia sofia, the Blue mosque, grand bazar and many interesting sights
The place to be for all tourists!. Definitely the place where all tourists in Istanbul need to visit as it is where all the mosques are. Look out for the annoying Bosphorous tour people.
NO 1 TOURISTIC AREA. This Area is the main turistik Area of Istanbul which Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapı Palace located in this Area.
Great place. There are many historical sites, great restaurants and hotels.Nice small shops. Everything is close by.

The heart of Istanbul. If you want to hang around, go shopping, have a snack and admire the daily life in Istambul, you must walk down Sultanahmet District. You can visit every store and let the owners offer you their best products at a reasonable price! My advice is buy stuff to people who sell handmade products because by doing this, you're promoting local commerce.
Lots of restaurants and hotels and shopping. The area is filled with restaurants, hotels and shops along with some of Istanbul's famous sites (Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and the Grand Bazar).

You feel like you're walking through history. I think it is one of the most magical places on earth. the architecture of the Mosques and the old bazaar, the Egyptian market all seem to come together to revive the past. the old stones of city and the merchants cries for customers only add to the mystique of the sultanAhmet's charm.

Got to spend a day...and night.. Apart from the usual sights and sounds, the best part is the walk around the Blue Mosque, specially in the night. The lights on the mosque and the ground gives a surreal look to the place. And there is good foor all around...that helps a lot/

Great location and sites. But there are many, many people there on the hustle - the guys selling tourist books, the tourist bus barkers, the rug salesmen, etc. At best, it's annoying. At worst, tempers are likely to flare. Try not engage in any way and definitely don't express interest. And don't follow any of the affable, attractive men to their rug shops. Their stuff is marked up 1000%.

Where you should stay in Istanbul. If planning to go to Istanbul, that is the area that you should search the hotel to stay. It is the old city and where most of the attractions are. It is safe, beautiful and with very welcoming people.

great place to visit!. We spent 5 days in this area of Istanbul. It has a tremendous amount to offer in a really small area. We ate, shopped, and did some great sightseeing all by walking. And this was with a 6 year old. Okay...I did have to carry her up a hill a couple times:) You can stay in this area and see so much!

Good Location. Good place to be for all the main attractions. Excellent regular tram service. Worth buying the Istanbul Kart which is a card you can load up and then use on most of the main transport systems. Plenty of good restaurants and cafes.

The best!. This is a fantastic area of Istanbul as there was always something happening. The main attractions of Istanbul are located all in walking distance within the Sultanahmet area. Highly recommend to all visitors to Istanbul as there are also lots of eating and drinking places where you can stop for a break. I would also go as far as to say that this is the best area for visitors to Istanbul especially for first time visitors.
Sultanahmet District. A wonderful area in Istanbul to stay, eat, shop and visit the many sites this amazing city has to offer.

Convenient location. This area is nice to explore on your own. It is at a convenient spot so if you have your hotel in this area, you will be very close to Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia Topkapi Palace, Spice Bazaar, etc. Plus you can catch a tram very easily. Bosphorous cruise and the Galatta bridge are also not very far away.
Live The History. Old Istanbul Rocks your heart. Incredible Lands. Something like the history still lives in the walls. Enjoy OLD ISTANBUL

A Beautiful Area of Istanbul - But, Be Careful. One of the best spots in Istanbul is the Sultanahmet District. Many great sights from the Blue Mosque to Topkapi Palace are in the area and it is one of the stops for the Hop-On/Hop-Off buses. This is also one of the areas that scam artists and dishonest taxi drivers ply their trades because it is a beacon for world-travelers.Be very wary of anyone that unannounced approaches you on foot in the area, especially men who are alone. They will usually get to stop you with a ploy that they thought you were Turkish or for a light and then the scams start, (you can research this on this site or any Internet search engine).Another typical problem in this area are dishonest taxi drivers; from money switches to wanting to take you to their "special" night clubs instead of where you told them to go. Many times they will not take no for an answer and will rack up expensive bills.Sultanahmet is a great place to visit, but it has the highest proportion of scammers to regular people in any of the 39-countries I have visited.

Best area.. Great location with many attractions in walking distance. Nice restaurants with local specialities and not only. Not far from the airport either. Like a 20-30 minute drive depending on traffic.

Super. If you visit Istanbul as a turist then I strongly recommend to book a hotel in Sultanahmet, there are many in the Akbiyik Street. Everything can be done by foot, however there is also a good Tram line if you want to go to Galata.

Great Spots, beautiful streets. Charming, small streets, nice small restaurants, and the center of the main buildings to be seen. History all over, contains Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, The Gran Bazaar, the Spice Bazaar, roman ruins, bizantine walls, good shopping areas, what else?

Not sure why this is a separate review.... All of the tourist locations (Blue Mosque, Ayasofia, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, etc.) are in Sultanhamet, so trust me, you'll be walking through it. You don't just go there to walk the streets. I'd suggest buying ALL of your nik-nak touristy items in the shops OUTSIDE of the bazaar for a much better deal.

Great sights with equally great scams. The sights are unique and must be seen, including the Blue Mosque and the Tokapi. However, the carpet scams and restaurant touts are unbearable. If you're thinking of buying something like a carpet or jewellery, do your homework very, very, very carefully. It's so unfortunate that the Turkish tourism industry is suffering greatly because of the scams. The government should really close them down.

Love This Part of Town. We were in Istanbul in June, 2013, where we stayed near Taksim Square. This time we opted to stay in the Sultanahmet District and are we glad we did. It is a completely different feel. The streets are very narrow and it feels more homey. We shopped in the local markets and felt like we got to experience the every day, ordinary people. Of course there is the touristy area as well, where someone is always trying to sell you something. Most will back off once you say "No, thank you." Tons of shopping opportunities.

BEAUTIFUL. Now that is so amazing, safe you can walk there anytime of day or night it is totally safe, it is always buzy plenty of tourist, little carts selling freshly squeezed pommegranate juice for 1lira, if uou feel for a nibble whilst waiting to get into the Isofiya you can nibble on the everyday turkish bread sold from the carts and you can have it filled with Nutella mmmmmm, the entire square is just beautiful, the Blue Mosque, incredibly beautiful, the shops around, the restaurants amazing.

Fun little place to walk around. It was a pretty fun little area to walk around, lots of great hidden restaurants. Beware of the street peddlers and gypsies.. Lots of stray cats too.. All and all a very nice scenic area to walk around!

shopping paradise, amazing. this is the area surrounding the blue mosque, ayasofia and grand bazaar. The area is quite good for shopaholics. There are lots of options to choose from, If you are good in bargaining, this is the place for you to be. From antiques to accessories,cultural clothing,spices,turkish cuisine,calligraphy, everything is available here. You can spend a whole day here. Except from shopping, many cultural landmarks like ayasofia, blue mosque, topcapi palace etc lies in this region. I recommend to stroll around rather than taking a vehicle or tram. If you are a vegetarian, eating options are minimal so plan accordingly.

Great Little Town. Recommended highly for tourists. All the major attractions are within walking distance including the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazaar, and Spice Bazaar. There is also a metro stop that allows easy access to the airport and Taksim Square.

Don't Miss It!. We stayed in this area for about 3 days. We walked the streets on our way everywhere, and it NEVER stopped taking my breath away. Great for strolling, picture-taking, shopping, and dining! Make the trip!!

Absolute worth even for a short trip. I had a few hours stopover in Istanbul and wanted to see the the town I had never visited before. I took the metro from Ataturk Airport to the terminal station in downtown, changed to tram number one and stepped out at Sultanahmet station. The Blue Mosque was directly in front of me. From there I continued few hundred meters to Hagia Sofia, followed to the parc area and saw the famost Topkapi Palace of the former leaders of the Ottoman Empire. Then I walked the very cosy and European-style small streets to the water front at Sircesi since I wanted to see the Golden Horn, which has historically divided Europe and Asia. Then kebab lunch back same way I came. Well done in two and half hours I spent downtown.

Good Place for Shopping. This area is good for shopping as it is close to Grand Bazaar. You must negotiate prices while buying items at Grand Bazaar. Must visit Blue Mosque at least from outside. Overall, the area is quite enjoyable to explore and is usually crowded by tourists.

Lovely - just prepare to be touted for carpets :0). Just wandering around here is a rewarding experience. There is so much to take in & observe. Keep your eyes peeled for hidden sites, like Turkish baths, street statues (e.g. the 'Hamal'), and the simit sellers.

Never get tired of it.. We stayed just behind the Blue Mosque. Every morning and evening, we walked across and along the Hippodrome passing the Blue Mosque and we enjoyed it. Every attraction there are to see is just within walking distance that you don't have to worry about transportation. Walking to Eminonu pier or Grand Bazaar wasn't that far and there were so much to seem smell andt taste that you don't feel tired.

Nicer than I expected. I was very impressed by this area, it was clean and open. lots of interesting shops and felt very safe. Not always easy to navigate but following the tram line helped us get from the Spice Bazaar area to the Hagia Sophia with ease.
So Much To See and Do. This area of Istanbul has the top three sitews one should visit while in the city. All within walking distance from each other. Great restaurants and shopping here.

Beautiful place for a day visit!. Sultanahmet is a perfect place for historians, there are countless mosques and attractions and bazaars. The Blue Mosque and Cistern are a must see, Blue Mosque is free entrance and Cistern costs only 10 turkish lira. We also saw the Hagia Sofia which in my opinion is overpriced! Our over all favorite place at Sultanahmet was the Egyptian Spice Market, we loved it! We purchased tea, spices, coffee and turkish delights. Stay away from the grand bazaar, it's a tourist trap!

There is always something to discover. Like many travellers to new destinations you feel a sense of insecurity and vulnerability! but after a day all that went out of the window like they say! Istanbul is a safe city and there is always people who will help if you ask!.Its tourist friendly and most essentials are not too far off.take care and enjoy this lovely city Istanbul.

The soul of Istanbul. Sultanahmet District & the Grand bazaar are the soul of Istanbul.They showcase the historic character of the city .Intriguing, charming, old world yet modern.Clearly a blend of east with the west.A must visit.
busy. touristy area really but very nice just dont get put off by the ppl trying to get you into their restaurants the ppl work really hard and their service is 90% really good
A must see. If you visit Istanbul you definitely have to visit Sultanahmet, there you can find the Grand Bazaar, the beautiful mosques and other historic evidence.

its avery convinent location for site seeing. I like food over there and you will get all facilities in that location there is a tram facilities you can travel to many places spice bazar and grand bazar is with in 10 min walk area

Fantastic History. Get yourself a good guide book and lose yourself in 6000 years of history, remembering that as you stand in Sultan Ahmet square you are standing what was the great hippodrome of Byzantium where the gladiators fought and died.

Lovely. Had lots of lovely walks in the residential areas and saw the locals. Lots of local and tourist shops and wonderful restaurants. The busiest place is near the Tramway where the money exchange places are and local fast food and sit down restaurants.

Enter at your own risk!. This is the tourist district. Having said that, there are a number of scams taking place. We were subject to several the first two days we were here. The first was the shoe shine. Google this for an explanation of what the scammer does. We were saved because we were both in sneakers - difficult to shine! The second was the food scam. Google this too. The restaurant tried to get $40 USD out of us for two kabobs and two cups of tea. Be VERY CAREFUL about what is brought to your table. Just because you didn't order it, doesn't mean it's complimentary. Here's the problem with Istanbul: 99% of the Turks are genuinely kind and honest. The other 1% are extremely smooth thieves and very dangerous. More than one tourist has been threatened with violence. Just do a search to read a few stories posted. The trouble is its impossible to tell who belongs to the 1% and who belongs to the 99%. Before you go to Istanbul, go on line and read about the scams and how to protect yourself. NEVER, EVER, follow a stranger into a shop or a bar if invited. Let me repeat - NEVER, EVER go with a merchant or stranger. You WILL be robbed, and there is nothing the police can do to help you. Do your homework when considering Istanbul as a tourist destination, then don't let your guard down because people seem friendly and nice. THATis exactly how one gets trapped.

One of my favourite places in the world. I absolutely love Istanbul and especially Sultanahmet District. The mosques are beautiful and the Blue Mosque is simply captivating.There are an array of wonderful restaurants and the grand bazaar is great fun. If you visit Istanbul I would recommend you stay in the Sultanahmet District. On my 2nd visit we stayed in Taksim district which was an area I did not particular enjoy, for me it was soulless and has none of the charm and essence of the Sutlanahmet District.
Atmospheric!. Lovely area of İstanbul. Lovely atmosphere and all the wonderful toursist attractions are here. Must visit if you are in İstanbul

The essence of old Istanbul. The crumbling yet imposing walls of the ancient city still stand in the Sultanahmet area, the heart of old Istanbul, where Byzantium and Constantinople survive in the semi-sunken Milion marker (Rome's starting point for all distances measured in the Empire), the capacious 2nd century Hippodrome, and the iconic Hagia Sofya of Emperor Justinian. Among these treasures of the past, crammed into every available space, are the hotels, the neon-lit cafes and pastry shops, the souvenir and trinket-sellers and street vendors of today's Istanbul. Find a good hotel in this area (there's no lack of choice) and surround yourself with the essence of Istanbul.Sultanahmet is a snapshot of Istanbul, past and present. In winter, the acrid smell of burnt chestnuts (roasting is not an option!) and singed corn-on-the-cob from street carts fills the air, against a backdrop of soaring minarets and the call to prayer. Sleek new trams snake up and down the revamped tourist hotspots, linking Eminonu and Sirkeci to Aksaray and parts further afield, delivering sightseers to the Topkapi Palace, the Museums, the Hagia Sofya and Hippodrome, the "Blue Mosque" and the Basilica Cistern. Walk. This is the best advice we can give. Everything in the Sultanahmet area is within easy reach and winter is the best time to visit. Mediterranean winters are mild and the hordes have not yet arrived; the place is yours, particularly at night. Around the Hagia Sofya and "Blue Mosque" are streets of cafes and restaurants, ribboned with lights and vying for business in the good-natured way of the Turks ("Albura Kathisma", 36-38 Akbiyik Caddesi, two streets behind the Four Seasons Hotel, is highly recommended).Pace yourself -- another important piece of advice. There is so much to see that sensory overload is a very real problem. Take the time to find out the details: the frescoed angels supporting the dome of the Hagia Sofya, for instance, have six wings each, two for flying and four for shielding their faces from the radiance and beauty of God, whom they protect. Look for them when you are on the upper floor, peering round the scaffolding in the centre of the church.Talk to everyone. Turkish people are warm and hospitable, and most understand English to a greater or lesser degree. (Proof of their goodwill is all around, in the number of stray cats everyone seems to feed, and the fact that a stranger searching a map inevitably draws a "Do you need help?" from passersby.) And even if you discover that the shawl you bought in the Grand Bazaar is 10TL cheaper at a street stall, you will have had an amusing conversation with a highly skilled salesman in the oldest and largest covered market in the world. Worth it!
The Idea Area to Stay.. Everything you need is in this area from places to stay, visit or just go out for a drink and dine. Everything is in walking distance...

Into the heart of the city..
