I can't find the right words to describe the Sultanahmet district, I think it's worth coming to Istanbul just to visit this district full of history of odors and flavors, this is the daily business hub of the city, the many craft stores, shops, street vendors, a place very crowded it is hard even to walk as it is busy and hectic. Obviously it is a tourist place and therefore it is frequented by many tourists in search of the spice or souvenir, but it is highly traditional and therefore I am sure that will amaze you.

Very interesting. we stayed at the heart of the district ,bang opposite Hagia Sophia & the Blue Mosque.It's teeming with people and there are so many shops, restaurants to visit quaint by-lanes to walk down, benches to sit on & eat hot hazelnuts when you are tired, trams to ride when you want to go to Eminonu or Kabatash . Oh ! how I miss Sultanahmet.

Atmosphere with size. The semi-dark atmosphere is interesting, the fishes are big in the water, and it is reasonable size to walk through. The medusa heads attraction was not a big catch to walk to the very end just for that.You see the same from the first few meters. Anyhow if you already there you will do it for sure.

A lot of attractions. Sultanahmet district is chock full of attractions and restaurants and makes for wonderful evening walks. There is so much to see and do, with street vendors around every corner. Truly an experience.

Spiritualy good. Blue mosque perfect very artisticaly painted. It will leave you breathless . Hagai sophia s another world. Used both church and mosque and now museum. 25 lira for entrance is expensive but if u have museum card will be affordable

Historic Sultanahmet. The Sultanahmet District is historic, very safe, very clean, full of neighborhood restaurants, beautiful parks, and most of the things one would want to see in Istanbul - the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar.
Very historic. A great place to stay and visit, much to see. Lots of great restaurants, Turkish bath houses and a great skyline.

history comes alive here!. we walked around and around. One felt as if one was walking side by side with history. It has historic neighborhoods, walking areas, shopping areas, the old Istanbul in all its grandness. Topkapi palace and Blue Mosque area not far off.

An area full of life. This is an area which is must do in Istanbul to stroll around, buy souvenirs, eat dinner at one place and Buklava and tea at other. We stayed at Double Tree Hilton old town, and in our four days at Istanbul, we were at Sultanahmet every day.

You won't be board. What an awesome area of town! There is the hustle & bustle of everyday life everywhere you look, but also lots of touristy bits too! Do yourself & favour & don't plan, just go and have a wander and go from there! You won't be disappointed!

Great place. Had an eventful day raoming on foot through the streets of Sultanahmet.....Sultan Ahmet was on 14 when he ascended the throne and 28 when he passed away....sad.....but the area in his name does amply well to remember this Sultan of Turkey....

All an more!. Shops, street cafés , souvenirs , ceramics, Turkish delights, lamps, carpets and so much more! The metro , although packed, stop right in the middle! The Turkish is the friendliest nation in the world!

Great historic area. Just seeing he Haga Sophia and Blue Mosque, Topeki palace and Hadrian' s wall was worth the journey. There are many Ottoman historic sites along complete with Harem's at Topeki palace!

One of the world`s number one districts. Lovely park area to hang around in, restaurants, awesome historical sites... For me it is so wonderful place because of its old history, which this place is plenty of, but it is nice place to hang around and eat as well.

Awesome Vacation. We spent 10 days in Sultanahmet it was extremely fun. The sites, smells and people were fantastic. We visited the Blue Mosque, the Haggia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Cisterns. We also took a quick boat ride to the Asian side. Overall, it was a relaxing vacation. The restaurants were fantastic and both the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar are must sees. You also need to get your shoes shined by a street shoe-shiner and buy some freshly-made cigarettes near the Spice Market. Well worth the trip!
historical place. you are doing a journey on history. Topkapi museum, blue mosq, ayasofia was excellent.. i advice around of sultamahmet for trip of istanbul.

A small pause in Sultanhamet. On your walking path to visit the impressive Haghia Sophia or magnificient Topkapi Museum you can make a pause and enjoy an apple tea in the street which climbs the hill,when leaving the tram at the Parc station before Haghia sophia

Must See. If you want to feel Old City in real meaning you have to go! You can find very interesting placeses. If you want to learn anything about Turkish History no doubt you have to visit Sultanahmet. Especially Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace must be seen

magic neighbourhood. this is the "old town" neighbourhood of Istanbul. It is a bit more touristy, but it's where a lot of the old monuments etc are and there's really nice cobblestone streets and bars, restaurants, shops.

Interesting, accessible, safe (if you're smart). Sultanahmet can end up getting some bad reviews from people simply by merit of the fact that it's where most tourists tend to flock. However, while this is absolutely, irrefutably true, there's a very good reason for it. This neighborhood is a truly excellent platform upon which to build a trip to Istanbul.If you're a savvy traveler you're going to have a sense of where you should and shouldn't be eating and shopping, and it's very true that Sultanahmet has a large number of tourist traps. These stores absolutely do not define this neighborhood though. If you do your research it's easy to find wonderful, authentic, and reasonably priced shops and restaurants, and easy to avoid the places selling overpriced junk. This is also where the lion's share of famous historical sites are that most travelers will have heard about. The Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are both here, in addition to Topkapi Palace and the adjoining gardens. You'll also find the basilica cistern here and beautiful grounds surrounding the mosques.My girlfriend and I also found this neighborhood to be quite safe, as long as you take necessary precautions. Pickpockets abound and we almost had one of our phones snatched literally out of our hands at night, being saved only by some quick thinking and sharp eyes. However, police are everywhere and the city is clearly on its A game when it comes to protecting tourist safety both during the day and at night.In short, this neighborhood has a lot to offer and is a nice place to come back to, particularly if you're like us and prefer to start with one neighborhood and then work your way further out into the city. It was reasonably quiet at night, felt safe, and had a lot to offer.

Best to go in January when crowds aren't to bad. Nice old city experience, just just learn to ignore the carpet salesmen and restaurant guys every 15 feet or so along most streets inviting you into their businesses.

Istanbul historic district. This is the city historical heartbeat. All the major monuments are there: Topkapi, Haghia Sophia, the Blue Mosque. Don't miss visiting the Basilica Cistern near Haghia Sophia.There are also many nice boutique hotels, restaurants or cafés. This is a busy commercial area in town as well with many antiques or souvenir shops. It is a place worth exploring on foot to see the Istanbul daily life and get lost in its small, crooked back lanes to discover uncountable scenes.

Walking the streets of Saltanahmet. I just can't say enough about my visit. I enjoyed the culture, the food and the people. If there was one negative it would be the consistent solicitation from shop owners vying for your business. Once you get used to that, you just say "no thank you" and walk on.

Istanbuls best area for mind-blowing attractions. Sultanahmet is ideal for the big 3 - Topkapi Castle, Aya Sofya and the Blue Mosque. Combined with excellent and affordable accommodation and spoiled for eating choices, this area is unsurpassable.
exciting walk. The district is not that big itself, however lots of attractions to visit and admire, including mosques, shops, restaurants and cats.

Istanbul's Grand Bazaar. If you are in Istanbul you must visit the Grand Bazaar (or Covered Bazaar) to make you trip complete. The sights and sounds must be experienced in person. From Postcards to Antiques, the perfect place to shop for that someone special on your list. Or if you are a window shopper you will have hours and hours of looking enjoyment.

Joyfull area. a lot of bars , pubs and restaurant , excatly on akbiyik street. some restaurant has live local musicians . fish restaurant not bad but a bit expensive i think.bars were exciting and very crowds. visit there too :)

Great for walking around in and enjoying the neighbourhood. As part of the old city we were staying in this area so everyday would walk around on our way to some site or to travel elsewhere. I would recommend to visit here as part of any trip to Istanbul and take in the people watching, stop for a coffee on Ordu Caddesi and visit such places as the Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque etc whilst you are there.

Sultanahmet District, Istanbul. Wonderful area for people watching, strolling and enjoying the ancient sites.... don't hesitate to try one of the "cafeteria" style restaurants along Ordu Caddesi..... simply point and choose and enjoy some fabulous local food!

This is where everything is.. This is where everything is. Be prepared, it's like Vegas in that people are trying to sell you. if you make eye contact, they will try to draw you into their store. However, they use different tactics than what you see in the West. They might give a friendly smile and ask "where are you from?" or "US?" Or "how is your vacation?" Any innocent question to get you to respond...and then they are all over you. So you have to learn to immediately say "no, thank you" or "Koli gelsun" - which is Turkish for may it go well for you, and is similar to "no thanks". In Rome, people say "grazie" and keep walking in these situations. But that said, this is the tourist area where you will find all the attractions you came for. Right off the sultanahmet is a downtown and the Grand Bazaar. The Grand Bazaar has so much, but be prepared: it's wall-to-wall people and of course, hawkers. You don't want to go there tired or you'll just walk right back out. the entrance is off the main drag and really small, so you don't realize you are entering the world famous grand bazaar, and there you are!

Take in the sights, avoid the hustlersAbsolutely stunning architectural marvels. The whole are is filled with architectural wonders that catch the eye and take your breath away..certainly a must see area if you are looking for beauty and/or a student of history. Having said that..be prepared to wait in long lines to enter the 3 most visited sites:Sultan Ahmet/Blue Mosque, Ayasofia, and the Basillica Cisterns...AND beware of all the hustlers and hawkers and over priced goods and restaurants. Believe me you can eat better and cheaper if you just walk a couple hundred meters or take the tram a couple stops in either direction away from the SultanAhmet station. lso worth a mention is the Topkapi Palace/museum. Some of the exhibits truly are stunning but to get the best view of whats on display you would be just as well served buying a book in the shop or going on line. Probably the worst lighting I have seen in any of the so-called world museums. Still, if you have the , time, the patience and the desire to be humbled..do visit the Blue Mosque. Remember, shoes off and in a plastic bag, please..and women must have heads ..and legs ...covered...but the entrance is free.
An action-packed tourist area shrouded in history. Lots to do and see. A great place to wander and savour the sights. Slightly too much 'tack and trinkets' though and greasy kebabs...

Sultanahmet District in December. This district includes many of Istanbul's points of interest and as a result is a touristy area. I do not imply anything negative by that: a lot of restaurants, shops, vendors, etc. but with higher prices. We were there in December: it was bit cold (in fact it snowed) but there was NO crowd. This is a great area to get acclimated when you first arrive in the city.

Great place to stay as a tourist. I really enjoyed staying in this area when I came a weekend ahead of a week long business trip. Great neighbourhood to walk in, awesome architecture, great restaurants and shopping!

Love it. I love this area of Turkey, it is absolutely jam packed with pretty buildings, interesting architecture, shops to explore, local street peddlers and not to mention some of the best sights in Istanbul - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi

Everything in walking distance. Haja Sofia , Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Islamic museum , little Haja Sofia, Big basar. Just ignore the naughty man asking you silly quetions (Where are you from?) and then offering you carpets, leather products, souveniers and restaurants.
Great Place. Great Place to be! A lot of trading, monuments, travelers from all over the world. National turkish cuisine along with west fastfood cafes.

Taxi fraud. Avoid riding a taxi in the Sultanahmet Area-or the old town in total- as much as possible, unless they are called from your hotel from a trusted cab station. They are all waiting for tourist rip offs, either taking you for a longer than needed ride or exchanging your 50 tl bills for 5. You can see all the major tourist attractions(Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar etc) and shopping malls if you travel with the metro or tram line
Great street... In this neighbourhood you can find everything from food to clothes and carpets..crowded strets..with bars ..restaurants

THE OLD CITY. All the major attractions are in this area of the city.Crowded day and night but has so many attractions to see, i could say the most important one.You can walk , shop,drink a cap of cofee and also enjoy your lunch or dinner in restaurants with great views.Sultanahmet is the heart of the city!

Tourist trap. Although there are some nice things to see around this area, I found it incredibly irritating with the crowds and tourist touts. Tourism in Istanbul is still very driven by getting the tourists cash - its just done too aggressively and obviously! Definately get off the beaten tourist trail!

Just Relax And Enjoy Walking. This is a great district to walk through. Sure you get some more than aggressive selling by meechants, but remain polite, keep walking, and forget some of the guilt trips, e.g. "Why you no say hello or goodbye?"...it is all part of th sale.

Compare price, workmanship & negotiate aggressivley before buying anything!!. My family was there for 2 weeks and we did a lot of shopping. The #1 thing I learned was prices and quality of workmanship vary greatly from store to store. So, slow down and pay particular attention to the details of workmanship as well as cost. Don't make the mistake of buying the first item you see before getting a feel for nuances of how different stores produce these products...don't worry you'll see the same items over and over again at other stores. Above all negotiate aggressively at 1/3 of asking price...If you're patient you will probably find better quality at a considerably cheaper price if you take some time. Lastly, there is more inferior products than quality ones so look around to find the stores who take pride in their work...you won't regret it.
Traditional turkish world. + Nice place with a lot of hidden miracles- Prepared to save your money, for women alone: don't get bored of the frequently chats of men "around the corner"

Very Beautiful in the night!!. When I visited this area in the night time, I walked around there. There was fountain lit up by various colors changed time by time in front of the blue mosk which was also lit up. The set of the colored fountain and lit-up mosk was very beautiful and impressed !! The disappointed experience here was there were three pairs of guys who tried to cheat me by saying they were foreigners and inviting the drinks. I had read the news that they tried to take the tourists to their local bars and made the tourists paying lots of money. Of course, they were not foreigners but actual local persons who have existing relationship with those bars or more dangerous places.This area is beautiful, but we should not forget that bad guys are always watching us.

Arasta Bazaar. This is a great bazaar just behind the Blue Mosque and has shops that sell everything.It was also the only place I could find my rosehip turkish tea, my favourite. It is also home to my husbands favourite pipe shop, which is run by its wonderful owner makes the most beautiful handmade pipes.The shops in this bazaar are definitely my favourite in Istanbul

best place to stay in Istanbul. our hotel was in Sutanahmet District and this was really a wise choose...all wonderful attraction were around us....we didn't need taxi...everything so near...so many restaurants and shops too....I loved this District

The History Part. If you visit Istanbul for the first time, you should definitely stay in Sultanahmet. Most of the historic sights (that most have a fee) are located here, so you don't have to move much. Tram passes through Sultanahmet though. There are also plenty restaurant choices for everyone. With NO traffic, you can be at Ataturk airport in less than 30 minutes.
Don't miss. A great place to stay and play; a lot of history in the area and it is all very accessible. With all of the tourist options in Turkey; this is a must explore district in Istanbul.
beautiful, clean. Its a famous and beautiful district of Istanbul, Its more like historical. The district is clean. And it really has a nice atmosphere.

Beautiful Area!. if you like history and walking around all town this is the place!in each corner you will find something interesting!All thje important museums and palaces are in that area!You will not be dissapointed being in that area!Except those runners who are following each single tourists for getting commission!if you can run from them this is the best palce in istanbul!All the small hotels and restaurants are around are making also good ambiance!

Quıte good. Got a bıt borred of lookıng ınsıde mosques, the blue mosque was quıte dıssapoıntıng haggı saggı was very good as was the Palace all wıthın walkıng dıstance.Really lıked the cıstern place wher bond was recorded although ıt dıd not take long to look around

A great historical place. In every corner you get to see something historical and very special from buildings to monuments to restaurants and mosques everything is historical and beautiful! I strongly recommend spending a couple days in this district!
Nearby. A beautiful area to stay if you prefer to be nearby the most important sights of the city. Also very nice to take a stroll and to get lost among the countless hotels and restaurants.

Excellent area.. Perfect area in which to base your stay in Istanbul. Very friendly people. Even the "guides" are polite when you say no.Everything in easy walking distance.The Big Red Bus is a great ride (pick up from outside the Blue Mosque) but avoid the night tour as very long, very boring and you get "dumped" at a restaurant for over an hour, with nothing to do other than eat or drink.
Beautiful architecture. I liked this area! Lots to see and very close to water! Boat trip to Bosphorus 15tl was good price for length of trip & ability to take many pictures

Our first stop. Our first stop here and basically it is fun for your first stay, but it gets repetitive after you see all the main landmarks and you get tired of the cheesiness of it. Be aware of all the tourist traps.

Restaurants, Mosques, Shopping. There are plenty of places to eat, see and shop. Be careful of all of those "friendly" folks who come up to you on the street. They are trying to lure you into their restaurant, shop, carpet store, etc. At times it can be annoying because they are relentless, but after a while you learn to say, "leave me alone." If you do the Blue Mosque, be certain to go to the Lecture on Islam in the building next door, it is free and you will learn what to look for when inside the Mosque.

Heart of the amazing city. I really enjoyed to stay in sultahahmet with a treat walking around and the vicinity to the popular attractions.there is a plenty of shops, aristaa bazar, and cafes.amazing scenery and great people.

New experience every time one visits it. Amazing! Istanbul is definitely worth seeing and Sultanahmet district is experience for itself! Even if you're only walking around it, you will be more than amazed with its beauty and so many people walking, sitting or rushing somewhere.

Perfect area to stay in Istanbul. After researching Istanbul on Trip Advisor we decided to stay in Sultanahmet because of the vicinity to the atttractions, and we were not disappointed. The area is hilly, quaint, very old and original, but it has plenty of shops, bazaars, cafes, restaurants and markets. Also millions of very well looked after cats.

Wonderful architecture. The whole area is studded with magnificent buildings and it was a total treat walking around and exploring the area especially with snow everywhere. We particularly loved the Topkapi Palace with its majestic buildings and wonderful treasures. We really enjoyed coffee and cake in the cafe overlooking the harbour.

Where Everyone's Your Friend. It's impressive being surrounded by so much history in the Sultanahmet district. The downside is that you will be constantly approached by someone who doesn't want to sell you anything but inevitably wants to show you his rug shop. You can either be annoyed by this (think Jakarta or Ho Chi Minh) or just play with it and keep walking. We did the latter and made it part of the experience. heading into the smaller backstreets and going behind the market you will discover streets focused on particular types of goods. Starting at the Spice market you can hit backstreets and end up at the Grand Bazaar. Take at least a half day if you plan to do any shopping.

Great area, but. . .. hawkers, some aggressive, are out on the square near the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. One went so far as to put shoe polish on my shoe, after repeatedly being told "no," in the expectation that I would ask him to complete the job. The area is in old Istanbul and you can walk to almost all of the great sights. It is incredible to be able to walk about and see some historic places without needing to find a taxi or the tram. Expect that hotels in the area are in very old buildings, and few have elevators., but the convenience is beyond reproach.Don't gorget to have a freshly squeezed pomegranate juice.
stroll!. this area is great to just stroll around, there are plenty of restaurants nearby and lots of shopping opportunities. The prices are not bad, and the quality is often very good!

Watch out for the thieving taxi drivers. When I got off the plane at attaturk airport I was excited. Turkey! The city everyone goes to on holiday. I waited in the queue to get my passport stamped so I could leave the airport, unfortunatley I didnt have the correct visa so had to purchase 2, 1 for myself and one for my sister. I was then waiting in line once again. I was 'knocked back' by the same rude police/immigration officer who claimed I did not have the visa stamps once again. I summoned another police officer immediatley to clarify the situation. He flicked through my passports and correctly established that me and my sister did have the correct visa stamps. He allowed us to go to another advisor who was sitting at the desk. They looked at our passports and let us go through. I stepped out of the airport and immediatley spoke to a taxi advisor wearing a yellow high visibilty top. I asked him for a taxi and instead of putting me in a taxi he told me he would get me one. The taxi operator signalled at me to follow a man who approached from the opposite side of the road. He was a plump, chubby turkish man wearing a dark coloured suit. He asked me to follow him. I was feeling very nervous at this point as this man had a gleaming smile on his face, considering me 'easy pickings' he askd me where I wanted to go. At this point me and my sister were at the entrance of a car park a few minutes walk from the airport. Another man was waiting at the entrance of the airport. I refused to allow my sister to enter. The other man was introduced as the 'hotels manager manager' he was apparently the main manager of all the hotels. I had never heard of a job position like that. I decided enough was enough and I told the men politley that my 'dad was near' and I had to go. The men wernt very pleased. I noticed a yellow taxi approach me and to remove myself from the situation of these weird men I got in. The driver seemed polite and sincere. He had broken english. I explained that I needed to go to a hotel. And I told him I wanted the price to be around 40-60.00 lira. We started speaking. We got into a deep conversation regarding the beauty of turkey. The driver asked me for my mobile phone. A black iphone 5, which i was happy to give him to enter his mobile number into. I would rather stick with one trustworthy taxi driver then go with loads of different taxi drivers. We got lost in conversation. Eventually we reached our destination, mavi onur hotel in sultan ahmet district. The fare was 43 lira (equivalent to £25.00 or their abouts) and I had 20 lira and £60.00. The taxi driver charged me 20 lira and £60.00, £80.00 in total. I did not realise I had been ripped off. My sister told me not to pay him, but being in a vulnerable situation their was not a lot I could do. I asked him for my mobile phone back and he claimed that he had given it to me back. Which he had not, if he had I would have had it in my pouch with all my important belongings. I was left feeling skrewed at the hotel as their was nothing else I could do. I could not contact the police. I did not have their number. I just took it on the chin and tried to forget about what had happened. (I later realised that the yellow taxi I got picked up from was not an official airport taxi) the hotel staff were really friendly and advised me on what tov see atch out for. I was several minutes away from sultan ahmet mosque. It was really nice. It was a shame my whole holiday ended before it actually began in turkey. I understand you should not judge a whole group of people by the actions of a minority however I would still recommend everyone to stay away from turkey and go to Muscat Oman which was my next destination. That was an experience I will always remenber for the right reasons.

The best area for visiting and do shopping in Grand Bazar. I did like everything! The area is clean,very close to Blue Mosque,Topkap and others.Also have a few street with bars and small nice restaurants.

In the heart of the old town. We stayed in the Sultanahmet area, just 2 minutes walk from the Blue Mosque, the Arasta Bazaar, lovely restaurants, shops and wonderful views of the sea. I wouldn't stay anywhere else.
there s dangerous. good view but problem is there s too much street seller.they hassle all the time. Books carpet leather too many things they sell and alwaus disturb you.it s very pushy
Great place to visit!. Great mixture of modern and ancient. Great sights, great food, great turkish coffee, grand bazaar, spice bazaar, etc. Great place to spend a couple of days.

Beware the touts!. This otherwise pleasant area with all the spectacular sights is completely spoiled by the overwhelming number of touts trying to sell you something - usually a restaurant meal, but often package tours, shawls, carpets, souvenirs, etc. My advice: See the sights, then take the tram and head to the less touristy areas (e.g. Taksim Square) and eat and shop there.

Beautiful historic and fun. This area is full of tourists but it's also very historical, full of shops and really beautiful. Be aware of over-priced shops and restaurants though. If you step away from the main strip, you find better deals.

We stayed in Sultanahmet. Such a great area to stay in and fun to walk around. VERY hilly. Children should be able to walk a lot, and adults should be able to make it up and down hills pretty well if you're lodging is in Sultanahmet. We absolutely loved it in this district.

Best place to roam about. A true family vacation. The district contains tens of huge attractions such as Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, TopKapi Palace, The Snake Monument, Byzantine and Ottoman Relics etc etc and the outclass Tram :-) All add up to make Istanbul, a most favourite tourist spot.

Cultural Blast. Istanbul really is full of colour and activity. I loved the washing hung between the buildings, the mosques and the Turkish Delight stores. We stayed in Sultanahmet District which I think highlights Istanbul perfectly. It is easy to find by tram, and you will notice the hoards of cats and trolleys selling you nuts and corn on the cob. The only this I disliked is the men to be honest- I found them very leering and disrespectful. If you are a girl cover up! I wore full length clothing and even put a scarf around my hair but at times even this did not stop me from feeling very unsafe. If you stick together and preferably have a male with you it should be fine. Oh and the tulips! absolutey sensational all around the mosques and streets when we were there near Easter time.

Feel the centuries. This is the old city. We were only here for a week so I knew we wanted to spend it here. The streets are narrow with cobblestones. There is more than enough to see and do. From the Blue Mosque to the Bosphorus Sultanahmet is the place to be especially on a first visit.

A feast for the eyes - you can't get bored here!. What a beautiful, interesting area. Cobbled streets, historic and beautiful buildings, amazing art and crafts, cafes and restaurants galore, etc etc etc. I especially loved the Istanbul happy well fed cats that were everywhere. Can't wait to go back.
Don't miss it. Wonderful area to stroll around, whether you want to shop for carpets and lamps, eat great food, or just wander the back streets of Istanbul.

Heart of Old Istanbul. We decided to stay in the Sultanahmet District, also known as the Old City, so that we'd be close to the historic sites. We were less than a 5 minute walk from both the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. Just steps outside of our hotel our street was lined with charming cafes. The food was okay. If you want more authentic, not places trying to cater to a more Westernized palate, venture out. For shopping, they will bargain a little but since the area is so populated with tourists you likely won't get the best deals in this area.Also, the tram was extremely convenient and easy to use. We took it everywhere from going to the Topkapi Palace (5 minute tram ride) to going to the Galata Tower and up to Taksim. It's only 3 Turkish Lira (or $1.50) each way. You can't beat that.Next time, I'll probably stay in the Taksim area, it's a little younger and more trendy. Plus the Hotel Marmara is there. You must try Raika, their restaurant on the top floor. The food and views are amazing!

Beware of Scams!. This place is full of turkish scammers. Especially at night! Don't go there at night, although it looks touristic but if you re alone you can easily get robbed or be offered drugs you don't ask for and then then d ask you to pay for that.This place is dangerous!

Very touristy and lots of grime, but many of the big historic spots are centered here. I wasn't hugely fond of the general area, which I walked through extensively going to all the different sights, but the sights themselves are impressive.
Stay here. The main attractions, the best restaurants and most hotels in a walking distance!Istambul is an amazing and global city, and Sultanahmet is the hot stop on it.

Fun area and a breather from central Istanbul. First of all this is a faux city, a tourist enclave that doesn't get that many locals except for the better restaurants. That said it is pedestrian friendly and a nice break from the hustle and bustle found in the streets of a huge city of 19 million. I'm not a great tourist and I don't generally like being around other tourists (rude, noisy and provincial). But somehow here in Sultanahmet it was just fine with me; almost relaxing. Yes the shop keepers will badger you and they all seem to have PhD's in psychology or mind reading. Smile and ignore them without speaking. They are efficient with their time and won't bother with you. Make jokes and otherwise engage them and you are fresh meat. They are mostly very nice, earnest capitalists but you have just a few seconds to establish the terms of your relationship so do it firmly, in good humor and silently and do it QUICKLY.

Perfect central location to stay. I loved how most of the iconic attractions are in this district. Best to get a hotel in this area. Everything is within walking distance. Grand Bazaar, Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern,,,,,, it goes on. Enjoy the quaint local cuisine, and avoid the touristy ones. You will find them, just explore. It's easy to get lost, but once you use a landmark like the Blue Mosque to locate where you are, it's easy. Transportion via the tram is direct from the airport. And trams go straight to Taksim for the nightlife as well.
Amazing. Amazing History in the area! We went to a Turkish Hamam while there an it was truly an incredible experience!
Great Great Area!. This is the area to stay in to see the major sights in Istanbul! We stayed @ Efendi Hotel which is the perfect location within walking distance to most everything you want to see.

Stay in this location. This was by far the best location to stay, eat, chill out, we travelled around most of Istanbul trying different restaurant, sights, attractions but this area was by far the best.

good place to visit. good place to visitgood place to visityou visit Istanbul should be come here and use the tunel very attractive and so nice place and I like to visit's againgood place to visitgood place to visityou visit Istanbul should be come here and use the tunel very attractive and so nice place and I like to visit's again

So much culture. So much history, what wonderful vibes, food and people. Only draw back is being a tourist as it seems that there are signs on us. But with a bit of smiling and simple hellos can enjoy to the fullest

Such an interesting area. We happen to arrive on the day of the Istanbul marathon so the streets were chaotic but we did manage to clap home those completing in around 5 and a half hours before finding our hotel. these area has some wonderful sights, fun restaurants, lovely little wooden houses, good shops and such friendly people.

great place for first trip to istanbul. This is the place to be if you only have a couple of days to spend. The major sites and markets are here. Everthing is in walking distant and if you really can trek, there are many off the beaten track places to discover. From my chat with the locals because of quickly rising property prices in this district, everything else also went up such as resto prices and hotels. Nevertheless i really enjoy my first trip to Istanbul and Sultanahmet district and it gives me just enough of a feel for this lovely city to want to go back and explore more of Istanbul.
Everyone have to see. This place is great for everyone both local and tourist.if you come in Istanbul wispy this place it worth to give a few hours. It will leave you breathless

such a cute little town. friendly people and as opposed to what we were prepared for, nobody annoys you or chases you for business!many souveneir shops, little restaurants, and good transport system!! many historical attractions!

Vibrant district close to the tourist attractions & lots of restaurants. A vibrant district in which most of the main attractions are situated. There is also a bazzar and lots of restaurants. Although be careful as the alcohol can be expensive as it is taxed quite heavily.Would recomend going to the blue mosque and Hagia Sopia early in the morning as it can get busy

Loved staying right in Sultanahmet District. We accidently landed up in this District after a botched hotel booking. What a blessing in disguise. We bought an Istanbul kart, and then we could move in and out as we please. Lots of shops, restaurants etc etc. Lucky for us it was not super busy and we enjoyed a meal every night in and around the area. It most definately get a 10 out of 10 from me!!

Busy Energetic Sultanahmet. Close to several mosques, including the Blue Mosque, Suleymaniye Mosque and Rustem Pasa Mosque. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar are in this area and are a great place to do a great deal of shopping. we only had an hour in each place but I suggest you set aside a few hours to shop in the Bazaars. expect to haggle over what you purchase but be realistic and know your prices ahead of time. Like any big city, we were always aware of pick-pockets but we weren't affected by any. Unique shopping and restaurant choices in the area. Great area to sit in a street-side cafe and people watch.

Be prepared. I wouldn't recommend staying in this place, better to find a hotel in another area.This area is probably the busiest and most crowded areas in Istanbul, lots of historic sites, museums, restaurants and hotels.You'd get annoyed by those who force you to by something or those who beg for money, I'd suggest you never respond till they're gone, because if you help/buy they won't stop asking for more!!!Visiting this place is a must in Istanbul, but put in mind that you have to be prepared for a lot of walking, I suggest starting in the morning after having breakfast and see if you can cover most of it.

visit. ideal area to tour the main sites but everything is in easy reach with trams- no need for expensive taxis or of course you can walk but take good shoes!! Loved the tiny restaurant and bars and everyone so helpful.

Good for a first visit. Wouldn't do this again as I get a bit tired of the annoying restaurants touts and the carpet and bling shops. Good to see and experience but the next time I will stay in one of the cooler and more contemporary neighborhoods in an apartment. Maybe Kakadoy or Galata. If you have never been to Istanbul and seen the major sights, stay in Sultanahmet as it is close to the majority of them. But on your next visit, branch out.

Lots of walking!. Very walkable area,with so much culture!!A photographer paradise,for sure.lots of little cafés,etc.,everywhere.very safe,and enjoyed walking and experiencing Istanbul,at its finest!!

busy and interesting. This quarter is busy with tourists and also locals. When you like shopping, negotiating, eating, drinking, good priced accomodation and good connections all around the coty with the tram, you should stay here.

Magical!. Whether you visit in springtime when tulips abound or in winter when steam rises from the carts of the kestane vendors and a hot cup of salep provides needed warmth, the Sultanahmet area is a treat for the senses. Listen to the tram bells, ferry boat foghorns, seagull cries and calls to prayer. Taste not only the chestnuts and salep but an endless variety of delicious and healthy Turkish foods. Even if you do not go inside the buildings (there can be long lines), the exteriors are still impressive (to me, the Blue Mosque is the most beautiful building in the world) and there is a lovely fountain that is especially pretty at night. Great place for an outdoor snack and people-watching, too.

Tourist haven. This area of Istanbul is very touristy. That said, there are a lot of significant attractions, and the architecture is amazing. From this area, there are multiple options public transportation wise to get you elsewhere in the city, or across the Bosphorus.

Loved it. Great, so much to see and do all in one area. It was nice to walk around and to see the locals in their great city. Felt completely safe and we spent a lot of time here just visiting the mosques and the lovely quaint shops. Some lovely restaurants in the area also

gorgeous!. Istambul is so full of amazing spots and this is definetaly one of the most importants. You can walk to every sight and the number of attractions make this area a must go! Clean, safe, works till late hours.. perfect to stay at one of the many options of hotels!
TOURISTIC OR TRUE?. goal of the most 'traditional tourist route this area offers all you may have in mind when you think of Isanbul...so TRUE or TOURISTIC? THIS is the question...

The most beautiful district in Istanbul, especially Akbiyik Street. Relaxed and the most fancy part of Istanbul; with turkish elite wooden houses adopted as a hotels; great location for chilling and sightseeing - Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cisterna, Bazaars ( Great and Spice ), Galata Bridge, Galata Tower..

Don't stay anywhere else in Istanbul. Fabulous location. We loved it.Close to everything. Great restaurants, amazing attractions and absolutely magical at dusk. So glad we decided to stay here instead of in new town. Safe to walk and we did walk everywhere. Got lost several times when we decided to explore a bit off the beaten track but never felt unsafe.

definitely recommend. beautiful area, near to all main attractions within walking distance to the blue mosque, the Hagia Sofia museum, grand bazaar, spice bazaar, but the local people are truly the heart of this district, I would always stay here if I am going to Istanbul........beautiful..oh and you should also stay at the Best Point Hotel, amazing people and history there

About Sultanahmet. well, fine area to settle, many hotels, restaurants, you'll be very close (just walk) from top sites (Blue mosque, Topkapi, Aya Sophia..). We enjoyed taking tea in some nice cafés (or rather call them Thés for so many wonderful varieties of teas and sweets you may find there. another good point is that we felt secure, at all times, early morning or late at night (00:00).
exotic and lively. This area has many of the main sights and lots of colour. It never felt threatening, even late at night.

CENTRAL LOCATION. Sultanahmet District is the place to stay when visiting Istanbul. Within its precincts are a number of excellent and idiosyncratic boutique hotels. Staying there puts you in easy walking distance of several of the must see tourist sites in Istanbul. There is also any number of local restaurants that cater well to the tourist market where the food is good, the prices are reasonable and the service is friendly.

Go to the egyptian bazaar..!!!. All the places in Konstantinoupoli are great and you have to walk a lot to enjoy everything..do not forget to go to the Great bazaar and also Egyptian, where you will find all the spices you may wish for your cooking..!!!..and after all the historical center take the boat and go to the other side where the east city lives...in a different world...
Great atmosphere. Great atmosphere, despite the humid weather it was worth the visit. Lots to see and nice people to meet.

Essential for those who want to see the "Big Three". This district has the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Grand Bazaar. Stop in the Pudding Shop for a quick bite. Visit the Cisterns. Plan to spend the better part of a day exploring this rich district.

Best place in Istanbul. We stayed right in the heart of Sultanahmet, and were absolutely blown away by the place. The attractions are all in close proximity, and the square is the hub of activity between locals and tourists! The atmosphere is buzzing - everybody is friendly and helpful, of course being the main tourist area there are locals selling tours etc but if you say no once they generally left you alone, very polite.Don't forget to explore the small streets around the square too, there are some lovely hidden gems.Brilliant!

A busy place with lots to do!!. This place is full of restaurants, shops, cafés and hotels. There are many restaurants on the Main Street. Lots of the restaurants have roof terraces as well. There are lots of people selling things on the street like juices but I would avoid these due to hygiene. If you want to buy something from the many markets or shops remember to hackle as this works very well. Also beware if the many people on the streets calling you into their shops and restaurants. They are very persuasive but friendly at the same time. They will try to engage in general conversation to persuade you to visit their business. There are many dogs on the streets and plenty of cats too in search of food, if you sit in one of the restaurants with an outdoor area you will definitely have a cat around you crying for food. The street was safe and both myself and husband walked around the area comfortably during the day and night!

The Best in Istanbul. If you want a good place to stay in Istanbul, this is the right one! Restaurants, shops, bazaar, the main attractions within a walking distance and the unmissable view of the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia iluminated at night!

Nice place to explore. Look for nice small cafes and restaurants and you may find what you like. Along the final days of our visit, we were craving for some Chinese food and indeed we found one Chinese restaurant. Food was average but it is a good option just to reset those taste buds from eating kebap and all.

The place to be in Istanbul. This area of the city is the old district, with most of the sites you will want to experience. There are many small hotels and lots of great restaurants within walking distance of the major sites. There also is an over-abundance of jewelry and carpet stores with very polite but persistent owners - watch out if you want to return home with your money still in your wallet!

Best place to stay first time to the city. Definitely the best spot to stay during your first trip to Istanbul! Close to all major historical sites, as well as the bazaars. Lovely area, with mixtures of ancient buildings and new ones. Despite the crowds it must get, the area is very clean! Always people trying to sell you a tour or something, but a small price to pay for the convenience of this amazing location! So much to learn, see and do! Favorite part of the city, at least thus far after trip one!

We love narrow streets and different shops. Yes, most of the shops are restaurants (or it felt that way) but it is just charming. There is a little of everything to see in this very old neighborhood and be sure to have a fresh squeezed glass of pomegranate juice for a pick-me-up as you wind your way up and down the steep streets.

Full of culture and history. Had an amazing time staying in Sultanahmet. We stayed at the Kalyon Hotel which was superb. Lots of sightseeing including the Blue Mosque, The Aya Sofya and lots of tours available for the bosphorous. Very close to grand bazaar, spice bazaar and lots and lots of very good restaurants! The locals are very friendly and helpful. A place anyone would enjoy to visit.
Lovely area. Really enjoyed staying here, walking through the cobbled streets and visiting shops, mosques and museums.

Explore all the side streets. Being a world heritage site, the whole area retains it's old world charm. The Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace are all must see's but there is a lot to explore throughout the area.

buzy sightseeing. everyone should see once in their lives. If you love the city you are in a busy place. The Turks are very nice, listen to you and curious. your every wish fulfilled. This district is clear, everywhere you find nice restaurant, which is not expensive, or you can eat some delicious fast food or you also can eat in the street corn, shellfish or türkish bakery products. but is think corn is not so fine. In sultanahmet district you can visit lots of historical attraction and you arrive max10 minutes by walking.

So much to see and learn.... Sultanahmet is the area where most of the tourist attractions are concentrated. Tram line, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Hagia Sofia, Basilica Cistern, a short tram ride to the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar, it's all here. You'll find that Istanbul, like Rome, is built on seven hills, some of them very steep, Everything always seems to be uphill from wherever you are at the moment. Don't know how they managed that. <grin>

Can't be missed!. Experience the real atmosphere of this beautiful city. Beside having all the main attractions to see, there is so much more… Gulhane Park with a lovely tea house overlooking Bosphorus, the fabulous Caferaga Medresesi gallery and school hosting workshops for all traditional Turkish arts and the buzz of all the markets. An absolute gem!

A Turkish Delight. I traveled previously to Istanbul in 1986 and 1988, so it was a welcome visit to one of my favorite places in Europe or Asia. The Sultanahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque) is a magnet and draws you to it, a very spiritual place because it is still a practicing mosque. There is excitement even when they have to send you away when prayers begin. There are options, i.e. the Hippodrome, the Cistern, Topkapi, the Haghia Sofia - just wandering around the neighborhood and even to the waterfront. The district has retained its flavor over time - rug sellers still offer apple tea, prices have not escalated as much as other cities, people are friendly and even the dogs and cats are well mannered. I am a female and felt very safe the entire time I was there.
Best Place to be. If you want to be where all the action is, this is it. Great area of the wonderful city of Istanbul.

Fantastic sights but way too touristy. Positives: many of the main tourist attractions in Istanbul are in or near Sultanahmet, including the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, the Cistern, and the Grand Bazaar. It's easily accessible from the airport using a shuttle or public transportation, and there are lots of dining and accomodation options within close proximity.Negatives: very touristy and relatively expensive. Of course you expect a place to be touristy when you've in the tourist district, but as a woman traveling alone, I found that many of the vendors and restaurant personnel were so pushy that it actually bordered on aggressive. Several men working at restaurants near the Grand Bazaar actually blocked my path so that I couldn't pass and kept blocking me until I finally rudely told them to move. Similarly, other vendors "introduced themselves" by shaking my hand and wouldn't let go of it for 30 seconds or more while they attempted to convince me to buy something from them. Finally, everyone who claimed they wanted to practice their English with me actually just wanted to sell me a rug. As I said, you expect the place to be touristy, but when you're approached by people in this kind of aggressive or pushy way 15 or 20 times per day, it's way too much.

Great time. Very easy to walk to all the sites. Traffic in Turkey is chaotic by north american standards. Dangerous for pedestrians. Practically no stop signs...as for lights, well they are not always respected.We spent 3 days exploring this neighbourhood of Istanbul and were not dissapointed. The history, the architecture, the people left us with the will to go back another time.

One of my favourite places. The Sultanahmet district of Istanbul is a wonderful mix of history and modern life, although some of means by which work is done still is not modern. There are numerous amazing sights and lots of good places to eat and drink.

Wonderful. The area is obviously the main tourist hub and very much caters to tourists. You certainly won't experience much of the 'real' Istanbul here. However, it has so many wonderful sights, shops and restaurants, it was a delight to wander around.

Top Sites. If you only have a day you could see all the top sites here; albeit it will be a long day. The Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Hippodrome and the Basilica Cistern are all close together. The Grand Bazaar is just a stroll away, followed by the Spice Market. Lots of restaurants and shops too. The tram stop is Sultanahmet and the trams are easy to use. Of course there are many other great sites to see but if you are pressed for time, this is the area.

what an amazing place. Sultanahmet is a great place full of culture and history. the food in the streets is wonderful [especially as you travel away from the main sites]. Always use a meter for taxi travel.

This is the place to be at Istanbul. I am a tourist , for sure I got to be here to see all the attraction . Shops, restaurant plentiful . Local street food, dessert shop , Turkish ice cream everywhere . Got all my souvenirs here . Been there and done that the Turkish haman , taking the metro , sight seeing all here in Sultanahmet .
Sultanahmet. Many of the main attractions are in this area. The Blue Mosque, basilica Cistern, hippodrome, Haghia Sophia, Museums.

Magical Mystery Tour. This is what wandering around this bit of Istanbul feels like. Magical: some of the unexpected and striking views opening round nondescript street corners, the rich layers of past civilizations competing for your attention, the smells and sounds (particularly at prayer times) of the old town. Mystery: the lack of street name signs in the area south of the Aya Sofia/Blue Mosque which makes finding any particular place impossible in the dark if you are adventurous and want to walk for more than 10 minutes, like we did. It this a way a making sure that Istanbul taxis find customers every evening? or to increase the sense of achievement if/when you do find the restaurant you were looking for? Or did the municipality run out of cash when it got to this area? we will never know, but be warned. Of course the unwanted restaurants you pass by will do their best to grab you off the street ,when you start to look tired and confused and your feet are beginning to falter. Do enjoy the big sights during the day, visiting the Aya Sofia, the Cistern, the Hyppodrome, the Millenium pillar, the Blue Mosque are "musts" on a first visit, before you take the tram down to Eminonu and catch the brilliant ferry up the Bosphorus.
mostly it is about Sultan Ahmet mosque. The mosque is the icon of istanbule, you can't complete your visit to Istanbule without visiting this maginficant old mosque

Disgusting... You feel like a tourist waiting to be butchered. You can't step one step in the Sultanahmet district without being annoyed to death by people trying to sell you stuff. It is really, really, really annoying.
Sultanhamet. Brilliant area, Hagia Sophia, Blue mosque, Basilica Cistern, grand Bazzaar, spice Bazzaar - fantastic, must see, loved it.

Don't miss the streets around the bazaar. We walked down to the Galata bridge from up alongside the Bazaar late Sunday afternoon as the street stalls were closing....cobbled stone streets, last minute purchases of sox, men's trousers, girls' dresses being purchased by the locals. Loved it.
Really nice area and lots to see!. We loved this part of the city. There's plenty to see and you don't have to walk far to see the sights. The salesmen do hassle, but just ignore them.

Lovely area!. Though we did not stay in this district, we stayed in Beygolu, which we liked as well ,we spent most of our time here, reason being that most of the main sites are here ....within minutes away from one another, plus it is a lovely area...vibrant area:) i think I would recommend this area for first time visitors.

Tantalising all the senses. The Spice market is well worth a visit,just hang on to your belongings,the smells and colours of this market are like nothing else I've experienced,fantastic,when you exit the other side,your in the shopping centre,very busy with narrow cobbled street,lots of beggars with children trying to make you feel sorry for them,felt a little threatens at times.
So much to do and See. We are so glad we booked a hotel in this area. There were so many historic sites within walking distance. there are plenty of restaurants too.

People watching. We spent a week in Istanbul and toured all the top sites at our leisure. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district and had a lot of time for causal strolling and people watching. I am so glad we stayed there as opposed to in town. Most everything was in walking distance and for the rest we rode the tram. We had a guide for one day, and then our guidebooks were our leaders.
Shopping Experience. great shops, good options to choose from and for a shopaholic, a place where you will have to control your wallet :)

sightseeing. this is a place where most of tourist attraction are gather in Istanbul. you won't missed one of them, since it worth to visit with their own history. easy access via tram or freely walking. plenty of choice from fancy to local cafe, or if you simply choose burger king or starbucks and expect a busy day (get the sit won't be challenge though). there are a lot of money changer ( but you really need to look the currency, and better get from the bigger money changer) a lot of souvenir shop with bargain price a long the way and especially when you reach grand bazaar. expect to chill and relax at topkapi palace garden with a lush garden and try for tea garden on top where they offer Turkish tea with bosporus facing you.

True Turkish Experience. We spent so much time shopping. They have amazing scarfs, jewellery, and sweets! The shop owners are so friendly and they tend to offer you a taste of the sweets they sell. But dont fall for any price any shop owner offers you.. always bargain for cheaper prices. Also dont forget to have a tea break in one of the cafes were you sit on little stools and watch people pass by. I suggest you be careful with your belongings and stay in a group as it is very crowded in there and there's a good chance for thieves to practice some pocket picking or purse snatching. Nothing like that happened with us but people advised us to do so and its always better to stay safe then sorry.

A wonderful Tourist Place. I think , Sultanahmet district is the best place to stay in Istanbul, because it is the centre of a number of most famous tourist spots of Istambul. Hagya Sophiya ,Topkapi Palace , Blue Mosque, Bessilica Cistern, Grand Bazar all are within walking distance around 10 to 15 minutes walk. So , to me one should stay in this District , but for those who loves to nstay in a Grand luxury type hotel , for him/her this is not an ideal place . Most of the hotels in this district are not that much spacious compared to other places and the room rent are comparatively higher.

Historical streets. It is very magical place.. Everyone who visits istanbul must visit there and feel the history ... Amazing but should be careful about pickpockets :( also after evening women should not walk alone in quiet neighbourhoods..

Vibrant District!. Our hotel was in the Sultanahmet District. Even though this district is clearly for tourists, it is absolutely worth the stay because most of the famous historical sights are in this location. Folks can walk, ride, whatever mode of transportation suits their particular needs best is available to see this colorful and rich in history part of the city. No matter your budget, there will be a place that is acceptable to your wallet. Not only are the sights close by, but there are so many restaurants to choose from, shops to purchase curios, anything one night have need of that is readily available.The only difficult part of this district we had was finding a hotel with a lift. We had an older person with us that needed one to help make her stay a better one. With much research, we were able to find one. So whatever your needs, do your homework and you will be glad you stayed in the Sultanahment District of Istanbul.

The best place to walk in Istanbul. This place is like you mixed Europe , Middle East, Asia all in one place.its very nice to walk there and have a meal in one of the great restaurants in front of places full of history and storiesits very elegant, romantic and classical walk at night especially.

Great location. There are so many historical places in this location that one can spend several days visiting them. There are many places for food, souvenir purchases and experiencing the life in this area.

THE place to stay in Istanbul. Really, if you are in doubt where to stay in Istanbul, definetely come to Sultanahmet district. Not only because its very convenient to visit most of the biggest attractions in the European side of the city. The atmosphere is also incredible. It made me fall in love for this city in the very first day. You can spend some quality time just by walking in this place.

Wonderful experience. I fell in love with Istanbul the minute I arrived at my hotel, the White House in this colorful district.I have to heartily disagree with reviewer who found it "a filthy, dirty, tourist trap. I found the area cleaner than Boston or NYC, public wc's were cleaner than turnpike rest areas. In addition, I found an abundance of terrific restaurants. Granted, the Grand Bazaar is a bit much and I only spent a short time (I thought I might be lost for a week inside), but the Spice Market is a must. Also, do not miss the Basilica Cistern built in 532. My favorite experience was the Turkish Bath. Pure bliss after two days of walking. I traveled alone and found Istanbul and the old district not only safe but I had a great time bantering with the Turkish, vendors and people. Can't wait to return.

If you haven't been to this part of the city, you haven't been to Istanbul.. We picked a hotel in this area and it was the best thing we ever did !! All tourist attractions and historical sites are a walking distance, wherever you go you are surrounded by shops, bazaars, street vendors, restaurants and cafés. Getting around is so easy, by taxi, tram or even walking... there's always something to do or see.A Bosphorus cruise is highly recommended, also the hop on hop off bus is easily accessible.I personally believe that this place is the heart of Istanbul, your trip would not be complete if you haven't been to this part of the city.

Must see..... We were only there for one day but everything is so close together you can walk from each site (hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophie, etc). I must say from all the places that I have visited this was by far one of the cleanest places. So much to see so little time, you definitely need to have at least a couple of days to really experience everything this wonderful place has to offer.

Amazing selection of goods of good quality - especially for jewelry. Especially I liked the grand bazaar, I heard it is about 4000 little shops inside there, structured like a matrix of roads and pathways, for me rather like a labyrinth. Truly amazing, hence a bit touristic except for some things that even locals buy here, jewelry, cause here is the biggest competition.

A excellent part of the city!. I stayed in this part of the district and it is just beautiful. A diverse mix of small back-streets where cars seem to be a commodity rather than the necessary. This is completely juxtaposed with the bustling streets full of cars and street vendors. There was also a mini-modernised Bazaar that you can enjoy with many different types of shops ranging from Handbags to Tea Spices. There are also good transport links on the T1 tram-line which goes all the way in to the suburbs to BAĞCILAR and across the Golden Horn to KABATAŞ (where you can get F1 - the Funicular line.)A lovely part of the city.

Excellent stay. Sultanahmet was great area to stay as it was within walking distance to all the historical sights, lots of shopping areas and plenty of great restaurants to chose from. Loved the atmosphere with lots of tourists. Lots to see and would recommend the Bopharous Cruise. Very easy to get around and lots of areas to explore all within walking distance.

Filthy, dirty and a tourist trap. We stayed in this area. What a dump. The mosque wailing constantly, coupled with rain and filthy streets didn't make me want to jump for joy! The attractions are absolutely within walking distance, just keep your eyes down and don't look around too much in between. lol. I was tired from a long trip and this was not ideal at the time. Stay across the river and catch a cab over for a visit for the day- then run back! And watch the sun set over the river from a decent restaurant on the safe side- you don't see the dirt that way!!

Great restaurants. This street in Sultanahmet was perhaps one of the busiest in numbers of restaurants and hotels. It also had shops selling many items including souvenirs, carpets, etc. however it is the sheer number of restaurants that makes it so unique.

Excellant Scenery. I love Sultanhmet area as there is so much to see , all historical sights are with walking distance ( Blue mosque, Topaski Palace, Haiga sofia etc...) Plenti of shops , amazing restaurants etc..Extremely safe and plenty of tours available. I recommend the Bopharous Cruise ( 2 Hours) ....Love love Sultanhmet..Just 1 metro stop and tram from Taksim Square very easy and cheaper than cabs at 35 to 40 liras for the trip...Will cost you 3 liras only

Only place to stay. We loved the area, so old and so close to all the main attractions, highly recommend the area. Tram line close, so able to move around freely at small cost, and quicker, as can be traffic moving very slowly.

Miles and one nights. The European side of Istanbul is a touristic place, it gathers the most important monuments of Istanbul, such as the blue Mosque, Ayasofia, Topkapi palace, or Galata tower. All these very important monuments are situated in a very famous district called Sultanahmet, in the name of the sultan of the Ottoman Empire Ahmet the I St. The first time I arrived in this district I was really surprised because it was really crowded, full of tourists,shops, restaurants and transports. In this district we can feel a real disorientation and above all the domination of the oriental culture.When you walk through the streets of Sultanahmet you can enter to these candies’ shops and taste their products. You can also smell the smell of Narguile and tea in all the streets.

Fun, Entertaining, and Full of Options. The Sultanahmet District is a must visit. There are so many historical sites all in walking distance of each other...The Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, and the Aya Sophia. Also there are so many restaurants that cater to any tastes you can't starve.

Great for walking around - but careful of the tourist-traps. It IS a great neighborhood and no visit to Istanbul is complete without walking around in Sultanahmet area. This is where you find the palace, the blue mosque (and lots of other mosques for that sake), the aya Sophia, the bazaar, the... you got it. Apart from the major attractions I loved the neighbourhood, you can walk around safe and once you just allow yourself to get lost a bit you will find interesting side streets, food (and tea) for half price and friendly and curious people. I would not recommend staying in this area as it is really touristic and you risk not seeing much of the "real istanbul". The whole area is "walkable", so no need for taking taxis/public transport here, but wear comfortable shoes!

Free for most sights. Although you have to pay for Topkapi and Aya Sofia admission, the other areas of the Hippodrome and the Blue Mosque are free and well worth a stroll. But, except for early morning (ie. sunrise) it is crowded.

Replete with history and charm. What an incredible experience, to stand on sites where Suleiman the Magnificent walked, the Romans raced, the Crusaders invaded.... The area streets were very clean. My only criticism was the number of stray cats, though not as great as in Athens Greece, for example, excessive nevertheless. The shops are very nice- and please note that one is not expected to pay asking price. The salesmen were a bit aggressive, but never did they invade my private space nor insult me. If I refused to respond to them, they essentially left me alone once I passed. Beware of the question" Where are you from," as once you tell them that you are from New York, Ft. Lauderdale or Kalamazoo Michigan, they will respond that they have a cousin who lives there... and please come and visit their uncle's shop. Every salesman has a relative in every city in the U.S. and Canada! Yet again, no one was rude or threatening. I as a single woman felt comfortable walking the streets. And the history that one sees, feels, experiences is absolutely fantastic!
WOW. Loads to do in this area People are friendly and the atmosphere is always bubbly & live. Would recommend for a visit if you are away on Holiday in Turkey
Post cruise visit. Very pleasant and busy area, we travelled there by taxi from cruise terminal as uncertain how long it would take. Interesting g to see all the famous buildings.

THE district to stay in Istanbul. Jammed packed with botique hotels and within walking distance to all the important sites of Istanbul. Wear comfortable walking shoes that have good support. The streets and sidewalks are cobble stones and marble slabs that can be slippery.
Lots to do in this area. Lots to do in this area- Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Basilica Cisterns, lots of restaurants. A good restaurant in the area is Albura Kathisma and another one is Siva Cafe
Nice of course must see. Waw.. Impressive place where east meets the west.. islamic areas are sooo nice.. And must see the nice architecture

Love this place. Sultanahmet is an excellent place to live if you are visiting Istanbul. The hotels are a bit expensive but there are tons of choices so make sure you pick something which suits your taste and the budget.

Absolutely alive. The old city is amazing. It has a blend of everything. Sites, restaurants, hotels and shopping. Easy access to everything. With metro running to all areas in the district. Many places within walking distance. Absolutely loved it.

Very relaxing place. Very relaxing place as there is no car passing the street and it's a quiet location. Suppose a historical place with no car around and people taking photos and talking and walking.

Love it!. History, old buildings, restaurants, cafes, small hotels, shops, busyness, all contribute to the wonderful vibe of old town. Love the busyness and crowds - definitely for people who love the buzz of Istanbul. Very walkable, never boring, with always something of interest as you walk the main streets, tramlines, or mosey through the back streets and alleyways discovering something new.

Could stay there all day.. One of the best places to stay on Istanbul. The place captures the essence of the old city with its bazaars and old buildings. Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia and Sultan Ahmet are located at a walking distance, with a park and restaurants in between making it a top of my list of Istanbul areas.

Awesome place. My husband and I stayed in the Sultanahmet District for 6 days last week. It was an excellent place to stay and it was very easy to get around to the sites (many within walking distance). Quite easy to go across the Bosphorus Straight onto the Asian Side of Istanbul and also very easy to go across the bridge over the Golden Horn (the inlet dividing the European side of Istanbul).We hope to go back to Istanbul one day, and if we do we will certainly be staying in the Sultanahmet District again. We felt very safe and everyone is so friendly.

nice area. Busy and bustling area of the old city, our hotel was here and we were in the middle of all the sights, Literally 10 minutes walk to all the major attractions. Lots of shops in the side streets and the tram line is convenient. Love this area.
Everything in one area. A good district with all of the mains sights a short walk away. The tram ride through the middle and easy to access if you do not feel like walking.

Unbelievable area, so alive both Day and Night. This is an area that is rich in History, so many places to visit, so much to do. Great eateries, and make sure your camera has plenty of capacity. Beware of the Rug sellers as they are everywhere and great at trying to get you into thier shops. Make sure Taxis have meters, ask for approximate cost for going to your destination. Note the taxi nnumber, and watch the meter isn't tampered with by driver.

HEART OF THE OLD CITY. It is the center of all the big attractions in Istanbul. It is very walkable. Many places to eat and have coffee including a Starbucks. St. Sophia, Tokapi Palace, underground cistern and many mosques are here as well as the Grand Bazaar.I recommend staying in a hotel here to be in the center of the activity of the old city as opposed to Taksim SQ. which is far away.

Excellent Place - Sightseeing and bargains. Stayed in the Hotel Daphne in the heart of this district. Very close to the Blue Mosque, The Cistern, Hippodrome and Topkarpi Museum. A short five minute walk to the Spice and Grand Bazaar. Full of restaurants serving delicious food and at very affordable prices. Great views from all the roof top restaurants, who always seemed pleased if you pop in only for a beer or two. Go for the local Efes - smooth and refreshing after a hard day haggling in the Bazaars.

The place to stay for culture, not for nightlife. Let´s be extremely clear about it. This area of the town is as full with once in a lifetime sights as it is full of hotels and tourists.That means: Rooms are abundant and comparatively cheap and often with a bit longer stay hotels offer some extras as a free airport transfer. Organizing anything touristy will be pretty easy as there are dozens of agencies around. On the other hand, food and drinks do come at a premium (though the quality general is good).And if you stay there you have everything within walking distance or within two tram stations.On the other handm it is often crowded and the more or less reckless way of driving meets the streams of tourists. Many nice sights are missed due to the big attractions.And if you are a party goer and like to club or dance. Sorry, this is not the area for you to book a hotel. It takes some time, money, and walking to get to the hip areas. btw, generally guided tours do take lunch break and the main atrractions become comparatively empty.

Lots Happening. This area is awesome.It is a happening area.Lots of shops,restaurants and with in easy walks to the major tourist attractions.Also right on the tram line.We loved this area and feel it is a don't miss area when in Istanbul.

great neighborhood to stay and eat. A very handy location for seeing Istanbul's sights, lots of good hotels and restaurants. The main street in the area can be overwhelming with all it's restaurant "barkers" but they are good natured and not so pushy...
Exciting. Great area to stay in. Exciting, always something happening, great restaurants and attractionsEverything is within walking distance.

Lovely area of Istanbul. We stayed in this area and loved it. It was close to the tram and historic locations. Near Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Spice Bazaar and the Grand Bazaar. Restaurants were plentiful and you could walk anywhere and feel comfortable.

2nd Istanbul trip...16 years later. I very much enjoyed the Sultanamet area of Istanbul, lots of historical sights, friendly people, good food and most sights accessible on foot or by tram. Be ready to banter in the bazaars and with shop vendors, enjoy the roadside roasted chestnuts and sweet corn. Only dislike was the amount of day trippers from the cruise ships which put the historical sites on overload. much busier than my last visit 16years ago.

Fun, lively, cultural Turkey. My wife described it best. It's Egypt and Italy coming together in one awesome district. You can really see the european and arab world come together and meshing quite well.
Great place to stay. Can't beat this location if you're staying in Istanbul. Lots of interesting things to see and do. Be sure to use the Turkish bath near the Four Seasons Hotel.

Home to 3 top Istanbul Attractions. This historic area is the home of the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace, important sites of Istanbul and not to be missed. The Blue Mosque is an active mosque so entrance is limited during prayer times. Located on the Bosphorus Strait, all sites are within walking distance of each other.

A place I called home. One of the things I enjoy most when I travel is just being able to wander around aimlessly. I was able to do just that in the Sultanahment District in my four day stay. I got very settled in the area with just the four days I was here. This area is close to all the major attractions, short walking distance to many others (Grand Bazaar Old Spice Market,) and the rail station stop is also nearby making for easy access to other parts of Istanbul (Galata Tower,Taksim Square..) If there were any negative aspects, it would be that the area is saturated with tour agencies and I could not walk anywhere with someone trying to sell me something whether I was alone or in a group. (Though they were more persistent when I was by myself.) Next time I'll think to wear earphones so I won't be bothered as much. With that said, most locals that talked to me in the area were very polite and generally pleasant to talk to.I was able to find nice place to sit down for the evenings at one of the hostel cafes/restaurants at Akbyik Cd. which was around the block from the Metropolis Hostel where I was staying at. Never a dull moment in my stay for sure!
The old city. We loved staying in the old city as well as sightseeing and eating. The remarkable ancient sites were only a few seps away

"Free" guides come at a cost, but can be worth it. First, let me say that we thoroughly enjoyed many of the top sites in the Sultanahmet district. It is jam-packed with beautiful and fascinating historical buildings and activities. We just spent 6 weeks touring Eastern Europe, starting in St Petersburg and working our way south, and Istanbul was easily our favorite place.Referring to my headline: When you get off the Tram in Sultanahmet you're likely to be approached by someone offering advice or even "free" guide service. We knew going in that this would happen, but we liked the guy that came to us and offered to take us through the Blue Mosque "and end with a stop at my carpet store... no obligation!" So we took him up on it. Turns out he was very knowledgeable, helping us circumvent lines and then, once inside, giving us the level of detail and background on the place that we had paid for in previous cities. Once we finished, we went to his nearby shop, where the "closer" took over, at which time our guide faded away. We sincerely looked at several carpets and we were willing to buy, but none suited our tastes or budget. The salesman tried pretty hard to get me to commit, but I knew to not even put a price out there that I would be willing to pay. He soon realized he would not make a sale. Total time spent was maybe 20 minutes. Because we had the right attitude and held our ground it was actually kind of fun, and has become another experience of a great trip.
