Fun to walk around. Very touristy but fun to walk around and check out the people etc.There are vendors all over the streets, crazy traffic. You will be approached to buy things all the time. If interested start below 50% and be willing to walk away.

Steeped in history. A great area to visit, with unbelievable mosques, the underground cistern, fabulous cafes and restaurants, great boutique hotels, wonderful views and much more.The Government has made it more pedestrian friendly recently as well. TOugh if you're driving but great for sight-seeing!

Derinkuyu Underground city Turkey(close to Capodoccia). It is an am amazing place to visit. The ingenuity of the people who dug these underground cities was truly astonishing. Makers of Raiders if the lost ark rolling boulders to block a cave entrances must have got their ideas from here. There are many other underground cities beside this one and the nearest is seven Kilometres away connected by an underground passage.This underground tour is not for the faint hearted or large people and definitely not for claustrophobic people.

A great neighborhood. We stayed in Sultanahmet during our visit. It was within walking distance to Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapi. There were quite a few restaurants and shops very close by. We really enjoyed it.

Nice to walk , ok to shop. Nice safe area to walk but be prepared to be ',welcome in '' in each restaurant and boutique . Too bad the quality of some of them is not as up to the efforts they make getting you in ...
Very friendly distric. Perfect place to stay lots a very friendly neighbourhood with a bohemian flair there are very nice shops, fashionable bar and restaurants and boutiques hotels

Best part of Istanbul!. The Sultanahmet district really is the best place to stay and visit in Istanbul,so many places to see and such a lot of history.Easy to walk around as so many interesting places are in this general area.The Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market are close together and just behind the spice market is the chance to eat fish in bread straight off the boats,cooked on board at the wharf,wonderful.This is the place to mingle with the locals and really enjoy that experience.Great tram system,easy to get around if you don't want to walk.I would have loved more days here.

life. The vibrance and hustle bustle of this square fills you with cheer and zest. it is impressive and you are filled with a sense of fullfillment as it has a complete experience to offer. it has history, food, shopping, feel of the city overall leasant experience

Like stepping back in time!. Stay in the district and you'll have history, food, entertainment at your fingertips. Even the people watching is fabulous. Lots of sites closed on different days...plan carefully!
Walking. Loved the atmosphere. Totaly safe. Never felt threatened or in danger from pick pockets. Could roam around this neighborhood for weeks and not get bored!!

Great area to stay. Everything is in walking distance such as Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. Good local food easy to find. Many small hotels. Hop on Hop off bus stops here as well

Beautiful historic district. This small area is packed with beautiful buildings with so much history. The local community obviously take great pride in their locale, as the streets and cafes are bright, clean and well kept. Most attractions are within walking distance of each other. Great place for a short get-away.

We loved it!. Loved the mix of old and new, had a nice vibe and the city hums along. The restaurant areas are great, open air eating choices and food quality is very good. I could go on and on, but visit and find out for yourselves.

History at its best. Just loved this area. Rich in history and a wonderful atmosphere. Wonderful sightseeing. Excellent restaurants. Our hotel which had a view of the Blue Mosque and also overlooked the Bosphurus was a gem.

Amazing & Beautiful!!. Ok so if your family is like mine they've probably told you that Istanbul is super conservative and that if you're a woman your going to have to damn near be covered from head to toe. Well I'm hear to tell you NOT!!! Honestly this area remindse of the meat packing district in New York. But it's just that you get to walk by artifacts. But over all I love the mix of ancient treasures with modern elements. Also the transportation is simply to die for. And people are super helpful and nice and the night life is amazing. But as with traveling to any place use common sense. Don't walk down dark alleys alone, let people know where you're going and who you're with. But most of all enjoy your time here. I loved it and plan on buying a house there soon. So who knows I may see you around. :)

ISTANBULS TOURISM CENTRE. The ideal place for tourists to stay close to all major tourist spots its location is ideal eateriesbars moneychangers hotels walking distance to most of tourist spots tramways buses availablecheaper options available for tourists to see other places hop on n hop off buses ferry bookings cost cheaper here next to hyppodrome a great place to walk nights very safe we miss this area very much.

Ideal area to stay. This area of Istanbul is perfect for tourists on a short break. Cobbled streets with plenty ofhotels, bars, restaurants and souvenir shops. It has a lovely laid-back feel about but is onlya short walk from the hustle and bustle of the main areas and attractions. The buildings are original and colourful with many flowers. Very few cars drive around this area so it is very quietand non-threatening.

Great area to stay in. Istanbul is such an enormous city I was glad we were based here with so many important sites. We had a coach as we were a group - hats off to the drivers - but you could easily walk to many places if you have no mobility issues.

Exciting with lots of local flavour. We decided to break our Istanbul stay into two different parts..On one leg of our journey we stayed at Taxim and the other leg we decided to stay in the Sultanahmet District. This was the best decision we made.It gave us the flavor of both parts of Istanbul.The Sultanahmet district is good for sightseeing as all attractions are within this area.Almost all the top attractions are within walking distance. The advantage was that we went to the blue mosque 2-3 times however being friday it was shut to visitors for part of the day and also at other times prayers were going on, yet we did not miss seeing it coz we were so close we could just walk back and see it at a time convenient for us.Also all around the district all kinds of foods are available.Even other parts of town were easily accessible because of the trams and boats. Infact even spice bazaar and egyptian bazars are all close by. We could also just walk to take the boat cruise. The tram noise can get a bit annoying but not too much of a problem.All in all a good place to stay.

Nice area for tourists. Ideal place for any tourist visiting İstanbul or the first time as you are here in the heart of all touristic attractions.Hundreds of different shops,hotels,restaurants,bars,fast food shops are around this place and you can enjoy yr time in this beautiful athmosphere.

Get in with the locals. This isn't a trendy area like Beoglu but better for it - meandering streets, cay bars and friendly locals. For a city of over 20 million people, it manages to exude a village feel.

exciting sultanahmet district. we stayed for four days in this area of Istanbul in august 2013 and it is totally fantastic. Everything great about Istanbul is right here and so old and fascinating, full of colour and original buildings. The people are wonderful and we never felt unsafe. We walked for miles and just took in the wonderful sights, sounds and colour if this wonderful place. Divine kebabs off the street for about $5 lira or the wonderful divine mezzes and food in more expensive restaurants. The people were so friendly and we had so much fun with them. I cannot wait to go back to Istanbul and Turkey as a whole. Do not miss going to this wonderful country.

Great place to stay when in Istanbul. Lively place with loads of restaurants, juice shops, souvenir outlets. The historical attractions are walking distance. The place has the old world charm and all modern facilities. Unless you choose to party hard till late night, this is the best place to be your base while in istanbul.

A Wonderful Part of Istanbul. We stayed in this part of Istanbul for 4 days and it was perfect. It is so close to most of the major sites that you can walk to them easily. If you hate the traffic of Istanbul this is the are to stay in. They have their own smaller bizarre and have a ton of good restaurants, shops, and boutique hotels. The views from the top of our hotel was beuatiful, the water on one side and the Blue Mosque on the other. We stayed at the Ferman Hotel.

Ideal place to stay. There is no better place in Istanbul to stay if tourism is the purpose of visit to this great city. All the major landmarks are located herein and grand bazaar is not far off either. Lots of good restaurants to chose from besides shops and roadside earteries. There are no big name hotels here but there are several tiny boutique hotels offering excellent service and rates.

Nice Place. This area is nice place in the old city of Istanbul, you can find nice building like Topkapi Palace, or nice old type shops, or nice Turkish restaurant, and nice Hamam, ....etc.If you visit Istanbul, be sure that you give part on of one day at least to visit this area.
plenty of shops. the ability to haggle it is expected very quiet on sundays a lot of istanbul workers are off on sundays

Stay in this area of Istanbul. We were going to stay in Taksim but changed to Sultanahmet hotel and so glad we did. This is the area to stay in, a great area to walk around at night. Around the Blue Mosque / Hagia Sophia at disk is beautiful. Some of the restaurants are tacky but there are a couple of good ones also.
Best place to stay in Istanbul.. This is the most central and charming part of Istanbul for those looking to explore, eat and shop in Istanbul.

The oldest Mosque in Turkey.. Sultanahmet Mosque is a crown jewel in the busy' Spice ' bazaar . It reminded me of the Pyramids in 'Cairo'; resplendent structures that seem almost a part of the busy streets of Cairo, yet magnificient and compelling!The mosque is a must visit fo all those that visit the market as it is at as tones throw and is too large and compelling to give a miss!

the place to stay. It is the old city and it is recommended for staying if you have less than 5 days to visit. There are many hotels around; I've stayed at AZADE Hotel, I warmly recommend it; moreover you have all the main attractions nearby, you can visit them by walk; nice restaurants, tasty food, the best Turkish coffee.

Should be on your to-do list of İstanbul !. İt's mainly a historical district. There are plenty of museums, shops, cafes, restaurants, etc. to go to. İt's very touristic, there is a lot to see and it's definitely a must see place because of all the important historical monuments and buildings ! Like anyother area of İstanbul, it's crowded but it's still a pleasant area to go have a shoppig spree in the Bazaar. İt's better to go to this area during the week days, but keep in mind that Friday's some shops close at noon for prayers.
Easy for sightseeing. Most of the main spots (Aya Sofya, Tpikapi, Blue mosque, etc.)are in this small area. Easy for sightseeing. But guidance panels and so on are not enough

Truly alive and happening!. This is probably the place to stay if you are a tourist in Istanbul with limited time. The Divan Yolu (main street with the tram line) is littered with restaurants and shops of every kind. It's unbelievable to imagine that there are so many historically significant monuments within a stone's throw of each other. Almost all the top-rated attractions (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, Cemberlitas, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Suleymaniye Mosque, etc.) are within a couple of kilometres of walking distance. One should definitely do this by themselves on foot. It is not at all worth paying a tour operator to show you around. There are numerous hotels in the Sultanahmet area, and it makes sense to stay in one of them and go around the district.

Fascınatıng Introductıon to Istanbul. Thıs area of Istanbul ıs the lıkey fırst port of call for many vısıtors to Istanbul. There ıs an abundance of thıngs to see and do ın the area, the Sultanahmet Mosque beıng th most popular. The area can keep you busy for hours wıth the hıstorıc archıtecture, busy shops and good value restaurants there to re-fuel and rest the legs. I thınk a large portıon of one's day can be spent here, gıvnıng tıme to all the areas attratıons. Just soak ıt all ın as thıs ıs the hıstorıc area of Istanbul and a wonderful place to spend one's day.
The place to visit. Beautiful part of the city with so much history. Spend at least 2 days exploring the area. Enjoy the sweetcorn, freshly squeezed pomegranate juice and simit!
A great experience. My wife and I walked around the area a number of times and enjoyed the experience of the bazaar, nice restaurants and lots of vendors.

very beautiful place!. this area is wonderful to visit.All of the highlights are walking distance from centre of the city.Hippodrome &Blue Mosque & Hagia Sophia & Topkapi Palace.I took a day tour to see all of them was wonderful and also at night time the area is magnificent.you should stay in that area at least one night.

Busy. Loved the area
Busy but easy to walk about.
Not very disabled friendly
Felt safe even when alone .
Lots of restaurants, but some DON'T serve alcohol!

Full of all sightseeing opportunities and good restaurants. Everything is within a walking distance from tram Sultanahmet station - Ayasofya, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cisterns, Topkapi and Arasta Bazaar. There is plenty of restaurants and is safe to walk after dark to your hotel (we stayed in Hotel Seraglio).

a lot going on. This is the district we stayed in the Arena hotel located in this district. We were on only 10 minutes on foot of the main parts of the district. You are in the greatest part of the town, the most beautifull touristical things are situated here. Just keep in mind that the sellers of the shops, and the proppers of the restaurants can be a bit pushy, but then again isn't that that we all love about going on holliday, a bit of fun.

An amazing trip through culture and history. Having stayed for five days in this wonderful pocket of the world, I was transfixed by the amount of pivotal history packed in to such a small location. Would love to go back again.

Best place to be. Had two three day stays in Sultanahmet before and after a small ship cruise in the Black Sea. We also stayed two nights in the New District as part of the cruise but Much preferred the old section.

Incredible experience!. All the main attractions within walking distance (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi palace, Grand Bazaar) - a great place to stay with lots of restaurants and shops all around. Great atmosphere, very lively and safe. Loved the call to prayer, you'll hear it easily anywhere in Sultanahmet. Shahot Travel Agency helped us with our trip all around Turkey, airplanes, hotels, tours and it was a delight! They were very professional and went above and beyond to make things work around our requests. Loved the country and the people!

Recommend Staying in this Area. This area has close access to a lot of the main sites in Istanbul: Blue Mosque, Hagia Sohpia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market and much more. We stayed at a B&B - Sari Konak - which was super cute with a great view of the Bosphorus River and Blue Mosque from the rooftop deck. I'd recommend staying in this area to anyone as it's a great central location. Lots of restaurants on a really cute street - Akbiyik Street is also worth checking out - a little touristy but still a great experience.

Wonderful sights and sounds..on foot.. A great place to sink into Istanbul and absorb the shops and restaurants. Not only do you see the tourist view, you get to see how the denizens of the city live. Follow their example for places to eat and grab a quick coffee. Go with the flow and not against it and you will love this segment of the city and it's historic backdrop.

History and architecture is alive and well in Sultanahmet. It is incredible to be around all these great tourist attractions with 1700 years of incredible and varied architecture / history, and it definitely has a great atmosphere. Probably need a minimum of three full days to really experience the area. I found the area to be relatively safe no matter where or when I found my place semi-lost. Only thing you need to watch out for are “Hello friend, where are you from?” calls. Someone on every corner wants you to buy a rug or give you a cup of tea (translation: come talk about buying you a rug or giving a tour). Just best to wave at these guys and ignore them. If you want to make a large purchase like a rug, it really is best to do your research to find out who are the reputable dealers (they are usually not the ones hawking and are NOT found in the bazaars). If you want to get away from the tourists and the hawkers, head on down to the sea side for a walk along the shoreline or into the Gulhane Park… it sure was nice to meet some real locals around there and just stroll around. Now there are plenty of decent places to eat and have a drink around here, just some of the best prices and quality to be found is along the less traveled backstreets and often along with service. Also, if your into guided tours, I recommend booking a them in advance of arrival (plenty of tours reviewed here on TripAdvisor), instead of purchasing on the street. I found the guided tours helped get me adjusted quickly to all that there is to see, and since I stayed here 5-days+ I had plenty of time to go re-visit at my own leisurely pace
safe nice. just mixing with the crowds locals and tourists alike watching people move around watching the live shows outside on the big screens
wow. everything (all the main sights/venues) within walking distance - a great place to stay. St Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the underground cistern, the topkapi palace

Visitors short on time spend most of it here. The Sultanahmet district is the one near the similarly named tram stop on Istanbul's public transit line. Most of the major tourist sites in the city are accessible from here including the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, the Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, the Hippodrome, Grand Bazaar, and Spice Market. Don't miss it!

Historic part of town.... The Ayasofia mosque and Blue mosque are located here.
Make sure you go to a rooftop cafe for a good view of both!

Perfectly safe. I and a friend stayed here for four days in August; we were two women traveling alone. We walked all over during both daytime and nighttime and always felt safe. We paid attention to what was happening around us as some reviews had mentioned that it might not be as safe as one would like but we never had any problems. Our hotel was in this district and it was so convenient since we could walk everywhere that we wanted to go.

Really central. We stayed at the Neorion here. Unbelievably close to everything. The pier, the bazaar, blue mosque and most sites within a 10 -15 minute walk. Very safe and literally 1000s of restaurants.

The place to stay when visiting Istanbul!. We'd been told in advance that we should choose to stay in the Old Istanbul / Sultanahmet area when visiting Istanbul. Everything you would want to see as a tourist is within walking distance - Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, underground cisterns. If we were to return to Turkey - and Istanbul in particular - I can't imagine staying anywhere other than this central location. No car required, and steps from the metro stops, which will get you anywhere you want to go that isn't in walking distance.

Best place to stay, very lively!. If you're sightseeing in Istanbul then there's no better place to stay than in Sultanahmet. If you pick a hotel in the right place you'll be minutes walk from all the main sites, cafes and restaurants and no need to use a taxi. A nice walk or a short tram will get you everywhere you need to go.

Great Area in which to stay. Sultanahmet is the best area to stay for bars and restaurants and smaller bed and breakfast type accomodation. The sights such as Blue Mosque,Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace are located just minutes away as is Kennedy Avenue the Coast road running along the Bosphorus.
Lively!. The area is busy, busting and atmospheric. I felt comfortable being alone and the locals were extremely courteous and helpful.

The place to stay in Istanbul. We did our research from the UK and chose a hotel in Sultanahmet as our base. It is the place to stay for most major tourist attractions and an endless amount of excellent restaurants and bars.

A must for first time visitors. This district is where 90% of tourist attractions and historical attractions reside and with it are some of the best and worst aspects about it. The history, culture and attractions are great. The bad is its a bit difficult to find good true Turkish food, peace n quiet and tourist free places. There are a lot of tacky shops too. Kind of like New York City's manhattan, it has its pluses and minuses, but the sites are worth it.
one stop walking tour. All touristy places are in the same metro station. Get off the street car and you can walk to every sightseeing place on foot.

The area to stay when in Istanbul!. The best location when you're visiting all the historical attractions - not so good for shopping or clubbing though!Narrow winding street, modern trams slamming their way past you inches away, great restaurants and 10 minutes walk from the Cistern, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque.. 20 minutes walk from the Grand Bazar.. easy tram rides to all over the cityWe were with our 12 year old, so he was big enough to walk a lot.. but even families with smaller kids wont have a problem

a must visit. this distcit needs mulitple visits other wise you wont be able to cover it all, it has islamic sites to visit ( 4 majour mosques0 resturants and pastry shops and cafes) as well as shopping spots..split it on two days at least to be able to enjoy everythingread my other reviews for more details on what to do in sultan Ahmed district.

Great historical place and bazaars. This place has so much to offer, that you wonder if you have enough time to explore. My favorite part was the quaint restaurants in lanes and the historical monuments around. The bazaars are so lively and filled with tourists and vendors bargaining. It’s maddening but so exciting. I would highly recommend this place and chances are if you are Istanbul, it is hard to miss the Sultanahmet District.
Walk the streets ... and watch the world. To see the volume of people in this area whilst they view all the wonderful sites around them.... To have a meal in one of the local restaurants... all good
Old City. Close to everything we wanted to visit, Up-scale shopping readily available.Hard to get taxis; everything was so close, so they couldn't make money. Have mobility issues.
the historical peninsula. Most people forget this historical Place beneath all other exotic monuments. The cistern, located 500 feet (150 m) southwest of the Hagia Sophia.

Wonderful Historic & Tourism Area (Must See). Sultan Ahmet Area is very wonderufal with many amizing hoistoric mesuems & bulding (such as Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, Sultan Ahmet Mossque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazar, etc) . You should visit this area if you are in Isntabul. You can reach there by tram with Sultanahmet Station.
Sultanahmet district. Staying in the Sultanahmet district of istanbul was an excellent choice as there are many toursist sites located within walking distance of numerous hotels.
Recommend staying in this area. While busy, this is the area with all the main sites; the Mosque, the Tipkapi Palace, the sisterns etc. Defintely stay around here if it's your first visit.

Touristy but good for a short stay. Many of the major sights of Istanbul are in this area along with tons of hotels and restaurants. The hawkers for the Bosphorus tours get tiresome, but the proximity to the attractions and easy tram access make it very convenient if you've only got a few days.

often called the Blue Mosque. Often called the Blue Mosque, but built by a Sultan name Ahmet and is thus known locally as
the Sultanahmet Mosque. Although hundreds of years old, looks as if it was built yesterday. Quite beautiful

Great area, full of nooks & crannies.. Excellent shopping, super restaurants, and endless little streets and alleys to wander around. If you don't mind the hills there are an endless choice of things to see and do.

Great Historic District. Commercially viable, and visited by people of all over the world for it's important historic value. Yes, there are hustlers trying to see us something. To be expected when one is in this area, and not unlike Mexico or New York, or Rome, or Florence near the attractions. But, it is unique to visit, and we did it in 2 1/2 days, but didn't have time to go on the Bosporus tour, which we wanted very much to do. I loved this country, and it's people, and never felt threatened or intimidated;just eager for more historical understanding of the place where east meets west.

Very touristy but very friendly. The big plus here is that you are living/visiting perhaps the 5 most touristy spots of Istanbul within walking distance of each other. The atmosphere is just perfect, with quaint winding streets, street food, great energy, so many tourists who are friendly with each other and exchange notes happily!
All life is here!. Although a tourist centre, the area is packed with all manner of people from across the world and from all walks of life. Just wander round and soak up the energy and atmosphere.

The real Istanbul. or at least the essence of Istanbul...absolute chaos in the streets close to the bazaar, eyebrow raising historical sites such as the Haga Sophia or the Blue Mosque, fun and friendly people, good food....just get lost in these confusing little streets and go into the places as you come across them or else you risk not finding them ever again.

Do not stay anywhere else in Istanbul. The small bazaar on the way to the Mosque is wonderful. Having toured the Souks of Morocco, this place was like Neiman Marcus. There was no shouting, no pressure, and if you didn't initiate a bargaining session, you wouldn't get one. However, most of the shops will bargain with you, the average giving you the "typical" 10% - 15% off if you say you will pay cash.There are a million rug shops in the Sultanamet and everyone has an uncle with a rug store. I had great success at Galeri 97. I bought rugs here on my first day, and each day as I perused other shops I got happier and happier with my purchases, both the beauty and quality of them, and the price. Highly recommend.
Quaint area. An enjoyable area to wander around it has it all, lively cafe culture, loads to see, a great place to people watch, ALS plenty of places to just sit and watch the world go buy

lots of Tat for sale but rise above it !. Every place that has a large tourist influx will also have lots of vendors selling the very same "local" dresses, pots and pans etc... My rule of thumb,,, Will you wear it or use it when you get home..... NO.. Then dont buy it and move on..... This area has many side streets to roam and explore... I kept looking up to find many wonderful views of minerets and quite a few old christian churches.....

JOY. I loved the Sultanahmet district. There are a wealth of restaurants and coffee shops here and gift shops and jewellers to make your eyes pop. You can dine quite reasonably here and enjoy 'true' Turkish food' The historical sights are close together so it is easy to visit Hagia Sophia, Suleymaniye Mosque and the Topkapi Palace. A visit here is a real treat and the transport links are second to none.

Old city...very touristy. Whilst I enjoyed seeing the sights of the old city I found it very crowded with tourists and so all the shops were expensive and annoying with their constant yelling out to you to come buy! Same with the grand bazaar, I enjoyed the back lanes near the spice bazaar much better as these were where the Turkish people shopped and it was fascinating to see what was on offer and no one bugged me there. However probably it is the best place re a Hotel as you are within walking distance of most of the major sites and the tram is also in the Main Street.My best tip for getting into Istanbul from the airport is to organise a car transfer. It took over an hour on the Saturday I arrived and would have cost a lot in a taxi so I was relaxed knowing I didn't need to worry. Make sure you have small change available for tipping as well.

Walking distance to most sites.. We especially liked that everything we wanted to see was close walking distance.Topkapi Palace,Blue Mosque,Haya Sophia,Spice Market,Grand Bazaar and we went on a Bosphorus cruise which was lovely and relaxing,interesting to see the different old palaces and also private homes dotted along the way We found the Turkish people to be courteous and helpful with any questions we might have.Would like to go back again someday.
Lovely area of Instanbul. It was a lovely area to visit - the Sultanahmet district gave us an insight into Turkey/Ottoman culture, food, fashion, art, craft, etc. It's a nice place to stroll around.

Old part of Istanbul. Allthough Sultanahmet has lost some of its original charm in the last 10 years and has turned more commercial it stilll has to offer the unique feel of what Istanbul was like in the 19th century. The beautiful wooden fascades, good rooftop restaurants, authentic dhops and nice little boutique hotels are all in abundance here. Climb one of the rooftop restaurants and ejoy great viws of the Bosforus.

Location location. Without question the only area in Istanbul to be for a tourist.Make sure you get a hotel towards the blue mosque, hagi Sophia,. basilica cistern. They are all within 5 mins of each other.
Old City. This is the "Old City" of Istanbul. Most major sites are within walking. Recommend Erganval Hotel in this area.
Nice Area. The Sultanahmet District has many of the Tourist sights as well as plenty of Restaurants. No one visits Istanbul without going here. Enjoy?

The heart of Istanbul. Such a great buzz in this area. We ate many meals here and a number of our tours also commenced in this area. Very safe, reasonably priced restaurants and some excellent shopping.

You cannot take two steps wıthout seeıng a facınatıng sıte. The sultanahmet dıstrıct ıs the place to be ın Istanbul. One cannot take very many steps wıthout comıng upon a very ımportant hıstorıcal monument. There are huge crowds all over the area, yet ıt ıs easy to fınd all you needç

Perfect Place to stay at. i loved the place so much, as if you are living in history. the beautiful sights surrounding you and the narrow streets are so interesting to walk at.
the restaurants are nice there, however they are touristic and not cheap. most of the hotels are small family hotels with Good reputation and the area is so safe even late night.
Best Location. For all the major attractions that you will need to see, this is the best area to stay. Very safe, with lots of bars and restaurants.
My hotel experience in Sefa Hotel. I stayed in a cozy hotel that came me comfort and the distance with the Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar is so close. I enjoyed my walk to this places.
Beautiful Area. I liked this Area more than Taksim area it is more crowded with tourists. There a lot of coffee shops, restaurants and local shops.

Good for sights, less so for food. This area is crowded and busy and noisy and all of those things, and understandably so, when almost everything there is to see, is here. Most of it is pedestrianized so it's fairly easy to get around. Food was mediocre unfortunately, and they can be quite pushy about you eating there!
sultanahmet. great place to wander and look around even if travelling alone. People are helpful and friendly, most of them know English and tourist help is always around the corner.

Historic and stunning area. I loved the mosques, the large expanse of garden grounds, including water features. I enjoyed walking down the street and seeing the ancient pillars and ruins. The area also has some fantastic restaurants and people watching.
SULTANAHMET DISTRICT. Full of top-rate things to see. Very lively area if inevitably rather touristy but looking below surface gave valuable insight into Istanbul as a city.
Best location if you are interested in history. Definitely the area to stay in if one is interested in culture and history. Area is full of attractions, restaurants and very safe.
Location,location. a great district to stay in and wander with great resaurants and atmosphere especially in the evening when it comes alive.

Very lovely. It is a very lovely place to visit. While your eyes are enjoying the colorful shops, your desire to buy something to make you remember Istanbul , drags you into the shops with hospitable shopkeepers. A narrow lane with shops on the both sides keep you walking down to the end of the lane and back again. Ceramics, carpets, kelims, leather goods, pepper crashers are among the most visible items.

Love To Walk Here... This area is a must visit while you are in Istanbul. The old and the modern Istanbul are mixed together. Easy to walk to Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace etc. There are a lot of shops, restaurants to dine in here, souvenir shops, sweets and pastries shops too. Put on your comfortable shoes and enjoy your time by walking this area. It's really nice to walk in the evening...

Fun area to wander through for a day. This was a great picturesque area that has lots of great historical sites, shops, restaurants and fun & colorful atmosphere. We enjoyed wandering around here and just experience Sultanahmet.

Must Do Walk. After hitting some key sites this is a wonderful way to get a feel for the city itself. It is modern and ancient Istanbul rolled together. The displays of pastries and candies are wonderful. We stopped at several places for sweets and wandered into one of the many neighborhood restaurants for an casual and reasonably priced meal. I was impressed to see how well the locals treat cats who seem to be most every where. Best of all this walk is free.

Great to stay here if you dont have much time. We'd thoroughly reccommend a stay here at The Ottoman Imperial Hotel. Its a 1 min walk to the Aya Sophia & Blue Mosque 3 mins. Topaki Palace 5-6 mins.Great Panorama Restaurants & Byzantine Cysterns can all be done in a day- Topkapi Palace & Harem takes longer
Old Istanbul. Can easily be reached by metro and tramp, no need for a taxi, you will save a lot, especially if you were a family or a group of people.

Must see in Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the must see in Istanbul with all the historical places. For people looking for a calm and sea view hotels, it is preferred to stay in Sultanahmet, otherwise Istiklal is the place.

What a lively place!!. We really enjoyed exploring the Sultanahmet District, and its wonderful restaurants and boutiques. The whole vibe of the place was so lively. There is so much to do here, the shopping area, the fountains, the mosques, and the delicious local food. It was the best part of Istanbul for me. Living right around here would have been perfect honestly, right in the middle of the action. The food around here was amazing. The street vendors selling corn was such a great touch. This old town as it is known as offers a great cultural experience. It is surely the best place in Istanbul and not worth missing. It was a unique experience to explore this city, which is nothing like you have ever seen before. I was so glad i explored this area and We came here many times during our trip to shop and wander around, to soak in all that Istanbul had to offer. It is touristy but when you shop in the local boutique stores, it is different every time.

you want miss it cos it is impossible. definitely the best street in the old town
by walking it, you can see all the major sights,
Thousands of shops, cafes, restaurants(Burger King,McD's), boutiques, and of course, at every step-exchange office

Istanbul. If you have not been here then you have not been to Istanbul.For the tourist from one end there is the Galata bridge,Eminonu ferry terminal and Spice Bazaar.You can walk up along the tramway to the grand bazaar.All the attractions that are famous in the world and attract millions of tourists every year are within this walk.If possible stay here and enjoy the multi cultural ,multi ethnic and truly cosmopolitan city that is Istanbul.Just walking around the area gives one immense pleasure and introduces you to the delights and sounds of the ages.Many excellent hotels and restaurants are located in the area in addition to the familiar Mac,King and KFC.Enjoy.

Shop Around , Don't Waste your Money Unless you see the Area. If you are shopping for Souvenirs Walk away from the Area and Into the Sirkeci Train Station area (About 15 Min Walk) .. Every thing is 50% cheaper !!

You will love the place. Oh it's just amazing, wonderful place to spend a relaxed evening. It's a wow experience. Have been there quite a few times and always found it to be more interesting than the last visit. The blue mosque is just amazing and in evening it's beauty is increased many times. Worth a visit!!! Your visit to Istanbul is incomplete without visiting sultanahmet!!!

Wonderful Turkey. Loved staying and visiting in Sultanahmet District. Dont stay in the new town - too far from all the facinating things to see in Turkey. Vibrant, exciting and fun place to visit. Stay a few days

Dont miss this place. Sultan Ahmed is the best place in Istanbul it combines Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Zysterne and Topkapi Palace.There is also fantastic garden in this area, and variety of restaurantsYou can use the tram to reach it coming from Eminonou or from topkapi.The best time to visit Sutan Ahmed Iand other sights in Istanbul is in May to Sep.
Overwhelming!. So much history, religion, different cultures, trade, smells and people, all in one place. It's amazing but really overwhelming!!

Good base. Right in the hub of things with excellent choice of restaurants. Can be a bit heavy traffic wise - our airport taxi was late as he got caught up in traffic, but that is true of a lot of Istanbul and you just have to allow for it. All in all an excellent base.
Great walking. My wife and I really enjoyed touring the area... so much to see and enjoy. Going in April we were blessed with great weather to have warm afternoon strolls.

A Must!. Sultanahmet offers some of the top sights of the world, such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Zysterne and Topkapi Palace. Visit also the alleys around the Big Bazar where you can experience oriental atmosphere. Sultanahmet is very crowded and very touristc. Try to be early in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the worst crowd.

Stay in the historic district of Sultanahmet!. There are so many treasures to visit in this area of Istanbul, most are easily within walking distance. We visited three areas of the ciity. The Asian side is mostly residential, the Taksim area seems to be the business area with good shopping and the historic district of Sultanahmet. The latter is by far the most interesting area. Although it attracts many tourists, I also feel that Sultanahmet is the most authentic. When we return to the city (which will hopefully be soon), we will surely stay in Sultanahmet.

The best part of Istanbul. It is really one of the most beautiful places in the world. Unforgettable. I visit is again and again while coming to Istanbul and always find something new there. Better to visit in the morning: too much people day time.

So much history in this area. There are several days that can be spent here exploring all the many sights. It gives the traveler a wonderful understanding of the history of Istanbul.- from Christian to Muslim .My husband and I felt very safe and were able to walk around by ourselves throughout the day.

Best place to stay in town. It's the ultimate place to have your accomodation. All sights of the district are in walking distance, and all the other parts of the city are well connected with Sultanahmet (main tram line passing through, Eminönü port). Because it's full of tourists/people 24/7, it's very safe even at night. Before travelling there, I had been wondering about booking accomodation near the Taksim, but I'm glad I didn't do it. Sultanahmet has the vibe you can't find anywhere else.

1st class tourist district!. In addition to Hagia Sofia and the mosque, make sure to eat meat balls at Sultanahmet Kufteci because it is - in my opinion- one of the best places in the world to eat meatballs. The park, the walking path, sellers of corn and chestnuts are all a beautiful mixture for the tourist to enjoy
Don't miss this on any visit to Istanbul. Stroll through the Grand Bazaar, visit the Cisterns, and go to the Hammam across from the Hagia Sophia!

Great place to walk around/explore. This was our favorite part of Istanbul - so charming, with lots of shops and wonderful restaurants. We came here every day to explore and take in the sights and culture. Definitely recommend to anyone coming to this beautiful city!
Top location. Major attractions here.Amazing buzz at night.Lots of restaurants and shops and metro station located here.

Charming Neighborhood Filled with Restaurants and Shops. We stayed at the Armada Old City Hotel, located along the Kennedy Cadessi, which is directly across from the Bosphorous. Everyday we walked up the winding hills behind the hotel and through the Sultanahmet Disrict, on our way to the Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Gulhane Park or the Bue Mosque. We stopped for lunch a few times and stopped to shop. Next time I come to Istanbul, I plan to stay in this area again. Charming, safe, friendly!

Best area to stay in for first time visitors. Easy access to subway lines, walking distance to the major sights (Grand Bazaar, Palace, Blue Mosque, etc.). Plenty of great restaurants and this part of the city is well-maintained, clean, and always busy with tourists (even late at night) so we always felt safe.

touristy - but fun!. There are many tourists, but this is a very enjoyable area to see the historic sites and absorb the energy of the city. I enjoyed the watching interactions between tourists and the shopkeepers(just keep a sense of humor - some can be quite aggressive, but most are harmless) You can get a snack, a meal, or shop in one of the many boutiques.

Such a Vibe. We stayed in this district and felt no regrets. The restaurants are great and the shopping fantastic. Such a buzz walking around the old district. Obviously we did go into the new city during the day. However, was always great to be back across the river.

Loved it. Loved to walk in narrow streets, with eateries around. Somehow was astonished with quantity of the cats around but it was great as everybody was taking care and they feel Istanbul belongs to them. Great boutique stores around on every taste, from art to silk rugs..

Go and relax there!!. Just sitting in the middle of this district right in front of the fountain where you can see hagia sophia in front and the blue mosque behind gives you the inner peace anyone would love to have. You can drink turkich chai, fresh juices, local simit and different types of local delicious snacks. I loved walking in it, sitting in it and definitely relaaaaxing in this great place :)

Worth visiting, but touristy. I'm glad we did not get a hotel in this area as it's super touristy...but it's certainly worth a visit as almost all the main attractions are in this area and it's a very walkable district.
Great place to wonder. Great place to spend day wondering around. Seeing Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, the Mosques and people watching.
Best area to stay in. This area has all the major sites mostly within walking distance. If you are going to Istanbul for the first time, best to stay in this area.

amazing. best thing was how clean they keep it despite the huge number of tourists. You can't go hungry, there are pretzel carts and roasted corn on the cob and hundreds of restaurants around the area, local and fast food. Drinking water is plentiful - cold water bottles for YTL 1 only

the best district in all of the world. in sultanahmet district i was in between tow miracle museums, hajia sophia & the blue mosque with the strongly smell of turkish atmosphere & i think this district includes more than 100 restaurants each of them has a marvelous view. any person does not see sultanahmit district has being lost 50% of his life
beatiful area. like accessibility, diversity of available attractions & facilities for touristsdislike people running after tourists in irritating way offering services you will not need

Stay There and Visit. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district and there was so much to see right in walking distance!! We did five days and covered so many mosques, the cisterns, did a walking food tour with Istanbul Eats, the Topkapi Palace and Harem, Spice market, Grand Baazar, and the best restaurants, all walking distance! You can also walk to the Tazim Square! Tip - don't wear heals, there are lots of cobblestone streets!
Best neighborhood in Istanbul. You`ll be close to the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the Cistern, a lot of little restaurants. Cute and clean, great to walk around.

Istambul is here. People who said that the Istambul was all here, were right. It is a surprising place full of different attractions and four days are not enough to see everything. It's safe, even if full of people, transport is really good (transport card).

A Great Neighborhood to Explore!. The streets are hilly and laid with cobblestones. There is a street full of restaurants and hookah bars. VERY close to the major attractions in Istanbul. Great little bazaar, perfect to shop for souvenirs. Wander the neighborhood one late afternoon, you won't be disappointed.
Sultanahmet well worth it.. Everything close-by and jam-packed with very impressive, beautiful things to see and do. Disliked rude tourists who push in queues.

Explore on your own. Sultanahmet is well connected with Modern Tram and Buses however one can travell through Boats from one place to another which is very competetive mode of transport and time saver too. Much hype on sultanahmet but i did not see much worth than visting grand masque.

I love this culture!. You can spend a whole day here. Enter the facility when it opens. You will want to see as much as you can before the crowds arrive. The culture and size of the Ottoman Empire is so important in our world history. Read up a bit on the position of Sultan and Sultan Mother prior to your arrival. This whole day was a fantastic experience.

My favorite part of town. So much to see and do, all easily walkable and close to so many important historic sites. We stayed here and would do so again. Everything from humble hotels to the Four Seasons and everything in between.
Worth a Stroll. Quirkey little streets and bustling busy ones! Everyone wants to sell you something but all part of the atmosphere.

Love to walk. Those who love to explore new places on foot should roam the twisting avenues. I've only been to the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia area for an hour's exploration. Can't wait to do a wider area in the coming days, including the famed Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, "New" Mosque (heard it's over 500 years old but still called new mosque), Tamsin, and many more.

Grand Bazaar. The Grand Bazaar really is grand and bazaar! its different than those yo may experienve in Dubai or Abu Dhabi. You get the real old world feel. there are many small cafes to stop and have tea or coffee jsut outside the bazaar. Enjoy! I did!

So much history. Loved Istanbul esp the Sultan Ahmet district. There is so much to see with so much history, from the Blue Mosque, to the Hagia Sophia. These sites were grand and spectacular in their enormity. And to see them standing after all this time is amazing and all the history associated with them.... If walls could talk....

Experience the old empire. We stayed in Sultanahmet and even though the hotels are expensive and not fantastic - it was worth it! We enjoyed the small restaurants, shops and was completely awed by the historical sites. In a way it felt as if you could still sense the centuries old civilization and almost see the city , the way it was during the ottoman empire. An absolut must!

Cultural and Shopping experience. This is an interesting town to visit. Old town, as it is referred to, has a lot of culture to offer. The streets are full of venders with different kinds of ware. The best part of it, for me as Kenyan, is the fact that one can negotiate the price. the prices are quite affordable. Lots of shops and restaurants to choose from. If not shopping, a walk in the streets is an experience in itself. From a band of young people playing music at the street corner, to families walking together among other things. Dint get to eat the meat balls though.
A colorful place. Here are most of the important and amazing things to visit. You can eat here, there are many restaurants with traditional food. You find here also food in the street.

Best place to stay. This is the heart of the old and amazing city of Istanbul. There are hundreds of hotels and most within walking distance of all the amazing sites...hippodrome, blue mosque, Haggia Sophia, grand bazaar
historical moments. must visit region of İstanbul,just walk and enjoy the mistic atmosphere.Don't forget to eat famous meatballs of Sultanahmet!

Wanderer. Really enjoyed the area between the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market. Lots of tine streets devoted to different items: Street of buttons, street of mannequins, street of prayer beads. Just kept heading downhill to eventually hit water near the Spice Bazaar. My Favourite day!
Old City. This is the old city. Must see & visit. Lots of shopping + shops + restaurants. Many places to see. Everything is within walking distcance.

Great location. This district is a great location for a stay of 4-5 days. Walking distance to Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topaki Palace, Grand Bazaar, and the water front. We would choose this district over Beygolu for an Istanbul experience. The transport links are also numerous and you are a 45 minute ride from the airport via shuttle service.
excellent location with many landmarks. I liked the fact that the landmarks were nearby and that there were different modes of transport that you could take. Would recommend.
where it is at. home to the spice market and tiny streets and the bustle of the old city--back in time-do bargain and have fun in the bazaars-the people are friendly and kind-

Amazed at the pace this place is visited. Old town feel outside, old charm indoors...
Like, how tourists had head coverage prepared to wear indoors.
Cleverly thought!
Will visit again!
excellent for walking. Easy walking, despite the small hilly streets, with lots of excellent restaurants/cafes and stores. A real sense of history and long habitation, excellent views, as you walk.

It has everything except a pool. Great shops, restaurants, sights, views for days and ancient history. To stand where the Romans raced their chariots, is pretty thrilling. It was great to explore the many different neighborhoods that make up this area, wonderfully compact and all kinds of things to see shop and do.

The centre of everything. Excellent location to stay......everything within walking distance.... there are so many local restaurants and shops to see... We enjoyed using the trams and metro to move us from one station to the other. We brought a tram card which was very useful throughout our 10 days stay... cheaper then buying tram tokens everyday. We also used the card for the ferry, which was a bonus!!! Local markets are within walking distant.....easy walk to the Grand Bazzar, Blue Mosque etc.... we enjoyed the night life and the walk around the streets every night.

Wonderful location, the centre of all the historical points of interest. Great cares, street food, restaurants and night life, and of course home to the major historical sites of Istanbul including topkai palace, blue mosque, aya sofa, grand bazaar and spice markets and underground cistern. Highly recommend staying in this neighbourhood
lovely buzz and vibe....... It is very well endowed with tourist facilities - public transport, great shopping, beautiful people, stunning historical buildings and great natural views

Most of the history of the city in one place. From the hippodrome, to Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, the Blue Mosque, Archaeological Museum,Basilica cistern, the Grand Bazaar and various restaurants and hammams, it is a great place to start touring Istanbul. And if you don't have time to see the rest of the city, it is fine.
Safe and fantastic at night time. We went to a place right next to the Four Seasons called Seven Steps. You have a great view of the Mosques. At night the mosques are lit up and look beautiful.

Center of everything in Istanbul. The district of Sultan Ahmed mosque " Blue Mosque" is the busiest area in Istanbul because it has top three attractions in Istanbul. Hagia Sophia, Sultan Ahmed Mosque, and Topkapi place. In addition to Grand Bazaar and many other attractions in this area with hundreds of restaurants, cafes, sweet shops, and souvenir shops.
Dipped in hundreds of years of history. It was very nice, dipped in hundreds of years of history, lovely place to walk in the evenings, restaurants, shopping and historical sites galore.

central place to stay.. Wonderful location ...everything within walking distance for our brief visit. made use of the trams...easy to use..buy token first..easy walk to the Grand Bazzar, underground cisterns, Blue Mosque etc.... we were joining a cruise and this location meant we had the best of both worlds...history and culture around us and a short taxi ride to the port.. will definately stay in this area again.

What tourists are looking for in Turkey. If you only have a short stay in Turkey or limited days in Istanbul, staying in the Sultanahmet District is a must. The Grand Bazzar, The Blue Mosque, Topaki Palace.....its all here. Istanbul is enormous and has insane amounts of traffic.....so if you stay elsewhere you could spend all your time just trying to get to this area and you are much better off being able to walk to these destinations. This area also has tons of cafes, etc.. to make your stay easy.However, if you are a business traveler looking for the nightlife or the best high end restaurants and or shopping districts.......this is not the area for you.
A must. The rooftop bars and restaurants in this area are my favorite. Went rooftop hopping on a Saturday for brunch, took a nap in the park and then hit the bazaar.

I am glad that we stayed in Sultanahmet. If you wants to make your visit to Istanbul a memorable one and you can enjoy all the history, shopping, night stroll in the Hippodrome Turkish food and Mc Donland cones the place to stay is Sultanahmet..its very peaceful and safe area and every attraction is just 5 min.walk..
Great mix of history. Love to go back.. A place of many historic / shopping areas. Just visited the blue mosque, Aya Sophia, the palace and the Egyptian bazaar. A house of sweets and spices.

Sultanahmet. The only way to experience Istanbul is by staying in the Sultanahmet district! Close to the palace, the Blue Mosque and Hajia Sophia, the Grand Bazaar......a great little hotel in the heart of it all is the Poem Hotel.

Great historical sites, but very touristy otherwise. We loved visiting all the museums and mosques around Sultanahmet....but otherwise it is the usual mess of over-priced restaurants with average or sub-par food, shop owners harassing you to visit their shops, etc. Oc course you'll visit this area while in Istanbul since a lot of the major sites are there, but expect crowds and a bit of chaos.

A place where you never get tired of it!. This is the place that I never got tired during my 5-days stay in Istanbul. Every corner here is full of history and just sitting on one of the benches in the garden between the Haghia Sophia and the Blue Mosque is an experience. Our hotel was located in Sultanahmet and that gave us a great advantage to spend more time here. It is also packed with many restaurants and cafes and we didn’t have to venture any further. Most of the historical sites are here on walking distance. Every day we started with a walk around the Hippodrome – this is he square in front of the Blue Mosque. It was here that chariot races were taking place and also here, in 532 during the Nika rebellion, when 30,000 rebels were trapped and slaughtered. No much left today – only three monuments. There were brought here from all over the Byzantine Empire to decorate the central line of the Hippodrome of the new capital Constantinople. I was attached mostly to the Serpent Column. The three intertwined bronze serpents were casted to celebrate the victory of the Greeks over the Persians during the Persian Wars in the 5th century BC. Constantine ordered the column to be moved from the Temple of Apollo at Delphi. It must have been a beautiful work of art. The other monument -The Egyptian Obelisk – is also fascinating. It was originally erected in Luxor. After nearly 3,500 years and after such a long journey from Egypt it has not only survived, it is also in astonishingly good condition. Here also is the Museum of Turkish and Islamic art. During my visit the museum was closed but at least I had a glimpse outside. The building was one of the grandest private residences ever built in the Ottoman Empire and I was quite intrigued by the tragic story of its ex resident – Ibrahim Pasha. He was a Greek, born to Christian parents and at the age of six sold as a slave to the Ottoman palace where he became a good friend of Suleyman the Magnificent when he was also a child. This good friendship gave him the advantage of being promoted to various posts and his power and wealth became so great that some diplomats referred to him as “Ibrahim the Magnificent”. He had so much influence on the Sultan and his affairs that the Sultan’s wife, Roxelana, in a fit of jealousy, managed to convince her husband that his dear friend was a traitor and had him assassinated. It is said that Suleiman later regretted Ibrahim's execution and this is reflected in his poems, in which even after twenty years he stresses topics of amity and trust between friends. Going further you encounter Haghia Sophia - after 1500 years it is still one of the truly great buildings of the world! As you pass through the great Imperial Gate behind Haghia Sophia, you enter the First Court of the Topkapi Palace. It is fascinating to have a glimpse at the world of the Ottoman dynasty ruled an empire that included the cities of Athens, Budapest, Belgrade, Sarajevo, Bucharest, Sofia, Beirut, Damascus, Baghdad, Jerusalem, Mecca, Cairo, Alexandria and Tunis, all at one point.On your left is the Byzantine Haghia Eirene, Church of the Divine Peace, commissioned in the 540s by Justinian to replace an earlier church that had occupied this site. The building here is almost exactly as old as Haghia Sophia. My favourite part of the palace was the Harem. The scholars regard the harem as a vital system of organizing the Ottoman Empire. Here also is the Archaeological Museum – one of the best in Europe, and the Basilica Cistern, a fascinating and almost romantic place that once brought drinking water into Constantinople. On your way to the Grand Bazaar you will encounter the column of Constantine – one of the most venerable monuments in the city. It marks the centre of what was once the Forum of Constantine the Great and was erected by him to celebrate the dedication of the city as capital of the Roman Empire in 330 AD. There are a few benches around the column where you can sit and admire the monument, even with the many pigeons perched on it. After dusk the city becomes ever more beautiful. The elegant silhouette of the Blue Mosque is illuminated and looks spectacular. We used to sit or walk in the garden between The Haghia Sophia and The Blue Mosque with a large fountain in the middle and enjoy the view. Here in a few restaurants we witnessed that amazing dances of the whirling dervishes who never get tired. Their performance is magical. I understand it is a religious ceremony but still it is a must see. While walking around every day we had a fresh piece of watermelon, sweet corn - roasted or boiled, roasted chestnuts, ice cream or Turkish simits (circular bread with sesame seeds). We also stumbled on the friendliest street cats I ever met.
Great area to stay and visit. You can walk around everywhere ..wear comfortable shoes and don't forget water. You can also take tramway around too
Lively. A very lively place till late at night. Very good vibes and not a very European feel. All buildings are historic and streets are of cobblestone. Like the area a lot.

One of the oldest area full of tourist attractions. It's close to major sightseeing area, located near Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque and Topkapı..It's full of local shops selling Turkish goodies, carpets, sweets, many kind of souvenirs, Turkish tea, Turkish coffee.It is full of restaurants and bars. many are them local but you can also find global chain bars such as North Shield.There is tram going in the middle of the street, and its stone streets look very colorful and nice.since it's a major attraction area especially for tourist it's a bit expensive but not too much that you can't enjoy an afternoon beer or eat/try some food.If you want to buy souvenirs, especially big ones such as carpets don't forget to haggle!..
A nice days. Sultan Ahmed is not mere a street ,it's a summary of Istanbul ,no one could say that he visit Istanbul without seeing Sultan Ahmed,old city is mixed with active live .

Beautiful. This is a very old area with lots of the main sights in walking distance. Food is Definately overpriced and everything needs to be bargained down. Go to Beyazit or taksim for cheaper deals. Tram is cheap so fill your IstanbulKart with 20-30 TL for the whole trip.
Wonderful Historic Area of Istanbul. I loved to walk around window shopping and admiring historic buildings. The area is full of shops, restaurants and tourist attractions, all worth visiting.

Beautiful. Hagia Sophia in particular is a must-see, but the Blue Mosque was a treat as well. Other than that, the area is overpriced. I wouldn't stay here--food will be cheaper and better up around Taksim or Beyoglu.
Location location. Close to all the major sights such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace. Interesting streets since it is the oldest district of Istanbul.
An experience not to be missed.. August is peak season had to queue for a very long time lots of people and very hot as it was prayer time for the Muslims one better go after two.

My favorite part of Istanbul. This area is superb! Great shopping! Rather do it at the small bizarre here than at the rip off Grand Bizarre. There are many excellent restaurants and sights in the facinity

crowded and inspiring. If you are looking for an exotic place to visit in Istanbul, it is a really good one because of its incredible bazar full of shops of different colors and "oriental smells"! Everything can be found from spices to fake bags!

Where all the major sights are. This is the place to stay in Istanbul as all the major sights are within walking distance so no public transport is required. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Basilica Cistern are all with about 5 minutes walkk of wach other. Also some interesting little shops around this area.

A beautiful central area of Istanbul. So much of what one visits Istanbul for, is contained within the Sultanahmet district. The gentle slopes of winding cobbled streets and roof-top cafes afford views of the sea and ferries beneath, over to the bridges and the Asian side. To enjoy a light evening meal overlooking the mosques and the islands as the sun sets is an experience to be savoured, the call to prayers rolls around on the air from mosque to mosque - breathtaking!!

Beware of carpet salesmen. This district is really good to visit. All kinds of things to see and places to shop. Some much in Istanbul. Just beware, if you stop to read a map or look the slightest bit like a tourist, you will be swarmed on by the local carpet salesmen. If you accept directions or a compliment from someone, they will expect you to visit their carpet shop. They are very aggressive.
the best. Fabulous area and neighborhood with numerous side streets. I've visited many times and always get pleasure out of another visit!

Definitely Must Visit, Recommend to Stay Here. We stayed here as a second choice actually-- during the protests in Turkey, we were bringing some undergraduate students and rather than stay near Taksim, we decided to stay in Sultanahmet.We would have seen all the tourist sights here anyway, but being so close was FANTASTIC! Each morning it was quite a doable walk to all the must-dos in Istanbul... the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace. I feel like I have a good sense of the geography because we stayed there, and I think we were able to be really efficient and make the most of our stay.There's good shopping and dining here as well, although prices can creep up since it's a touristy area. Still, there's no better way to get acquainted with the historic aspect of Istanbul, to really feel the layers of history. For the business, cosmopolitan side, you will need to look elsewhere.

A must if you visit Istanbul!. This is really a must if you are visiting Istanbul. The Old City will really leave you breathless at times with its historical gems, most located a short walk away from each other (mosques, Ayasofya, Topkapı Palace, etc.).
a really lively place, great atmosphere. Lively and brilliant. You can never get bored here. However, for women I advise that you cover up as the men will hassle you continually,

Good Place to Explore. This area is definitely one of the more touristy places in Istanbul so it has some drawbacks. People keep trying to take you for a ride, specially the taxi drivers, so it is generally better to walk around or take public transport. Both ways are safe, and more economical since there is a lot to see. The other thing that I did not like was the price at the eateries. Everything was grossly over priced compared to other places I had eaten in. The food was good, but not worth the cost. All that said, if you are careful this place is certainly worth visiting to check out all the beautiful historical buildings.

Best area to stay in Istanbul. Loved the area - it's my 20th plus visit to Istanbul over a period of 30 years and I usually stay here - close to lots of the most interesting sites, good roof-top restaurants with views, excellent small hotels, you can walk to most places so no need for public transport, taxis etc.
This the area for Turist. This is part of Old Town. If you are a tourist this is the area you want to visit. Mosque's, Underground cistern ,carpet dealers.. Busy but safe area.

Best place to stay and visit. We visited Istanbul for the second time and booked our hotel in the Sultanahmet area because most of the major sights are walking distance ;Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Basilica cistern, etc.  To get to the Bazaar, Galata tower or take a cruise you can hop on the tram.The Sultanahmet area has a very good, vibrant athmosphere and felt safe during our stay.Best place to stay and from there it's easy to get around.

Fabulicious. Day or night, this is the heart of the vibrant city of Istanbul. At night, the best place to be is at the colourful fountains between the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. The sights and food are simple fabulicious!

Best place in Istanbul. I wanted to stay in Sultanahmet versus Taksim as it's near all the places I'd like to visit. It's well serviced, and all the historic monuments of Istanbul are within walking distance. The tram runs through it, so it's also good if you don't like walking. Here you can walk to Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topcapi Palace and Gulhane Park, among others.

Exploring this heavenly place & beyond!. These are the major attractions that you should visit when you are in Istanbul. Some can be covered in a day, as majorities are located in the old city Sultanahmet.I stayed in Sirkeci, which was just a walking distance from Sultanahmet, so you don’t need taxis.1. Hagia Sophia Museum / Church (Ayasofya)2. Suleymaniye Mosque (close to the Grand Bazaar)3. Sultanahmed Mosque – The Blue Mosque 4. Rustem Pasha Mosque5. Sultanahmed District (have a walk around the area for exploration & eating)6. Bosphorus Strait cruise7. Topkapi Palace8. Dolmabahce Palace9. Galata Bridge (takes you from Sirkeci to Taksim)10. Galata Tower (located at the end of Taksim road, worth the walk)11. Princes’ Islands (take half a day tour, don’t waste the whole day!)Don’t miss out in going to the following Bazaars:1. Kapali Carsi –Grand Bazaar (closed only on Sunday)2. Egyptian Bazaar –Spice Bazaar (open 7 days a week)3. Fatih Carsamba (open on Wednesdays)There is a tram that crosses Sirkeci, which can transport you to Sultanahmet, and also take you to the other side of Istanbul, the European side. Then you can take the underground metro to Taksim square / road for a long walk. End it by visiting the Galata Tower. There are restaurants there. Warning: there are nightclubs there too, so prepare yourself for some loud music. But there are also live performances by street musicians as well. It’s a lively place, and packed with high market brand shops.One unique experience that you should try, if you want to, is the Turkish Hamam. Çemberlitaş Hamamı is considered the oldest Hamam (built in 1584). I tried it and it was heavenly.Sirkeci has a lot of restaurants & supermarkets, so you won’t go hungry till 3 am.Things to eat & drink: Doner Kebab (national snack) and Turkish coffee! Most restaurants will have the usual Mediterranean appetizers (like hummus), and usually serve you a basket of freshly baked Turkish bread. Try their meat & seafood dishes. They play very well with spices, so you will enjoy it. Don’t eat from dodgy places. Last thing you want is food poison. Galata Bridge has some of the funkiest eateries, and stall markets.Take the following:1. Camera and the charger2. Get Turkish Lira before you travel3. Take some Euros too, just in case5. Clothes according to the weatherHave fun!
The place to be. Sultanahmet was in my view the perfect loction on any visit to Istanbul. everwhere was easily reached but the city traffic was a nightmare

Turista tour - Bosphorus Afternoon Cruise. We booked this afternoon tour through our hotel desk. The cost was 35 euros which we thought word provide a really nice tour. We were collected from our hotel and taken to the Spice Bazaar to a specially designated shop who was meant to explain about the various spices. This did not happen at all. We wanted their advice on the various Turkish apple teas but they were so rude that we walked out the shop and purchased elsewhere.Next we headed to the wharf where we would meet the boat. We were disappointed to find that we went on the regular hop on hop off river boat. There was a commentary on the boat in Turkish and then English in between times our "guide" repeated what had just been said (although he did occasionally add some additional bits of information).When we got back to the bus we were offered the chance to go to a leather outlet which was refused by all on board. We were expected to fill in survey forms and hand them back to the guide which he then read and discussed with the driver.A disappointing end to our holiday and would not use this company again.
very busy. you will find so many different culture and very busy street, there is live in that road always busy even at 2 or 3 in the morning.

Beautiful Area. The suntanahmet is a lovely part of an amazing city. There are restaurants, book stores, rug shops, gift shops and of course the grand bazaar in the district. Everyone I met was friendly and helpful. The tram is modern, efficient and inexpensive to use. Highly recommend.
The place to go. You can find everything in Sultanahmet.Its got the most important sight seeing attractions.Just watch out for turist traps.
Hilly, but worth it!. A truly lovely area is that of Sultanahmet. Arm yourself with a bottle of water - Put your walking shoes on and keep walking!

So much in one location. Easy to visit all the attractions in one location. Soon find your way about. So many places of interest to marvel at yet within minutes of each other.take as long or as short as you wish. Just get used to the "carpet sellers".

Culturally rich thoroughfare to explore. Very rich in culture, from people to streets to buildings. Watch out for over-priced Turkish ice cream, there are unscrupulous vendors about! Ask for price before placing order; they are clever to distract you with their acrobatic skills in flipping the ice cream cone and scoops, do not fall for it. Otherwise a fascinatng district, very vibrant and busy, and almost loud as we were there during Ramadan and witnessed Iftar every night out in the lawns outside the Blue Mosque.
Sultan Ahmet. Sultan Ahmet District is very good. Touristic area. Sultan Ahmet Camii and Ayasofia is very nice. You have to pay for Ayasofia but Sultan Ahmet Camii is freee.

a nice area. it is a really nice street and all around of it full of resturant coffee shop ,you can take a table out of resturant in street and order your food , we order duner kebab which provided from both meat or chicken , but really they use too oil in their kebab and it is not satisfy ours at middle

wow!!!... what a pretty place for girls!!!. I fell in love with this place since the first step into the grand bazaar... million of jewerly and accesories which is, for a girl like me, the heaven!!!... And all around the district you can find precious dresses, skirts, shoes, t-shirts, tops, jeans, etc, etc, etc... If you are a girl like me who wants to wear pretty clothes, Just take with you your wallet and a large suitcase to put inside everything you will buy.If this were not good enough... take a look of the turkish man... My goooooddddddd!

Sultanahmet - interesting experience. We stayed in a hotel in Sultanahment District. It is noisy to stay there, but very interesting during the day. You can hear plenty of honking and yelling from the local drivers until 1-2 AM. We loved walking around and shopping at the souvenir shops. Bargain when shopping, otherwise you would pay more!!! Plenty of restaurants, the quality of the food varies a lot! It is hit or miss sometimes. It was interesting experience overall.

Walk the Turkish way. This is the heart of Istanbul. The vibrant cafes, the cobbled streets, the attractive lanterns in all the shops and smiling welcoming Turkish people is what makes this area so beautiful. You will find numerous cafes here, try the local kababs, try the lemon tea served in the special Turkish glass. We stayed in this area and hence we could experience the true Turkish culture
Great Atmosphere. It is amazing, we prayed Tarweeh and had our breakfast in the Square, we saw the shops and the atmosphere is great, praying there helps forgret some of the stress you live

Window into urban Turkish life. visit sultanahmet and find yourself walking through cobble stone streets, thousands of years old you can get fresh cherries, exotic nuts and witness a crowd of locals cheering for their favorite soccer team. eat lamb/chicken kabobs at an outdoors cafe and people watch. sip some local effe beer, or mint tea while you hear the nearby mosque chanting prayers. amazing place buzzing with activity late in to the wee hours of the night.

Walk in the Passages of History. Showcase for many early civilizations and empires almost competing with each other in architecture and design. In addition good food, entertainment and shopping makes this place complete.

wonderful place to start your Turkish vacation. I loved this area - so alive and so vibrant - Enjoyed walking everywhere and felt safe - the cafes were welcoming and it is a good place to base your Istanbul stay. Taxis and trams make moving around very easy
Major sites just in walking distance. Places where the major sites located close to each other, you do not have to walk far to reach all. and many unique street food around this place.

Exciting place to wander in!. We really enjoyed the old town of Istanbul and just wandered around, soaking in the sights. We used the trams quite a lot too. Very easy once you find the ticket machine. Everyone was very friendly and helpful. It was great!
All inclusive. This old district encompasses all the most important historical attractions and all are accessible by public transport,very economical and most convenient

Excellent for all Site seeing tourist. If site seeing is your main agenda, please stay in Sultanahmet District, as this has all the tourist sites as well as the famous Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. The night life along the sea front is also recommended

Lacks fun. Only a few bars and night clubs. I understand that the area is full of religious and cultural monuments but it would be nice not to have to go all the way to Taksim or Bosphorus while staying in the oldtown. Sultanahmet has many things but it certainly lacks in the fun department. I highly recommend visiting it but not staying in it. Especially young people looking for nightlife.
Awesome. I really enjoyed walking around and shopping in the oldtown of Istanbul. The prices can be steep sometimes but it sure is fun to negotiate a little! :)

Best Walking Neighborhood for Major Sites. I loved that you could walk safely everywhere here, and that there were lovely cafes and shops throughout. Coming from LA, the last thing I wanted to do was get into a taxi. The streets are cobbled ladies, so leave the Manolos at home. Best place to stay is the Four Seasons Sultanahmet, and if you can't stay there at least go for drinks at sundown on the rooftop.

Everything in one square!. World heritage sites within a stone's throw of each other, a lively square where local people meet to chat and to worship, overflowing with bars and restaurants and great shopping. The best place to stay in Istanbul

The Best Place to Stay!. I stumbled across Sultanahmet whilst looking for a hotel in which to stay for a week. This was the perfect spot. We walked to all the main attractions, Basilica, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market and many more. There are plenty of restaurants and cafes too. This has got to be the best part of Istanbul!

Beautiful city of Ottoman Turks. My husband and I spent 4 days in the Sultanahmet district of Istanbul and all 4 of them were very well spent. If there is one place you can see in Istanbul, it has to be this district.
