The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Basilica Cistern all are in this area and the best part is that you can easily walk from one attraction to the other. They also have a metro line connecting all of these which you may consider taking to the Galata bridge, Galata tower and the Spice bazaar if you are too tired to walk. Sea of Marmara, the Golden Horn, and the Bosporus add further to the beauty and charm of this place. I would recommend staying at a hotel in the Sultanahmet district that serves breakfast on the terrace with a view of the sea (there are many such!). Walk as much as possible to truly experience the city. Audio guides are available at all major attractions for an extra charge but I did not find them informative enough. You will be better off saving those liras and reading the information boards instead. There are some small cafes that are open till late night and serve good food at very reasonable prices. Try and find one and if you do, don't forget to ask for a backgammon or checkers board and have a fun game after your dinner while drinking tea :)

Good but too much hassle. All the history is amazing but the whole area is full of pushy salesmen and just random people trying to take you to a carpet store. I wish there was less pressure for shopping and more opportunities to meet real local people.

The best area to stay. If it's your first time in Istanbul (as it was mine), this is the place to stay. You can walk to all the main attractions of historic Istanbul (easily), like the Hagia Sofya, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar and the amazing underground water cistern. There are also literally hundreds of restaurants to choose from, including loads with great roof terraces with views of the city and the sea. It's easy to find your way around and get oriented - oh and there's plenty of shopping nearby, too. Highly recommended.

Full of fascinating architecture (and a few questionable characters). This is the place to put your wallet in your front pocket or hold on to your purse. In fact the pleasant female announcement on the tram will remind you of the same before you offload into the Sultanahment District. It's probably because everyone will be staring upwards at the Aya Sofya (Haga Sofia) and the Blue Mosque and other stunning pieces of architectural history. Enjoy the area, and don't forget to walk to the Spice Market or Grand Bazaar...
History at a glance!!!. NO need to say about the district. Please let yourself lost in there... While you walk, think about thousands of years before, think about the civilizations how they evolved.

The heart of Old Istanbul. We stayed at the Q Hotel so were in walking distance of everything and also close to the tram stop so could get to other places easily. If you go during Ramazan, be sure to go to the Blue Mosque area at night as well as during the day as it is transformed. In the late afternoon older family members reserve spaces at the many picnic tables laid out in the Hippodrome. After nightfall their extended families join them, the feasting begins and everyone is in high spirits. It is a lovely family atmosphere.

Going back in time. If you like to know more about the culture, the history of the city you should spending a day in this area. Drinking coffee in one of the small streets, watching the many tourists, seeing all the stuff sold on the streets. Amazing!

A Feast or the Eyes, Ears and Nose. Imagine market stalls piled high with delectable edible treats: chunks of lightly dusted Turkish Delight, mounds of golden dried apricots, or freshly made Baklava oozing with ground pistachios. These are just some of what lies in store for you, if you stroll through the Spice Market. Listen to the hypnotic call to prayer five times day from any of the hundreds of minarets that pierce Istanbul's skyline. Gaze at an Egyptian obelisk, at the intricate mosaics that decorate the walls and ceiling of the Hagia Sophia, or marvel at a Whirling Dervish who never seems to tire or get dizzy while twirling in a trance like stupor. Snack on a freshly BBQ's corn on the cob, or a grilled fish sandwich, or some freshly brewed apple tea.

The place to be in Istanbul. Going to the Asian side and the New District is great, but staying in Sultanahmet is the best because you are close to all of the historical sites and at night when the mosques are all lit up, it is gorgeous to see. Especially if you find a hotel or restaurant with a rooftop terrace!
Almost too much to absorb. Beautiful mosques, shopping, restaurants, confluence of people and transportation, absolutely fascinating.

Busy district for good reason. You will spend a few hours between the 2 massive mosques, get lost on your way to the Grand Bazar, find hundreds of cafés and restaurants (choose some with a roof terrace), enjoy Turkish atmosphere (although also quite touristic one), and... love it.
Lively area. Quite a happening area surrounded by many popular sites. Great for relaxing, snacking on street food like roasted chestnuts, corn and watermelon and fresh juices.

Great place to walk around. I live the old City. Lovely to walk around and discover. I normally go here during the day and prefer to return to the Western side (Taksim area) by night. The other side is where the locals are. This side is heavily touristic and I wanted a vibrant night life which I feel is better on the other side.
where do all these people come from?. nice but very congested neighborhood. liked the historic buildings and the many, many restaurants with tons of delicious dishes.

Turistic but it's worth it.. Things are more expensive here than other places, as the place lives on tourism, but it's the price you pay to be close to most all the atractions of Istanbul, like Haya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, The Cistern, Topkapi Palace and the museums.

Cooollll place. Everything you've always wanted to see about Istanbul is here but just watch out for the little guy who claims his father has a carpet shop and he can get u into the Hagia Sophia sans queue as he just haresses u afterwards to buy carpets and they are not the best examples one can get in Istanbul!!and he gets a bit "upset" about it if u don't buy!!!
Most of the Hotels are situated around there. Is the district where many good hotels are situated and its close to all the sightseeing places. Its a happening district of Istanbul
Blue mosque. I liked the relaxed atmosphere which can be found away from the main squareI really disliked the constant touting in the main square area up near the Sophia museum awful space
Loved it !. So many restaurants ! The food everywhere in Sultanahmet is delish ! Shopping here is brilliant too, especially down the side streets away from the bazaar

loved it!!. Crowded streets, vendors, restaurant owners trying to get your business, hundreds of tourists, but still a lovely experience! I particularly liked to walk around later in the day when it was cooler and some of the madness had subsided. Ancient streets, the sound of the muzzein calling to prayer, the smell of food, and of course tasting Turkish delight at every opportunity

Ramadan. This district does not sleep during Ramadan. People, even children, were out all night on the streets enjoing corn on the cob and watermelon. The atmosphere is amazing and the people are very nice. There are many people in this district trying to lure tourist into carpet shops. Simply say no and keep walking, if you show no sign of interest they will leave you alone. Don't even glance at what they try to give you.

Make Sultanahmet your home base. If you are visiting Istanbul for the first time and you plan on seeing all of the big sites then Sultanahmet is the place to stay.  If you choose the right hotel (we stayed in the Empress Zoe - an excellent option) you will be no more than ten minutes away from Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern and many museums. The Grand Bazaar is about a 15 minute walk and you can jump on the Metro and zip down to the Galata Bridge to go to the Spice Market, take a Bosphorus cruise or make your way into other parts of the city. There is no shortage of restaurants or stores hawking souvenirs from carpets to lights to pottery.

Perfect base for 1st time visitors. Within walking distance of all the major attractions, Sultanahmet is a great base for the first time visitor. The tram offers a nice alternative for tired legs, but most of the area can be canvassed on foot. There are heaps of eateries, souvenir shops and lots of activity day and night, so safety is not really an issue even if you are travelling alone. Gulhane Park-- in the middle of the district --offers a wonderful respite from the busy-ness of the streets (there are some gorgeous tea houses at the end of the park overlooking the Bospherous). Unless you are a heavy sleeper, look for where the nearest mosque is to your accommodation and plan accordingly.

A walk back in time. We stayed at the Ada Hotel n the Sultanahmet district. As we drove in I wondered about the obvious antiquity of the area and whether we had made a colossal mistake. How wrong I was. The area was enchanting. On our first afternoon, we walked two blocks up a hill and came out onto the Hippodrome and the Blue Mosque. I fell in love with the area and nothing occurred to change my mind. This was truly ancient Istanbul/ Constantinople. Everywhere you walked, and you could walk everywhere, you encountered historical sites. Plus the area had great restaurants and shops. The shop keepers were friendly and answered questions readily. We spoke only English but had no problems communicating. We were out into the evening hours and always felt safe, wherever we walked. What a great introduction to Turkey!

Just walk and feel history surround you. You have to just explore this area. It is truly the heart of Istanbul and the reason to visit. Go thru the bazaar, visit the mosques, see the churches and visit the palaces and parks.

Historical and breathtaking views.. The old town of Istanbul. Very friendly people around that help you get around. Loads of tourists like on every other historical place like this but for us it never felt crowded since it is a fairly big place.I can really recommend going away from the main streets and just walk around and take in the atmosphere of the area.

Overall Good experience. This is really beautiful city.... Worth visiting it. Good blend of Islam and Christianity. We walked and little and took tram for some distance. These district offers several restaurants also to cater hunger....

Great for walking. Lovely to wonder around and just take in all the sights and people enjoying the area. If you want to avoid the crowds, you can also find smaller, more quiet streets and lovely hidden garden restaurants. Lots of shops catering for tourists as well, but the sellers tend not to bother you too much. Numerous little fruit and juice stalls, and corn sellers can be found, too. During Ramadan, it got really crowded with the locals around the mosque. But it all still worked peacefully and harmoniously, tourists and local muslims side by side.

Nice in Ramadan. Nice to watch people in small groups, families, elderly and children, people from different walks of life setting up picnic like arrangements in the square of Sultan Ahmet waiting for the announcement of the end of a long fasting day of Ramadan. The square with its street cafes, mosques and bazar like shops, transfers you to an era of sultans an khalifs, however holding to reality you realize to find your self in a modern city with a fascinating touch of the past.
A distinct area. A lovely area to visit with lots of shops and cafes, restaurants. Spend the day in this area and you won't be disappointed.

An adventure in itself. Walking is the best way to enjoy the Sultanahmet area. Cobbled streets which wind to sometimes nowhere, and sometimes to a nice surprise! We stayed in the area, and enjoyed every moment. loved the 'old town feel', plenty restaurants to whet your appetite, and the historic attractions like the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Aya(Hagia) Sophia, are there. A small but good bazaar, Arasta Bazaar, is also there. Try to visit, it is worthwhile

Visiting the Sultanahmet district. The Sultanahmet district ("old town") offers so much to see, all within an easy walking distance: the Ayasofia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, the remnants of the old Hippodrome (with the Egyptian Obelisk) -- and numerous restaurants and cafes offering refreshments and meals for the travelers. If you are coming to Istanbul, you really should visit these historic monuments.

Great historic district. This is the center of historic Istanbul. Lots of attractions like the Blue Mosque the Hagia Sophia are around Sultanahmet Square. There are also many fine shops,restaurants, and hotels.

Small streets and historical places. This area has a nice, friendly atmosphere and nice places to visit. It is mostly touristic area, where many hotels and restaurants are located, as well the famous sites.

touristy but still interesting, but get into the side streets. the best experiences in cafe's and old istanbul feeling can be found off the beaten path is the side streets. Walk in the opposite direction of tourists, and find cafe's filled with locals, you will enjoy.

Fun shopping and haggling. The sultanas eat area has the grand bazaar and the spice bazaar. I love going there it's so much fun to visit. They love to haggle and you probably can knock down the price a good 40 percent if you are good at it. The spices are great, I spend a lot of money getting different teas and spices that I don't find in US. Well worth the visit.

Sights and sounds. Sultanahmet was a sight to behold when we first arrived in Istanbul but immediately we felt at home. Easy to find our way around and the tram or light rail is terrific at 3TL per journey and very frequent. Easy walking, friendly but persistent sellers and may close attractions. Steep hills and some very persistent touts can wear you down but just smile and say "no thanks". We spent 3 days and were very busy and plan another two days for final shopping and seeing Tokapi Palace before leaving Turkey. Wonderful is the word.

great area. We stayed in the area with a group of family and friends and thoroughly enjoed it. It has everything you want to see within walking distance and also you get the feel of what Istanbul is all about.I have stayed at the other side of town near Taksim square but it had the feeling of any other city so I will always choose Sultanahmet District when i come again.

Very interesting part of town. Make sure you spend a couple days here wandering about, the main hub of the tourist centre however it's easy to see why, the Grand Baazar, The Blue Mosque & lots of good ice cream!

Enjoyed this area of Istanbul.. Sultanahmet district has so many wonderful sights and attractions...it's the best place in Istanbul to stay. You can walk to most things, which safes you from the traffic...the traffic can be intense.

Very nice!. This is a very nice disctrict.Quite crowded during the day and almost empty in the evening. Standing on the square, you feel the spirit of history.Everyone should visit Sultanahmet area as many times as it is possible!
historic and beautiful. i adore this area, i recommend if u want to stay in istanbul to stay in sultanahmet where you can visit the market , resturants , historic places
Great to be where everyone is.. If you're going to stay in Istanbul, I would say this would be the best starting point for all your walks. Lots of attractions, shops, and restaurants.
Best area. All the good places to visit are there... All walking distance... Tram handy to go to other places.................

Extremely visitor friendly. A wonderful area, full of life and lots of helpful people and we never felt unsafe. The loos are not very good, much better off going to the ones in the Grand Bazaar! Just wonder around and enjoy all the ancient sites.

Riches. Sultanahmet District has been settled for a millenium (at least) and the historic centre of present-day Istanbul from Byzantium through Constantinople until the present. There is so much to see and do here that some travelers never leave. There are mosques of great beauty, the Topkapi Palace, the Bazaars, trams to "faraway places" like Galata, ferries across the Bosphorous and to the Black Sea, and more carpets than you can shake a stick at. It also contains a little visited museum just below the Blue Mosque in the Arasta Bazaar. Called the Mosaic Museum it is a recently discovered and restored floor of the great Palace of Byzantium. It is an astonishing insight into ordinary behaviour of the Fifth century. There are children playing hoops, a man milking a goat, a monkey catching birds, animals some domestic, some fantastical from long ago. It shoud NOT be missed.

Never felt safer :). Loved the whole area! Had been on safari in Africa prior to this and also in South America. We felt totally safe in this area. It was bustling with people all the time but this just added to the atmosphere. Without a map, we just wandered off and explored, often finding ourselves away from the main drag passing through old residential areas where inhabitants perched on stairs and peered through windows, always friendly and acknowledging our attempts at Turkish greetings. In the more touristy areas there are scores of eating places to suit every budget; also heaps of litte shops selling, well, everything. Visited twice, both during the demonstrations - you would never have guessed there was unrest in the city at all. Will definitely return :)
crazy. Bustling with life from day to night. Fascinating to sit back and watch life go by. Lots of restaurants, people watching, street hawkers etc

fabulous area. this whole area is completely steeped in history and has not changed for hundreds of years. Easy to walk to the different points of interest and the Turkish people are extremely friendly

The area is very interesting yet u know is the tourist spot.. Many cafe, bazzaar, hidden surprises, restaurants.....close distant to all main historic area of Old City of Istanbul. Need to get lost and wonder the area....

An excellent bustling place to visit. The mosque's, grand bazaar, spice markets and eateries,are all here for you to enjoy. Take care with some store owners who try and take you in with offers of just giving you their business card or a tea. It is all god natured but some cane be a bit pushy especially in the market areas

A Lot to see of Istanbul. Nice places to see around for people who love walking. The spice (Egyptian) bazar, the grand bazar, the burnt column, the blue mosque and the areas around with streets full of restaurants etc.

Nice place u can see civilization of Ottoman and Constantinople. i was there 3 times before its very nice and most of people visit turkey go there u can see to much people u can find to much things good there

Can you Feel the Vibe. Sultanahmet is one of the busiest cities I've visited...ever! It's definitely worth visiting, as there is so much to do and see. All the major attractions are around the area as is the Grand Bazaar. If you find it all a little to much, you can find refuge in the nearby Gulhane Park, which houses the Topkapi Palace. I loved the park; my kind of place to hang out and get away from the hustle and bustle. There are cafes that sit facing the ocean, where you can sit and relax with a cup of chy (tea).Check it out if you can
Min3days!!!!!!. Grand bazzar,Blue mosque,Ayasofia church/museum,bosporus cruise,the hop on-hop-bus,Turkish hamam....spice market....and much much more,all in just 3days time....

Loved it!. This area is so cute. It's very touristy, but we really liked the European charm this area had. There were good restaurants and shops everywhere and a lot of major historical attractions are within minutes walking distance of each other. The only thing I would warn about are all the pushy men trying to sell stuff. Met a lot of nice Turkish/Kurdish people, though!

Family visit. Amazing place.Its very calm and beautiful.You can get alot of shops and hundreds of eating places.In the evening the garden between blue mosque and Aya Sofia is the most beautifl place in Istanbul!
Nice clean, happening area. Liked the ambiance, didn't like the overtly exuberant guides trying to sell packages and stuff.The close to the port area offers something for everyone and its a must see.
Fascinating part of town. This is a fantastic area to explore the older architecture and the hussle and bussle of modern life set in the narrow, hilly and winding alleys.

Plenty To Do and See. While there are areas of tourist trap material, the back streets still give plenty of colour and interest, from hairdressers to fabric shops and, of course, a million cafes and restaurants. Well worth some time

If you are first timer a must. You see the Blue Mosque and the Sultanahmet Mosque and several other museum and turist attractions in one place. At Sultanahmet Mosque take the narrative that the facility offers at free charge. It is a bit of advertisement about Islam and they are trying to present you with the peaceful side of Islam as we here in US are bombarded with a lot of negative news about this religion.

Romantic yet Vibrant.... The ambience that you will never get in other place! It's really beautiful, romantic yet so vibrant! I love to hang out around this district! You'll see alot of friendly and nice Turkish people around this area. Some of them might will approach you with their offers, but, they do it in creative way I never found in any other places in the world and somehow it entertains you.

Best area to stay in Istanbul. Most historic attractions are here and you will have no issues finding restaurants, shops and sites to see. Plenty to do and easy access to and from the airport and the newer areas of the city.
Simply awesome...so much history. Everywhere you turn there's a story to be told and most likely it will be over 100 years old (the new ones...just kidding).

Main tourist attractions - prices to match for the tourist restaurants/shops !. This is the area with the main tourist attractions - food prices in the area for tourist restaurants are at least double that of the places where the locals eat (and the quality is not much better ! ). Of course you pay for the convenience of having those places to eat on the doorstep of Aya Sofia and Blue Mosque- but make sure you know what you are paying for. And if you look round some of the side streets you will find a number of places that the locals use which are much cheaper. Tourist shopping also requires you to be careful on pricing.

Walk, have a coffee. First time I was kin on historical part of it. This time I took a long walk, trying not to go all the time where most of tourists were. And it was a good choice. SImply walk and look around

Very Viberant. It is an incredible area. It is buzzing throughout the day. Plenty of things to do, good shopping, sightseeing, lots of restaurants, easy walking around and felt quite safe as well. We would have loved to spend a few days in the area. Very friendly people as well. Will be back some day.

Just enjoy the wandering, but beware of carpet sellers!. This is the oldest, most unique part of Istanbul. You should be staying here at the Armada Hotel! The big sights are here... the Blue mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia but also the fun little twisty lanes and ancient houses, great restaurants and yes, the carpet sellers! I got snagged when I had just arrived, jetlagged and was having a wander...I later learned it was the classic "pick-up" line...a handsome man approaches you speaking English while you are taking a photo or looking at your map. He offers to show you the Blue Mosque (or whatever), tells you he is not a tour guide just a Turkish citizen who wants you to be sure to see the Mosque because it will be closed tomorrow...or some version of that line. Off you go walking with him, he takes cuts in the huge line of tourists and in you go. After that lovely favor he has done...you says thanks, but wait! His family happens to have a carpet shop and he would like to just show you....before you can say Visa or Master card, you are having rug shipped home...which is OK if you want a beautiful rug, but if not, just stick to your wandering about. It is all very safe and if you get lost like I did, just ask anyone. It helps to carry a card from your hotel as well, so the language issue doesn't hinder you. Be sure to take water with you...it is hotter than you think and it is a lot of walking on cobblestones. You can also pop into a bar or restaurant and enjoy a tea...please don't waste your money on Turkish wine, but the Effes beer is quite good!
NICE DISTRICT. just a lovely district to visit especially with the historical places around it.I recommend to you here when you visit Instanbul

My favourite area in Istanbul. I was in Istanbul twice and both times stayed in this area, because it's beautiful, full of landmarks and good restaurants, safe and doesn't sleep late at night. If I go to Istanbul again, will stay there, too :)
We spent most of our time there. Very cute and quaint neighborhood with lots of restaurants, cafes, and stores. With all the sights to see and things to do, you could easily spend days here.

Exciting and Interesting. you could walk around this area for days, and see something wonderful and different at every turn. Food of any type you wish is available, bazaars, higher end quality shopping, mosques, museums, palace cistern, people, views.

Charming. I came in to Istanbul in a cab and as soon as we entered Sultanahmet it felt like I was in a fairytale. What a place! In the evening, lights everywhere and the smell of grilled food together with the sea. Narrow cobblestone streets, charming houses of all shapes and colors and some of Istanbul's finest monuments. In the morning, quiet before coming to life, you can only hear the breeze and the birds. I chose a hotel in this area and I'm very happy about it!

A lot to discover..... Sultanahmet is a beautiful, safe but crowed place in Istanbul. There are a lot of Restaurants and Bazaars or shops. Some of Istanbul´s most important sights are there. Men who sell roses, watermelons, fresh made pomegranate or orange juice, ice-cold water or Simit (Baked Sesame Roll...they are soo tasty) can be found everywhere. Also sweet people who sell necklaces, postcards or city guide books are all around Sultanahmet. If you go to Istanbul you definately need to go to Sultanahmet!

Chaos. Absolute chaos but it all works really well due to the efficient transport systems. This is life to the full, like it or love it.We love it. The people of Turkey are friendly.kind & very helpful.

Great area. In this area you can see the old souks including grand bazaar and sultan Ahmet mosque as well as ayasofia And all the shops sells antiques. And carpets you will not find such places any where else

A lot to see and enjoy. Apart from the excellent historic sites, this is a safe and agreeable part of Istanbul with plenty of smaller intimate corners as well as vast public spaces. There's something to buy no matter what your budget, and the merchants remain friendly and charming even when they know you're not going to give them a sale. Smile, chat with them, and gently disengage as you move on.

Old and New. In this area the old and new of Turkey can be enjoyed. The shopping is excellent, the sight seeing fabulous and then the restaurants are veeeerry nice. Visit this area to really get the feeling of Turkey at its best.

Fun to wander the Sultanahmet. I liked wandering around the Sultanahmet, especially the back streets where there were bargains. The architecture is interesting and I was surprised to see the old weatherboard buildings. One thing I didn't like was the hustlers outside restaurants. I found that by saying "I've already eaten" they stopped pushing for me to come to their restaurant.

Almost Impossible to Miss. This is where the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque are, so it is a must-see neighborhood. It is also really well done as plenty of benches and green spaces are provided near both large tourist attractions. I recommend going and sitting by the Hagia Sophia and relaxing on a bench after a long day of sightseeing. Even though there are people everywhere, it is still really relaxing.
A Byzantium experience. Warren of tiny streets, easy to get lost . . . but adventure may await around that next corner. Stop at a cafe, order a tea or an ayran, and observe.

Back to the future. Wandering and wondering around sultan haven't, thinking of ancient times, sipping Turkish coffee at a street corner after enjoying a bath at the cemberlitas hamman, what a way to spend a day, dreamy and surreal

A beautiful, historic neighborhood. Sultanahmet seems to be the most popular neighborhood for tourists in Istanbul (given the iconic sights it houses)... and rightfully so. The cobbled laneways and deep history are easy to get lost in. However, with that said, it's probably quite easy to simply stay here and spend all of your time here without exploring further. ... this would be a mistake. Sultanahmet is a delightful neighborhood but be sure to venture out and see as much of the city as possible.

Real Istanbul. Loved the area. Nice place to walk around with many restaurant options. Moreover, most of the historic and touristic options are located here and walkable. However, be careful of the many beggars and children trying to see things. We had some scary encounters with them.

Worth a walk. I went there to have a Turkish Bath. Instead of taking a cab we decided to walk, and it was worth. The neighborhood is very friendly and read to help you despite the fact almost no one speak English. Walking around we ate the best kebab ever, in a place with a window from where they sell it, and a line on the sidewalk.
Good District. Although full of tourists it was a relaxing place. We often spent evenings sitting with the locals in the park near the Blue Mosque. Plenty of restaurants to choose from.

a must see. nice side of istanbul, all main attractions are there, if you have few days it is the place to stay and see. easy to walk around (avoid traffic at all costs!!!), you can find both touristic attractions and great hidden restaurants and bars. from there you can also go visit the Bosforus but beware of the people selling the cruises close to the main attractions because you can book a two hours ferry tour for 10 turkish liras, around 4.5 euros by yourself at the ticket counter. aya sophia, blue mosque, grand bazaar and basilica cisterns are all there at 10 minutes walking radius
Walking Tour. A great place to discover on a walking tour of the back roads...away from the maddening crowds...see where the real Istanbul locals live.

What you expect from Istanbul!. I think the best place in Istanbul for tourist who looks for the real Istanbul is there. There are thousands of restaurants, hubs and bars, while they are surrounded by well preserved historical attractions, like the Blue Mosque, Haqia Sofia, Topkapi palace, Grand Bazaar and so on... Tram station with the same can get you any other places in the city. It's good idea to buy a 3 day ticket with unlimited trips instead of one trip ticket. It's much cheaper. In bazaar beware of the carpet dealers it's good to negotiate as much as you can. sometimes they offer the price three times more than the carpet actual price.
Very touristed. It's a nice area with lots of attractions, but herefore it's also a big tourist area, with prices that follows

The real Istanbul. This is where you see the real Istanbul. The markets, where they sell everything, the mix of people, restaurants and the most interesting sites to be seen. Best to visit in the mornings, before the mass of people make it impossible to walk or see much of anything.

History!!!!!!. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district in 2 different hotel. There is alot of history and sites to see everywhere you went, I would recommend that if you're in Istanbul, stay somewhere in the district

Better Than in the Movies. We debated whether to stay in this district or across the bridge. For a stay of just 4 nights, we were glad to have opted for the oldest district, not just because, coincidentally, the demonstrations in Taksim and tear gas made access to parts of the new city unpleasant or impossible. It's also quiet at night (if you are strategic about your hotel--staying near the Blue Mosque may offer a nice view, but the calls to prayer can wake the deepest sleeper), and offers easy access to most of the places one frequents.

quiet and beautifful. This district is very special. Besides the great top attractions, there are many small and quiet streets south of the blue mosque and agia sophia. Good and reasonably priced restaurants, small surprising houses, completely in wooden style.
Brilliant highlights but that's all. The highlights (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi etc) are brilliant but the area itself is dull. Don't recommend staying here, Beyoglu is much better.

great in early evening - very clean & relaxed. Busy with locals taking a stroll or relaxing on the lawns in the early evening. Enjoyed the cool of the fountains. Tour touts do approach you but are friendly & do not persist once you say that you are not interested, they do not spoil the atmosphere of the square, The new turkish baths that have just opened look very good too, so pack a costume if you fancy a try.

Where a lot of the famous sites are. Blue Mosque, Agia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern all very close - Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Galata Bridge all within reasonable walk. Felt safe even at night.

An open-air museum. This area of Istanbul is about all the big and famous sites such as Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazar, Spice Bazar and a lot of different mosques. You cannot visit Istanbul without going to this area. But please also visit other areas such as Beyoglu, Dolmabache and Ortaköy along the Bosporus.
Beautiful. We loved walking the streets and looking at all the small shops and old buildings, millions of restaurants and all the traditions is amazing. We much preferred this side of town to Taksim.

A Magical Place. This area of Istanbul is both magical and mystical for me. There is the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia and wonderful grounds with fountains along with lovely parks and benches to sit and look at the wonders of these two structures ! There are many nice eateries in the area.
Great district of Istanbul. Convenient and safe location for visiting the city and especially for around the clock access to the treasures of Istanbul from historic venues to shops and restaurants.

Oozing character. From the little streets to the rooftops bars to the amazing mosques to the Grandest of baazars sultanahmet is the place to be. Our hotel was a 2 minute walk from the blue mosque. I would advise all to stay in sultanahmet.
Easy walking... The streets are bustling with tourists and locals. Very accessible through tram and buses. A lot of good restaurants and cafes on the sidewalks.

A bit touristy but convenient and efficient. Sultanahmet is very touristy and in the face, its crowded and not something you would really likeBut at the same time it has a lot to offer and hence all of the above.The district is very convenient from a transportation and amenities point of view.Traffic both pedestrian and vehicles could get a bit crazy especially during the season.If you decide to stay in nearby hotels or pensions, expect to walk uphill most of the time, and the hotel would mostly lack an elevator.
Wonderful architecture, very old world. Loved the atmosphere. Walked for miles and enjoyed so much in this area. The people were lovely and we enjoyed many a banter with some of the shop owners

Very interesting area. The sultanahmet area is one of the most interesting site in Istanbul. I enjoyed my time so much. You can feel the history there. It was very interesting to see the local dance in some of the restaurants. The food was great too. Also you can't get enough from the antique shops especially the carpet. I strongly recommend this visit.

Beautiful Neighbourhood. This is agreat area, try to spend at least two days/nights in this area. Get immersed in the splendour of the past centuries, and enjoy the glory. Get to the Hammams to get you the relaxation.
sites, sounds, nightlife. this area of Istanbul has it all and one must visit and preferably stay in this older section of Istanbul

Touristy, but amazing!. Historic (as is most of Istanbul, it seems) neighborhoods with plenty to see while walking. Shopping, sightseeing, and more in the "old" section of Istanbul, where other absolute must-see attractions are, including Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque.

So close to all you need. Loved this area. We found it so easy to walk everywhere taking in the shops, views and atmosphere. In the area by the Blue Mosque there are numerous restaurants and a pub. If you want to find more of a cafe just for a snack, walk down towards the bosphorous where you will find more cafes and it is also a bit cheaper.
Awesome location. Overall a great location, its central to everythingThe panhandlers, and people selling stuff annoyed me at times.

Amazing Istanbul. Sultanahmet is an amazing , ancient and very interesting site. This is the historical district of Istanbul where most of the tourist sites are located. The place has great sights, good food, and friendly people. If you plan to buy souvenirs keep in mind that things are overpriced here (obviously it’s a touristy place), also the shop keepers, especially restaurants and carpet sellers, are pushy.

Busy old part of Istanbul. All the sights are within walking distance, the Hippodrome, Hagia Sofia, "Blue Mosque", Ayasofya and the Grand Bazaar. I found some of the roads steep and the cobbles hard to walk on.
Lots of food and shops. Great stroll through this area. Good pictures to take of the Sultanahment mosque and the Hagia Sophia...

MUST visit while in Istanbul!!!!!. If you do not visit he Sultanahmet District while you are traveling in Istanbul, Turkey, then one might venture to ask, why did you even come here/go there?There is something for everybody in Sultanahmet. The history and architecture is great. It is a bustling and diverse place and very close to many of the most famous attractions and sites of the city.If you can (afford it), stay in Sultanahmet, too, so you can mosey around at night and during the day and take it all in.

Beautiful place to stay!. We stayed near this district but traveled to Sultan Ahmet nearly every day as all the main attractions are here! The blue mosque, Topkapi museum, Hagia Sofia, bascila cistern are all here. Restaurants are plenty and it is a safe and friendly area.

Busy and crowded street. We stayed at the Sultanahmet street.One can easily find loads of food joints,shopping stores,souvenir shops, cafes, travel and tours etc etc......My suggestion: try to go outside this street i.e Aksraya and Findikzade. You will find the same stores and cafes and at a reasonable price. In case you plan to take a day trip to the Bosporus river then there are people standing besides the Haga Sophia church and selling the same cruise at 15 €!! we were cheated by the shops selling the same tour @ 35 €...That apart even a doner is so costly from 9-10 TL whereas 2 stops down you will get it for half the price...do not be in a hurry to shop from this street.Rather enjoy the beautiful blue mosque.Sit around and take a breath taking view of the churches and monuments....1

istanbul. A great place to visit. People are friendly. I felt safe. A lot to see and do. The Mosques are beautiful, the bizaar, the food is good. Must see the Cistern. There are many ancient artifacts. I did not take any tours but they are available. See the whirling dancers.

Not to Miss Sites in Old Town Istanbul. The Blue Mosques, Topkapi, Roman Underground Cisterns, Haga Sofia, all located within walking distance before you walk up to the Grand Bazaar. And also the most famous Hamam (bath house) is within walking distance too.

Beautiful historical part of Istanbul. We stayed in a hotel in his area for 3 days. Loved that most historical sights were walking distance. Even the spice bazaar and bosphorus cruise were a short cheap taxi ride. Great hotels of all price range from cheap B&B to the Four Seasons. Great cafes, good food, open late, very safe. Must see for first timer. Beautiful confluence of eastern and western cultures...
Perfect location for a tourist. Our hotel was located in this area as are many of the most popular tourist attractions. We felt safe walking around both day and night and there are many restaurants.

Picturesque streets. Soak up the atmosphere of historic Istanbul by wandering the streets and engaging the shop keepers. Being friendly doesn't mean that you must purchase something. When in Istanbul, do as the Turks--walk and be open to the neighborhood.

full of history. if you want to spend your time in Istanbul, this is the first place that you need to visit. Located in the historical peninsula, Sultanahmet District provides you with contemporary world and stunning history of the great city Istanbul!

Lovely area. We were there whilst "riots" were going on. We witnessed nothing at all and felt very safe. The whole area is so different to anything else or anywhere else I have been. The contrast between West and East is very noticable around Istanbul. Plenty of street vendors selling food, and lots of cafes and restaurants around. Look for ones that display their wares, then you can be sure they are all freshly cooked.

The place to stay in Istanbul. This is the place for sight seeing and eating out. Use the trams to get about and everything worth seeing is in easy reach. Only negative about being here (or elsewhere in Istanbul) is the price of wine; the tax level now makes ordinary wine cost between £22 to £35 per bottle; more than London or Paris.. but food is good value.

This area is a must for the first timer to Istanbul. Sultanahmet District with all its historical monuments like, Sultanahmet Camii, museums, Grand Old Bazaar and Byzantiinian monuments that we have seen in the last 14 visits to Istanbul, are a must for a first time visitor.
Great, safe area. Travelled as a family with child and felt very safe even at night. Lots of good, affordable restaurants. Enjoyed the Arasta bazaar.

The old Town. We stayed in the old town. This is where all the Tourist attractions can be found. It is also home to the spice market and the grand bazar. We did a walking food tour that lasted over 6 hours. You would be amazed at just how much you can actually eat in a day !

One of the better historical city centers. A great area to visit as most sights are then within walking distance and there are lots of accomdations to choose from nearby. The Turkish people are lovely especially if you take the time to learn a few words to be polite, like; merhaba, çok teşekkür ederim, lütfen, to name a few. Remember not all Turks speak English but they do their best to help you anyways especially if we show the right attitude.

Great for browsing. Take a camera as there are lots to see and do. Enjoyed the shops and browsing around all the local crafts. Watch out for the bantering salesmen. Great walking around the area - wear comfortable shoes!

Best tourist district. Within the old city walls, very accessible by tram, close to all the important attractions (including the Bosphorous, the Grand Bazaar & the Spice Bazaar), lots of hotels and restaurants, nice safe feeling walking about day & night.Two tips:- when walking around, if you get lost, make your way back to the tram line; this is a good check point. Also, when entering the Grand Bazaar, make a note of the Gate number (written on the gate archway), this will help if you get separated from other members of your party or wish to visit an area of the bazaar later. A known-numbered Gate is useful as a meeting place.

You can't miss it. This is an area all tours will go through; pretty much all roads in Istanbul eventually run through here. And rightfully so. The fountains and Hippodrome area between the Blue Mosque and St. Sophia Museum is breathtaking albeit mobbed.

Everything you want to see in walking distance. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Cistern, Arrasta Market, restaurants, sweet shops, tram, and shopping all within walking distance. A great place to stay and see
Many good food outlets. The local food is fantastic with many nice restaurants where a cold Efes was always available on hot days

Fantastic "village" in a city with so many historic sites. Not at all what I had expected of Istanbul - lovely little side streets, wooden clad houses, cobbled streets, restaurants and cafes spilling out across the pavements into the sunshine. Nothing at all like a big city. Oh and don't forget the concentration of amazing historic sites on practically every corner. Definitely the place to locate yourself if site seeing in Istanbul.
Everything You Come to Istanbul to See. This is an amazing area with mosques, The Grand Bazaar, The Spice Market, The Cistern. Just awesome how old some of this area is.
Good to walk. It is very nice district. A lots of main Istanbul attractions near.Very good restaurants with wonderful food.You can have e beer (Efes) and enjoy the view.

THE place to stay and see in Istanbul. A great area to stay as most sights are then within walking distance. Unless you are not okay with walking a couple of blocks uphill, don't worry about staying on the top of the hill or at the bottom as the entire area is quite small. The people here are lovely as they are in all of Turkey! Thank you to all the Turks we met as you are wonderful; so warm, friendly, helpful and hospitable.

wonderful maybe too touristic. this area is really amazing. elegant and full of nice shops and restaurants. maybe too toristic but it's inevitable considering that it's located in one of the best area of the city

busy market area. its a busy area with lots of eatery shops spice market and the grand bazaar . What i did not like was that the eatery pull you and nag you to come and have a meal with them it becomes impossible to walk on the streets peacefully

The place to stay. If you have a few days in Istanbul and need to find a location to stay where everything is walking distance, with the most important sites nearby including the Grand Bazaar - this is the answer.
Good shopping and historical place. a bit dusty but overall extremely interesting. No need to pay for a tour. Take a map and walk!..the best way to see the old center.
Great location containing key sights. Although a network of trams and buses makes the city easy to transverse. The concentration of historical sights in this area is a boon for travellers!

Hustle and bustle of shops and restaurants. Had lots of lovely walks in the residential areas and saw the locals (away from the tourist hot spots). Lots of local and tourist shops and wonderful restaurants. The busiest place is near the Tramway where the money exchange places are and local fast food and sit down restaurants.
May 2013 Stay. It was our 2nd time in Istanbul and we love to stay in this area with most major sites within walking distance. The restaurants are plenty and most are good.

The hub of old Istanbul.. It's the area where the main tourist sights including The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar and the Basilica Cisterns. You can easily walk to all plus numerous restaurants and cafes and shops.

Historic & Exotic. The Sultanahmet district in Istanbul is where all the action and sights are centrally located. With some research and travel books, one can easily navigate and tour the sights without a formal tour. Most sites offer audio guides for a fee, although not essential. When cruise ships are in port, the various sites can get over-whelmingly busy. Museum pass allows for entry to multiple historic sites, buildings and museums. Restaurants and vendors are everywhere, the merchants can get somewhat aggressive, trying to get your attention. Turkish delight is a very tasty treat not to be missed. The entire area is walkable and safe during the day.

Sultanahmet..... Was there during May....lots of things to do and see with loads of historical sites. Loved everyday of our stay. We stayed at a hotel that was centrally located. Done visits and sights in the morning. Returned to our hotel for a couple of hours (siesta) and went out again for the rest of the evenings. Lots of restaurants to choose from. We ventured out to the residential ares to see some real life living and came across some really friendly people. I salute the Turks for being so friendly and welcoming. just one piece of advice...Walk to all places as all attractions are nearby...just follow the tram line and you'll never get lost. Loved the place and will visit again.

ancient and historic site. apart from the top atttractions such as blue mosque, hagia sofia, topcapi, basilica cistern and grand bazaar, this district gives you an aura of the past. many of the buildings are hundreds of years of age and is one of the most visited in istanbul. food is easy as there are so many restaurants available along the road. traveling from the airport is hassle free using the train and tram.
For locals and tourists. I liked the market which locals where buying Cafè and also tourists were shopping. Very nice landscape and overview over the see and bridge.
The most amazing part of Istanbul. Pay attention to the ques in every station in the old city. It is better to have a Istanbul visit card
Sultanahmet. a lot of history in a small area. Loved the Sultanahmet square. The food was amazing and there is so much to see and do. Istanbul revolves around this area and Taksim Square

Beautiful Are to Visit. We stayed in this area and felt very safe. There are lots of places to eat and lots of friendly people to get to know. Most speak English and other languages as well. It is easy to communicate.

Have plenty of time. Plenty to do in the area. All within walking distance. Blue mosque is a def. boat trip wasn't what I expected but does give you a pretty view of the city for two hours. The light show on my trip was the street lights and bridge lights coming on at night???? Not how they sell it. A short walk up from the blue mosque is the grand bazaar. Leave plenty of time for that and remember to haggle. With some items I offered a fifth of what they said and managed to purchase. Over 5500 stalls. Remember to check out mehmet pasha too.. Beautiful city x
Great food and sights. The area is packed with so many great restaurants, shops, and walking distance to all of the great historical areas of Istanbul. It can get quite busy with tourists.

The place you want to be. Pretty much everything you want to see in Istanbul is in this district. Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, and the tram that will take you everywhere else you want to go runs through the district as well. You will want your hotel to be in the Sultanahmet district. But do watch out for pickpockets and the shoeshine scammers.

BEST district for walking/exploring as so much it there to see. spent 2 nights on this side of the Bosporus and liked it for the proximity to most sights including the main mosques, the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market and the Turkish bath house we went to and

A great area to stay. With all the best tourist attractions in the area it is a good place to stay. The quieter smaller cobbled streets have some excellent boutique hotels to stay in with an easy walk to the attractions.

if you like to walk. Traversing the old Hippodrome and the region between the Blue Mosque and Haghia Sophia in the early morning is wonderful. The nearby Islamic Museum and its tea garden as well as others throughout the area make for a pleasant start to any day. Do this before the crowds start to gather from the tour companies. You get a sense of ancient Byzantium and old Istanbul since this was the center of life for thousands of years. You will not be disappointed. Don't mind the book sellers. Be nice and joke with the young men and you will truly have a time to remember. Remember, they are trying to make a living as well.

Good place to start understanding Istanbul. This area has all the important sites and a must visit to Istanbul. The only drawback is the touts that roam the areas preying on tourists. To avoid this, it is advisable to arrange for a guide through your hotel or join one of the tours.

Home of wonderful architecture and rich history. This historic district is home to some of the most wonderful architecture and history in the world and easily accessible by the tram. Sadly that is also the reason it is so congested - thousands of tourists and tour groups/buses converge in this part of town. Line ups to see the sites can be long and if it is a hot day, exhausting. Fortunately there are some lovely shaded parks to relax in. Get to where you want to go EARLY (before 9:30)- and consider buying the Museum Pass which is 72TF and good for 72 hrs. You can bypass most of the line ups using the pass- Note the Pass is not good at the Bascila Cistern. And be ware of helpful, very friendly people - they want to sell you a rug! Some are very persistent and after 3 days of this, we really, really had enough!

great, but watch out for the touts. this is the exciting historic centre of the city- a range of accommodation and restaurants etc to suit a variety of traveler's needs, and excellent transport links by tram and ferry - a perfect base for a stay in Istanbul.We did grow a little tired of the "harassment" by the touts, trying to sell themselves, or carpets, trips, books, meals etc. It was a pity that we couldn't simply stand or sit in a place for a short while without having to deal with unwelcome requests to shake our hands and/or answer questions about where we were from and how they could help us... such a pity to doubt everyone's motives and integrity in such a beautiful place .

The heart of the old Istanbul. LIfe is sweet in this district. Everything is close at hand, interesting winding streets that are not overwhelming with skyscrapers or vendors. Easy walks to primary sights, restaurants, shops. Buy some food at the local shops, take it to your hotel roof and watch the sun set over the city and sea!
Busy & Lots of Street Peddlers. Great foods and sites but street peddlers aggressivness can be annoying. Young women, be prepared for vendors to flirt with you until you buy their products.
excellent... looks like u r in India actually . same bustling steets, street vendors and lots of nnoise and people. beutiful opn palces to sit and enjoy and soak in the history

Plenty to see and do. Loved being able to wander around and see the tourist areas at my own paceVery easy going around this area. I felt safe at all times.Some people could annoy you but just be polite and keep walking

Amazing vibe. The Sultanahmet District is easily reached by Tram and features major attractions such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Grand Bazar and Tokapi Palace, all in walking distance of each other. One could spend days exploring that area alone. Despite being crowded it felt safe. We truly loved sightseeing there. One word of caution, and this goes for the city in general, watch where you are stepping on the sidewalks! The stumbling possibilities are endless, from bricks that stick up, to sudden stairs, to caved in hollows and holes, to weird metal clasps sticking out...we've never seen so many tripping traps.
10/10 - restaurants and shopping!!. Make sure your hotel is situated here or near here... itscentral to all things to see and all restaurants and shopping are based here. its a great central hub...

A Place I Like. Being to Istanbul nine time for different purposes, (business, family vacation, solo), this is the place where I like spending my free time in. Walking around, having a coffee or smoking nargilé are activities I enjoy there. Surrounded by more than 2000 years of heritage, I enjoy the streets, the architecture and watching people enjoying the place
All the main things to visit are here. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Suleymaniye Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar and Egyptian bazar. Full of restaurants, in Eminonu you can take Bosphorous tours

Beautiful area. The best location for the major sights of old Istanbul, it's a beautiful area with lots to do. The Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace & Grand Bazaar are all located in or near this area.

The Greenwich Village of Istanbul--with Mosques. Just great walking around here. Millions of shops and restaurants, many beautiful mosques, too many vendors in your face (like in Beijing) but you get used to it. There are new(ish) areas, very old and decrepit areas, many small twists and turns- and all of it very interesting and a little more exotic than Europe. Five times a day you hear the call to prayer over loudspeakers, which is actually pretty cool. You can stop anywhere for an apple tea ("chai" is tea here) or an Efes (beer), although some restaurants don't serve alcohol. Tons of little shops selling rugs, tiles, scarves. Everyone has a relative in America, and everyone has prices that you'll never believe -- you're always "the first customer of the day" so you get a very special price. You can usually get them down about 80% just by not being interested. A few streets will take you to the seashore, which is undeveloped but has big rocks you can sit on, and great views. After a day or so it becomes very comfortable and a great place to walk around at any time, from early morning to late night.

Vibrant and busy. I loved this place. People from all walks of life everywhere. The sightseeing is amazing. You can spend hours sat on one of the many benches watching the world go by and still be entertained. Steeped in fascinating history.

Walk till you drop!. The Sultanahmet (old city) area in Istanbul is THE place to stay. You're right in the tourist Mecca here and can visit all the main sites (think postcards of Istanbul) on foot. If you get lost, which you probably won't, a friendly local will help you out. From the old city you can easily walk down to the quieter waterfront and stroll for kilometres along a pretty esplanade. Back in the old city there's cafes, restaurants, street food, ATMs, tour shops, souvenir shops (cheap or expensive), carpet and leather sellers, little hotels and a myriad of other wares and it seems every one of them has a person standing out front trying their very best to coax you inside theirs. This may get a little overwhelming, but politeness goes a long way when dealing with these guys and so does a bit of good humour. We spent the best part of five days roaming the squares and little alleys of Sultanahmet and loved every minute.

Vivid and wonderfull. When you go to Istanbul be sure you have to go on Sultanahmet cause all the day life and history is there...The monuments,the life,shops(more cheeper than Grand Baazar) and good hotels :D It"s unbelivable!! If you don"t go you haven"t seen most important things...Unique experience :D

My favorite place to stay in Istanbul. Sultanahmet doens't have the energy or excitement of Taksim but I prefer it for the great attractions of the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Cistern and relaxing atmosphere.

Fab is the word. Very lively, Very colourful, Very vibrant with restaurants, blue mosque, hagyasofya and basilica cisterns all in stone's throw distance. Nice park in front of the blue mosque where you can just relax in the evening or after dinner with a slice of watermelon or corn on the cob watching the blue mosque in the moonlight... bliss :)

Charming and friendly. There's something charming about the way the locals will strike up a conversation with anyone strolling along the streets of the district. (The only downside is that it is difficult to stay on schedule and I missed a boat tour because I was too busy chatting.)The boutique hotels are lovely and the food choices are incredible! The shopping opportunities are endless - from inexpensive trinkets to the finest in jewellery and carpets. There's definitely something of interest for every traveller.Take your time visiting the area and you won't be disappointed. If you accept the offer of a Turkish tea or coffee and spend some time talking with the locals, you'll have a new friend for life!

Have at least two to three days for Sultanahmet. Plenty to see - Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Hagia Sofiya, Grand Bazaar, Basilica Cistern, mosques and tombs. 15 minute walk to Galata, river cruise and Spice Bazaar. Plenty of eateries, gift shops

Historical, beautiful but.... Wife and I really wanted to see the blue mosque, ayasofya and a few other historical landmarks which landed us in the Sultanahmet area. It's chock full of sites. But after 2 days, we had to get out there because of the hoards of people, fighting off restaurant owners, tour operators, etc. It's like Times Square: historical but with terrible food, overpriced everything and loads of tourists. 2 days was enough for us

Get location for first time visitors to Istanbul. If visiting Istanbul for the first time I recommend a hotel here. It's close to all the sites. There is never a dull moment.Sight seeing, the Bosphorous, shopping and just roaming through the narrow streets - a tourist must. Spent 3 days on my own and felt safe - only one unsavory incident with a taxi driver trying to charge 3 times the regular fare... My recommendation for solo female travellers and taxis is to go to the closest hotel and request a cab from there. You're less likely to get a dodgy taxi driver.

Loads to do and see in Istanbul. We recently spent 4 days in Istanbul and 3 of them in this area. Besides the great mosques, grand bazaar, spice market and other historic attractions, please take the time to wonder the narrow streets. This is where you will get a great feel for this incredible city and learn more about its culture and history. The locals are extremely friendly, happy to help with directions and are eager to please. We walked everywhere and found the most incredible markets, stores, baklava and Turkish delight!Loved our visit!

so much to marvel at. Planning a short break? Sultanahmet will keep you busy. Blue Mosque, Haghia Sofia, the Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Arasta Bazaar, Museum of Mosaics, the Hippodrome, the Archeological Museum, Gulhane Park, and Green Corner Cafe for a break.

Stay and Play Here!. My boyfriend and I stayed in this bustling tourist husband it's proximity to most of the big sites, transit and the waterfront can't be beat! You will see lots of cats, have lots of opportunities to shop and be so close to every attraction, you will save precious time to enjoy your visit!

Old City. Staying in Sultanahmet provides the opportunity to walk to the blue Mosque, The Hippodrome and the Hagia Sofia while mingling with tourists and locals. We made our first purchase in Turkish Lira from a tiny convenience store. Everyone was friendly and pleasant.

Nice place for tourists. This place is specially prepared for tourists, I saw many many places in Istanbul and nowhere is like here. This place is a great show of ancient buildings in a modern city. I liked this place but just keep in mind that this is not the real face of Istanbul. Also, do not eat in restaurants of this district, just walk about 5 minutes beside the railway and just after the Gulhane tram station you can find several better restaurants.

The place to be!. We did a few tours in Istanbul and we had the opportunity to see other areas from our bus, and we reconfirmed what we thought when we first arrived: Sultanahmet is THE PLACE to stay when you go to Istanbul! It is so easy to get around on foot, there are lots of shops and restaurants, hotels for every budget, all kinds of wonderful historical sites, and everybody is so friendly! Aww we just loved it! You cannot go wrong if you choose to stay in the Sultanahmet district.

Easy to navigate, everything nearby. There are many options for staying in Istanbul. For our first experience, I am really glad we stayed in this touristy area, as it set us within walking distance of the top things on our list. That Sultanahmet is touristy does not mean that it is without local flavor. We rented apartments down the hill to the south of the sites, in one of the neighborhood strips. This added a special flare to our experience with fruit vendors passing by in the morning and utilizing corner shops for groceries, etc. again, for our first experience, staying in Sultanahmet was important. We would probably consider other options for our next visit.Some tips for staying in Sultanahmet:1. Look into renting apartments. This saved us a ton of cash as we could cook our own meals. And it gave us a lot more room to spread out.2. Expect hills. Up, up, up.3. Don't be afraid of the tram. It passes right through Sultanahmet with a stop near the Constantine Tower, as well as Hagia Sophia, and down by the water near the Bosphorus tour boats and Egyptian Bazaar. 4. There is a Starbucks on the main road in Sultanahmet, between the Hagia Sophia and the Constantine Tower.

Great Place to Explore. This historic area has so much to offer and it's great that everything is so easily accessible by walking. I was surprised that all the sights were much closer than they appeared to be on the map. Loved staying in and seeing this area of Istanbul.

Worth getting lost. Actually I was expecting to get lost in the labyrinth of streets but didn't. The tram always proved to be our life line. Do get off the main roads and sites and visit the areas that have not been gentrified. Will these areas last. Often we'd see older home next to renovated boutique hotels.

This area is relatively safe and friendly. We stayed in the Tan Hotel in this district. We felt that the neighborhood is relatively safe and the local people are friendly. Even with the restaurants, they are not as aggressive as other tourist places in trying to get you in. Politeness works. There are many restaurants but food quality varies.

Had my doubts but.... I'm glad we stayed in this area. Myers, a fair portion of it is very touristy but so what? It's all part of the experience!! You get tons of choices for clothes, foods, gifts, transport etc and not ALL parts are touristy.... You can get cheap stuff if you look. If coming for the first time, stay here, but next time stay elsewhere.

Terrific location. We stayed in this district for our 3 days in Istanbul. We had never been there before and really didn't know where to stay. We are really glad we chose this. It is a terrific location for seeing the most popular tourist 'hot spots' in Istanbul. We were able to walk to everywhere we wanted to go or to the tramline that took us to the waterfront for the Bosphorus tour. We could have spent the whole 3 days in the Grand Bazaar! But we didn't :)It is most important to wear good, comfortable walking shoes. Many of the roads are cobblestone and some are a bit hilly, so comfy shoes are a must.Yes, it can be a bit annoying to have men constantly touting for business, but they are just doing what they need to do. We quite often joked with them in response to their light-hearted flirting. Most of the people we came across were very friendly and everyone we met, spoke English.There are plenty of restaurants and cafes with reasonably priced meals.If you only have a short time in Istanbul, this is the place to stay and visit.
The right place to stay and explore Istanbul. if you wanna explore the real Istanbul then staying at the Sultanahmet district is the only organic and most convenient place to stay and explore.

People Watching. As much as we enjoyed the the amazing tourist sites in this district, we loved to watch the multitude of tourists and locals streaming by as we sat on benches in the square. The spring time display of tulips was outstanding. Of particular note was the antics of the ice cream vendor promoting his resistant to melting product.

Please accept it for what it is.. This area contains the major tourist sites all within walking distance eg Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazzar, the Tokpai Palace etc etc. It is clogged with tourists all year. There is block after block of souvenir shops and hotels and restaurants, all with annoying touts so do not lose your sense of humour. Once you accept this you can relax and revel in the colourful,lively chaotic nature of Istanbul. And areas like Askaray are only a couple of tramstops away where you can shop till you drop without a souverir shop in site. Viva Istanbul!!
A must visit ..... a concentration of sites and restaurants here. Important landmarks in every direction. Excellent restaurants and cafes all around ..... a must see!

A world to experience. We spent 8 days in Istanbul and had a great time.we stayed at yusufpasa hotel , our hotel had a beautiful view of Marmara sea and old homes of IstanbulEven though the distance to sultanahmet historical places was no more than 20 minutes distance , we had to ascend a hilly street .there is a great restaurant row nearby the hotel that could be reached by walking 200 yards up the hill. English is spoken in most shops, hotel , restaurant , but knowing some Turkish words will help with taxi drivers . One thing they won't tell you , is that he area is connected with narrow alleys where taxi drivers do not like to go , even though we met some honest taxi drivers but couple of them would refuse to drop us of I front f our hotel. Good news is that Istanbul has plenty of clean restrooms for only one Turkish lira (70 cents).With all the great hospitality and good food, you are face with numerous cigarette smokers who are polluting the air including the inside of hotel, bazaar , restaurants , front of the shops etc.Do not start a conversation with shop salesmen if you do not want to buy otherwise they won't leave you alone.Having plenty of Turkish lira will help , you can get a better rate at the exchange office ( not banks)' they do not change money!!!!!!.The food in the restaurants are goo but little pricy , we were very disappointed on our return trip, the airport was hotter than hell at 3 am . Automated dispensing machine was in Turkish And accepted only credit card to purchase water or soda.Good news , there was plenty of porters who were happy to help with the luggages for 10 lira

Ruined!. This area in the heart of the old city was my least favorite neighborhood in Istanbul. In my opinion, it's completely ruined by carpet/kilim/jewlery/tourist shops and tour buses as far as the eye can see. The only good time to visit this area is early in the morning before the tour buses and hordes of package tourists show up and ruin the atmosphere. One day is enough to see the obligatory sites. I preferred staying in Galata, Taksim, and even Sirkeci (which still has a sliver of realness) than Sultanahmet.

If it is your first visit, this is the place!. If you are visitng Istanbul for the very first time, you should not hesitate to stay at this old neighborhood. This is the timeless Istanbul, where the most iconic sites in the city can be discover by foot! You actually have the tram to go everywhere in this area, as other parts of the city too. Istanbul offers great means of transportation options. Sultanahmd is: great mosques, palaces, bizantium, roman and ottoman legacy, good restaurants, nice shops, safe, clean and very turkish!

Old City. Majority of places to visit are all found in the Sultanahmet district.The Blue Mosque, The Hagia Sophia, The Basilica Cistern, Museum of Turkish & Islamic Arts, Hippodrome and the fountains of Sultanahmet square are all located here.Excellent place to visit, relax and watch thw qorld go by. Lots of nice places to sit and relax.

Best location. The Sultanahmet District is the old city and houses so many of the famous buildings for which Istanbul is famous, the Blue Mosque, Hagis Sophia, Topkapi Palace and of course the Grand Bazaar. The tram runs right through the middle and a ride to anywhere costs only 3 TL. Full of laughter and smiling faces.
Good area to stay. Walking distance to all attractions and restaurants. Felt safe walking at night. Direct drive from airport.
bustling hub!!. quaint, old world charm and simply lovely. great place to just walk around...stop at street side cafes and sample food. just lovely

Old city of Istanbul is full of history. This neighbourhood of Istanbul is full of spectacular sites such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Basillica Cistern and others, all in walking distance from each other. Many restaurants, cafe's and shops make this area a very pleasant one to discover during your Istanbul city trip.

As you think Istanbul would be.. Narrow streets, interesting people, wonderful shops and restaurants; this is Istanbul as you imagine it would be. Walking is the only way to see the district and its not that big although very uneven and hilly. I noticed traffic signs but the local drivers don't seem to see them, when walking don't assume traffic will come from a logical direction! Difficult place to eat badly if you go for the local dishes, restaurant front men are vocal but not overly pushy compared with other places in Turkey/Greece. That said its a great place to eat, just take your time when choosing where to stop. When we were there major work was ongoing which will make walking much easier but cobbles are an issue. Cash machines are plenty full and all shops seem to take plastic so no need to carry large amounts of cash. I would say a minimum 3 day full day stay, but it can be done in less if you plan well - but who plans that well & wandering is part of the charm of the area. Safe feeling when out, day or night but minimum police presence was evident. A must visit destination.
Everything close. The best part about the Sultanahmet District is how many attractions are so close and easy to walk to. Also easy to get to tram and good restaurants.

Crazy crowded on a Saturday! Definitely worth a visit. OK, So I tried to stick in a visit on a long layover in Istanbul. I didn't take the traffic jams to and from the Airport (S. Gokcen) to town into account. An hour and a half each way for the HAVATAS shuttle bus (13 TL each way). The shuttle takes you to the Takses neighborhood - very fashionable broad and long shopping street. On the 4 km walk to the Sultanahmet district I found the crowds - on mainly local people very impressive. It took 2 hours to walk 4 km!Great shops and resturaunts. At the Spice Market - the crowds became impossible to transverse. I think early morning might be a better bet - or midweek....Definitely a city to visit - but use the public transport to get around!Plan to take it slow!
Bustling. You get a little hassle but not on the scale of Morocco. Better priced ( and qulaity ) restaurants can be found on the fringes.
Picturesque. Lots of little shops and restaurants to browse or just grab a roasted corn and people watch. Wear your walking shoes though lots of hills to climb.

A Must Visit. How can anyone come to Istanbul and not visit this area--it is the heart of Istanbul. Yes, it is crowded and the traffic is incredible but that IS Istanbul. I would not even think about driving here when public transportation is so good. All, or at least most of the historical sights are in this area. The tram is crowded, watch your purse, but incredibly cheap (3TL). The people try to be helpful in getting to your destination. There is great shopping and eating. Please do not be discouraged from a visit to Sultanahmet area,

You'll love it. The Sultanahmet District is a fun place to see historical monuments, have great food and meet interesting people. Its very crowded during the day and is amazing late in the evening. You might want to prepare yourself to deal with pushy restaurant agents.
Old Town. If I were to return to Istanbul, I will still choose to stay in Sultanahmet District. Rich in Culture.

Traffic Nightmare, Walking is Great. This area of town is a walkers paradise but a driving nightmare (even in a cab). Even the tram system is packed for most of the hours of the day, so throw on your best walking shoes and get out and explore.Downside, LOTS of tourist paying too much for average quality food. Upside, a little investigation off the beaten track leads you to some wonder finds.

Vibrant during the day and the night. This area of Istanbul is fascinating for a tourist. Many of the old Ottoman wooden houses have been changed into hotels and tourist shops but a sense of the past mixed with a vibrant present pervades the place. It is fascinating walking around this area during the day with its busy street life or sitting in a cafe in the evening playing backgammon while having a drink. The streets are really too small for the flow of traffic that tries to force its way thorugh but almost every other doorway seems to have a cat just lazing around.
Nice area. Liked this central location. Lively. Safe. In fact Istanbul felt very safe everywhere. Restaurants. Use the restaurants off the main tourist streets as much cheeper

Great place to wonder. but, be forewarned that you will be beset upon by every carpet seller in Istanbul...lol. We tried to escape one who attached himself to us by going down in the Basilica Cistern but there he was outside waiting for us. There was no escaping him. Instead of being nice tourists, we just had to firmly say NO.

Fabulous sights, ugly crowds. Can the Turkish government figure a way to crowd one more cruise ship into this port. These areas were doubtlessly incredible 12-15 years ago. Now absolutely spoiled by impenetrable crowds and endless lines. Be prepared to be jostled by tour groups with their rude guides.
Lovely to wander around. A lovely characterful district, with the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and plenty of cafes and restaurants.
Tourist central. This area is very much tourist central with many eating places and shops targeting the visitor. It is a lively and bustling area reflecting Turkey's thriving economy.

Has to be seen!. so many culture and so many people living peacefully togheter! The bazaar is huge, the mosques beautiful, in the middle of the "normal" houses. Very nice the other part of the Blu Mosque, near the train station.

Walked for miles, Always felt safe. If you are a shopper and like the thrill of bargaining this is the place. The Grand Bazaar and the adjoining area leaves thousands of shops unseen after several days of trekking around. If you see your prize in another shop, don't ask the price because it is usually less. Be happy and keep going.

Interestng area. This is a very interesting area. The hotel being walking distance added to the overall experience. Interesting area with all the vendors, food carts etc. Late eve I think is the best time.

THE MOST CHARMING AREA in İSTANBUL. I've been there so many times as a local and never bored.
