Besides the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, Covered Bazaar, the Basilica Cistern the houses of Soğukçeşme Sokağı, the garden of the Green House, the Four Season's hotel once used as a prison and the magnificient view of its terrace, other smaller but historical mosques and monuments, availability of exploring other historical places, the old town and the most lively parts of İstanbul such as Eminönü on foot, in brief breathing this old and vibrant district and everything there charms me. Only negative thing i can say for travellers with younger kids is that there are no playgrounds. Just beside the Blue Mosque there is a big green area with banks where street sellers offer you everything even tea! and there, kids can feed the birds. But there are no restaurants offering activities for younger kids or any other attractions that younger kids can enjoy except the month of Ramadan. Although not in walking distance not very far from the place there is Feshane in Eyüo which is a well designed lunapark by the sea. Younger kids can enjoy there.
Impressive clean and safe tourist area. We just loved this area with many local venders selling roasted chesnuts and fresh pomagranite juice. Get there early before the tour buses decend upon you!

Stay here!. Our hotel was located in the Sultanahmet District and it was a great choice. So close to everything you want to see! Great sights, great restaurants, easy walk to anything. The tram is also an easy way to get around, though it can be a bit crowded.
A must see. Off the main streets is a must do! You see a lot more of the REAL Istanbul when you veer away from the 'Tourist' areas. Recommend you take a look.

Old City Charm. I loved Sultanahmet. If it is your first time to Istanbul, I would highly recommend that you spend at least a day or two walking about - all the main tourist attractions are in walking distance. I avoided the constant calls to join the tourist buses (even when offered tours for free) and just stayed on foot, despite a pretty good public transport system. Ignore the constant calls for your attention (especially if you are a woman travelling alone, though some comments will definitely make you laugh) and explore the city safely. Some of the side-streets off the main strip of Divan Yolu have lovely eateries at very reasonable prices. And the currency exchange offices all along the street have reasonable exchange rates too. I found that having Turkish lira rather than euros made things easiest.

Cağaloğlu Hamamı. If you are looking for a great experience for a massage in the Sultanahmet area Do Not Go to the Cağaloğlu Hamamı. It is the biggest rip-off. Euro 60 is charged for a 10 minute experience including a weak body wash & massage. As well as the rip-off for the massage, as for common courtesy to enable you to relax afterwards Turkish tea should be served at no extra charge.To add insult to injury you Will Be Charged for the tea!

lots to see. Easy to reach with public transportation. Get an Istanbulkard and load with money for easy use and saving money with each trip. Lots to see and eat but great that we didn't stay in this area. To congested. Stay in Taksim square area.
The place to be. For visitors this is the only location to stay and play... most of the major historcial attractions, good restaurants, good hotels and shopping.

The perfect place to stay. The Sultanahmet District is the perfect place to stay in Istanbul as it is the home of most of the attractions you will want to see. The Hagia Sofia, the Hippodrome, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cisterns, Grand Bazaar, and many other attractions are all within easy walking distance, as well as fabulous restaurants!

The place to be in Istanbul. Love how many amazing architectural treasures you can see is such a small area in this District, including the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the underground Cisterns, bazaars, street vendors and many colorful people, restaurants and shops.
we stayed in this area. great hotels..we rented an apt in this area on vrbo...was flawless and lots of restaurants and markets everywhere... we loved this area..

The epitome of Istanbul. Sultanahmet area is bustling with people of all nationalities and traders of thousands goods. Go there and experience the essence of Istanbul. Do not miss the pomegranate juices, the sweetness of Turkish Delights, the various taste of Turkish cuisines, buy cheap souveniers along the way, get yourself a t shirt of Istanbul and do mot forget to post a postcard to your love ones. Sultanahmet is definitely not a place to miss. It defined Turkey and it is no doubt the pulsating heart of Istanbul.
A must see area to visit. Got to be seen plenty of safe walking areas and seating especially around the Blue Mosque/square, great water features
The place to be in Istanbul. The Hotel (Erguvan) we stayed in was an easy walk to mayor sights, and there were plenty of hotels in the area to choose from.

Sultanahmet. Safe, clean, geared for tourists, plenty to eat, plenty to feast the eyes on. All the great tourist sites close at hand. Overheard conversation between a Brazilian and a Romanian: 'The Turks trust is. Thousands come here but you see hardly any police.' I did not see a single police person in Sultanahmet though there was a police car parked discreetly near a corner, and there is a large Tourist Police office near the Cistern. I thought they were redundant!

My wife calls this area going Home. We have travelled to Istanbul many times and as we arrive my wife aways remarks this feels like coming home. This area is the cradle of civilisation full of history and good restuarants.

Great lively and energetic place. Grand bazar, Spice bazar, Trams, Many mosques, Icecreams parlours, Doners Kebabs and Sheesha cafe, what a justaposition, modern, traditional and cultural. I loved the every minute I stayed there. Take walk to Grand bazar from Blue Mosque to get a real feel of Sultan Ahmet district.

In the thick of everything. Very noisy and congested, but best place to stay (for short visits) to see the main tourist sites of The Blue Mosque, The Topkapi Palace and Aya Sofia.
Restaurants expensive because so touristy

Beware of 50L scam!. Be very careful when paying for cabs or goods, particularly with a 50L note. We were two couples in the city for a long weekend. When paying for tickets to see the Whirling Dervishers, my friend handed over 150L for 4 tickets. The young man pointed out to her that she was 45L short. She duly gave him the additional money, thinking that she had made a mistake. The following day I handed a 50L to a cab driver for a 40L fare. He then waved a 5L note at me saying that I hadn't given him enough. He actually started to shout at me and was casting his eyes skyward. My friend then aid him the fare. It was only after we had gotten out of the cab that I realised that I had been scammed. We then realised that my friend had also been had! They swap the 50L for 5L as they are both virtually the same colour and the printed 5 is the same. Make sure you look at the note and point out that it is a 50L.

The place to stay. The Sultanahmet district just fill you with history, you are in walking distance to the Grand Bazar, Hagia Sophia, and a lot of fashion shops. The tram brings you around the city and is often faster then a taxi. Secondly it is only 30 - 45 minutes for Atatürk Airport.

A great place to stay!. There is so much to see here. Besides the obvious wonderful old buildings and culture, there is the street life, the restaurants, the crazy narrow streets where vehicles, including buses, seem to manoeuvre with ease. I loved staying here. The tram line and ferries work really well to get you to other places as well, so from a fascinating place to stay, you can still access the other interesting areas of Istanbul. What a place. I can't wait to go back.
Nicest area to visit. probably the nicest area to visit, THe spice market is awsome. The grand bazaar I found too commercial

Istanbul at its Best. This is the heart of Istanbul. Whilst we were staying in the Nisantasi district this is the heart of Istanbul. You haven't visited Istanbul if you haven't strolled this district and seen the main sites. Soak up the atmosphere because this place is unique.

The old city. This is the area that most people thnk of as Istanbul. It is the home of the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the underground cisterns the Hippodrome,, the archeological museum and Topkapi Palace. The tram system stops at Sultanahmet station from which you can access all of these sites. It is a wonderful mixture of ancient wonders, restaurants, shops, mosques, parks, and the best people watching in the world. From here you can take the tram to Eminou (Egyptian spice market, Galata bridge and ferries to Europe) or up to Beyazit and the Grand Bazaar. Sultanahmet will have you clicking photos all day long. At night the view of the Blue Mosque is awe inspiring. You will be offered tour books, Bosphorus boat cruises, rugs, whirling dervish shows and the memories of a lifetime. It is clean and easy to navigate.

Perfect location for a long weekend. All the main attractions in Istanbul such as the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar and Topkapi Palace are located in this area. As is the river cruise on the Bosphorus. All within working distance. Lots of places to eat and drink. Team available for a small fee to go further afield if wished.

The heart of the Old City. If you come to Istanbul, the Old City is one of the key areas visited by tourists. With the large number of historical sites and the amazing number of shops, it is easy to get overwhelmed there. That's why we chose to stay in the Sultanahmet District, as well as to do most of our shopping and eating there. The convenience of being able to walk to everything is really great and it allows you to space out your touring -- especially given the long lines of people you will likely encounter during your stay there. All in all, a great place!
Great place to stay and walk around and enjoy local restaurant and bars.... Local restaurant and small bar to sit and have a local beer "Efes" when washing people passing by...

Glad our hotel was here. We weren't sure which part of Istanbul to stay in because I read that there is no nightlife in Sultanahmet. Not true...lots of places to get drinks and hangout, Akbiyik Street near the Blue Mosque had tons of bars. Easy walking to all in Sultanahmet, including Grand Bazaar and the popular tourist sites.

A place to be. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica cistern, grand Bazaar are among some of the sites you must visit in Istanbul and all lies there. The district is always renovated and besides the landmarks has many coffee shops and nice restaurants. Also you can easily go there by tram

Interesting and rich districtyof Istanbul. Very picturesque place to be in Istanbul. Lots of local stores, buildings, people. It really gives you an insight of the soul of this city.
Be prepared to be seduced by local handicraft.
Transport is rather difficult and if you are not nearby, be prepared for an extremely crowded tram or lots and lots of traffic. But it's definitely worthwhile.

Fascinating. Just go to soak up the atmosphere of this amazing city.So much to see and do in such a small area.It is busy but it is so friendly that you can walk around and feel safe even late at night.Expect some hastle in the Bazaar but smile ,be polite and carry on walking if you do not want to buy anything.

The Place to be. For visitors, the place to be is the old town, Sultanahmet. There are many hotels from the Four Seasons to boutique charmers to inexpensive and downright cheap lodgings. Even for us (mature travelers), the tourist destinations were all within walking distance. The restaurants served good Turkish food The police have increased their plainclothes presence and it was very safe to stroll the streets at night. Most of the restaurants have a choice of inside or rooftop dining terraces (4-5 stories high) and the views are amazing. At one very reasonable restaurant (Tamara), it seemed like you could reach out and touch the Blue Mosque and its six minarets.
Location, location. Excellent location for tourists visiting Istanbul.The area has good restaurants, hotels and bazaars. Many vendors and service people speak English.

Perfect area to stay when in Istanbul. We like being able to walk everywhere. All the main attractions are here and there are many restaurants to choose from. It's magical being so close to the two mosques and hearing the call to prayer.

Explore and go local!. The district has so much old architectural beauties that you'll discover more by foot.. Getting lost is the keyword to discover here.. Local small restaurants turn out to be favorite spots to savor local taste at local price.. Unfortunately, it's a bit frustrating that at such touristic area, we found not many English-speaking locals.. Love the Adana & Iskander kebab! Prices vary from 7 to 12 Turkish Lira/portion for above food with tasty presentation.. Not bad at all, I believe.. :)

Very safe and close to everything. We stayed in this area for 4 nights and felt totally safe. There is bars and restaurants within 500m and it's super close to town if you want a bigger selection of food. It's also very close to the waterfront.
market shopping. offer 40% oft he asking price and be prepared to walk away if you are not happy with the eventual price..

Nice & Friendly Area. Stay in Sultanahmet Old City area if you're planning to go to Istanbul. We will feel the friendly atmosphere of Turkish and we can find anything here with a close step to the transportations (only require to reach other places in Istanbul).

A bit corrupted over time- but still quaint and enticing. The experience can get a bit diluted in the melee of buses, persistent salesmen and cheating taxi-drivers, but the essence of the area, it's history, it's magnificent structures and rich history are not lost. Getting there can be a challenge unless you're already living in the area, but once there, you can run through a lot in a day or two.

Must see. It's the area were Agia Sophia, Blue mosque & Topkapi are situated so it's a must to go there, baring in mind its very crowded and its very difficult to visit the 3 sites in one day, also after it there is the Grand bazar which is the most Famous Bazar in Istanbul and must be visited as well so its advisable to take it on 2 days if there is time..

You haven't visited Istanbul unless you've been here. The main historic area of the city, the location of the principle mosques, bazaars, museums, etc. a definite must-see. But expect crowds in high seasons. Some steep and narrow streets. This part of Istanbul is probably not handicapped-friendly.

Plenty to see in the old part of Istanbul. A very good location to base yourself as many of the sites are within this area. My advice is to pick your key sites and walk to each one. You may get tired but you will see live and smell Istanbul. Given a modicum of map sense you should be able to navigate easily. Even if you cannot the Istanbullas will always offer to help.
Detailed Islamic Architecture. A must to visit with Aya sophia in the same trip, the mosque is huge with a wonderful glass colors.Take as much photos as you can.

Nice area - don't be put off by the ticket touts. Great place to be during the day except for the ticket touts at the weekend and the ever-so-friendly carpet sellers.A polite "no thank you" normally does the trick ...
sultanahmet square. amazing historical place I was really impressed by the atmosphere and strongly recommend to others planning to come to istanbul

Perfect location!. On recent sister trip (we're 64 and 72, and planned our own three-week visit) we spent five days in Istanbul, basing in a pension in Sultanahment District. The locale was perfect, convenient walk from major sites and public transport, good, small neighborhood restaurants, safe, quiet. Would choose again without hesitation.

very touristic. it is a nice area, with a fountain in the middle, a touristic area where you see all the tourists walking around and taking pictures, there is Aya sophia, blue mosque, basilica citerna etc.. shops and restaurants. it is a nice area
This place is old and cool.. Lots of lovely old buildings, restos and shops, and of course the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and enuf history to choke a horse.
Istanbul Trip. Nice food, Turkish ice-cream and many tourist attractions awaiting one here. At least a full day is needed. Breathtaking scenery and awesome spot for photography.

Impressive. quite a good visit and place to immerse in the culture of the turkish people :)
it's where you can do really old turkish baths!
to feel at the edge of Centures. go to Istambul at Sultanahmet you will meet all the Centures and cities at one square!Medieval charm, trace of Bisance, Modern chick, it all in one place!
The best place to stay. Staying in this area frees you from the need to travel in and out to the main attractions. Everything is convenient and you can savour the atmosphere.

Tourist Traps Abound!. Sultanahmet is the definition of a tourist trap. That said, it is where most of the best attractions are, so it makes for an obvious base of operations. I recommend booking one of the many great hotels there, and using the free, offline Istanbul TripAdvisor city app to look up reviews. All the streets are lined with scammy restaurants and shops, and their owners will endlessly haggle you to come in and spend money. The shops never close - almost all were still open at midnight when we were walking around. Many of the restaurants are tourist scams - Wikitravel's Istanbul article lays it out nicely if you want more elaboration. Bottom line - don't go into a store and buy anything without an idea of how much it normatively costs, and don't eat anywhere without looking up reviews and ensuring you are receiving the menu with the lowest prices (i.e. preprinted and with Turkish & English). Be prepared for gypsies and other street vendors everywhere you look and many stray dogs and cats.

Bring you Walking Shoes. The only way to feel like you are part of the experience is to walk through this wonderful District and smell and see the people and the shops. Bring water as you can get thirsty for sure.
The best place to stay. Is close to the best sights in Istambul. You will maximise your time, walking or getting the trainway to every place you want to go.

Many attractions concentrated in one place, do visit!. Go in the Blue Mosque, as the interior is even more breath taking, and you can experience how muslims perform their daily prayers in peace and calm. Next to the Blue Mosque, there are historical pillars dating back from the roman era. For a fee you can enter the Hagia Sophia, and see many things reflecting christianity and islam. Furthermore, take a break in the cool Basilica Cistern, which is on a 2 minute walking distance. Visited all in 2010, and 1 May 2013

restaurants. the place to be for eating out , choice of different restaurants , beers wines good ambiance with mostly terraces were you eat out...don't go to Metropolis looks good but the food is not, we tried a local special preparation, lamsmeat in a clay tin who they served in as and fire and then the cut the top off wonderfull

Great place to walk around. All of the major tourist attractions are in this area from the Blue Mosque and the Topkapi Palace to the Grand Bazaar and everything is within walking distance. There is a lot of public transportation, but along the tram lines, there are narrow walkways. This area is filled with all kinds of shops and cafes. It is fun to walk around and explore.

Very touristy. A quick place to buy an overpriced meal. Do yourself a favor and get on the tram to get to Beyoglu/Taksim or Eminonu and get some good cheap food. Go to this area for the historical attraction but nothing else.
Overwhelming. Much to see, ranging from Grand Bazaar to numerous other sights in old city. Can be very crowded, but that's part of the ambience
Fun. Busy tourist area. Handsome men charming you into their stores to buy things you done need. Windows full of Turkish Delight. Call to prayer echoing through the streets. Doesn't get any better.

It's a heart of the city, but it's a symbolic area as well. Every time when I visit Istanbul I have to come here to breath an air of ancient history, an air of Osmanli empire, to feel a spirit of Byzantium/Constantinople. Each time I try to see something new on the old city walls, on the Blue Mosque, Aya Sufya, souvenirs shops, cabapci restaurants ets.,

Great location. If you stay in this area you will have the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Cistern, Archaeological Museum, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Mosaic Museum and as many restaurants as you like all on your doorstep - and the tram to go elsewhere.

Bazaars. We visited both the Spice and the Grand Bazaars a couple times each on our recent trip. For those who like to shop and especially to negotiate prices or compare shops this is a dream. We spent over 8 hours walking from one to the other and only visited about 30 of the 5,000 merchants and a handful of shops in between the two Bazaars. They have tons of spices, of course, also ceramics (trivets, bowls, plates and cups), linens, scarfs, carpets and Turkish Delight (chewy candy squares but with tons of different nuts or flavors added and samples everywhere. There are also lots of fake designer goods and cheap stuff so beware.Outside of the Spice Bazaar the boats catch, cook and sell fish on french bread that you can sit on a barrel in a covered area and enjoy! Only 5TL (equals about 3 USD), don't miss the cultural experience!
Travel Istanbul. Wear comfortable shoes, there is a lot to see and its all very good.April is a very good time to go, the weather is great and the crowds haven't gotten to big.

So much history.... I thoroughly enjoy the Sultanahmet District. They have recently finished some rennovations, so things are new and clean. There is a new park in front of the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. It's beautiful with a big fountain. There are trees and grass and benches, which makes it nice to sit for a while. I cannot express how clean it is. Plus, they are still working on some things, so it's bound to be even better in the future. Istanbul knows what it's doing with making things accessible. Next to the Blue Mosque is the Hippodrome, which is underrated. It's very interesting to walk around, to imagine chariots racing each other around the column and the still-standing obelisk. (How can that still be standing?! It's amazing) When you come to Istanbul, plan to stay in this district for quite some time. It's old and beautiful and connects you to the past. It is also, in my opinion, the most important part of Istanbul. I really enjoyed just being there. It's really nice.
Looking for ceramics?. Have I got an excellent recommendation for you. CS Iznik ceramics in the Grand Bizarre is the place to go! Hakan is the man to see..

Be alert. Very beautiful and central to any Istanbul trip. Although there are many tourist police about, do continue to be alert for pickpockets who target this area particularly for tourists. Any sensible traveller will be safe though, and can enjoy the surroundings.
excellent. Stayed here and loved the buzz and excitement evident around the entire area with restaurants, bars, shops and markets in plenitude

Keep your map handy. Walkind around this area can prove tricky as the extremely narrow streets and tall building provide no view of your surroundings or points of reference. Winding streets get you disorientated very quickly. Fortunately the road name signage is very good and with a good detail map, you will be able to get where you want to fairly easily. Locals are very helpful despite lacking much fluency in anything but Turkish.

I Wouldn't Stay Anywhere Else. I heard that across the Galata Bridge is the "happening" place to be. I disagree strongly! I think Sultanahmet has the best of everything that makes Istanbul a great travel destination. Mosques, museums, food, shopping, easy access to the metro. I visited other parts of the city but they don't have the same charm as this neighborhood.
Good to see. it is one of the beautiful mosque. if you have access to tramway, it is better to use it. ayasofya mosque is close to it.

Ottoman Istanbul. An area easy to stroll around and see some of the finest sights in Istanbul. By day visit the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Sarayi and as the sun set admire the beauty of the Blue Mosque as the building becomes illuminated

Paradise for sightseeing and shopping. This is the oldest past of the city where the major attractions are found but it is also the place to go shopping. There are stores everywhere. There are also plenty of restaurants. If you want a place to stay, there are hotels in every price range, some of them only a stones throw from these attractions. This is where you want to stay, if possible, since it makes visiting the attractions so much easier.
Loads of fun. Want somewhere to wander? This place is full of streets with vendors selling everything from scarves to spices, carpets to ceramic, all prices and quality.Loved it

Don't miss this. Smoke a hooker, eat a kepap, down a pomegranate juice and buy something from the Grand Bazaar. Leave on a ferry that takes you from Europe to Asia for a dollar and you will know why the locals love this area of Istanbul and I do too :)

A good place to base yourself. This is I felt the best place to have as a base as it's very close to get to the main attractions and easy to find you way around. It also felt safe to walk around but day and night. It also has a blend of the old and new living and working alongside one another. I enjoyed being there and exploring the district.
Really central. Loads of tourist attractions, shops and restaurants. The best area to stay if you want to walk to main tourist attractions.
Crowded. I have to say there were so many people it was difficult to get around. The grounds were beautiful with the tulips.
Nice place. I loved the area especially Sultanahmet square where is the Blue mosque and Aya Sophia. It gets so busy during the day but still an inspirational place to go
cultural/historical heart of Istanbul. This is the place to stay in Istanbul if you want to be close to everything. The prices are higher than in other places in the city, but the choices are great.

Spend time and just wander. This is the heart of Istanbul with all the major attractions within easy walking distance: Blue Mosque; Topkapi Palce; Hagia Sophia; Grand Bazaar; and more. The centre is effectively the squares between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sphia. The Grand Bazaar is a short walk up hill along the tram route and in on the right. Don't be put off by delapidated buildings and an air of being run-down: this is Istanbul which found itself slightly neglected when the capital moved to Ankara in the 1930s. Explore the side streets: there is a small bazaar behind the Blue Mosque that's well worth a visit. There are numerous places to eat; open air cafes and a number of surprisingly well signed toilets (1TL turnstile). The open-top tour buses all go from the square and boat tours of the Golden Horn/Bosphorus have booking (and assembly) points here. You will be approached continuously by traders: if you don't want, just say "No thanks". Everyone is friendly.
You feel the history. The History, the richness of the sights smells and the brick roadsI dislike shop keepers over marketing in a sloppy way .

Beautiful area. We strolled around in the afternoon sun enjoying the views of all the mosques, lovely flower beds, fountains and friendly people. Unfortunately for us, there were armed guards at the gates of the Topkapi Palace saying it was closed.Places to eat and drink all around at reasonable prices.

Magical. I have never had such a good feeling in my soul as walking around Sultanahmet. It feels so good to be in the centre of all of that history. You cannot possibly take a bad picture there. The entire area is so alive and dripping with beauty

Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Market need at least a full day to explore and practice your haggling skills. Also, go to the garment district between the two to see the fashion of the locals and get a feel for the amazing garment industry of Turkey.

Touristy but attractive. Even this early in the season there were masses of tourists but the area is very attractively laid out and the flowers, particularly the tulips were a delight to see. The various sites are well signposted too.
Grand Bazaar. You have to go to the Grand Bazaar, Turkish Hamaam(bath) and the Hookah bar here! Also the Basilica Cistern is within walking distance.

A Place You Should See and Stay in Istanbul. It's a place for tourist with lots of tourist attraction within; only a heartbeat away from the main attraction as well as Blue Mosque, Ayasophia, Spice Market and Topkapi Palace, it's just... amazing!
yes. walk around, to my opinion the best, intersting side of istanbul,historical and turkish at the same time

Just Beautiful. Istanbul, once Constantinople, was considered to be the center of the world. Upon arriving in Sultanahmet tram station i instantly noticed the old charm of this place- cobbled streets, doves at the park, vendors selling grilled corn and pretzels. Then, two lovely historic edifice will greet you, as soon as you enter Sultanahmet park, the magnificent Blue Mosque and the charming Hagia Sophia. Sunrises here are spectacularly serene and peaceful. You will wake up to the sound of flying seagulls and the daily morning prayer. Never miss the grilled kebabs in Turkey, considered to be the best in the world. They have one of the nicest people around. This place has to be on the top of my list. An instant favorite!

Walk and get Istanbul Kart. Amazing area, better to walk around than take city tours. Good restaurants and shops. Even the streets have a charm of their own. Can take the tram. I bought an Istanbul Kart 8TL and add 12TL for travel expense that covered ferries, tram and buses.

75% of Istanbul tourism is here. This is the heart of the tourist area for Istanbul and one just needs to walk around the area to visit mosques, museums, restaurants, churches , mausoleums etc. Recommend area to stay to avoid taxi hassles in Istanbul

Packed with history. Liked - walking around the old area, but be careful of touts and chingadoo merchants who want to sell you anything and everything.Disliked - the merchants who try and entice you to walk into their shops. Good piece of advice for women - carry a headscarf and when you feel you've had enough of being approached by the shopkeepers, stick your scarf on - works a treat!
LOVE THIS PLACE. Love it, so peacefull i started to cry when i hear the adhan, it was so powerful !!!the mosque have a massive size! the architecture of the mosque is just amazing! really amazing!!!
Awesome place to get lost!. The cobbled streets are amazing! We loved it here. Definitely spend time exploring this place, but avoid eating around here. Is very expensive!

A trip in time. Highly recommended for people who like to take a glimpse at the past.
The region is well organized and prepared to accept tourists, but beware of inflated prices in the nearby markets.
Best transportation method is using the T1 Tramway that cover the historical area in a proper way.

Turks do have a sense of humor. Every 5 metres you will be approached by some-one selling something. It gets a bit annoying when you are in conversation with your partner, but just stay friendly.
One person liked my mustache and asked in Dutch if I have a Turkish Neighbour.

Great Start. If you only have a few days in Istanbul this is a great start. By walking a few blocks you can find most of the greatest places to visit, eat. It's easier to walk in this district and find some good shops for souvenirs. Walk distance to Grand Bazar and many interesting places to take photos.
Just take a walk!. Such a great place to walk around or sit on a bench and absorb the culture, history and it's obvious future!

Historic. It was easy to walk around and not get lost. Too much to see so give yourself many days to explore. People are so friendly and like to practice their English, so ask as many questions as you want. The vendors can be pushy at times, but just shake your head no and walk on.

best place to stay in Istanbul. this is an area where you will want to spend a full day, many restaurants too. If stay on other side of Bosphoros -to0 much driving and too far away, I think there is also less to do over there.

More of a European feel than we anticipated!. We loved wandering down the cobblestone streets, stopping for meals at sidewalk cafes (although beware that each one has someone standing out friend ready to persuade you to choose their cafe over all the others...but this seemed true wherever we went), and the historic sites were breathtaking.

Stunning sights in a tourist trap. There is more sights in this district than you can shake a stick at and it is thus likely you will spend a considerable amount of time here. Beware the carpet touts and guide book sellers which can be quite persistent and annoying. I would also mainly avoid this area for shopping and eating - save that for the bazaars and Beyoglu.
All tourist, all the time. The Mosques, Museums, Churches and Cisterns are all GREAT, but the rest of this neighborhood might as well be Coney Island. Endless souvenir shops with the same stuff.

If you are interest in Sightseeing this is the area to stay in Istanbul. If you are interested in doing sightseeing you must choose this area as it keeps you close to the tourist attractions. We stayed far due to a International Dance Festival which we were going to in the Asian side of Istanbul. However, if we were to return this area is full of restaurants, tourist attractions, stores and many other things to take advantage off if you go to Istanbul.

Nice Area!. I liked the attractions in that area, as well as the restaurants and food.
It is super-busy, a lot of people, and it's nice to walk around. The bazar is nearby, Aya Sophia and SultanAhmet mosque is close there..
It's just a nice area to spend some time in...
always very interesting. long queues to buy tickets. then you have to queue again to get actually into to any of the museums.

Good location for sight seeing.. Sultanahmet was in the old part of the city, walking distance to The Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar,Bosphorus cruise, hop on hop off bus,plus had quite a large area of restaurants and shops

Why stay elsewhere.. Cobbled winding streets, interesting shops and antiquities, cafes, museums, historic sites- the only place to stay in Istanbul. Well worth the extra distance drive from the airport.

The best part of this beautiful city. I was pleased that I chose to stay in Sultanahmet and I felt this was the 'true' Istanbul. So many attractions in this area and eateries, from fine dining, to English pubs, to local kebab houses and the best Koftas in the world. I walked the streets often by myself and felt completely safe

The main tourist drag. The whole area is obviously a tourist trap but it also has all the services you could possibly need- so in that, I highly suggest you stay somewhere in it. The river tour people are rip offs, just go to the ship yourself and save yourself a lot of money. its right on the light rail. But the walk about tours and the bus tour was strangely worth it in my opinion.

Sultanahmet. Great place to stay on a first visit to Istanbul. Lovely boutique hotels. So close to major sites and easy to get tram to the port and bazaars. We stayed at Darussaade just off the beaten track and very quiet. Something quite magical about being in the shadow of the blue mosque and the calls to prayer. Don't look for Moon restaurant. It no longer exists. By using back streets it is easy to avoid being hustled for business.

Old Town. Just what you go to Istanbul to experience. Although in some ways our hotel disappointed ( see review) the situation within walking distance of all the sights and sounds ( call to prayer from the different mosques), and the bustle of tourists and locals alike was excellent.
Best place in Istanbul. Historic part of Istanbul with all local attractions in one place. Plenty of restaurants, full of history and everything is within walking distance.Truly remarkable!
Good place to eat.. Very good restaurants and one or two good pub/bars too. If you want to try transitional kofta, this is the place to go.

Central to everything and full of history!. This is a great area of town to stay in for a visit to Istanbul, especially for your first visit or for a short visit. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern are just a few highlights. Ancient city walls, historical architecture and cobble stone streets make this area so charming to visit. The only negative thing about this area is that, because it is in the most touristy part of Istanbul, you will be constantly asked for your business in carpet shops, stores, and restaurants.

The best area to stay in Istanbul. We stayed in the Sultanahmet District and felt really safe. The cobble stoned streets have old world charm and they are quiet at night. If you stay at a hotel here you'll be near the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia which is handy as they are star attractions in Istanbul. Also, there are nice restaurants in Sultanahmet but more expensive than usual so try to explore neighbouring areas.

Historic Istanbul - past, present and future in one. If you are wondering where to stay in Istanbul for your first visit, then stay here. All the key sights are in easy reach by foot or tram, and just strolling around is enough to give you a flavour of Istanbul's history, and progression.

Lots to see and eat. This must be THE PLACE to be while visiting Istanbul. Everything goes on here. All the major attractions are centred in this district which is the old part of the city. Besides the Grand and Spice bazaars, there is also the Arasta Bazaar, which is smaller but more elegantly presented than the other two noisy and chaotic ones. I prefer to shop leisurely at the Arasta than fighting around the labyrinths of the grand or spice bazaars.

Sultanahmet. If you go to Istanbul, you MUST visit Sultanahmet. This is where you feel like you have really stepped into the soul of Turkey - yes, it's crowded, but one of Istanbul's major characteristics is that it is a city teeming with life, almost to overflowing. The history, character, color and exuberance of Istanbul are in full display in this magnificent district.
You have to stay here. All the major tourist sites are located here and the Grand Bazaar is very close. The hotels and restaurants were great.

PERFECT LOCATION. This is a great location for most main attraction..the only thing not so happy is hard to find others country cuisinie..except mcd,burger king..so youdont really have option when it comes to food..

Definitely stay in this area. Such and incredible historic district to wander around the Turkish people are all very friendly to foreigners. Restaurants shops and markets all in a very small area. The smaller mosques are better to visit as they are more intimate and less tourists. We loved the charm AG and character of this district.

Walk, walk, walk!. You never get tired to walk at the Sultanahmet district. It is a lively, lovely, international, beautiful place. It is the main area of the city, with palaces, mosques and museums next to each other. Lots of restaurants and shops. Day or night, there is always something to do and enjoy.
Attractions. Probably best area to stay I if you are there for sightseeing. Loads restaurants, gift shops and main tourist attractions

Easter 2013 Istanbul Break. Lots to explore in the area. We were there for five days and that did not do justice to the area! There's an excellent buzz about the place from morning through to late night.

Only one problem...... As far as I'm concerned, Sultanahmet is the best place to stay while visiting Istanbul as a tourist. The sights are surprisingly accessible by tram and by foot, and you'll definitely realize you're not in Kansas anymore.There is only one real problem, and sadly I don't even remotely have a solution for it - I'm referring, of course, to the rug merchants who relentlessly prey on tourists. It is especially irritating when one has only a few days of precious time to enjoy all that Istanbul offers.As documented elsewhere, these guys (and they all seem to be men) approach tourists, ostensibly to become their new best friend, and simply will NOT take "No!" for an answer. It seems that the more politely one says "no" the more eager they become to tag along with you. If you try to escape by entering an attraction, the person will wait for you to come out (if there is only one exit.) Inevitably, one is forced to become very forceful and rude to get away from these people, only to almost immediately be confronted by another. I felt as if my short vacation in Istanbul was being stolen from me.

The core tourist area. This is the area to go if you only have one day. It contains the key attractions, such as Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern and Tokapi Palace - though you won't be able to do them all in a day.The tram comes right into the centre for easy access - get off at Sultanahmet Square.

Night time view. Make sure you walk around this district at night. The lights on the fountain are quite nice! Also, the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia look spectacular at night. The crowds have thinned by then as well. Enjoy a grilled corn on the cob.

Good central location. Our hotel was in Sultanahmet. it was close to the bazaar and all other touristy areas. You can take the train to the bazaar, spice market, etc. Plenty of taxis around and be careful about the cab drivers who don't use their taximeter.
Compact sightseeing. Many things to see within minutes of walking. Bring you camera! Good restaurants everywhere.Quite high prices. Taxis are cheap.

Turista Tours. We went on three tours with this company, located on the main street opposite the Blue Mosque.It was an excellent way to explore this wonderful area of the city. The guides spoke very good English and had lots of knowledge. It was a great way to learn about the attractions and local culture. Highly recommended.

Great atmosphere. This is the most popular area in Istanbul and it is full of tourists,restaurants, cafés, pastries and little shops. At night it is lively and beautiful; the mosques and fountain area is beautifully illuminated so everyone should spend one night dining in a restaurant terrace and enjoying a walk around.

wander and wonder. The center of it all in Istanbul. See the Mosques. See the people. Buy a few souveniers. Catch the tram to points beyond (Galetta or the Unviersity, ie). There will be a lot of people and you might get asked if you are interested in buying a carpet. Don't fret it. Soak in the splendor of this place. And most importanly...have a Salep.

Super Crowded and over rated. We visited Blue Mosque , St Sophia ,Topkapi palace and grand bazaar, without a tour guide it is almost impossible to do all in a a day. Each of the above attraction was ecrowded. If you have longer time to see these places you could be more relax. Blue mosque was OK, you are not allowed to wear shoes inside, so be prepared to smell some sweaty feets there including your own :D. Topkapi Palace was great but unbelievable LONG Q and crowded - go early in the morning.These atraction were though worht for visit, but would be better if less crowd:).
great area. we walked around the area a lot and found the main sights as well as great little local eating places

Great area. This is a lovely area full of shops and restaurants. Food prices are very similar in all cafes & restaurants, even in more local ones. It is an easy area to wander around, with most of the sites in a few minutes walk from each other. the tram line makes getting to other areas very easy.

Pretty and Bustling. Stand in the middle of the square and be awed by the magnificence of the Sultanahmet mosque one side and the Aya Sofya on the other. The illuminated fountain in the middle of square a nice touch. See people from all corners of the world. Looks very pretty at night. Good access to trams and restaurants just across the road. You will most definitely be stopped by a guy selling boat cruises and tour buses. Please do avoid the tour buses as they are a rip off !

A perfect base to explore the old city. Our hotel was only 200 metres from the Basilica Cistern, therefore we had no need for taxis. If you want to travel further afield the Metro trams are excellent and only cost 3TL (£1.13) per trip.

Long lines everywhere. Most of the main attractions are located in this area (Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern). Lines are long, so start early or purchase the Istanbul Museum Pass from online or your hotel prior to visiting the museums. You can avoid these long lines with the museum pass except Basilica Cistern, which requires a separate entrance fee. You can reach this area by taxi, or by taking the T1 tram to Sultanahmet stop. Avoid the rug stores in this area!
Lots of variety, close to everything, inexpensive hotels and dining.. Restaurants and vendors approached tourists to agressively - annoying! Learn - "it's not wanted!" in Turkish before visiting.

Awe-inspiring scenery, with one warning..... This is truly one of the world's most remarkable squares - the Blue Mosque to the west, the Hagia Sophia to the east, and behind the HS, the Topkapi Palace with its extensive grounds and gardens. Besides the buildings themselves, there are lots of little craft stands and cafes where you can stop for a bite or admire Turkish wares. Nearby is the Mosaic museum and a lovely long bazaar with lots of tourist-friendly shops. *But the annoying and continuous persistence of the tour guides and jewelry/rug salesmen can be extremely vexing.* I am a patient and polite person at heart (from the Pacific Northwest), but I had to put my game face on and hold up a hand with a head shake that meant business at frequent intervals. Don't feel bad if you have to get loud and direct, or just walk briskly away - it's not your job to fill their quotas. Outside of this one area, I had hardly difficulty in Istanbul at all with overly aggressive sales people. Go, just go with some psychic armor.

Get there early!. The sights in the historic part of city are amazing but the queues are horrific. Maybe it was because it was Easter weekend but I would recommend getting there really early before the hordes descend. And wear comfy shoes - lots of cobbles.

Great place to walk around. The Sultanahmet district is a great place to walk around - I particularly enjoy the area south of the Blue Mosque which is a bit quieter. Sure, it's touristy - there seems to be no end to the gift shops and heckling restaurant workers - but if you can look beyond that then it's really quite an experience.

Good for a day. Plenty to see, but start early. Thousands of tourists pour into this area, so plan well and move swiftly. Get a three day pass for the attractions, saves time and money. The lonely Planet guide was a great help in navigating around. The buses and trams were a God send.
a must see. one of the most worthy areas on the planet. a real gem of the orient, and for an Islamic state, you are not intimidated to travel around.

Wonderful place to go. Everything about the district is memorable. The blue mosque, hagiya sofiya, topkapi palace, cisterns, grand bazaar, hippodrome... everything is just fascinating! I would strongly recommend spending one day just in the district and then half a day for the bazaar. Must must go place in Istanbul
Best place to stay. You can find cheaper restaurants if you don't go to the main street where the flags of Turkey are hanging--that is where all the tourists hang out.

Walking with History and shops... Although this is the Tourist District it is also the Historic District with stunning sights from Hagia Sophia to stunning views of the Straits. This is a great area where you can find cool cafes, smart hotels, stunning history and an easy place just to chill out.
A district with magnificent Mosques and monuments. Within an almost limited area of the District one can find more than 10 astonishing mosques and monuments to visit.

A nice athmosphere, but beware of the overpriced carpets. Sultanahmet is the perfect place to live for a 3-5 day visit in Istanbul, because everything is nearby; The Blue Mosque, Topikapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Sultan's hammam(bath house), tours on Bosporos, the Grand Bazaar...It is a nice quiet area, with small shops and restaurants as well as bigger places.The streets around the Mosque can be crowded with "guides" really wanting to sell you expensive goods, so beware. Instead choose the small shops and quieter streets, down the hill from the Mosque or around the more quiet corners. It is absolutely possible to do good bargains, but please be sure that what you buy is really worth it. Check more places before you decide on carpets and jewellery, as the prices normally start out very high. And even then you should be careful. Women travelling alone do not have to wear headscarfs but it helps a lot, especially as the men are much more clingy to women who does not wear them.Istanbul has an openminded style, but in the tram there are pickpockets and in theGrand Bazaar you should not pay more than half the asking price.The park with the big fountain is lovely and there are several nice restaurants in the area. The hammam was expensive, but worth the price! Newly renovated and with good massage and soapwash, in calm, luxurious rooms with your own locker room and loads of time to relax after treatment. Very friendly and nice women work there, and there are offers for a lot of different packages.
Fabulous atmosphere. Everywhere you look in Sultan Ahmet is packed with history. Busy, bustling and noisy but has the true flavour of Istanbul.

One feels transported back in time but at the same time one sees ultra modern cafes and shops. The Grand Bazar and the Spice Bazar are straight out of Arabian Nights. But there are other elements such as hip shops and restaurants which give the district a feeling of stradling two very different epochs, definitely worth a visit

Old town of Istanbul Area. i chose to stay in the Sultanahmet district because it the old town and i would say i made the right choice and it a lovely area and very close to all amenities and easily accessible by walks and tram. Night time shops open and able to have a drink and people smoked water pipe (not us) Hot soup and kebab with cake available locally. I can't think of anywhere else to stay apart from the sultanahmet because it the best place to stay and visit.

charming. Many of the major Istanbul sites are here and a short walking distance. I did take a cab once and the fares were reasonable. The winding little streets are quite charming with another interesting shop or restaurant just around the next corner.
Magic!. Narrow streets, lamp shops, carpets, music & delicious spice smell from tiny restaurants... lovely to feel Turkish culture. Please do not choose other quarter to stay!

Sultanahmet District is the Lifeline of Istanbul. Due to the existence of the various Monuments, the Sultanahmet district has grown into a touristy socio-commercial zone. Well secured by handsome & smart policemen, it is a glitzy district where one can shop for anything.

Sultahmet Square. Priviously a hypodrome, now only some ruins survied from the old Byzantine Empire. This is one of the places that you can see three cultures meet at the same time. Rome, Byzantine, and the Ottoman
In the heart of everything.. Staty here. Period. Great sites, within walking distance or the tram. Lots of shops, and wonderful restaurants. Every alley and every corner open up to new adventures.

Nice area to stay and to hang out.. Sultanahmet District is just the right place to choose in term of accommodation, dining, shopping, sightseeing.. or just to hang out at the public park near Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque... the transportation system is just superb and convenient...

The epicenter for the old historic sites. This area housees all the older sight seeing places in istanbul. Is it also known as the Old istanbul. Here you will see structures that have been around for several centuries, maybe 1000 years old. Really cool to walk around in the area and know the amazing architecture that was erected back that long of a time ago.
The best place to stay in Istanbul. All attractions are located in this district therefore it is recommended to choose the hotel in this area

Nice. Just wander,around, go down the side streets, the bazaar, you will get people trying to sell you stuff, just keep your humour, a polite no thank you and a smile seems to work, and you will come across all sorts of nice little sights

Sultanachmet. The old town of Istanbul. You have to visit the area , Agya Sofia, TopKapi Palace, Walk the street with with the wooden houses and flowers from Agya Sofia to TopKapi. Also visit Kapali Carsi and Egyptian Market

Lots to do and see!. Markets, mosques and more, this is a great part of town. You can probably find party areas but we stayed in a quieter place that was seconds from the mosques. Love this part of Istanbul... brings out the bargain hunter in me!

Lively and full of atmosphere. All the sights were nearby, and there were some lovely restaurants also. Try some of the backstreets to find typical local eateries, it's impossible to eat badly in Istanbul!
Clean. Clean. clean. clean and safe safe safe - LOVE Istanbul. Almost every neighborhood was extremely clean including this district.

Sofa Art & Antiques. I don't normally recommend stores but in this instance I can't help but write a review of this shop called Sofa Art & Antiques. It is located just outside the Grand Bazaar and it is fantastic! It is a treasure trove, there is everything from amazing pottery and ceramics to art, paintings, copper trays etc! It is so beautifully presented you don't want to leave and whilst the price tags reflect the quality of the merchandise I would highly recommend a browse at least (the owners are lovely and happy to leave you alone to poke around or provide the history of the piece that catches your eye). If you want to spend money on the perfect momento of Turkey then you're sure to find something in here... I certainly did! :)

exciting, vibrant and good fun.. This is a fascinating area of Istanbul with much to see. After our visit this is our order of preference:1) Ayasofya Camii, 2) The Cistern, 3) Boat trip on Bosphorous (2 hours 10 Turkish Lira each), 4) Topkapi Palace and Harem, 5) The Spice Bazaar, 6) The Grand Bazaar, 7) Blue Mosque 8) Guilhane Park alongside the Topkapi, (look for storks nesting in the trees if you are there in spring), 9) The Hippodrome where chariots raced (near the blue mosque), 10) the Galata Tower, (not really in Sultanahmed but not far) great views over Istanbul (TIP: there is an arrow showing a one way direction around the top, but when it is busy it is difficult to see, also remember to use the toilet next to the lifts on way down, they are 'free' now you have paid for your visit and very clean).TIPS:Prices seems higher around the Topkapi Palace but drop within a relatively short distance.A downside for us was that traders were constantly trying to engage us in conversation and asking us to to look at something. This may be OK for the first store or restaurant, but it happens at the next, and the next and... We found a simple and polite way to stop them was to say, “I already have one”, “I've just eaten”, “I've already been” or something similar, depending on the circumstances. Prices for things like nuts and Turkish delight tend to be priced per kilo. This is not always obvious and can make them look prohibitively expensive, which they are not.Some people just wanted to talk or practice their English. We even had a conversation with an old lady who spoke fluent German to our broken school German. However, two traders developed a dark side to their chat; “You promised to come in” which we didn't, and “You people come here but don't want to spend any money”- not true. So my advice would be to try not to get involved unless you are sure it is appropriate.Try the apple tea and different Turkish delights.The round bread rolls with seeds on the outside were really nice and filling. They cost 1 Turkish Lira each from street vendors and were handled hygienically with plastic bags/gloves and handed to you in a plastic or paper bag. If you have a good breakfast, they make an excellent stop gap before you have lunch or dinner.Following tram tracks can help you find you way round easily, going down hill will get you to the Bosphorous and, going up hill, back to the Grand Bazaar area.Be careful with the traffic. It seemed to be quite common for bikes and vans to use what we would think of, as pedestrian areas. Also keep your eyes open as there are many changes of levels and unprotected steps on pavements.

You have got to stay here. We have been in Istanbul for 9 days and this area has been perfect for us. We have been able within walking distance see all of the top sites, pop over to the Bazaar Quarter and shopped for our treasures off the beaten path. You will be able to see the tourist areas as well as the way real people live just by walking down the streets. We have felt safe the entire time we have been here with friendly people everywhere and undercover policemen throughout the area.

Great Place to See and Stay. Sultanahmet is a great place to explore as well as stay in Istanbul. It is very safe, the only thing to watch out for is traffic so be careful when crossing roads! (This is true for all of Istanbul.)There are lots of cafes and shops to explore. A lot of the main attractions are also here which is another reason staying in the district is desirable. It's also a quieter area of the city -- another plus. A minor thing to be cognizant of, there are cats all over this district. All have their home areas and are cared for by the locals. (I would assume they're valued as rat catchers.) Most are friendly but it would be wise not to pet them. It's not very sanitary and I wonder about the vaccination laws in Turkey.
fun to walk around. we sat outside a small cafe in the sun and enjoyed a lunch with friends... there are so many choices (we probably didn't pick the best one) but the atmosphere is great

Take your time. The old district with lots of culture. Spend an afternoon getting lost in the Sultanahmet District, drink some turkish coffee, eat some Turkish delight, and enjoy watching the people/culture.

Good area to stay. It was delightful to wander about this neighbourhood. As well as the beautiful attractions of the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace et al, there are lots of hidden little streets of shops, not to mention the Grand Bazaar. Also easy to catch a tram to take you over the Golden Horn to the Beyoglu area.

A Palace !. Very well maintained and a decent place. The history intrigues you, the opulence will dazzle you and you may not want to see any other place in the whole day as there are endless places to visit within the palace

MUST SEE ... Heart of old Istanbul. This is the 'historical district' that contains the gems of the city. Great part of town to stay, eat, shop and sights see -- take a Turkish bath and shop for the best jewelry in the world. You will be dazzled...and yes...it is very safe.

Good Place to Stay. Found this area to be a great area to stay in as it holds all the main attractions if you are on a quick visit to Istanbul. In Sultanhmet you can see the following attraction: The Blue Mosque and fountains which change colour of an evening, Topkapi Palace, The Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sophia, The Spice Bazaar and a few other attractions as well.There are quite a few shops to browse in and numerous restaurants to eat in and we felt that we had chosen the best area of Istanbul to stay in, especially for a first visit as it gave us a flavour of what Turkey is all about.

Filled with history... Sultanahmet is most popular touristic destination in Istanbul. You can see so many tourist groups from China to USA... You can have a chance to visit near thousand years old mosques, basilica cistern and many... Also so many shopping oppornuties available...

only the best!. if you were going to visit Istanbul, this is the place to stay..everything is here..the Ayasofya Hamam, Blue Mosque, topkapi, cistern and Hagia Sophia..it feels very european and at the same time the exoticness of Turkey! soo much history here..great restaurant selections as well...if you have 3days or 10days, this is your place/district..
traditional. shopping,fast ,easy,cash or vredit card any .you can touch ,you can feel what you are looking for and than buy it :))

I love the history and architecture!. A great place to wonder and explore. So much to see, so many little stores. Suggest you go in a group of two or more. And always be sure to dress appropriately out of respect of the culture, and also to avoid being followed by Turkish men.
excellent area to stay. Most attractions are accessible on foot but transport system is excellent. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Grand Bazaar are a must and all easily reached.
Great for a walk about. Reasonable priced trinkets - great food. English speaking hosts. Nice for a meander about. Turkish delight aim to pay no more than 35TL per kilo

Lively neighbourhood. It is a lovely district, where you can see how asiatic and european cultures lives together, a very charming neighbourhood with old and new houses, ancient and modern buildings. Hagia Sophia is a must to see.
A must while in Istanbul. Great historical area. The Hagia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Cisterns, and Grand Baazar are all within 5 minutes of each other.

So much to do. Right in the middle of the T1 Kabatas tram route (3 TL from anywhere). Lots to do and see with some great restaurants. The whirling dervish show at the resto between sultanhamnet and Gulhane stations is well worth the money. Amazing!

We stayed here.. super convenient!. It was historical and lively!
The trams provided good links to other areas. The Blue mosque was close by and the Grand Bazaar was too.
Sultanahmet. Great area for visiting main sites. Trams cheap & easy also taxis. Buses best avoided at busy times as they can take a very long time due to traffic congestion

Where else?. If you come all the way to Istanbul, and didn't visit this neighborhood, you'd be crazy. Yes it's a rather touristy, but just deal with it. And find ways of avoiding the worst of the crowds - like visiting the Blue Mosque after dinner, right around evening prayers, when all the tourists are looking for a place to eat.This area has amazing history and so many sights crammed into a very walkable space.
Historic area of Istanbul. Busy, buzzing and culturally diverse. Excellent range of good quality restaurants and shops. Historic sites a well worth a visit.

Easy access from the airport, best area to stay in Istanbul. All the historic sights are within walking distance of Sultanahmet. From the airport, take the metro to Zeytinburnu Station and change there for the light rail to the Sultanahmet stop. The best of Istanbul will then be at your feet.

Lovely place. The central place in the great city of Istanbul. Almost all the major attractions of Istanbul are easily reached on foot or by tram. Also a variety of restaurants are located here and are easily accessible.

Could get lost in this area for days!. Tons of things to see, tons of restaurants, tons of Turkish Delight places where you can sample baklava and Turkish Delight until you are stuffed, tons of everything!! Lots of little streets to veer off and see stuff. You could spend a whole week in just this area alone (but don't! There are plenty of other things to do in Istanbul!) I can't say enough about how great this area is and how nice people are in Istanbul.

Wow - vibrant. I loved this area. It reminded me of the streets of New York, that are always so vibrant and something happening all of the time. It was a great experience just to walk about. All the vendors on the streets selling their wares. Sometimes you can buy something from the street vendors that will cost you double at the Grand Bazar, (as I sadly found out to late).Walking the streets late at night is especially wonderful. So alive, so busy so different. The shop windows made me stop in awe as to the array of foods available. Just get out there and walk - and if you tire, hop on a tram and just ride up and down the street - you can see so much that way without the leg power.
Fabulous. This whle area is steeped in tradition an age and has many tourist attraction. It is nice just to go for a wander and see where it takes you.

Remember to stroll around. Although you may be intent on visiting the key sights in a limited time, remember to set aside some time to stroll around the park and surrounding streets and sit and take some time to take it all in. Probably not strictly Sultanhamet, but we found Gulhane Park to the south of Topkapi palace lovely for strolling in on an early spring day, but avoid the cafe overlooking the water unless you really like Turkish tea and coffee as they sell hardly anything else!

Great restaurants.. Right next to our hotel and a wonderful place. Good restaurants, and some good shops, find Hassan he is Istanbul's best and most hospitable rug salesman. :) (even though we did not buy a rug).
Incredibly cozy. Good restaurants and many cultural things to see. Smag et mix af appelsinjuice og granatæble - or the delicious turkish delight with marshmallow.

Walk in the heart of Istanbul. If you want feel something about Istanbul you need to go there.You'll find story,culture,merchant selling all their stuff. A dive in the Istanbul atmosphere.Avoid to buy not orginal accessories.Wide choice of restaurants there!

This is Where It's At!. Title pretty much covers it. Really suggest you do Bosphorus Straight cruise and do not miss the tour of the Sultans' New Palace on Bosphorus. We stayed 8 days and found prepaid transit card great convenience for trams and ferries.

Best area. If you want to know about the history of Istanbul, this is the place to stay and tour. This was the heart of Constantinople and its remains are there, open and hidden in the streets... the walls.. the museums, bazaars, etc. It is just a fascinating place.

great!. sultanahmet is great,you really must visit it when in istanbul. you should definitely try to find a hotel around there since it is well conected with other parts of city and you wont spend a lot of money on taxi to get to blue mosque or hagia sofia

Close to the water and historic sites.. So glad to have based ourselves here within walking distance of the main sites. Hotels are plentiful, mostly small and privately owned.There are good public transport links, restaurants, shops and views of the Bosphoros from both sides of the historic peninsula. It feels completely safe and the streets are clean. Unlike some major cities, such as Madrid and London, there were no beggars or rough sleepers.
Excellent place. It is very nice to walk in Historical places. It is mostly discusting the illegal randy sellers on the streets and squers
Walk and enjoy the scenery. You have to visit this area to get a good sense of the people, trading and architecture in the city. Plan where you want to go though as there I.s so much to see.

Heart of your Istanbul visit. For the first time visitor this is your district. 6/7 of the top MUZE Pass sites are located here - and much more. Aside from the touts (especially rug merchants) I found this area to be pleasant and safe (mind I am a senior female traveling on my own).

just so much to see. I dont think there is anything to dislike along this stretch its full of little cafe's restuarants kebap places and big squares and parks all with lovely floral displays in fact theres flowers wherever you go such a lovely extreamely clean city people sweeping up continuosly there are so many cats that there is a strong whiff in the air but you get used to it
love this part. it is heart of old part of Istanbul...with its hisctorical beautiful places and little cafees... if you go to Istanbul you have to go there...

The place to stay. Brilliant location for exploring many of the famous sites all within easy walking distance. Good range of eating establishments with a wide variety of menus. Good place to book Bosphorous boat trips and bus tours. Haggle the prices down.
istanbul main heart. this is the heart of Istanbul. the mix between oriental and occidental culture. This is a rich safe district. I've spent a whole day there discovering every inch of it

The Place to Stay in IStanbul. After visiting IStanbul, I could not think of a better area to stay, but having said that, Istanbul is so brilliant, I am sure there are many areas that would be as good.Stayed at Albatros hotel which is right in the middle and surrounded by great places to eat, drink and visit. Most of the major attractions are within 15 minute walks, only five minutes to Blue Mosque area, trams that get you wherever you need to go.Whilst the area is vert tourist, it is also quite residential, so you get fine mix of living.I cannot wait to return to Istanbul and would not hesitate staying in Sultanhamet.

One amazing new world. All those colors, smells, sounds, helpful people,good atmosphere ,nice architecture, good and cozy restaurants,mosques......those thinks will make some special peace in your mind and heart ....

Where most of the tourist sights are located. Has a lot of the must see sights, easy to get around, close to tram and bus routes that take you to other areas in the area. Very touristy, but also where the locals come to shop for wedding dresses.

A great place to base your visit.. This is the best place to see Istanbul from. Most of the great sites are within walking distance and the touring, Hop-on, Hop-off buses are based from here. The cafes and restaurants are excellent and in the evening it is very worthwhile to shop around to see what discounts or benefits you can get at the different eateries.
Too crowded and dirty. The grounds between the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque were dirty with rubbish, empty bottles (without the caps), and smelled like pee.

Sultanemet Istanbul taxi scam. Taxi driver tried the scam on us but he didn't get away with it. We may be pensioner's but are street wise to, (70 and 72)He tried to tell us we had only given him 5tl instead of 50tl, well we have been going to Turkey for a very long time and know the difference !So as my husband was trying to get our money back I took a photo of the number of the taxi, made a big deal of it so he was aware and that we would give it to the police, the driver then decided he had found our 50tl on the floor and returned the change.I was very proud of myself not allowing him to rip us off. A cafe also charged us for free tea but was not worth arguing over but they did not get any more custom from us. We loved the area and had a fantastic holiday and will return this year.We had asked the price before getting into the taxi so in future we will make sure we have plenty of notes and only give taxi exact amount to avoid any more nasty surprises !

Quaint. I loved this area of town. All the small boutique style hotels, restaurants and shops. It's full of history and easy to walk around. I felt totally safe here. The people are very friendly, but everyone wants a sale, so be prepared.
lovely walks. Great district - all museums, mosques are in this area and of course the lovely Grand Bazaar. You can also find tons of little casual eateries and coffee shops. Enjoy the Old Istanvul!
it never sleeps. fun-fun-fun! lots of bars and restaurants and caffes - very colorful and fun, both during the day and at night - till the morning hous

definitely the heart of Istanbul!. Definitely the historic heart of Istanbul and a must-see. We actually stayed in Sultanahmet (at the Hotel Amira) and it was so convenient to be right next to the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, etc. We also had the Rick Steve's guide, which has an excellent, detailed walking tour of the Sultanahmet area.

Perfect place to stay in Istanbul!. We stayed at a wonderful boutique hotel in this part of the city. It was wonderful. Everything is in walking distance. Hagia Sophia, Blue mosque, Topkapi palace, spice bazaar, bosphorus ferry, etc. we did all the attractions and never took a cap or metro. Yes, the prices are a bit higher there than in other parts of Istanbul. But it is well worth it. If you like walking, then this is the area to stay in. I did hear that it gets very busy in the high season. That's why we went in March. The weather was cool but sunny. Absolutely lovely!

The place to stay. The sultanahmet area is the best place to stay. Most of the key attractions are withing walking distance. The atmosphere and vibe are truely amazing. Get lost in the side streets and see where it takes you.

Sultanahmet Area. The Sultanahmet area is the heart of Istanbul's tourist sites.It is full of history, but it is best if one reads up on the sites before going.I thoughly loved just walking around!The only bad thing about the area were the guys who desperately try to sell you something!

Take it with a pinch of sense of humour!. I stayed in one of those smallish hostels in this area for four good weeks, and yes, I agree with the previous reviewer that next time I come to Istanbul (cos I know I will..) I will prefer to stay somewhere else - probably around Taksim or Beyöglu areas. But if you only visit Istanbul for the first time for a less than a week, I don't see the reason not to. Yes, the constant - at times persistent - advance by those shops and other street entrepreneurs can be frustrating, but after awhile, we decided to take it with some sense of humour. Yes, most restaurants are overpriced, except probably Doy Doy behind the Blue Mosque which became our sort of local, but it's also a short walk to Sirkeci area where cheaper local cafes such as Fasuli can be found. The area is within walking distance to those main historical sites - which it is a great introduction to Istanbul (well, for the first timer like me), but if one needs to go deeper, then she/he needs to simply do some research and explore the other areas in the city. I decided to first explore the 'old' Istanbul, before treading its new parts, that was how Sultanahment fell into my itinerary the first place.

Better to stay somewhere else. Sultanhamet has the three most important historical sites in Istanbul (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Topkapi Palace), and thus is the center of tourism. It is also the only part of the city where you will be surrounded by gift shops, rug shops, and over priced restaurants, all geared to the tourist trade. My suggestion would be to stay somewhere else (Taksim Square area would be great, but really anywhere near the tranvia line is fine) and just go to Sultanhamet to visit the sites. Yes, it is neat walking by the Blue Mosque every day, but being hassled by all of the people trying to get you in their stores/restaurants is tiresome, and it really is not at all representative of Instanbul, nor Turkey, nor Turkish people as a whole. Also, if you stay here, you run the risk of not seeing anywhere else, which means you will end up missing out on what a great place Turkey really is. The Fatih district, right next to Sultanhamet, is a little better, but it is a lot seedier, still kind of touristy (particularly in terms of the restaurants), and not very conveniently located in terms of the tramvia unless you are up by the main boulevard. Something across the bridge on the "Golden Horn" would be much better in my opinion. Taksim Square is the center of night-life in Istanbul, so if you like lots of cool bars it is definitely the best choice.
a great area. This is where to stay in istanbul all sights close by are awesome having travelled throughout middle east we loved Istanbul wishing we had more time there.

headache. through our travels for 2 weeks in turkey, we generally met very nice people, the one experience i would not want to relive would be the Grand Bazaar...its a complete hard sell treatment and if you dont buy then they get upset..advice - visit it, ignore all the calls and only enter if you really want to buy. If you can ignore all the hassle from the salesmen then lively place to visit
Nice area and well worth the commute... Very nice area with many attractions and many restaurants, cages, and bars. Easy access on the metro tramway.
So many places to see. If you see nothing else in Istanbul, Sultanahmet is an essential for anyone interested in history or architecture

Tourist purist. So what if its crawling with tourists, there are mosques, museums, great restaurants, bazaars, cemeteries, the ocean, etc. all within half a mile. We were there in February and the tourists we could identify blended in for the most part. Also, the carpet and other salesmen were not nearly as aggressive as we'd read.
I love it. i like the small cafes and hidden restaurants. the antique shops and the sweets shops. a must see walk through the area to enjoy the little details
Great Shops and Restaurants. Apart from visiting the Blue Mosque, this area has great restaurants, Baklava and Turkish delight, I would recommend.
Busy area. This district is very busy with lots to do and see. Here you can enjoy the Blue Mosque, The Basilica Cistern, Hagia Spphia, etc.
A must in Istanbul. Loved the bars - the Sultan pub and the Bar Locum are v good.There was a lovely old bar further up the street that had the water pipes to smoke
bad food. Most of the restaurants were very keen to get business but this could perhaps have been better achieved by providing better food instead of hassling people to come in.

Great area - its like it was built for tourists. How convenient having the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, and other attractions all in one area! Topkapi Palace is right near here too. A great place to sightsee and people-watch. We enjoyed going to Denizen Coffee, which is located nearby and much enjoyed the Arasta Bazaar in this area which is a nicer, less crazy version of the Grand Bazaar (with legit carpet sellers - check out Troy Rug Shop!).

A history lesson in a small area. Wherever you go in this area there is history at every turn. A fascinating place and so much to see. Streets are easy to walk, and were kept clean. Shopping.... yes yes yes!!

best area. my first visit to Istanbul and stayed in Sultanahmet area.it was cozy place and historical and of course touristic.you can stay wherever during your visit to istanbul, but sultanahmet area is a must visit place.you will find lots of cafe provide cay (tea), coz Turks drinks tea a lot :)

A feast for the senses. Loads of character, extremely clean and very friendly people everywhere we went. having our breakfast in a local cafe, three days in a row, introduced to some of the local traders who treated us like friends (no we did not buy much)
