The Big 3. Conveniently located within a few hundred metres of each other, Sultanahmet contains the three big gest attractions in Istanbul - Hagya Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque.These outstanding historic buildings conjure up so many images from the past. Enjoy them at leisure

the heart of the city. All the important sights are there, full of tourists, noisy, but charming as well !In the streets behind the main areas you can see " normal " life as well. The people are all very friendly and you never feel threatened.
Sultanahmet District. Most of the historic sites are in this area and within walking distance. There's lots of bars and restaurants for you to chose from.Try the Cosy bar for great western music.

The Center!. A great square with many of the great monuments to visit! Many places to eat (also not turkish). if you have only one day in the city, go there and you can go to the basilica sistern, the Agia Sofia and the Blue Mosque.

The heart of the city. Narrow streets and loads of history at every turn, with very friendly people. All the shop and restaurant owners happy to help and not upset if you wander by - just join in with the banter and enjoy the experience!
Historical area. By far my most favourite area of Istanbul. The sights and stunning architecture is truly out of this world.

Wander at will. This is the place to stay in Istanbul. The very large five star hotels are across the Golden Horn but the traffic is such that you would spend most of the day in transit to the key sites which are all in this area. Stay at the Yasmak Sultan and you are five minutes from everywhere. Walking between sites is no problem and you cannot go wrong for restaurants, cafes, etc.

Excellent place to stay. It was our second time in Istanbul and again we selected to stay in Sultanahmet district.All major attractions are close by, there are a lot of restaurants, gift shops and the tramvay station of Sultanahmet .We definetely propose the area as your base for exploring Instabul

Central Tourist Area. What an historical area - well geared up to take money from tourists but very welcoming all the same. So much to see and experience, but make sure you venture outside the area on your visit to Istanbul

Nice area to stroll around. We chose to stay in Taxim area and we visited Sultanahmet district mostly for the various sights.In Sultanahmet you can find almost everything.It's a pretty touristy place and prices are a bit higher than other areas like Taxim. However for a first time visitor who wants to visit all the sights and doesn't care about nightlife it is recommended.

Old Town. This part of Istanbul was facinating. Lots of sights, lots of shopping. It was painful sometimes to walk down the streets and to keep getting hit on from vendors... constantly. But if you can get past the peskyness, there are many great shops and restaurants.

The Place to be in Istanbul. Planning a trip to Istanbul? Don't think of staying in any other area. This is the place. There are many hotels from the Four Seasons down to budget accommodations. Its advantage is its proximity to the must see places in Istanbul, all really easy walk as many are in this area. It is easy to take public transport from the area and there are many choices of good restaurants and stores.

Visit at night!!. Go walking and sightseing especially at night.. You can start by visiting the sultanahmet square (or Midan), Walk in the alleys where you can find great souvenir shops and then have dinner/drink in any pub or restaurant.
Walk, Walk, Walk. Put the walking shoes on and walk. Don't be afraid to turn down lanes, ally ways and see what you will find

Lovely historical district. Nice district with many historical points like , Sultan Ahmed Mosque , Ayasofia , Top Cape palace .And nice historical shopping points like , Egyptian Market for spices , Grand Bazar for antiques & historical staff with Gold Market
Magical at night. This area is very impressive any time, but be sure to see it at night. The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are beautifully lighted.
Old Istanbul. When you walk around this district, you are transported to the old istanbul. Narrow streets, markets everywhere, and old buildings.

best place to be SULTANAHMET area. The Old City of Istanbul is the oldest part of Istanbul, and the location of most of its historical -The tram line connects almost all of the sights frequented by travellers

Great night life, felt safe to me and people watching.. Crowded sometimes but at night with the breeze it was beautiful to sit and people watch. We did some shopping but almost everything was made in China. LOL! We walked around and ate ice cream and enjoyed the locals putting on their displays.

What a deception!. Amazed by the beautiful Istanbul and the luxurious shopping surroundings and taken to GALATA QUALITY RUGS. By our tour guide Sandy , we bought some rugs with the documentation and full payment that no further freight taxes would be charged when our purchases were delivered home. What a surprise, when the rugs arrived together with them came a freight receipt of US$ 600.we payed to receive our rugs.We were trying to be refunded since then, and they just don't give any importance. They don't give any real solution or refund. You know why? Probably because they think we are tourists that will never be back there. The menttality of the explorers.So, be aware, do not buy rugs at GALATA QUALITY RUGS, because they are not honest . I have all the documents to prove and can scan to anyone wishing to Verify.

Great for people watching. The major sites are all close to hand but the area is nice and open, lots of places to eat and very clean food stalls and lots of benches to just sit and enjoy the sites.The shop owners trying to entice you into their shops can be a bit irritating but they are good humoured and will take no for an answer

This is where we stayed. Stay in this area and you are within such an easy walk of everything (it's a massive city so I presume we only saw 1% of it) that the first timer to Istanbul should see. It seemed to me to be ultra safe, we walked around at night and just had a really nice peaceful time drinking in the magic of the Orient (well almost, that's a ten minute ferry ride away).

Not too crowded in the offseason. Visited Istanbul and the historic district in Jan/Feb 2013, the weather was pleasant and the attractions were not too crowded. Did not wait longer then 5 min to enter any attraction.

Lots of fun, few hassles, amazing color. Yes, it is touristy, but it is also lovely, filled with restaurants others may turn their noses up at, but which also have good food. I have had great conversations with the Kurdish and Afghan store staff and got from them images of another side of Turkey and Turkish life. Sultanahmet is located close to all the big sights, has terrific hotels and is filled with color.

Amazing. an amazing area to stay in Istanbul- slightly pricey in comparison to other areas of Turkey (but thats just big city prices i suppose!), and the amazing attractions and beautiful cobbled streets make it woth it!

beautiful. gorgeous place to visit with a lot to see, lot of very good restaurants and people are lovely and a lot of historical things to see. make sure you get in the tramway, great way to get about

Bustling Bazaar of Istanbul. Absolutely mind boggling to have 4 great attractions so close to each other. Walking distance of Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Musuem and the Basilica cistern.Great place for eateries and the vibrant street food of Turkey. njoyed everything from the roasted chestnuts, the corn, the special orchid drink- Sahlep to the kebabs and not to be forgotton the pomegranate juice.Defintely the best place and the local populace was just great and helpful. unfortunately for us the Hippodrome was closed at this time of the year.Would recommend all to stay in the quaint hotels here so that you can enjoy all the sights

Haghia Sophia and heavenly kofte. What more can one hope for? One would be hard pushed to think of anything that matches Haghia Sophia in scale and beauty. After that you can potter round the Topkapi palace which seems artless in comparison (but great if you're into emeralds the size of a small passenger car) and finish with what may be the best kofte (grilled minced lamb patties) in the world - and that is hard thing for a Greek (me) to say - head down the street that runs straight to the Grand Bazaar and it's a rather stark place on the right that serves kofte, soup, perhaps some lamb kebabs and not a lot else. If you have the energy there's also the blue mosque, a bevy of Sultans' tombs (and those of the siblings they strangled to avoid competition), the site of the old hippodrome (where some sensible chap called Belisarius slaughtered 30,000 rowdy sports fans in the 6th century), and the best lukum shop in Istanbul.

Plenty to do & see. Even if you only have a few days to spare in Istanbul, this is a great area to stay so that the main places of interest will be on your doorstep: Topkapi Palace, Agia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cistern, Hippodrome, etc. Its all geared up for tourists but at the same time you don't lose touch with the real Istanbul - a local waiter using his break to attend prayers at the Blue Mosque; a tourist attraction to us and a place of worship for him - makes you think ! You will still find kofta restaurants who have been serving Istanbulites meatballs for over 100 years, and pastry shops with a menu which reads like a catalogue ! You can just stagger from one to the other ! Do it and enjoy.

The place to stay in Istanbul. This area is right in the heart of everything that a first-timer to Istanbul wants to see. Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Mosaic Museum, etc are right at your doorstep in Sultanhamet.
Great area. Nice place to shopping but beware about the price they offer, bargain as your please and find at others store if price doesn't suit you. Hard to find public toilet around these area.

Historic Istanbul and tourist trap.. I love historic Istanbul and generally stay in this area. It has many famous great-big, old buildings and also lots of not-so-well-know old buildings nustled away down side streets and alleys. There is a lot to see within a short walking distance.Unfortunately, historic Istanbul has been a tourist trap for a very long time and you will be hassled continuously while you are walking around. If you are here for more than a week then this can get very wearying and trying. Please note that after dark the area is patrolled by men who will try and get you to go with them to bars, particularly in the Golden Horn. If you go with them expect to be scammed of at least everything you are carrying and probably more. Take care not to spoil your holiday. Additionally, there are quite a few street children who prey on kind-hearted tourists and it can be hard to spot whether they are genuinely in distress until you have seen them pulling the same tricks for several days. * Worth going? Oh yes. I keep going back, but take care.

Very attractive area. This is a lovely area of Istanbul, lots of cafes, restaurants, sweet shops etc. Bit annoying at certain times of the day as people want you to visit their restaurant or shop, sunglasses help as they cannot catch your eye. The front by the sea is a nice walk as well.

Romantic district. I love Istanbul sultanahmed district. It is so serene and so beautiful during the day and at night . Besides all the history the place is so tranquil . The people are friendly and not because they have to be ,but it is in their nature. My husband and kids loved it , i have been before , and will be back again and again.
Love this area. I really liked walking around this area. There are many cafes and restaurants and many historic sites are accessible.

A typical European neighborhood with a beautiful street walk experience. It is a typical European district with streets perfect for walk. It has some of the famous attractions of Istanbul like Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazaar etc. There are some fine restaurants and shops on both sides of the tramway. Visitors can shop, dine or walk throughout the day till midnight. It is a great place to book your hotel as well.

Woow. Liked pretty much everything .. The people, the food, the tramway, the traffic, the shopping, the restaurants, the souvenir shops, the desserts, the mosques and museums, the park, Topkapi, Ali Usta, Mado, Hazer Baba ...

''Too many people but so much history''. On the whole the Sultanahmet district is Istanbul's most touristic area. Whatever the season it will always be packed with people. Crowds and waiting in long lines can be really frustrating, but the place will compensate you with the joy of visiting Agia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Top Kapi Palace and the Basilica Cistern, all within walking distance of each other. I'd say you need to spend two days here if you want to take in these sights, not just visit them. You can take long breaks between them sitting on the benches around the fountain and the tiny park or savoring Turkish dishes in one of the many restaurants located there. Make sure you stay till the night falls to see the sights illuminated. Entrance fees to all sights but the Blue Mosque, which is free, are a bit high (25 TL each) and so are the prices for a decent meal in a restaurant.
amazing. I Have been before but my wife to be loved it.1st time for her and experience to treasure for life.Lovely city. Grand Bazaar and Blue Mosque. When it rains, got to the cozy bar not far away.

Just walk around... everything is beautiful!. Just loved this neighbourhood! The streets, markets, people, shops, restaurants, sights, Mosque, sceneries... don't miss anything, because everything is worth being seen! It's a great place to book your hotel, you will be close to everything.

Istanbul's Tourist District. The Sultanahmet District is full of great restaurants, shops and historic sites. There is even a Starbucks. Most cafes offer free internet and the locals are happy to have customers. It's a fun place to spend a day!

the heart and soul of the old city. There's a lot to see in Sultanhamet if you are a history buff--the old churches--including the converted ones and the newer grander mosques. The choices are overwhelming and you need to pick and choose depending on your length of stay, but in addition to the must sees--which include the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, the history musuem and the grand bazaar, there is so much else as you walk around--splendid architecture, but there are the other quaint sights as well--the fishermen on the galata bridge, the fish bread boats by the bridge, the cobblestoned side-streets and mansions, the remnants of the old Byzantine walls, the street food, the restaurants. It's even charming in the way shopkeepers approach you as you walk

Historic Amazing Area. The historic buildings in the Sultanahmet district are absolutely amazing. To be where so many cultures intersected and historical events occurred is an experience that can't be described.
Nice neighbourhood. Lots of nice people, nice shops and lunchrooms. Food was really incredible nice. Our hotel in this neighbourhood was also very fine.

A unique atmosphere. I liked this unique area. Special atmosphere, narrow streets with small, old houses and mosques, many historical sites. A real piece of history. There are also a lot of traditional cafés, restaurants with good Turkish food and the famous bazaar!

Great place to stay and visit. My friend and I moved to a hotel in the Sultanahmet District for the second half of our trip in Istanbul, and we absolutely loved it. While Istanbul does have a great public transportation system, it was nice to be where the action was. It's easy to walk around the district and see a lot of the city's highlights - including many of the major mosques, the Grand Bazaar, great restaurants and various Turkish bath houses. It's a touristy area, but great for accessibility.

perfect District to explore in Istanbul. I like this Old Istanbul-"Stamboul."- called the Sultanahmet district on perfect location in the very heart of historic town.We saw in this part Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya and very special-and known as Blue Mosque-best place to relax inside.When you enter the Mosque,blue is color of tiles,and I like it very much.This is very well known as -Sultan Ahmet Camii with the Byzantine Hippodrome, Binbirdirek Cistern and many more such as Istanbul Archeological Museums,and Great Palace Mosaic Museum.The district of Sultanahmet is very vibrant and popular as tourist atraction and everyone can have some personal posibilities to explore and relax.Aerea is full of restaurants and hotels.Many people are seling souvenirs for very low price,and tourist books about Istanbull in so many languages you cant emagine. Not to forget to tell you -dont miss to try very delicios Turkish ice cream..

beautiful and clean with lots of history. so friendly, clean, loads of history, easy walking distance. good food, fantastic weather, what more do you want? we loved it and would love to go back some day
Nice open spaces. Loved the new Hamam. Open spaces are well managed and the busses are hidden. Good use of space to put benches for the waiting. Loved the hot chestnuts.

picnic. You should definitely have a picnic in the evening, in the garden, which is between Blue Mosque and Sultanahmet. There are lots of cheap souvenir, carpet, antique shops and also barrowmen who sell chestnuts, corn, Turkish tea, you should try!
Beautiful. Great to walk around! Highly recommend getting into some of the alleys where the best food and shopping is. Spend some time just people watching between the blue mosque and hagia sophia
fascinating. Besides all the historic sites and interesting shopping, this is a wonderful place to people watch. There are no end of good restaurants. I felt very safe.

Beautiful Medieval. Walking through the Sultanahmet district is both awe inspiring and romantic. From the sounds of the people in the street to the majestic beauty of the towering mosques - there certainly is no other place quite like this. The weather in January is rather cold (4 degrees Celsius) so make sure to take a warm coat along and try some of the (rather highly priced, but still delicious) Ottoman "Special Drink" from one of the venders (5TL) a milky glutinous drink with cinnamon and honey. Also be careful of trams going through the streets as the sidewalks are not too wide here and you might at times find yourself a bit too close for comfort.

Unique place to visit.. It's very cultural, and has very interesting character, the atmosphere is so relaxing. People are nice and have a good sense of humor. Many things to see, dine and wine, taking picture, relaxing, souvenier shop, and many more.

heart of istanbul. it doesn't matter if you are christian, jewish or muslim you will find something you love here. no need to book a hotel just take the first flight & pop in to a hotel or motel and enjoy the history good food while chatting with friendly locals....a must see before you die......
Lovely. This is the place in Istambul! You can find most of the atractions here. Most of them you can walk too.

A must to visit. I loved the variety of food, shopping and the wonderful people. Be wary of people who chat to you on the street, their motive is usually to take you to their friends carpet shop - but also all part of this vibrant city. The hot apple tea is lovely.
Great civilisation. Beautiful architect, when you go inside you feel like you re in very civilised country, is really magic

Full of tourists, but feels like the UN!. I was a little worried about staying in the "tourist" section of Sultanahmet, but as there seemed to be few Americans visiting Istanbul, I found it not only convenient but also very interesting to see so many different nationalities while I enjoyed the sights.

Crowded, messy, touristic, beautiful!. Of course, Sultanahmet is essentially populated by tourists and people who work for tourists, and becomes suddendly empty when the Bazaar and commerces get closed in the evening. But even the most alternative of backpackers wouldn't want to miss it. Just lose yourself in its streets and monuments for at least half a day.

Worth it!. This area mix of everything!Old and new part you can feel it here!Nice restaurants,hotels.i just want warn people about that runners are in that area.Keep away yourself from this people.other way you will pay much more than real value in your shopping!
Good mix of Turkey meets hassle and bustle. Great showcase of modern meets historic. If you love some bustle and can handle some hassle/hussel then you'll enjoy this area.

wonderful atmosphere. Walking in the area of Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia is fantastic. Such a friendly and vibrant area! Walking to the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar are also wonderful experiences. The people are friendly and the food is great. There is a calligrapher near the tram tracks that is WONDERFUL! Stop by to see him to get a taste of Ottoman history - personalized just for you!!
Very historic place. So much too see and so very interesting in every aspect from shops too cafes and all the museums try the roasted chestnuts

What a fun place!. So much to see and so much history. If you enjoy Byzantine and early church history, visit the sites in the Sultanahmet district. Don't miss the Aya Sophia museum. Originally a church then a mosque and now a museum. You will see how the church changed through the many years and religions. It is a sight to behold.

Istanbul core. Besides the great tourist attractions (mosques, Topkapi, Grand Bazaar) at walking distance, the main public means of transport (tram, ferry) are easy to catch here. This is important in Istanbul, as the metro lines connect only with rather suburban areas and taxis are useless in the rush hours.

Great central location. For 1st time visitors to Istanbul I would recommend this area to stay. Easy access to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and the Grand Bazzar plus the tram make it an ideal launching point from which to explore the city.

the heart of old Istanbul. iN Sultanahmet you will find many of the historical, cultural and shopping places of Istanbul, including Ayasofia, the blue Musque, Topkapi palace and Grand Bazzar. Ist very safe and easy to go around. Downside is the extra prices you pay and the pushy restaurant workers trying to make you get into their restaurans.
central. This area is central, our hotel was based here. all sights in walking distance. lots of bars ice cream parlours restuarants etc

A nice place, but a little crowded. It is a historical district of Istanbul, the heart of the city. A very authentic place with many tourist attactions. One can get so much pleasure just simply walking there. It is wonderful especially at night.

Tourist area. So many sites to see, museums to visit, places to eat. The restaurants are amazing and it's hard to pick one. Just walking along the small roads is amazing. Sit and enjoy an ice cream cone and watch the people walk by.

Great area... full of historical architecture. Imposing buildings from the Byzantine period! But beware of the numerous tourist traps.... It`s unfortunate but most restaurants and cafe`s in close proximity are not service mind but only into taking your money.

Super touristy but so rich in history. This is the number one area to see in Istanbul, even though it is touristy. You can walk to all the sites very easily or take the modern tram which is convenient. Nice tourist shops as well.
history in every corner. Sultanahmet is the historic part of Istanbul where almost all the historic attraction are located. The area is very walkable and all attractions lead to one another.
Touristy. Touristy, but fun. Lots of action and sights all within walking distance. Lots of carpet touts, but they are just doing their job and add to the atmosphere

The old city. The most important sights of Istanbul are here. Within walking distance you can visit Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, Arasta market, and the Grand Bazaar or the Egyptian market are just 10'-15' away from the square. You can find also there many restaurants and cafes and some of them are really good.

The markets. The Grand Bazaar and Spice markets are worth seeing even if you do not want to buy anything. Take a lazy walk and look at the shops - the multitude of colors and smell from the spices are sure to tingle your senses.

Very easy to access the sites. Right in the middle of everything- part of the fabric of Istanbul- tea shops, durum shoppes, restaurants and these incredibly old sights. We were not hassled - people are very friendly and even the bit of "suggestion" you get from a shop vendor is just their job - we enjoyed this atmospheric area - just don't limit your trip to only Sultanamet
great lokation. nice walk but the retautants high cost all , in the night nice with the lights , walk all it is easy and you will love it
Deserves a visit. A really nice quarter, the heart of Istanbul in my opinion. It deserves a stay, it is lively and typical

Live area with thousands of tourists. Being in a place like that gives me energy. Although some people try to sell their books and stuff with amazingly different ways you have experienced before!!View of the two temples is perfect when you're standing in between and also I liked the Doner kebab and other restaurants in the area. There's a shisha bar there as well (opposite to Sultan Ahmet, in a narrow street) which can be a positive point for those who like it.

this area is great i will be back. i mostly liked the kind of houses its a public area , you can find shops there but you can walk about 20 minutes to bayazit if you love to walk you can walk to lalleli and grand bazar but its walking up , i have been there while snowing in January 2012 its was the best visit ever , i recommend this area very much also i recommend (best western antea palace and spa ) do not be afraid of the location of the hotel the hotel calls the taxi and from the first day you will knows how to be back because there is a football play ground near the area , it fabulous to see the player playing under the snow or rain , you can see them from the hotel with no noise , go for it do not go to taksim its just for new tourists (visit taksim its good but do not stay there).

A city full of LIFE. We only had 5 days in Istanbul and hardly had time outside of Sulanahment with it's bustling life: people, pigeons, cats, great historic sites, restaurants, shops, bazaars, trams, ferries, muezzin calls to prayer, steaming hammams, etc., etc. Amazing area where yesterday meets tomorrow!

Touristic but charming and easy to navigate. I feel like my experience of Istanbul was particular due to the fact that it rained and/or snowed the entire time I was there. Therefore, I didn't really get to experience the beautiful Bosphorus or seaside atmosphere. Rather, I spent the majority of my time in shops, restaurants, and attractions in the Sultanahmet district. Yes, the area is very touristic, and I heard more people speaking in English and Italian than in Turkish... however, if you're a foreigner with a limited understanding of public transportation in Istanbul, it's definitely the best place to stay while in the city! Within 15 minutes you can walk to most brand-name shops, the Grand Bazaar (waste of time), Blue Mosque, Ayasofya, Basilica Cistern, and many restaurants. Naturally, beware of prices at all sites and restaurants... they are inflated in this area because it is full of tourists. Also, double-check all prices before paying as well as change. It wasn't uncommon for shops, museums, government offices to try to rip you off by stealing a few Turkish Lira from you. Always google the exchange rate for Euro in the morning so that you can ensure that shops aren't charging you too much in Lira, as they often list the price in Euro rather than Lira. If you're in the area, I recommend staying off of the main street with the trams and exploring the side streets. There you will find cheaper restaurants, a cinema, shopping centers, and artisanal shops. As always, be smart with your belongings as theft is not uncommon!
Colourful & Viabrant. great place to walk around. People are super friendly....shop keepers are a touch pushy, but very friendly.

shop till drop. lots to see just by walking about.many proper shops and street stalls.colourful and vibrant.Grand Bazzar well worth a visit for the building architecture as well as shopping-hundreds of stalls like a rabbit warren covering huge area selling absolutly everything.

Not quite what we expected. We wanted street food, turkish handicrafts and an authentic spicy experience but what you get is cheap chinese junk being thrust upon you by insistent vendors. Food is all round very expensive and generally pretty poor. You dont come all the way to Turkey to eat nasty copies of American style fast food. Very picturesque however. Excellent tram service from the Blue Mosque.

History history history. Grand bazaar, Hagia Sophia, suleymaniye mosque, basilica cistern, Topkapi Palace, original sultanahmet koftecisi restaurant are the highlights of the area. It is very lively area. You might need to spent 2-3 days in this region since it takes time to see all these places.
Gulhane Park. This park offers a nice escape from the crowds,located by the Gulhane tram stop,it's a great retreat for a stroll or picnic in a peaceful setting.
Bluen mosque. Beware again the taggers trying to take to the ir shop for kick backsBlue mosque has anourmous sizd and tiles and splendid columns

beautiful night or day and full of history. Amazing view of Blue Mosque and Topaki Palace along with Hagia Sophia which was outstanding! The archeological museum was really interesting and loved all the mosques to step in a view!

Best area to stay if you are in Istanbul. In this are are the most attractive sites to visit. Everything you can reach on foot. Only what you need to take care of is a proper clothing for visit the religious sites. Interesting is that everybody here is selling something and the people have a "movable shops" and they will make you to buy something even if you hadn`t any intention to :-) In Istanbul people are the best sellers !
History. This area is so full of sights and sounds and smells. An incredible place to walk to try to absorb a little of the ambiance.

The main historic area. Apart from the many beautiful mosques and other attractions, there are lots of places to eat, with a wide price range. We particularly liked the ottoman architecture - graceful wooden houses and interesting little streets and city walls.
Fun!. Walk up and down divanyolu, jump on tram and see where it leads. Don;t forget to go to the famous Kofte Shop and you can jump on city sightseeing buses from here too.

Could be better. This is the most historic area in Old Istanbul, so definitely a must see for any tourist. I am not happy about the general appearance of the streets, about the many people trying to take advantage of the tourists and the prices above the average in Istanbul.

lots to see and do, essential part of your visit. historic buildings and architecture, city walls, rambling markets and souks, great food and simple transport form the modern part of the city. quite lovely way to spend a day or two. Remember to come equipped with the correct stuff (headscarves and long clothing for women, long trousers and long sleeves for men) and the correct attitude when visiting the mosques, and be aware of prayer times as access is limited or closed at these times.
Perfect area to live in. This are is by far the best area to live in as a tourist. You are close to all the sights and the tram line T1 that goes all the way to Istikal cad.
:). Love this town. So much to do. The people are very nice and healpfull. so many places to eat. I have been here 6 times and every time I find something new to do

This is a most. you need good pair of walking shoes and afull day .most attractions are in this area,Grand bazar can take a good half day.the food is really expensive paid 7 TL for an scoop of ice cream that would cost 1 pound even in London.Bazar is very expensive ,do not accept the first price told.

Outstanding Neigherhood Area. In the Sultanahmet area there is all kinds of activies going on. There are venders selling items, scrap merchants picking up items deliveries of all types and tourist busses. The workng class people are very interesting and willing to talk to you as you walk down their streets. There is pleantly of variety of places to eat or just grab a snack, go see one of the many places of interest. You could spend a lot of time in the area and not see it all.

Visit by day but dont stay at night. Sultanahmet has a lot of this historic sites and so is key to any itinerary, but there isnt much nightlife. We stayed across the bridge in Beyoglu/Galata and had much more fun in the evenings
Huzzle and buzzle. A busy and exciting part of the city. Traders everywhere trying to make a Lira. If you are into shopping this is the experience for you.

GREAT AREA TO WALK AROUND. We loved walking around the area. Lots of shops, eateries, bakeries, it was great. We came to this area 5 out of the 7 days we were in Istanbul, this is where its happening. Everything is close by. Istanbul is a great city, we are so glad we made the journey and would return. A really great trip!

Magical and strategic location to spend your time in istanbul. Many many restaurants, historical attractions, 10 minute walk from the grand bazaar (must see), spice bazaar, mosaic bazaar and a 15 minute walk from the hodja pacha show (highly recommended dance show)

Walking distance from major sights. Sultanahmet is not a typical Istanbul neighbourhood by any means, but its main advantage is that you can walk to the major attractions of the city: Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Spices Bazaar, etc.The hotels here are small, on 2 to 3 storeys houses, and are generally owned by a family. This is because the majority of the streets are steep and not very wide, so it is impossible to have a lot of huge hotels.A good option would be to spend 2 nights on a hotel on this area, and then another 1 or 2 on Beyoglu / Taskism area, so that you can experience both walking or using public transport for short rides.Avoid the restaurants if you want a decent meal. In general they are all more expensive than in other areas and usually the food is just OK. There are some exceptions - check the top 5-10 recommendations on Tripadvisor!

Two days just for this area. We took two days to explore only sultanahmet. Bahia Sofia, Blue mosque, archeological museum, the park, hamam, grand bazaar and the Tarihi sultanahmet koftesi are all we could manage. Rest we kept for our next trip.

I am currently here and I do not want to leave!!!. I am staying here while I am visiting Istanbul and I love the area.
All the main attractions are close by, I can walk everywhere from the grand bazaar to the blue mosque.
It is full of restaurants (very good ones too) and I feel very secure.
If you are visiting Istanbul and you can, stay here.
I love this area. I loved being in the center of it all, there is so much to do, see and buy! The food is great, you just have to check Trip advisor and you will find some great places!

Great place, but too many weird men. I love going to this part of town, except for the weird men I encounter along the way. No matter if I go there during the fall, winter, summer or spring, there is usually always a man trying to talk to me, propose or use some weird pick up line on me. I try avoiding this part of town, only for that reason. Aside from that, it's a great place to hang out with people and a fun place to be.

Spend more than a day here.... much to see and enjoy. I love the ancient mixed with the modern. This district has the majority of tourist attractions in Istanbul. Take it all in, and relax at a hammam when you need it most.
Overpriced, Touristy. Historical old town area so lots of history but the prices of things is so inflated and the businesses harass you as you walk around. I used my headphones to get some peace.

Everything happens here. need to look no further: the big bazaar, the best restaurants, the best city highlights are here. No need to use public transport cause everything is within a walking distance.

Delightful. Sultanahmet is, like the whole of Istanbul, full of the most beautiful historic sites - surrounded by thousands of little restaurants and shops - and off course, right by the Spice and Grand Bazaars. Cannot skip this place.
Very busy full of tourist. Quite lively place, lots of hotels and restaurants. The prices are bit inflated in the restaurants, but can have mcDonald, Burger King.

One of the liveliest places you could ever hope to see!. We were in Istanbul in the first few days of December this year and, despite ministrations from well-meaning friends that Turkey was hardly the place to go to at this time of the year, fell in love with this charming city the moment we walked out of the Ataturk airport. It is a place where the ancient and the modern co-exist in perfect harmony. The Sultanahmet district more than any other part of Istanbul best embodies this symmetry. All the major historical sights of Istanbul lie within a radius of three-fourths of a kilometre of Sultanahmet Square, Istanbul's crown jewel. The wide open spaces, the quaint palm trees lining the perfectly--paved walkways, the many-coloured fountains that light up the square after sunset, and the stunning view of Hagia Sophia looming from behind these fountains -- and yes, the carts selling freshly-roasted chestnuts and vanilla-flavoured teas, together make an hour spent here in the evening a memorable experience, relaxing and exhilarating at the same time. We sat there the first evening, after visiting the Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern-- and could not help coming back to it every evening we were there. Yes, there are vendors goimg about trying to sell their wares, and tour operators inviting you to book a trip on one of their excursions-- but each one of them has the innate tact and courtesy that distinguishes practically everybody in Istanbul from people in other metros in most parts of the world: they never hard-sell their stuff , never get on your nerves and always take a 'no' with a polite smile. The Square is a perfectly safe place too, and my daughter and I happen to have walked in the deserted Square well after ten on a windy winter night , never feeling insecure or threatened. That night we were privileged to see something truly extra-ordinary: high up in the sky on the full-moon night, a flock of seagulls was going round and round one of the Mosque's brightly-lit, tall turrets, their white bodies beautifully complementing the blue sky and the reddish-brown light from the turret. I will not forget Sultanahmet in a hurry!
Sultanahmet. Very enjoyable. Had lots of fun. it is the heart of istanbul and the original city. Contains all the important sightseeings nearby.

Too many touts. Istanbul has a load of great historical sites and wonderful mosques to see, however the locals are aware of this and even off peak in December, the Hippodrome was full of touts trying to sell books, beads, etc, And if you say "No" to one tout the others dont get the message and will try and sell their books to you. Also watch out for Taxi drivers on the make with fake 50TL notes and literally taking the tourist route, ask the Four Seasons (or other good hotel) to call a Taxi and those drivers seem trustworthy. Also watch out for fake tourists/locals who will ask you take their picture and then offer to treat you to some Turkish Tea as they will try and take you to a leather, carpet shops or a fish restaurant. Great sights but Istanbul police need crack down on these touts.
strolling. just let yourself stroll around and enjoy the streets, a visit to a coffe shop and dont miss the sweets!

Tourist traps. Simply stay away from all restaurants of Sulthanahmet...If you've been ripped off, don't hesitate to go to the nearest tourist police station (next to the tourism office in Sulthanahmet) & complain... The Police is very friendly.

A Lovely place full of History. Every corner awaits you woth a surprise bigger than the last one! Is another world. We love the food, the scenic views and most of all the people. Do not allow vendors to spoil your time just keep walking and politely but firmly say NO haw many times you need to say it!
Great Shopping. I both walked and took the tram through the Sultanahmet district. There was great shopping and great food. Bring good walking shoes, you will need them.
great place. one off beautiful mousqe i ever seen with a lot character you must see it .very busy with tourism, the building in out side with alot off history,
don't miss it. It's a great place to go. You will find many narrow streets, old houses and cosy hotels, small boutiques with huge prices :)

Touristy but worth the visit. It's amazing to think about all the history crammed into one small district within 15 minutes walking from each other but that's what Sultanahmet is. It's probably the one place everyone thinks of when you talk about Istanbul with the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace... The only complaint would be the multiple random strangers who would start talking to you and try to sell you something, but a firm no usually does the trick.

Very walkable!. I imagined Istanbul was going to be cramped and crowded, but it was so comfortably walkable and was such a pleasure to wander about in. Yes, lots of people, but the streets can handle it surprisingly well. I love how the minarets of the mosques are lit up at night...stand still, and watch the birds fly around as the light hits the bottom of their soaring wings...ahh...Istanbul!
OLD IS GOLD. Sultanahmet District. All the Old Museums buildings sorrounded the district. All were very attractive. Grand Bazaar is very nice. cheap products and nice people.

No, I don't want to buy a rug. Walking anywhere around Sultanahmet, I was constantly approached by rug salesmen. The first few times, it was just an inconvenience, but soon it became annoying to be approached 5 times a day. Most salesmen would lead with "where are you from" as though they were going to be helpful - though we didn't need any help. A few would follow trying to start a conversation for 3-5 minutes. When the same guy approached me for the 3rd time in 3 days, I knew I wasn't making enough of a negative impression.If has been about a month since I returned, yet this is what I remember most about the local people. Sad.There were some guys trying to sell upscale tours in the Ayasofya area too - they were professional and polite. Never a bother at all.The Hippodrome area has the top 7 sites all together, but seeing them all in one day would be nearly impossible unless you were extremely rushed. 1.5 days would probably be fine, if it wasn't during a busy period.Restaurants in this part of town will be much more expensive than elsewhere, but the food will be fine to fantastic and the staff's command of English more than sufficient to prevent mixups. I'm positive their English is better than my Turkish!

Sultanahmet District. It is a lovely place to visit. The environment is peaceful and serene especially at night. Even though it was cold we still like to go out in the evening and see the beauty of the buildings lighted up. The fountain was especially awesome. We also like the morning atmosphere. We would usually walk from our hotels to the district center passing by the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. It is a nice place to stay and we would suggest tourists to stay in Sultanahmet District if you are in Istanbul.

Turning back time. I'm in love with this area and can't wait to go back. The entire stretch from Sultanahmet to Gulhane is my favourite. Some of the best monuments in Istanbul are located here and it's a complete lesson in history.
Very picturesque. A nice compact area with great things to see, shops, sights and restaurants. Tram line near by also. Close to the harbour and mainline station.

everything is here. we stayed here which was great as all the beautiful sites were short walks from us. lots of restaurants and mosques etc. though some food places are touristy so educate yourself about them first
Istanbul Here I Come!. It is worthwhile visiting as it is generally inexpensive and a shopping heaven for carpets, leather goods and ancient ceramics.
Love it, like it better than Paris.. Seeing the Blue Mosque on one side and Hagia Sophia on the other. What more do you need? 1500 years of history in one place

Neorion Hotel. I am currently in this wonderful little hotel for the fourth night. You really don't need to leave this area! I am here with my adult son due to the Tripadvisor recommendation and couldn't be more pleased

Stay here, see all the important attractions. We stayed at the hotel Sirkeci Konak in this district and we did not regret it. The sights and sounds of the Sultanahmet are unparalleled. This is the markets district like the Grand Bazaar, and the spice market. If you stay within this district, you will never have to hail a taxi, just walk to take the tram. So much to see, so little time!
wonderful bazaar for shoping.. There is a small bazaar just next to the blue mosque, and you can find anything there, and much much better grand bazaar.

great district. the sultanahmet area is a historical area you can visit aya Sofia and other places, you'll find a lot of shops that sell Turkish souvenirs. if you want to eat this area is full of restaurants, you'll enjoy every moment in the sultanahmet
Great City. The people were Great , Bizare Market and Others..everything was easy good transportion and many very restaurants in area...

Tons of spices!!. Ok go in this place with knowing how much you want to spend...everyone will be tugging on you to sample tea, spices, candy etc. I spent over 500 Turkish Lira on spices but I love to cook...you will be able to find great spices that are only located in Turkey or Iran...and if you are American you probably wont go to Iran to get spices...

If stones could talk. There is so much to see in this historical old area. With a good guide book you can visit a number of smaller, less frequented sites such as Kuckuk Ayia Sophia and Constantine's column. For shoppers the Grand Bazaar is nearby as are well priced hotels and eateries. The area is also serviced by the tram which crosses the Galata bridge.

An interesting place for walking. This is an interesting place for everyone to go for walking,eating and shopping.This place has historical places such as Ayasofia mosque,Topkapi palace.You can go to restuarant as well to taste delicious Turkish foods or to have Turkish tea or coffee.You can go to this place via metro and tramways.

Touristy but fun.. The fact that many of the most important historic sites are in this area of the city leads to it being a hot-spot for the usual touristy shops, restaurants and street peddlers. Beware the many locals who offer to provide guided tours, etc. do not feel bad about courteously ignoring them and continuing on your way (although some may want to use their services).

Fabulous!. Love the sights, sounds, and business of the area as well as all the architecture! Their breads are to die for and the Baklava is right up there with it! Easy to walk around and I was alone and loved the city!

Beautiful historic places. We enjoyed visiting Sultan ahmet mosque, Aya Sophia,Top Kapi Palace,and Dolma Bahce Palace.Top Kapi Palace was facinating with its Ottoman and Islamic history. To see the belongings of the Prophet Mohammed is something fantastic. As for the arts and clothing of the Ottomans it was enchanting. The architecture is unique and grand.

To pushy and to many knock-off. Went to Istanbul for a get-away weekend and stayed in the Sultanahmet district. Location was key and area has it all. While the historical buildings were amazing the pushy merchants physically grabbing you were not. All the designer manufactures in the world could not manufacture enough product to supply the shops in this area. The constant pressure to buy and then the rudeness when you didn't made this a weekend to forget.
Great if you want to stay close to agia sofia museum. It is much better to stay in sultanahmet than in taksim area because is more quiet and you can visit agia sofia, blue mosque.

A buzzing place. Sultanahmet with its concentration of palaces, mosques, shops, restaurants and hotels lining the cobblestoned streets is the epitome of living history.There's so much to see and do here, every corner is fascinating. It's a unique experience being in Sultanahmet. Don't worry about the waiters trying to get you into their restaurants it's all par for the course. Enjoy the sights and sounds of a place thats been around since antiquity.

Very beautifully preserved. We felt very comfortable walking down this place and listening to the peaceful murmur of the water where huge carps swim leisurely by. You can only feel in awe when you see the amazing pillars supporting the roof of the Basilica and cannot leave without catching a sight at the two columns where the Medusa is represented upside-down.
Perfect... It was everything I expected in Istanbul..Shops, cafes, the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market...Need I say more?
Go early so you won't be bothered. Pretty streets offset by constant hawkers trying to sell you rugs and meals. If you look at something for a second you are going to get the hard sell.
Lots to see. So much to see and do and so many great places to eat its hard to tell you about it.Come see for yourself and you will NOT be dissapointed
Loved. I was afraid this would be overly touristy but it was in a good way. Many beautiful sites and history and lots of great places to eat.

If you are a tourist in Istanbul, book your room in this area. I often ponder staying on the Asian side of Istanbul, but that is much more modern and indicative of a regular city. Sultanhammet, with all the people trying to sell something to you still holds the most charm and ambience. I always pick a hotel either close or withing view of the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia.

Full of interest. We chose a hotel in this area to be able to reach the main sights on foot and we were not disappointed. The first day its difficult getting used to the constant approach of people wanting you sell you this that and the other, or to get you into their shop or restaurant, but at least with a polite no thank you, they leave you in peace.We knew the restaurants here would be more expensive, but we enjoyed walking out in the evening and what we paid more for the meal we saved on taxi fares. We always felt safe and loved the views of the historical buildings illuminated.
excellent. nice area, very lively, everything is open until late... lots of restaurants, souvenir shops, and hotels. Very friendly people.

Great location to eat, shop and walk around. Great area to walk, eat, sightsee and shop....if you get a chance, be sure to stop at the Four Seasons Sultanahmet for at least a cocktail on their garden patio....wonderful!

Beautiful old city!!. it is really great to walk in the heart of istanbul and explroing old city!Bleu Mosque,Hagia Sophia,Cistern and many other places.it is much better than staying Taskim area.Which i did not like is just this runners.They are allways arount you.They dont live you alone and just understanding,or geeting lost in the city!

Wow. What a perfect place to start to explore Istanbul - try the Iskander food, the Sahlep drink, the hot chestnuts, the pomegranate juice (or mix with orange juice). We also tried a soft sugar sweet that was wrapped around a stick in front of us. Sultanhamet for the Hop on Hop off tours. Look out for Mohammed and Mahmoud from Syria who were delightful and so so helpful.Good place to get an Istanbul card which reduces costs of transport (good for ferry, train, tram). Watch out for the carpet sellers!
busy!. lots to see and do, pleasant place with lots of walking and wonderful when the call to prayer happens from every direction...
Reasonable priced hotels. Best district to stay and eat. Convenient for sightseeing and resturants are cheaper then Taskim. General public very friendly and helpful

Good but a tourist-trap. Great area and ideal for photos. A bit of a tourist trap but it is an ideal place to sit whilst having a cheap lunch and catch up on your diary whilst listening to the calls to prayer echo around you.

lots of friendly cats. I loved walking around the district with all the mosques and historic sites and restaurants. It is very safe. Only drawback was the vendors who wanted you come to their shops. I finally turned rude. Interesting to me were the friendly cats which appeared everywhere, particularly at the mosques. I noticed people putting cat food out to make sure they were fed. The ones venturing in public all looked fed and kept themselves clean. The streets are mostly cobblestone, lots of hills, and there is a lot of uneven-ness. Would be hard for people with major disabilities. I navigated ok with my 2 arthritic knees.

Take a stroll. This district is touristy, but that doesn't stop it from having lots of local color and flair. Walk around and take it all in. Stop have a coffee or tea while you stroll the streets and tour the sights.

Beautiful with History and Culture. I stayed in the Sultanahmet District for 2 days and had a great time wandering on foot. There is so much history in the area that has been preserved, from the cobblestone roads to the buildings. If you stay here then you will be able to get to all the major attractions in the area by walking. A tram will drop you off right in the heart of the area. I felt 2 days was perfect to see most of the major sights without rushing, but I did not get to see anything else in Istanbul. Also keep in mind that a lot of attractions close around 5:30-6:00p (at least in November), so plan your trip accordingly.
Friendly people. Many restaurateurs trying to persuade us to dine with them but all were good-natured and never persistent

Wonderfull.... I stayed nearby Sultanahmet District. My hotel are nearby by walking distance. The are are full of shops, restaurants etc. Try on the restaurants along the roads, they serve good food and good hospitality. The tram are nearby which we can travel to spice bazaar and Grand Bazaar easily. Just purchase the Istanbul Kart, start being the locals.Not much shopping complex around this area, have to go a bit far out from the district. There is a lot of outlet centers such ad Olivium, Kale etc...The public transportation a jut within reach, easy and fast..taxi is a bit expensive though, try to use Tram or Metro services.

Heart of the city. The Sultanahmet area is the best place to be its so accessible to the cultural attractions such as The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Archeological Museum and for shopping The Grand Bazaar and the Egyptian Bazaar. These are all within walking distance and believe its worth not to take a taxi or tram. There are great reasonably priced restaurants and such a great atmosphere. I just love sitting taking in the local street life and the friendly locals. It's like no other place in the world it gets under your skin. I've travelled all over the world but this area of Istanbul is unique.

Best place to stay. I like the historic buildings around it, the train and everything around it!! The food, the garden, the fountain. A lot of backpacker lodge to stay. Must go to here if arriving in istanbul

Very Busy, but exciting. This is a great part of the city. Plenty to see, easy to walk around, but busy. Lots of tourists lots of locals, but the smells, the sounds and the activity make it a great part of a great city. Istanbul is a must visit place. Lots of restaurants, bars and take away places to eat. Easy to get to using the tram. Try one of the Kebab places, they are fantastic.
Made for the tourist!. It's almost as if the grand mosques, the Topkapi Palace, the Hippodrome, and so many more Historic sites were planned for the tourist, they're so close together and accessible!
People watch. This is very touristee, but great to watch people and relax on a bench. Also enjoy views of Hagia and the Blue Mosque at night.

Filled with beautiful ancient architecture. This really is the heart of old Istanbul and the 3 days we had to explore were not nearly enough. One of the main attractions, the Topkapi Palace needs half a day on its own.

Montmartre of Istanbul. Sultanahmet side streets, shops, cafes and mosque are the magic of the city. You should live here for a while, listen to loud prayers, get a Turkish dinner and just breathe the air of a time...
So much fun! So alive!. Loved the charm of the old city! The main sites are within walking distance. Was there four days and need more in Istanbul

neat area BUT expensive restaurants. It's a beautiful area! Easy to access from the train and close to the Mosques. Very disappointed in the restaurants, bad food and big prices. This area caters to tourists and the poor food and price reflect it!
Old Istanbul. U'll love the place..gives u the feeling of Arabian Nights.. :) sure I recommend visiting this area and enjoy the history.
A must see.. Istanbul is not only an amalgum of East and West, Europe and Asia, Christianity and Islam, old and new, but also a study in contrasts. A must see as part of a bigger picture.

Food galore and plenty of shopping. The area is filled with all types of eateries, from roadside stands to all out fancy dining. Between all the restaurants are shops selling all sorts of items. Most of the stores sell the same, or similar, items, but it is still fun to look.Also in the area are the main historic sights, The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, and Topkapi Palace to name a few.A tram runs through the heart of the Sultanahmet District, so you can be anywhere in minutes. You would be wise to get a hotel in this area to stay close to all the main sights.

Nice place to stroll around. Enjoyed my stay at the hotel at this district. Has plenty of restaurants and shops and all the touristy places are within walking distance. If anyone is concerned about safety, I would say it is very safe.

Busy busy. It was very clean and I found it to be open spaced with lots of different areas to sit and relax.Lots of fountains. Restaurants are good and I loved the cakes in Grande shop. Trams were clean and travelling was so much easier.

Old Istanbul. Loved the maze of narrow cobbled streets and all the little eating places and food shops. So many "must visit" tourist attractions within walking distance. So glad we chose to stay in a hotel in Sultanahmet
An interesting 'old town'. We stayed in the Sultanahmet and enjoyed a walking tour with our guide around all the very promiate sites.

THE place to stay in Istanbul. Get a hotel here, walk to all the main sights. Everything tourists come to see is located here, within walking distance of each other. Pay attention to the street vendors, sometimes they put on a real show!

amazing sultanahmet area.... just about everything you need is in this place...and its over 12.000 years old...from the grand bazzar, to the blue mosque,hagia sophia and the much overlooked area...of restaurants,a perfect location...if you visit without your camera,video, you might as well go to nigara falls with a paper umbrella, not too get wet...lolthere is a hippodrome...*sultanhamet meydhyani) the square...including cleopatras oblesik and other sites...well worth the panorama....the most historic places on the planet...
Very touristy. Lost of tourist shops, very busy, not quite the 'mystique' we expected of Istanbul with a Starbucks etc, but we had a good wonder

Both Christianity and Islam Have Left their Distinct Mark. You'll not find a more historically fascinating city. There are magnificent mosques all over Istanbul, with the most significant ones being located in the Sultanahmet. You can't buy alcohol in this neighborhood because of its religious influences, and the locals are less impressed with Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the father of modern Turkey, and more tied to traditional Islamic thinking and values. All that said, no visit to this great city would be complete without spending some time in the Sultanahmet.

Sultanahmet area. Lovely area, steep streets but very interesting, take care to plan your trips as wondering round this area can be very tiring, although there are trams, careful of the taxis as they can try to rip you off
One-stop area. The perfect place to be in Istanbul. EVERYTHING is around you, near you, shops, restaurants, museums, monuments, Grand Bazaar. Perfect location.
the place to be. everything you need to see is around this area, within walking distance of all the sites, good restaurants (check to see they serve alcohol before sitting) and a good atmosphere
A place where a day is not enough.. This is one of the oldest and most historic places of Istanbul. Here you can find Topkapi Palace, Sultanahmet Mosque and Basilica Cistern.
old world charm. the whole district makes u go back to the olden days ....if u want to cover history in istanbul this is the place ...

Great Buzz in this area. I have been in this area several times this year, most notably in August / September with friends. For the sights etc you have the Blue Mosque and the Cisterns which are both seriously worth a visit. However I only recently discovered all the wee side streets and bars.. You can spend a whole weekend in this part of town seeing the sights and cooling down with a wee beer..... Or two... Three if you want... And then try one of the excellent restaurants.... Then have beer four.To get here there is very good...... But very busy public transport. The trams can be Mobbed!.. Watch out for those Turkish armpits in summer.

Spiritual... Looking at the Blue Mosque makes u wonder how great the Ottoman Empire was! Even inside the mosque was fantastic..I loved the paintings and drawings on the ceiling, the stand of the Muslim prayers "Juma'a" was a masterpiece of pure art!

Great walking district. Love Sultanahmet as it hosts so many of the wonderful attractions of this amazing city. Other areas of Istanbul hold different charms, however for me Sultanahmet is distinctive in its ancient offerings.
good for shopping, sight seeing, lots of places to eat.. Blue mosque, Topkapi Palace and grand bazaar all easily accessible. lvely area. Walking distance to hotel.

Great place to tour and walk. Walked from hotel to Grand Bazaar then thru local streets/vendors down to the Spice Market and across the plaza to get a ferry boat on the Bhosphorus--all very walkable and interesting sites. So easy to walk in this area. Really helped to get more of a feel for the city and people than always in a car.

Full of history and contrasts. There's a lot to see and experience here. In addition to the obvious attractions, it is interesting to just walk through the area and experience the smells and sounds. The people are very friendly and anxious to please. Bargaining with vendors can be fun when you want to buy something but they can be a pain if you just want to browse. If you even look in the window, they think you are ready to buy.

Place to stay. This is definitely the place to stay and walk around in the evening....You have plenty of shops, restaurants, fast food... all street are animate with great atmosphere and colorful lights and surrounded by magic architecture such as the blue mosque or the grand bazaar that make you feel in holidays...

Gorgeous, packed with things to see, do, and buy. The Sultanahmet area has got to be the most famous area of Istanbul. If you are looking for neighborhoods to choose from, I'd definitely suggest here. Suggested attractions: Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Arasta Bazaar, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Akbiyik Street. You can shop, eat, marvel at wonder-of-the-world-type of attractions, relax in a hamam (Turkish Bath), pet the thousands of cats wandering around.
Best City Break in the World. We liked everthing about it, coming back for another visit, as we didn't manage to visit all the historical places
history abounds. one magnificent sight after another, all within waking distance of each other. it gets crowded but for good reason

Full of history, culture & shopping. We stayed in a VRBO self catering flat in the sultanahmet district and awoke everyday to views of the blue mosque and the sea. There are restaurants that offer amazing views in this area, the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the grand Bizarre and a smaller bizarre behind the Blue Mosque. There's really great restaurants. If we were to visit again we'd definitely stay in this district again.
most interesting part. a lot of restaurants,all the most interesting buildings together,terrasses,dubbeldecker start voor touring around.

Best place to stay. We had 5 days in Istanbul and found this was definitely the best place to stay. It is within easy reach of all the best the city has to offer. The trolley bus is a big help to get around and we loved the buzz and excitement, the multitude of places to eat, the shopping and the friendly locals
Sightseers delight. So much is packed into this area it could keep you busy for days.You can see palaces,Mosques,museums,the Hippodrome,parks where families walk and play,an obelisk and much more
The District to stay in. This is a great place to stay and have easy access to the historic sites of Istanbul either on foot or by tram.
History at your Feet. Too much to do! Haga Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, and the Grand Bazzar! And Great food everywhere!
Best area to stay in Istanbul as a tourist. Comfortable feel, decent hotels and restaurants and great access to main sites and trams to other areas of Istanbul

best area in Istanbul. This is the best area to stay in Istanbul. The Spice market, Grand Bazaar, red bus etc, all great. The tram system is cheap and easy to use. the restaurants and the lovely little shops make this area the choice are to stay in Istanbul.
Walk around, taste, smell & enjoy. Pleasant district to walk around during day or evening. Taste the snacks, drinks, diner option (Ottoman kitchen) and sweets!
A beautiful area. It has to be seen to appreciate it. We loved the relaxed atmosphere of the area with hardly any hassle. It was lovely to sit on a bench eating corn on the cob like the locals do.
So much to see and do. A great area to stay because you are so close to all the sights. It has tons of restaturants and shops - all that a tourist needs.

very visitor friendly. therea re clear maps everywhere. Convenientlky the Ottomans have arrange for the three major sights to be close together (with the Basilica Cistern and the Hippodrome also there) and there are lots of places where you can sit and get a drink or something to eat without being ripped off.

It is just the area that most of the people imagine hearing the name of Istanbul. I really like the atmosphere very much it's the best place to meet many people from all around the world and to visit the very nice and historic monuments of Istanbul
Stay here. If you only have a few days in Istanbul and have planes to see much, this is were you should stay. All the big attractions are beside each others so no trams are needed.

Touristy, but aren't we tourist. This area of Istanbul is touristy, but I'm a tourist so it was perfect. The best attractions are the Blue Mosque, Haga Sofia and the Basilica Cistern (loved the latter). There are also great shops and restaurants. You may find cheaper prices in the Bazaars, but it's still a nice place to wander. Don't miss the Cagaloglu Turkish bath. It's very close to the Basilica Cistern and of the one's I tried, the best!

perfect place to start visit of istanbul. The old city is all very close together and great to walkabout...lots of attractions close by...Feels safe to visit even in the dark....good restaurants...can walk down to the seafront.. Minutes to the blue mosque...easy to find a good turkish coffee or delicious pomegranate juice...

MAJOR TOURISTIC AREA. This is the major touristic area of Istanbul, with most of the historical highlights located in this district and are all within easy walking distance of each other. There is an abundance of hotels, many of which are smaller boutique hotels housed in renovated old buildings, a variety of restaurants with menus of a wide price range, bars, small clubs, shops selling Turkish crafts, fashion and accessories especially scarves, etc. Shops and restaurants tucked away in small hidden streets tend to have lower prices, while those on the main drag charge the most. Mature travelers may find this district more appealing than the modern Taksim area & Istiklal Street frequented by the younger set due to the large number of cafes and bars and a boisterous nightlife. Sultanahmet is much quieter at night.Sultanahmet gets overrun by tourists in the summer, its main drag congested with foot traffic during the day and early evening. In the large public areas. if you're a woman walking alone- young men loitering there may follow & try to befriend you, starting by asking "Where are you from?" or some other cliches. It is best to keep your personal distance and go on your own way.
Beautiful. Impossible to drive through but very interesting. A lot of the really important places to visit are there: Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, Blue mosque etc.

Overhyped location - Grand Bazaar. The Grand Bazaar is very old. That is all about it. The shops, goods et al is new. Shopping experience will be good. Good chances of you feeling lost but do not worry. You can get out from any of the many doors / entrances. The people around will guide properly. Or look for a policeman / woman. They are courteous and very helpful.
Delightful. The narrow streets, the atmosphere both make staying in that area a must. Plenmty of good restraunts to visit as well as historical sites.
History, great sights and lots of people. The main attractions got very busy - so visit early. Lost of history, but also good to look at. Even the children enjoyed it!
Istanbul old city, Topkapı Palace, Hagia Sophia,Cistern Sultan Ahmet Blue Mosque. , It contains many culture at this area on your walking distanceyou can easy arrive , we all like them

Amazing Place. A beautiful and a MUST place to see and visit and explore pure Turkish culture. There are plenty of places to shop around and eat.For shopping, the main streets are a bit expensive for obvious reasons. If you get some time at hand, make sure to get lost in those small, hidden markets/shops where you can find extremely cheap, traditional Turkish stuff. You might have to push yourself with communication skills if you don't know Turkish language :-)

Quick tour through Sultanahmet. After all our travels, it is good to see Sultanahmet. We did not have a chance to see Topkapi Palace because it is closed on Tuesdays. One thing I like during this quick tour, is that everything is in walking distance. Put on a comfortable pair of shoes for walking!
Quaint. We stayed in this district. It is within walking distance to the major tourist sites and good shopping. It was busy but not overwhelmingly so. I highly recommend staying there.
Great area. This side of Istanbul is also great with a lot of interest and things to see and do including lots of shopping ~!

I like this place so so so much.... I have spent my honeymoon there. It is very calm place with its small hotels. You will enjoy the small roads and the restaurants here and there around you. You can walk so easily to the metro station and go anywhere so easily. You can walk to the blue mosque, Hagia Sophia, Top Kapi Palace and other places. You will enjoy your stay there. For me I have enjoyed my stay in this marvelous place. You will feel as if you are at home. Don't miss it and book your hotel in this area and enjoy!

you know you're in Turkey!. It may be chaotic, noisy and dirty in some places, but this is an essence of this city. Whether you are a history buff, after culinary adventure or just want have some fun - there is something for everyone.

great place to stay at. we stayed in taksim before, my husband and i, but sultanahmet district was a lot more. its very close to all the historical monuments we wanted to see, grand bazaar is close by and tram line takes u almost anywhere you wanna go. lots of really nice restaurants, some are rather cheap and lots of cats in the parks, very friendly and clean cats i must say, some are really nice breeds to. so being a cat lover i really enjoyed hanging out there.
The main reason for sightseeing in Istanbul. Key exhibits and buildings within easy walking distance of each other. The centre is easy to reach by tram
tokopi. all was good except long ques ,but thats acceptable. as i said earlier the place has been well maintained.
fantastic spot. This is one of the most spectacular places to visit. You have the topkapi palace, hagia sophia, the cistern, historic markets, the Blue Mosque

One of the most interesting districts. This area is filled with fascinating museums, mosques and churches, a warren of ancient streets and parks and shops. It's also very safe and usually loaded with tourists day and in the evenings.
Must visit. I really like this old area of Istanbul the small streets the different cafes the stores etc a bit slow at night but nice overall

A good place to watch tourists and see the major tourist attractions. You will see the major mosques, and Ottoman buildings, the Hagia Sophia, and a few scraps of the Roman and pre-Ottoman period. This is Istanbul's prime location for housing, feeding and entertaining tourists. It is not to be missed, but this is no more a representation of Istanbul than Disneyland is of America, or the Eiffel Tower is of France.

Perfect location near main sights.. Great place to stay for tourists visiting the mosques, bazaars, and restaurants. However, there is not much nightlife so you would near to go to the Taksim/ New City for clubbing.
Take a hotel here!. There is no point to stay away from this neighborhood. Better take a cab or tram by night for a trendy area than keeping doing that for daily sightseen in Sultanahmet.

Best area to stay for Istanbul Virgins. If this is your first time in Istanbul, it's best if you choose a place to stay around this area. If not, you'd end up travelling to Sultanahmet area for at least 2-3 days using the tram to cover the main tourist attractions - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace and Basillica Cistern, Bazaars and restaurants and sift through tons of other tourists. Tips:- Go very early or very late for entering Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sofia. It is worth it.- Check Tripadvisor reviews to find the best restaurants in the area.- There are bazaar, restaurants and shops that will sell you everything almost 24/7.- If you dont buy anything from street vendors, most will say 'Sorry, No English?!', Buy something from the vendors like the bread or corn, and they'll be your friends and they speak to you in fluent English.

A walk to remember. Get off at the tram station sultan Ahmet and then walk a around. Try the ancient koftacesi ( meatballs), tour the mosques and museums and the under ground cistern. A little walk down there are some beautiful Turkish restaurants and even some that serve bodrum cuisine. Try the salt baked fish. A stop away there is the Grand bazaar but I'd recommend comfortable shoes as the market itself is a walk. The streets are dotted with smaller monuments all little gems.

Experience Old Istanbul. I would advise strolling and staying in this district. It is well worth the experience and there are many quaint hotels and you are only a 5 minute walk from the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, and a few minutes more and you can catch the tram anywhere

the best place to roam. it is just fun to walk in this place and visit all the sites like the blue mosque. walk a little more and yu reach the grand bazaar. shopping is amazing. also can dress in turshish style and take a photo. have watermelon or anything on the road. really clean and resonable. buy the turkish cap 10 dinars. see the sweet shops just amazing

Lots of history in a small area.. There is so much to see in this area - the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofia, Basilica Cistern and the Hippodorme. Saves walking too much . Noone made us feel we had to hurry. YOu can get a giude but we preferred to use our books and visit at our own speed.

Impressive Place. the size of the mosque is huge in the middle of the Square the Area name belong to the most famous mosque located there " SultanAhmet Mosque or as most of arabs Called it " The Blue Mosque " which took this name cause of the Ceil inside the mosque decorated with the Blue stones .. first time i heard about the Blue Mosque when i been to Egypt and visited the Citadel of Saladin where the Albaster Mosque located there of Mohamed Ali it was one of the highlight mark in Cairo as well .. very recommended to everyone want to visit Istanbul you must stay in Sultanahmet District you would be surprised ..

no brainer. It is tourist central, but there are numerous great historic sites, and the bazaars are well worth a visit. I would eat elsewhere though - go back over the river and up the hill - lots of nice places near the tower.

international tourism. i liked the number of tourists there were from all over the world, but, it was an area that was full of us!! This meant we were subject to all the hassle that you might expect...I could have done without the offers to buy stuff all the time. The whole area was so clean though! Really puts London to shame. and it was very easy to go off the main drag and suddenly find yourself far from tourists. It is full of tourists for a reason though - there is so much worth seeing..mindboggling.
The beating heart of Istanbul. My fav place so much to see and do from shopping to historic sites. If pushed for time try to stay here as all the sites are walkable from many good hotels
Just do it. Love this area. Can't say enough about it. Will stay here on every social visit to Istanbul? It has everything you will want to get a sense of the place and history.
Viisite of Sultanamet. Sultanamet is a very nice place to visite, mainly for the Hagia Sophia Museum and the Blue Mosque. Even, if the price offered on this area are more expansive than elsewhere.

The real Istanbul. There is nothing not to like about the heart of old Istanbul.It is the historical centre with character and all the 'must see' important sites are within walking distance. Great street vendors will sell you roasted chestnuts and sweetcorn cobs.

Lovely area for sightseeing and shopping. Perhaps we didnot research the food part, which was exceptionally bad at one of the restaurants that we ate at, but the rest of the places were very good. We went for a Whirling Dervishes Ceremony & Sufi Music Concert (you can email them at istanbulsufiensemble@gmail.com for more information about the timings) - it was a beautiful performance (try to negotiate when it comes to price of the ticket, we paid 45lira per person). The Sultan Ahmet mosque has an astounding solid structure given its time of construction was so early. The have fine places for shopping at sultanahmet district catering to tourists, including the normal wear for females in turkey (voluptuous skirts and pants).

Yoohoo I'm over here !.
