I dont think Ive ever experienced the huge amount of people in one place before !I'ts an amazing place so much going on, so much to see and do.Whether you travel by train, tram, metro, taxi or car, it's a mad mad world. Dont miss going on the sightseeing open top buses hop on hop off. 50 TL each but worth it.We obviously looked liked tourist as we were hassled as soon as we got off the tram. but stick to your guns if your not intrested.Great places to eat, but watch out for the price of wine by the bottle can be 95 TL

Fantastic!. I absolutely loved Sultanahmet. I would definitely recommend staying in this area to anyone that is visiting Istanbul. It is a little touristy in parts but there are a lot of outdoor restaurants and bars that create a really fun and friendly vibe. Its close to a lot of the historic sights - Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Hippodrome etc. I was traveling by myself but I was never bored in Sultanahmet. I couldn't recommend it more!
lots to see. There are lots of small side streets to walk along, to explore, things to see. You can get engrossed here.
It has everything!. Sightseeing, shopping, eating, relaxing, you can spend the whole day in this area without getting bored.

huge mosque. One of the majestic mosque that worth to visit, ordinary clothing are acceptable for tourists to enter the mosque. Very clean and there's a bazaar nearby where you could buy souvenir and other trinkets

lots of accommodation options. lots of accommodation options and the area close to at least 5 of the top 10 sights in Istanbul for tourists. It's cheap and easy to get a cab to the other districts, or catch the tram too... some good restaurants, try a rooftop terrace!
Loved it!. Great area, wonderful atmosphere, fab shops and restaurants along with all the amazing historical attractions.

Close to all the best attractions in Istambul. Attractions open until late. Close to all the best tourist attractions in Istambul.Area for foreigns, but very pleasant, full of good restaurants, and places to have a tea.

Avoid Sultanahmet other than to see the sights. Crowded, full of touts and perhaps the most unfriendly woman working in the tourist info centre that we have ever encountered. Even the exchange rates you get here are not as good as elsewhere in the city.

Old European Area. Beautiful cobbled streets, old quirky buidlings and stunning mosques. All the small hotels are well located for walking the area for a couple of days and loads of lovely restaurants too.
What a old city. Everyone has to go and see the history in Istanbul sultanahmete . We will be back for sure with the family

Have only scratched the surface. We absolutely love exploring this remarkable, historic , vibrant part of an extraordinary city. We have returned- and am sure will find ways of 'stopping over' in Sultanahmet again and again and again. Guide books are useful - although stumbling across places is also great. We loved some of the rooftop restaurants overlooking the Bosphorous and over to another continent. An extra trat this year was a spectacular firework display on their national day.
Overhelming owner of restaurants and shops. Yes they are overhelming but this is the charm of the place. Dont bother yourself wiht it take it as it comes and enjoy
My place. Whole day we used to be at this place moving here and there, relaxing, eating, shopping, all historic sites nearby, trams, tours..this place has everything.

Great Area. Well, you're almost assured to go to this area at some point in your trip to Istanbul, assuming you're there as a tourist and not on business. This area has all the best and most well-known stuff, and you can walk for hours on end just exploring new places. Have at it!
Everything is nearby. Most of the sites are near this area and its well connected with nice cafes and restaurants. It has the famous Hafiz Mustafa shop for baklava. Highly recommended

The Place to Stay and Dine. We stayed in this area for 5 days and the convenience of being able to walk to all the major sites and the Bosphorous was well worth the extra accommodation costs of staying in this area. We felt very safe at all times and were very comfortable wondering bah to our hotel after diners of an evening. It is a great place to end the d ay with a glass of wine people watching.

You could spend a week here. Hotels, restaurants, Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar --- they are all here! The district is easy to walk around and the public tram takes you to many of the major sites. A wonderful experience!
Small and compact. Small enough to walk around and packed with amazing sites. Very good outdoor spaces ie. Hippodrome.Great variety of shops, cafes,restaurants
Great place to stay and walk to mnay of the attractions. We were easily able to get to the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Bazaar, the Bosphorous, Hagia Sophia, and many neat restaurants.

The beautiful Blue Mosque. Lots to do and see, including the Blue Mosque - visit just after prayers, Aya Sofya (arrive early - we had to miss this as the queues were just too long), and two amazing cisterns (Basilica - well known - and the smaller Binbirdirek seemingly unknown - we were the only visitors when we were there).

Plan a full day to see this area. Even a full day may not be enough to see the best parts of this area. Highlights include the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophia, Cisterns and Topkapi Palace as well as the bazaar. To see it properly, two days would be better. It is just too wonderful to describe.
Byzantium/Constantinople. Many examples of human enginuity and building skills from antiquity, Greek, Roman and Ottoman eras. All in a compact area and close to transport and other tourist sites.

Great place. Really enjoyed walking around the narrow, ancient streets full of souvenir and carpet shops, full of charming little cafes and restaurants. No need to take a taxi as all the main attractions are so close to each other. Plus with the traffic really terrible (no parking rules at all) it's actually quicker to walk. Need a map though as it's a bit of a maze.

The essence of Istanbul. For a tourist, it is the perfect place to stay. Lots of nice hotels, plenty places to eat, and the food is great. Most of Istanbul's attractions are in Sultanahmet, within short walking distance to eachother, and once you figure out the tram, it is very fast and easy to get everywhere else in Istanbul. It is safe, friendly and convenient.
Just amazing area. So many things to do and see. Colourful, noisy, good restaurants, vibrant.... everything what you need is there. Just fab.

So many beautiful and interesting sites. Awe inspiring and so easy to walk between one fabulous place and another. I think it is imperative to stay in this quarter to really enjoy the atmosphere. There are so many 'Must Sees' in this quarter - it is a history buff's Aladin's Cave.
Great areas of town to stay and eat.. This was my favorite area of the city. It was a great location to access most of the old town sites with short walks, or easy access to the tram line.

Wonderful place to stay. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district and absolutely loved the area. Of course you have the main attractions like Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque which are truely beautiful. But we also like the atmosphere. Especially on the square / park between the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque there are many benches to sit on. You can buy fresh fruit, fruit juices, freshly prepared popcorn tea etc. on this square. It's very nice and relaxing just to sit there and watch the beautiful buildings and people passing by while enjoying a drink. You can find plenty of nice restaurants. The area is clean too.

Best place to stay in Istanbul. If you want to experience the culture and feel the buzz of Istanbul this is the area to stay. Everything is within walking distance- historic sites, restaurants, bizaars, tram station. Just magic!

Centre of Istanbul.. This is the place to be in Istanbul. Most of the main mosques, bazaars and museums are here within walking distance. Plenty of good restaurants too. Galata Bridge is within walking distance and all those seafood restaurants below, have my taste buds savouring at the thought.
Old Town Turkey. Tons of shops and restaurants, friendly people and lots of energy. It's close to the major Istanbul sites like Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque and just a fun place to be.

okay. it's kind of historical area and i was there for several times. i like to be there. the only think i dont like there its the kind of apache people around. they always disturbing people and trying to sell something.

The Old City. There is nothing quite like walking the streets of the Old City. Beautiful colours are everywhere and beautiful old buildings. Make sure you have a very comfortable pair of walking shoes on as the cobble stoned roads can be hell on the feet.
THE ONLY PLACE TO STAY. Loved it to pieces. Stayed in Taksim too which was lovely but I would recommend the Sulttanahmet area as it's quaint, European and close to all the sights.

The center of history. Easy walking to many of the major ancient sights of Istanbul.
Loads of good restaurants on every street. On the down side the restaurant and carpet hawkers are a bit of a nuisance at night.

Historic center. This is where you find most of the major attractions. They are easily reached by foot. I was pleasantly surprised by the atmosphere, not at all as crowded and no peddling in the streets.

A walk in history. What a wonderful area. Within easy walking distance you have so many things which bring together the Turkish history. And how wonderful that so many historic areas are still alive and
well today. A must see for any Istanbul visitor. Impossible to pick a favorite, everything is on the top ten.
Sultanahmet District. We stayed in this area, and were glad we did. Walking distance to all of the major sites. As well as a charming area to walk around in.

History to see and touch, modernization in the making. One of the places where the world's cultural heritage was nurtured. The effort to make it into modern times is impressive, yet the surroundings still show the signs of poverty, and whealth in progress
great area. handy for most of the tourist sites don't be afraid just to wander about felt safe even at night plenty of places to eat all serving much the same menu try the apple tea

Busy area, better if you are in to shopping. Very busy area of the city. Shop owners are all trying to get you in to their restaurants, shops, etc. If you can try to ignore that it is quite a beautiful area with a large square and views of the blue mosque and haga sophia. I found the grand bazaar somewhat underwhelming.

Interesting, amazing.... This district is really amazing - so many great historical monuments and buildings in a small area... Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hammam, Cisterne, Topkapi palace, etc... incredible! We were truly amazed with the historical value of this area...
Center of Exotic. Stayed around this area, total convenient to all attractions of Old Istanbul. Mosques, Grand Bazaar, cafe, Starbucks, Restaurants. It's a recommended area for accommodation.

Hard to beat an area with such history and charm. First time in Istanbul - great area to get a taste of real Istanbul (I was on a business trip so had limited time) - you can go to the Blue Mosque (a must), Hagia Sophia, the Old Bazaar, Spice market, and just wander around little shopping streets, and soak up the atmosphere. Bargain hard - the shop keepers will love you for it - and enjoy. The Turks are a wonderful nationality - so kind and charming! If you have limited time, go here first.

Gem on Bosporus. We walked through most of Sultanahmet area maybe 10 km radius and we have seen things you will never see from a taxi. Architecture of the old buildings is unbelievable and who likes history will be in owe of it.

You need lots of time here. You do not want to miss the Spice Market or the Grand Bazaar. The maze of little shops, all underground, will delight you and even scare you a bit because you'll be nervous that you will not find your way out. The colors, patterns and delightful shop owners are a treat.
Ancient and modern perfectly coexist. Sultanahmet is a part of Istanbul which surrounds you slowly, where Mosques and Gran Bazar coexist perfectly with modern electric trams.

Fascinating Sultanahmet. This area of Istanbul is it! Most of the main tourist attractions are to be found in the area: Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, The Cistern and the Hippodrome. It is easy to walk around and feels very safe. There is good transportation but walking around is the best way to go. Because of all the tourist attractions, there are lots of hotels at different price range and other amenities such as restaurants, money machines, shops etc...

Nice neighboorhood. Everything in this neighboorhood is beautiful! Bring your camera and shoot some nice pictures!What I like most is the Aye Sofia and the the park. It's nice to sit there and watch the fountain.

Couldn't be more convenient!. Really liked the Sura Hotel--fine restaurant, reasonable for dinner. Breakfast not included in room rate the only drawback. Enjoyed finding other great places to eat and shop in the neighborhood.
Heart of the Old City. That there was so muc to see/do in such a compact area. All within walking distance. So many shops of differing quality goods.

Buzzing with atmosphere. Tourists love this area for a reason. I stayed here in 1974 as a student then again in 2008 as a bit of extra luxury when my wife met up with my teenage son and I on our 10,000-mile cycle expedition from Ireland to Japan (book: Long Road, Hard Lessons). I've been back twice since. Its charm never wanes. In fact it has improved over the years due to the more relaxed attitudes of the locals. No longer are you hustled into shops to buy trinkets or carpets. It is a great place to stay as there is so much happening here and it's easy to get a tram to Taksim or other areas each day. For cheap, lovely accommodation try Antique Hostel or the more frequently available but less beautiful Nobel Hostel around the corner. For something more luxurious but small and romantic, try Hotel Zoe. These are all a stone's throw from Sultanahmet square. Plenty of others though.

a big and relaxing area with loads of history in the air and in the buildings. Go and enjoy the walk around Sultan Ahmet mosque, or Aya Sofia mosque, Hippodrome, see the Museum of Islamic and Turkish art, a beautiful Soguk Cesme street, see the German fountain, and relax in the park between the mosques. Muslim visitors should not miss the opportunity to pray in Sultan Ahmet mosque.
rosneb. Within walking distance from our hotel. Quite a few different sites to look through. Not too busy when we were there
busy busy busy. packed with people most of the time.tourists<lots>loitering turks and people going about their business.got annoying after a while but that is turkey and wouldnt want to miss it

Easy Parking - Great Location. We were advised by a friend to stay in this area and he was absolutely right. We stayed here twice, once with a pre-booking and the 2nd time a walk in with car needing 2 rooms. It was busy but we found great spots both times for around 100 euro. You feel you are out of the manic tourist zone yet only a 5 minute walk to the front of the blue mosque and the historic area. We got car parks in front of the hotels both times - free and we felt safe.

A must Visit. With so many major sites you would want to come here anyway, but the place was very friendly, and we felt safe at all times, even in the late evening as places were starting to close up. It is a central place to stay and we loved it.
Very Rich District... Most of the attractions are located in one spot and within walking distrance from each other. you can easly spend a full day moving from one attraction to another.

Great area, but too many hustlers and cheats.. This is the historical centre of Istanbul, rich in history and beautiful mosques etc. The place is, however, full of tourists and that has lead to some unfortunate side-effects. The street vendors charge extra from unsuspecting tourists and getting a taxi in this area is totally unadvisable as the drivers cheat, lie and put their meters on triple-speed even if you try your best to agree on the price beforehand. The people selling guide books and trying to force you into getting your shoed cleaned are also very aggressive and ill-mannered. In my opinion visiting this area alone is not advisable unless you're a body-builder with a menacing face.
Heart of the city. it's really really heart of the city.i have been very central hotel there.i could reach everywhere from there.so nice
central part to see all the highlights. stayed at constatine hotel.. it was a 3star, but the people there were very friendly and accomodating.. tram station was across the hotel
Exciting place. Wonderful atmosphere. Great restaurants and charming little hotels. Shops are in danger of causing sensory overload - they are full of decorative and colourful treasures.

The best place to stay in Istanbul. Choose from one of the many boutique hotels in Sultanhamet and you will be within walking distance of most of the main tourist sights and a plethora of restaurants to suit all budgets. Sure the shops are very touristy but there are two very good bookshops stocking only English language books so you can catch up on some Turkish history whilst there.

Touristic Centrale. This place is Touristic Centrale but most of us love the fact that we can see everything that we've seen on a calendar or a Discovery Channel doco in the one spot. And that's what you have at Sultanahmet!The purists will tell you to get into the 'real' istanbul (wherever that is) but you can do some exploring after you've taken the photos and ticked the box for the major attractions at Sultanahmet. It's not cheap, it's crowded but it's a great place to stay with easy access to transport, no shortage of attractions and generally very friendly people!!

Bustling with action. So much to see and so little time is a feeling that you would end up with at Sultanahmet. You'd like the Topkapi palace and the various restaurants.You would not like the Grand Bazaar as bargains are struck every second and not by you !!!
So much history. This area was quite fascinating, although quite busy our base at the Sarnic meant that we could wander before and after the tourist buses! This made a big difference.

Beautiful day or night. I love being able to walk around in this area. I visited the sites during the day but this area is also great after dark, when it seems to become a spot to hang out. There is a restaurant near the Haggai Sofia that was a great place to get a sandwich and take in the local atmosphere (can't remember its name),

the heart of Istanbul. If you have one day in Istanbul this is where you start and finish your visit. Very beautiful and atmospheric, unlike the chaotic real city, with all the important sites within walking distance, with plenty of shops, bars and restaurants around which are quite pricy of course as they're for tourists only. You won't see anyone local around this area and even bargaining won't make any difference...There are many metro stops as well, that conveniently take you anywhere.

Amalgam of colours. This is the hub of tourist activity in istanbul. All the historic sites are located in this area with lots of good eat outs. Tram station is near the blue mosque which is an easy way to other areas.

Great area. This area is amazing with most of the main sites within walking distance. Restaurants are excellent with a wide variety of foods and the patiserries have all of the Turkish delicacies that are amazing

Amazing history and culture. I see Sultanahmet as the Asian side of Istanbul even if it's in the European side. You can wander for days in this district and admire the beauty of the old streets and the intriguing architecture of the Byzantine and Ottoman empire. Sultanahmet is a MUST. Highly recommended.

The heart of Istanbul. This area is great for walking around, full of wonderful shops, restaurants and markets and contains many of the best sites. Aside from the wonderful Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and Hippodrome be sure to seek out the fantastic Archaeological Museum, Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts, Yerebatan Cistern and a little further afield, the Sokollu Mosque, a real find.

Great area to stay in. Within walking distance of all major sites - Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Underground Cisterns and restaurants. We stayed at the Hotel Esans - Ottomon style hotel, small, clean and very friendly and helpful staff.

Best place to stay. Get a hotel in this area as you can walk to all the main sites from here, loads of places to eat, all good and the tram system is very easy to use if you want to go further afield, also near the port so you can use the ferries

The best site for tourism. Assuming you're a tourist and want to see the historic sites of Istanbul, this is the place to be. If you're in town for business, shopping or night clubs, Sultanahmet is not for you.Most of the historic sites are located within walking distance of one another, so if this is what you want to see and do then my all means stay at a hotel in Sultanahmet. I discovered that the charm, ambiance, and profusion of outdoor cafes almost overshadowed the attractions themselves. You can easily use the tram system to get around and into the "real" city as needed. Be forewarned though that the historic sites are likely to be mobbed with tourists which arrive by the busload. I found that visiting the attractions early in the morning worked best for me, then enjoy the charm of the district in the afternoon and evening.

Must see!. This area is convenient for all of the attractions in the old district of Istanbul. We stayed at Agora Life in the Sultanahmet District and everything we wanted to see such as the Blue Mosque were all close at hand. Would highly recommend a visit to this area.

busy part of Istanbul. Although it is reagarded as the tourist area in Istanbul, it has a lot to offer. Just wander in the small streets and take a look at all the small shops. Some streets manufacture only shoes, others only sell leather... People work there and to me it is the nicest place in istanbul.

Lush and Green and full of Surprises. By far the biggest surprise, was how green everything was. This part of the city is like an island as it is so different from the high rise areas. It is peaceful, beautiful and worth the visit.
Just for tourist. Nothing to do with the actual Istanbul, it is just for tourists, avoid and just come there to visit the attractions in the area.

"Lovely to explore". Apart from being close to many of the major attractions in Istanbul the area is lovely to just wander around in. There are interesting little hotels and restaurants, old wooden houses, rug and ceramic shops and friendly locals. We love just heading off and seeing where each of the little narrow streets takes us.

Charming place. We had a hotel in this district. You can get over there by tram and get off at the Sutanhamet stop so the name is the same. Very close from the stop is Hagia Sophia and other important attractions. There are a lot of nice restaurants and shops. There is really nice in the evening but crowdy.

Happy Wandering. We were lucky our hotel was in the district and most of the sights are a short walk from each other. It's a truly enjpoyable place to wander. Beware the tour buses sneaking up behind you as they park on the pavement though

smart part of Istanbul. We stayed down the hill towards the Mamara from Sultanhamet Square and walked up every morning to have a cappuccino at the Denizon Cafe (Turkish breakfasts don't do it for us) expensive but good. The area is beautiful and it is easy to walk to all the 'big' attractions - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofya, Topkapi, the archaeological museum, the renovated wooden houses etc etc. We even found a newsagent selling the Guardian newspaper.

A Must!. All the attractions are in the Old City.
If you want to stay in a hotel in that area -be prepared to spend a lot of money for mediocrity. As well as for dining.
Ask around for dining recommendation, read reviews, do food tours. Lots of mediocre restaurants in the area - so shop around.
Lovely area.. It's a wonderful area, our hotel was located in the area, there are many restaurants , small shops and wonderful outdoor cafes. All the major sights are located in the area.

Awesome area of Istanbul. Streets full of restaurants with rooftop terraces and views of the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia, a wide array of cafes and bars, fantastic sights.... What's not to like about this part of town? We found a nice hotel here and even though we had some recommendations for restaurants in other areas of town, we ended up eating here three out of four nights because we loved the atmosphere! Must see part of town!

I hate Turkish people in this area.. Well, it's not so easy to be a blonde in Turkey. But it's even harder to survive in that area. I didn't like it at all. I was even afraid to go out alone. Maybe the people don't have anything bad on their minds but still - asking you if you are married or if you want to have sex with them is enough for me. Also the prices of food are higher in this area. U have to pay more and you can't even it by yourself because everybody will disturb you asking what's your name or do you wanna go out tonite. I totally found myself in the Asian part of Istanbul. Sultanahmet - nevermore.
Historical. Fantastic part of such a large city, I loved the small streets and easy access to the famous monuments and antiquities.

There is more to Istanbul. The close proximity to several of the major drawcards means there are many tourists in this area - and the locals know it. Trinket shops are everywhere and every second entrance seems to be either a hotel or a restaurant. Many of the restaurants are expensive to very expensive and their claims of 'authentic food' stretch the truth quite often but it is possible to find a reasonably priced meal if you're looking for it.A carnival atmosphere seems to preside, especially in the open area between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. The fact that this is a popular meeting place for Istanbulians adds to this. There is still a hint of Turkish authenticity to the place but the "Brand" stores are beginning their approach. The plethora of persons, shops and services that are determined to part you from your money makes me feel as if the area has lost some of its soul or maybe a new one is being forged in a 'Turkish bazaar' kind of way.I'm certainly NOT suggesting you shouldn't go there. In fact, you can't avoid this area if you're doing your job as a tourist properly but you need to get further afield to experience the real Istanbul.
The only place to stay. This puts you near the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, and a host of fine restaurants (Metropolis was our hands-down favorite).
Best place to stay. This area of the city is where everthing happens during day or night walking distance to monuments nice restaurants shops Great
Beautiful and interesting!. If you look patiently you might find a mosque calle Little Haghia Sophia - charming and peaceful place. :)

Always in Motion. The Sultanahmet Area is so exciting and fast paced. Between The Topkapi Palce, Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Spice Market, Arasta Bazaar, New Mosque, Sulyeman Mosque it goes on and on. Shop till you drop, eat till you burst, people watch till your eyes fall out and try to keep up with the pace!!!

The best place to stay in. Its the best place you can visit in Istanbul. You can see hajasofia and sultan ahmed mosque while you are settings in the chairs there. You can see tha darwishes dancing there Also you eat fresh fruits and vigitables. And the best us hearing Azan (the call for praying).
Love this area.... I feel that you get the true feeling for both old and new Turkey in this area. There is SO much to see and do here!

Walk Along the Tram Line. you can't go wrong if you follow the tram line for shops and attractions.
if you get tired and or want to go further out, pay the 3 TL for a tram token and hop on.
plenty of good places to snack and by turkish delights. :)

nothing can describe it. as being Muslim, this place touches a spiritual part, i am not only watching treasures.i am watching a part from amazing culture take a place in the world for many years, also seeing the prophets tools and treasures was amazing experience
don't try to steel the big jewel in there, you will know it when you see it ;)

An excellent centre and base for a visit to Istanbul. Excellent restaurants and many good hotels and all very close to the main key attractions of Istanbul. Probably the best area for visitors to stay in, the people are friendly and helpful and we felt at ease and safe throughout our visit.

Nice. A lot of nice hotels, tourest attractions, resturants. I had visited Istanbul two times and I stayied in the Old Sultanahmet area, where you can walk or use the tram transportation to most tourist attractions, and traditional turkish foods.

the sounds of the trams, smell of chestnuts roasting, bustle, calls for prayer and even the carpet sellers!. Hadn't been to Istanbul for 30 years and it was my husband's first visit. We both loved it and definitely won't leave it again for another 30 years! We stayed in the Neorion Hotel, absolutely brilliant, just in the midst of Sultanahmet so you could walk to the spice bazaar and the Bosphorus in one direction and up the hill in the other direction to the Blue Mosque, Santa Sophia and Topkapi. On the last morning we walked up to the main Bazaar which took about 20 minutes.

Close to all tourist attractions. Great district close to every tourist attractions... but if you have more than a couple days... PLEASE GET OUT OF THE SULTANAHMET. Istanbul is GIGANTIC and each neighbourhood are very different.Many much nicer, quieter, different neighborhoods make Istanbul such a special place.

People dropping litter everywhere. Sultanahmet District is worth visiting for the areas of special architecture and historic interest. Unfortunately, it is not clean...Local people throw their rubbish everywhere. I saw young people dropping litter on the pavement , even if there were litter bins one meter away :(The workers came to empty the rubbish around noon , so tourists who visited the Blue Mosque or the Hagia Sophia had to cope with the terrible smell and the ugly view.
The heart of the Istanbul. Lots of historical sites . Lots of restaurants. Lots of hotels. This is the heart of Istanbul ! A must visit area !

If you miss Sultanahmet you were not in Istanbul. The historical buildings, mosques, bazaars, hamams and narrow streets allow you to travel though time and dream of the splendor and power of the Sultans
Love this area. This is where we stayed for a few nights when first in Istanbul. I loved walking around and shopping, choosing from the many bars and cafes and being close to the bazaars.

Great location!!. This area of Istanbul is an excellent base to visit the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Grand Bazaar. Although within a short walk. Excellent choice of good quality restaurants also.

Beautiful district. We loved the Sultanahmet District on our trip to Istanbul. I highly recommend staying here if you are on a leisure, sightseeing trip. We enjoyed being close to the attractions as well as good shopping and the great hotel / restaurant options in the neighborhood

Lots of shopping and tourists. Lots of walk able shopping and sights. Wear comfortable clothes and shoes and enjoy all the close by sights. Trams are 3 lira and very easy to use . Grand Bazaar....., just that. Very grand with Lots of shops for the shopaholic. same items in most shops, so compare before buying. it will save you hundreds!!!!

Clean. The area by the Blue Mosque is currently being revamped with what will be stunning gardens. The area in general is very clean and a trusting area - not once as 2 ladies on holiday did we feel at all uncomfortable.

Not staying here = lost opportunities. Why are we/you in Istanbul? In essence it is because of the Sultanamet district - "old Istanbul". It contains the bulk of the historic sites and magnificent monuments; the bulk of the well-rated restaurants; the bulk of the interesting bazaars; and the bulk of what is intriguing, quaint and photogenic in this great city. Not to stay in Sultanahmet means unnecessary local travel and hence lost opportunities. It is the very core of why one visits Istanbul.

Close to everything. A bit seedy, but Sultanahmet is next door and within easy walking sitance of where most of the historical places worth visiting are located (the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, Haga Sophia). Traditional food is cheaply and easily available - as are carpets and ceramics if you don't mind being badgered. I would stay in the neighbourhood again. Greg Pullen, Brighton, Victoria, Australia.
Increadible!. Very amazing, this is the area where everthing that is a "Must see" is located within walking distance of. It is definitely a Must see.
The place to start visiting Istanbul. Historically divine, everywhere you look a place of interest. I think it is the best place to stay on your first time in Istanbul.
Restaurants in Sultanahmet. Many restaurant owners scouting for business , can get a bit annoying at times but all in good fun. Lots of variety and choice options for food.

The tourist area of Istanbul, but still very charming. This is the area of Istanbul where you will find most of the citys major historic attractions inclusive of the Blue mosque.
Around these major attractions are small charming streets with plenty of local restaurants and shops. Even a small but relaxed bazaar is situated right behind the Blue Mosque

Easy district to navigate and much to see. The Sultanahmet District may seem confusing at first, but once you understand where the Hipordrom, Blue Mosque, and Hagia Sophia are it all comes together and it's darn near impossible to get lost. There are plenty of tourist-friendly spots on the beaten path, but you can definitely find some quieter places to eat and rest your feet.

love istanbul. What is not to like? ok, vendors a little annoying but you learn to maneuver around them....sometimes fun to engage and they usually tell you about their kids who are in college in usa...

Stayed here. just a good feel to this area, we had a hotel here and it was so nice to sit out and eat here, just felt fascinating.
The people were just loverly, gentle, courteous and kind, loved the whole experience

Bustling and busy. With all of the most iconic sites scattered around here you will obviously spend part of your trip to Istanbul in this old part of town. Packed full of restaurants, bars, hotels and tourist shops it is a lively and fun place to be. It is more expensive than other places and you do need to choose restaurants carefully, but this didn't stop it from being my favourite place.

Great historical area. The whole area is suitable for Tourist , many attractions,hotels restaurants, cafe...Top kapi castle, hagia sofia museum,blue mosque ..Grand bazar spice bazar.. all in the same area

Must stay here!. This area is THE place to stay for a short trip to Istanbul. It is very safe and most people speak English. The prices on food, cafes, are reasonable. TIP- if you go to the Bazaar, it's worth a look but you MUST negotiate prices. Even after negotiation, some of the prices are still lower on the street souvenir shops. If you are going to Greece, buy your souvenirs here first. You will see the same in Greece but in high prices.

Very nice historic place in Istanbul. What can you see in Istanbul? The most of the historic places are in Sultanahmet. You can walk in the streets, if you walk to side streets there are lots of shoe producers' shops. Very cheap You are lucky

Best new arrival spot!. We loved the area as it was close to the main attractions and very easy to get around from there. We found interesting shops, nice restaurants and cute local delis for you everyday needs in the one locale.

history comes alive. just walking around the area , you are immersed in history
just love this area - the mosques and cistern espically

Why?. Walking around Sultanahmet station, Turkish guys talked to me every 10 min. and always they were asking the "completely" same three questions : "Where are you from?", "Is this first time to visit Istanbul?", "Do you speak Turkish language?". Once I answered, he was gone and another guy came to me asking the same questions. Once I enter travel agency, a staff talked to me in Japanese but he asked me the completely same questions! I get fed up with it.Some people were very kind and help me to find shops. But I should not walk around Sultana so much.
islamic mosque. I was very happy to see people from all nationalities & religons visit this mosque . and the desgine of the cielings .
Wonderful part of Istanbul. The local people are very friendly, this area is the center of local tourist action. Great sites, food and drink and local shopping.

Amazing place. You can walk in history.Eat in real Turkish culture atmosphere.Feel what history mean in middle of modern city.You can stay there and enjoy from that area for more than a week and every day find new things for trying.

A Haven of Tourists. It's a blessing and a curse having all of the tourists located in one spot in Istanbul. Huge variety of hotels and restaurants and tour agencies. Dining is quaint with fierce competition amongst street cafes, and in my opinion, they need more budget options. Don't just settle for the street cafes though. At least once, have dinner at a rooftop terrace restaurant with stunning views of the Blue Mosque.

Fun to walk around. We wandered throught the Grand Bazaar, the Blue Mosque, the New Mosque and sipped tea at outdoor cafes. All in all a lovely city to walk through if you don't mind the crouds. Avoid the spice market on Saturday- It is Mobbed!!

Best Place to Walk Around. I did love my walking activities along Sultanahmet area. There are many restaurants offering Turkish daylight. And there are many attractions that are worthed to be seen. Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Cistern Basilica, Topkai palace and many more. There are many hotels around with the variation of prices. The choices are yours. Enjoy your walk in Sultanahmet.

Vibrant, great atmosphere and very clean. This is a magical place to spend a day wandering round this vast area, with Aya Sofya at one end and the Blue Mosque at the other, with cafes, restaurants and Turkish-style fast food kiosks aplenty. What a wonderful place to soak up the sights and sounds of this lovely city. The whole area is kept scrupulously clean both by local authority workers and stallholders themselves. We felt safe at all times.

great location to stay in while in Istanbul. my hotel was located in the Sultan Ahmet district and it's such a lovely area. it has all those old amazing monuments to check. strolling down the streets of the district itself is enjoyable. it's has lots of restaurants and cafes to check and also souvenir shops.

Great!. You can see here the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia Mosque, The Topkapi Palace, including the Harem and some breathtaking sights over the Bosphorus straight and The Golden Horn. More, The Basilica Cistern is something you must see!
Take a walk around in the past.... There are most wonderful sites and places to eat here. Istanbul is carved out of the past and leaves you with new memories of a great place.

See 2000 years and more of history. In one rather small region of Istanbul, you will visit and see relics, buildings, and ruins from the past twenty four centuries. In the immediate region, you'll find many stores. Be ready to haggle about the price. NEVER buy at the first price offered. We learned that the hard way.
Walk back in time in Sultanahmet. So many things to do and see in the Sultanahmet district. The streets and clean and safe for the whole family at any time of the day and night.

A must-see. If you come to Istanbul for the first time and would like to see the historical places, this area is the first one to visit. Topkapi Palace, Sultan Ahmet Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Gulhane Park and Grand Bazaar are all in this district, within walking distances of each other. There are lots of hotels and restaurants, too.

The good, the bad and the ugly. The good: Picturesque, clean, filled with hotels and restaurants, near the main sites. Impressive sights, especially if not obscured by a heavy coat of tourists. Walk around the open areas after dark when the tourists are snug in their hotels and the sites are lit up. The bad: Not enough main sites. The number of tourists divided by the number of sites equals madhouse. The early bird catches the sites before the mob.The ugly: (1) The friendly, uninvited guide. I call them fishermen. The tourist walking with any hesitation concerning his destination is the fish. We are yanked into the carpet store, hopefully not entirely off track from the intended destination. Tip: Ask the fisherman whether he knows a good place to sell carpets - you're trying to get rid of some. The fisherman quickly cuts bait.(2) The taxis. Taxis are allergic to Sultanahment. They don't know their way around and don't want to learn. Their idea of a destination is the neighbourhood, not the specified address. I wonder how the deluxe hotels manage the obstinate taxi drivers. On one occasion, two taxi drivers engaged in a good chat declined to take us, indicating that the hotel was only two or three kilometers and that we should walk.More tips: 1) Get the hotel to identify a taxi-friendly location on the rim of the district which is within walking distance of the hotel. 2) Have a good map or GPS. 3) Learn to take the trams OR, failing all of that, stay in the hotel and look at pictures of Sultanahmet.

Excellent. People everywhere. The place is buzzing with history. Many of the historical sites are located in sultanahmet making it easy to walk around and see all within a day. Many restaurant around the area.

Amazing place. This is my second visit to Turkey and what made it so special is Sultanahmet district.. amazing place with a lot of shops, restaurants and sightseeing very close to tram where u can take it to almost everywhere in the city :)
fulll with monuments. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cinsterne, Byzantine Hippodrome, Byzantine Great Palace Ruins...Everything around Sultanahmet.....

Great location for tourists. As a first time visitor to Istanbul, this area was surprisingly easy to get around, see the sights, eat great food and do a little shopping and speak to all sorts of cool people.

Nice Ancient Attraction. Sultan Ahmet District is an appropriate tourist attraction who like the ancient places. There is a park "Gulhane", one traditional Bazzar where the shopkeepers sell spices, delights and handmade crafts. Sultan Ahmet mosque is one of the symbols of ancient Turkey and Islam. I recommend this district to every one!

Good location.. Good place to stay,as within walking distance of major attractions,eg Blue Mosque,Topkapi,Cisterns. Plenty of restaurants of all ranges and choice of accommodation from cheap to top of range. Tends to be very crowded,but not really a proble.
Old part of the City. There is nothing to be disliked. As in each City of the world be carefull, look after your stuff, but this District awesome, you can even smell that it is full of history!
very beautiful. beautiful and full of attractions. really liked Cisterns and other museums in the area. great place to visit

Stay here and walk everywhere. If you only have a couple of days in this city or longer, stay in this area. All the historic places you might want to see are an easy walk from wherever you are staying. Also the tram service is cheap and easy to use. Stroll down to the Bosporus and tram back if it's too hot.

So convenient and beautiful.. Such an extraordinary area of history and outstanding Istanbul buildings...spoilt for choice with restaurants.The Grand Bazaar also a must see,such vibrance.The centrally located tram to the new city also very handy for popping around the city on Istanbul's hot summer days.

Full of history and a bit overwhelming. There is so much to see, hear, eat, buy, take in. Make wise choices and review before you go but keep open to changing your plans. In terms of people you could be in Times Square or Trafalger or... but the historical choices are there to fill as much time and energy as you prefer.
Best Private Tour Ever in Istanbul with Salih. Salih showed us this area while we were on our Istanbul tour. It is a tourist area yes but must see anyway.

Must See and Experience. If you are coming to Istanbul, you will certainly experience the Sultanahmet District while you are visiting the big attractions (i.e. Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern). But the district itself is an attraction. The public spaces are clean and well maintained with an excellent array of art works. It is rather "touristy" but when you explore its margins, Cembalitas, the Egyptian Market, Sulayman Camii, you will get a feel for life in Istanbul for the man, or woman, in the street. There are an array of small shops selling every imaginable item at less than tourist prices.The Turks are a great, warm and welcoming people. But there are touts and crooks and thieves preying on tourists. So keep your head up and enjoy the show. .

The Old City on foot. The most interesting neighbourhood in Istanbul.All historical places are around, tons of shops selling almost everything. Many restaurants and cafes and sightseeing. Yet it is a typical touristic place, prices are somehow higher that other places in Istabul. In general, do not buy any stuff except when you have seen other places first.

So many restaurants, so little time. A sensory overload in this area. So many people, sounds, smells, sights. It is really fun and quite an incredible place when you think about its history. So much to see and a great place to stay as well - close to the water and the main tourist sights.
Wonderful part of the city. So peaceful and relaxed. There are tons of people, but the city holds them well. Very easy to find your way around.
old city. very touristic place, and very communicative local people. dont buy anything in sultanahmet, it is 3 times expensive than in other areas of Istanbul.
Great area to walk around. Easy to get to all tourist sites. Also some great windy roads to get lost or go tschotchy shopping. There are a few spice and Turk delight stores to cut your teeth on too.

wonderful place. The best possible location if you want to experience the sights and sounds of this extraordinary city. The people are friendly and polite and the area is a lovely mix of beautiful historical sites, shops and restaurants.

Tourist area. We stayed in the Sultanahmet while in Istanbul. The area is close to all the major tourist sites, has many restaurants, and hotels. Easy access from the international airport is possible by taking the metro and then transferring to the tram and getting off at the Sultanahmet stop.

Crowded place. I had to the area 12 years ago and it was much more pleasant, much fewer people and much cheaper back then. At that time there was no queue to enter any place. Now long lines for Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the underground reservoir. The 3TL tram is rather expensive if it is for a shop hop ride. Anyway, Sultanahmet is still a great place ti visit.
amazing for me .. it was amazing for me but i think is a little boring for young guys .enjoying of that depends on the observer , and beauty is on the eye of beholder .
the old city charms. the architecture, the history, the food, the friendliness, the ease of access, really this place has it all, and a unique charm unmatched anywhere I have been so far.

Historical Sites. Sultanahmet district should not be missed. You might not be interested in the historical part of it but strolling here for a day or 2 in this area should cover it. You can pretty much cover the main sights within 2 days. Sure, its a little more expensive than any other area, like Taksim but you have to remember, vendors and restaurants cater to the tourist.Great place overall!

Sultanahmet. Lovely old town especially to to just wander and browse the shops. All the historic sites are within walking distance.buildings are reminicent of 14th and 15th century austria nad Europe with overhanging balconies. In the evening the stall holders and sellers are in the streets hawking their wares, delicious street food is available. seating is available between the Ayasofya and the Blue Mosque including a fountain that has changing coloured lights. You can wander around safely talking to locals or other tourists in til very late at night.

A real taste of ancient and modern Turkey. Stairways and alleys, beautiful feral cats, friendly and polite locals who didnt mind us wandering around. Lots of eating and drinking options, but avoid the touristy places - for better value and better food.
the best place to stay!. Staying in this area gives you the opportunity to visit many sights on foot! Aghia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Top Kapi, Cemberlitas Hamam
Vibrant, exciting part of Istanbul. Lots of great places to eat, easy to get to and from there (trams are cheap and easy to use) lots of shopping opportunities and close to main attractions

Busy trams!. The trams are always packed!!! Bought an Istanbulkart which we found very easy - able to share one card between us - just hopped on and off trams and furniculars by swiping the card.Busy area with loads of tourists and locals alike - lots to see and do.Loved every aspect of Istanbul!

Amazing place. The Old Bazaar is much better than the much more touristy Spice Bazaar and you can have a really good experience of bargaining there in a more light-hearted manner than the Spice bazaar. There were long queues for tickets followed by entry to the Topkapi Palace and then you have to pay more to visit the Harem area which is the best bit. Amazing all the same.

Dozens of Sites within walking distance. While there are huge number of touristy stores that distract from the real sites, the sheer number of buildings and history rival any from other European cities.Don't miss the Basilica Cisterns

So much to Explore!. The Blue Mosque was beautiful, but more impressive from the outside. Make sure you brings a scarf, as you must cover your head, shoulders, and legs. Also, you can't wear shoes inside the mosque, so be prepared by bringing socks for hygenic purposes. Take a cruise down the Bosporus at sunset, the views of the city are astounding in the evening. Remember that the Hagia Sofia is closed on Wednesdays!

Plenty to see without paying high entrance fees. There was plenty to see - the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, market shops in this area, plus Spice Market and Main market with shopping streets between. Prices to get into main sites were high if you were to go to several so would add up to quite a lot for a couple if you are not interested in the detail - however we enjoyed looking around the outside (including the courtyard of the Blue Mosque) and soaking up the atmosphere. A trip up & down the Bosphorus was offered by 2 people at just 15 euros each (list price 20 euros this company, more from others) starting from the area beside fountains near Blue Mosque. Very pleasant on our Sunday afternoon (as markets closed I think) . It's always worth asking for a lower price for everything, although there were some small shops by the Blue Mosque that had realistic prices displayed for small touristy bits & pieces.The street food we tried (chicken pitta near market) was also very reasonable and tasty (2.5 TL = about £1) .We expected to use trams, but didn't need to as all pretty close together in this district.
So much to see. Beautiful buildings .lovely places to walk plenty of things to do and see over a few days loved the blue mosque vand the ayasofia hamman .topkapi palace

Truly the old quarter with history and great sites!. Everything about it is excellent....places/people/ambience/restaurants....A MUST VISIT!
My tip is to stay in this area!
Cosmopolitan. The whole district was fantastic for sightseeing and shopping and people watching. I was also surprised at the amount of park space for such an old city.

Historic Istanbul. We stayed in a hotel in the Sultanahmet District. We enjoyed the cobbled streets, shops and markets as well as watching Turks go about their daily business. Many of the historic sites are located here, and there is a tramline station.

A must to see. Sultanahmet holds the blue mosk, Ayasofya, the obelisk, the typical ottoman houses. The best view is between the blue mosk and Ayasofia which are build in the same line.If you walk down the steps behind the Blue Mosk you can find a street with typical ottoman houses, lots of restaurants, bars and small shops. If you want to have a good deal on things you want to buy you will get it here not at the Grand Bazar.What did shock me was how dirty and abandoned this area was at night. Also incredible the amount of cats (all very well fed) on the streets.

very close to everything. Perfect base to start exploring Istanbul. Close to walk to most places or close to the metro. Good restaurants, nice shops. If I go back to Istanbul I take a hotel again in this area.

So friendly, busy and fun!. This is where the Blue Mosque, Top Kapi palace and Hagia Sophia are.. we also took the Bosphorous cruise from here.. you must must visit this area before you can say you've seen Istanbul, theres also a lot of cafes and restaurants around this area and it is very lively highly highly recommended

Vibrant and good place to wander. We didnt stay in this area as we had the cruise ship to sleep on! But worth catching the tram from the port area and get off in this part of Istanbul. Lots of interesting shops and touristy things. You can walk to Blue Mosque, Sophia, Basillica Cistern, Grand Bazaar and stop off at many many places to try all the cuisines or just spend spend spend. A area you have to explore.
Great location. This distict has so many historic sites. We spent most of our time visiting museums, mosques and shopping in this area.

quinte. this place was so beautiful with the cobble stone roads and roadside cafe's. the people were also so friendly and accomodating. the shops were just lovely in terms of the qulaity of goods and the prices.

Renovated with Hotels/Restaurants near Istanbuls Top Tourist Attractions. Much to the delight of independent travelers, this area has been renovated and is now full of boutique hotels and restaurants within walking distance of Istanbuls top tourist attractions!

Great place. I loved this area, everything at a walking distance...very scenic and relaxing environment... Must try the corn on the cob, the pomegranate juice and the roasted chestnuts... oh and the famous Turkish Ice cream, ask them for ' Harkat barkat' and watch the fun!
Restaurants. Try the Cozy Pub, a bit dearer, but great food, service and atmosphere. They have a roof top terrace - FANTASTIC views at night.

If this is your first visit to Istanbul you want to stay in Sultanahmet. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, The Basilica Cistern, The Grand Market and mass public tgransportation are all here.

Beautiful old city with historical landmarks. This is the old part of Istanbul, it contains historical landmarks such as the Blue Mosque, Aghia Sophia museam and Topkapi Palace, souvenir shops, restaurants, hotels and the Grand Bazaar is near. The tram passes inside the old streets of this area. It is really a touristic place.
A tourist must. It is a bustling touristic area full of such wondrous ancient monuments. The vendors are plentiful but not too much of a nuisance.

Interesting. So much to see in this area and nice places to visit and eat. This is where the Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia , and the blue mosque are. Also worth a visit is the basilica cistern and of course the grand bazaar.

Go Sultanahmet. I stayed in the Sultanahmet 4 of 7 nights in Istanbul. The other nights were near Taksim Square. Taksim was OK, but very shopping/chain store heavy. The stone lined streets and many, many small hotels and cafes in Sultanahmet are much more to my tastes. I could walk to Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofya and Blue Mosque in less than 10 minutes. There is music on the square (Dervish Cafe and the bazaar behind Aya Sofya) and tons to do.

The generous architecture. It very difficult for m to assimilate the place cause of the brilliance in its design and construction. Here you really understand th meaning of gifted people who can conceive such place

Lovely area to wander around.. Vibrant, friendly, interesting. Felt perfectly safe as a woman on her own and even ventured to the side market areas where the goods sold were more towards local people, still feeling safe although quite clearly getting looks from the locals as I was obviously a tourist.Try the Pomegranate, Pistacio and Chocolate ball covered Turkish Delight if you can find it, there are only two traders that appear to sell it. Its lovely and keeps really well.Do be patient tho if you have time to look around. I liked a lovely warm scarf that was being sold for about 30 pounds and I ended up buying the same scarf at the Viewpoint for the Golden Horn River for only 14 pounds!

Tourist Trap - with great bait. Where the main tourist attraction are located and as such, expensive, hectic and noisy. What else would you expect ? Soak up the atmosphere, get your wallet/purse at the ready and go explore. That's what you came for isn't it ?
Loved the place. we loved the walk at night while it was raining !! worth every penny ! i really advise the winter visit..

This is the place. If you're coming to Istanbul then this is the area you should stay in. You're within walking distance of all the main sights, shopping area, train station, port, Bazaar and so many restaurants and bars you'll be spoilt for choice. Son't worry about waiters calling you in to their restaurants - just smile and move on. They aren't insistent or aggressive like they are in some other countries. In fact, this goes for all the shopkeepers. They take a no with a smile!

One could spend a week never leaving the Sultanahmet area and still not see it all.. Great museums, mosques, restaurants, and the shopping in the bazaars is an experience all its own with excellent transportation and cooled by a lovely breeze from the Sea of Marmara

Pittoresque. Strolling in this district in the evening is a delight. This is an ideal mix of a touristy place and encountering daily Istanbul life. Lots of places to eat, the hotels are sometimes inviting and sometimes quite grubby. Shouln't miss this part of the city.

Sultanahmet. Fantastic place to stay / area to visit when in Istanbul. Centrally placed for the Grand Bazzar and Spice market. Take a trip along the Bosphorous - great way to see both sides AND avoid the traffic.

Old Istanbul District. It is a walkers delight but you need stamina to climb up the hill of the district.Ok once you reach the top. A wonderful tourist area as there are great sights such as the "Blue" Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Old roman Cistern and a little farther west, the Grand Bazaar.

This is the area to stay. I have stayed in this area twice and would suggest it is the best area to stay. There are lots of enclaves with the streets lined with cafes and restaurants, nearly all of which serve alcohol. You can use the tram to take you to the other areas which only costs 3TL each.

touristic area. it is really nice area and also there are so mcuh tourist there but as every touristic area there are so much hustle place too...some where u can just walk away on street, from every restaurant and cafe they shouting at u...come my place, buy something...so annoying stuation...so much historical place at the same area so u can see so many different things at the same day...hagia sofia, topkapi palace, basilica, grand bazaar, spice market, blue mosque and so many place like this...there is tramway and transportation is easy but most of the time tramway is sooo busy...so many nice place to buy some gift for ur friends...and good price too, ofcourse like anywhere else if u r tourist they try to sell expensive to u therefor choice some place which u can see the price before u get in...
Fab place to stay and eat. We loved this area! As we only had three nights in Instanbul it was great to be so close to the historic sites and to so many great restaurants and bars

Shopping History and Art. What more could a girl want. Start with a coffee on the roof top of the Four Seasons Sultanahamet. shop along the streets. Go to Sofa for beyond fabulous antiques, so many shops so little time!

excellent for restaurants. there is so many reataurant to choose from and the quality of food are fantastic and the prices are cheap,also you can sit down and just drink tea and rest your feet when you have been siteseeing.

If u r in a hurry skip it. If u r spending a week or more you can choose to go or not
I wasnot impressed and nothing really to see
If you want to stroll along the town ok , I'd else I suggest u go shopping

Old town. Whenever we have gone to Istanbul we have always stayed in this part of the town. It is so convenient as it has all the sights me would want to see. We stayed at a hotel near the blue mosque which was convenient to got to all the famous sights. The rooms in this area are predominantly small due to the nature of the city. The chortles cater or all price ranges but expect to pay about £80 per double room with breakfast which will be typical Turkish. The area is hilly and the cobbled stones near some repair. High heels are not recommended. The place is well linked by the tram which is cheap and regular. The Grand Bazaar is something else. It is like a tardis you can get lost for hours and be prepared to haggle. What ever is the asking price half it and don't be embarrassed or shy about it. You are expected to haggle. A lot of people stay near Taksim square which is more modern but for menot a patch on Sultamahmet. By the way the atmosphere in Sulthanahmet during Ramadan is like a carnival with families gathered around the blue mosque and street traders everywhere you feel that you have been transported to the Istanbul of the 14c AD quite amazing.

Lots to see. This district can be a bit overwhelming with the streets that twist and turn. When walking around, make notes of locations near your hotel as guide. After a few hours, everything can start looking the same.

Would you like to by a carpet. Sultanahmet District is quite quaint to walk along, just beware that all the shop merchants will ask you in for Apple tea and try and sell you Istanbul proper. Most are friendly some can be rather pushy, but all are quite harmless.

vibrant. We liked this area, it was very lively and colourful. The little bazaar near the Blue Mosque had some items every bit as good and well priced as we saw in the Grand Bazaar. There were also some interesting, if expensive shops near our hotel.

THIS IS THE PLACE TO STAY IN ISTANBUL!!. The Sultanahmet is an area that is concentrated with some of the greatest historical sites in Istanbul. Staying in the area places everything at your fingertips
Has to be done!. This is a must see location. Best way to do it is Haiga Sophia, then Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque. Avoid the queues at Hagia Sophia by doing it first.
Very very interesting- only good photographs!. This is an area so full of history. Small alleyways and streets, great buildings and interesting cubby holes. Just gorgeous.

Must see at night!. I walked around this entire area and it was a joy! Love it! Specially the bazaars. However, I do recommend doing the Galata bridge at night. It is gorgeous! The view is amazing. Me and my boyfriend sat down to have dinner and hooka, so much fun! Be aware of all these restaurants harassing you to have dinner at their venue. You will get used to it :D
Loved the neighborhood. Great little eateries and shopping opportunities. It is definitely the tourist zone so not a good feel for the "real" Istanbul.
Good shopping and restaurants. Very exciting area where you can find restaurants which cater to everyone's palate, lots of good shops where one can shop, etc.
Don't miss the small streets around. The guides will lead you to the most recognizable places, once visited give you some time to stroll around and feel the real flavours.
Sightseeing at Sultanahmet district. Several spot to see in a unique location. You have the market at the old square, were you also can find an obelix. And, try to visit the underground waterbasin.

So much fun to wander around.... We had a free afternoon, and came over from Kadikoy to explore stuff. Such an amazing place! Really friendly people and very safe, ime - lots of families around. We were two women alone, and did not experience anything more annoying than the occasional overzealous salesperson. Wish I could remember the names of the places we had tea and ice cream, but the whole day was just lovely and full of helpful people and fun surprises.

Such a historical place full of dirt. I wonder why the municipality of Fatih, which tends to be very proud does never wonder around the sultanahmet square in Istanbul... It is literally smelling dirt... especially in the evenings it is horrible... Moreover the shopkeepers kind of attack tourists to get them into the shops. I belive a lot of things must change so that I tell people go to this place....

Up and coming, yet historical area of Istanbul. This district is full of historical sites but keeps bumping due to modern restaurants and bars to make your days & evenings full of fun right next to Haghia Sophia and others!

old historic area not to be missed.. Every street we walked provided new sights and sounds and interesting corners to explore. Getting used to the hawkers and sellers of merchandise is an exercise in patience but can be amusing if you allow.
Well worth the visit. Great trip, easy to get about, just watch out for the helpful locals who offer to show you around, which includes their carpet shop.

A fabulous shopping area!. If boutique shopping is your thing, make sure to spend some time here. There are wonderful little restaurants (make sure to try a fish restaurant) and beautiful boutiques selling turkish handicrafts. It is also home to the most wonder ham man (bath)-- Sultanahmet Hamman!

Must stay here. Very exciting, busy, and right in the thick of it all - public transport, Istanbul highlights, shops, markets, and many many cafes , rooftop terraces and restaurants. Can walk to any attraction from here.
very expensive. very expensive, dont try to use doviz (exchange offices there tooooo expensive) but if you want to have a good exchange rate go to aksray or laleli they are good offices there

life stile. it is the heart of İstanbul, it is full of history, every where you look you see something breath taking. it also has many nice little hotels and cafes. great area to stay if you are visiting.

Tourist meet tourists. Its ok, but felt like a whole bunch of tourists moseying about with other tourists. Don't get the 'being there' feel we seek when visiting a place. Best advice given to us and we share with you is to get an Istanbul Kart which can be used on trams, busses and boats, incl Princes Islands. Use the trams and the venicular tunel to take you to Beyoglu district - Istiklal Cassesi pedestrian street at the top of the hill and enjoy the ambiance. You can visit the Galata Tower on the way down!
A old & gold. istanbul.. the people are very good. respect. humans.everything very near. traffics over bridges not like. vibrations very peaceful.azan time to time praying......make lock..bed soul.
Always a pleasure. I've been a number of times and never bore of all the riches that Istanbul has to offer. Especially in the spring or autumn, when the level of tourists is a bit less.

Good to see. Despite the fact that it is an historical place which was built more than hundred years ago but still it attracts hundreds and thousands of people from the world who visit this place every day. The nearby shopping centres have good varities to offer to the visitors at reasonable rates.

Very clean. Great street vendors, good food. Tram is easy to use and get around the city. Try the Sahlab hot drink from street cart in the winter and the roasted chesnut. The sesame breads are so good.

A Great and Humble place. The twin to Hagia Sofia when it comes to the old city tour, no one can visit one without visiting the other..By being there you got the seal of Istanbul, one time is not enough to appreciate this monument.. try to sit inside and look at the walls and ceilngs and pay attention to all the details on the walls, windows, and ceilings then close your eyes and hear the call for the prayer..What a feeling!
Great area. You can't feel you had visited istanbul without this area full of history full of life full of tourists .. I recommend it more than any other place in Istanbul
Historic Area. Many historical sights within walking distance (Haghia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Bazaar, Hippodrome, Cistern etc.) For us definitely the best are to stay.
One of the best in the world. Wonderful place with many things to visit and see. A lot of people so come when they are not here...if you wish to enjoy it and make photos

A tourist must see this area for historical Istanbul. This area of Istanbul is standard for a tourist. History is amazing but if you get a chance go on a tour and see all of Istanbul I think a person could not see all of Istanbul in their entire lifetime! There is so much to do and see! Beautiful city and the people are most helpful as English is spoken everywhere so I feel very comfortable traveling here.

Very picturesque!. I had the chance to book a hotel in the area, and I walked a lot around each and every day of my trip to Istanbul. This is the very core of the old and historical Istanbul. Nice place!
EXCELLENT. This is the most important district in Istambul, because is the storical one. You can make a tour around the the restaurants, shops and the main plaza.

A lovely people's square. This was a great place to just people watch, which we did several evenings. The fountain with it's spectacular colour show, all the children running around with their bird whistles and little lit up flying things (no idea what they were called) and all the little girls with their pink flashing hair bands with butterflies on - gorgeous.
good base for a visit. good place to stay good transport system to get around the city plenty of shops & restaurants close by
best place to hangout. for a first visit to Istanbul - this is the best place to stay & explore. Lots of accommodation choices.

In the Lap of History!. Every corner of the Sultanahmet area is like rediscovering a part of history! Looking around just mesmerizes you by the sheer presence of some of the world's most renowned structures. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Arasta bazaar, Basilica Cistern....the list is endless. Each place unique...each place with a story. The quaint hotels with their restaurants on the street give it a rich look..the cobbled streets transfer you to the 18th Century. It is always advisable to stay in one of the hotels in Sultanahmet and then explore Istanbul. It all started here for Constantinople as a trade route. And who can forget the Museum of Archaeology with its astounding collections of artifacts, mummies, stone carvings, pieces from Troy and the huge collection of sarcophagi! Sultanahmet will leave you spellbound and you will truly be in the Lap of History!
History and friendly people. History and beauty everywhere. The people of Istanbul are so friendly and most speak english. See the Hagia Sophia, the Hippodrome, and don't miss the Basilica Cistern.

middle of few markets and malls beside historical places to visit. people around the area sells items very very expensive. you need to bargin with all more than half the price.
also, you can change your money in this area for a high rate

The place to be and the place to stay. When most people think of Istanbul, they are picturing the Sultanahmet District: street markets, the Grand Bazaar, the Cemberlitas Hamami, the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque. No visit to Istanbul is complete without a stop here. You must see the Egyptian Spice Bazaar as well - a highlight of our trip. This is the can't-miss district in Istanbul. Bring a camera. And cash.
biggest historical place. I was amazed when we saw the sultanahmad place because of it was great and hagia sofia mosque ,tophakapı palace as well.

Found a great seafood restaurant. The Sultah Fish House at Professor K Ysmail Gurkan Caddesi No. 14 is within 3-4 minute walk up the stree from Cistern area and is one of the best seafood places I eat at during my trip. In fact, I went back 2 nights in row since the seafood and service were great. Make reservations if you want to dine after 8:00 PM.

Sultanahmet District. If you go to Istanbul, you have to go to the Sultanahmet distsrict. Let yourself get lost, wander and feel the history of Istanbul. One day will never be enough, there is too much to see and do. I stayed in Sultanahmet for 1 week and have to go back to see all of the rest.

Definitely the place to stay, eat, start from. Just wandering around is a great experience, especially off the main streets....store keepers/market sellers are tough, but you get your no thanks mojo going after a few days. Rooftop restaurants are great, cooler and fun to see a bit of water and the lights all around. Try Oceans Seven--good roof location and very good food for gentle prices.
i love this place. if you ever went to istanbul ,this place is the most you will stay in, full of restaurants and mosques and hostels and this is the area you will enjoy the most
Picturesque. Stayed here and absolutely loved wandering the winding, hilly streets. Beautiful old houses, lots of cats around. Truly like something out of a postcard. I just loved it.

The Essence of Istanbul!. We had such great time visiting this district...it is a must while in Istanbul. Just wandering around the area...very lovely, clean, exotic. The HagaSofia Museum is the most incredible church/mosque/museum...it's huge. The Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace (and Harem), all musts. There is a Mosaics Museum worth a visit, too. If you buy the tickets for the Palace, and I believe the HagaSofia..you can also get in the Mosaics Museum..which is small and has incredible ancient mosaics. Do buy the tickets so that you can get by the lines without waiting. We had no big push to buy Turkish carpets with one exception...a kind guy seemed like a tour guide but was really a salesperson who gave a "tour". Eventually we said we wanted to be alone and that...thank you very much...but we are not going to the shop now...and he walked away okay with this.

Items from BC at your easy touch!. This area is so cool. Mixture of ancient, old and new. I loved the obelisk and all the beautiful architecture. This is also a good area for people watching. When I was there a muslim protest occurred, and that was a bit intimidating.

Ubforgettable!. This is an area that you must stay in. Esans Hotel is absolutely perfect and within minutes walk of everything. The people are warm and friendly and the Restaurants in this area are fabulous. We will miss it forever!

First Time Visitors Head to Sultanahmet. If you're visiting for the first time, you'll want to spend at least two days in this district. The historical sites are 'endless' and require some time to visit. I feel that most of the restaurants and shops are tourist traps, but there are plenty of good places to eat nearby if you do a little research on TripAdvisor.Tons of tourists, tour buses and tour guides. The sites are worth navigating through the hoards.
Sultanahmet. Full of the most delightful restuarants, local pastries and baklavas, great position for any direction to visit, and stacked with historical buildings. Must see.

Lovely area to have a walk. We just passed through the area while checking out the Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque, we walked through the gardens of Topkapi but didn’t want to pay the 25 TL to enter. The area is really quaint with small cobble streets and lots of cafes and rooftop terraces. Though it definitely is predominantly tourists I would maybe suggest pre booking a good tour (find one on trip advisor!) and they might be able to take you to more authentic areas. But a great place to walk around.

Arista Bazaar - Smaller version of Grand Bazaar. Although this is a much smaller version of Grand bazaar and you might not get better bargains here, this bazaar is certainly worth a short visit if you have the time after covering all the must see attractions in Sultanahamet. Definitely not a replacement for a visit to Grand bazaar- nothing can beat the atmosphere and the variety available in Grand bazaar. However if you are looking for a less crowded version with fewer shops and in-your face hard selling Arista Bazaar with its open courtyard style layout might be worth a visit.

My Favorite Part of Istanbul!. On my vacation in Istanbul, I spent a week staying in and exploring the Sultanahmet, and it still was not enough! Frankly, I preferred it to the more Western part of Istanbul on the Bosphorus. I walked everywhere, visiting major sites, mosques, the Cistern, and markets, but also explored many of the side streets and lesser known mosques. Very rewarding, even a cemetery off one of the main streets. The people are charming and courteous. Istanbul exceeded my expectations!

Lively Place. We visited Istanbul from 15th to 20th August, and stayed at Sultan Ahmet. We love this place as the district has whole lot to offer. It is really a touristic place with all major attractions are at walkable distance. All kinds of food are available within the reach. As we went during the Ramadan the place was full of locals, activities and temporary market. Easy access to trams and taxis. Ideal location for first time travellers.

A Convient Place to Stay. The area has a bunch of cheap hostels to stay at and is close to major transport and sights.However, most of the food in the area is simply terrible and overpriced. I wouldn't even bother buying anything from any of the privately owned shops here, unless you like being robbed.

Great Location For Site Seeing. This area of Istanbul offers countless things to see and take great photos of. There a plentiful restaurants that off all kinds of dishes and of course Turkish local cuisines. Be advised - this place Is a tourist Mecca and Turkish carpets are famous as well as the Carpet Presentations that happen in many of the galleries which the folks will pull you in to see in hopes that you will buy a carpet. Few places in the world are famous for their carpets. Turkey is one of them.

Just go there to have a nice walk. I recommend to go there not only by daytime but also at night ,you can just sit here and rest there are many small fountains,nice banches,ou can buy traditional ring named Simit with a cup of tea which is served right there on the street and pass lovely time there sitting and glacing around!!!! great view
