experience istanbul. complete with places for accomodation, restaurants, and closeness to the main attraction such as Ayasofya, Blue Mosque. it's a nice place to stay when one is in Istanbul.
So much to do.... This district is bustling with things to capture the tourist and overwhelm the senses. Worth the stroll....

Dirty. It was just a mess of rubbish and was so sad to see! The grass around the new fountain is just a mud bath.
The streets nd ountsins are dirty
The fountain in Gulhaine park is not working and when we went in 2009 this was fantastic but o sad to see everything in such disrepair

Cramped, Crowed but wonderful. I was slightly dissapointed with the "new Istanbul" but the Sultanahmet district, retains it's charm of bygone days. But like every city in the world it's full of people trying to sell you "somenthing".

Historical area. Navigated starting Sultanahmet mosque then Hagia Sofia and the surrounding parks, bazaar with lots of people both locals & tourists all the time. Benches to sit on under pine tress when u get tired walking. Food sellers restaurant everywhere. Accessible by metro train. I went here alone from taksim by taxi for TL15, maybe cheaper if i didnt encountered traffic
A lot to see in the area. Definitely a lot to see in the area - the Blue Mosque (Sultanahmet Mosque), Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia, etc. Spend a day out there - you will not regret it.
So happening. Amazing buzz, this place was bustling well past mid-night. I didn't want to leave and go back to boring Australia.

Bayram experience. We stayed in Sultanahmet this week over Bayram and the atmosphere was amazing. Loads of people seeing the sights and soaking in the atmosphere. Unfortunately all of the grass has been killed off by the recent weather and footfall so it's not as pretty as usual but still a stunning location. Visit at night to see the blue mosque, Hagia Sophia and fountain beautifully floodlit, take a stroll down the alleys and avenues and enjoy some of the famous Sultanahmet kofte.

Atmospheric. The area is full of tourists, but ordinary Turkish people still live in the area as well. Loads of restaurants and cafés as well as the ever-present carpet-sellers. The Arasta Bazaar has a good selection of things to take home and is much smaller and less confusing than the Grand Bazaar.

A different experience!. Extraordinary experience! so nice people! nice tours o just walking around! We really would like to go back some time in the near future! We are recommending our friends to visit Istanbul and sharing our experiences with all of them! Beautiful part of the world!

Can walk to the Blue Mosque. Beautiful old city of Istanbul. The area is packed with little, quant restaurants, shops and mosques. As a women traveling alone I felt very comfortable in this area. A short walk to the Bosphorus Strait where you can catch a ferry to Istanbul on the Asian side.

Walk and enjoy. Early morning walk At Meydani, and have buns Simit. Take a picture of the Hagia Sophia, at any time of the day, look for a cake shop and eat delicious chocolate baklava. Do not miss the Column of Constantine, Cemberlitas Hamam, Egyptian obelisk, hear the call to prayer from the Blue Mosque and enjoy unforgettable moments. Be sure to visit Arasta bazaar. In the evening, sit in one of the cafes and share with friends water-pipe.

For me, the heart of Istanbul!. My husband and I spent about 2 days in Istanbul at the beginning of our trip throughout Turkey, and 10 during our last leg of the trip. Both times we stayed in Sultanahmet area. We were able to visit a lot of other districts in the city, but I wouldn't change Sultanahmet for anything. Yes, it is crowded, noisy, vendors harass you and some restaurants are overpriced for what they offer, but you walk within history and you can witness culture and tradition with every step you take. I live in NYC where streets are parallels and no too hilly for the most part, so to get lost in these cobblestone streets and stretch your leg muscles up the hills adds to the magic!

Touristy but pretty decent area. We stayed here for half our trip (four days, the last days in Sirkeci) three-four minutes from the hippodrome. The area is obviously "designed" for tourists and full of "traps", but you can still find some gems around - for instance a köfte place very close to the end of the hippodrome. It is beautiful though, and the distance to a lot of places of interest are easily within walking distance. We stayed in a very quiet part of the old town, but I wouldn't stay in this part of Istanbul again.

Must visit to experience the bustle and buzz. This area is central for most of the main attractions in Istanbul. Of course being a tourist haven, there are the usual touts, guides, hawkers and street artists. Be careful of pickpockets here. Don't feel offended by merchants always trying to sell you stuff and drag you into their cafes. It's to be expected. Just smile and walk away.There are troops of men and women dressed in blue or red. These are "official" tourist helpers and we asked for directions several times - they were friendly and spoke excellent English. An amphitheatre across the street on Divanyolu had several acts on offer (we went during Ramadan) and this was fun. There is a long street to the right (as you look at the Bosphorus) where there are tons of little shops for souvenirs etc. There's a place that sells cold water bottles, 2 500ml bottles for 1TL. A bargain! There are lots of ice cream parlours and pastry shops and most are very good (see pics attached). Do not miss the quintessential experience of wandering around this area.
Very nice district. Very beautifull place. Nice restaurants, safety. People Who works at the bars, restaurants are friendly and helpfull
busy busy busy.... it was soo busy.. there a lot of tourist and turkish men around who are trying to offer you something like apple tea etc.

Nice hidden treasures. We were staying in Sultanahmet and we ended up discovering 2 shops that we found really good and cheaper than most:- for lamps and souvenirs, a little shop just behind the Blue Mosque called "Mozaist". The owner is the artisan and he sells his work cheaper than you would find in the Grand Bazaar and other shops (believe me! We searched a lot for nice lamps...)- for leather goods, a little shop owned by a female designer (very rare!!!) with great bags and great sandals). It's located on "Taya Hatun Sokagi" street - to find it, just follow down the tram line that passes by Topkapi palace and gardens and follow it along the walls of the gardens in direction of the see. It's a little street just off the tram line to the right.These are my 2 "great buys" from Istambul!
Istanbul a rising star inTurkey. all the major attractions in the city are here, Blue mosque, haig Sophia, palace, bazaars, spice/grand.
"Great place for dining in ". Its a busy street here.Very close to tourisy attraction like Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Grand Bazar.
Absolutely amazing!. Impressive, beautiful, interesting... what else to say? We had the chance to visit Sultanahmet during the Ramazan and it was a unique experience that I would highly recommend.

nightmare. This area has to be visited to see the sights but beware everyone tries to sell you something, their are people begging others try to drag you into their shops, people shout at you to buy from them from their stuff all over the pavements, it drives you mad, if you buy anything check your change every single person including shops tried to short change me

centre of all the great attractions. The area of sultanahmet is lively, bustling and where you will find all the main attractions of old istanbul...there are some nice restaurants and lots of touristy shops, beware of carpet salesmen!!

Unique. Open to public within pray time schedule.It's amosque wich is well preserved, it has it's own fashionable feeling. So many people vist this place every day , Muslim and not .Very big building .
Beautiful area. A very lively area with all the tourist attractions around it. Nice cobbled streets with little cafes/restaurants/tramways. Best area to stay in Istanbul.
Turkish Delight1!. The area is a rare tourist delight! a park surrounded on all sides by decent hotels and historical attractions all within walking distances!

So Much To See In Sultanahmet. There are so many beautiful things to see in this area that you need at least two days, or more, to enjoy them. The Blue Mosque, the Ayasofya, the Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome, many local restaurants, the friendly local people, and countless shops.

Fascinating and atmospheric. We were in Istanbul during ramazan which mean that it was a bit different from normal. Although the cafes were quieter than usual during the day, the really nice aspect was the evening gathering of Istanbul families to break the daily fast. In the shadows of amazing buildings like Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque this was a great experience.

A wonderful place to walk around. I can't think of too many places where so many historical places are just a stone's throw away from each other. Be it the Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, Aya Sohpia, Grand Bazaar,a nd other museums. Its a beautiful place, the main street's buzzing with activity. Shops selling baklava, Turkish delight to ceramics, pottery, and other souveniers. A beautiful place to jsut walk around, filled with stret side cafe's restaurants with friendly service and great food.
Turkish delights. Fantastic part of such a large city, I loved the small streets and easy access to the famous monuments and antiquities.
Nice neighborhood. Good area to walk around and experience a bit of Istanbul, from the touristic point of views of course.
Ideal base area to stay. This area is were all the main attractions are located. Therefore it would be a good place to stay. There are many restaurants and shops that will cover your everyday needs.

Pity about the souvenir sellers. Impossible to miss this historic area of Istanbul, where many of the major historic sites are situated, but it's hard to walk past the shops without constant harassment from touts selling trinkets, rugs, ceramics ... all at very inflated prices unless you are prepared to haggle intensively. If only they knew how off-putting it is, I bought nothing in Istanbul because of it.
Brilliant. We attended an open air concert every night to enjoy the true meaning of community. With live singers and bands I would highly recommend this on your visit to Istanbul.

A must!. The area has everything you need for a short visit within easy walking distance. Hotels; all the main attractions - and a tram to get you to most of the others. Shops; Bazaar; (open till 11pm )and lots of places to eat. The square is a great place to 'people watch', and it seemed to transform, and burst into life in the evening, with street food sellers, and flood lights on the fountains and monuments.There are some public toilets which are clean enough - but the ladies are 'turkish style' (standing up )
Sultan Ahmad. Nice place, there's a very nice mosqe which i uploaded a photo of.With a big market.Go there in Ramadan, nice time. ;)

Convenience personafied!. We were on our first trip to Istanbul and had no idea how this one area was like a diamond mine until our guide took us here. Not only can you walk to the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilical Cisterns, the museum and lunch, but all these places will blow your mind. Start here while in Istanbul.
No place like "Old Town". Easy to get around. Many of the cities famous sites located within a short walking distance of each other. Great restaurants and shops, for all palates and pocketbooks.

Nice Area To be - specially during Ramadan. It is quite a side during Ramadan when families all begin to assemble in front of the Blue Mosque & Ayaa Sofia & break their fast at sundown. Its really a very festive & carnival atmospere one must partake in..
Great Historical site. Aya Sophia, Sultanahmet Mosque, Basilica, Topkapi Palace... you get a real feel of the culture of Istanbul!

Nice area to walk. We enjoyed walking the streets of Sultanahmet and taking in the impressions of this wonderful city very much.As we visited during Ramadan, we got to experience the fast braking atmosphere in the evening which was one of the most astonishing and inspiring things I have ever witnessed.I would recommend to pick up some street food and go to the hippodrome area / the area between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia in the evening to enjoy the atmoshpere.

A must be place, but can be done in one or two days. If you don't mind the thousands of people or if you choose a quiet time, you will enjoy walking amongst the great sights of the area... Don't forget to try Sultanahmet kofte!

Major sightseeing. Blue mosque,Hippodrome, Aya Sofya, Archaeological mueseums Topkapi palace within walking distance to each. Loads of eateries, shopping, Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar This has a big WOW factor.

Beware of Turkish carpet salesmen in the Sultanahmet district!. Historic and very interesting area.Disliked the men who would come up to you and begin to tell you about the attractions in the area-who turned out to be carpet salesmen!
liked the mix of old and not so old. I liked the Hipodrome, the German fountain, the small bazar behid the blew mosque, the whole area is very inviting and nice and easy to stroll

Touristy. Bit touristy, but if you wander amid these streets you can still find amazing sites and shops.There is amazing baclava and turkish delight to be found plus some sellers of porcelain that beat the higher prices in the Grand Bazarr.
sultanahmet. very central area for holiday you can go every where by walk distance you like to here because very popular

Nice. We stayed in this area, and it is conveniently located to all the major historical sites in Istanbul, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, Topakapi Palace, Grand Bazaar. All are a walkable distance, 4-5 mins to Blue Mosque, about 20 mins to Topkapi and 30-40 mins to the Grand Bazaar. Doy-Doy Restaurant and Sultan Kosesi Restaurant are the 2 restaurants we dined at frequently in that area. Both good, Sultan is a little more expensive, so we only ate our first and last meals there. We ate in and ordered out from Doy Doy, great food and great price!

Tons of history and here's some tips.... Read any tour book or other reviews here and you'll quickly learn that Sultanahmet is the home of most of the more notable, centuries-old sites in Istanbul. There are a plethora of hotels ranging from backpack-budgets to a Four Seasons. We hit a number of restaurants and they all serve pretty much the same food in this area. It's good, but it's mostly a variation of one sort or another on kabops. But it is good! Roof top restaurants abound with great views of the Bosphorus. The area is best covered on foot and you need to be able to handle hills. It's not quite as steep or as high as San Francisco or Seattle if that's any help. Also, in general, there are stairs and no wheel chair access. Hold the negative judgements. It's just the way it is. Do not expect great clubs here. Those are up north mostly on the west side of the Boshporus. That's where you will find the swanky night life and very nice hotels to strictly relax. If I was with a lover, I might just stay up there and catch a cab to Sultanahmet for the sites and do the night life up north.

amazing mosque. great sights, magnificent architecture everywhere, very photographic sceneries. i think sultanahmet mosque has to be one of the most beautiful ones in the whole world. don't miss the sights around it, though. there are all the tombs of sultans, and hamams (arab spa).
sultanahmet. sulatanahmet district is small difficult to drive car .But it was very clean it id good for all peoples.I think turkish people is very lucky
Discover the old Istanbul. Small streets, jewellery, Turkish Delight (Lokum), different cultured people, arabesque and gifts... Long Live Soultan Ahmad area, long live Istanbul...
good place for tourist. see the topkapi palace and hagia sophia which is 1500 yeras old. Its fantastic. Some restauranst were too much touristic choose the local ones

Hive of activity. This is the area where all the main tourist sites are found. The tram gives you easy access or just follow it along the road to get the full atmosphere. There is a peaceful garden area between the Basilica Cistern and Blue Mosque to rest tired feet and enjoy the place.
Relaxing. Very nice district with lots of food stalls (despite visiting in Turkish Ramazan). There are also the Obelixes to see and parks to relax in.
Definitely A To Do. This is the area where you have to visit! It has all of the historic sites and there is so much to see and explore!
Old City. This is the heart of old Istanbul. Shops, restaurants abound along with historical sites within easy walking distance. Also, the Tram runs right through it to take you anywhere else.

Home of top sights but very touristy and high probability to be ripped off. Sultanahmet is a very good location to stay if you want to be close to the main sights of Istanbul. Indeed, top sights such as the Blue Mosque, Ayasofia, Topkapi Palace or the Basilica Cisterna are all in Sultanahmet. I was there during the Ramadan and at night, it's the noisiest and liveliest place of Istanbul. Everybody is eating with friends or family in the parc near the tram station and the obelisks. It's worth to see this ! Sultanahmet is also a very good idea to explore Turkey's huge choice of food! Kebabs, baklava, Turkish delights, ..., there is everything. The drawback is that it's one of the most touristy places of Istanbul and as a consequence, prices (especially for food) are sometimes double compared to other quieter areas and you have a very very high chance to be ripped off in those shops or restaurants (experienced myself several times until I understood what was the "normal" price).

Incredible Sultanahmet, Istanbul. This old district of Istanbul has changed a lot since I first visited it about 25 years ago. However the little back streets retain their charm and if you venture down to the sea you will find old wooden houses which give you a flavour of what Istanbul used to be like.The tram goes straight through Sultanahmet but get off and sit in the park to get the best views of Aghia Sophia and the blue mosque, still facing each other after centuries. Wonderful buildings and they exude an amazing sense of history. Not to be missed!

A Must See. I have stayed on both sides, but I would have to say I enjoyed my stay here. The atmosphere is great and the Cafe/Restaurants are abundant. The shopping/restaurants on the drive up were great, and you old poke around there for hours. We stayed at the Ottoman Imperial... Highly recommend this hotel. Location was superb.

one of the lovliest place!. excellent!u can spend a full day there!
lovely markets , nice restuarants!
u can see peopel from diff natinalies there!:D
very touristic area. the place to be for a tourist, lots of restaurants, shops the grand bazaar Topkapi museum and hammam

Heart of the City. Sultanhamet is basically the Old City of Istanbul and visiting this place is the main reason for people coming to Istanbul. Within this part of the city are located: Topkapl Palace; Ayia Sophia; the Blue Mosque; the Water Cistern;the Hippodrome; and an Arts Museum. The Old City also gives easy access to (my favourite) the Grand Bazaar; the old Byzantine walls of the city, broken through by the Ottomans, heaps of street shopping and restaurants. I usually like to stay in the Old City so that I am only a short walk from all of these sites. In the warmer months you can buy pretzel/bagel type bread to munch on, pomegranet juice, and sit in the park to reflect on the amazing structures and Chestnut Trees by which you will find yourself surrounded. Access by train, bus, foot, taxi. Cameras are mandatory.

The Magnificent, The Execrable Sultan's Quarter. The "real" Istanbul is here: from layers of Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman history to modern touts breaking your will to live with their incessant pleas.."excuse me..! Where are you from? Want ..a bus tour, a rug, look at my shop, guide book...?'Tke dep breath and plunge into the wonder of some of the world's most breathtaking architecture..discover hidden gems like the actual mosaic palace floors of the great Byzantine palace...make friends with the charming waiters in little restaurants..splurge for a night in a modern, elegant Turkish restaurant such as Nar...do a little hookah and sit on couches at Dervish...enjoy the rooftops of hotel restaurants with views of Asia, Hagia Sophia and Sultanahmet and the sea! Yep, there are some persistent salesfolks, but they mean no harm...steel yourself and then jump in for an exhilirating experience! Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Underground Cistern, Grand Bazaar..all walkable!

Wear comfortable shoes.. I loved the narrow streets and little shops throughout this district. The locals were very helpful and tourist friendly. Because the streets are like a maze, it is easy to get lost. On several occasions, however, I watched as an obviously lost tourist was approached by a local resident and offered assistance. Very impressive.
A nice stroll in old town. The large park between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia is delightful. Don't forget to sit in one of the tea houses and have some Turkish tea in small glasses.

Must do. great walk around a very vibrant area of town. Also a tourist destination, so make sure you sharpen your bargaining skills. Beautiful architecture, local feel, well serviced by public transportation, clean and fun for everyone in the daytime.

Great area. Many interesting things to see including the Topaki Palace, the Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar. Istanbul is an amazing place. Very busy and chaotic but organised. The traffic is murder but taxis are plentiful and drivers polite.
living part of history. there are no words to describe the district. it is the heart of one of the most historic cities in the world, well preserved, clean and yet modern

iftar experience par anything.. i had the good fortune of experiencing the sultanahment district during ramzan and although imsak time is very late into the evening, the brotherhood and the feeling of community when thousands of people assemble, each group minding their own business without disrupting the peace, was a sight in itself. Istanbul impressed me because although it is an Islamic state it is not an over bearing one and is truly secular. other than that, being the city centre it is well connected to the tramway, bus and has all the must do's for a regular tourist like the blue mosque..etc. my husband and i also visited the pudding shop which is just opposite the tramway and walked all the way right of it. was a wonderful trip !

Visited Grand Bazaar and others.. Be careful with the shops. You will be accosted by the merchants. We had a tour guide with us, so we had less to deal with. Visited the scarf merchant, carpet merchant and porcelain merchant.
Istanbul 101. Obviously, the first area to visit in Istanbul as it has the top sights:Sultanahmet Mosque, Hagia Sophia, archeology museum, Topkapi Palace, cisterns, and Grand Bazaar..
Busy and hot, but a great experience.. Do your reading ahead of time. There are so many sites to see that you don't want to waste your time in long lines. Better yet, hire a guide and skip the lines.
An amazing area. Being so close to our hotel meant it was easy to walk around and find great eating places, although it was quite easy to get lost in the maze of winding little streets!

True city heart. It's not Taksim, it's here that you see the real Istanbul. Although if you look for some real authentic feel, just turn in any direction away from the main streets. You will find yourself in the wonderful city maze, quieter, more authentic, less touristy and therefore more interesting.

As it is called... the centre of the town. A very crowded area but here you can find almost everything you need, from souvenirs to clothes and shoes. The restaurants are OK, but many are non-smoking. There are also some young people who wear "ASK ME" t-shirts but they don't know very much about the neighbourhood... :))
Interesting area. We realy enjoyed this area, not only all the historical sights are located in this area, there are some very nice restaurants you can eat decent food for a decent price.
Interesting Area. The Sultanahmet district is a wonderful place to stay in and everything is within walking distance and some amazing gems of hotels are also found in this area.
Old city. I have said it.. "A district of contrasts". You will find nice and ugly at the same place, but it has its exotic flavor.

Touristy Place. Sultanahmet istrict good for walking and sightseeing. Food and drinks are expensive. Taksim is good for night lıfe and there is buch of cheap restaurants.
I recommmend everyone Istiklal street
Sultanahmet. Every thing in Sultanamet is a very good atraction! The area, food, bars, artesanal market. You can go around different streets discovering nice places.

You must stay in the Sultanahmet. The old district is a mixture and maze of mosques and historical sites. It is an interesting place that has not yet been completely spoiled by over commercialization. There are people from all over the world visiting this area and there are sections of beautiful gardens along with small shops and restaurants. Get off the main street and you can discover the charm of Istanbul. It is unfortunate that you have to deal with people approaching you to book tours and buy carpets, but I suppose it goes with the territory. There are many charming hotels in the area that are an oasis from the buzz of activity. The public transportation is good and convenient. You can also walk everywhere, but take a map. Many Turks speak English, so you will not have a problem getting around in the tourist areas.
Excellent. Glad we decided to stay in Sultanhamet. The old town is beautiful and is so handy for all the historic parts of Istanbul

Excellent Place to Stay. I enjoyed my stay in this area, all main attractions are located here, many good Turkish cuisine restaurants, hard to choose from. Also close to the Grand Bazar, make sure you do your homework on how to bargain when you visit the bazar.
Best location for tourists. I loved this district very much. Very peaceful and you can fine around everythign whatever you need and easy to use public transport.

Amazing Historical Walk. Many wonderful places u can see . My advise to book your hotel in this area. Most charming area with full of history and shops. But for females , if you are traveling alone, be careful with the guys who always wanted to disturb u by any ways.
Filled with History and Architecture. Other than some touristy stores and restaurants, this is the area with the most fascinating sites in Istanbul
charming. this is the most charming place full of history and shops and rest. well worth the time to spend a day here
Clean. We stayed in Sultanahmet District. I love the place because it is so clean and easy to get many things to eat. The dogs are every where, nice... easy to get simit every where lol

Nice walking around Sultanhamet. Just like in the old part of Rome, there are many interesting nooks and crannies to visit around Istanbul's Sultanahmet area. The area takes its name from the King (Sultan) Ahmet. It has many wonderful places to see and is the heart of the tourist attractions.

Amazing. My hotel was located in this district so I did a lot of exploring. I found that I was getting lost easily so that was frustrating but I did feel safe. You have to get accustomed to having waiters or store owners yelling at you, however.
Busy, busy, busy!. A very nice busy area. If you like browsing the shops amidst the crowd than this is a nice place to walk around. Watch out for bad deals though!

wonder around. this district is lovely to wonder around to drink tea and have a off the turkish delights.
it is hilly so wear good shoes...many small souvenir shops

hustle and bustle all the time. this district has so much to offer - from the tourist spots to restaurants to shops. this district doesnt sleep as well and it has eerything you need. is busy all the time so be ready for lots of people.

A taste of another culture. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, bazaars, shops, and one great restaurant after the next - what's not to like? Just know that an offer of a business card can lead to a protracted discussion towards your buying something you were not looking for…
Wonderful area. This is an amazing area full of little streets and shops and with the historic sites right there. You feel like you are in the true Turkey.

buzzing, cosmopolitan and vibrant!. The Sultanahmet Meydani Park in the main area of Sultanahmet was known as the Hippodrome and was the site of bloody Byzantine sporting events and was based on the design of the infamous Circus Maximus in Rome. Nowadays it's a pleasant park, surrounding various tourist attractions such as Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofia (Hagia Sophia) and the Sultan Ahmet Camii (the Blue Mosque)Check out the grand obelisk "aquired" from Egypt and dating from 1500BC, as well as the wonderful Wilhelm II fountain which was constructed in Germany and brought to Istanbul for the emperor's visit in 1895. The fountain was built to show strength and unity between Germany and Turkey against WWI allies.A good base to start exploring this vast amazing and vibrant City.

Great historical places!. There is one museum after another...definitely spend time here...visit the beautiful places and learn the history..I think I wouldn't stay here again...but you have to visit...kind of loud at night for sleeping...and hard to walk around in the evening...but do visit during the day.

Touristy charm. Sultanahmet reminded me of Khao San Rd in Bangkok, touristic with touts trying to draw you in everywhere. Both are also quite a lot more expensive than the more outlying areas of the city. Difference is that dining in Sultanahmet is quite pricey while you can get some nice cheap places in Khao San.I guess if you want a more Turkish experience and have an adventurous streak in you, there are much better places to stay in Istanbul. Just make sure it's close to a tram line and you will be all set and will definitely save a lot more on dining and accommodation!
Worth Staying in this District. So much in the area to enjoy - I say stay in this region. Great sites here, tram nearby, grand bazaar in walking distance.
Always so busy!. This place is where you want to be when on vacation - restaurants, bars, shops which work until late and can meet expectations of 'spoiled' tourists :-)
Sultanahmet. This is an excellent place to visit, there are so many attractions in and around the Sultanahmet that it compeletely filled our week's stay in Istanbul

AMAZING. This is the real old Istanbul (constantinople) Really oldy world feel,crooked leaning houses,washing hanging across the street in the backstreets. Very historical,uneven pavements so not good for those with mobility issues. Not to be missed if you go to istanbul. My fave part of the city

Time travel!. The hot spot where all the main historic sites are. Lots of life and activity, good restaurants, street vendors, and sights. Each of the individual sites are reviewed by many people so no point getting into them right now - but if you don't go here, why even go to Istanbul at all!?
What's Not to Like?. The place is teeming with life, color, history, smells, sounds...it is a feast for the senses and an amazing place to visit.
History round every corner. Stay in this area and you will be within walking distance of so many amazing places from Topkapi palace to the Bazaar to name but two
Topkapi palace. Stunning culture fingerprints.The harem and the heritages costs more than billions of dollars

don't stay in this area. it's nicer to stay over in the European side, the subway and tram networks are great. This area is a tourist trap and everything is costly and overpriced. You'll walk away feeling harassed.

Time machines are true.... Go their at night around 9, and walk aroun Hagia Sophia and up till the Blue mosque, truly a very nice experience that is certainly alone worth the visit back to Istanbul, it is like you are reliving earlier centuries.

Go During Ramadan. My husband and I loved the area we simply couldn't get enough of it, we went during Ramadan so there were festivals and bazaars every where, it was an amazing cultural and spiritual experience for me.It's very easy to get to and you don't really need a tour guide, take the Tram or one of the hop on hop off buses and just walk around it's pretty much self explanatory.

So much fun!!. The entire district is full of life. Many sites to see, many shops, many restaurants. We went with our two children (ages 9 & 4) and we enjoyed every minute!
Like stepping into Disney's Aladdin. Picturesque, and full of character and history, the real heart of Istanbul.
The Taste of Istanbul. In Sultan Ahmet you find the history of the city. This area must be visited to learn the old city and visit the Grand Bazar.

Extremely nice people!. I have strolled around Sultanahmet for three days now. Initially I was aware of the salespeople saying hi all the time, and of potential pickpockets, as other reviewers had pointed out. The area is however extremely safe. I even walked around by myself (many friends had told me that women are not to walk by themselves...? not sure what that was about) on Sunday evening, in the Grand Bazaar area, where everything was closed. I saw many groups of men together and was never approached by any of them. That was amazing. Had I been in Brazil...the story would have been much different. The bottom line is that this is EXTREMELY safe. I also attended the international folk dance competition (just behind Hagia Sofia) two nights in a row (started around 9pm). I sat next to folks who seemed to come from Turkey, and started talking to them. Most of them did not speak English. So that gave me the perfect opportunity to try my almost inexistent Turkish on them :) Sure enough, they were ready to help! I went from 'tamam' to 'teshekur ederim', 'gule gule', 'iyi gunler' in 5 minutes. After that I kept repeating these so I wouldn't forget them, and they laughed at me. That was really cool. I so loved to interact with them. They let me take pictures of them and pointed to the dancing folks and gave me thumbs up when they were liking the group. I so enjoyed the people here!
A place out of time. I liked the ambiance of the place.There was a baklava festival which was very joyful .

A little crowded and expensive. If yu are a tourist and you want to hang around in a good area, this place is one of the best in Istanbul. Great place to stay. Very near all of the main places to visit. Very good choice of restaurants, clean, friendly and safe.

Fantastic - I love the place!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Make sure you stay in the area, there are lots of reasonably priced hotels. To visit inside the attractions - I would also recommend going at opening time.The place is magic - one of my favorite cities, and there was so much more to enjoy than I had expected.

The heart of Old Istanbul. The Sultanahmet District is the heart of Old Istanbul. It sprawls over a ridge-line high above the European side of the city, and looks down on the busy Bosphorus waterway. It contains all the ancient monuments and buildings and tourist sites which make Old Istanbul famous … such as the Ottoman Sultan’s Palace (Topkapi) the fabulous Hagia Sophia, the imposing Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome, the underground Byzantine Cistern, the Archaeological Museum, and even the Grand Bazaar.The district itself takes its name from the Sultanahmet Mosque (known commonly as the Blue Mosque because of the abundance of blue tiles inside). This great mosque, built in 1616 by Sultan Ahmet 1) is instantly recognisable by its six minarets (most other mosques in the area have from one to four minarets).Because it’s so famous and rich in history, Sultanahmet is also crowded with hotels and tourists. Fortunately, the city building laws limit house sizes in this area to three-stories, so there are no high-rise buildings to spoil the skyline. Consequently the sights are there to be seen.They are, however, usually crowded with tourists, both foreign and domestic, so my best advice is to go either very early in the morning (before the big tourist busses start arriving) or go late in the evening (when the big tourist busses have left). That’s the time I find it easiest to access the major sights without waiting in queues for hours. This advice applies particularly to Topkapi Palace, where you need to arrive as early as possible because queues form here early and are sometimes huge (but don’t let this put you off because Topkapi is really worth visiting and if you're there by eight when the doors open you can get a ticket and have an hour of relatively uncrowded enjoyment.) Also, a little tip for shoppers: the museum shop just inside the Topkapi Palace gate is better than the one beside the ticket office outside.)The other challenge for visitors to Sultanahmet is that the district is perched on a steep ridge-line, and while the central area is reasonably flat, the streets all around are often cobbled and often run steeply downhill to the water. So, depending on your level of fitness, walking around the district can be a challenge to some.Getting there: The easiest way to visit the sights in Sultanahmet is to book a hotel in the district. There are plenty … some closer than others. They all claim to be excellent and to have wonderous views, but be cautious with these claims … check the reviews carefully and look for photos closely because some hotels are not all they claim to be. However there are some truely excellent hotels in the area (for example: see my review of the Ottoman Hotel Imperial in Sultanahmet). If your hotel is not in the Sultanahmet district, the easiest way to get there from other parts of Istanbul is by ferry to Eminonu near the Galata Bridge, and then catch the tram uphill to the district. Get off at the first stop past the Hagia Sophia. Trams are easy and quick. You buy tokens at each tram stop (there’s one right beside the Eminonu ferry wharf near the Galata Bridge) and hop aboard for a ride up Alemdar Cadessi to Hagia Sophia and the main Sultanahmet area. The trip takes just a few minutes and costs two tokens (about one US$). If you’re fit for a walk, just follow the tram tracks uphill. It’s not steep and will take you 25 minutes, and there are shops and restaurants along the way.Bottom line: If you’re visiting Istanbul, you MUST visit Sultanahmet. The best of the city is here. But wear stout shoes for the cobblestone streets, carry a good map, go early & be prepared for a full day out. Oh, and take a camera, because it’s very photogenic.

An enchanting location. In Sultanahmet's imperial days, traders sold spices from distant dominions in the bazaars, dignitaries hunted in parks lining the Bosporus, & buildings rose to immortalise the sultans. So the location is very old & very interesting with many historic treasures. Sultanahmet is right at the heart of the old European city & is a highly recommended place to stay. The old town centre was once the heart of Ottoman life & for first time visitors to Istanbul, the allure of the old city is inescapable.I found the ideal way to explore Sultanahmet is on foot - it is compact & seemed to be safe. The city's buses, trams & trains are also easy - you can find information at the Tourist Information place. The Sultanahmet area is handy for trams to modern Istanbul. If you use a taxi, ALWAYS be sure to agree a taxi fare with your driver before setting off. But proceeding through the city at a leisurely pace, taking the time to really enjoy the surroundings, the buildings and the people, means you have time to notice all the little things, from the man selling peeled & salted cucumbers, to the dilapidated posters of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of modern Turkey, that still adorn cafe walls.Wear very comfy shoes. The stairs/steps are very uneven & the streets are very rough cobblestone.Take your own scarf for your head to enter the mosques. Shorts are inappropriate in the mosques as are sleeveless tops. They will loan you a cape to wear (that everyone else has worn).THINGS TO DOFirst it's time for some consumer culture! Allow plenty of time in the Grand Bazaar. Make sure you try bargaining, too - the locals love it when you do. Annoying carpet-traders are a fact of life - keep on walking, avoid eye contact & don't answer questions if you are not interested.If you get hungry/thirsty, Erenler Cay Bahcesi, Yeniceriler Caddesi 36/28, Cemberlitas is an old city nargilah cafe tucked away in a former medrese (Islamic school building) near the Grand Bazaar. Men in uniform hurry from table to table with trays of tea glasses & cups of thick Turkish coffee & shovels full of hot coals to stoke the nargileh pipes.In the Spice Market Bazaar henna is heaped into green cones & fist-like sponges are strung from the ceiling.The Yerebatan underground cisterns are worth a visit for the carved stone columns used willy-nillyYou can view treasures in the Topkapi Palace - from mosaic rooms & acres of manicured gardens - once lit by tortoises carrying candles on their backs - to the centuries of bling kept in the dimly cabinets of the Treasury.Exhausted by the strain of not buying a kelim in the Bazaar, you can find respite in one of Istanbul's most famous sights, one of the more than 3,000 top mosques.Rustem Pasa Mosque within easy walking distance of the Spice Bazaar showcases exquisite Iznik tiles, which cover the walls, columns & facade of its porchHundreds of tiny glass lamps hang low from the roof of the Blue Mosque on wheels of iron, & appreciating the glamorously tiled dome gave me a crick in the neck!Once a Byzantine church only for Christians, then made into a magnificent mosque, the Hagia Sophia is now a museum. Glorious, mosaic-filled & not to be missed.  Most of all.......HAVE FUN!
Bustling place, has everything.. Great place to stay, eat, shop and hang out! In the center of all the attractions and is close to a lot of great places.
Old Town Historical Center. We stayed at Hotel Amira and were able to walk to all the destinations in the Sultanahmet District. It is safe and the city area is very clean. Very enjoyable visit.

so much to see. I picked a hotel in this area (the Neorion; I highly recommend it) as it was where I figured I'd spend most of my time. This was a good choice for a base of operations, as there is so much to see in this area.
touristic. it is the most beautiful area in the city, but it is full of people and shops are mucho more expensive than in other parts of the city
Sultanahmet Distric. Very busy with tourists but very clean and locals very friendly.
great walk to soak in the atmosphere. a great place for a walk around and excellent sites in the vicinity. food vendors on the street corners give a taste of local snacks.
Great Location. People were great, lots of places to eat and shop.

Lively, fun, easy to get around; near everything. Why stay anywhere else? Sultanahmet has the Bazaar, Topkapi Palace Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, restaurants, sidewalk cafes and shops. You can walk to the whole shebang. Wow.
Great Area. Easy to walk around, people friendly and helpful. lots of eating and drinking places. Many places to sit and enjoy the scenery or just rest

Best place to stay!. It might not be "authentic" and it is full of tourists but it is convenient,vibrant and fun!! The local Bazaar is great and more relaxed than the Grand Bazaar - be sure to check out Jennifer's Hamam. The restaurants might not be world class and a bit overpriced, but we never had a bad meal.

Refreshing in the heat of Istanbul. The spice market in the sultanahmet district is a fine display of turkish Delicacies and All the is Turkish, like Nazar Bundheus, Turkish Delights, Lamps, Teas, Nuts and dry fruits. In short whatever is special to turkey is available here.A stone's throw from Taksim Square, it is a must visit place.
A must do! Then, repeat.. I've traveled much but this area has more good restaurants and interesting sites than any other. Overwhelming in a positive way.

Nice area to explore!. I was based in this area and nice to walk around and eat and drink lots of turkish things, try the turkish coffee but wait for it to settle first.
Really nice area to just chill and explore.

A neighborhood packed with history and beauty!. In one day and one neighborhood, you can visit a cathedral that became a mosque and marked the end of the Byzantine empire (Haja Sofia), one of the most spectacular mosques of the muslim world (The Blue mosque of Sultan Ahmet) and the residence of Ottoman sultans for 500 years (Topkapi)!

Wonderful experience. You can't go to Istanbul & miss this district! We started our walk from the suleymaniye mosque to the Grand bazaar then to the blue mosque & hagia sophia & walked through dozens of neat streets. Beside the hassle you get sometimes from the shop owners, it was a wonderful experience. The neighbourhood is safe, packed with historical sites & plenty of nice restaurants & of course shops. We really enjoyed our 4 hours walk & didn't even notice we walked that much!
Everything is in this area. Lots of character, everything is in the old town. Shops and even the bazaar not too hassly.
Excellent base. Everything is so easy to get to from Sultanahmet as long as you can walk easily - Blue Mosque, Baslica Cistern and Topkaki Palace and its museum

Extraordinary collection of sights, history and culture, must see.. Complexity, antiquity and range. This is one of the worlds great crossroads and elements of many of the different cultures from Greek through the present day are visible.
calm and relaxing. It's good you get to see so many things in just one spot.

Sultanahmet. We are so glad we stayed in this neighborhood as all of the important historical places are so close and easy to visit within a couple of days. There is extreme competition amongst the carpet sellers and the restaurants and they really value any recognition from Trip Advisor!
You must have a Turkish bath!. One of my best experiences in Istanbul - a great way to while away an evening.
Great atmosphere. I love oriental atmosphere in this location, especially while sunset.

Where everything is happening. We were so glad we stayed at Sultanahmet and could walk to every historical site. It mean't we could go out late at night and walk around then meander home without having to worry about trams etc. This is really the best place to stay in Istanbul

Brilliant lend of history & modern. The Blue mosque is located near this area, easy to get to by tram. After looking around, go to the roof top of one of the many bars & restaurants along the tram line, and enjoy a drink with fantastic views.The Grand Bizaar is one more stop along on the tram. Great for bargain hunting but be prepared to haggle a lot!
World history within a few steps. The blue mosque often has and extended wait, but is well worth it.

History, clean and safe. This was our 2nd visit, we arrived at 1am this time and walked around to stretch our legs and to see the blue mosque with the light and birds, just lovely. Safe and friendly location

Best Place to Stay in Istanbul. I could walk to see all the main attractions in Istanbul living in Sutlanahmet. The tram is very convenient. Any place I coulnd not walk I took a tram, a bus, and a ferry. You can easily shop, eat, visit historical places come back to your hotel to rest and go back to see beatiful Istanbul reenergized.

Sultanahmet. Let us be honest, the area is, in general, a total hole filled with arrogant waiters screaming in your face and trying to force you in to their establishment. However, it contains pretty much every significant Tourist sight in Istanbul....so you have little choice but to stay here if it is your first trip
Great place to stay. All the attractions of old Istanbul are here including the Blue Mosque and Grand Bazaar. It's safe to walk around at night and there is great shopping.

Marmara university art gallery. At the far end of the hippodrome across from the column of Constantine is a small art gallery & museum with free entrance. Not in the tourist guides but it is a delightful find with many outstanding works on display. Including a collection of the works of an Egyptian born graphical artist that is a pleasure for those interested in figurative drawing. Well worth a visit.

The Centre of Everything. We stayed in Sultanahmet and we were able to walk to many of the sights which it offers - the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are a must. There are restaurants aplenty too. Don't miss the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market area.
A Very Lively Place. It's the perfect spot to stay in Istanbul if you are single, couple or a family

Starting point. this is a turistic part of Istanbul. You can find many different shops and fast food (mc donald for example) and different turkish restaurants. I would say, Istanbul is definitely not in sultanahmet but it is a good point to start your visit cause all the main attractions are located in this area.
Fine area!. I would like to come back there one more! Old area in Istanbul with old buildings and fine atmosphera

Sultanahmet - Tourist central point in Istanbul. All tourists to Istanbul must come to Sultanahmet district. This is where mostly all the tourist attractions are. You can go to The Hagia Sophia, The Blue Mosque, The Topkapi Palace, The Basillica Cistern, The Kucuk Hagia Sophia, The Archeological Meseum and many other historical places from here.The Grand Bazaar and The Egyption (or Spice) Bazaar is also within walking distance from here. One must start its tour of Istanbul here and move outwards with the tram, buses or taxis.Be careful with friendly men who approached you pretending to be a friend. Most of the time, his mission is to 'pull' you into one of those carpets or other shops. Nothing criminal, just sinister.

Heart and soul of Istanbul. Such a diversity of travellers, locals, historical attractions, restaurants etc.... Lovey to sit and people watch with a turkish ice cream! When someone tries to sell you a guide book the stock answer is .......I've already got one thank you...... it works better than no thanks!

Historical area within walking distance. Good walking distance to all historical place. A lot of side walk cafe whenever you are tired. Being the tourist area, all shopping need to negotiate for prices.
No tour agent is needed. Please don't be fooled by travel agents who try to make it sound like you need them for this. It is a very very nice place that you MUST go to during your trip to Istanbul.
Fantastic. The big sights, easy access to the rest of Istanbul and the bars are better yet about half the price you pay where the books & guides send you.

We liked it but ended up spending a lot on a rug. The sights are beautiful. We went there with a few hours to spare in a layover in Istanbul. Not really knowing what we were doing, a local rug merchant approached us and gave us a nice tour of the area, which was great. The blue mosque was very interesting. Then he took us back to his rug shop and served us drinks. We ended up buying two rugs and spending way more than we had planned. Later we had a good dinner in one of the local cafes. It is about 45 minutes cab ride from the airport, about 45 Turkish lira ($25) for the fare.

One of the best historical place in the World. All around looks like a dream, It looks like get into a fairy tale. Egyptian column, Ottoman's and Byzntinians buildings, you can see and feel the World's historical heritage. Also you can see famous places from books and movies.
old city. Really lovely to walk around, lots to see for couples as well as families, and good variety of places to eat.

Spiffed up area. The Sultanhamet area is really a spiffed up tourist area compared to the Sirkeci neighborhood on the other side of the hill. Worth a visit just to compare the differences in the various neighborhoods but it is a bit like going to a theme park version of Istanbul.

Relaxing evening in the park. We loved just sitting and watching the people - families strolling, a free concert in the ampitheatre, the fragrance of chestnuts roasting on the two-wheeled carts...awesome. Safe. Walkable.
Heart of the city. This is definetly the place to stay so many attractions within walking distance. Restaurants in abundance and good shopping. Easy transport links if you want to go firther afield.
Ambassador Hotel. The bathhouse was great, the guy scrubbed parts I didn't know I had and gettung naked wasn't an issue. I felt like a baby getting bathed by a parent

Best area of Istanbul. Better to stay at a hotel is this district to be close to the major sites
Many restaurants in this area
Lots of History. Had lots of things to do, really culturally rich. Worth your time and money.

Nice piece of history.. I liked all the restaurants and the old buildings. It was amazing to see how European this part of the city actually is. Reminded me a lot like other old cities in european towns.

Perfect!. really really lovely! I just don't know what to say, besides the great historical buildings , the overall atmosphere and the taste of this district is great! I would definitely travel there at least another 2 times!
sultan ahmet mosque. loved this beautiful mosque known as the blue mosque
Historical. Historical area,close to a lot of Historical sites but very tight quarters,Hilly if you have problem walking up and down hills,This is not for you

A "Must See" for every tourist in Istanbul. This is a great place to base your stay, some of the main tourist sites including Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Cistern are in this area. Many other areas of the city are accessible via the tram system which runs through it.There are numerous touristy restaurants near to the Blue Mosque (check out a map and look for the streets between the Mosque and the sea). ALso in the area, if you let yourself wander you will come across little shops/bazaar. Not the cheapest place to pick up your souvenirs but beautiful buildings to enjoy regardless.
S much to see & feel...in such a small area. There is so much to see. It is ll within walking distance. Every turn has a photo moment. Wear your walking shoes.

get away from the tourist spots to have a genuine feel of the area. After our first day, we generally stayed away from the bazaar area and shops. Instead, we just explored the rambling cobbled streets that led us to the quieter areas of Sultanahmet where we admired the architectural features of the quaint houses. Bring good shoes cos the cobbled streets can take their toll on your feet if you are walking the whole day.

Loved Sultanahmet. It's the heart of Old Istanbul. Of course you'll be in the midst of thousands of other tourists, but persevere and get off the main streets to see some other parts of Sultanahmet. DO NOT MISS the Cistern. It's one of the great marvels of ancient engineering, and awesome in its size. Same for Hagia Sophia, which has beautiful mosaics, tile work, and calligraphy throughout the wondrous building. The Blue Mosque, too, is gorgeous. It's an active mosque, so do show proper respect once inside. Then there's Topkapi, which is a visual wonderland. Like so much in Istanbul, there's an excess of everything one can see at Topkapi.

Culture you cannot ignore. Sleeping with the windows open, it was hard to ignore the 5 daily prayers blasting from the megaphones perched on the towers of each mosque which began bright and early, and ended quite late. You get used to it, and it definitely adds to the experience. We booked a hotel in Sultanahmet for 4 nights and were extremely glad we did. Access to everything from here.
topkapi palace. an amazing place to visit, see the harem and the beautiful architecture and the wonderful mosaic tiles, very well maintained with a good restaurant to eat if hungry, a must visit
Sultanahmet is worth visiting. We really liked the sultanahmet area. The trams were very clean.The whole area was very clean with lots of cafes andrestaurants.
Tourist hell...... ....but still worth basing yourself here for the amazing sites.

Good location. This is a great place to lodge while you're visiting Istanbul. It is within easy walking distance to major attractions, restaurants, shops, bazaars and the tram. The tram is easy to use since the stops are clearly shown on a map and announced while underway.
A dream come true. It was all we could Imagine, and a lot we couldnt possibly, without being there...

Definitively the place to stay. Ok, so i have not stayed in other neighbourhoods, but having walked throught the others I thought this is the place to stay, specially if it is your first visit to Istanbul and you want to go to all the must see places (Blue Mosk, Hagia Sofia, TopKapi palace, cistern, Grand bazar, etc...). It also is very lively and full of nice restaurants for all the budgets, and it is well connected to other areas (i.e. Taksim, Galata Tower, Spices bazar, etc...) via the tram.

City feel with beautiful sights!. We enjoyed the Sultanahmet district. We stayed in a small boutique hotel in the heart of Sultanahmet and were very happy we did! The museums, mosques,shopping were all within walking distance. The Turkish merchants were very friendly and would respect "no, thank you" without further haggling! Things not to miss in the Sultanahmet area include: Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cistern, Hippodrome, and Grand Bazaar.

Picture book. Blue mosque, Aya Sophia, Topkapi, cemberlitas hammam, Suleymany mosque, Bazar (small and great), all too much to take in.You keep astonashing yourself of these great cultural high lights.

Vibrant and interesting, but also pretty touristy. We were in Istanbul for two weeks and spent the first week in this district and the second week in a little more off the beaten track area for the contrast. You really can't beat Sultanahmet for the proximity to the must sees and the atmosphere. It is very pleasant to walk through the cobbled streets and explore (even though when I was visiting it was snowing pretty hard- thus a little less enjoyable than I'm sure it would have been in better weather). Naturally, it is overrun with tourists pretty much year round but that also makes for great people watching. I wasn't as impressed with the food in this section of town as I was with other neighborhoods...that being said there are a few shops right in front of the tram stop that had amazing baklava and borek :) Enjoy!
great buzzing place anytime of the day. good choice of bars and restaurants, excellant choice of food and service +++. But haggle on the price of fresh produce

Sultanahmet District. There aren't really enough adjectives to describe the wonderfully rich history and beauty of this district. It's truly a great part of one of the greatest cities in the world! Not to be missed.

Really can't miss this. The best part - people watching. Of course you go there for the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, etc. but with so many tourists, both foreign and domestic, it's a great place to see the diversity of visitors in Istanbul.
Fantastic atmosphere, especially at night. The community was there as well as the tourists. Loved walking around the square and seeing the buildings lit up at night
In a different century. Cultural, brilliant, time warp. Superb structures and great food and articrafts
Great to see everything.. Stay In this area and get the most of the city and he atmosphere of the area. This is where the Blue Mosque , Haggia Sophia, Cisterns, Topkapi etc are situated.

Lively area full of shops and restaurants. Sultanahmet is a wonderful area full of charming shops and delicious restaurants. It is very accessible by train and walking. Just wandering around is very enjoyable.
Give yourself plenty of time. There is so much to see and enjoy in Istanbul, do give yourself plenty of time to view the Sultanhmet District.

Friendly, helpful with a small town atmosphere. I love the friendly manners and the pride that the local people take in their area. If you ask for direction and look confused you'll find your self with a guide. Of course the shop salesmen want to sell something, but they also want your visit to be comfortable.
Interesting Area. Everything I expected to see in Istanbul is packed into this area. Most interesting, to me, anyway.

Far more interesting than the Asian side. I highly recommend staying here as opposed to the other side of the Bospherous...but I suppose it's a matter of taste. In Sultanhamet, so can wander into Turkish neighborhoods that are really only a few steps off the beaten tourist path and see a whole other way of life...It felt perfectly safe even when I explored streets that were more ramshackle...I especially enjoyed the shoe district for a slice of real turkish life...go see it now, too because they say this area is becomming gentrified and all those shoe factories will soon be unable to afford the rent. Go into the little corner grocery shops. Try getting a wash and blowdry at a salon. Sit in one of the small public parks and watch the groups of men socializing. :)

wonderfull. It is a place where you can find everything. from the shop that sells you the tipical turist gift to the one that sell tipical manifacture leather stuff!In some streets you also will find nice pub, where you can smoke a narghilè or even drink a çai, with the wonderfull view of the camii!!
Sultanahmet. Very clean, lost of young people. Lots of food to snack on even at reasonable prices - always a surpise for a South African traveller in Europe!.
Many Historic and Cultural Sights. Twisty turny roads, modern shopping, tram. Many historic/cultural sites including Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, etc.
Good for history trip. Aya Sophia, Sultanahmet, Topkapi and many, many other.
Great. This for me is wonder place for sure with many great view
Best area to stay if you are a tourist. This is where it's at. The historic istanbul where you can walk around the heritage of old empires.

Carpet salesmen. This area is, believe me, beautiful. There are so many things to see and do here and it's definitely worth the trip. However, the pain in the _ss (I'd like to buy a vowel) carpet salesmen pests sully the place. I've been there two times and each time found the experience spoiled by pesky carnival like barkers who hound you at every stop to come and see their carpet shop. If you visit here don't make eye contact with the carpet "beggers" and make sure you know where you're going so that you won't need to stop and ask anyone directions.

Interesting. Grand Bazaar was a dissapointment in term of prices:you can by cheaperon the streets.Should have visited Egyptian bazaar (spices bazaar).Streets are very crowded each day ,each hour,you can find a lot of good restaurants.Blue line of city buses is the most interesting (2 hour tour including passing over bosphorus)
Old world feel. Thoroughly enjoyed wandering around Sultanahmet area and getting a feel of the old world, Ottoman houses, history and hospitality
Very interesting area. Its a busy place and people everywhere. History, columns and buildings all around. Lots to learn

There's a story at every corner. This area is a maze of tiny streets and lanes with beautiful old buildings, real people and the bustle of everyday Istanbul life. A slow walk around this district letting very twisting lane open up a new piece of the past mixed with the present will engulf you in a cacophany of sounds and a barrage of smells that will bring your experience of Istanbul's historic sector to life - and when you think back on it, it will be this heightening of all the senses that will remind you of what a wonderful and exotic place it is.

Supurb Sultanahmet. There is a whole lot of history in a very small area. All the features are beautifully preserved and are within easy walking distance of each other. Each is a moving experience of itself.
Amazing historic sites, restaurants, Dervishes etc. Many of the most visited sites are within walking distance. arm yourself with a good guide book or better a tour guide
historic location of istanbul. it has the best historic sites and it is a great touristic site lots of hotels and restaurant but a bit high prices
Exciting and historic. The district was busy but romantic. We enjoyed sitting in the small park watching th world go by and even got a chance to enjoy a free concert of traditional music

great site to see. it was free entrance, and open 24 hours daily. very nice at night as well when all the lights are on. However, when i visit, there are some renovation of the path way in front of the Blue mosquse so it was a bit messy outside

very hip and central location. Loved this area, the Mosque, Sophia and grand bazaar all within walking distance, as are all the wonderful restaurants, shops and bazaar. Be careful of the shisha lounge - i got a terrible chest infection after a tiny session. Haggle galore at the shops. and have tea in the evening with the locals love the area lots to see and do. Book your tris with Sam just on route to the Mosque

this is where you want to stay. We stayed 4 nights at the Sultanhan hotel. Five minutes to the left the grand bazaar and ten minutes walk to the right the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and every place else.
Amazing history. The historical sites have a good mix of restored and unrestored. The crowds can get a bit overpowering

Amrosia Dwells here!. A great location if you are a foodie! Apart from the food on the main street you can lurk into small corners to also find some cheap stuff. We found a menu for less that 3Euros for lunch and tasted as good as it gets !
Great for walking around, taking pictures and getting lost. So full of great things to see. Also many nice restaurants.

Wander. Be sure to wander down to the Istanbul Craft Center,near the Blue Mosque. You might see the artist at work. Also, great little restaurant near there called " The Secret Garden" Near the Four Seasons Hotel

awesome but be careful by toursit traps. the market, the monuments are heavenly...but beware of people trying to approach you for a haman. or asking you to join them for a pub etc.. they may take all your money...else the people of turkey are quite helpful, friendly .. you may have language problem but they will help you to their best

A place to stay and explore. We stayed in the area for 8 days. We were in the heart of it and all major sites were within 1.5 km (1 mile) from the hotel, including Aya Sofia, mini Aya Sofia, etc. Hotel was on Pierre Loti street. Many restaurants and small convenience shops scattered all over the area, many small family owned restaurants with amazing and inexpensive home-made food. We walked everywhere from it. We also saw Taksim Square and we felt that we made a right choice by staying in this district instead. We felt that Istiklal street was somewhat overrated. Perhaps other major cities have spoiled us and this street did not measure up to them. We will be back :-)

Avoid locals who talk to you!. Fun touristy but historic area. Unless you want to be suckered out of your time and money, do NOT stop to respond to locals who talk with you. Usually they will start with, "Where are you from?" "I have a cousin in the US."

Traffic is a nightmare. The Blue Mosque and Grand Bazaar were worth a visit. Sailing on the Bosphorus was very pleasant. However the dirt and traffic means I wouldnt visit again from choice. Finding restaurants that sold alchohol was difficult and expensive. If they want to make this a dry city then they should make it clear to travellers. Dont visit toilets at Blue Mosque unless you like squatting.
Filled with history. Be careful with prices of touristic items, shop around or haggle
Beautiful!. In this district you find the main sites of the city. Everything is in a good condition, it's just a great district to walk around in!

History around every bend & in the air... unless you have business across the water, this is the area to be in...one of the oldest churches in Christian history, beautiful mosques, museums, Topkapi Palace, old and new shops & market places...a great walking city/area...relatively safe..use common sense..over time I've found the street life to be never dull..don't let street business people intimidate you..a polite "NO" or simply walk away is enough..Grand Bazaar never gets to be old news...several very good places to eat in & around the bazaar...if you're there during/end of Ramadan, you will have a great time at night...enjoy

Great Historical area. Filled with tourists clicking photographs, Sultanahmet district is a must see. All the major historical sites are within a walking distance from each other.A great host of restaurants are also there offering different cuisines.
THE place to stay in Istanbul. Why stay anywhere else but in the heart of the old city in the midst of the historic monuments and near the tram line?

not to be missed. too many historic venues for one day in this area: Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia Museum are must sees but require a full day to properly visit. Multiple ethnic groups, religions and thousands of years of history have left their mark on the magnificent structures.

see this!. must see sight of Istanbul, Old City area. get in there during Ramadan. you'll feel like in Ottoman :) lots of fast food and local restaurants around, prices are not that high, similar to Istiklal's. I love Old City!
nice location. there is like a historic city , everything is very old there , amazing , and you will be shock when you arrived there , because there is have many important things

A Great Place with a lot of Attractions. The Sultanahmet district offers you a variety of things to do including visiting historic places (Topkapi and Blue Mosque), and shopping around as there is many shops nearby and the Grand Bazaar is just a 10 minutes walk from there in addition to the various restaurants around. Your trip to Istanbul would not be complete if you dont visit that place
Sultanahmet Revisted...... The centre of Roman, Ottoman etc history. Amazing architecture and monuments. Makes one think about what has gone before and how it affected all of our lives.

Tourist feeding frenzy. Although this area is great for being near the sites, I would not opt to stay here again. Too many people trying to get your attention, your money and at unfair rates. Not anything like the rest of Turkey, with rude people who pester you and everything ridiculously overprices. Great to visit for the sites, but not to stay.

Old world charm. We stayed at Ferman hotel in the district. It was a pleasure to walk through the cobbled stone lanes and roads. To think these were the same routes used centuries before made it even special.

This is where Istanbul is happening. It's loud, crowded, and alive! Be prepared to be enticed to buy anything and everything, but it's a feast for the eyes, the ears, and the nose. Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Blue Mosque, any street - it's all a wonderful experience.

Arista Bazaar. This Bazaar is tiny by has all the same stuff as the Grand Bazaar. It's open air street and less aggressive merchants as well as a good choice in scarves, ceramics, carpets, wonderful Turkish Ice Cream, overpriced jewellery..... good fun and it takes only a short stroll to feel the atmopshere. Skip the open air Cafe and head to a neighbourhood restaurant ...The staff do not understand English and could not get our order right and were surly.

So much to do!. If you enjoy history and learning about other cultures, than this is the place to be. Topkapi Palace, The Hagia Sophia and The Blue Mosque are just a few of the beautiful sites you can visit. If shopping, eating and drinking are your thing, than this to is the place to be! Try the local food and beer at Hayem Restaurant, near the Sikeci Konak Hotel and shop for beautiful pottery afterwards!

Interesting place. The area is very good, but the staff outside the restaurants are very aggressive, and they hazzle the tourists. If you are offered to eat or dring at their place, and you turn them down, they can be rude. We had our meal at Faros restaurant. There we could look at the menu alone without being told that they have the best food and drinks in Istanbul.
Top european touristic area. Well organised, competitive. Congratulation to the Mayor.
Always new discoveries. Always love to wander around and this time discovered the Arasta Bazaar and Jennifers Hamman, great place for Turkish Towels - strongly recommend a visit.
Interesting and safe. Nice coffee and pastry shops. Great for window shopping. Interesting street vendors. We enjoyed walking around.

Interesting. I've been here many times, but I was surprised on my last visit that most of the sights are closed at around 18:00 which is too early especially during summer.
There are many nice places to see, but be careful of the taxi drivers - they have many ways to rip you off
April May 12. History, culture and the overall feel of the area enevlop you. The grand designs of the past are alive and really take you to an age past.
Its historical and magical, clean and attractive. Sultanahmet district is a clean place, lots of places to visit, very historical. People are tourist friendly and humble.

This is the area where the sights are. This is where you want to be. There are lots of great sites here as well as the Grand Bazaar, and restaurants. Many of the sites are walking distance and there's a fantastic tram that is a life-saver! Be sure to use it.
Sultanahmet District has it all!. Reserve at least half a day if not a whole day to visit all the major historical sites of this area!

Its great.. Yes its touristy, but it's safe, picturesque and provided you choose restaurants carefull, you wont get ripped off. The Turks must be among the kindest people in the world, and this area makes a good base. getting around Istanbul is easy and quick.

The place to stay in Istanbul. On saying that we did do a tour of Turkey and stayed the first couple of nights in Taksim which was great. We then stayed in the old city for 4 nights when we returned. So close to all the tourist attractions and great restaurants. Lots of gift shops with very reasonably priced good and woulstill accept an offer. Loved our stay.
Stay Here. Be sure to stay in this district where everything you want to see is within walking distance.
Outstanding Area. Clean area and very good resturants. Very organizined area and everything is close by. you can spend three days easily there without being bored!

My hotel was in this area - and that was a huge plus. It has been said by many reviewers that some 'visitors' never get out of of the SULTANAHMET area area of Istanbul . They state that other areas are worth the visit-which is so true. I explored other areas including a few trips to the Asia side of Istanbul.I stayed in the Sultanahmet area in a small, personal hotel/inn with 16 rooms. Everyone working there knew who you were.I was minutes away from the Hippodrome(site of ancient chariot races), the Blue Mosque , Aya Sofia and my favourite street-Divanyolu Cadessi. I'm already thinking of when I can return...

Full of people and life. A feast for the senses! There is so much to see and do in a relatively small area. Mosques, palaces, museums, shopping, bazaars all centuries old. The Turks will drive you crazy if you stay long enough. Just roll with punches, we were constantly harassed to buy a carpet. If not that, then you will be asked to eat or drink at their restaurant. Just politely say no and walk on. The food is good and there are plenty of eating places to satisfy all tastes. Wouldn't have missed it for the world.
very good area. very clean with many historical places,like agia sofia , top kapi ,basilica sisterna , blue mosque , grand bazar.

At the centre of Turkish History. We took this 3 day trip for our Daughters 40th Birthday to Istanbul and stayed in Sultanahmet which is very close to a lot of the more interesting historical sights in Istanbul. We stayed at the Ottoman hotel Imperial which is a small boutique hotel with a special certificate. It has a lot of history at this hotel very interesting as it used to be occupied by the army and was a school also. It has subsequently been renovated into a very beautiful boutique hotel with interesting decor the colours in the rooms are vibrant in reds and oranges very uplifting.The bedrooms were a little small but we thought it good value for money. The terrace area a lovely setting for breakfast with views over the domes. For sightseeing in Sultanahmet you were right there a few minutes walk away from the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace.The Basilica Cystern was across the road .Breakfast was very good and tasty consisting of cold meats, fruit yog, cereals,and hot food etc a very good choice. The first day we thought it a good idea to orientate ourselves to the city and took a City Sightseeing tour bus around a really good idea and you could get on and off to see the sights. That day we also went to the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque as very close together. The next day we went to the Grand Bazaar and the Basilica Cystern. We are going back to visit for 3 days this September as such a lot more to see such as Topkapi Palace and Dolmabahce Palace also the Egyptian Spice market. We also want to go on a Bosphorus cruise.You do have to be very aware of the pickpockets, bagsnatchers and the taxi scams the "you only gave me 5 lira", when you gave them 50 lira and do not agree to go with anyone that stops you in the streets especially if they want to befriend you and take you to a bar for drinks where you end up paying thousands of lira for a few drinks and some fruit. Do not engage in conversation with anyone who approaches you on the street as a general rule best to ignore them.If you answer politely they take this as encouragement. Forwarned is forarmed. None of this should put you off of what is essentially a wonderful and beautiful city with an endless wealth of history.We hope to use the same philosophy and common sense this September on our return to Istanbul.
Great Walking Tour Area. with a Lonely Planets apps in hand, self-guided walking tours of this district are really rewarding - very rich in living history
must see in Istanbul. a nice area with a lot to see, a mosque, nice neighborhood, gift shops and so on
Fun & Vibrant area. Area where most of the bars are.Go here for a nice drink and make sure you have a shisha!
Incredible amount of history in a compact area. So many wonderful things to see that I would need at least 3 days to see a good amount of the amazing sites.

Beautiful, but crowded. I spent four nights there, which is not much. My general feeling is that the area is expensive and crowded, but with nice views and friendly locals. It's fine for a short vacation.

Must See. Try to stay close so take in all action. So many things so close to each other. Blue Mosque, Cistern, Restaurants, Shopping you name it. every thing within the walking distance. Istanbul transit is very crowded so if you are within the walking distance you can avoid.
