Just wonder around. You can walk for hours and on every corner you will see something new like bazaars, small shops, mosques, palaces, spices, bars, restaurants.

Enjoyed it very much. Sultanahmet is the area where all the historiacl sights are located as well as the popular Grand Bazar about a 15-20 minute walk. Area has many restaurants for all budgets as well as shops and cafes.

Fell and Live the Culture. If you want to see and fell Istanbul this is the first place you should see. You can understand what is Ottoman in the place. Also you will find Byzantium and mix of the cultures. Lots of museums, shops, turkish food and classic turkish arts. Be careful about sticky dealers:)

The heart of historic Istanbul!. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district, a street away from the main thoroughfare.So much to see and do here.Aya Sophia, hippodrome,Blue Mosque, topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern all within a5 min walk of each other.The tram line runs right thru this district for the weary tourist, but we preferred walking.You do need very good walking shoes as the cobbled streets can be very hard on your feet!Walk up the little side roads leading off Divanyolu to find hidden treasures, wonderful restaurants and coffee shops, not to mention wonderful shopping ...carpets , shawls,souvenirs,etc etc etc...just love this city!
Excellent place to stay. Choose a hotel in this area and all the main attractions will be at a walking distance!

Frames of Byzantium. When you walk on the streets of Sultanahmet district, in front of you constantly changing a lot of different colorful frames. But sometimes - and this is so really amazing between tipical muslim pictures - a frames of a real old Bizantium float up!

Nice place to walk around and see the sights.. I loved walking around and watching the Blue Mosque and little cafes around. Food terrible though in that area, advice go uptown to Galleria area. Try eating sweet watermelon and roasted chestnuts.visit the Agia sophia church. Catch the tram to Eminonue and then a ferry to Princes Island, so easy to use.
Don's know where to look first. There are so many historic buildings in this part of the town that it is difficult to know where to go first. Lovely old buildings which are reasonable to visit

Location, Location.... Lots of hotels to choose from , suggest a reservation though , cab from airport then unpack and let the games begin..Safe to walk just about everywhere in the area, keep looking up , lots of restaurants and bars on tops of buildings that offer amazing views..Blue Mosque, Sofia, so much to see, lots of walking but take your time and rest when you feel like it..3 nights minimum stay, an amazing City and a Bucket List must see...
A shopper's paradise. There 's lots of shops to bargain for good prices on anything you like. Restaurants we visited were all excellent. Tasty food and excellent service
The area to stay in. Besides all the sites, it also has great variety of restaurants
Sultanahmed District. Great area for sightseeing! 6 pillars instead of 4 in the Mosque area

Sultanahmet. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district or old town if you like. It was only a short trip but, would recommend staying in this area to anyone who plans on going to Istanbul. there is just soooo much to see and it's all within walking distance. Every corner you turn is loaded with history

The happening part of town. This part of town has come on in leaps and bounds in the last 10 years, great for walking about and lots to see, but beware, dont change money here, go up to the Grand Bizzare you will get 5% more in any of the exchange offices with no commission
Awesome neighborhood.. Great restaurants, landmarks, and it felt very safe. We were able to fill three hole days within a one mile radius.

A wonderful cultural experience.. We stayed in the district at a hotel and we loved it. Apart from being right close to all the main historical attractions, the neighbourhood is a lively area with multiple cultural characteristics, which make your stay really and truly unforgettable!
worth it. Make sure you walk round this area to get a real feel for the city
Cosy. Very cosy area, can be done walking. Wear comfortable shoes cuz the stones used to build the street will hurt your feet.
Nice district for walk, many sights. There are a lot of "must see" sights in this area which are all in walking distance. For example Blue mosque, Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace and Basilica cisterns.

The historic centre became a tourist district. And it isn't is bad, but if you are looking for an "authentic" experience, not the place for it.I personally enjoyed my stay here immensely. Crowded. A lot of mediocre restaurant, you have to search for the gems, but what else is new.Can't say that the sellers really bothered me, but I was already experienced after my Morocco trip. Good place to stop for a first time visit.

A Great Area. This is one of the main areas to visit in Istanbul. There are several historical sites here including the Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome and Hagia Sophia, just to name a few. Also, there are plenty of restaurants to eat at, but look around before you choose one because the prices can be low to high.

Gorgeous district...but with more carpet dealers that attractions. Yes, there are few and even may be most major and amazing attratctions over there BUT you would find much more carpet dealers who are staying on your way all days long and so annoying that they are destroying the whole gorgeous atmosphere and image of this part of the city.There are few really good quality restaurants but not on the major street full with them but on aside streets. Don't be fooled with some discreet advertising and you can really find a gem.Restaurants are full with tourists but it does not always mean that the quality of food is bad.Try the ones behind Arasta Bazaar in the side streets.

wonderful. If you are lucky enough to stay in this area you are within walking distance of everything. You should see the Archeological Museum first, Topkapi Palace, The Cistern, Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque,
Pitoresque. Crowded but charming..Nice traditional restaurants and places
Exciting part of the city. We are interested in history and enjoyed the splendours of the Hagia Sofia, The Blue Mosque and the Basilika cistern.
Best food ever!. Lots of friendly people that offer you Apple tea and Turkish coffee. Try everything on the menus at all the restaurants - you will not be disappointed!

Prepare for the onslaught. Lots of tourist groups, more enjoyable if you can just strike out on your own. There isn't enough time to take it in on your own, but with a tour group you have to meet their timeframe. Don't be afraid to get lost!
Heart of Istanbul. All the really important monuments that are a must see in Istanbul are right here - Topkapi palace, blue mosque, cistern and hagia sofia

Central to a mass of sights. The area is packed with historic buildings, museums, a beautiful park, restaurants, shops and is a great starting point for all sorts of trips. There is a big tram stop and the start point of the Hop-on-Hop-off bus. The square itself always has something going on.
Wear good walking shoes. Since we stayed at the Hotel Amira, we walked throughout this area daily for a week. Go looking into side streets, many with terrific restaurants.
the centre of the world. our hotel was in the Sultanahmet , we had easy access to all sights. wondering through the cobbled streets, visiting cafes was the highlight of our trip

Great location. This ara is where you think of when you think Istanbul. In a small area you have the major attraction within walking distance. Except for the spice market and wharf which may take about an hour plus of walking. And not a fun walk but a boring walk along a regular street that has nothing fun to look at. If your staying in a hotel in this area then you are about 15 mins from any major attraction in many different directions.

Great are to stay while visiting Istanbul. This is one of the most historic areas with the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Bazaar, the Spice Market, and many other sites. Everything is an easy walk and there is a street trolley that is very tourist friendly. We felt safe walking around, even late at night.
Must. An "alive" area, places to see, places where to eat, good kebab, blue mosque, grand bazaar, st sophie

The Centre of the old city. Our hotel was 10 minutes walk from the Blue Mosque.We were allowed in without shoes & ladies wearing head scarves.There were people praying.We felt very honoured to be allowed into such a sacred place.A lot of the tourists were very noisy & quite disrepectful of the building they were in.
walk on cobbled streets. Wonderful area to walk and visit the historic sights and eat. Too many restaurants to choose from. Have fun.Quite safe
Sultanahment. fun to visit and have lunch. There are Ottoman baths, museums, cafes and restaurants. Try icecream in Mado, have "kofte" meatballs in Sultanahmet koftecisi.

Tourist swarm. The problem with the Sultanahmet District is not that it isn't beautiful but rather that it is. So beautiful and pleasant to walk around in fact that it is impossible to see or walk around because it feels like the whole world has just landed on top of you on a coach tour.For more on Istanbul and other city breaks visit Offwithorla.blogspot.com
Interesting walk. Interesting just to walk around and see the shops (rather kitsh but colourful) and note the high number of mosques.
Good for sightseeing. A good area to stay when visiting Istanbul as all the main attractions are within walking distance.
Lots of tourists. Amazing area but be prepared for crowds. Get a good map and spend a few days just wandering. Have tea at the cafe in the park beside the Topkapi Palace overlooking the Bosphorus.
Take a walk in the afternoon, evening. The light at sunset and the lights in the night might make for some really beautiful shots.
A must. Sultanahmet is such a charming place to visit. It's not big at all, so you can really enjoy your sightseeing on foot. I recommend entering Blue Mosque, Ayasofia and Basilica Cisterns.

The Sultanahmet District, Istanbul, Turkey. If you are first-time visitors to Turkey like us, just walking through the Sultanahmet District of Istanbul, you immediately feel you're walking through history. There is so much to see and so much going on in this part of Istanbul that I believe, reading about it before your visit or taking a well-guided walking tour would certainly be worth doing. Otherwise, taking a stroll on a lovely sunny day or warm evening just to enjoy the sights & sounds of this amazing city should be part of the visit to Istanbul. Just like many big cities, I kind of expect that Istanbul is no exception as far as locals endlessly offering wares for sale, trying to make a living. But my personal experience of always responding with a smile and a definite no if I'm not interested at all always resulted in a positive way for me. Given the chance, we certainly will visit Istanbul again.

Sultanhamet, the place to be.. If you are lucky enough to stay in this area you are within walking distance of everything. You should see the Archeological Museum first, Topkapi Palace, The Cistern, Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, Walk the Hippodrome, Small Aya Sophia is a jewell, see the Mosiacs from the old Bysantine Palace under the Bazaar near the Hippodrome, go to the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Market and more it's all so handy from Sultanhamet. Have a glass of wine in a restaurart that is built over the ruins of the old palace, so much to see and do. We didn't dislike anything, and the people are wonderful, so friendly and helpful. Ride the trams, eat in the Hafiz Mustafa apstry shop (established 1864) and more. Food also is great, plenty to choose from in this area.
Generic tourist site with hawkers. Great ancient sites, but the usual pestering hawkers. Food was suprisingly expensive and bad (how do you dry out braised lamb?) hotel resturaunt is the way to go
best area in the city. i just fell in love with this place, sophia, blue mosque, cistern, the bazaar - all those beautiful places within walking distance
Real Istanbul. Here you will feel like it is to be in Istanbul. A little hard to walk on the cobblestones streets, but worth it!
just wander the streets and take in the atmosphere. A lovely area for walking around, taking in the atmosphere and enjoying the skyline
Lots to see. History everywhere and lots of interesting places. Our only dislike would be the never ending invitations to buy something whenever you stop to look at a shop window.
Wonderful area.. Just walk around and take everything in. Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophie, Grand Bazaar ,Arista bazaar ,Topkapi Palace ( get there before 9 )
Walking in history. Great area to just walk around and explore, never felt unsafe day or night. Grab a coffee at a out door cafe and enjoy!

Wonderful area with exceptional architecture. The thing that unites everyone in this district, no matter what their religion, is the sound of the Muzzein which is ever present throughout the day. After a few days here we felt like locals. We got to know the area well and the tram system was cheap, efficient and easy to use - it was also extremely well patronised. We were delighted at the almost total absence of litter on the streets and dog mess. Istanbul seems to have a surfeit of cats all living peaceably with the inhabitants. There were dozens of restaurants and tea and coffee bars as well as street vendors and numerous hammams, museums and other places of historical interest. This side of the Golden Horn felt more intimate than across the bridge where we spent the last part of our stay in Istanbul.
Historical centre of old Istanbul. Easy to reach by tram from airport . Major sights all very near. Good restaurants and bars.

Great area!. this District is a great area to spend the day. Some if Istanbul's main attractions are a 5 minute walk from each other such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Grand Bazaar is a 5 min cab drive from there. There's a bunch of great stores and food all minutes from each other.
Lots of character. There are so many different types of shops that give the area a great character.
A place where you feel close to God. A must see as well. With its 6 pillars the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmed Mosque) is a mosque of its own

An adventure in itself!. Walking down the winding streets of the Sultanahment District can be a challenge looking for a particular hotel or restaurant but each street is full of character with shops or restaurants that will amaze and keep you entertained. Discovering the streets of this area is quite an adventure. On the very end of my visit to Istanbul which was primarily for work, I moved to the Sultanahmet District to experience the flavor and energy of this distinctly fascinating area.
Busy. Really old worldlie giving a real feel for life in Istabnbul. Very busy but a very nice atmophere to all the hustle and bustle

a life experience. Besides the historical wonderful sights, just looking around was a feast for the eyes. The people, the people, the people - the variety of clothes for the ladies, the colors, the smells, the smiles, the apple tea, the Ottoman style restaurant, the serving-of-icecream ceremony, the Dervish dance at night. A must return place!

Best place to stay. Although busy everything about Istanbul is here - apart from obvious sites go to the area by the station near the Galata Bridge and have a fish sandwich straight from the boats - amazing!

the centre of the universe. This is where most of the action is, for all age groups. We were staying further out in the Golden Horn, but spent most of our 3 day visit in & around Sultanahmet. The shopping is more relaxed than the manic Grand Bazaar & the restaurants are plentiful and excellent. We shall stay in this vicinity next time.

Bustling place.. A LOT of local fare, so highly recommend referring to your guidebook or simply explore to find restaurants your heart desires! Restaurants along the Bosphorous, are in my opinion, a waste of time. Maybe go there for a beer and chai, but not a meal. It's quite expensive and quality could have been better.
Quaint.. Plenty of eateries, safe happy and vibrant but it can close down earlyish.
worth the visit. A long queue to enter, apparently because it was Friday, but well worth the visit when you get inside
Sultanahmet. A lot of beautiful things to buy. Ceramics, jewellary and jewellary. Nice caffees and restaurants, and tourist sites nearby. However quite touristic and expensive area.
Great walking area. There's so much to see and walk around and buy stuff, eat and take photos of.
History lesson. A journey trough history, a mix of east and west. History concentrated in a short perimeter.
Blue Mosque. Thıs area ıs beautıful. there are so many mosques and beautıful buıldıngs ıt's just beautıful.

main historic sites. this area of the city is where the main historic sites are located. it's VERY touristy, so i actually prefer not to stay in this part of the city (although there are many reasonably priced small hotels). once you've spent all day touring the sites in sultanahment (aya sofya, blue mosque, topkapi palace, grand bazaar, etc.), you may want to escape. i suggest staying at a hotel or renting a flat in galata or cihangir. they're great neighborhoods next to taksim, which is the heart of the city for shopping, restaurants and clubs.
Nice place.. A nice place to walk around and was relatively safe late a night.
A great place to spend time.. We really enjoyed this district and all of its sights, sounds and history. Plan on walking and enjoying. The people are great!
The Buzzing n happening district. Only that it was raining now n then n a bit cold in April, otherwise loved the vibe n feel of Istanbul, specifically The Sultanahmet District:-)
bustling with life. this is what turkey is all about. Wonderful to see and every corner has a new discovery
So close to the hotel.... The whole district is interesting, with old walls and buildings left standing. Most hotels have rooftop restaurants and bars and the streets are clean and busy.

A life of its own!. Walk the ancient streets, feel the sense of community that still fills the "Old City", ignore the tourist junk and look for the doorways and alley ways for the real Turkey. Shopkeepers invite you to have tea, its just their way!
Tourist side. This is the tourist aread located in old European side, Sultanahmed

Rich in History. If you are going to be in the area for more than one day I recommend buying a Museum pass, 72 Turkish Lira, with it you get into, Hagia Sophia, Kariye Museum, Topkapi Palace, the Archaeological Museum, and the Museum of Islamic Culture. And you can skip past the ticket lines for all of those places with the pass!

A Must. A must when visiting Istanbul. You must visit the Blue Mosque, The Cistern Water Works; the Topkapi Palace and there are many restaurants in the area - all reasonably priced. If you need a hotel a must is the Amira.

Lots of Variety and Interesting Sights. You'll find many things to see and do with great shopping at the Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, etc. and many historical sights to tour. Very pleasant atmosphere with many excellent restaurants.
Amazing!. Great area full of nice rerstaurants, roof top bars, cafes and historical sights
Don't miss. Between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia, you must come here. The Hippodrome, Egyptian obelisk and Topkapi Palace are all here.

This is the heart of Istanbul!. Very picturesque, easily explored on foot, no tour guide required. Can use the tram to get here, especially if you just got off at the cruise ship terminal. The taxis will overcharge you to get here (10 Euros is way above the actual price) The obelisks aren't particularly impressive, blue mosque is overrated, but the Topkapı palace and hagia Sophia are well worth the visit.

Packed with attractions. From the Basilica to the Blue Mosque. From the Obelisques to the underground sewers. From the many restaurants to the tramway. There is so much to do here. Sultanahmet is at the heart of tourist Istanbul and cannot be missed
Pure history. Walking around the district we can see and breath centuries of history.

What a place. If you are visiting Istanbul, you must visit Sultanahmet district. It is vibrant and has a lot to offer (including the Grand Bazaar and the historical Cemberlitas Turkish Bath). Some of the historical monuments are also close by.
Beautiful, charming, easy to get around. Wonderful sites within walking distance. Charming stores, easy to get around, good restaurants.
Very animated. Lovely architecture, very animated, lot of restaurants
excellent. very nice large mosque nice place to walk and enjoy the green and the flowers and tulip and to sip tea or coffee

30th anniversary. The city is stunning - public transport is easy and cheap.A must is a genuine Turkish bath at the oldest one in the city - Suleymaniye Haman - it is also mixed which is nice if you visit as a couple. The high point was the boat trip on the Bosphorous - a really busy waterway and a great way to get a feel for the size and depth of Istanbul - we saw lots of dolphins as well.

So many things to see and explore. There are so many attraction there and you can never get bored. Make sure to where durable footwear as the street are uneven and if you could walk, you can see most attraction by walking.

never lost. First of all, the area is very clean, and safe.the roaming dogs are also clean and cute.lots of beautiful places to see, even on the corners. and also has great places to sit and enjoy the view or while waiting for others.the presence of the three significant historical buildings in the area create not only a stunning horizon but a great reference, a map, to follow your direction.
Bustling area. Lots to see and do.. Very busy here. Full with tourists and locals too. Plenty of interesting sites.
Walk but don't overnight. All of the key sites, walk and enjoy? Don't miss the cistern underground

You wanna buy a carpet?. Lovely area to stroll around but nearly every shop/restaurant has a saleman outside wanting you to buy. It can be aggravating, particularly when they thrust a menu in your face EVEN after you tell them that you have eaten already! Need a thick skin!
great area. wonderful area with all those hystorical sites and nice cafes.great atmosphere.you can hang out there for hours non stop!

The Old City. Superb monuments and great street life. Tulip display on while I was there. Lovely! Safe to walk around but you will get hassled and need to be polite but firm to shake people off. If you do succumb be prepared to be ripped off. The remoter areas are being revived and some of the conversions of the old wooden houses are great when you get off the main drag. Worth walking round beyond the obvious places.

Old town charm. Crowded, but easy to get around. The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia are a must view. Be careful of pickpockets. A companion had their wallet picked when he tried to help a shoe shine guy who 'dropped' his brush 'accidentally'. Beware of hawkers who will befriend you and try and sell you anything. They are VERY persuasive! Bargain down to about 60% of asked value.

Must see spots, with everyone else. The historic district is a must see in Istanbul- the mosques and surrounding neighborhood are teeming with stories and sights. Only one catch - everyone, that is every tourist in Turkey will be there too so try to catch off-peak times for less crowds and more time for reflection.

Center of old Istanbul. The Sultanahmet District is the center of old Istanbul where former churches and mosques, museums, old wooden buildings, new and remodeled houses, villas and a large number of hotels, countless shops and local bazaars are located. Don't miss to visit at least one of the interesting cisterns (city water reservoirs), the former largest church of Christiandom-the mosaic-filled Byzantine Church of Constantinople built more than a thousand years before the Seville Cathedral and now serves as a museum in secularized Turkey-called the Hagia Sophia (Aya Sofya), the famous Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet mosque), Topkapi Museum and Grand Bazaar.

Walking solo around istanbul. Can at first be daunting but after a couple of days it's easy to feel like a local. Stick to the tram lines at night time but be sure to explore the laneways and fooderies and stop to have chai in the lane ways at Hodjapasha area during the day. (Not too far from Spice Bazaar) Sit and drink tea and watch the locals go about their business. The vendors will soon know if you're up for a chat or happy to sit and watch the world go by.
A treat for the eye. Just standing watching so many diffrent people You can not say how fantastic the Blue Mosque is and all around it.

Picturesque and historic. PLUS - architecture and history
MINUS - annoying street urchins and the incessant "call to prayer"

Place to live for express trip to Istanbul. This is the place where you would feel comfortable to stay if you like to walk and be close to the historical part. Many restaurants are here and all historical places can be reached by walking.
Great dining place!. Loved the area. Great food and vibe. Lots of tourists. Not the best place to meet locals.

Disneyland of Istanbul, not much authenticity. It has all the grand monuments, but appart from that, it's definitely lacking in vibe and authenticity. Carpet sellers, tour guides, other tourists, average restaurants catering to tourists and a lot of hotels. That's it. I felt Sultanahmet as an area was an unfortunate must when visiting, for example, marvellous Hagia Sophia or beautiful Topkapi palace. I gladly explored other, more "real" parts of Istanbul the rest of my time (Kumpaki, Balat, Ortaköy...). For example Beyoglu on the other side of the Golden Horn had a much more "old town"-vibe to it than this place I could "honour" with the title "the Disneyland of Istanbul".

Oriental atmosphere, architectural aesthetic.... The area is full of life during day time. Several hotels, restaurants and cafes are located there. It is nice to walk and safe even at night. Very close to all the famous sights.

Very atmospheric, despite restoration work. Walking in the twilight and evening through this area one feels very safe and relaxed (which is in fact the case all over Istanbul). There is a lot of restoration work going on (very good) so the atmosphere is somewhat affected, but you still feel the age and beauty, the magic and excitement of this vast city.

Very nice, full of history!. A lot of historical places. If you want a fair restaurant, don't take the ones on the main road. Try the secondaries alleys.Don't buy from the people on the street!!!!!!!!
Great place for spring escape. this April was relatively cold; but that's great time for city walking tours. City was full of tulips gardens. Really great feeling for Eastern time

Heart of Istanbul. The Sultanahmet district is where all the main attractions are- all well within walking distance. The Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Hippodrome area with the obelisks, Topkapi palace, Basilica Cistern and museums are within a block or two. The Egyptian/Spice market is about a10 minute walk from the Grand Bazaar down an alley downtoward the pier. Entry to the Blue Mosque is free, but be aware that you must be modestly dressed. Shoes must be removed before entrance (a plastic bag is provided) and ladies must have a head scarf and no sleeveless tops or shorts are tolerated. They will provide coverage if necessary. There are fees for all the other sights; we were on a tour so luckily we didn't have to deal with that,but all were worth it. Grand BazaarLoved this! But, you must Bargain, And Bargain hard. Start at half the asking price and slowly advance to what you feel it's worth. If you're not satisfied with one vendor, just move on to the .next. The people everywhere we went were so friendly, helpful and courteous. Bosphorus tourCheck the weather before booking this one. We went in late May and it was 40 degrees with 30 mph winds. I'm sure it would've been much more enjoyable on a clear, sunny day, because there are many beautiful and interesting sights to see. When walking around the Hippodrome/Mosque areas, you will be approached by someone asking if you need a tour, directions , pictures taken etc. Be aware, they are salesmen and after they take a pix or 2, they want to take you to their uncle's carpet shop.  FoodLoved the food in Turkey, but, must admit we did'nt always know what that great tasting meat on the spit really was! Tasted great and we never got sick ever! Wear sneakers or very comfortable shoes as there are many cobblestone streets and hills to deal with. You can get anywhere you need to by the trams that run thru the city to every imaginable place for 1.75 TL. We only changed money to get small bills for the trams. Every shop we went to accepted USD without a problem.  The street vendors are amazing! They sell everything from "elastic" ice cream" with a show to pretzels, grilled corn on the cob, chestnuts and even grilled fish. Loved Istanbul! People are so friendly, helpful and courteous everywhere. 2nd time visitor to Turkey- not our last! Happy to answer questions.

Quaint and safe. As a female travelling alone, I did not feel unsafe here, even at night, unlike other parts of Istanbul. I walked at night coming from restaurants or events I attended. Well lit, tourists. But the area is charming, and the shops are nice.
What a buzz. Very busy little area - lovely traders and very eash to get around
History at it's best. You will need days to truly experience, but can be done in a day
Its simply great... One feels to be here forever.... everythng here is beauty, serenity and mesmerieing.... Especially at night, its unbelievable...!
Lots to do and see.. Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cisterns, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Tokapi Place and the list goes on.

An atmospheric walk. Hopefully you'll visit the district on a sunny day and with a camera in hand. The architecture, the shops, the spring atmosphere, turned our visit to Sultanahmet into the highlight of our vacation.
Nice. Very special places to know the ancient people of Turkey

Atmosheric and exotic. Great place to walk around and see wonderful buildings. Spacious square at present being renovated which will be fabulous when finished. No beggars or hustlers and felt safe everywhere, even in the back streets. Lots of restaurants, choose ones with a roof terrace for the views.

Same as Istanbul Historic. You have to go if you have money and time to do so. Beautiful and interesting. Read books by Orhan Pamuk and/or John Freely on Memories of Istanbul and Strolling Through Istanbul

Istanbul Visit. A very clean, organized and efficient historic city with good Public transportation. A city tour by tour bus proved to be very interesting. Clean restroom facilities (paid). Hard to avoid merchants disguised as helpful tour guides!
Refreshing spring vacation. Nice unusual area with nice small family-run hotels and delicious traditional food. And great historic sites of course!
the best place to be in Istanbul. Everything a traveler needs is with close proximity, The neighborhood atmosphere lefts your spirit.

Loved the area. Good collection of resturants and antique shops. Grand bazar is also in this area,, recommendation is to visit Ayasopia, Sultan Ahmet mosque, and grand bazar in Beyazit area in one trip.

Lots to See. Lots to see around here - Hagia Sofia, Blue (Sultanahmet) mosque, Hippodrome and columns, Basillica Cisterns, Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum, Mosaic Museum. You could probably spend your entire holiday and never leave Sultanahmet.
A must see. Love the place. You can just sit there and observe the tourists moving around.

Just wander around. It doesn't matter much where you go in this part of town it chuck full of hotels, restaurants, shops interesting sights and more for tourists. I do recommend that you let yourself be conned into a carpet shop just to ask what gives with Turkish carpets. Watch the people, they are facinating.

Great area to walk around. Besides the obvious (Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia), the whole area is beautiful, it is really worth it spending some time walking around all the small streets. There are a lot of nice restaurants, stores and hotels. We had a Kebab from a cart on the street that was great.
The Amazing Heart of Instanbul. Spend the extra money to stay in this district so you can walk to all the amazing sites, eat at the delicious restaurants and visit all the wonderful stores!!
Koefte. In the area you may find the best Koefte Restaurants in Istanbul. Most of the times you will recognize them by the que of people waiting to enter the restaurants...
Old Istanbul. Interesting palace and harem; there is an audio guide to assist you in seeing the various symbols and gems in this museum.

All the history in one area. If you travel to the area you can count on all of the major sights being within walking distance. Be prepared to pay money for each attraction. It is easily accessed by tram
Nice place. It is interesting to fill today and old-old places at the same plase.
Expensive place. 50% out of 6000 shops are selling jewellry and rest selling clothes. You can get all cheaper from anywhere else

the smell of the past. It's not a joke .. it really does smell different than any other place in Istanbul
It's a must visit when in Istanbul
Great Spot. Thsi location has it all a must place toc hang out and walk about.

Colourful sights. The Grand Bazaar is fun but overrated and the wares on offer are not good quality by and large. However it is a wonderful and colourful sight! We walked from the Grand Bazaar to the Egyptian Spice Market - the colours and smells in this market were amazing! And the route there takes you through a shopping area favoured by local people.
amazing. the touristic area of Istanbul. If you go there, first place to visit.
Lots of sights to see. Look at the grand bazaar - but buy in shops near there for 1/3 of the price.

Mosques, cats, cafes and shopping - what more could you want?. Well - not everyone would appreciate the cats, but they are very much in evidence, and well-fed. The area is awash with mosques (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque) and the Grand Bazaar is worth a visit - if maddeningly crowded. Some good restaurants near the Cisterns.
Happy place. Good restaurants...buzzing streets.....happy ambience

Loved just walking around and looking at the residents of the area. I really enjoyed just walking around this old area of town, looking at the little barber shops, restaurants everywhere, regular people doing their daily activities along with bunch of tourists walking around, loved it.

Bussling tourist centre. Carpet, pottery and Turkish delight sellers. The latter assuredly fat and calorie free!!! Not really hassling too much, though persistent. Fun area. Restaurants best avoided - take hotel recommendations
Prices ridiculous. Lots of great historic sites, which you must see, but the food, service, and prices are all horrible as a general rule in Sultanahmet
Wonderful. It is much quieter than Taksim square so the sleep quality is much better.
Great architecture. Easy to get around, lots of buildings, monuments, and parks to see. Lots of amazing mosques!

Compact, vibrant, exotic, frustrating but a worthwhile experience!. This is where it all happens and is the centre of the main attractions. Bustling with restaurants and cafes and full of carpet sellers who will entice you into their shops with a cup of tea!

Very beautiful and clean. All the touristic areas are very clean and well take care, there are beautiful flowers, and is very nice to walk around.
The prices are not market or even if market you mus ask for a lower one, they are very high for the tourists but we can get a 20% to 40% discount if you bargain the price down
Great area. A lovely area comprising many of the must see sites for visitors to Istanbul.

Busy, confusing and fun.. I stayed in Sultanahmet and found it very busy, confusing at first but enormous fun. There is loads to see and do, if you don't mind it being a bit hilly, Quirky back street bars and eateries. Just put your guidebook away and wander as I did. Take in the atmosphere!

Historical place in 1 area. There's Sultanahmet Mosque (famous as Blue Mosque), the Hippodrome, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and many more. Those sites all just in walking distance one place next to another. History lovers must spend more time here, where in my case we spent about 4 hours due to the tour schedule, and I feel it's not enough.
Story of the Sultans. There is so much of this great complex still in existence it really tells the story of the life of the Sultans.

Very touristy but worth a walk around. An enjoyable walk around this historical area with its mosques, museums and cobbled streets. The restaurants vary greatly in price and quality. Worth a visit is the Sultanahmet Koftecisi. Simple but tasty and great value.
A very nice place. A very nice area af Istanbul. Lots of things to see
Touristy but full of sites. Amazing how much you can see in such a small area. Many of the restaurants and shops are pricey and touristy, but there are some great gems to be found.
Excellent spot. A wonderful historical area in istanbul where Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, cisterns, obelisks, museums etc. are side by side! The first place must be visited in this city.
Quaint streets and lots of restaurants. We stayed in Hotel Daphne in this area. It is very close to all historical attractions. We walked every where and lots of interesting areas to explore.
Full of interesting things to see. Very noisy but it gives you a feeling of the old ambience of Istanbul!
Mix of authentic Istanbul and some hotels/restaurants too. I liked staying here and enjoyed the ambiance. There are some affordable restaurants and a very good internet cafe.
Best location for exploring Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the place to stay to explore Istanbul. It is ideally located near the main sites and has a great selection of bars and restaurants.

Incredible. See the basic hotel review for comments on Sultanahmet. Suffice it to say that there are many world heritage sites within a five minute walk from one another. Serious viewing of what's available could take up your entire vacation.
You must spend time here.... Our hotel was here and we spent a lot of time eating and exploring, lots of cute cafes and rooftop restaurants. very hilly though so bring comfy shoes!
HISTORY EVERYWHERE. Liked how much history this small area carries and how well the places are maintained; disliked the incredible numbers of tourists and the touts.
Heart of historical istanbul. I stayed in Sultanahmet district while on my visit to Istanbul with my family. All the top attractions are nearby and within walking distance.
chock-full of interesying places to see.. Very cheerful environment. Attractions are close to one another and it's easy to get around on your own.
The best area to get the most from Istanbul. Good places to eat and there are some lovely rooftop bars to drink in too. This is where to go to see the old city.

Love this Place, Just try and avoid the crowds!. What an incredible place to immerse yourself in Turkish culture and sights. We stayed in the area for 3 days which was plenty to see most sights and get out to a less hectic part of Turkey. All I can suggest as it can get CRAZY busy is get up early to avoid the queues, and don't get irritated or rude with some of the hassle you'll get from the local traders and hawkers, just smile big, say thank you and walk away if you're not interested :-)
Beautiful Area of an amazing City. Very easy to get around. By an Akbil card (like London's Oyster card) from the kiosk and away you go. Csan be used on tram, bus, public ferry and cable car at Eyup.
Take a walk here and you've seen half Istanbul. Almost all the historical and local heritage is situated on this district, a must visit!
Best place. great place to stay! Mosques aren't to loud and don't bother you either. Great food. Great area! A must!
excellent. great place to be, everything is closed and you enjoy every moment in it!

Absorb the Flavours. This area has it all from carpet sellers and cheap kebabs to the best of fine dining. Very easy to get around and all of the hop on/off buses start and finish here. Don't miss it and take you time to suck it all in. Don't get lost in the markets!!!

Great Tour with She Tous. Tour was excellent and very narrative including lunch but the tour guides Fatih and Yahya had attitude problem. Being older couple and new to the city we missed our group twice for 15 munites the guides yelled we will leave you alone and go back to yr hotel of yr own.
A well traveled and worthwhile visit to this area. The blue mosque is nice but just big and kind of bland. However the Topkopi Palace was great.

Old Istanbul - Walkable, Historic, Religiously-Significant and Wonderfilled. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Tokapi Palace, Grand Bizarre, a luxurious 4Seasons Hotel that used to be a Turkish Prison - smoking a hooka - La Luna restaurant - all highly recommended
So much to see.. All sights are in a compact area which is easy to walk around.

Great Location for Istanbul attractions. We stayed around the corner from the Blue Mosque. The museums were nearby and all the attractions were walking distance. The main road had a tram and McDonalds, Burger King and Starbucks were on the same street. There were also several other reasonably priced places to eat. Overall a very clean area!

Can I go back.......please!. That says it all. Sights, sounds and smells!!!! Walking and seeing all the colours, lovely food and hearing the sounds of Istanbul will stir your mind for weeks there after.

This area is a regular spot for locals as well. This area is rich with history, in minutes one can be transported from one milenia to another one. Different than other historical centers of tourist attractions in most other parts of the world, locals also hang around this area

do you reallly want a carpet?. you should decide this and have your refusal spiel ready to go! If you DO want a carpet however...or almost anything else for that matter then this is the place! Streets laden with monuments, souvenir stores, street vendors selling everything from grilled corn to pomegranate juice and loads of casual restaurants. Everything is within walking distance so I personally found that the walking tours on offer for 60Euro were unnecessary as everything worth seeing in the Sultanehmet District is literally within a stone's throw of eachother! There is no entry fee for the blue Mosque but try to time your visit if possible so it does not coincide with prayer as we were swiftly ushered out almost as soon as we walked in. A MUST see! Shoes off, women cover your arms.

Say you live here!. Great area to stay in. Everything you need. Tourist-friendly. Only thing is anyone comes up to you on street and asks where you're from say you live in Istanbul now and keep walking. Every carpet salesmen in town stopped me to make small talk before inviting me to his carpet shop. Not necessarily a bad thing, but it can take away all your free time!!!

so much too see. we went by tram as first day tax took like 1 hour from our hotel and now we drove to end for tram and for $1 we went by tram number 1 , within 15 minutes
must do sultanahmet & grand bazaar
Tourist Trap. Overpriced poor quality eating out - take the trouble to walk a few hundred metres to eat where locals eat to get a much better experience.

So much to see in such a small area. A great walking neighborhood where you can see amazing sites and eat some great food. We loved to just hang out in the hippodrome and enjoy the atmosphere and the towering mosques around us.
Old Istanbul. You can really get a feel for the old style charm of Turkey.

Sultanahmet District. Lots to do and see. Most places take credit cards but take Turkish Lira which you can exchange at numerous money changing locations (shop for the best rate and confirm up front if there is a commission and if so, how much).
best location to stay. So much to do and see! everything you want is within walking distance and most things are within five minutes!

Cafes. Service was slow to non existent near the Blue Mosque and one waiter tried to ask 100 TL for a coffee and Iced Tea and then pretended he was joking when I immediately queried it. I didn't get a very good feeling from those cafes and eating places nearer to the main tourist traps.
Great place for a walk!. It's wonderful to walk these old streets and see the remnants of old Constantinople. Just beware of pickpockets and overly aggressive salesmen. Turkesh food is wonderful!

Cosy nice place,but not as exceptional as expected. If you take the upper parts of Sultanahmet District (including Agia Sofia,Topkapi and The Gran Bazar) you will be impressed and that's how we felt,it was just impressive and huge. A big historic background and breathtaking views.The lower part of the district instead,was still nice,but nothing different than other parts of Istanbul. A lot of kebabs and restaurants for the turists,busy streets,but still,I was not that impressed.Short: upper part fantastic, 5/5 , low part (close to the sea) 3/5
Stayed in the old city. Fun to experience and learned a great deal. Even in off season ( March) traffic is horrendous. Don't ever think of driving . Mass transit better or cabs.

Easy to Walk Around. We loved walking around looking at the sights. Of course, you'll be approached asking where you are from, if you'd like to buy carpet, leather, etc. Just politely refuse, and they'll go away. Much less hassle than in Egypt!

Great atmosphere. This area has great atmosphere. The restaurants are all very good with fabulous ambience and wonderful views of the city. A lot of the tours leave from this area and we found that it was very central and easy to catch trams to other parts of the city from here. The shops were also cheap compared to the touristy grand bazaar!

Carefull for what you pay!. Its a great and historical place. Nice shopping places where you can find rugs, carpets, silver, hubble bubble's and etc. However if you are a tourist which looks realy interested in what they're looking at then there is a chance you'll pay for somthing you get more then its normal value.The poeple there will try their best to sell you stuff...You need to have great bargaining skills..If you dont...just pretend you have :)If you're interested in something that hasnt got a price tag on it..chances are..the price you'll get for it will be a lot...Lets say they said its 20 dollars or 10 euros..say you will only give 2-3 euros..If he says no...walk out..If it is something with a price close to that...you will be stopped before you leave and will be given a new price...something like 5 euro..if you want to push it...say 3 again :) If you think thats fine..go for 4 euros which will probably be excepted. There you go... you have a spare 6 euros in your pocket...Apart from what I said above...great place to see historical buildings and mosques, eat good meals and buy brilliant souvenirs.

Amazing!. I'm just impressed with Istanbul in general, the constructions have so much history that is amazing to see them standing till the present days. The whole Sultanahmet District, is breathtaking.

Can't get any more historic than this.. Not only are the top sites of Istanbul here, but if you take the time to wander around the back streets you can see for yourself how the locals live, work and eat.

Best place to stay. Sultanahmet and Sirkeci areas are the best to stay for visitors liking to meet the traditional Istanbul and having all the important historical buildings at a walking distance. Avoid any restaurant inviting you to go in (most of them) and look for a Lokanta.

Interesting but full of tourist traps. Very interesting to wonder around but is full of tourists and therefore people who like to take advantage of tourists. The hawkers constantly pestering you to buy from their shops or eat at their restaurants can get annoying. However, if you've never been you should stay here to be near the sites which you must visit.
beautiful. i love visiting the old shops and enjoy walking around for hours. I really love old buildings and the beauiful bosphourus seas
A world of the old and new-appealing mixture. Best area to stay if you want real Turkish cultural and historical experience
back to the past. very nice area with the blue mosque and its tile andalusian "i think" decoration..
Sultanahmet. Really interesting area. Loads to see. Long weekend was too short.
Buzzing!. Very lively area, good for peoplewatching. Great view of the old town and it's major attractions, a nice place to sit, visit one of the many restaurants or bars and enjoy.
Everyone is selling something.. The merchants are out there trying to get your business. Be kind.

Historical treasure of several empires in one place. This is a national treasure, you'll see the history of 3 empires in one place, not to mention the lovely shops and delicious restaurants all around.
Bustling and friendly. Liked all of it - apart from street sellers could be quite annoying after the 3rd or 4th time.

Full of history. Liked the concentration of history, narrow streets mixed with modern open spaces and transport, and the food. The eager touts trying to get us to visit their businesses 'just round the corner' got tedious by day 5, though - but they got the hint when I respectfully but firmly said we're not interested.

Historic vibrant area of Istanbul. A really good mix of the very ancient and modern. The metro stops at Sultanhamet and gives you access to all the top sites as well as a good mix of ace family restaurants and bars.

It's one of the mostly visited area. Sulatnahmet district is one of the mostly visited by tourists places due to the location of Sultanahment Mosque, Ayasofya mosque, Topkapi palace, Hippordrome and many other monuments and old architecture
Sultanahmet District not to be missed. Don't take it personally when restaurant owners and shop keepers don't take no for an answer. Enjoy the banter and politely keep walking.
brilliant location!. Gorgeous and lively and so so historical. This district is something out of history books.
Old City with beautiful scenery. i love staying at this old city, the place are great with all the attraction within walking distance, like spice & grand bazaar, Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque many others
Picturesque. Probably the best part of Istambul. Don't forget your camera. Impressive!

Sultanahmet District. Liked the sheer diversity from the world heritage attractions to the small side streets. Everywhere you went there was something of interest. The friendliness of the people.
Disliked - nothing to dislike

Stay Here!!. Tons of boutique hotels and neat sidewalk cafes. Expect a small room, but the stay was nice and so much to see within a short walking distance. Breakfast was included in all hotels I looked into.
Charm. It has definitely charm of a district in which you have loving embrace of 2 kinds of cultures - western, modern one and eastern, magical and enigmatic.

A Must See. This is the area that holds the Hagia Sophia - the Byzantine Empire's proudest jewel, the Blue Mosque,The Byzantine Cistern
and the amazing Topkapi Palace where the sultan's used to rule.
The area put's Turkey's,The Ottoman Empire's and The Byzantine Empire's history in a vivid and beautiful context.

The place to be for sites. Most of the history that Istanbul as to offer lies within the Sultanahmet District. There is also the Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar and many other attractions in the area all close by within walking distance to eachother.

Great place to be.... If you are into history then you'll understand how amazing it is to be standing in the same place where Alexander the Great once walked himself. Chelopatra was here along with many other world conquerors. It's amazing. This is the crib of civilization and being here is unbelievable. The District itself is very nice, well kept, very clean and clearly marked with signs and directions. My main recommendation is: be ware of the restaurants in this area though. The food is expensive and people will pretend they do not speak english and put a ton of stuff in your plate (most places are set as buffet style) and you'll end up with a huge bill. This is an expensive place to buy souvenirs. If you want to buy pewter plates or artifacts it's best to do it OUTSIDE of the spice market. The little tents outside the market have very affordable and good quality items. The Sultanahment District is a MUST. Don't even think about missing it. Go to the Blue Moque, Hagia Sophia, the Hippodrome and Topkapi Palace during the day and enjoy the restaurants, the bars and the view at night.

All in one place. So many of the ancient sites are in this area, along with great food, shopping and there is often something going on in the park between Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque. Its easy to get caught up in the vibrant energy here.
Must See!. Such Beauty inside and outside of the many historic buildings. Can walk from Niles Hotel, or catch the Light Rail.

soak up the cultural feel of Istanbul. It was lovely to walk around the streets taking in the smells, sights and sounds of istanbul. the market and bazaars were fantastic with lots of bargains on offer. Find the ice-cream man and let him show you his tricks !

Must do while in Istanbul. Very nice place to take a stroll and take in all the sites. So much history here. Haggia Sofia and Blue Mosque are stunning in the evening. Only downfall are the hoards of carpet/book salesmen looming in the Hippodrome area. They can be a little much.

Sultanahmet, ancient and exotic. This is one of the major historical tourism sites in the world. You have the Aya Sophia, Basilica Cistern, and Blue Mosque here and more. It is a lot of walking on stone roads and walkways so wear comfy old shoes as they may be too dusty to take home with you. Out of respect for the mosques females should wear the headscarf. Shoes are removed and often bags are provided. Try to stop in for a snack or drink at the Four Seasons (pricey) but very nice.
Magic square. I liked everything.Racetrack,Blue mosque and Hagia Sophia and especially undegraund cisterns
Lots of interesting things to see. Like everything except the extremely aggressive rug touts.
History in motion. Fun, different from anything western. The gender segregation is very uncomfortable. Loved all the attractions in this area, it is a small area and therefore easy to negotiate.

Walk and wonder, but so much better with lots of info. I use wikipedia as I walk around to at least skim the surface of the astounding range of historical linkages to so many buildings and monuments. Give yourself a good day of leaisurely strolling about this area in addition to the specific tours of palaces and mosques.
Tourism area. It is a nice area to walk around, prepared to tourism, plenty of hotels. The most importants highlights are here. It is well connected by tram,
Friendly, fun, full of life.. Every tourist needs to stay here. Central to all must-sees in Istanbul, lots of good places to eat, absolutely the place to stay.
Sultnahmet Meydanı. A huge open place. Hagia Sophia and Sultanahmet Mosqe is in this place. There are colums wich are dating back the byzantin times.
Old city. This is where the Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace abnd the Blue Mosque are located. The Grand Bazar and Spice Market are walking distance.

The area of Sultanahmet is magic. The entire area is easily accessible and well connected by public transport (tram line T1) is well maintained and quiet. The Blue Mosque is remarkable. It is amazing and in addition to being free entry is also possible to take pictures (without flash).Who has trouble staying barefoot is better that they are taken away, the shoes are absolutely banned!!!

Great wander. If you want to walk arond Sultanahmet without people... do it at 3 am.. if you don't want to walk around the wee hours, then, do it in the afternoon. Groups and guided tours go mainly during the morning, so to avoid crowds try to do in afternoon/evening. Even though, you will ALWAYS find people around and no wonder, it´s a great place to be!!!

Magnificent buildings amidst rich history. We found the district to be very inviting and full of varied shops. The major sights like the Blue Mosque, Tokapi Palace and Hagia Sophia were truly outstanding structures. The vendors and shop workers were all extremely friendly and hospitable. We had no issues with safety and security.
All you want is here. Great place to find anything you want. Central to all the sites and public transport for trains, ferries,
I like very much. It is the best one. Very beautiful. I like very much. It is the best one. Very beautiful
Tumult. Crazy, busy area, near the Grand Bazaar and Blue Mosque. Massive crowds, but we expected it. Do it once, but that's enough
Historic Centre Superb. Having Topkapi, Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque within a short distance of each other is knocking most of the world for six - bit unfair of them really.
so close. We were so lucky to be able to walk everywhere,and be close to shops restaurants and all the main sites.

Amazing place.... Sultanehmet is such a beautiful place with amazing history, buildings and sights. The old Mosques architecture and designs are just fantastic! Plenty of museums, eateries and artefacts to see! Shopping in the grande bazaar is just great, even though the sales people can be annoying and almost force you to buy! The spice bazar is brilliant, filled with spices, herbs, fresh honey, scents, turkish delights and lots more! You can always get some good deals from these places!Overall great place!
if you like pottering. very clean lots to see and do, it is slghtly hilly so wear good and comfotabe shoes but there is much to see in a small space.
history site. The area is great. Be careful with taxi drivers- they love ripping off visitors
Best place to be stay and visit///. If you like to see and visited palaces,nuseums,Hogia sophia,Blue Mosque and cıstern this is the area to be...

Bustling with life!. This area is the Old Istanbul. Everywhere you turn, there are people, music, food sellers, trams running up and down the street, shop sellers of every item imaginable! I recommend having at least one "free day" to spend wandering this area. You will not regret it!
Excellent Area. Excellent Area, for browsing and shopping for presents
Exploring the Old Town. Great area to just wander around - something interesting on every street and every turn.

the ottman era is there. enjpy everywhere in this district, blue mosque, hagia sophia, egyption citadel, and topkabi saray (home of ottman empire).
inside it find allah passengers legacies from nouh to muhammed
find the 3rd biggest diamond and know its very interesting story
dirty. nothing special-anarcy everywhere , not enough sings for the monuments
Bustling. Yes, it's very touristy, but still a great place to base yourself as it's so near all the sights.

Sultanahmet. An area which has many historical attractions including the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, the Archaeological Museum and the Basilica Cistern. And the Topkapi Palace. Need atleast two days to do a thorough visit
Typical Old Time City. It is definitely the heart of Old Istanbul with all the history of churches and mosques.

look for a hotel in this place. a lot of souvenirs, nice caffes and main tourists attractions, Great place to stroll before\after lunch. If you only have a couple days in Istanbul, combine the whole Sultanahmet with Topkapi
Good and the bad!. Great shopping, amazing sights, but very dirty. And be warned: the shopkeepers are relentless. Just be prepared for it and laugh along the way, which is what we did.
Great area to stroll. Liked Topkapi Palace Harem, Aya Sophia, Spice Bazaar and Hamams in the area but not the really old one... beautiful but not a good scrub/massage
The old city is charming. The old city is charming, and worth visiting. I wouldn't stay there, find the neighbourhood too touristic, but a visit is a must do.

...so interesting. The history, and the feeling of being somewhere slightly exotic. The number of unwanted advances by people wanting to sell you something is slighly annoying. You need to be firm and brush them off or ignore them

Very Convenient for Tourists; almost all sites a short walk away. In both my visits to Istanbul, I have stayed in the Sultanahmet district. All major sites are only a small walk away. I love walking along the tram line from, say, Sultanahment station, all the way to the Galata Bridge. This area is full of shops, restaurants and cafes. This part of the city has kept the old beautiful architecture and is full of tourists. This also means the are is safe. I traveled alone and felt completely safe walking around the streets at almost midnight. ( I am a 27 year old female)
Good ambience. Good ambience, historic and easy to navigate in. Good restaurents, historic hamam.

Superb area. We stayed in this area, so much to see and so much to do. Clean, people helpful and buildings in a good state of repair. I expected this area to be a little run down as it is so old and historic. This was not the case. Safe area with friendly people.

The entire district is a must see. This is THEE place to first visit Istanbul. Major sites plus the Grand Bazaar are located here. You can walk for hours on end and be always fascinated by the surroundings,. As I have already left reviews for various sites and our guide service, Istanbul Daily City Tours, I will necessarily be brief here. Word of caution - the Grand Bazaar is incredibly huge, fascinating and confusing. Try using a guide or expect to get lost somewhere in this site. Also, we were not shopping for anything in particular and so the great number of jewelry, Turkish chotchkies etc. were not of much interest. The site was. We enjoyed the Spice market more for what it had to offer especially Turkish Delights.
Many monuments within walking distance. We stayed here, but found it too touristy. There are some really terrible restaurants in the area.
Great area for first time visitors. A great location, close to all there is to see in Istanbul, good transport links to the rest of Istanbul. Some of the best restaurants in the city.
Touristy, but fun.. A little bit like Disneyland Istanbul, but the big stuff is here. Walk down the hill from the grand bizaar to see the real istanbul.
Great Palace but very busy. The history is great but very crowded even in February
Historical & Fun. Good food, great sites, fun to haggle with the shop keepers.

Some stunning architecture. This World Heritage area has to be one of the tope places to visitbin Istanbul. Yes it is touristy and yes it does not give much of a flavour of 'real' Istanbul. But the architecture is stunning - both by day and by night
Magic. Put some Loreena McKennitt music on your iPod and walk around this district at night when the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia are all lighted up. It's magic!

Wonderful - Very worth it. I won't repeat what a lot of the other reviews are saying. Just a couple tips.TIP: If you are trying to save money, bring food with you. Food in this district is more expensive and not as good as the rest of the city. Bring lunch with you and have a picnic on the Hippodrome or in front of the Blue Mosque.TIP: This place is ripe with people pulling you into their carpet / leather / jewelry / ... shops. Most will strike up a conversation, and then proceed to take you to look at their wares. Bought a fantastic leather jacket this way, and the experience is really wonderful. Tea and chatted up all done so very smoothly. Sales people back home could really learn from these people! Just as a heads up. In front of the Blue Mosque is especially heavy with them.
Sultanahmet is one of the most amazing historical sites ever. They say there are places you need to visit once in your life time...For Sultanahmet and Istanbul.... This is not enough.
Allow 2 full days minimum. Every turn produces ambience - shops to sniff around, restaurants that take you on the journey of a very fresh, caring cuisine and fun experiences in the Bathhouses/Spas

Enjoyable area to browse around .... Plenty to see and experience. For a short trip you really won't need to leave the district. Sultanahmet. Something that you will not find in another country
Buzzing. This district was buzzing superb to have a walk around any time of day especially at night city feels and looks amazing
Cultural heaven!. Cisterns, The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, gardens, Archeological Museum (an absolute must!), this area is a walking Encyclopedia of the Roman, Greek, Ottoman Empire.

Wonderful Attraction. We had a great time. Got to see the swirling Darvy dancers on the street and plenty of shops and resturants and even music playing in the streets. So many people out walking around; it was the best experience ever!

Best Place In Istanbul. Everything is there, everywhere you walk there is something to do or to look at, I could have spent days there.

take pictures. one memory card is not enough for imaging it.
i ate at a restaurant near it .. it has a delicious cuisine,
Beautiful...old world charm.. Such a charming neighborhood, great pedestrian walking, lots of shops and restaurants, beautiful cobblestone roads....and tons of ambiance!

Sultanahmet - Yuz deyuz. A very vibrant and colourful district, full of charm , busy with tourists, but not at all tacky. The main tram line running from Divanlioglu down to the Galata bridge and across to Beyoglu is very useful for getting about, and only costs 2TL.Pastry shops galore, with exquisite treats apart from Turkish Delight.Apple tea and chai to refresh you on your walks wherever you are.

The area to be in while in Istanbul. The Sultanahment District is what Istanbul is all about. This place has so much history with all the museums and mosques and cobbled stone streets. Everything is within walking distance or very near the tram. Avoid taxis and walk the streets, take a wrong turn, get lost and find your way back and in between you will find the real Istanbul and have an amazing time. The Good:Old IstanbulHistoryMuseumsFoodTram stationsStreet VendorsShoppingThe BadSometimes too touristyAvoid the doner kebaps. I was so looking forward to eating doner kebaps, however I was very disappointed. It seems they only sell to tourists who dont know good food. The meat (what little they put in) is tasteless. You take a bite and you only get bread and some salad. Tips:1. Eat what the locals eat. We watched for a couple days and noticed that the locals hardly eat the doners from the street. Instead they eat Tost and we tried that and it was delicious. What is Tost? Basically a panini made with Turkish cheese and your choice of meats. 2. Also try the Islak, which is a wet burger - sounds unappetizing but believe me, try it - much better than the doner. 3. Definitely go to the Spice Bazaar - much friendlier vendors and their prices are reasonable - they dont quote you an outrageouse price then discount by 70% like in the Grand Bazaar. 4. Dont waste money on Bosphorus Tours. Get a good guide book then go to Eminonu and grab a Bosphorus Ferry cruise for around 10TL. 5. Do use the Trams. Very affordable and easy to navigate. Go to Kabatas and take the funicular up to Taksim Square. Much cheaper than a taxi and better experience.

Great place to stay. This area contains many of the monuments that are must sees during a visit to Istanbul. It is an easy area to walk around and has a very useful tram service that connect you with the Taksim area over the Golden Horn
So interesting. So much to see. Needs at least 2 days...3-4 would be better
lot of places to go, museuns, shops, cafes and restaurants. I liked everything, it seems that I belonged to it sometime ago...

Central to so many of the Attractions. The area is just beautiful. So many beautiful mosques, close to shops and transport. If you're a woman and travelling alone be prepared to be annoyed heaps by the men trying to lure you to their carpet or leather business. Too many of them boys trying to sell cheap perfumes also. It can be very tiring trying to just do what you went out to do. Best to keep walking and pay no attention.
sultanahmet district. this are lot of mosque there we can see the all the mosque and there architect dezine
Hotel was here. So much to see in this district. Many sights close to each other in walking distance.
great for tourists. The major tourist sites are in walking distance from the cobbled old streets to the main square and tramway system. Vast choice of eateries! Many hotelsand travel companies.
Walk Anywhere. Walk the cobble streets or take the tram. Everything is close by. Sites, eateries, bars, the Markets...
Another Must. Old İstanbul, streets, street's salers, magical athmosphere. also many hotels around.

Right our of Arabian Nights. Wandering the old part of the city gave me a taste of a a history and culture that I have read about but never visited. A different fell an ambiance than wandering the streets of old Paris. No minarets there.

Worth seeing once.. Busy, chaotic, enchanting, annoying and claustrophobic. Almost like a theme park, maintained for the entertainment of the visitor. Other areas of Istanbul are modern, well organized and more like other 21st century cities.
Culture Central!. Lovely place - home to lots of tourist attractions, restaurants and cafes. A great vibe, was glad that our hotel was located in the district!
Great area to stay in. This is a great area to stay in as it is within walking distance to many of the big sights and there are TONS of restaurants and shops.

Busy and Unforgettable.. We spent a week in the superb Topkapi Apartments in Sultanahmet and loved the area. Much of the time was spent walking from site to site and soaking up the atmosphere. Gems, such as the antique carpet museum, old back streets, mile post, small markets and buildings using Roman materials can be found extensively. We purchased multiple transport tokens and used the trams and ferries extensively. The Spice Market and wider area behind it was one of our favourite places. We often ate in little shops where English was not spoken but the smiles and friendliness of all made us feel welcome.We were approached all the time around major sites asking where we were from and offering to be a guide or take us to their shop around the corner. This was part of the charm of the area as these people had a delicious sense of humour and when you got speaking to them a story which often impressed. One person was able to converse in five languages of which we had a smattering and was thrilled when we told him we had visited his Kurdish town a few weeks earlier.When we return to Turkey we will again stay in Sultanahmet.
People, people, people !. Very social meeting ground. You have to watchful not to get lost - best going in a group.
A very friendly area. Shop keepers were so friendly, you could even holiday here on your own and feel welcomed and safe.
Lovely old town restaurants - very local flavours. We loved this district as there are many local kebap restaurants and the whole district is steeped in history.

Place has everthying that i like. I walked around this area for half day and will come back again if i can, this place is full of interesting stuffs such as restaurants, street food shops, souvenir shops, mosques, historic places.... A little crowded but it creates a great combination with the atmosphere... Great to see local people mix with tourists. Very good place to catch the soul of Istanbul in my opinion.

After dark during Ramadan, the square between Aya Sofia and the Blue Mosque is the place to be!. At the end of August, on the last Friday evening of Ramadan, my girlfriend and I arrived in Istanbul for the start of a 5-day visit. After checking into our hotel, we took a taxi up to Sultanahmet Square - actually, the area was so congested that our cab driver got us as close as possible, and then we had to walk the last couple block or so up the hill.Wow, what a crazy festive scene! It was after all after dark and time to break the fast. There were carts selling all kinds of snacks and desserts: grilled corn on the cob, handmade lollipops and ice cream, all kinds of things.Then there was the outdoor crafts fair, which apparently is open just for that last weekend of Ramadan. It was filled with crafts made by local artisans. My girlfriend bought a couple pairs of earrings, one for herself and pairs for her daughter and a friend or two. Walking through there, we met with a feast for the eyes.As we approached the Blue Mosque, the crowd grew thicker. There was, of course, one more prayer for the night, and people were gathering for that. We wanted to be respectful, but we were also curious to witness the pious fervor of Ramadan. Indeed, the prayers were broadcast over loud speaker, so that hundreds and hundreds of people who could not get inside the mosque could still participate in the courtyard outside.We were thrilled to see that we fit right in with the celebration. We spoke to many English-speaking Turks who were thrilled to talk about New York City - many said, "oh, I would love to go there!" or "oh, my cousin lives in the USA!" And they were all very friendly.What a great party! And I'm glad we got to not only witness it, but also to be there in the middle of it!

Ideal location to explore Istanbul. We stayed in the Faros Sirkeci Hotel in the Sultanahmet District and had a wonderful stay.The Sultanahmet District is mainly a tourists area, but all major attractions are closeby. And there are alot of bars and good restaurants where you can safely eat without being afraid to get sick.I would recommend Imbat Restaurant and Amedros for evening dining. A little bit more expensive then eating Kebab on the street. But you get a romantic atmosphere and/or spectacular view in return combined with a lovely meal.The Faros Sirkeci Hotel is right next to the Tram station (Gulhane) and with the tram you can easily go to Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, or even on foot to Topkapi Palace.

Beautiful area. Here is where all tourist interests are located. Walking around and taking lots of picture, eat good food at the kofte restaurant, do shopping for souvenir at spice bazaar and grand bazar that are within this area.. super great

Love the resto and cafe there. It has many restaurant and cafe that you can choose. Tried pudding house... it served decent affordable nice meal. In this district, there are lots of things that you can browse and buy such as carpets, souvenir, ceramics, etc
Amazing. Takes you away!You've gotta be there to believe it.

Wonderful to walk around for hours. This is the most amazing area. I walked around it for hours on several days an despite the incessant touting of the carpet and tile sellers I loved it. Oozing with history and atmosphere.
heart of old istanbul. things that you really see and visit..this kind of places remenber you that you are in istanbul and turkey

The old Neighborhood. Had a wonderful time walking through the streets of this neighborhood. The restaurants and food vendors were everywhere. One of my favorite things to do after seeing the mosques and museums was to people watch and sit at the cafes and drink some tea and alcohol.
Interesting. A definitely interesting area, you need to be keen on walking though! Lots of hidden back streets and old houses to see. Very interesting, take your time and just wander
Lovely part of old Istanbul. Worth paying a visit while in Istanbul if your not staying in one of the hotels in the area. So many restaurants with friendly staff.
First visit. So much to see, every corner you turn there is a new experiance

Touristy in some ways. but worth it all the same. I was there during Ramadan, and I wouldn't have traded the experience for anything! Great place. Lovely streets, ambiance charming place and scenery
nice area. very clean, many coffee places, lots of overpriced rugs. worth spending 2 hours there.
Sultanahmet. A history packed district. Walking the streets is a joy.

Walk righ into a fairy tail!. Exotic and beautiful. Filled with history. It is like waslking into the One thousand and one nights of your childhood. Beautiful!. Sultanahmet is full of famous attraction spots in Istanbul. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazar, New Mosque, Yerebatan Cistern, Topkapi Palace, etc. If you don't go to Sultanahmet, it's like you've never been to Istanbul!

Very pleasantly. You will fall in love with this place very quickly. Bazar, carsija... everything is interesting. People and lokal sellers are hospitable and very pleasant. They wil you give gifts, and offer you to eat some cakes for free. You have to try pressed pomegranate, which make on the street in front of you.

The Istanbul's old-town. Best place to stay if you are visiting Istanbul first time. All the places of interest is nearby

It is a must in Istanbul. If you go back to your country without strolling in Sultanahmet, that means you haven't seen Istanbul indeed. This district should be number 1 on your list. A neuralgic center of humankind history!. In the middle between the blue mosque, Haya Sophia and the hippodromus, this place is in the middle of old Istanbul. Close to myriads of small cafes, restaurants, stores and always full of people, is a delight to enjoy.

The best tourest place. i like the place,the buldings,the atmosfare,many cofees

The Times Square of Istanbil. Every kind of store and service you might need you´ll find there. the mosque was amazing. the whole district is amazing,, shops , places and even the city tour bus was a nice experience

Sultanahmet has buzz. Safety is paramount and sultanahmet gave me that. I loved the tram running through the area, the people buzzing about the streets, the azaan going off at prayer times, the restaurants and koftecis but most of all the smiling faces everywhere
Wonderful in every way. I love Istanbul, so start with that. This area has the famous sites (e.g., Hagia Sophia) as well as several interesting art museums.

Lots to see and do but beware the touts and carpet salesmen. Beware of constant approaches from men saying 'I'm not a guide- they are trying to take you to a shop' or ' I'm not selling carpets - they are!' or generally getting in the way. Amazing place. That huge castle is amazing , also had many things belond to sultan Hmed had kept there , also many cafee to have nice rest

Excellent for Tourists. Sultan Ahmet is the name of no 1 tourist district. It has Blue mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, hundreds of hotels and restaurents. It is not very far from Grand bazar and Eminonu......
