Great place to stay while in Istanbul. My fiance in I stayed in this district at the Hotel Grand Peninsula while on our honeymoon. It's a great district to stay in since you can walk to all the main tourist sites and can see both the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia from the roofs of many restaurants and hotels in this district.
wonderful. Very nice place for all visitors to Instabul.You have to pass from Sultanahmet Disctrict.Good service,nice food,the waiters are very friendly and proffesional

Great atmosphere. Sultanahmet is great part of city - especially at the evening and during night. Dont be scared of day tourist swarm (you are one of them, arent you?) and enjoy some calm attractions. You are in the centre of it!I have to recommend one thing - stay in one of hostels at Sultanahmet for 4-6 days. Dont storm it, use it as your base in Istanbul. There is nothing so beatigul as calm walking during night round Blue Mosque, just sitting in park... Sultanahmet isnt best when you see it first time. Its best when it became familiar. Walking around Sultanahmet. It was a great experience walking around the main plaza in Sultanahmet and visiting Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Topkapi Palace, Archaelogy Museum, and the Museum of Islamic Arts.
veri gut. You can see everywhere traces of the Ottoman Empire

Stay in Sultanahmet. This is the historic center of old Istanbul, once Constantinople. Within a small area you have so many of the distinctive sites of the city -- the Blue Mosque, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Egyptian spice bazaar, what remains of the Hippodrome, and the underground cisterns from the 6th C. Just watch out for the aggressive rug sellers!

Bustling and fascinating.... We stayed right in the heart of Sultanahmet and it's a brilliant area. Easy walking distance to all the biggies - Haghia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, the Grand and Egyptian Bazaars, Beyazit and the University - and not too much of a hike to Suleymaniye Mosque and over the hill to the Eqyptian Spice Bazaar. Also close to the excellent and inexpensive tram that will take you across the Galata Bridge to Beyoglu.Full of good restaurants and cafe that don't all break the bank. A brilliant base for a week in a wonderful city...

One big bazar. Sultanahmet has enormous number of bazars and shops and unfortunately for tourists sellers are very rude and aggressive. a beautiful walking district for visitors and cultural place. bustling with food and culture. easy to get around. on the tram tracks. Close to many other attractions. Beware of young man offering you " a free gift " and then expecting you to pay them money. giftd include flowers, travel books setc. They become quite hostile and you need to be firm and say no.
Just Magnificent. Very friendly people, clean and tasty food, very cheap shopping and very well looked after. Everything is within walking distance

There are many many restaurants around this area where waiters will talk to you constantly trying to get you to come into their restaurant. It's definitely an experience.
Very good place to walk arround. It's a very nice area to walk around. There around are the most attractions of Istanbul.

Loved the area. We trully enjoyed staying in the Sultanahmet Distric area, all the historiacl sights are close by as well as the Grand Bazar, lovely place, many good Turkish restaurant to choose from.

historic attractions around. walk around but think twice when you want to buy something. You can find it cheaper in the grand bazaar maybe ?
lovely area. wonderful place to base yourself in, good food, clean safe and on the tram lines
not that brilliant. u feel mass, crowd and noise everywhere, it smells so old but not that magical

The true flavour of Istanbul. This district is very beautiful, from the shops to cafes to the mosques... everything has a royal touch to it and makes you feel like your in a 19th century kingdom. Spend a couple of evenings to take home the good memories.

enjoy every everything. everything here is nice and great lots of hotels and restaurants and bars plus lots of nice parks and heritage and ancient buildings wherever you look you see something interesting the only bad thing is some people trying to force you to buy things while you are walking

"Old Town" Istanbul. This is the main tourist area in Istanbul full of all the "biggies" like the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. Great Place to stay!. First, it's a great place to stay (I stayed at the White House hotel) because there is SO much to be seen in that area, so much within easy walking distance. People were very helpful if you were lost and there were SO many people who spoke English and were patient with my attempts to say a few words in Turkish. Only 3 negatives: 1) DON'T drive in that area, leave it to those who live there and know how to get around. 2) Be prepared to hear regular Prayers over the PA system. I was thankful they didn't wake me up with the prayers, but the first time I heard it, I wondered about the frequency and duration. But it added ambience to staying in the area. 3) Be prepared for every person that has a "rug" shop, or has an "uncle" or "cousin" with a rug shop. They are very persistent. But, that's a lost art in America, the ability to engage someone in conversation, quickly develop that rapport and then make a sales pitch!
So much to see. This whole area is full of hitorical places to visit. Three full days is just enough.
So much so close. it was great to be able to spend the day walking between the various attractions. Made it well worth staying in the Sultanahmet.
walk and walk, feel the pulse of this city.. You cannot be bored and or get tired of this. Just walk and feel and get yourself transported and promise you will feel; I am on vacation.

Spend a day to see the "popular sites", then get to the Aisian side to enjoy living with the real Turkish people.. Overpriced everything; food, trinkets, sites. I wanted to see the famouse sites and walk through the Spice Market and Grand Bazaar, The Cistern but the vendors drive me crazy.On the asian side, there are almost no tour busses and most foreigners like to blend-in shopping and living with the locals. The Turkish people are friendly, helpful and few places are out "to get" foreigners (except the vendors at the covered tables along the waterfront; the will over-order for you).
excellent. i like the place but i did not like that i cold not go evrey wer

So Much Fun!. Just people watching is enough to entertain. I wouldn't necessarily do much shopping in this district as you can typically find prices cheaper in other areas, but it is still fun to look around.

Handy to most sites. Lovely old world with most of the city walls now in disrepair except for adjoining historical sights. Cobble stones everywhere so sturdy shoes are a must. The Hop On Hop Off bus is a good way to see the district and also the Asian side of Istanbul (cost is 20Euro and takes about 1.5 hours).

Fabulous History. About everything you could ask for, including probably the most historic church/mosque in the world, a historic palace, unique shopping areas (Grand Bazar & Spice market), lots of shops, restaurants and hotels in a terific setting.
History is huge but lack character. A lot of pushy salesman. I recommend spending more time over on the new city and the asian side.

Vibrant and colorful. This area, though besieged by shops and sellers, is a pleasure to walk through. It's steeped in both history and modernity; is extremely safe and is great just to stroll, wander and shop.

Make sure you go here when in Istanbul.... This is one of those areas that you need to visit when in Istanbul. There are a plethora of venues to choose from, and you can really get a feel for the culture and people within this maze of shops and stands selling their wares.

A ton the see right here!. A ton the see right here!
If you are approached to go to someone’s rug shop: Just Ignore Them!

Your Start !. Dotted with popular tourist spots such as the Hagia Sophia Topkapi Palace Blue Mosque, and walk laps. I think in the very busy heart of Istanbul said. Since there are many hotels and restaurants also seems an appropriate starting point for your stay in Istanbul.
the 'hood. Very busy, very aggressive, very chaotic, although convenient.
Tourist Attrtactions. Easy walking distance, excellent metro system and many sites to visit in a reasonably small area.
Lived there for two weeks. It feel like home now. It's really the heart of historic Istanbul

Where I can spend days walking. I love Sultanahmet District,
For you can walk around and see all the historical places, eat amazing food. go shopping and bargain for little amount to be deducted from price, have a turkish tea or a glass of wine on the street and just chill.
Beautiful. Stayed in this area.. close to everything interesting, old and historically fascinating..from the cobbled narrow streets to the carpet sellers etc..an interesting adventure..

Many sites in one part of the city. I would suggest getting a hotel in this area as many of the big tourist sights are located near to and within walking distance of each other. There is also a very handy tram service that runs between all the main sights and the locals are very friendly and keen to help with directions if/when needed.

Loved staying in the Sultanahmet area!. We stayed within walking distance to the major attractions of Istanbul. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia (Aya Sofia), the Topkapi Palace, and the Bacilica Cistern were all in the center of Sultanahmet. It is magical walking through the area at night (and we felt very safe doing so). From Sultanahmet, it is easy to walk or catch a rapid transit train, bus, or taxi to other areas in the city---Taxim Square and Istikal Street. But in my opinion, the place to stay is in the Sultanahmet area.

enjoyable. an unseperable combination between old history with all the surroundings( blue mosque, aya sophia church and basilik cistern in addition to the modern very romantic restaurants every where , it looks like paris in the movies i recommend to have a long stroll there , we went from therer to tpkapi through narrow alleys but very european style and
Great sites and shopping. Area is full of great shops, restaurants, and history.
Old Istanbul. Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet mosque(blue mosque), basilica cistern, Hippodrome, Topkapi palace, many restaurants, not so many bars(for nightlife go to Istiklal street).
Lovely historic area. Great for walking and taking in all it's lovely sights
stay here. this is a great area to stay in,everything is close by and a very active district.

Good Restaurants, Architecture, History, Shopping. We spent four days in this area and enjoyed good meals, interesting history, art and architecture. It was a return trip to Istanbul (the first visit was via cruise ship, so we only had an overnight the first time). We'd done some research on the sites, and one day we had a guide, Erkut Aldeniz, a recommended luxury for getting more from your visit.
Get all of your gifts from there. very nice place to find Souvenir and you have to bargain.
just old city. Old city sometimes indicates the history and culture of a city, like Sultanahmet District, is not really my style but worth visiting.
i liked the area. many shops so interesting ....near to the port the train station and the ferry boat

Interesting Area. Our Hotel was in the centre of this are which meant we had access to most of the historic parts of the district all within walking distance. Lots to see here as most of the items on the tourist must see routes are in this area.
Passage of the Ages in one small walk. Fantastic history spanning over 2000 years - all within a 1 hour circular walk which included bazaars and shops.
peaceful!. the district is not so crowded or dangerous as Taxim. Good I stayed at Sultanahmet
Easy to walk. If you don't smile too much, the vendors are not so pushy.
Great area in Istanbul. I loved this area...so much history and away from the crowds of the Marina.
Incredible sights among monuments, Mosque and other. We really loved Istanbul and its historical district. You cannot walk 5 minutes qithout seeing something terrific

Nice to visit in my all visits of Istanbul. I have been there more than 20 times:) Maybe because of its being free,but more than that, ı like the atmosphere of the area. It is one of the oldest part of the city and you can see some remains in the middle of hipodrom,still surviving today. And the Narrow streets around the quarter are also worth visiting. There are many resturants you can find all variety of food,even from Chinese,Korean and Indian culture:) There are also travel companies ,but the ones on the main street is a bit more expensive than the ones in the narrow traditional steets.You can also see the mozaics museum and remains of the old Byzantin Palace,known as Palatium Megara in the area. Some hotels,travel companies and carpet shops protecting some mozaics and cisterns, also availabe to visit for free :) just ask people how to find such a place:) Many people can speak English and also variety of languages in the area:))
Historical and modern at the same time. Enjoyed walking around, drinking salep and exploring historical atmosphere.

Awesome place to go and Explore. Brilliant. Loved the streets and the shops and the colourful wares they sell. Go around the little alleys and make sure you are exploring the area around the Spice bazaar. There are many surprises around that area.

Heart of historical Istanbul. Touristy, but convenient to the major sites. Within walking distance, you can tour the underground cistern, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and Archeology Museum.
where to stay is where most of the attractions are. I will come back. The best place to stay in Istanbul is the Hippodrome Hotel : reasonable, perfect location and great staff.
good place to stay and explore. We stayed here and it was an excellent choice as all the major attractions are within walking distance.

Very safe and central location. My wife and I liked this area due to its location to the sites and overall selection of things to do. I would still venture out to the different areas, but you can feel comfortable staying here.
Great location to stay. This is a great district for any tourist to stay. It is within walking distance of all the major sights.

So much to see!. I am not sure if all of this is technicaly in the district, but is all close by. We walked to all of these things from our hotel, Acra Hotel, which we Loved! We enjoyed the dinner and view at Hamdi, have to sit on the 5th floor, its right by the spice market. Sultanahmet Koftecisi (its a place that sells only 'meatballs' for lunch quick in and out near ayasofia on Divan Yolu Cd). The obvious blue mosque, Ayasofia, spice and grand bazaar Topeka Palace was a nice walk. I could not get enough of the honey rings the street cart and bakery guys were selling, not the bagel/pretzel looking ones but the more churro looking ones and their cousins sold at bakeries that look like little oval nuggets(the place I really liked that sold them was outside the spice bazaar, I think on the same 'street' as this famous stand that sells coffee beans (everyone knows it).

expensive. it's a very nice place, with lots of attractions to visit and restaurants to have a bite. i have no complaint about the food, which is very tasty and diverse, but i very much dislike the fact that they charge more for tourists. and yes there is a card for museums, which could grant you entry cheaper than the normal ticket, but it cost 72 TL for tourist for 3 days and 20 TL for Turkish people for one year.

Great to be back. Now bold, then a long haired hippy, I am back after 40 years. Still lively during the day. And surprise surprise: The Puddingshop Lale's Restaurant, still exists. The one and only meeting point for travellers on the cheap towards the Far East.
Sultanahmet has so much to see in the day, at night Taksim is more lively.
Full on. Average priced area. You can exchange currency there. Good prices
Tourism District. Since it is located near popular attraction, you can easily found restaurant in any price that suitable with your budget.

The location of many of Istanbul's historic sites.. This is a great location IF you have come to Istanbul to see historic sites. It is not good if you have come for shopping or night life. One excellent fish restaurant: Balik Sabahattin.
Vibrant. crowded, colorful, nice. people are nice and generally helpful but watch out for those hard-driving sales people. one essentially stalked me!
Nice area where there is à lot to see and to do.. We almost Linked everything, touristbusses are storting Thierry loops in front of the Sofia museum, great to start à citytrip!
Pleasantly surprised. Overall the district is nice and clean...loaded with history dating back several thousand years...plenty of folks who speak English. Biggest drawback is the pushy shop-owners!
Has charm and style. It makes you want to wander and poke about - take time with the area and the people - you'll be glad you did
Friendliness and hospitality. The best district of istanbul; historical, cozy, hospitable and safe.
sultanahmet. I walked past here every day of my 4 day visit, evenings or mornings and found it safe, clean, spacious and highly enjoyable to be able to walk in the heart of a big city
It's the place to be.. We spent a week in Istanbul - we could have beautifully spent it all in the Sultanahmet district, there is so much to see and do there. Fascinating.

Walking. It was a wonderful place to walk & take in the views and charm. I was somewhat tired of the constant agressiveness of shop owners and restaurants triying to get our business. I would have loved to just take in the area without deciding who I wanted to interact with or ignore every 2 seconds.

Spectacular Mosque. This mosque was so impressive and so full of history. the lines were very long so we used a guide who told us so much about the building and Islam. Would recommend a guide so you don't miss anything.

The historic center of Istambul. This is where you need to go when visiting Istambul. You'll find the most important monuments and a maze of shops where you can buy every kind of souvenir. And don't forget to drink a nice cup of tee.
all in one place. what more can you want? from old roman palaca to leather shop, all at one place
Most important district. Thousand years of History within a relatively small city area
WALK EVERYWHERE. Almost everything is within easy walking distance and if lost just ask, although you may find yourself in an always nearby carpet store.
a real jewel in the crown. all the heritage sites were within walking distance. be careful of pushy salesmen who begin any conversation with "Where are you from...?" - invariably its to sell carpets!
Easy, central, accessible, interesting!. Everything easily accessible including cultural, historic, gastronomic aspects.

A maze - or should that be amazing. All the old city in a microcosm - wall to wall shops, cafe and restaurants. BUT if you want free tea just go inside a rugshop and fein interest - it wastes half an hour but you get a free cuppa!
Beautiful. I like it because I find the place facinating and the place looked clean and well maintained. There is so much of history behind it for me to learn by spending my time reading the placards
Tourist Area. Shops, restaurants are only for tourist after 6:00 PM. Can't feel Istanbul night life there.
excellent touristic area.. close to everything.. Sultanhamet square, blue mosque, topkapi palace, the tram..

Sultanahmet is a must. This is the place every tourist must visit in Istanbul. the most interesting sites are in Sultanahmet, the historical part of Istanbul, and the one word every tourist should memorize. This is where Haggia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Museums, the Grand Baazar, Topaki Palace, the magnificent Yabatar Cistern, and other attractions are located, all within walking distance. The streets in Sultanahmet are clean, and there are many shops and restaurants, as well as many good and reasonably priced hotels. I found many tourists, especially from Europe, staying there. But most importantly, the people are friendly and helpful, which made me feel safe, even until late night (midnight). It is easy to get there from the International Airport, just ask almost anyone for “Sultanahmet”, and you will get reliable directions. Get off in the "Sultanahmet” station, or the one after.

Historical Istanbul comes alive here!. This is where most of old Istanbul's tourist attractions lie. From the Topkapi Palace to the Blue Mosque to the Basilica Cistern.. you can these and more here!Taking a stroll here is pleasure, as it is very homely and the aura is different: the best thing is that the look and feel of the place has been maintained to its historical background. The alley are narrow, and never too crowded with cars; even human traffic in and around is not too cramped. The restaurants are friendly and not too expensive. The buzz is just right and not too loud.All in all, anyone going as a first-timer to Istanbul to should book a hotel in this district to make the most of his trip! Its charm will surely grow on you. Next time I'm there again, I will surely stay here and nowhere else.

Everything you want for tourists. Great place to find everything you look for! Shops, restaurants, sightseeings, local stores, candy shops, museums, etc. The only they have missing are bars to go out and meet locals (most of them are in Taksim Square Area). Loved this area of the city! Next time I plan to come in a less rainy season to enjoy the parks at its full!

It is where all the historical sites are located. This is where you want to stay and visit. You walk through and past more than a thousand years of historicallly important sites. Make sure you walk there at night to see the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia. They look beautiful with the lights shining on them.
this is a unique place in the world. You can never see a 5th century church and mosque next to each other
Great area. Very historic. Watch out for pickpockets. Good value restaurants by main tram stop.

Sultanahmet - THE place to stay. When researching places to stay in Istanbul, we were continually drawn to the Sultanahmet district, home of most of the historic sights in town. We were not disappointed. Staying in this neighborhood put all of our key sights within easy walking distance, and other sights within a convenient tram ride. Looking out your hotel window to see the Hagia Sohpia or Blue Mosque up close and beautifully lit at night will take your breath away. There are plenty of restaurants and lots of shopping nearby, as well as easy access to small grocers and all forms of public transportation. After visiting Istanbul and many of its neighborhoods, we would choose Sultanahmet over and over again.

every thing its close. getting to to the sites in 5 minutes as maximun, Aya Sofia its atwo minutes from the hotel , the big Market its 10 min walking galata bridge 10 minutes, etc. nice places to eat something in a lots of restautants sorroundig . youa can find super markets and very cute stores

Wonderfully historic. Worth the trip to be able to walk around in this area. The sights, buildings, people, foods. What's funny is that Trip Advisor misses 1 of the 3 must-see sights in this area - Topkapi Palace; you can review the Hagia Sofia and the Archaeological Museum.
old istanbul. nothing like visiting the older part of the city to get the flavors of what life was like.

Bustling. Lots of restaurants, shops, tour operators... everything a tourist my like to see and do in close proximity. Shop vendors and restaurant hosts will try to charm passersby into their shops or restaurants, very friendly people.

Back to the Past. This side of the city has its own charming way! You can imagine yourself back to the time of the Otoman period with its races on teh Hipodrome or the Sultans on the Mosques!
Can´t miss!
The place to be in Istanbul. Great architecture/atmosphere within walking distance of each other - make sure you visit the Underground Water Cistern.

Unexpected delights. There are so many unforgettable places to see in this district, we were very pleased to have booked ourselves into Istanbul for a full five days. We wished we had booked for two weeks, really!
eccellent. nice location,historical area blue mosque hagia sophia basilica cistern

Perfect for first time Istanbul visitors. The district is the the perfect place to stay for those visiting Istanbul for the first time. The attractions of Old Istanbul are all walking distance from the many fine hotels and B&B. The eateries are also there in a wide array of choices - dont miss the Koftecisi (the original one since 1920) with the best meatballs ever. The ATMs and tram are conveniently located near the Hagia Sofia when you want to venture further to Taksim or the Galata bridge area.
sultanhamet beckons you to historic Istanbul. this part of town is extremely charming, lots of great shops, friendly shop keepers, very clean, nice restaurants, and very safe.

Beautiful to visit, but not to stay. This neighbourhood has all of the sites, but is really touristy. I personally like to experience true culture when I travel, so while Sultanahmet is a must-visit, I'd stay elsewhere. Grand Bazaar neighbourhood, while still touristy, also has more of a local feel. I liked it there. Across the water in Karakoy was also nice.

Better Sultanamet than Taksim. If you can't decide where to stay in Istanbul, stay in the old district of Sultanamet. You can see everything here in a couple of days but when you come out of your hotel in the morning or when you come back in the afternoon or evening from going out, you get off the tram and you see the Blue Mosque right in front of you. It is a wonderful experience every time.

We spent a week and just skimmed the surface. There is so much to see and experience that a week would just be enough for an introduction to this lovely old part of Istanbul. We selected a hotel in the heart of the Sultanahmet district and stayed during Ramazan. This allowed us to walk around late into the evening to enjoy the festivities and special foods. I highly recommend timing your visit around this time of year.
Full of life. A place to walk about and discover new things at every corner. Don't be discouraged by the apperance of several buildings..just keepo walking until you find another treasure.
A gigantic bazaar. Just stroll your way around or take the tram, it's a huge area full of all kinds of commerce. Crowded morining 'till late night, yet you never feel crushed or unconfortable.
Great area a must for visitors. Very close to our Hotel Amira, great shopping and lots a beautifull restaurants and lov ely food, close to the biggest Market, close to tram, GREAT!
Turistic Place. You can find everythıng there. All tourist attraction is there. Shops and food are little bit expensive. Taksim is more cheaper. You can see all the local at Taksim

The soul of Istanbul. The Sultanahmet district is really the soul of Istanbul. Most of the major historical attractions are in and around this district. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern are right next to each other. Do visit it at night to enjoy the lit up sites of the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque in particular.
Sultanahmed it's a must!. You'll feel completely turkish in Sultanahmed district, it's more than a simple neighbourhood :)
Amazing history. Amazing history & major sites are all close together, facilitating easy walking tour - either with a guide or self-guided. Don't miss Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia & Basilica Cistern.

The Must-See Heart of Istanbul. People-watching and wandering/entering/viewing the various sites is quite rearding. If you have the time, try to do this district across several days; between the crowds, the traffic, and the touts, it can get wearisome rather quickly. be patient, cautiouos, but ever curious. We enjoyed it immensely.
World culture centre. A brilliant mix of cultures old and new. So many important sites in one small area.
Must visit. wow....how wealthy the ottomoman emphires previous....
you must see. It's amazing to see what people like and can do to make it intresting to go there.

Blue Mosque and Great for Shopping. One of the top and popular historical mosque of Istanbul A must visit. For the Muslim, it will be great to pray here. The dome is simply amazing. Very serene.
Try taking photos at night and you will know why this place is a must visit.
Old part of Istanbul. Good place to walk and enjoy the shops and local sights. There is always a Mosque near to wherever you are in Istanbul.
Lots to see close by. The area houses most of the "must see" architecture in Istanbul, and the Bhosporus itself was a pleasant surprise - blue water, lovely buildings, beautiful bays.

Must see if in Istanbul for the first time. This is a very densely built district that has all the major attractions (Aya Sofia, Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar etc). Beautiful (and not so beautiful but colorful) stores and small houses make for a very unique scenery. You simply have to visit it if your are in Istanbul for the first time. But in my personal opinion, every trip to Istanbul should include a visit (or revisit) of Sultanahmet.

Historical and beautiful place to be. Just go and bring your camera, don't forget your tripod cause you'll need it in case you can't find anyone to take pictures for you and your whole family/group. If not just ask anyone there to take a photo for you, I'm sure many will help.
Tourist. Too touristic. Interesting contrast of touristic business and old turkish tradition. When you step out of the main streets you see a totally different Istanbul.
Peacefull place. Peacefull square especially at evening, Blue mosque is full of romantic lights.
Great Shopping and People Watching. I really enjoyed watching all the different nationalities mingle here
I found a hotel here too. THe Deniz House Hotel is in this area so it is easy to walk out the door and see so much

Be prepared to buy stuff.... ... or at least, be prepared to be sold stuff to, most politely. The historic district is legible, filled with these amazing wonders of architecture and history and highly recommended, but expect to do more shopping than you'd perhaps want to.
Great sights and smells. What a fantastic place to walk around and soak up! Deep history combined with contemporary life.
Beautiful Area. We met so many nice people and saw impressive historic sites.

Can't miss. Sultanahmet is the most tourist friendly area in Istanbul. There is so much to see in such a small space. You could spend two days walking around taking everything in. If you are crossing the bridge to enter the area make sure to pick up a fish sandwitch from one of the local fishermen. They look a bit off but are AMAZING
Great Place. Very Clean, the vendors did not hassle you. A lot of cats but it did not bother us.
Great for strolling. We walking around the area quite a bit (frequently not sure where we were!). Everyone was very helpful if we asked for directions. We always felt safe.

Best location in Istanbul for sightseeing. If you only have a few days in Istanbul then the best area to stay in is definitely Sultanahmet. It is great to walk around and sightseeing is free of charge !There are numerous small boutique type hotels in the area and lots of restaurants which gives a great choice according to your budget. We loved the Acra Hotel as it was in a quieter side street and during the height of the season those hotels located on what is known as "Backpacker Street" I imagine could be quite noisy. It was great to be able to walk out the front door and immediately be in the centre of everything. If sightseeing is what you want then with the Blue Mosque, Sophia Hagia Museum, Basilica Cistern and the Hippodrome all basically in the same area and the entrance gate to the Gulhane Park and Topkapi Palace a 5 minute walk away and the Sultanahment tram station giving cheap and easy access to other areas it really is the best location. You can also hire a bicycle which can be fun - although I would recommend staying in the general area as the roads in Istanbul are extremely busy ...and also make sure to stay out of the way of the taxi drivers..!From the main square you can also get your tickets for the "hop-on/hop-off" tour buses - currently 19.95€ for 24hrs.Don't forget to try a Nargile (or hubble bubble water pipe) as well as the obvious but delicious honey turkish delight....and enjoy everything Istanbul has to offer.(A tip is to make sure you have 0.50TL coins available for the toilets and be prepared for "non standard european" facilities when you are in the centuries old Grand Bazaar !...lol).
this district is rich in history.. many great buidings with rich history n all within walking distance. the people friendly.

beware of the man whose "cousin owns a shop". lol... you hear variations of this sentence from almost every hawker out to make a commission by guiding tourists to certain shops... otherwise highly enjoyable

Interesting experience. Always fun to go through a local district, but the hawking is very consistent. I just ignore them and keep going as I love the architecture and seeing the various artifacts, history and unusual scenes and people watching but there is a price.
Must see.. Very beautiful. All the major tourist and historical sites are located here.

a city within the city. The historical district of Istanbul, it concentrates the majority of the most famous buildiong of the city; Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosk, Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome, the Grand Bazar. It's like a small city within the city, easy to walk around, plenty of carpet shops (unbelievable quality). From a restaurant point of view a bit too touristic but you can go somewhere else to eat :-)

Great area of the city!. Istanbul is huge, but being our first time visiting, I'm glad we stayed in this area of the city. It's the older (and basically) original portion of Istanbul. Current day, there are tons of shops, restaurants, a lots of history in the area. The Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia museum are in the area, along with the Grand Bazaar and Egyptian Bazaar. There is a train/tram that runs throughout this section of town and it's very easy to use. There are fresh pomegranate juice stands everywhere!
The heart of Istanbul. Well laid out - lots of shopping and dining options - stay here to be close to the most important sights of the city!

Mosques, Palaces and Museums. Sultanahmet is home to the Blue Mosque, New Mosque, Haiga Sophia, Topkapi Palace, the Cistern, Spice and Grand Bazaars all within easy walk of each other or take the tram for 1.25 lira.

a trip in the past. as being Greek, it makes you happy and sad at the same time...one of most known monuments in the world, Agia Sofia is in Sultanahmet, still a very nice area, romantic, well preserved
Bustling area - great for anyone needing a carpet or 50. Great location for all attractions. Choose your eating restaurants carefully. Chance to buy a carpet every 20 mtrs!

Crowded and historic. Steel yourself for crowds and most restaurants and businesses with salespeople beckoning you in. It is full of life but can be bewildering. Visit the Tourist Information Office for help in orienting yourself to the district.
a must see. short tour and very interesting. reasonable price. all underground, not really handicapped accessable.

Sultanahmet is extremely charming!. I stayed in Sultanahmet and found it have everything I needed. Great places to eat, tons of shopping, the heart of the city with all the great sights right there within walking distance. There's also a tram that will take you wherever you need to go and is quite inexpensive.

Great for Restaurants and Tourists. If you only have a few days in Istanbul, the Sultanahmet District is a great place to absorb the major parts of the city. It is located right by the Ayasofya and the Blue Mosque. There are plenty of touristy decent restaurants, shops, street peddlers and tea shops to give you a decent taste of what Istanbul has to offer. It is also on the line of the tram line so if you are feeling daring and want to take a ride, it is a good place to start.

Cool place to walk through and lose yourself. This is unique and enchanting area full of shops and restaurants in which you can stroll through and enjoy. Some of the restaurants cater a bit too much to the tourists and can be a bit pushy with their sales tactics. My advice is to get off of the main street and wander through some of the smaller alleys - and take in any of a number of little spots to sit down and eat.I also highly recommend taking in a Turkish Bath. It is a one-of-a-kind experience that you will never forget!
vibrant part of town. Great area to take in the sites, so many in this area alone. This part of town dies down at night which was a little unusual but overall a really nice area.
where the cultures mix. The area is filled with historical places. Transportation to the area from Taksim square is easy. Metro stations are clean and new.Well organized museums.
Old Istanbul. Nice area, loats of places to stay, eat out and drink. Very close to main atrractions

Close to all the sites we wanted to visit. Very convenient and safe to walk around. Lots of people have said that you are hazzled by the shopkeepers etc but we didnt find that at all. Quite a few restaurants that had quite good food in the area. Lovely stroll down the back streets behind the Blue Mosque. where there are lots of buildings with character. Close to the tram so that you can easily visit other areas. such as the Spice Market. Close to the Grand Bazaar.

The heart of the Ottoman Empire. Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia Mosque, Basilica Cistern, the narrow streets of the old Ottoman Empire and the other a lot of historical structures at some point you will find.Taste the Sultanahmet's Meat Balls and drink 'Ayran'.
Great sites, great food. I stayed in the Sultanahmet District and very much enjoyed walking around to shop, see the sites, and eat. Found plenty to keep me busy.
Good but a bit touristy. Good food. Pudding shop a bit smarter than 40 yrs ago. Try a visit to Uskudar as well though. Very cheap and real Turkish.

Don't miss a Donor. Many food shops offer "meat on a vertical spit" - a Donor -
carved into a pita with veggies and spicy stuff and yogurt. YUM!
I miss these already! Good shops, an ATM.

My favourite area of Istanbul. I love Sultanahmet with its bustling streets, hustling salespeople & lively activity. There is so much to see here, even if you don't go to visit the wonderful attractions such as Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque & Aya Sofya, which you defineitely should. The streets are full of fascinating characters; whether they are trying to sell you a carpet or a packet of tissues, there is such a "buzz" that you could never be tired of the place. I know some find the hawkers a bit much to cope with (believe me, they are far worse in Bali!), but a smile & a firm "no thank you" while you keep on walking helps keep your sense of humour. Istanbul is like no other city in the world & Sultanahmet is a treasure.

The most fascinating area of a most fascinating city. Here's where all the main tourist attractions are located. We stayed in Sultanahmet because we wanted to be able to walk everywhere, and it was fun to just step out of the hotel and see the Blue Mosque at all times of the day and in any light. Other district of Istanbul are very similar to parts of other European cities, but the Sultanhamed and the Bazar district are certainly unique. The area is very lively and walking outside at night at any time is a lot of fun because so many people are around. There are many restaurants that look like tourist traps but in fact many of them are pretty good. Just do your homework and check out the restaurant reviews on tripadvisor.com. The district is full of things to do and see and one could spend the whole vacation here, but public transportation from here is also very convenient and makes it easy to explore other interesting districts of this amazing city. I would definitely recommend staying here to all people visiting Istanbul for the first time. Yes it is more touristy... but the nearness and convenience to all the major sites is unbeatable, and you can still experience the full flavors of turkish customs and life because the district is also full of Turkish people going about their daily business totally oblivious of the tourist around them.
Traditional beautiful views. The heart of Istanbul.... lots of people, beautiful viwes of Haghia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and the Marmara Sea. Always felt safe walking around.

Amazing area to explore. Loved Sultanahmet. Lots of things to see and do in close proximity. Shopping was more low-key and enjoyable in local Arasta Bazaar than the Grand Bazaar. Streets easy to navigate to explore local attractions--Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, and Topkapi Palace were all nearby. Hope that we'll have the opportunity to return!
Beautiful place. If you go to turkey you will be have to visit this place. It is beautiful

Fascinating district - giving the feel of Old Istanbul. We stayed in Sultanahmet District at the great Hotel Basileus, and loved being in the center of all the major historical sights. What a colorful, vibrant and interesting district it is. We'd return to stay there again (at the Hotel Basileus) on any future trips. It gave a real flavor of Istanbul.
A lovely district. It is a very traditional district with the Blue Mosque and Ayia Sophia as jewels and the big bazaars which make the whole area very vibrant and charming.

So Much to See. The Sultanahmet District is the primary reason there are tourists in Istanbul. The more luxurious hotels are located across the Golden Horn, but I recommend staying in Sultanahmet since there are numerous brand-name attractions like Agia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Hippodrome, shops, restaurants, etc. The history and beauty of this particular area is unsurpassed by almost any other city in Europe in my opinion. Take a lot of pictures and do some homework before you arrive so that you can absorb all that it can provide. While Istanbul and the Sultanahmet area are key attractions, there was a downside for me that did not impact my rating of this area but something to keep in mind. What I disliked were those who I believed were out to con me into buying things I didn't need, didn't want, the presences of potential pickpockets, and being approached by the classic opening conversational lines by male strangers that may have led to the classic bar scams. You may want to get to know the locals better. If so, do it on your terms and your approach, not on someone elses approach and come-on to you. This is not limited to Sultanahmet but any global city where a good tourist industry thrives. Don't be paranoid but be informed and have a great time.
Sultanhamet. Make sure you get off the beaten track and visit some of the little shops in side streets. Cheaper food and you might have more chance of a bargain than in the market.
..... clean,very clean!!with a lot of police but without seem disturbing as they were polite...with a lot of salesmen that sometimes were disturbing you...but really nice!!!!

Great side walking tour. I really enjoyed walking around Sultanahmet. The many shops offered the same as what you would see in the Grand Bazaar but two thirds cheaper! Wandering around there are other historical sights to behold plus local vendors selling every kind of trinket, tea, sahlep drink, pretzel, photo with a man in supposedly traditional Turkish garb, etc. The gardens are beautiful and you've never seen so many stray cats in one place!
Local flavor. Located amoung residents and visitors hotels. You really get the flavor of living in Istanbul.

shops galore. lots of shops full of unusual and beautiful things to buy..make sure you take lots of cash and a large suitcase. You never tire of the place. Its fantastic and by far one of the most exciting places that I have visited.
Great place to stay. For an authentic feel and great location, easy access to all the major sights and great restaurants stay in the Sultanahmet District.
Tourist Area. Good tourist area to see, with lots of important historical facts around.

I believe I could live here. Even though I did not travel to many of the other districts, I found this one to be amazing. I enjoyed the sights, energy and culture of this district. Most everything that I wanted to see was within walking distance and those that were a bit off the beaten path, I just caught the Tram and off I went. Many shops and street vendors ( both food and souvenirs) to choose from. Upscale and inexpensive items to buy and take back home with you. Please note: I found out that the shipping company: DHL will not ship any spices back to the USA. I purchased some Saffron (the real stuff from Arifoglu #31 in the Egyptian Bazaar) and I had them vacuum seal it to take back with me. I held onto it like it was worth millions. It was only 25 Lira for I gram, way less than what I would have paid back in the US. Even though I spent about 10 days in this district, I still did not see everything. I have lots to look forward should I be able to come back. Food markets, drugstores and Turkish Baths. I found that the Tram was very easy to take and understand. What a Great Place

Madding crowd !. It's a madding crowd with all tourists from all over the world just enjoying the nearby historical sites like Hagia Sofya and The Blue Mosque right at the plaza,restaurants, tour buses & etc.
We loved staying so close to all attractions.. This area was perfect for us. we could walk everywhere. Both hotals were excellent.
High end shops.. If you want the good stuff or you just want to look at the good stuff this is the place. The Beverly Hills of Istanbul.

nicest part of Istanbul. Sultanahmet is the most proper place to stay in Istanbul, to go sightseeing, to eat and to walk is you are tourists. Also please don’t be afraid of Grand bazaar in terms of shopping, you should just keep an eye at your belongings and don’t take all the prices seriously and you’ll like it ))
Just soak in the history. Just love to get lost in the back streets and wander around
one of a kind. there are so many places that could be visited in Sultan Ahmet District, and actually the more you travel to Istanbul, the more you realize that this district has so much to offer
excellent district for everything. Excellent location to stay in, most attractions are there or close to. You can enjoy your time there and save money of transportation.

A spiritual experience. Walk around the square and take in the regal and classic architecture of the main buildings. The garden and grounds, the paved square are well maintained and clean. There are food vendors carts scattered around the grounds selling a variety of Turkish snacks and drinks. We went in autumn and the autumn leaves, the cooler air added to the beauty of the place. To complete the experience, we were in the square during hte noon time call to prayer. The call to prayer that came across the square from all the mosques , All these sensual pleasures together, made it a completely spirituality experience.
Everything. Everything you've ever learned in history class. All world heritage sites in one place. Great Bazaars

Historical Place. all the historical places and museums in Istanbul are located in this district. Really nice to walk around and some great restaurants here as well. During tourist season it can get really really busy of course. Also try ignoring all the locals trying to sell you guide books, tours etc.

all history ofthe city in one place. i very love this district, all most important sightseeings are here, if you like history more than shops, stay in one of sultanahmet hotels. All greatest memory places are avaliable by 10-15 walking.
Walk in the night. Its probably the ideal area to walk in the night. The atmosphere is far beyond expectations!

Sultanahmet District - Everything is handy. Lodging in the Sultlanahmet District provides the traveller with an at-the-doorstep location to see Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Museum, the Haggia Sophya, stroll in the park, eat in the Dervish Cafe, get fresh-squeezed pomegranate juice, have some street-made ice cream, pet the cats, buy nifty souvenirs, and feel safe. Everything is handy - the tram, the bustle, early-morning getcha goin' bakery delights, beauty, and, of course, eye candy from the ages. May I add my respect for Attaturk, who seems to have thread the needle so perfectly to bring his country forward with its history intact. In the Sultanahmet District, you absorb the beautiful Istanbul which accepts its guests and shares its treasures with the grace of one of its many purring cats. A must see.
great place to walk around. I liked people who respect relegious sites I disliked vendors who trick you into buying seeds to feed the pigeons
Everything is here. You do not need a guide here, but look up for carpet sellers who would like to guide you around!
Must See. The Sultanahmet District was amazing. So rich in history and the people are very friendly, but watch out for the shop keepers!
Lovely area but very touristy. It's a great area but there's lots of street sellers and it was packed even in November. Great place to relax for an afternoon
like like a postcard. so much to see in a very walkable area. the blue and red mosque. the old cisterns ala from russia with love. the old palice and so much more
Bustling and truly international. The smells, sights, tastes, colours, buildings, sounds - just amazing.

Best behaved crowds.. My wife and I were lucky to have been here during the Islamic feast time of the Bayram. This area was full of families visiting this city and, obviously, all kinds of hawkers selling every type of snack and drink imaginable. Though there must have been several hundred people present there was never any unpleasant crowd noise or any misbehavior.
Charming Area. Lovely district, great touristic area, many sites to visit. Great neighborhood and eating areas all around. Very friendly people.

Heart of the tourist area. Lots to see and do. When I visited in May the authorities were putting down new pavement around the major sites. I expected it to be finished by the time of my second visit but it seems they don't work that quickly. I expect it will not be finished before next spring.
Cosy, friendly and very interesting. The area is full of interesting places as well as very good restaurants. It's really easy to walk around and enjoy the scenery.

The reason you go.. This is the reason to go to Istangul. On our return from Goreme and Selcuk we stayed for two nights near the airport at the Titanic Port Hotel to compare old Turkey with modern Turkey. The Titanic is a great 5-Star hotel and I would recommend it to anyone on a business trip to Istanbul; but after you have marveled that Turkey's largest shopping mall next door is just like a shopping one in the US, there's very little to do except grab a taxi to the Sultanahmet or in our case over the Galata Bridge to Taksim Square.
Beautiful blue mosque. Crowded with people but absolutely well worth seeing. Another must see.

Lost in Ottoman Heritage. Just wander around this area and gives yourself a treat of all senses to the great surroundings of Sultanahmet. Watch those vendors at Grand Bazaar, hustle and bustle of spice market, gazing at the grand dome of Sultanahmet mosque or Hagia Sofia and you will surely fall in love with Turkey.
THE BEST PLACE FOR THE TRAVELLER TO BE BASE. The best place to stay because all the major sights are within walking distance.
Inspiring atmosphere. You can simply spend a unique half day at that beautiful district. Pay attention to the prayer times as sultan Ahmet mosque is closed for around an hour at each prayer.
Traditional Istanbul. Lively by day, eerily beautiful at night. Don't miss taking photos of Blue Mosque at sunset and in the night.
Sultanahmet. Our hotel was in this area. Many sites of interest and some great restaurants. It has a pleasing atmosphere.

The best area in istanbul to stay.. Our hotel was situated there, the parks are clean and very safe to walk around in day and night, there is some great history there, wonderful eateries, and reasonable prices.

Wonderful. Nothing beats walking around in the Sultanahmet Area, enjoying the atmosphere and eating out in any of the numerous restaurants there, with sigh seeing places in every corner. I cannot imagine any tourist visiting Istanbul and not staying in Sultanahmet, its the best place to visit for tourists.
Sultanahmet District. The stores, the restaurants and the historical sites were all great. Store items were varied but on the expensive site (compared to items in Ankara)

Roman and Ottman side by side.. This area includes the Hippodrome with its three columns, the Blue Mosque and the even more impressive Aya Sofia. Easily covered in a morning but to see properly would need a week.
OLD TOWN. Its one of the most interesting places in the world. Endless sites to see and places to go. The people watching is excellent and the food … ooooh the food.

The main attraction.... When staying in Istanbul, the Sultanhamet is definitely the place to be. Most of the major attractions are here and there is a great tram that runs through the area that easily transports you to what you would like to visit in other areas such as the Dolmabache (sp) palace. It is worth the visit indeed.

touristy in a good way. We enjoyed walking along the main street ( where the tram runs) in Sultanamet--restaurants, sweet shops, souvenir shops, and at least one Turkish bath. And you can walk to the Blue Mosque an Hagia Sofia.

Stay here - you will not be disappointed!. All the historic attractions and excellent transport links. Try and get a hotel in this area - walking distance to major attractions, and access to the tram system to get around to those further afield.
loved this area, nice cafes. loved the area, but nice back street places to eat at, nice local people
Cobble Stone Streets. This area is very authentic, Cobble Stone Streets, lots of restaurants and attractions.

shopping unbeliveable. it is worth the flight for the shooping! do not miss the spice market or Grand Bazaar well worth it. Be prepared to Haggle and enjoy the experiance. The main shopping street are wonderful. Do not miss going to a cafe for coffee and a delicios cake . They all taste better than they look!
Heart of the city. So much to see and do and we never tired of walking round just looking at the architecture

Old world charm. We loved wandering the streets, visiting all sorts of museums, shops and historical sites. Some excellent restaurants too. Watch out for young men trying to lure you into their carpet shops!
Like old times..... The place looked like the old times, I could imagine myself in the good old days of the Ottoman times, it was wonderful!

Tourist. This is the district you want to go to if you want to eat good food and smoke nargile and just enjoy life.
But its overall expensive and many over riendly barkers

SultanAhmet, the city's heart since ancient times. This is just excellent, what a mixture of cultures, religions and architectural style. If you have quite a few days, make sure to spent them here in the this district of Istanbul. Cistern, Ayasofya, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Grand Bazaar, name it and it is right there. To relax after a long day, go to the cemberlitas for a true treat: Turkish Hammam1

Nice but expensive. Its got lovely tile work on the inside but apart from the mosque there is nothing else. there are some nice cafes on the outside but they are overpriced. It is an expensive district

Lots to see. Lots of interesting places to visit, but check out when they are open. We missed the Topaki Palace as we left it until the last day and found it closed. Do go early to the main sights to avoid queues. lovely shops too in the Arasta Bazaar behind the Blue Mosque.
So much to see and do. Almost all the popular tourist destinations are in this area. Plan to walk the streets to experience the shops, restaurants, sights, sounds, and smells of Istanbul.
Liked the area for its history. Be carful with Taxi drivers from Sultanahmet. they love ripping off tourists.

A journey back in history. Take the time to see the Mosques, Topkapi palace, the Cistern, and to wander along the Hippodrome...stop for a pomgranate juice...and then on to the Grand Bazaar and down to the Spice Bazaar...allow 2 days.
A Great experience. Well maintained and clean. An eye opener and a pleasure to walk through the district and absorve Turkish culture and hospitality
a sea of diversity. Everybody who offers to help you with directions is just trying to direct you to their carpet store. Still a lot of fun.
My favorite. I could walk for hours here. The streets are beautiful and fascinating. Just walk, or sit and people watch. The city will never cease to amaze, so dynamic.
Charming and close to everything.. We stayed at the Marmara Guesthouse in this District and loved every minute of it. Easy to walk to everything, included tram.

Lively and fun area! You can't go wrong!. Sultanahmet district is several streets of wonderful bars and restaurants. While we unfortunately didn't have time to try every one, I really don't think you can go wrong in this district!!!Make sure to ask to be seated on the rooftop- don't worry they'll provide blankets- and you can get a great view of the district and possibly even the Bhosphorous!

Interesting area. The Sultanahmet District is definitely "touristy" but there is a lot to do and see here. Just walking around the area is a great way to spend the day. There are many historic sites and great architecture to see and learn about. Because this is a high-tourist area there are lots of restaurants and shopping opportunities. If you are in Istanbul, you can't forget to make a stop in this area!
Everything is here but a waste about the service... Food, souveniers..everything is at Sultanahmet.. However, it's sad that the service is not good. There's only a couple of shops with good service.
Lots to do.. All the attractions afre within walking distance. Be carefull when you buy at the Grand Bazaar. Know your prices. They will rob you blind if you are not carefull.

The best place for a week-end stay.. We stayed in October 2011 and this area was by far the best for seeing the main sights and eating out.We felt safe the whole time and in general I would say it is the area of choice for a tourist.

The place to be. This is where 90% of what you want to see in Istanbul is located. Everywhere you look there's something to see and photograph as well as wonderful eateries. Make sure you book your hotel here and you'll rarely need transportation.
Great place to stay and explore. Easily walked neighborhood with shops and restaurants, the tram line. Close to tourism sites and great hotel, the Sultanhan hotel.
A must go area!. Sultan Ahmet -- local said it's the name of the King (Sultan = King) and the area is a must go place!
Wonder the streets of Sultanahmet.... Romantic, peaceful, safe, wonderful district. Sultanahmet makes Istanbul's Old City so memorable. Its a must to visit.

Old neighborhood with some of the major attractions.. High on a hill, the Sultanahmet district is awarded the distinguished presence of the 3 largest, most sumptuous and monumental attractions. In contrast, the supply of restaurants and hotels is not the greatest.

I so wanted to stay here.... but thanks to Trip Advisor all the hotels recommnded on the site (in fact, all hotels) were full. Don't arrive on the off-chance, especially if you hit town in a May or September weekend! That's their busy time.However, I spent several hours walking through the district. A mind-blowing assault on all the senses. You had to be there. Make sure you are, one of these days!
Both calm and busy. Easy to find the quiet places and easy to find the more busy ones. To many "fake" tourist shops.

Culture Shock. Turkey is quite westernized, but it is definitely positioned between eastern and western culture. It was great to be out of my comfort zone a bit and I thoroughly enjoyed exploring this area by foot. If you have to travel within Istanbul, do take the metro as with a population of 12.5 million, rush hour is permanent and traffic jams are horrendous.

this is where to stay. If you are going to Istanbul , you are going for a feel of the east. Stay in Sultanhamet and you will get that. It has a character and charm that is very different from any western european city I have ever visited.

Location, location, location. The only place to stay in Istanbul - perfect for all of the biggest cultural hotspots and easy to get to from the airport via the metro and tram. Best moment - hearing the prayers ring out throughout the city - magical.

The Only Place to Stay in Istanbul!. My first trip to Istanbul was in February of 2003. A Turkish friend recommended me to stay here, so I did. I found a Tour Operator before going on my trip (Istanbul was the transit city) and set up the hotel accommodations and tours. I wasn't disappointed whatsoever and fell in love with this city. I became engaged a year later and vowed to myself that I would take my wife to Istanbul and I did: February of 2007. We loved it and stayed 9 days. Sultan Ahmet is quiet during low-tourism seasons and very inexpensive. It has everything and is near everything. You really don't have to leave Sultan Ahmet and if you want a short vacation, it is perfect. I would go to Istanbul just to shop while earning a quick getaway. Taksim (great for shopping and eating) is a madhouse and if you are a foreigner, you'll get approached by con-artists and pimps. I recommend Sultan Ahmet to everyone and please see my post on hotel accommodations.

Must see. We visited several mosques but this is up there on the rank. Go early, it is amazing how many tourists pile up in 10 minutes as groups must wait to get in.The engineering from Sinan´s work, the famed architect of Turkey, on the columns are pretty amazing; the actual hand work is equally breathtaking.If I am not mistaken, this one is close to the Roman horse track and the Palace with the huge diamond and John the Baptist´s fore arm and skull remains... Must confirm.

simply amazing. You should just walk around here and be amazed by the wonderful mosques, topkapi palace and further down the grand and spice bazzar. You will get lost in the bazaars, but it makes it even more fun and you will certainly get a bargain, even if the ralph lauren logo sometimes looks a bit dodgy :-)

Sultanahmet - great for a couple of days.. An amazing district with lots of fascination and interest for several days. Even if you go nowhere else in Istanbul, you'll find plenty to do here. It's busy, lively and interesting. It doesn't matter that most of the food is over priced and relatively bland - at least for a couple of days. If you're staying longer - explore the rest of the city.

Attack Your Senses. That's about the only way to put it - from the Grand Bazaar to the Spice Market, with prayer calls in the background. It is a lively and exciting place with days of things to do and see all within walking distance. It's the only place for a tourist to stay while visiting Istanbul.

An experience. Liked: proximity of things. The tourist and local vibe. The great food and the 'let me help you spend your money' drive by the locals.Disliked: crazy driving. Be careful when crossing the roads.

Walk history. Enjoyed walking narow coble stone streats, visiting traditional craft shops, galleries. Good to stay all day, specially immpresive during night. Had immpresion to be in time machine and go back in the best day of Otoman empire.
old town. very walkable but the hawking street sales people were obnoctious.
The place to stay. Very pretty. The best place to stay as it is close yo all the major sites and has lots of bars, cafes and restaurants

Vibrant area with lots of history. We stayed in this area and it felt very safe and had a good feel to it. The streets were quite clean in comparison to other areas and we were within very easy reach of all the main attractions.

So much to see and do. This area of Istanbul is so easy to walk around. We spent four days here and didn't see everything! Walk along by the river for amazing 'fish sandwiches' and take a boat trip to see Sultanahmet District from a different perspective!
Sultanahment. The Hamman located there is fantastic superb experience, and the whole locale is a bit of a maze
Full of history. Full of interesting things and very friendly peopl, don't be afraid to ask questions, turkish people are very friendly

A great place for a night out. This is a very active area, especially in the evenings. The fresh seafood, lively music and freindly Turkish hospitality. Sit down, take your time, have some Raki (Turkish liquor), order maza (appetizers) and have a wonderful dinner. The sites and sounds are enchanting.

A must see in Istanbul.. This area is very historically rich full of old mosques, musuems, bazars, restaurants and many others! We stayed in a very nice hotel within the same neighborhood which I really recommend over the other districts in Istanbul.

GREAT place to visit, and to stay when in Istanbul. Around Sultanahmet* This is a great area to stay for sightseeing, you can walk to so many places and there’s a tram stop there, so you can easily get to a lot of other places.* Sites & activities in this area include: Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Basilica Cistern (don’t miss this, and a great stop when the weather outside is bad), sitting around the fountain in Sultanahmet Park, walking along the Hippodrome; Topkapi Palace; Istanbul Archeological Museums, lots of restaurants and shops, and more.* We stayed at the Hotel Poem & liked the hotel and the location (easy to get places, a view of the Bosphorus, and a rooftop sitting area). We also went for breakfast a couple times on the rooftop restaurant at the Seven Hills Hotel, which had a great view of Aya Sofya & the Blue mosque, especially in morning light.* For guys – have your hotel recommend a small barbershop in the area where you can get a haircut & a traditional Turkish shave (but be forewarned, if you agree to the warm wax on the ear it will hurt when they tear it away to remove the tiny hairs – you might want to pass on that part)Here are some trips from Sultanahmet to other spots – and there are a lot more things to do than listed here: - Hop on a ferry and just watch the sites.  - Hop on a ferry to one of the Princes’ Islands. We saw Büyükada, which was large enough to offer restaurants, hotels, horse & carriage, and lots of walking. We also saw Burgazada twice, which we liked for walking around, but it was smaller so offered less activities, I think most visitors would prefer Büyükada - We took a cab to Ortaoy, spent some time walking around, took a cab to Bebek, spent time there, and then took a ferry back down the Bosphorus (I think it stopped at Eminönü that time, but check a map to be sure).  - In Bebek look for a little ice cream shop (warm season only) that is take out only & a bit below sidewalk level (you stand on the sidewalk and they reach up to serve you), they had great sour cherry ice cream. We went back for it a second time in November, only to find out they are closed in the off season. - Istiklal St, a modern street with Taksim Square at one end. Lots of restaurants, coffee shops and stores. There’s an old fashioned looking tram that travels up and down the street if you just want to sit and watch. - Istanbul Modern, if you like modern art there’s lots to see here. You can get there by tram, get off at the Tophane stop. If you get on the tram that says “Kabatas” at the front you won’t have to switch trams.  - Grand Bazaar – a short walk or 1 tram stop from Sultanahmet - Spice Bazaar - Eminönü area, the Eminönü tram stop is about 3 stops from Sultanahmet area. In Eminönü you can get fresh grilled fish on a bun, walk along the Galata bridge, cross over to the Karaköy area (where you can get great Baklava & other sweets at Karaköy Güllüoğlu), or catch a ferry to Istanbul’s Asian side - Spend some time on the Asian side, check out Haydarpaşa train station, and walk around the markets a short walk from the ferry terminal. If the weather’s bad you can always hop on the old fashioned tram (Kadikoy-Moda tram) that does a loop of about 10-12 stops. One day we sat on it for 2 full loops until the rain passed.Other Tips* Get an Akbil and load it. The Akbil is an electronic fob that you preload with Lira and can use for getting on the tram, ferry, busses, funicular, metro and probably a few more things. Multiple people can share one Akbil & you can add more Lira as required. This will save you money & time. When you’re done with your Akbil you can return it for a refund, or pass it on to some other tourist.* For food recommendations check out the blog Istanbul Eats. They also offer food walking tours (but book these ahead, we missed out when we tried to book at the last minute) * We took cabs about 5 - 6 times in Istanbul. They were reasonably priced. – the only problem we had was one cabbie refused to turn on his meter and quoted us a price about 5 times what we expected to pay, so we made him stop as soon as we could, got out and refused to pay anything. We asked our hotel about what we should expect to pay for certain trips & the cabs drivers were always close to that range.* The customer service in Istanbul was better than any other country we’ve been to (Europe, North America, Australia & New Zealand, and a few other spots), I can’t imagine the shock Istanbul residents must have when they visit other countries. Enjoy.* People in Istanbul were genuinely friendly, and I don’t just mean the salespeople, if I was sitting on a park bench in Sultanahment someone would stop to visit. If I was loaded down with stuff on a tram, someone was quick to offer me a seat. This is an amazing city to visit.

walking in history. if you are looking for a place to give you the essence of ottoman and history , definitely Sultanahmet is the place . you can walk down the narrow streets or sit at one of the cafes for a Chay ( tea ) . but like every other tourist areas , here also you should be careful . museum and site's staffs and guards and police are good sources . but if you found some one too eager to help avoid him/her . if you feel like traveling to more modern parts , you can use the tram which is running through the old city and having station at most sites . in bazar you might find nice souvenirs but don't forget to haggle . to be honest i found better bargains at SIRKECI a neibourhood just next to Sultanahmet.

Magical - but get help from the right people. As a woman - don't speak to anyone you don't want to speak to. If you don't mind a chat and a cup of tea, answer those men who call out to you. They won't attack you or try to seduce you (not in the first 5 minutes, anyway! but they will try to take you to a shop/attraction where they get commission. A Turkish woman would never respond to a man who called out to her in the street, so just look straight ahead and keep walking if you're not in the mood. Staying in Sultanahmet, you can walk to all the most famous attractions, but they are better with a qualified guide. Private tours are best, and not even that expensive. We got ours from TurkeyTravelCentre .com - because we needed a private tour to account for our special needs child and our need to go slow and take breaks. They were amazing!!! We then booked the rest of our Turkey trip with them. One of their tips which we followed was - after you've seen the sights - get out of Sultanahmet!!! There's more to Istanbul than the museums and Blue Mosque. This city rocks, but you need to go up to Taksim and Istiklal street and the area around Tophane and Istanbul Modern to get the vibe. The nargile gardens in this area are the bomb! although alcohol-free.

This is THE place to stay in Istanbul. Especially if you are short on time in this wonderful city as all the key sights are within walking distance - the mosques, bazaars, restaurants etc. I won't cover the key sights as others have already mentioned all those. My tips are:You can use Euros here, but to get better value, do buy the local currency Turkish Lira.Do try and include a boat trip on the Bosphorus as well to complete your sightseeing of this city.Everyone in the Bazaars are friendly and nowhere near as harassing as other cities in the world. Yes, they will try and catch your interest, but a smile and a polite no thanks works fine. Feel free to chat to them, they are a friendly likeable bunch! And of course, you MUST haggle with a smile!A refreshing bottle of water in one of the traditional outdoor cafes is a very reasonable 1.5TL, so don't be shy on visiting these lovely outdoor cafes for a rest and a cold drink. We also stopped at an outdoor cafe for a shish kebab lunch with salad for 10TL each - and it tasted great. Most of the locals speak some English.We loved Istanbul and can't wait to return.

The historical district of Istanbul - Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet is the historical district of Istanbul and it's where you'll find most of the popular tourist highlights -- the blue mosque, the german fountain beside it, hagia sophia on the other side, the big fountain in between, the sunken basilica beside the hagia sofia, topkapi palace and the archeological museum down the road, egyptian bazaar in sirkeci, the yeni camii beside it, grand bazaar 2 tram stations away -- it's all there. Most first-time visitors prefer to stay in the area especially if they have little time to spare. The tram is useful if you hate to walk, restaurantsd are plenty and so are cheap eats and outdoor cafe, several souvenir and carpet shops. You'll never run out of things to do, hotels to stay, and people to meet in this remarkable district of an amazing city.

Historic and gives you the real feel of Istanbul. We were fortunate enough to stay in the Sultanahmet and could walk to all the attractions. Istanbul, Constantinople, Byzantium, whatever you call it, you soak up the atmosphere and heart of this great city in the Sultanahmet - the old city.

If staying here no need to book City Tours. This is quite a historical district which is close to most of the sights which are covered in the conducted city tours. They are a bit of a rip off like the half day ones costing around Euro 35 & taking you to Rustam Pasha Mosque (free entry except during prayers when its closed) & Topkapi Palace( ok you donot stand in the ticket que but are you ready to spend that much for this little). Invest in the audio guide instead much better experience as the guide gives you the outline & disappears. Not really but he doesnot accompany you inside but waits in the lawns. My suggestion would be that you visit busy places like the Topkapi early in the day they open by 0900 hrs if I am not wrong & avoid weekends or school holidays. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia(Ayasofia), Grand Bazar, Cistern are also close byOnly the whole day tour which takes you inside Dolma Bache palace is worthwhile, but donot chose the half day one as you could do the cruise only (1 hr 30 mins on the boat) much cheaper by doing from Kardikoy near Eminnou station.For people not wanting to walk there is a convenient tram which moves from Kabatas & is only 1.75 YTL per person. It connects with Taksim via the funicular, so you have most of the city at your disposal.But like most cities with history,culture, architecture, interesting people this is best done on feet. Lovely places to eat specially near the Egyptian/Spice bazar area, good for people watching, Bosphorous etc. Only word of caution is being crowded be a little careful of your belongings & check the prices on the menu before sitting down in the resturants as the ushers could be a little too pushy for comfort.

Close to all of the major attractions. This area is so close to all of the main attractions, it is where you probably should stay if you are here for just 3 or 4 days. It is easy to get your bearings and navigate on foot.

SOLO FEMALE TRAVELLER. Sultanahmet is a very historic area and it oozes appeal. There are a great many negative reviews of Sultanahmet. However, even though I had some minor irritants as a solo female traveller but I'd say the beauty of the place outweights any annoying instance you may suffer. If you dress up (Jeans and lose covering top) and ignore the aggressive sales pitch and the occasional catcall you'd be ok.oure a solo female traveller, I would advise staying in the hotel after 9 pm. You can start the day early at 7 am and make the most of your trip.The shopkeepers and staff of Sultanahmet are the worst of Turks. Dont let them color your opinion. I found ordinary Turks decent and respectful.

Crowded, lively, fun. This is where everything happens. Where the most amount of museums, must see places, hotels and restaurants are. It's packed with tourists, everywhere but also locals. We had read many bad things about incidents happening in this area with shoe shinners, carpet sellers, etc but I have to say that I found it really nice; and the only annoying thing was the waiters trying to get you in their restaurants; if you dont mind saying no every 30 seconds, you are going to be fine. Very old area, with literally a million hotels, quite dirty at some points, messy, crazy traffic and with those horrible un-even stoned pavement that makes it impossible to wear heels and a challenge to walk without looking at the floor at all times.But it's got its charm. We were there during Ramadam and by the time the sun went down, a million outdoor parties started to celebrate it, and to eat; it gave us a chance to see something different. At night it's amazing with all the monuments and mosques lit, beaufitul, charming and very very special.Line 1 of the tram covers almost the whole area and it doesn't have as many hills as the other sides of the city (eventhough it does have some that are quite impressive).This is the area where we had dinner everynight and we certainly enjoyed it, each and everytime; we went to every single Sirkeci hotels branch restaurants and appart from the great breathtaking views, the food was simply amazing everytime and at a very reasonable price (we were adviced of these restaurants beforehand) and also a couple others around the area and we just had been told about the overpriced, tourist intended restaurants and avoided them, so simple, worked out perfectly for us. Ibni Kemal cadessi is great for food, and had a lovely atmosphere at night. Also does Ticarethane Sk, beautiful street packed with lovely restaurants. We didn't encounter any problems, no safety issues, we just took the same precautions we take when in London, Paris or NY.I wouldn't stay anywhere else in the city next time we go, and you bet we will, we loved it.
