the historical district of istanbul. sultanahmet is where you will find all the popular sights of istanbul. there are lots of it in other areas but the most popular ones in many travel books and sites can be found in this district - the blue mosque, hagia sofia, the hippodrome and it's obelisks, topkapi palace, sunken basilica, and the museums.10 minutes up the road is the grand bazaar and same distance down the road is the spice bazaar beside the new mosque.sultanahmet is the first place to explore upon landing in istanbul. great sights, good food, friendly people.

Great area to stay in. This is the part of Istanbul where most of the tourist sites are located and so it is a great area to stay in. We stayed 4 nights in a great place a couple of blocks from Hagia Sophia. It is a tourist area, so things can certainly be overpriced. Bu,t we were able to find good reasonably priced food to eat. The shop keepers, especially restaurants and carpet sellers, are aggressive, but we quickly got use to them and found that they were basically very friendly.

Watch out where you eat. You need to watch out when eating at this section of Istanbul. Well there are some good restaurants, most are far overpriced, and many engage in outright scams to get you to overpay. Your far better off getting out of the tourist areas. You will get far better food at a much better price .

Practical Tips to Visit SultanAhmet, Istanbul. We spent more than 7 days visiting Istanbul and we stayed in Garden House, a nice hotel in SultanAhmet area. This was our first visit. We are a family of 6 with small children, but the outstanding transportaion system and local help made our visits to different parts of the city easy & enjoyable. We did not have to take any guided tour. As such we were relaxed, felt the culture, spent as much time we needed in places we selected, and visited at our convenience and timing. We ate at different places and food was excellent. Few tips: Change your currency in shops. We got 1.92 TRY for 1 Euro (July 2008). In the money exchange places, the exchange is more like 1.80 TRY for 1 Euro.Always carry TRY for ticket purchases, entrance fees, etc. They may not convert other currencies.Avoid Taxi if you can, although Taxi is very frequent and convenient. Public transportation system is great - from train to bus to ferry. If you take taxis, please ensure that when you pay, you don't get distracted by the driver. Give the driver exact change - if possible, in front of others (like other members of your family). I don't want to sound paranoid, but my friend was cheated twice. He gave the driver 50 TRY and the driver distracted him and then produces a note of 5 TRY saying that is what he gave him! So watch out for such tricky practices. In general, people are extremely friendly, nice, smiling, and helpful. Food is great but if you crave for Chinese, Indian, etc., those are hard to find. Be satisfied with local food, Turkish Kebabs and Showarma, fresh bread, and fruits, they are delicious.Taking pictures are allowed in all places. Some restriction is Topkapi museum. Some places do not allow flash (like archeological museum). Some places are not open every day of the week. Check before you make your schedule.Here is a partial itinerary that we followed:1. Day-1 Evening: Blue Mosque(walking)2. Day-2 Ayasofya & Topkapi (walking)3. Day-3 Bosphorus tour: Take tram from SultanAhmet and go to Eminonu (1.4 TRY per person). Cross the stree toward the sea and take a left and go down until the bridge. The pier will be BOGAZ ISKELESI. You can buy a round trip ticket to Anadolu Kacagi (17.5 TRY). It takes about 2 hours to reach (with several stops in between, but you don't get down). You get down and find numerous restaurants around. You can just walk in one of the streets toward the hills that will take you to Genoese Castle (in about 20 minutes, uphill walk) from where you can also see the Bosphorus, Black, sea etc. You will also find a good place to eat prior to reaching the top. Once you return, you can also have lunch at one of the restaurants.4. Day-4 Basillica Underground Cistern (1001 columns water reservoir) and Sultan Eyup (Mosque of Abu Ayub Al Ansari, companion of prophet Muhammed, pbuh): Go toward SultanAhmet tram station and the underground cistern is right at the corner across Ayasofia. Entrance is 10 TYR. Eminonu and take a bus (99A) that will take you to Eyup city (about 30 minutes ride). Bus charge similar to tram, 1.4 TRY per person. They are frequent, nice, and you can always find seats. As you go, you can also have a glance at the city walls on your left. When you get down in Eyup on the right side of the highway, you will find several restaurants, shops, go right through the area and the mosque is about 2 minutes from the bus stop. There is the mosque and the shrine. Pictures are all allowed even with flash and video. It is a beautiful place. Catch the same bus from the other side of the street to return to Eminonu.5. Day-5 Dolmabahce, Galata Tower: both are on the other side of Golden Horn water. Take the tram and get down at the end of the route (Kabatas). Again, it will be 1.4 TYR per person. Get down and follow the same direction on the sidewalk on the right next to water. You will reach Dolmabahce in about 5 minutes.Return by tram up to Karakoy (Galata Tower). Get out of tram and on one of the street corners, it is written TUNEL. Enter and there is an underground train (0.9 TYR each). This train has only one stop, i.e., near Galata tower. Get down from this train, come to the street, walk, and take a right (in 1/2 minute) and continue on this travelling downhill for about 10 minutes. Then take a right and you will see the Galata Tower. You can go to the top floor for 10 TYR per person. You can see the whole Istanbul from the tower.Coming back, go to the underground train and come to Karakoy and take the tram to return to SultanAhmet.Day-6: Archeological Museum (SultanAhmet), Uskudar (Asian Side), and Beylerbeyi Palace: You should visit the museum, just follow the tram line from SultanAhmet and you will arrive in 3/4 minutes. Then you can take the tram (or walk) to Eminonu, and take the ferry from Uskudar Iskelesi to Uskudar. This is a small place on the asian side. You can catch a local bus to go to Beylerbeyi Palace (right under the suspension bridge). Return to Uskudar by bus and take ferry to come back to Eminonu. The bus stops may be tricky so please watch out so that you don't miss the place where you want to get down.Day-7: Chora Museum (also known as Kariye church), Grand Bazar, Beyazit mosque, and City Walls: Take tram from SultanAhmet in the direction opposite to Eminonu and get down at Beyazit (second stop). You can visit the Grand Bazar (at the stop) and the beautiful Beyazit mosque on your right. Next to Beyazit mosque is Istanbul University and the terrace in between is huge and nice. Grand Bazar prices are high and lots of bargaining take place, so be careful. From Beyazit, take a bus (I guess #85C) that takes you straight to Kariye. Get down, follow the same direction of the bus and take immediate right. Walk for another 5 minutes and on the right is the Chora Museum. As you come out using the same way you took to go there, but then go toward the main street on your right and you will find the city walls (also on your right - no need to go to the other side of street). The old walls are still there with some part being renovated.You can always squeeze in many other places, like the spice bazar, Taksim squre (you can go from Dolmabahce to Taksim and then to Galata tower), other shopping places and mosques, etc. Just walking along the streets are great and you can view so much of old structure and architecture.We went in July and the temperature was around 85 degrees F during the middle of the day. It was very nice. No rain except when we climed up the mountain for Genoese castle (Bosphorus trip). IT rained heavily for 30 minutes and then there was beautiful sunshine.Thanks and enjoy your trip!!

Surviving Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet is an enchanting location. Very old, very interesting.Walking everywhere is ideal and seemed to be safe. Most things are close. The public transportation is also easy. Most of all, take the time to really enjoy the surroundings, the buildings and the people.Do allow plenty of time in the Grand Bazaar. Bargain like crazy.And the restaurants in the Grand Bazaar have very good food.I ate in the Davidoff and had the very best pizza I've ever eaten!Yeah,,,I know....crazy to order pizza in Istanbul, but I wasn't feeling well and wanted food that I recognized.Take the Bosphorus tour. You can see the entire area and you get a chance to relax.I did not enjoy "Istiklal Caddesi." Busy, commercial street. Not quaint as indicated in the guide books. Tawdry shops, a few eateries, Best attraction was the window with the ice cream vendor.Also at the lower end of the street, you will find yourself at the Galata Tower. Nice observation deck.1. Annoying carpet salesmen are a fact of life. Do not make eye contact, keep on walking if you are not interested.The Turkish say 'no' by quietly uttering a sound like "tsssst!" and throwing their head upward just a bit, raised eyebrows. I found this worked wonderfully!!!! even with the cats that are plentiful!2. Beware of any person that takes an interest in you. They are salesmen. They ask if they can help you find your way; or they ask where you are from; then they ask where you are staying! And worst of all, rather than helping you find your way, they try to lead you to their uncle's carpet shop! (they get a commission!)3.. Wear very comfy shoes. The stairs/steps are very uneven and the streets are cobblestone. As a 60something, I did not even wear my sandals so as to not snag the toe in the very rough cobblestone streets.4. If you find your hotel unsuitable, change. There are many. We moved directly across the street to much better accommodations.5. Take your own scarf for your head to enter the mosques. Shorts are inappropriate in the mosques as are sleeveless tops. They will loan you a cape to wear (that everyone else has worn).6. There is a very nice patio restaurant behind the Yesil Ev hotel.In the garden passageway to that patio restaurant, look to the left and see a stairway downward (it is the lowest level of the hotel)...there are very clean free restrooms at the bottom of the stairs. The Yesil Ev is centrally located and easy to see. It is a light green building, directly behind the Dirvish Cafe, which is sort of between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia.7. If you use a taxi, make certain of the cost before you get in. Ask several. Flat rates vary. The very best is finding ones strictly charge what is on their meter. If you are going to the airport, ask your hotel for a taxi with a good rate. If you have a lot of luggage like we did(a month), a "car" rather than a taxi is available and not costly.8. Most of all.......HAVE FUN!
